Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nAll your friends are youths in jeans (ゆうじん)! Every single one. If any of your friends is not a youth in jeans, they're simply not your friend, I'm afraid.
141 | 毛 | け | Fur | Hair | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nLook down! You're holding something covered in fur. It's a furry kettle (け)! It's the weirdest kettle you've ever seen, but presumably it keeps the water hot for much longer.
142 | 少女 | しょうじょ | Girl | Young Girl | A little woman is a girl.\n少女 is a relatively formal word that's often used in writing to describe a young girl, usually between childhood and adolescence (or between the ages of about five and eighteen). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
143 | 半分 | はんぶん | Half |  | You have half a part. Half a part is still half, right? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
144 | 半 | はん | Half |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!
145 | 心 | こころ | Heart | Mind\n Feeling | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nImagine a giant heart sitting in a rowing boat. It's also drinking cocoa. Focus on all three of these parts and associate them into one story / memory. Once you've done that, sing the "cocoa row" (こころ) song! I don't know what that song is, but I want you to make one up and actually sing it, out loud. If you do, I bet you won't forget this word's reading too easily.
146 | こんにちは | こんにちは | Hello | Good afternoon | Connie Chihuahua (こんにちは) says hello. Connie Chihuahua is an amazing talking chihuahua. She can only say "hello", but that alone is pretty impressive.\nこんにちは is a formal way to say "hello". It’s generally used during the daytime, from late morning to early evening. Watch out for the は on the end, which is always pronounced わ.
147 | 大切 | たいせつ | Important | Precious\n Valuable | Think back to the old old olden days. Back when decisions were made with swords. A big cut is going to be important. Just imagine a couple samurai squaring off, then charging, then making one big cut. It's the most important thing they'll do in their lives (if they live!). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nIt's extremely important to keep your ties in sets (たいせつ). If you don't arrange them neatly in sets, the tie police might just come knocking at your door and take you with them!
148 | 内 | うち | Inside | Within | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nWhen this kanji is a word on its own, it's actually very often written in hiragana. Still, the kanji version of the word is worth knowing, too! \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThere's something inside and you wanna get to what's within. Look inside. Ooh, cheese (うち)! Your favorite. Ooh cheese, how I love you.
149 | 戸 | と | Japanese Style Door | Door | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
150 | ビー玉 | びーだま | Marble |  | When you see a katakana word, it's a safe bet that it is a foreign loan word from somewhere else. This one's interesting, because it combines katakana and kanji! The first marble came to Japan from Portugal, so the ビー part of the word is short for "vidro," which means "glass" in Portuguese. Anyway, don't get thrown off by that ビー. Maybe just imagine that your favorite marble is black and yellow like a bee. \n If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji 玉, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.
151 | 母 | はは | Mother | Mom | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is the polite and humble form of mother. You use this when you're talking about your own mother to other people, especially if you aren't very close to them. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just remember, your mother is a terrible person and won't stop laughing at you: "HA HA HA HA HA!"
152 | お母さん | おかあさん | Mother | Mom | This word starts with お which makes it more polite. Then, there's the kanji 母 which you know means mother. Last, there's the honorific さん which further adds respect (to the mother). So, this is the nice way to say mother. You use it when you're talking to your own mom or talking about her with friends. You can also use this when you're talking about your friends' moms.\nIf you need to talk about someone's mother that you don't really know, or you aren't close to, you'll want to use お母様, instead. Don't worry, you'll learn that last kanji in a few lessons. Until then, it's pronounced, おかあさま. Kay? \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You have to remember the かあ portion. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it:\nWhat does your super nice mother do for you (this is why you're so polite to her!)? She drives you all around in her car (かあ) taking you wherever you need to go... soccer, kendo, whatever. What a nice mother you have!
153 | 市立 | しりつ | Municipal | City | The city stand is municipal in nature. Municipal means "of or relating to a city or its governing body", and this vocabulary means just that. Or just city. City is fine too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
154 | 北 | きた | North |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou're going to the far north where it's very cold (north pole, perhaps?). One of the most important things you bring with you is a survival kit (きた).
155 | 今 | いま | Now |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nWhat'll you drink now? I'll have a Zima, ima.\nSay "ZIMA IMA" ten times fast.
156 | 〜人 | にん | Number Of People | People\n Counter For People | When you see this on a number, for example ７人 or ３人, you're using it to count people. Just remember, both 一人 and 二人 have alternative readings. From 3 and up it's just the number plus にん, like this. ５人 is ごにん, １０人 is じゅうにん, etc. This is the counter for people, which makes this word the number of people. \n This is a counter, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nJust think of the sheer number of people at Nintendo (にん). It must be huge. This really is just a counter for people that work at Nintendo.
157 | 大人しい | おとなしい | Obedient | Quiet\n Calm | Remember how you learned that 大人 means "adult?" Well this is the adjective version of that. The I-adjective (see how it ends in い?). What adjective do adults want to be able to use for their own kids? They want to say they are obedient, quiet kids! \n You already learned this reading when you learned 大人! You should be able to read this too!
158 | 古い | ふるい | Old | Ancient\n Out-Of-Date | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of old? It's also old, ancient, or out-of-date.\nThis word is used for things like clothes, food and friendships, but not for people! So a 古い友人 (old friend) is someone you've been friends with for a long time, not an elderly friend. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word:\nIf you're old, you're also full (ふる) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.
159 | 十万 | じゅうまん | One Hundred Thousand | Hundred Thousand | Ten ten thousands is equal to one hundred thousand. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
160 | 一台 | いちだい | One Machine |  | As long as you know the two kanji that make up this word, you should be able to figure out the meaning of this word as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
161 | 人生 | じんせい | One's Life | Human Life\n Life | The kanji for person and life combined makes you think about human life. What is your human life like? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 and 生 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour life boils down to just two things: jeans and a saber (じんせい). Your whole life, that's all you've ever needed, jeans and a saber. What are you, some kind of American pirate?
162 | テーブルの上 | てーぶるのうえ | On The Table | Tabletop | First we have a katakana word, so it's safe to assume that it's a loan word. Like many loan words, it comes from English. Say it out loud and what do you have? That's right, "table". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally we have 上, which you learned means "up" or "above". Put all of these pieces together and we have a phrase meaning on the table or tabletop! \n In this phrase, 上 is a standalone word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary. Easy to stay on top of that one, right?
163 | 外 | そと | Outside |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou look outside, it's totally frozen. You throw salt (そと) outside to melt the ice.
164 | 分 | ぶん | Part | Portion\n Content | This word has the same meaning that you learned with the kanji: part, or portion. By extension, it can also mean content, as in "alcohol content" because that's the portion of alcohol in a drink.\nThis word is used for fractions, too, as in one third or one quarter. Again, you can see how this links to "parts" and "portions", right? \n This word is usually combined with a word or phrase indicating whose part or portion you’re referring to. That’s probably why this single kanji vocab word uses the on’yomi instead of the kun’yomi reading. Check out the common word combinations to see what we’re talking about!\nAnd when it means part or portion, it's read ぶん. Probably because your buns come in two parts. Ohoho.
165 | シアトル市 | しあとるし | Seattle | City Of Seattle | The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a 市 attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). So this word means Seattle, or more specifically City of Seattle. \n This word uses on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji.
166 | 中古 | ちゅうこ | Secondhand | Used | The combination of kanji doesn't make perfect sense, but it's alright. Take something that's middle old and you have something that's used or secondhand. It's not 100% old yet... it's still in the middle, meaning you can give it to someone else to use, like your younger siblings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
167 | 日の出 | ひので | Sunrise |  | What do we call the sun's exit from the horizon? That'll be the sunrise. Imagine the sun exiting the horizon and climbing up into the sky. \n This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!
168 | 中止 | ちゅうし | Suspension | Cancellation\n Discontinuation | When something is in the middle of an action but it's stopped, this means it's put into suspension. Imagine getting frozen while you're running. It's kind of like that. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
169 | 用 | よう | Task | Use\n Duty\n Service\n Business\n Purpose | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This one uses the on'yomi reading, which you've learned from the kanji already!
170 | 十台 | じゅうだい | Ten Machines |  | If you know the two kanji separately, you should be able to put them together to form the meaning of this kanji. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
171 | 一万 | いちまん | Ten Thousand |  | When you have one ten thousand you just have ten thousand. In Japanese, though, you specify how many ten thousands you have, though (which is weird in English, but should make sense if you think about it). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
172 | 万 | まん | Ten Thousand |  | When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's ten thousand! \n When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!
173 | 今月 | こんげつ | This Month | Current Month | The now month is actually this month. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nOnly this month, your pet condor gets (こんげつ) to sleep in your bed. You usually keep it in a cage, but once a year, you make an exception. And that's this month. How cute!
174 | これ | これ | This One | These Ones | Collect (これ) this one right here! Go ahead, collect this one.\nYou can use これ to talk about anything that's close to you. Things that are close to you are easy to collect, after all!
175 | 生まれる | うまれる | To Be Born |  | Since this is a kanji with hiragana attached that ends with an う sound, you know that this word is a verb. What's the ultimate verb version of the kanji 生? That would be to be born, the very beginning of life as we know it! \n You have to remember the う part of this word to read it. To remember that, let's use a mnemonic:\nSomething is about to be born, and when you lean in for a closer look… it’s an uni (う). Yes, a sea urchin. You weren’t expecting that. Close your eyes and imagine what the process of an uni being born might look like, to help you remember this reading.
176 | 切る | きる | To Cut |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut, and the verb form of that is to cut. \n When you think to cut something, what do you think about cutting? One thing is cutting down a tree, which is also known as 木, or き. You きる a き.
177 | 今日 | きょう | Today |  | The now day is what day? Oh, it's today. \n The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work.\nYou have to work in one of those mall kiosks (きょう). Just think about how sad you are that you have to do this today. What a crummy day. It's sunny outside and you're stuck in a mall manning this hermit crab kiosk.\nNote: This reading mnemonic is pretty far away from the actual reading, as far as reading mnemonics go. Use this to get yourself close, and then use your own brain grapes to get the rest of the way there. This one won't be as easy as most of the others, but do some good old fashioned memorization and you should be okay. I won't ask you to do this much, fortunately. :)
178 | する | する | To Do |  | It's only through (する) doing things that we get better at them, so you need to do them as much as you can.\nする basically means to do, but it’s incredibly versatile and goes beyond its English equivalent. Besides being used alone, it can be put together with a whole range of nouns to turn them into verbs. We call these する verbs and you'll learn a lot of them as we go along!
179 | 太る | ふとる | To Get Fat | To Gain Weight\n To Grow Fat\n To Become Fat | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fat so the verb form of that is to get fat. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have to learn the ふと portion of this word to be able to read it. Here'a mnemonic to help you:\nIt's easy to get fat if you're always in your futon (ふと).
180 | 引く | ひく | To Pull | To Withdraw | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull and the verb version vocab means to pull.\nThis word can be transitive or intransitive. You use 引く in a transitive way to say you pull something, for example. But it can also mean to withdraw when you talk about things that pull back, like water that recedes, pain that subsides, soldiers that withdraw, or even your body recoiling when something puts you off. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading (ひ) is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!
181 | 広げる | ひろげる | To Spread Something | To Unfold Something\n To Open Something Up | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means wide, and the verb version is what happens when you try to make something wider. How do you make something wider? That's right, you have to spread something, to unfold something or to open something up. All of those actions will make a thing wider!\nThis is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You spread something. Like a newspaper, or a cloth on a table. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder mnemonic to help you:\nYou are going to spread something. What are you going to spread? How about your arms, so that you can fly into the sky like the super hero (ひろ) that you are! Most heroes can fly when they spread their arms wide!
182 | 止める | とめる | To Stop Something | To Prevent Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stop and the verb vocab version of that is to stop something.\nThis particular word is when you're stopping something (i.e. doing the action of stopping it). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to stop something from moving. Maybe a car... or a door... or a person... whatever you want. To stop this thing, you throw out your toe (と), getting it smashed in the process. Imagine it bleeding and swelling up. How much it hurts! You put your toe out to stop this big thing, what a mistake!
183 | 用いる | もちいる | To Utilize | To Use | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task or use. You can think of this verb as a more formal way to say to use, and that is to utilize. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to learn the もち portion of もちいる:\nWhat will you utilize to get the job done? You have mochi (もち) in your hand, so you'll use that. Now go think of some kind of imaginary task you'll complete with mochi, making it as ridiculous as possible.
184 | 二万 | にまん | Twenty Thousand |  | When you have two ten thousands, you have twenty thousand. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
185 | 二台 | にだい | Two Machines |  | When you combine these two kanji, you should be able to see how it forms the word two machines. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
186 | ベッドの下 | べっどのした | Under The Bed | Below The Bed\n Beneath The Bed | This starts with another katakana word, so you can assume that it's a loan word. This one also comes from English. Can you figure out what it means? That's right, "bed". Then comes the particle の, which joins two nouns together. Finally, we have 下, which you learned means "down" or "below". Put these elements together and you get below the bed, under the bed or beneath the bed. What's under your bed? \n 下 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
187 | 方 | かた | Way | Direction | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but it can be either that or the on'yomi reading, depending on the context. You haven't learned the kun'yomi reading for 方 yet, so there's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to go a certain direction. How do you get there? By jumping into a catapult (かた) and shooting yourself the right way. Need to get a particular direction fast? Consider the catapult next time.
188 | いつ | いつ | When |  | He eats (いつ) and eats and eats. When does this guy not eat?\nいつ is a question word that is used to ask when.
189 | 広い | ひろい | Wide | Spacious | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wide? It's also wide. \n The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned in the kanji section: ひろ, making this ひろい.
190 | 冬 | ふゆ | Winter |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the kun'yomi reading you learned for the kanji, meaning you should know both!
191 | 女の人 | おんなのひと | Woman |  | A woman person is a woman.\nThe の particle here means the first noun is modifying the second one, so you can probably see why 女の人 (a woman person) really just means woman! It's more polite than saying 女 by itself, so that's all you have to remember. \n This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 1 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
192 | 他人 | たにん | Another Person | Other People\n Stranger | When you have an other person, you really have another person.\n他人 has a sense of unfamiliarity or distance, and suggests that the person isn’t well-known, or is different from you or a specific group of people. It doesn't usually mean "another person" in the sense of an additional person, or another person distinct from the one you’re talking about. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nAnother person just stole your taco and your Nintendo (たにん). This complete stranger just walked up and took your taco and your Nintendo console straight out of your hands. Yoink.
193 | 早々 | そうそう | As Soon As | Just After\n Immediately After\n Quickly\n Early | Essentially you have the kanji 早 twice, because 々 is just a repeater kanji. When you have something early twice, it obviously has some kind of urgency to it. You'll need to take an action as soon as you finish whatever it is you're doing there. \n The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.
194 | 大気 | たいき | Atmosphere |  | If there is a big energy it's going to fill up the atmosphere! Think about big energies you feel in the atmosphere: thunderstorms, tornadoes, the aurora borealis. Just remember, this is the atmosphere in the sky, not the atmosphere in a fancy restaurant. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nImagine an atmosphere consisting entirely of ties and keys (たいき), floating around. The ties are getting tangled together, and the keys keep bashing you on the head. Bring back the normal atmosphere, this one's horrible.
195 | 赤ちゃん | あかちゃん | Baby |  | ちゃん is the honorific you put on a child's name. So, who is this mysterious child you're calling red? When a baby is born, what color are they? You got it, they're all red. And, because you want to be nice and cute you add ちゃん to that. That's why あかちゃん is a baby. \n If you know the reading of the kanji 赤 you should know the reading of this too.
196 | 竹 | たけ | Bamboo |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well! \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you associated with the kanji, earlier.
197 | 竹の子 | たけのこ | Bamboo Shoot | Bamboo Sprout | What is bamboo’s child? That would be a baby bamboo. Because "baby bamboo" doesn't really make sense, we'll instead call this word bamboo shoots.\nWhen this is written as 竹の子, the bamboo shoots are probably still growing in the ground. If they’re picked and cooked and ready to eat, the pronunciation is the same, but it’s usually written in other forms, such as タケノコ. \n If you know the readings of the kanji for 竹 and the vocabulary for 子 you should be able to read this word as well.
198 | 少年 | しょうねん | Boy | Young Boy\n Youth | Someone of few years is someone who's young. Since we already have 少女 for girls, 少年 means boy.\n少年 is a bit of a formal term that often refers to a young boy, usually between childhood and adolescence, or sometimes to a youth in general. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
199 | 虫 | むし | Bug | Insect\n Creepy Crawly | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is actually more general than the English words insect and bug, though. It covers things like worms and spiders, too, so in that sense it's more like creepy-crawly. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, which is also the reading you learned when you learned this kanji!
200 | 年内 | ねんない | By The End Of The Year | Before The End Of This Year\n Within The Year | Inside the year means by the end of the year. In other words, before the end of this year, or within the year. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
201 | 子牛 | こうし | Calf | Baby Cow | You have a child cow. What do you think a child cow is? Probably a calf or a baby cow. \n Since you should know the readings of the words 子 and 牛 from the previous level, you should be able to read this word too even though it's using the kun'yomi readings for the kanji.
202 | 平気 | へいき | Calm | Cool\n All Right\n Okay | You have a flat energy. What kind of energy would be a flat one? Probably a cool or calm one. You'd also tell people about this flat energy by saying you are all right or just okay. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
203 | 車 | くるま | Car |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou visit your mom who lives inside of a car. It's sad, and you feel bad. The first thing that pops out of your mouth is: "Cool Room, Ma (くるま) because you don't know what else to say about your ma's living situation.\nBe sure to sort of cut off the last letters of the first two words... something like "coo' roo' ma!" Sad thing is, there is only one room in this car your mom calls home.
204 | 中央 | ちゅうおう | Center | Central\n Centre | The middle of the central... that is really, really in the center if you ask me (and is very central as well). This is one of those "overdid it on the meaning" words. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
205 | 耳 | みみ | Ear | Ears | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji. So you should be able to read this word already.
206 | 早い | はやい | Early | Fast\n Quick | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of early? It's also early. \n The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn when you learned the kanji. You have to remember the はや portion to be able to read this word. In order to do that, here's a mnemonic:\nYou're fast! You're early! Your chop comes down onto your opponent's neck so quickly! As you chop him, you yell "はや!"
207 | 元気 | げんき | Energy | Health\n Energetic\n Healthy | What is the origin of your energy? It is your health. This word also means energy, and when it's used as an adjective it means healthy or energetic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
208 | 名人 | めいじん | Expert | Master | A person whose name is known (because he's famous?). Why is this person's name known? Why is this person famous? It's because they are an expert / master at something. How else does someone become famous or well-known? That's pretty much it, even if they're just an expert at being an idiot. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nDid you know that every expert has their own pair of May jeans (めいじん)? A true master of anything has a specific pair of jeans they wear only in the month of May. That's what makes them so good at what they do.
209 | 気分 | きぶん | Feeling | Mood | Part of your energy is your feeling or your mood. Just think of it like you're breaking up your energy into parts. One part is sugar giving you energy. Another part is your happiness. So, when you combine these together you get the total: your mood! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
210 | 花火 | はなび | Fireworks |  | The flower fire... what looks like flowers on fire? That would be fireworks. Totally makes sense, right? \n The readings for the kanji that make this word are the kun'yomi readings, where fire's ひ changes to び. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for 花 when you learned the kanji, so it's only a matter of remembering to use the kun'yomi for 火. If you do, you should be able to read this word.
211 | 先ず | まず | First Of All | To Start With\n Firstly\n To Begin With | The kanji means previous. This is an adverb version of that word. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with. You can't start your sentences with "previous" but you can start it with "First of all" or "to start with."\nThis is usually written without kanji though, so keep that in mind. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. In fact, the reading for this word is very rare, and kind of an exception. We'll use a mnemonic that uses both the kanji part and the hiragana attachment part.\nFirst of all and to start with, you have to make it through this maze (まず).
212 | 一年生 | いちねんせい | First Year Student |  | You'd maybe think this just means one year of life, but it actually means first year student. A second year student is a 二年生, and so on. Just think about how crazy the Japanese are about school. You can see why school is life, and not life itself, making this vocab word "first year student." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
213 | 五百 | ごひゃく | Five Hundred |  | When you have five hundreds you also have five hundred. \n This word uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
214 | 平ら | たいら | Flat |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same with a little hiragana sticking out. Because the hiragana doesn't really indicate what it is, it's okay to assume that they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a kanji plus some hiragana attached, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nSomething is very, very flat. Perhaps someone who doesn't eat much, like a model? Which model? Let's imagine it's Tyra (たいら) Banks.
215 | 花 | はな | Flower |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned when you learned the kanji, so you're good to go. Don't forget to stop and smell the roses on the way, though.
216 | 足 | あし | Foot | Leg | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. A foot is a foot, you know? \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nIf you remember in the radical/kanji mnemonic, you kick someone with your foot. But what happens after you kick them? Turns out they were made of fire, and you just burned your foot off, turning it to ashes (あし). Imagine this happening.
217 | 四十 | よんじゅう | Forty |  | What do you get when you have four tens? You get forty. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The only exception to this is 四, which uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death." Luckily you know these reading already, so there's nothing new to learn!
218 | 四百 | よんひゃく | Four Hundred |  | When you have four hundreds, you have four hundred. \n This word has number four in it, and uses the kun'yomi reading for that kanji (よん). The reading for 百 though, is the on'yomi reading (ひゃく). This is pretty normal when it comes to words containing four in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!
219 | 四日 | よっか | Fourth Day | Day Four\n Four Days | Fourth day or day four. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, is an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 四, so that's fine (the ん gets turned into a small っ, though). Think of it this way:\nOn the fourth day of being lost in the wilderness, you start yelling "Yo, car (よっか)!" out of desperation, never getting an answer. You keep marching on, occasionally yelling "Yo, car!", but no car ever comes to help you.
220 | 四つ | よっつ | Four Things |  | Any number with a つ attached is a word that means "NUMBER Things." In this case, it's four things. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can assume it uses the kun'yomi reading. The ん part of よん gets converted to a small っ though, so watch out for that.
221 | 四千 | よんせん | Four Thousand |  | You have four and you have thousand. Multiply them together and you have four thousand. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's true for the 千 part, but the 四 reading is kun'yomi. You should know how to read this word as long as you've been studying your kanji!
222 | さようなら | さようなら | Goodbye |  | I saw your Nara (さようなら), but I then had to say goodbye. It was just a short trip, but at least I saw your Nara.\nさようなら is a formal way to say goodbye, so a good word to use with colleagues and teachers.\nA quick tip before I say goodbye: さようなら often drops its middle う, becoming さよなら.
223 | こんばんは | こんばんは | Good Evening |  | Con ban, wah! (こんばんは) cries your friend, just as you say good evening. There's a report on the evening news about a con ban (yes, that's a ban on conning people). Wah! Exciting stuff.\nYou can use こんばんは as a greeting from around 5pm or 6pm, in both formal and informal situations.　Watch out for that は on the end, which is pronounced わ here too.
224 | 主人 | しゅじん | Head Of Household | Husband\n Head Of A Household\n Head Of The Household\n Landlord\n Master | The master person isn't just a master. You have to think back to when they were making these kanji. Who was the master? It was the head of household. This head of household probably told servants what to do and was all bossy and stuff. He was the master person.\nAlso, this often means husband. Because, I guess the head of household back in the day was the husband. Those sexist ancient people! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nIn Japan, tradition says the head of a household must slide down a chute in only jeans (しゅじん). Whenever you need to speak to the head of the household, they'll come sliding down a chute wearing nothing but jeans. What a sight!
225 | 穴 | あな | Hole |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. No holes in your knowledge!
226 | 休日 | きゅうじつ | Holiday |  | When you have a rest day you have a holiday. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nEvery holiday, you eat not one, but two cucumbers. Gee, two (きゅうじつ)? Take it easy!
227 | 百 | ひゃく | Hundred | One Hundred | When a vocab word is a single kanji without okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually has the same meaning as the kanji it's spawned from. If you know the kanji meaning you'll also know the vocab meaning. It's one hundred! \n When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!
228 | 氷 | こおり | Ice |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is what you learned with the kanji.
229 | 丸ごと | まるごと | In Its Entirety | Whole\n Wholly\n Entirely | If you go to (ごと) a circle, you need to go to it in its entirety. That means you have to circle around the whole thing. Otherwise, it isn't even a circle. It's like a line or a squiggle or something.\nYou often hear this word when talking about food – like when biting into a whole apple or accidentally swallowing a grape without chewing. But it's not just for food: you can also use it to talk about memorizing a whole book from beginning to end, for example. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading, so you should be able to read this too!
230 | 不正 | ふせい | Injustice | Dishonest\n Unauthorized | When you have something that's not correct, you have no justice. In fact, you have injustice. Just imagine yourself being put in an unjust situation, and think about how not correct it is. It's probably dishonest and unauthorized too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
231 | 車内 | しゃない | Inside The Car | Inside The Train\n Inside The Bus | The car inside is simply that, inside the car. This can be used for other means of transport too, so it can also mean inside the train or inside the bus. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
232 | 宝石 | ほうせき | Jewel | Gem | A treasure stone is a very valuable stone. What kind of stones are considered treasures? How about a jewel, or a gem? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
233 | 先月 | せんげつ | Last Month |  | The previous month is last month. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nAs of last month, your centaur gets (せんげつ) up every night and comes to sleep in your bed. Apparently, he gets really bad nightmares. Poor little centaur.
234 | 去年 | きょねん | Last Year |  | The past year is just last year. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
235 | 左手 | ひだりて | Left Hand | Left Arm\n Left-Hand Side | Your left hand is your left hand! This word can also be used to mean left arm, and left-hand side. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings. This is possibly because of 手, because body parts often use kun'yomi. You learned both readings with the individual words, so you should be able to read this.
236 | 文字 | もじ | Letter (Of The Alphabet) | Character\n Letter\n Text | A writing letter is simpler than it sounds. It's really just a letter, right? You're reading 文字 right now, in fact! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The reading of 文 is a bit of an exception here. It uses a shortened version of the on'yomi もん, which is も. Here's a mnemonic to remember this:\nYou know all the letters of the alphabet only because of Moe (も). If it wasn't for your buddy Moe teaching you all the letters, you probably wouldn't even be able to read today. Thanks Moe!
237 | 主に | おもに | Mainly | Primarily | 主 means main so when you add に it becomes the adverb mainly. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou mainly spend your time talking to your master Moe. But you mainly address him like, "Oh Moe The Great!" (おも). That's because he's above you. Imagine yourself saying "OH MOE THE GREAT!" as you walk into his room, bowing low.
238 | 男 | おとこ | Man |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nJust be aware that this word used alone can sound a bit rude. You'll learn a more neutral option very soon. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it:\nThere is a man. Think of the manliest man you can. He works in an auto shop. As a child, he was an auto 子 (おとこ), working at the auto shop from an early age. This turned him into a man very quickly.\nLike other mnemonics that aren't lined up quite perfectly, your goal here is to get close enough to remember the true reading. Step, step, step, jump!
239 | 仕方 | しかた | Method | Way\n Way Of Doing | The doing way is basically a "way of doing" something. More simply put, this is the method. "What's your way of doing this?" No no no. "What's your METHOD." There we go. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji 仕, and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji 方, so watch out for that! You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this!
240 | 百万 | ひゃくまん | Million | One Million | one hundred ten thousands is how much? Multiply the two together and you get a million. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
241 | 先々月 | せんせんげつ | Month Before Last | The Month Before Last | The previous previous month (remember that 々 just repeats the kanji before it) is the month before last. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
242 | 月見 | つきみ | Moon Viewing |  | When you moon see something, you're doing a moon viewing. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. For 見 you already learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji. For 月 you'll have to think back to the vocab word 月 which uses the つき reading. Combine these two together and you have つきみ.
243 | 名 | な | Name | Reputation | This vocabulary word is the same as the 'name' meaning of the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll have no trouble remembering this word as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just think of the first part of the English word name. What is it? It's na (な), just like this word!
244 | ノート | ノート | Notebook | Notes | ノート is a shortened form of notebook, with an extra "o" on the end since you can’t end a word with "t" in Japanese.\nYou can also use this to mean notes, in the context of taking down notes in a class.
245 | 号 | ごう | Number | Edition\n Model | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nThis word is generally added to the end of a number, as in 三号 ("number 3"). It can also go together with other words to give things like train car numbers, as in ２号車 ("car 2"), and room numbers. When used on its own, it indicates the edition number of magazines and the like. \n This word is made up of a single kanji all alone, but it uses the on'yomi reading. This is probably because you'll usually see this word attached to other things, like numbers. This shows the edition or number of an item. So, even though it's alone, it's usually used like jukugo, which is why the reading for this one is the same as the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.
246 | 一気 | いっき | One Breath | One Go\n One Sitting | It's weird to think of having one energy. But, what gives you energy? You do it one time every couple of seconds. That would be taking breaths. So, "one energy" is one breath. \n The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the individual kanji, though いち from 一 is shortened to いっ.
247 | 一打 | いちだ | One Hit |  | One hit is simply… one hit!\n一打 refers to a single impactful strike. It's often a hit in ball sports, but can also be a punch in boxing or a button tap in video games. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
248 | 他 | ほか | Other |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou need to go for a drive to the public gardens, but you aren't going to get your normal car, you're going to get your other car. Your hoe car (ほか)! It's a car made entirely out of garden hoes. You can drive it and hoe with it at the same time! Your other car can't do that!
249 | 休止 | きゅうし | Pause | Hiatus | A stop that's just a rest (aka not permanent) isn't a straight up stop. You're planning on continuing again. That's why this is a pause, suspension, or hiatus.\nThis is a fairly formal word, and it's often used when an activity or a service is temporarily suspended. For example, you could use it to talk about a class being suspended, a machine suspending its operation, or a pop band going on a hiatus. Check out our common word combinations below for more example usages. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
250 | 皿 | さら | Plate | Dish | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you learned when you learned the kanji.
251 | 人気 | にんき | Popular | Popularity | If a person has a lot of energy then they're very charismatic and fun! What's another feature of charismatic / fun people? They are most likely popular as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 and 気 both have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're so popular that you've been given the Nintendo key (にんき). That's right, Nintendo gave you the master key to their entire office. Just like that.\nThis is a lot of responsibility even for your levels of popularity, so be careful not to lose this key!
252 | 切手 | きって | Postage Stamp | Stamp | This is a pretty old word, and in the olden days, everything was cut by hand, including postage stamps. Having to cut thousands of stamps each day by hand sounds incredibly laborious, so maybe that's why this word came to be associated specifically with stamps. \n You'd think that the reading for this would consist of the on'yomi readings, but human body parts (hand) do funny things to words. In this case, it's the kun'yomi readings of both the kanji. You should know the kun'yomi reading for 切 and 手 from the previous levels, meaning you should be able to remember the reading for this word fairly easily. Watch out for the small っ, though.
253 | 赤い | あかい | Red |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of red? Why, it's red! \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
254 | 赤 | あか | Red |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
255 | 休み | やすみ | Rest | Break\n Vacation\n Holiday | The kanji rest has a little hiragana attached, but it's nothing that would suggest it's anything but a noun (it is!). It means the same thing as the kanji, rest. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nSo, do you want a rest from work or school? You should say "YAASS (やす)!"
256 | 右手 | みぎて | Right Hand | Right Arm\n Right-Hand Side | Your right hand is your right hand! This word can also be used to mean right arm, and right-hand side. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This word, however, uses the kun'yomi readings. This is possibly because of 手, because body parts often use kun'yomi. You learned both readings with the individual words, so you should be able to read this.
257 | 二世 | にせい | Second Generation |  | The two generation is the second generation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
258 | 本気 | ほんき | Serious | Seriousness | What is book energy? It is energy you put into reading - it is your studies! In order to have book energy, though, you have to be very serious. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
259 | かき氷 | かきごおり | Shaved Ice |  | This is かき ice, which is shaved ice. \n The reading for 氷 is the same as the one you learned (こおり) except it gets converted to ごおり because it comes after かき, so it's rendaku'd.
260 | 貝 | かい | Shell | Shellfish\n Clam | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.
261 | 不足 | ふそく | Shortage | Insufficiency | You have something that's not sufficient. When something isn't sufficient, you have an insufficiency or shortage.\nThis word is more commonly used in formal contexts. In more casual, everyday conversations, 足りない is often preferred to express something being insufficient. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
262 | 一本気 | いっぽんぎ | One-Track Mind | Single Mindedness | You have only one book energy. No other books cross your mind. Only this one book. Why? Because you have such a one-track mind. \n The reading is based off the on'yomi readings for everything, though every reading is slightly altered. いち getting shortened to いっ, ほん changing to ぽん, and き gets changed to ぎ. They're based off the readings you know already, though, so making this shift shouldn't be too hard... that is, unless you have an 一本気, ammiright?
263 | 小皿 | こざら | Small Plate | Small Dish\n Little Plate\n Little Dish | You have a small plate. Wait, is that it? Yep, that's it. \n さら uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, except it's ざら this time because of the rendaku. 小 uses an alternate kun'yomi reading. You can remember it by thinking "What are small? Kids (子) are small. Bwahaha."
264 | 気 | き | Spirit | Energy | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji that makes up this word. Lucky you!
265 | 石 | いし | Stone | Rock | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n You pick up a stone. You throw it through a window. Huh. That was surprisingly easy.\nDo it again. Throw the stone again. It's so easy, just do it.
266 | 一文字 | いちもんじ | Straight Line |  | When you have one writing letter what do you have? Here's a hint, there's one kanji in this word that consists of one writing letter (aka a straight line). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nStraight lines are for monsters (もん). Only a monster would ever draw a perfectly straight line. You're no monster, so no straight lines for you!
267 | 名字 | みょうじ | Surname | Last Name\n Family Name | A name written in letters is the surname. Back in the day your surname was the important name (it's your family name after all, and family was king back in the day). This is the name you'd write out in kanji... aka in letters. So, that's why this combination of kanji means "surname." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nNote that the 名 portion is the alternate reading, so adjust your thinking accordingly so you can get to みょう. Just imagine someone saying "more" with a funny accent. They say "myou" instead of "more". Imagine them saying they have myou people in their family than yours. Their surname is spread amongst myou people than yours.
268 | 先生 | せんせい | Teacher | Sensei | Previous life... So we're talking about someone who has a previous life, or maybe previous life experience? When you have previous life experience, you can teach others about it, making you qualified to be some kind of teacher.\n先生 is often used for school teachers, but it's also used to show respect to doctors, lawyers, authors, and other respected experts. It's used as a standalone word or a name ender like トム先生. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
269 | テレビ | テレビ | Television | TV | テレビ comes from the English word television. It’s been shortened, which is really common with loanwords in Japanese. The "vi" sound becomes ビ, too.\nテレビ is sometimes written as "TV", but even then it’s usually pronounced テレビ.
270 | お礼 | おれい | Thanks | Gratitude | The meaning of this word is the same as the kanji, except it has an お before it, which just makes the thing you're saying elevate the other person more. Basically, it's more polite and awesome. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
271 | 先日 | せんじつ | The Other Day | A Few Days Ago\n Other Day | The previous day isn't necessarily yesterday. It can be any recent day, which is why this word means the other day. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nThe other day, you saw two centaurs! Gee, two (せんじつ) of them?! You're lucky you're still alive!
272 | 三世 | さんせい | Third Generation |  | The three generation is the third generation. Depending on the context, you can sometimes use this alone to say you're third generation Japanese. Usually, though, you'll want to specify whether you're third generation Japanese or another nationality. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
273 | 糸 | いと | Thread |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji it should use the kun'yomi reading (which is the reading you learned with the kanji).
274 | 先 | さき | Tip | Ahead\n First\n Future | Everything that happened to you previously is just the tip of the iceberg, and the important stuff is ahead of you, in your future. So make sure you put that stuff first!\nThe original meaning of this word is the tip of something, like a pen or a finger. From that meaning, it's expanded into all sorts of meanings, like ahead, first, and future, depending on the context and where it is in the sentence. It can also mean "previous" in formal contexts (and we'll accept that meaning too, but we're not teaching it here because it's more advanced). \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nJust ahead of you are the tips of a saw and a key(さき). You have no idea what they're doing there, but both saws and keys have very sharp tips, so watch out you don't hurt yourself. Imagine yourself edging carefully past those saw and key tips.\nYou can differentiate this from 先ず (まず) because it doesn't have any hiragana on the end.
275 | 足りる | たりる | To Be Enough | To Be Sufficient\n To Suffice | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leg or sufficient, and we're going with the "sufficient" meaning for this word! This word means to be enough. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the た portion. Whenever we need to remember the た we use the word "taco."\nWhat do you have enough of? What is sufficient? Turns out it's tacos (た). Your bunker is filled with them and it's going to be enough to last the winter.
276 | 写す | うつす | To Copy | To Photograph\n To Take A Picture | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy so you know this means to copy. You know this word means "to copy" because it ends with す. You're copying the documents you need to sue (す) someone who screwed you over. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the うつ part. To remember that, think of yourself as a beatboxer. You're saying うつうつうつ over and over again. Thing is, the other beatboxer is going to copy everything you do. That's why you're suing him.
277 | 出かける | でかける | To Go Out | To Leave | You exit but you do it with かける added to it. Just think of that かける as you are exiting while being "cocky" about it. You do this when you want to go out or to leave. You go out in a cocky way!\nThis word can only be used for a person going out. You can't say a train 出かける'd. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 出る, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!
278 | 打つ | うつ | To Hit Something | To Strike Something\n To Type | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hit so the vocab is to hit something or to strike something. It can also mean to type.\nYou can use this word to describe bumping a part of your body on something, hitting a ball or a nail, or typing on a keyboard. It can also describe hitting a person, but that use is less common and sounds a bit literary. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, but never fear! A mnemonic is here:\nIf you’re planning to hit an uni (う), you’re going to need a special bat or hammer. I don’t know why you’d want to hit a sea urchin, but make sure you have the right equipment if you do, because those things are spiky!
279 | 生きる | いきる | To Live | To Be Alive\n To Exist | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life," making this word mean "to live." \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use a kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn the い reading with this kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat does it mean to live? Life is pretty icky (いき ... the き comes from the hiragana part), but you have to take that ickiness and roll with it if you want to have a good life... if you want to live!
280 | 口にする | くちにする | To Mention | To Say\n To Eat\n To Drink | You've already learned that 口 means "mouth" and here it's followed by the particle に, which pinpoints a location. The verb する means "to do" so you're doing something to your mouth! Logically enough, this expression is used to describe lots of actions that you do with your mouth. It's often used to mean to mention or to say, but with an added descriptive nuance that you've said something accidentally or unexpectedly, maybe something you shouldn't have said! 🙊\nIt can also mean other things done with the mouth, like to eat and to drink! \n In this expression, 口 is a standalone vocabulary word, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
281 | 休む | やすむ | To Rest | To Take Time Off | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 休 means rest, so what's the verb version of that? It's to rest or to take time off. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to rest, right? Don't just answer with a "yes," this deserves a "YAASS" (やす)! YAAASSS let's RESSST!!!
282 | 申す | もうす | To Say Humbly | To Say | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means say humbly, and this is just the verb form, to say humbly. You can also call this to say, just remember that it's humble!\nThis is a very humble way to say "to say" so it's used in especially formal situations, and only to talk about yourself or your associates. Because of its formality, it's almost always in the ます form, which is 申します. \n The reading for this kanji is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. High Fives.
283 | 見る | みる | To See | To Look | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see so the vocab here means to see or to look. \n The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji (kun'yomi) so you should be able to read this.
284 | 見せる | みせる | To Show |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's related to the meaning of the kanji 見 "see," but this one is about having someone else see something. In other words, it means to show. \n The reading for this word is the same as the one that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read it.
285 | 気に入る | きにいる | To Take A Liking | To Be Pleased\n To Be Happy | You enter into the energy. When entering into (positive) energy, you are going to take a liking to something and to be pleased and to be happy with it. Just imagine yourself entering into some happy energy when you take a liking to something. \n The 気 portion is pretty straight forward. The 入る reading is the same as the one you learned with the vocabulary 入り口. Just imagine you're really, really, reeeally pleased with your lovely new pet eagle (い)! You're so satisfied and happy with it. Feel the good energy your eagle is bringing you.
286 | 町 | まち | Town |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou walk into this town. You hate it (because it's vocab, and who doesn't hate vocab?). So what do you do? You pull out a match (まち) and burn this town to the ground. Whoa, you some kind of psycho?
287 | 宝 | たから | Treasure |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Your treasure has a tackler (たから) guarding it at all times. He tackles anyone who gets close. If someone wants your treasure, they have to go through the tackler!
288 | 二十日 | はつか | Twentieth Day | Day Twenty\n Twenty Days | Two times ten days is twenty days. \n Words that count days use an exceptional reading. The readings for 二十 are exceptions, and 日 takes the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help with that:\nIf you make one hat for twenty days you'll have enough hats (はつ) to fill up your car (か) completely! That's a lot of days and a lot of hats.
289 | 二百 | にひゃく | Two Hundred |  | When you have two hundreds, you have two hundred. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
290 | 花見 | はなみ | Viewing Cherry Blossoms | Sakura Viewing\n Cherry Blossom Viewing | When you have flowers that you can see, you are viewing flowers. But not just any flowers. What flowers do Japanese people love viewing? That's right, this word refers to viewing cherry blossoms.\nThe focus of 花見 is on the act of appreciating blossoming trees, often accompanied by outdoor gatherings, picnics, or parties. Although cherry blossoms are the most commonly associated flowers, the term can encompass other flower-viewing experiences as well. \n The reading for this vocab is all kun'yomi, but you learned the kun'yomi readings of both these when you learned their kanji. So no worries there. You can spend the extra time viewing the cherry blossoms.
291 | 村 | むら | Village | Rural Town | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned already with the kanji. Huzzah!
292 | 村人 | むらびと | Villager |  | You have a village person. That isn't someone dancing while wearing construction worker clothes, that's a villager. \n This word uses double kun'yomi for its reading, probably because it's like two separate words (village and person) put together into one big word. You should know these two kun'yomi readings (it's the main reading for 村 that you learned and you should know 人 by now), though you will need to look out for the rendaku'd びと reading.
293 | 見方 | みかた | Way Of Seeing | Point Of View\n Perspective\n Viewpoint | The way you see is the way of seeing something. This is like when someone has a dumb opinion and you're like "oh, okay, so that's one way of seeing it..." \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 見る and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
294 | 天気 | てんき | Weather |  | What is the heaven energy? If you think about it, that's all the stuff that falls on us from the sky. Lightning, rain, snow, hail... What is all of that? It's the weather. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
295 | 平日 | へいじつ | Weekdays |  | The flat days are boring. They're the same. One day after another. That's definitely not your exciting weekends... that's your boring, flat weekdays. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWeekdays are flat, but you do at least earn two entire bales of hay. Gee, two (へいじつ) of them! What a hard worker you are.
296 | どれ | どれ | Which One | Which | Do re (どれ) mi fa sol la ti... which one of these notes are you going to start singing from?\nThe question word どれ is used to ask which one out of three or more choices.
297 | 白い | しろい | White |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of white? White, of course! \n This has the same reading as the vocab 白 you learned, so you already know the reading. Go you!
298 | 年 | とし | Year | Age | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also use this word to talk about someone's age. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThis year you plan on tossing (とし) out all your old stuff as a New Year's resolution. You pronounce it "toshing" though, because it has more vigor that way.
299 | ２０１１年 | にせんじゅういちねん | Year 2011 | 2011\n The Year 2011 | It's the 2011 year. I think the meaning is pretty obvious. This just means year 2011 or simply 2011. \n The reading is a little trickier. You start with two thousand (二千／にせん), then you need to add eleven to it (十一／じゅういち). Then, you simply add the reading for 年 which you already know. You can assume it's the on'yomi reading because it's attached to something else, like a jukugo. From there, you get the entire reading.
300 | 年中 | ねんじゅう | Year Round | All Year\n Whole Year\n Throughout The Year | The year middle sounds like it should be something like "the middle of the year," but it's not. Think of something that happens in the middle of the year and then all other parts of the year. It's just referring to everything within this year, which is how we get year round. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings for the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 中 does have a strange reading, though, which is じゅう. This is basically just ちゅう changing to ぢゅう, but since ぢ is very rare it just switches to じ and you end up with じゅう. That's called rendaku.
301 | うん | うん | Yep | Yeah\n Yes | Wanna play Uno (うん)? Yep! 'Course I do. I always wanna play Uno.\nうん is a casual way to say yes, or yeah, so you’d generally use it with friends and family, and in other informal situations.
302 | はい | はい | Yes |  | Want me to write a haiku (はい)? Yes, of course!\nはい is a formal word for "yes". You can use it to let someone know they’re right, or simply that you’re listening, as well as to respond if someone says your name.
303 | 休学 | きゅうがく | Absence From School | School Absence | When you rest from school you are taking an absence from school. This is only for very long absences though, not a day or a week, but months or years. Think about it like taking an extended leave of absence from school. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
304 | 空気 | くうき | Air | Atmosphere\n Mood | The sky energy... once known as a mystical essence that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the air. It can also mean atmosphere, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. ここの空気はいいね！\nFiguratively, this can also refer to the mood that's in the air or room, but not a specific person's mood! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
305 | 考古学 | こうこがく | Archeology | Archaeology | If you often think about studying old things, it's called archeology. All archeology involves thinking about old things, at least a little bit. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
306 | 当たり | あたり | A Success | Success\n Hit\n Guess | This is the noun version of the kanji right. What happens when you get "a right?" You get a success. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the あ portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you a success? It is the first answer, A (あ).
307 | 今すぐ | いますぐ | At Once | Right Now\n Immediately\n Right Away | You'll have to learn this word in two parts. You already know the meaning of 今 because of the kanji, which means "now." The すぐ part, however, is a new word, meaning "soon." すぐ and "soon" even start with a similar sound, so maybe that can help you remember this! If you put 今 and すぐ together, you get "now soon." Put in better English, that's at once or right now. \n Since you already know the vocab word 今 (read いま), you should be able to read this word as well.
308 | 牛肉 | ぎゅうにく | Beef |  | What do you call cow meat? You call it beef (what's for dinner?). \n Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
309 | 生まれ | うまれ | Birthplace | Birth | Remember how you learned that 生まれる means "to be born?" Well once you're born that place where it happened becomes your birthplace! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 生まれる. Just drop the る off the end and you have your reading!
310 | 青い | あおい | Blue | Unripe | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of blue? It's still blue! It can also mean unripe, which might sound confusing, but it comes down to the fact that in Japanese there's some overlap between blue and green. So while in English we think of the "go" traffic light and unripe bananas as "green," in Japanese they're actually called "blue." \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the あお portion to read this word. Think of blue things on your body. Those are bruises. Touch them. What would you say? OW! (あお).
311 | 体 | からだ | Body |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a car raider (からだ). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider.\nOf course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, からだ.
312 | 男の子 | おとこのこ | Boy |  | A man child is a boy.\nThere's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word.
