Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after.\nBut for now, all you really have to remember is that 男の子 means "boy." \n If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a の. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.
313 | 〜斤 | きん | Bread Loaf Counter | Counter for Loaves of Bread | This has the 〜 for counters, so you can bet this shares the bread loaf counter meaning with the kanji. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
314 | 兄弟 | きょうだい | Brothers | Siblings | You have an older brother and a younger brother. Wow! Both are here. These are brothers! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
315 | 毛虫 | けむし | Caterpillar |  | When you think of a fur insect what do you think of? My mind immediately goes to a caterpillar. Imagine the furriest caterpillar you can and touch it. How does it feel? Furry? \n The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - 虫 uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The 毛 part is like the vocab word 毛 you learned in the previous lesson.
316 | 近い | ちかい | Close | Nearby\n Near | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of near? It's close or nearby. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the ちか portion to be able to read this word. Imagine someone close to you... Too close. They are so close to you that they're touching their cheek (ちか) to your cheek. Feel the cheek on yours, it's getting awkward.
317 | 色 | いろ | Color |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, though, so enjoy.
318 | 会社 | かいしゃ | Company | Corporation\n The Office | The place where your company meets is your company. Sony is a company. Nintendo is a company. Etc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
319 | 作文 | さくぶん | Composition | Writing\n Essay | When you make writing, what are you doing? Simply put, you're writing. If you want to be fancier about it, you could say this is composition.\nNote that 作文 often refers to the end result of a writing process, like a finished essay, rather than the writing process itself. It’s also commonly associated with various writing tasks assigned to students in Japanese elementary or middle school. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since both 文 and 作 have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:\nYou can't stop writing compositions about sacks 'n' buns (さくぶん). You're obsessed with them. You've been writing essay after essay about sacks 'n' buns. Stop writing about sacks 'n' buns!
320 | コンビニ | コンビニ | Convenience Store |  | コンビニ comes from the English word convenience store, but who has time for all those syllables? That's why they cut it down to "conveni". So much more convenient that way.\nWatch out for the “v” sound, which usually becomes “b” in Japanese, and this word is no exception.
321 | 角 | かど | Corner | Angle | When the kanji for angle is used as a standalone word, it usually means corner. You can remember this because corners are pretty much the most common kind of angle you see in everyday life.\nIn math contexts, it can also mean angle — just like the kanji's meaning! \n This word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading.\nWhen it's used for corners, the reading is かど. Just picture a deck of cards (かど). What's the most important part of the card? The corner! The corners are where the numbers are. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!\nAnd the second meaning and reading pair is easy — angle and かく, which you already know from the kanji!
322 | 代金 | だいきん | Cost | Price | When you buy something, you basically substitute it with money. That substitute money is the cost or price of the thing you're paying for.\nThere are a lot of money-related synonyms in Japanese, but keep in mind this one refers to the money you pay to get some stuff in return (usually goods), not to an expense, price, or value. It's "substitute money" after all! \n This is a jukugo word, which means it uses on'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You already know those, so you should be good to go!
323 | 三日月 | みかづき | Crescent Moon |  | What's a "third day moon"? It's a crescent moon. A crescent moon is the newly visible moon that appears on the third day of the month in the lunar calendar that Japanese people used back in the day. \n The word comes from 三日 and 月, but the readings are slightly different. There's no small つ in the reading for 三日, and you need to rendaku 月, all to make it easier to pronounce. Try reading it aloud yourself to see what I mean!\nTo write the character づ, type "du" on your keyboard.
324 | デパート | デパート | Department Store |  | デパート comes from  department store. Yet another shortened loanword! There's an extra "o" sound on the end of this one, since a word can't end in "t" in Japanese.
325 | 図 | ず | Diagram |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.
326 | 外交 | がいこう | Diplomacy |  | You want to mix opinions from outside your country into the way you handle things. That's called diplomacy. If you mix your country with the ones outside of your own, you'll all profit! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
327 | 下町 | したまち | Downtown | Backstreets | You have the below town. Does this sort of sound familiar? We have another word for it in English, but it's essentially the same thing: downtown. It isn't the downtown you might be used to though. In Japan, this is an old word that was used for the commercial districts literally, physically down (lower than) the main city. So picture an old, urban Japanese area! \n The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.
328 | 工学 | こうがく | Engineering |  | Someone with the study of industry is someone who creates things. That would be the study of engineering. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
329 | 毎日 | まいにち | Every Day | Daily | Every day is daily (or just every day). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nEvery day you watch your favorite program, My Nietzsche (まいにち). It's a daily cartoon about Nietzsche and his life, which you follow religiously. Oh how much you love Nietzsche.
330 | 毎月 | まいつき | Every Month | Monthly | Every moon is every month (as you know from all the month-related vocab). This can also mean monthly. \n This word has the on'yomi reading for 毎 plus the kun'yomi reading for 月. That makes it まいつき.
331 | 毎回 | まいかい | Every Time | Each Time | Every times is really just every time. Do you get your kanji readings correct 毎回? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
332 | 毎年 | まいとし | Every Year | Yearly\n Annually\n Each Year | You have every and year to combine into every year (yearly works as well). \n The reading for 毎 is what you'd expect. The reading for 年 is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab 年 to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours.
333 | すみません | すみません | Excuse Me | I'm Sorry\n Sorry | Sue me, Ma Sen! (すみません), you yell at Ma Sen, before quickly adding "Excuse me…I'm sorry, so  sorry!" You shouldn't have shouted at Ma Sen like that. You hope she won’t actually sue you.\nYou can use すみません both to apologize and to get someone’s attention. This expression is really common in Japan, and dropping it in wherever you can will help you blend right in!
334 | 羽 | はね | Feathers | Feather\n Wing\n Wings | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.
335 | 林 | はやし | Forest | Grove | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.
336 | 〜形 | けい | Form | Tense | The kanji and the word share one of the same meanings: form. It doesn't just mean form though, it means tense too. Like verb tense. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
337 | 〜年来 | ねんらい | For Some Years | For Years | When you have years coming and going, you know it is for some years. Don't confuse this one with 来年 which means "next year." The kanji 来 comes after the kanji for year, so instead of "coming year" it's "years that come (and go)." At least, you can think of it that way to differentiate.\nYou can also add numbers to this word. For example ５年来 means something to the tune of "for five years." But this is a pretty formal word. Just keep that in mind. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
338 | 古来 | こらい | From Ancient Times | Age-Old | Things that are really old come from ancient times!\nThis is a relatively formal expression that’s used to talk about age-old things, like customs that have stood the test of time. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
339 | 大体 | だいたい | Generally | About\n General\n Gist | If all you can see is the big body of something, then you'll only get a general idea of what it is. You'll be able to say that it's generally a certain way, but that's about all. You'll get the gist, but no more. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nGenerally, it's a bad idea to dye your ties (だいたい). The tie police isn't a big fan of it, and you wouldn't wanna get arrested!
340 | 仕草 | しぐさ | Gesture | Action\n Behavior | Things you end up doing in the grass and not inside probably take a lot of big gestures and actions. You have to do them outside on the grass because if you did them anywhere else you might break something. \n The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes くさ become ぐさ.
341 | 金 | きん | Gold |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with お金, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.
342 | 上手い | うまい | Good At | Skillful | Remember how 上手 means that you're good at something? Well, this word uses the exact same kanji, and means the exact same thing! \n That い on the end is your clue that the reading is different, and you can forget about the readings you learned for each kanji. This is a native Japanese word, and the kanji were assigned to it based on the meaning alone. That means you just have to memorize the reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you see that someone's good at something, you say, "Ooh, my (うまい)!" at the top of your lungs. Try it! Think of something that impresses you and say "ooh my!" out loud.
343 | 草 | くさ | Grass | Weed | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
344 | 工作 | こうさく | Handicraft | Crafts\n Maneuvering | What is the "industry of make"? Well, it's when you industriously make things, obviously. That can only be handicraft or crafts, often referring to craft activities or hands-on projects done in elementary or middle school!\nBut wait, 工作 isn't just about glue and popsicle sticks! It can also mean maneuvering, in the sense of pulling strings behind the scenes. So, whether you're crafting a masterpiece or scheming a clever plan, 工作 encompasses the wonders of crafting! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYour favorite handicraft is making こういち sacks (こうさく). They're sacks that look exactly like こういち, and you're incredibly good at making them. Soon, the Tofugu offices will be decorated all over with your こういち sacks.
345 | 本社 | ほんしゃ | Headquarters | HQ\n Head Office\n Company Headquarters | The origin company is where everything in your company comes from. This is your main base. This is your headquarters. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
346 | 里 | さと | Hometown | Village\n One's Parents' Home | This is the village you came from. This is where your parents live. This is your hometown (same meaning as the kanji you learned).\nThis word is old-fashioned and evokes a warm, nostalgic image of home. Often seen in folktales and traditional songs, it represents an idyllic, pastoral life. \n The reading is the same as with the kanji you learned, so you should feel nice and "at home" with this one 😉
347 | 何日 | なんにち | How Many Days | What Day\n Which Day | What day equals the fairly obvious translation "what day." But, it also means how many days. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:\nHow many days does it take you to bake a naan Nietzsche (なんにち)? It's not easy to make a Nietzsche entirely out of naan, so I wonder how many days it would take.
348 | 何人 | なんにん | How Many People |  | When you ask what people you're not actually asking "what people?" You're asking how many people. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 何 and the on'yomi reading for 人. Since 何 and 人 both have two readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:\nHow many people eat naan at Nintendo (なんにん)? You've been tasked with counting everybody eating naan for lunch at Nintendo, so you better get started!
349 | 何回 | なんかい | How Many Times |  | What times? This doesn't make any sense. One thing you'll notice with Japanese and kanji is that 何, when added to other things, often means "how many _____" rather than "what ____." Just something you have to know and experience a bit to catch on to, but you will, I believe in you. So, for this one it's how many times. \n This is a jukugo word with a slightly unique reading, where the first kanji uses the kun'yomi reading and the second uses the on'yomi reading. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this alright.
350 | 自立 | じりつ | Independence | Self Reliance | You are able to stand using your self. Nobody is helping you. Nobody is holding you down. This is your independence!\n自立 primarily refers to a person’s ability to stand on their own, make decisions, and act independently. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
351 | 体内 | たいない | Inside The Body | Internal | The body's inside means inside the body or internal.\n体内 refers specifically to internal body stuff, so you'll often see it in medical and scientific contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
352 | 皮肉 | ひにく | Irony | Sarcasm\n Ironic\n Sarcastic | The skin on the meat is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use sarcasm and irony. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
353 | 入社 | にゅうしゃ | Joining A Company | Entering A Company | When you enter a company you're actually joining a company. Welcome, new recruit. Prepare to be hazed! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
354 | 光 | ひかり | Light | Sunlight | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou have a ton of sunlight where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: hickory (ひかり) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.
355 | 文学 | ぶんがく | Literature |  | If you study writing, it's called literature. You'll get to study lots of things other people wrote before you! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nAll the great works of literature are about buns (ぶん). That's the subtle thread running through all literature: buns.
356 | 大声 | おおごえ | Loud Voice | Big Voice | A big voice is a loud voice!\n大声 usually just describes talking in a big voice, but it can also refer to shouting depending on the situation. \n The reading for 声 is ごえ (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: こえ). The reading for 大 is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word 大きい (おおきい). Just imagine a loud voice saying "おお！."
357 | 男の人 | おとこのひと | Man |  | A man person is a man.\nThere's a の particle stuck in the middle of this word. Here it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after.\nDon't worry if that's hard to remember though. Just remember 男の人 means "man" (and that it's more polite than plain 男). \n This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
358 | 多い | おおい | Many | Much\n Lots Of | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of many? It is also many (or you could say much). Speaking of which, there are so many kanji to learn, ammiright? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThink of something that is many. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "おお!!!" as you get smushed.
359 | 多分 | たぶん | Maybe | Perhaps\n Probably | You have many parts. Look at them all. You have to choose one of the parts. You can't decide which one you want. This one? Maybe. How about this one? Hmm, maybe that one too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
360 | 肉 | にく | Meat |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!
361 | お金 | おかね | Money |  | The お is an honorific that makes this word a bit more fancy. When you're talking about money you gotta be fancy, after all. So, you're basically saying "gold" in a nicer way. What was gold back in the day? It was money. \n The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your money buying a cane (かね). Sucks for you :(
362 | 大作 | たいさく | Major Work | Masterpiece\n Blockbuster | The big make! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your major work!\n大作 means a large-scale, ambitious, or significant work. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from an artistically accomplished masterpiece to a big-budget blockbuster movie. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nDid you know that there's a monumental work about a tie sack (たいさく)? It's a masterpiece about a magic sack that produces tie after tie after tie after tie... A bit like The Magic Porridge Pot, but with a sack and ties instead.
363 | 月光 | げっこう | Moonlight | Moonbeam | The moon light (not sunlight!) can be bright sometimes. This is night when you're stumbling home from a nomikai after work. What is this light from the moon called? It's moon light. This word can also mean a moonbeam as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nThe moonlight brings out a strange creature known as a Geck-こういち (げっこう), which are geckos with the head of こういち. Imagine a swarm of them all crawling out of their crevices once the moon comes out.
364 | 来月 | らいげつ | Next Month |  | The next month is the next month! It isn't this month or the month before, it's the next one! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nNext month is when rye gets (らいげつ) into your diet! You're going to eat only rye bread and drink only rye beer for all of next month. Bet you can't wait!
365 | 来年 | らいねん | Next Year |  | The next year is next year! It isn't last year or this year, it's the next one! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
366 | いいえ | いいえ | No |  | Eeh! Eh? (いいえ) No! You’re so surprised by whatever the question was, you can only manage "Eeh! Eh? No!" in response.\nいいえ is a formal word for "no", so you can use it to answer politely in the negative.
367 | 北西 | ほくせい | Northwest |  | This word is so simple. North + West = Northwest. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
368 | 兄 | あに | Older Brother | Big Brother\n Elder Brother | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour older brother is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's Ani (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?
369 | 自分 | じぶん | Oneself | Myself\n Self | One’s self part is, after everything, still oneself. And the part that’s from my self is, well, myself. Everyone has their own part of their self. Pretty straightforward. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
370 | 三十代 | さんじゅうだい | One's Thirties |  | You have the number "thirty", and age. So this refers to one's thirties. \n This uses on'yomi for all the kanji, so you should be good to go here!
371 | 一回 | いっかい | One Time | Once | One times is one time. How many times? Just one. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 一 is shortened (as it often is) to いっ.
372 | 空車 | くうしゃ | Open Taxi | Empty Parking Space | When a car has sky in it (and not, say, a bunch of people) it is free to give you a ride. If you see this sign lit up on a taxi feel free to hail it down, it will be able to take you somewhere. It is an open taxi. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
373 | 本来 | ほんらい | Originally | Primarily\n Essentially\n Naturally | You want to talk about the origin where something comes from. That's where it is from originally. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
374 | 体力 | たいりょく | Physical Strength | Physical Power\n Stamina\n Endurance | You have your body power. This is just another way to say physical strength. Watch out, if you use too much of your physical strength you may run out of physical stamina and endurance completely! They're tied together, so make sure to pace yourself. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYour physical strength and stamina are tied together with a tie lock (たいりょく). That's a lock made of ties that ties your strength and stamina up together, making it much easier to pace yourself.
375 | 豚 | ぶた | Pig |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
376 | 雨 | あめ | Rain |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, you learned this reading with the kanji.
377 | 本当 | ほんとう | Reality | Truth\n Real\n True | What is real is right. It is the reality. It is also the truth. Don't believe anything that isn't real and true. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
378 | 近年 | きんねん | Recent Years |  | The close years are years that aren't too long ago. They are the recent years.\nThis is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
379 | 米 | こめ | Rice |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that this word refers to the grains of rice more than something that's a meal. If you're eating rice at a meal you'd call it ごはん. This is like when you're talking about the rice in the fields or rice grains or something like that. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\n"Everyone, we have rice! Come (こめ) and get it!"
380 | 同じ | おなじ | Same |  | This word is the kanji same with hiragana attached, and it also means same.\nIt's a bit of an oddball among Japanese adjectives, because you don't need な or い to attach it to a noun. So it's usually considered to be a "special" な-adjective. Have a look at the context sentences to see it in action! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you think of the word "same" think same owner (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.
381 | 同日 | どうじつ | Same Day | The Same Day | You have the same day, which comes out to same day.\nNote that this word is quite formal. To say the same day more casually, just use 同じ日! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nOn the same day, you once ate two entire doughnuts. Gee, two (どうじつ) on the same day? How did that feel?
382 | 入学 | にゅうがく | School Admission | University Admission\n Entry Into School\n Enrollment | You enter into a study (place). When does this happen? It happens when you get accepted into a school, aka school admission, university admission, or entry into school. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
383 | 学年 | がくねん | School Grade | Grade In School\n School Year\n Year In School | Your study year is kind of like the years you've studied. Where do you study? School. What is a year of study in a school? It's your school grade. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
384 | 皮 | かわ | Skin | Hide | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAs a human (we think), you have a lot of skin. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the car wash, of course!
385 | 空 | そら | Sky |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nIn the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The soarer!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.
386 | 水色 | みずいろ | Sky Blue | Light Blue\n Aqua Blue | You'd think that water color would have something to do with watercolors, but it doesn't. No, it has to do with the color of water, which, ironically, is sky blue in English. Light blue works as well. \n The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of 水 and the kun'yomi reading of 色. For 水 you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For 色 it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.
387 | 近日 | きんじつ | Soon | In A Few Days\n Coming Days | The near day is a day coming very soon. It's a day coming in a few days or in the coming days. In other words, you wouldn't use this word for something that's going to happen in a few minutes, or a few months.\nThis is a relatively formal word that is commonly used in professional or official contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nSoon, the place where you live will have two kings. Gee, two (きんじつ) of them? Yep, yours is the first country ever to have two kings.
388 | 音 | おと | Sound | Noise | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nDid you hear that sound? It's barely audible (おと). Go ahead and say the word "audible" with the pronunciation of おと to help you to remember this.
389 | 四角 | しかく | Square | Rectangle\n Cube | What shape has four angles? The most common one is a square, but it could also be a rectangle or even a cube. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!
390 | 学生 | がくせい | Student |  | Who has a study life? Only one person that I know of, and that's a student. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
391 | 日光 | にっこう | Sunlight |  | You have sun light. What kind of light would this be? Obviously sunlight. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the にち reading of 日 becomes にっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:\nThe best place for sunlight in Japan is Nikkō (にっこう). It's one of Japan's most beautiful national parks, and the perfect spot to catch some rays!
392 | 金玉 | きんたま | Testicles |  | You have some gold balls. What balls are more important than any other balls, at least for a dude? That would be his testicles.\nThis word came about because tanuki scrotum skin would be used to pound down gold into sheets. Tanuki scrotums are apparently very good at this because they are very strong and very flexible. Strange, yeah? That's why Gold balls = testicles.\nAs you might have guessed, this word is slang and you'll probably want to avoid using it at the doctor's! It's a comical word that is used in casual situations. \n This word uses the on'yomi for 金 and the kun'yomi for 玉. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.
393 | それ | それ | That One | Those Ones | Sorry (それ), can you grab that one for me? Yeah, that, thanks!\nYou can use それ for things that are close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you.
394 | その他 | そのほか | The Others | Other\n Other Than That | その means "that" or "the", and その plus other means things like the others, other, and other than that, depending on the context. \n This has two readings, but luckily you learned one of them when you learned the kanji, and the other one when you learned the word 他. The two readings are usually interchangeable, too.
395 | 今回 | こんかい | This Time |  | The now times is this time. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
396 | 何千 | なんぜん | Thousands | Several Thousands\n How Many Thousands | What thousand? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "thousands."\nIf this is used in a question, it can also mean how many thousands? \n The reading is the kun'yomi なん for 何 and the rendaku'd on'yomi reading for 千 (ぜん) combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.
397 | 〜回 | かい | Times | Number Of Times\n Time | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have １回, ２回, ３回, or even １００回 if you're into that sort of thing.
398 | 当たる | あたる | To Be Right | To Be On Target\n To Touch\n To Hit | You know this is a verb because it ends with an う sound. The kanji for this word is right or success, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. Like, a crazy amount of things. I tried narrowing it down for you, but it will still be a lot. This word tends to be about getting an answer right. As in, to be right or to be on target. It means many other things too, but I think these are the two meanings you'll see the most, so focus on those. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the あ portion.\nWhen your guess turns out to be right, you can't help but shout, "Ah! (あ)" That "Ah" is your victory cry.
399 | 見える | みえる | To Be Visible | To Be In Sight\n Can See\n To Seem | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means see, and 見える is to be visible, or to be in sight, though it's often more naturally translated into English as can see. It's used when you don't actively intend to see something, it just happens.\nThis verb can also mean to seem, when talking about how you perceive something you can see. \n The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.
400 | 来る | くる | To Come |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come so you know this word means to come. \n The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic:\n"I want you to come to the cool (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader.\n"What?" replies Luke.\nJust replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.
401 | 下がる | さがる | To Get Lower | To Go Down\n To Come Down\n To Hang Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means below so this means something gets lower, by falling or dropping. For example: Prices get lower or fall. Squirrels come down from trees. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to get lower or to go down. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji:\nYou know it means to fall so instead of using a saw (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)
402 | 生む | うむ | To Give Birth | To Produce | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "life" so what is the verb form of that? Would it be "to do life"? No, probably not. In this case it is to give birth, or to produce.\nYou'll have to differentiate this one from the word 生まれる as well. You can remember that this one means "to give birth" because when you compare, the act of giving birth probably feels shorter than the act of being birthed, at least in terms of sheer terror. The pain of giving birth will make it feel quick, when you look back on it... but just imagine how traumatized the baby must be from going through that as well. So, the act of giving birth is shorter, just like the word itself! \n You have to remember the う part of this word to be able to read it. It's the same as 生まれる, so that could help if you've learned that word already. If not, just imagine yourself giving birth, but not to a baby. Instead, it’s an uni (う) you’re delivering. And of course, all you can do when bringing the spiky uni into the world is scream: "UUuUUuuUUuUuu!”
403 | 行く | いく | To Go |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go so the verb form of this is to go. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle."\nYou want to go somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An eagle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.
404 | 上がる | あがる | To Go Up | To Rise\n To Get Higher | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means above so this means something rises. For example: A fever goes up. The sun rises. See? No direct object here. That's why this verb means to go up or to rise.\nBe careful not to confuse this with its transitive buddy 上げる, which means "to lift something" or "to raise something." With that other verb, someone is doing the lifting, it's not happening by itself like it is here. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading, which also happens to be a reading you didn't learn when you learned the kanji. Let's use a mnemonic for the kun'yomi reading now, though. You have to remember at least the あ part to read it.\nYou know that this word means to go up. Imagine something just rising on its own, like a floating tree or something. What would you say? Probably a "surprised" sound. Maybe you'd scream "あ!" when you saw this floating tree.\nIf you need help remembering the hiragana part, imagine that it's a girl rising up and you scream "Ah! Girl!"(あがる).
405 | 入れる | いれる | To Insert | To Put In | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 入 means "enter," but this word does not mean "to enter" (which you already learned as 入る). Still, the meaning of 入れる is still related to the kanji's meaning: it means to insert or to put in. It's something you do to another object, like inserting a key into a lock, or your hand into a glove. \n When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji 入. As long as you know that this vocab means to insert, you can use that to remember the reading as well.\nImagine inserting your hand into a hole and an eagle (い) flies out, screaming: "い!" This is something that happens every time you insert your hand into something: an eagle comes out. You don't know why.
406 | 学ぶ | まなぶ | To Learn | To Study In Depth\n To Study | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means study or learning. When you do these things, what ends up happening? You learn. That's why this word means to learn.\nThere is another word that means "to learn" that is going to be more common, which is 習う. You'll learn this one later on. 学ぶ sounds a little more serious compared to 習う, so keep that in mind when you use it. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there to learn manners (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.
407 | 作る | つくる | To Make | To Build\n To Create | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means make. The verb form of that is to make. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's too cool (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.
408 | 会う | あう | To Meet | To Encounter | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means meet so the verb form of that is to meet or to encounter. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want to meet more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "OW!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.
409 | 交ぜる | まぜる | To Mix Something |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb version is to mix something.\nIt’s transitive, so you’re doing the mixing. With this word, the things you’ve mixed are still distinguishable from each other. Two types of fish in your aquarium, books of different genres on your shelf — that kind of thing. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho always said not to mix your white and red socks in the laundry? That would be your Ma (ま).
410 | 回る | まわる | To Revolve | To Go Around\n To Rotate | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means times. There's no good verb for the word "times" but you can probably imagine something doing something over and over and over again. What word would represent this? It would be to revolve, to go around, or to rotate.\nBear in mind that this verb is intransitive, so it happens on its own. Something revolves or rotates, all by itself. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)" as they start to revolve around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.
411 | 走る | はしる | To Run |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run so now you know the verb version of that is to run. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the はし portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into hash (はし) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.
412 | 言う | いう | To Say |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means say, so the verb version of that is to say. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo remember the reading い we use the word "eagle."\nYou're trying to say something, but every time you try to say anything an eagle (い) swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.
413 | 立てる | たてる | To Stand Something Up | To Make Something\n To Set Something Up | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" and this means to stand something up. It also can mean to make something, both in a physical sense, like making a sound, and a mental sense, like making a plan.\nDon't confuse this with 立つ. 立てる means that you're standing something up. As in, "I stood up the action figure" or "I will erect the flag." You're doing the action to something else. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji with 立つ, so you should be good to go!
414 | 止まる | とまる | To Stop |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes to a stop. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to stop. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 止める, so you should be able to read it already!
415 | 出す | だす | To Take Out | To Hand Out\n To Remove\n To Turn In\n To Put Out | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit" and this is kind of a verb form of this. The word means to take out or to hand out, so it's like you're doing the action of causing something else to exit (rather than exiting yourself).\nIn other words, this verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in す. You can remember this because the hiragana す is like the word "sue." You're taking out way too much of something, and someone's going to sue (す) you for it. \n The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the だ portion. Remember how someone was going to sue you for trying to take out way too much? Well, that someone is your Dad (だ)! Your own Dad is going to sue you if you keep taking out way too much stuff, so you better stop!
416 | 考える | かんがえる | To Think About | To Consider\n To Give Thought | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think, so the verb version is to think about or to consider.\nNote that this isn't the "to think" that is like "I think that he is a power ranger." No, this is more like the actual thinking action. That's why this word is "to think about" or "to consider" rather than plain old "to think" which is 思う. \n If you want to think, the best way to do so is to do the conga (かんが). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.
417 | 分かる | わかる | To Understand | To Be Understandable | This word means to understand, which might surprise you if you remember that the kanji 分 means part. Think of it this way: to understand something you have to break it down into its parts to see how it works.\nWatch out, though, because whereas in English you understand something, in Japanese the thing you understand is the grammatical subject (it's doing the action). So, a more literal meaning for this is to be understandable. In other words, there's no object, and 分かる is intransitive, meaning it happens on its own. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou scream "WAHHHHHH" (わ) in terror and "CAAAR!!!" (か) as you careen down the freeway. Your dad is driving like a maniac and almost hit another car! "WAAH CAAAR!!!" (わか) you scream again. If only he understood your terror!
418 | 行き | ゆき | Train Direction | Bound For | This is a weird word. Call it exceptional. You'll see this at train stations, especially. You know the kanji means go. So, something is going somewhere. Now just use the き to help you to remember that this word means train direction (aka it tells you which direction a train is going), because this word is the key (き) to you knowing what direction you're going in so you don't get lost. You could also remember this word as "bound for" aka "Bound for Tokyo Station." \n The reading is also an exception. It can be いき, but instead we're focusing on the ゆき reading. You have to remember the ゆ portion, so think of it this way:\nJust think about the train direction that you (ゆ) need to go in. It's all about you. Not your friends or anyone else. You. You are the most important person at this train station.
419 | 走行 | そうこう | Traveling | Running\n Moving\n Driving | A vehicle that run-goes is running and it's moving you somewhere else. You're traveling!\nThis word is typically used to describe the movement of vehicles such as cars and trains. It carries a slightly formal or rigid tone, so keep an eye on our context sentences to make sure you’re using it right! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
420 | 三角 | さんかく | Triangle |  | When you have something with three angles, what shape is that? It's a triangle. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
421 | 大学 | だいがく | University | College\n Uni | What's the big study? If I had to choose, I'd probably say this is college or university. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYour university is best known for its dye gawking (だいがく). It's a sport in which you gawk at dye, and your university is the best at it! Other universities might be known for their football or basketball teams, but yours is the best at dye gawking.
422 | 今まで | いままで | Until Now | Up To Now\n So Far | You know that 今 means now. What you probably don't know is that まで means "until." So, this word means until now. \n The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word 今. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.
423 | 谷 | たに | Valley |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!
424 | 色々 | いろいろ | Various |  | This is the kanji color repeated twice (the 々 character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means various. \n The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.
425 | 声 | こえ | Voice |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!
426 | 西 | にし | West |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou go off to the west. It's the Wild West, even. There aren't many people out here, making it easy to find a niche (にし) for your snake oil business.
427 | 何 | なに | What |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.
428 | 何月 | なんがつ | What Month | Which Month | You have what month - as in: what month is it? It's １０月, you fool. Get a job, hippy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:\nWhat month gives you naan guts (なんがつ)? It's the month you eat so much naan that even your guts turn into naan! But which month was it again?
429 | 何年 | なんねん | What Year | How Many Years | You have the kanji what and year, as in: "what year is it?"\nThis also means how many years too, depending on the context. As in: "How many years did you play soccer?" \n The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.
430 | 麦 | むぎ | Wheat | Barley\n Oats | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji that uses the kun'yomi reading which is the reading you learned with the kanji.
431 | 一生 | いっしょう | Whole Life | All Through Life\n Lifelong | One life is all you get. It's your whole life. This can also mean all through life, and when it's used as an adjective it means lifelong. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho has been in charge of you your whole life? The shogun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your entire life.
432 | 社内 | しゃない | Within The Company | In House\n Inside The Company | When you're doing something inside the company you're doing it within the company or in-house. For example, we do our kanji in-house. It gives it that artisan flavor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
433 | 毛糸 | けいと | Wool Yarn | Yarn | When you have fur string (aka string made of fur) what do you think of? Hopefully wool yarn. \n The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With 毛 you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With 糸 it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.
434 | あなた | あなた | You | Darling | "A gnat, ah! (あなた). I’m going to get you! Yes YOU," you shout as you swat at that pesky gnat buzzing around your head.\nあなた is a lot less common than “you” in English, but you’ll come across it in adverts, online forums, and textbooks, where it’s used to address a general, anonymous audience. Some people also use it with their significant other, in which case it sounds intimate, like "darling". In casual conversations, though, it can come off as standoffish, so it's better to use someone's name or social title (like "teacher") instead.
435 | 弟 | おとうと | Younger Brother | Little Brother | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell "OH. Toe? TOE!" (おとうと) as you realize what's going on.
436 | 青年 | せいねん | Youth | Young Man\n Young Adult | Someone who is in their young years is a youth, or young man.\n青年 refers to young adults, usually in their late teens to early twenties. The word is gender-neutral in legal or official contexts, but in everyday use 青年 usually refers to young men. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. That said, this reading can be easy to confuse with other similar words, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nThe youth like to play with sabers (せい) and nendoroids (ねん). Think about it: as you leave childhood and become a 青年, you want more mature and dangerous hobbies, right? So you move on from plastic swords and soft toys to playing with real sabers and nendoroid action figures. You're such a cool 青年.
437 | 後で | あとで | After | Afterwards\n Later | This shares one of the meanings you learned for the kanji: after. You can differentiate this one from 後ろ (which you may or may not have seen yet) thanks to the で on the end. Some people believe that after something's dead (で), it goes to an afterlife. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAfter. Everything happens after. It's a cause and effect chain. One thing happens, and then another thing happens after. This is life. This is the universe. Everything is after. It's an automatic (あと) cycle that just keeps going and going and going.
438 | 全て | すべて | All | Entire\n Everything | This has a little hiragana attached to it but nothing that suggests it's a verb or an adjective. That means you can assume this word has the same meaning as its parent kanji. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou wanted to remember everything about your trip, so you bought every souvenir (すべ) available in the entire shop to ensure you had all the mementos possible.
439 | 全日本 | ぜんにほん | All Japan | All Of Japan | You know 日本 means "Japan." So, now you have the kanji for all added to it, making this word All Japan (as in "All Japan Railways" or something like that). \n You know the reading of 日本. Now just add the on'yomi reading of 全 and you should be able to read this word.
440 | 午前 | ごぜん | AM | Morning\n A.M. | You have something that's before (or in front of) noon. What is before noon? That is AM. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
441 | 足首 | あしくび | Ankle |  | What is the neck of your leg? Think about it. It's your ankle. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of 足 from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of 首 from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.
442 | カバン | カバン | Bag | Handbag\n Backpack | If there’s a car ban (カバン), you’ll need a nice bag to carry all your stuff in. You can’t just throw it all in the car, so get yourself a nice bag instead.\nカバン is used for bags that you can close and that have a fairly rigid structure, like handbags and backpacks, but not more flimsy bags that don't close, like plastic bags and paper bags.\nThis word can also be written in hiragana and kanji. All versions are pretty common, but you'll probably see it in katakana the most.
443 | 後ろ | うしろ | Behind | Back\n Rear | The hiragana attached to this word doesn't suggest it's a verb or an adjective, so we can assume it's a noun. While 後で (you may or may not have seen this word yet) means "after," this one means all the other meanings you learned with the kanji: behind, back, and rear. Think of the ろ as a hint. It's like saying you're on the "road" (ろ) and you're driving so fast you're leaving everything "behind." \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nContinue to think you're driving on this road. You hit something, then look behind you, seeing you hit a cow. Know the word for cow in Japanese? It's うし, which is also the reading for this word.
444 | 出血 | しゅっけつ | Bleeding | Bleed | When the thing that is exiting is blood, you are probably bleeding. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nNote that the しゅつ from 出 gets shortened to しゅっ. That's a small つ there, not a big one.
445 | 血 | ち | Blood |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou cut yourself and there's blood everywhere. You need to stop the bleeding with something, but the only thing nearby is a block of cheese. You grab the cheese and stuff it into your gash, but the blood comes out the holes (it is Swiss cheese, blargh!). Imagine this in great detail to be able to remember it well.
446 | 両方 | りょうほう | Both | Both Sides\n Both Ways | Here you have both directions / ways. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply both.\nClose to the kanji is the meaning both sides, as well. Learn either for 両方, they're pretty similar. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
447 | 両日 | りょうじつ | Both Days |  | Kanji doesn't go together much better than this. Both plus day equals both days.\nThis is a bit of a formal word though, you'll hear important people say it more than your friends. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nOn both days of your vacation, you get two boats to row! Gee, two (りょうじつ) boats at once? Try not to fall in!
448 | 両手 | りょうて | Both Hands | Both Arms | Don't use one hand when you can use both hands. This is simply both plus hand put together. It can also mean both arms. \n This word uses the readings you learned with both kanji. No problemo for a kanji master such as yourself.
449 | 明るい | あかるい | Bright | Cheerful | This is a single kanji plus the hiragana るい. Words that end in い are usually adjectives, and this is no exception. What's the adjective form of bright? It's also bright. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the あか portion. What is あか in Japanese? It is "red." So, think of something that's really bright. Now, imagine it being totally red (aka あか). In Japan, the color red is associated with the sun, and the sun is pretty bright. If you can remember this you can also remember the reading of this word.
450 | 茶色 | ちゃいろ | Brown | Brown Color\n Color Brown | What is the color of tea? You'd think it would be green, assuming it's Japanese... but this word came from China. What color is Chinese tea? It tends to be more brown. Think Oolong tea, for example. \n The readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this already.
451 | 仕方がない | しかたがない | Can't Be Helped | It's No Use\n There's No Other Way | You’ve already learned 仕方, which you know means "method" or "way of doing." When you don’t (that’s the がない part) have a way of doing or achieving something, you could say it can’t be helped, it’s no use, or there’s no other way. Makes sense, right? This is a popular phrase in Japanese, so we're sure you'll encounter it a lot! \n You already know how to read this from having learned 仕方, so you should be good to go!
452 | 安い | やすい | Cheap | Inexpensive | This is a single kanji with an い at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. One of the meanings of 安 is cheap, so this is just that as an adjective, cheap. Time to go to a 100円 shop and get some 安い goods, ammiright? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\n"Would you like this item for cheap?"\n"YAASS (やす), please!"
453 | 中国 | ちゅうごく | China |  | The middle country... who could that be? Let's think about it. Who invented kanji and therefore probably thinks they're the middle of the world? Who also is just a huge country that ruled much of Asia? That would be none other than China. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.
454 | 社長 | しゃちょう | Company President | President Of A Company | The company leader is the company president. Be sure to greet your 社長 with a hearty good morning when they stumble in! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
455 | 活用 | かつよう | Conjugation | Practical Use | What do you use to show that a word is lively? Conjugation! Lively things are happening, so you have to conjugate your words to match.\nIt also has another meaning. When you want to actually use something lively you are making practical use of it. I mean, you're using it, after all. So as long as you aren't pretending to use it, it's probably practical. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
456 | 国 | くに | Country | Nation | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nTell me about your country. Now imagine that everyone in your country has cool knees (くに). That's because the national dress code is shorts, so everyone's knees get chilly. That why they have cool knees. You could also imagine cool knees in the sense of trendy knees. What makes for cool knees, in your opinion?
457 | 文化 | ぶんか | Culture |  | Writing has changed our entire culture. In fact, when someone reads a good piece of writing it changes them, and changes their culture too. What writing has changed you so much it has changed your culture and the way you act? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nIn your culture, everyone drives bun cars (ぶんか). Indeed, bun cars are the height of culture. And because they're made out of buns, they're much less dangerous.
458 | 死体 | したい | Dead Body | Corpse\n Cadaver | The kanji for death and body put together make for a dead body. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
459 | 死 | し | Death |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
460 | 方言 | ほうげん | Dialect |  | The way you say things is your dialect. It's an entire "way" of speaking.\nYou can even think of the  方 as being a "direction." If you go far enough in different directions in a country, you'll discover different regional dialects. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
461 | 方向 | ほうこう | Direction |  | The direction yonder over there is still just the direction of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
462 | ドル | ドル | Dollar |  | ドル is the Japanese version of the English word dollar.\nThe dollar symbol $ is also common in Japanese, and the pronunciation is still ドル.
463 | 早く | はやく | Early | Soon\n Quickly\n Fast | This is the adverb version of the kanji early. It's a little thing you can begin sentences with to say you're doing something early or quickly. \n Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 早い, you should be able to read this word as well.
464 | 東 | ひがし | East |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou see a man walking east, toward the sun rising behind that tree, but it's too bright. He trips and he gashes (ひがし) his foot on a root that was sticking out of the ground. His foot is torn up really bad, but he tries to take another step and, oh no, he gashes his foot again! This guy is not having an easy time going east.
465 | 東方 | とうほう | Eastward | Eastern Direction\n The East | The East direction is Eastward or the East.\nThis word has an old-fashioned feel to it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
466 | 活気 | かっき | Energy | Liveliness\n Vigor\n Spirit | If you have lively energy you have more than enough energy for everyone to start noticing. They come up to you and compliment you on your amazing liveliness. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful because かつ is being shortened here to かっ. It's a pretty common change for on'yomi ending in つ, so keep your eyes open for more that do this!
467 | 十分 | じゅうぶん | Enough | Sufficient\n Plenty | You have ten parts out of ten. Which means you have quite enough. The amount you have is sufficient and plenty. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
468 | 元パートナー | もとぱーとなー | Ex-Partner | Former Partner | Your origin partner is a partner you had originally, but don't have anymore. In other words, this is your ex-partner or former partner.\nLike in English, this word is fairly formal, and it covers any kind of ex-partner, including business and romantic partners. \n This uses the kun'yomi of 元 and then it's just kana, so you should know how to read this!
469 | 有名 | ゆうめい | Famous |  | When you have a name (that is known to people) or you have famousness, you are probably someone who is famous. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
470 | 名曲 | めいきょく | Famous Music | Famous Song\n Famous Tune\n Masterpiece | Famous music is famous music. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
471 | 早口 | はやくち | Fast Talker | Fast Talking\n Fast Speaker\n Fast Speaking | When you have a fast mouth, you're probably a fast talker, right motormouth? \n Remember how body parts often change even jukugo words to kun'yomi readings? That's what happened here too. Both readings are kun'yomi, making this one はやくち.
472 | 外国 | がいこく | Foreign Country | Other Countries\n Overseas | An outside country is one outside of your own country. That is a foreign country, other countries, or overseas. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
473 | 外国人 | がいこくじん | Foreign Person | Foreigner | You know 外人 the word that means "foreigner," but that word is a bit informal and can come off as rude. The nicer, more politically correct version of the word is the one above. An outside country person. To differentiate this from "foreigner" we're going to use the more polite English version of this word as well (just like in Japanese): Foreign Person. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nRemember how to spot a foreigner? That's right, they'll be in jeans (じん)!
474 | 四十二 | よんじゅうに | Forty Two | The Answer | Four tens plus two. That equals forty two.\nP.S. Please don't panic. "The Answer" is NOT a correct answer for this. It is just a reference to the greatest book of all time. Sorry for the confusion and so long and thanks for all the fish. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But! Don't forget, 四 uses the kun'yomi reading, since the on'yomi reading sounds too much like the word for "death."
