475 | 前 | まえ | Front | Before | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nWhat's in front of you? Think about it. Make it something ridiculous. Now look at a tag that's on it. Who does this thing belong to? Oh, wait, it's my (まえ) thing there in front of me. Say that out loud for better memory.
476 | 全力 | ぜんりょく | Full Effort | Every Effort\n Best Effort\n Full Power | When you put all your power into something, you're putting your full effort into it. Hopefully that's what you put into your kanji learning as well! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWith your full effort, you were able to produce a Zen lock (ぜんりょく). It's a lock imbued with the power of Zen, meaning no one and nothing could possibly break it. It's the one lock to rule them all.
477 | 出社 | しゅっしゃ | Going To The Office | Arriving At The Office\n Coming To Work | If you exit somewhere in order to go to your company, that's going to the office, arriving at the office, and coming to work. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for  the しゅつ, which gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.
478 | 正直 | しょうじき | Honest | Honestly | You have correct and fix. When you're always fixing things to make them correct (for example, someone's lies!) you are a very honest person. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This is the case here too, but both kanji use their slightly less common secondary readings. You do know both of those, but in case you need a little help, here's a mnemonic anyway:\nBe completely honest, what's the strangest sound you've ever heard? The Shougun (しょう) going "jikijiki (じき)"?! Honestly, that does sound quite strange...
479 | 本州 | ほんしゅう | Honshuu | Honshu | You have your origin state. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: Honshu. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
480 | 家 | いえ | House | Home | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. But there's a second reading you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic for both:\nWhat do you do in your house? You eat eggs (いえ). You love to eat eggs at home. But it has to be on the 内 (うち), a.k.a. the inside, of your house. For some reason you can only eat eggs in the 内 of your house.\nBoth readings relate to house and home, but いえ is a bit more for the physical building (the house) while うち is more for your personal sense of home, including your family and household.
481 | 私 | わたし | I | Me | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is わたし. If you don't know that already, just think: "What, a し?" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is し.
482 | 国王 | こくおう | King | Monarch\n Sovereign | A country king is still a king, just of a bigger area. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
483 | 天国 | てんごく | Kingdom Of Heaven | Heaven\n Paradise | This is heaven country. Where is that? Probably just in heaven (or if you want to be fancy, the kingdom of heaven). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 国 is changed to the reading ごく though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.
484 | 九州 | きゅうしゅう | Kyuushuu | Kyushu | The nine states. This refers to a section of Japan from a long time ago that was presumably made up of nine states. Now it's just one big island, though, and that island is Kyuushuu. Go take a look at a map and find this giant island, it's a cool part of Japan! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
485 | 土地 | とち | Land |  | The soil of the earth is the portion of the earth that is made up of land. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading, but 土 gets modified to と for some reason. Just remember that the land you're standing on is made of toes... millions of them. Yuck.
486 | 生活 | せいかつ | Life | Livelihood | When you have life and are lively that right there is true life. What is your 生活 like? Do you live? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
487 | 長い | ながい | Long |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of long? It's also long. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have something that's really long. It's this crazy hair growing out of the tip of your nose. You don't really care either way if it stays or goes, but you're too lazy to cut it off. Your parents, though, keep trying to nag (なが) you to trim it. Imagine this process happening and be irritated about it. What naggers.
488 | 宝くじ | たからくじ | Lottery | Public Lottery\n Lottery Ticket | 宝 is a treasure. くじ is a lottery. So if you have a treasure lottery (you win treasure if you win the lottery) then you have yourself a lottery. \n The reading uses the 宝 vocab reading, たから.
489 | 小文字 | こもじ | Lowercase Letters | Lowercase Characters\n Lowercase | You know that 文字 means "letters". So, what are "small letters"? That would be lowercase letters. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, 小 uses the kun'yomi reading and 文 is an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:\nYou learned your lowercase letters from 子 Moe (こも). That's right, after Moe taught you all the letters, his son 子 Moe taught you the lowercase ones. Such teamwork.
490 | 地図 | ちず | Map |  | The diagram of the earth. What could that be other than a map? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
491 | 草地 | くさち | Meadow | Grassland | Grass covering the earth is a meadow. Or, if you're less creative, it's grassland. \n The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
492 | 水星 | すいせい | Mercury |  | The water star is the planet Mercury. That's where we hid all of our secret moon water. Mercury looks enough like our moon, so we put it there so no one could find it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
493 | 中東 | ちゅうとう | Middle East |  | The middle of the east is more simply known as the middle east. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
494 | 死亡 | しぼう | Mortality | Death | Death and deceased. That's a lot of death. This is mortality. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
495 | 国宝 | こくほう | National Treasure | Nic Cage | A country's treasure is their national treasure. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
496 | 全国 | ぜんこく | Nationwide | National\n Countrywide | When something involves all the country you know it's nationwide or national. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
497 | 首 | くび | Neck |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.
498 | 夜 | よる | Night | Evening | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nIt is the night, but it is your (よる) night.
499 | 直行 | ちょっこう | Nonstop | Direct | If you think about direct going (aka transportation) how would you make it better? You'd make it so everything was nonstop and direct. Just imagine how much nicer it would be if every airplane you took was direct and you never had to stop. So nice!\nNote 直行 is commonly used in business settings to describe traveling directly to a destination without making any stops, like visiting a client’s office straight from your home. \n This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The ちょく of 直 is shortened with a small っ, though, so make sure to take note of that.
500 | 足りない | たりない | Not Enough | Insufficient\n Not Sufficient | You know the word 足りる from Level 4. What is this one? it's the opposite (negative form on a verb is ない). So, what is the opposite of 足りる (To be sufficient)? The opposite is to not be sufficient or not enough. \n The reading is the same as 足りる (たりる) which you should have seen in Level 4.
501 | ない | ない | Not There | Not Exist | The knife (ない) is not there. It's not here and it's not there. It’s missing. It's nowhere to be found, so don't bother looking for it!
502 | 年上 | としうえ | Older |  | When you're years above someone else, you are older than that person. \n The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.
503 | 姉 | あね | Older Sister | Big Sister\n Elder Sister | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is your older sister, by the way. Not somebody else's. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet,  so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nPicture your older sister (even if you don't have one), her birthday is coming up and there's only one thing she wants from you. A necklace (あね). She's wanted a necklace for years and you're finally going to give her one. She'll be so happy.
504 | お姉さん | おねえさん | Older Sister | Miss | The お makes the word more polite. You're elevating the "older sister" title because you're a good younger sibling. Otherwise, the meaning of this word is the same as the kanji - just the feeling is different. You can also use this word to refer to a youthful-looking woman that you don't know, as in "Excuse me miss!" \n The reading is different too. It has some hiragana attached to it, which is a clue that this uses a kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to learn that reading.\nImagine your older sister (even if you don't have one). She is, for some reason, a horse. Imagine petting her, giving her carrots, and doing other horse-related things with her. What do horses say? They say nehhhh (ねえ).
505 | 一歩 | いっぽ | One Step |  | If 歩 is "walk" and you take one walk, then really you are just taking one step. When there's a number before 歩, it refers to the number of steps you're taking. The most common is this one, and you'll see it on urinals when they kindly ask you to please take one step forward because peeing isn't a game and somebody has to clean up after you. \n The reading is pretty standard in its trickiness. The いち shortens to an いっ and the ほ rendakus to ぽ. One step at a time, right?
506 | 元 | もと | Origin | Ex\n Former | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When it's used as a prefix, it takes on the related meaning of ex- or former. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou're trying to trace a person back to their origin so you can learn more about them. You finally get there - it's a castle. The problem is that it's surrounded by a huge moat (もと) and you can't get past it because the drawbridge is up. Feel the frustration of this. Think about your goal and how close you are to getting to it if it wasn't for this lousy moat.
507 | 海外 | かいがい | Overseas | Foreign\n Abroad | The outside of the sea is someplace overseas. It can also be foreign or abroad if those words are easier to remember for you. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
508 | 平安 | へいあん | Peace | Peaceful\n Heian | Something is flat and relaxed. That is you. What words does that describe? To me, that would be peace. Just imagine something that is flat and relaxed, like a field of grass with happy people in it. It's so peaceful!\nThis is the way you write the Heian period of Japanese history, which is probably where you'll see this word the most. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
509 | 私生活 | しせいかつ | Personal Life | One's Personal Life\n Private Life\n One's Private Life | You've seen 生活 before, right? So what about the "life" of I? Whose life is that? Why, that's my own personal life. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
510 | 午後 | ごご | PM | Afternoon\n P.M. | What is noon after? That is PM or the afternoon. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
511 | 点 | てん | Point | Score\n Decimal Point\n Viewpoint | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. As luck would have it, this word actually covers most of the meanings of the English word point, too! So it can mean things like score, viewpoint, and decimal point. \n The reading for this word is the same as the reading for the kanji that makes it.
512 | 豚肉 | ぶたにく | Pork |  | A pig's meat is called pork. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
513 | 私立 | しりつ | Private |  | The place where I stand is my own private area. Think of the "circle of personal space." This is where you stand plus an arm's length. This area is very private to you. Who knows what you do in your own private area. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nBoth 市立 (municipal) and 私立 (private) are pronounced as しりつ and it's hard to tell them apart when speaking. Although they're not official readings, people sometimes distinguish 市立 and 私立 by pronouncing them as いちりつ and わたくしりつ respectively.
514 | 車両 | しゃりょう | Railroad Car | Vehicle\n Train Car\n Railway Carriage\n Railcar | A car with more cars on both sides is a car that hooks into other cars... specifically other railroad cars. They have hooks on both sides, they hook into other cars, and they fit all the requirements of this vocab word's kanji. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
515 | 安心 | あんしん | Relief | Peace Of Mind | When your heart is relaxed, how do you feel? What if this is after something startling happens? You would feel relief or peace of mind. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
516 | 〜室 | しつ | Room |  | You'll see this attached to other words... like "waiting" or "guest." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ room, making this word mean room (same as the kanji). \n The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.
517 | 安全 | あんぜん | Safety | Safe | When you are all relaxed you are finally safe and in safety. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
518 | 土星 | どせい | Saturn |  | The ground star is Saturn. That's why it's called "sat"urn. Because the first people to find it sat on the ground there. It's a star made completely of sit-on-able ground. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
519 | 科学 | かがく | Science |  | The study of science is plainly known as science. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
520 | 羊 | ひつじ | Sheep |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nImagine a sheep fighting with Jesus. The first thing it does is hits Jesus (ひつじ) in the stomach with its fists, then hits Jesus again with its horns. Try to imagine this playing out, with an announcer calling the shots as well.
521 | 四国 | しこく | Shikoku |  | The four country is another section of Japan. It's quite nice, too. Look on a map and try to find it. So, the meaning of this word is also the reading, which you should be able to figure out because it's all on'yomi: Shikoku. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
522 | 店 | みせ | Shop | Store | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThink of your favorite shop. Okay, now imagine yourself going to it. When you arrive, the entire shop is totally missing (みせ). Feel the shock and awe of this. It's as if it picked up and left overnight. No building, no anything. Just missing.
523 | 姉妹 | しまい | Sisters |  | Your older sister and your younger sister. These are your sisters. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
524 | 石ころ | いしころ | Small Stone | Pebble\n Stone | You've already learned 石, which means stone. Add a ころ to that, and it becomes a small stone, or pebble. \n This uses the kun'yomi of 石, which you've already learned, and adds a bit of hiragana, so you should be able to read this!
525 | 他の人 | ほかのひと | Someone Else | Other People | Here you have other and person joined together by the particle の, which shows that "other" is describing "person". So this means someone else or other people.\nThis is more general than 他人, which you already learned. 他の人 can be anyone that's not the speaker, or not the person being talked about. 他人, on the other hand, has an added implication that the person is someone unknown or unrelated. \n This uses the kanji's kun'yomi readings, which you've already learned. As long as you remember those, you should be good to go!
526 | 南 | みなみ | South |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThink about the south. What's down there? Mean Amy (みなみ) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.
527 | 南東 | なんとう | Southeast |  | The South East is the Southeast. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
528 | 州 | しゅう | State | Province\n County | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading that you learned with the kanji, probably because it normally gets added on to other things, like the names of the state. Examples: カリフォルニア州, ニューヨーク州, etc.
529 | 代用 | だいよう | Substitution |  | A substitute task is a substitution.\nNote that this word has a slightly formal feel to it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
530 | タクシー | タクシー | Taxi | Cab | タクシー is the katakana version of the English word taxi. The "xi" sound becomes クシー to fit better with Japanese pronunciation.
531 | お茶 | おちゃ | Tea |  | The お just makes the word more polite. Since tea is so important in Japan, it gets the お. Otherwise, you should be able to figure out the meaning as it's the same as the kanji. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading, just like you learned with the kanji.
532 | あれ | あれ | That One Over There | Those Ones Over There | You need a lens (あれ)? How about that one over there? You’re in a camera shop picking out a new lens, and that one over there looks good.\nUse あれ to refer to something that's far from both you and the person you're talking to.
533 | この | この | This | These | Remember how これ means "this one"? Well, この simply means this. The difference is that これ is used on its own, whereas この goes before a noun. For example, この人 means "this person".\nNotice how words like this starting with こ are close to you? We'll be learning a few more of these, and they all follow the same pattern!
534 | 今年 | ことし | This Year |  | The now year is which year? It is this year. \n With the first reading (the more common one), the こん of 今 is actually just こ. This gets shortened sometimes, so look out for it. Also, the 年 is the kun'yomi reading for some reason. It's a total mystery why this is. Perhaps the ancient aliens know, but I do not. You're going to have to remember this exception with that brain of yours and rely on the SRS to bestow this knowledge upon you.\nThe second reading, which is less common but still common enough, makes more sense. It is こんねん and just follows the jukugo patterns.
535 | 三百 | さんびゃく | Three Hundred |  | You have three hundreds. What does that come out to? Three hundred. \n The reading is a little bit weird, so be careful. You should already know the on'yomi readings, but the ひゃく rendakus to びゃく. This pattern will repeat itself with 三 + many counter kanjis that can rendaku, so pay attention for it as you read Japanese.
536 | 足す | たす | To Add Something |  | Remember 足りる? That is "to be enough." How can you make something be enough? You keep adding things to the pile until you reach that point where there are enough! That's why this verb is to add something, because you keep adding things until you 足りる.\nThis verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in す, which is why you are adding something. It's not getting itself added all by itself. Maybe you add so much that someone tries to sue (す) you for that nasty pile of squirrels you keep outside. \n The reading is the same as 足りる, so if you know that you can add things up to this.
537 | 出来る | できる | To Be Able To Do | To Be Ready\n To Be Made | When you exit and come, apparently it means to be able to do. I think of it like you're leaving a location (出) to do a task and then you come (来る) back after you did it. Perhaps you were waiting in a room training like someone from Dragonball. When you leave the room, you are ready to fight the enemy and win. You train in that room to be able to do whatever you need to do, and only leave and come back alive because you were able to do it.\nThis verb is really common and it has a wide range of meanings. It can also mean things like to be ready, for example a meal, and to be made, for example when saying what something is made from. It's commonly written in hiragana, but you'll see the kanji version too! \n The readings are a bit strange. They're both kun'yomi readings, where 出 is で and 来る is きる. This is different from the reading you originally learned with 来る (くる), though, so be careful. If you can remember that and remember the kun'yomi readings from the previous vocab, you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.
538 | 切れる | きれる | To Be Cut | To Snap\n To Expire\n To Run Out | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. The kanji means cut so this generally means that something is cut. Something breaks or snaps. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be cut or to snap. Another meaning of this verb is to expire or to run out. This could be various things like your passport, or a deadline for an assignment. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Here's a refresher to help you remember the  き portion of this word:\nSomething is snapping. Turns out that something is your arm. Your arm is a 木 (き) that grew out of you one day. "What's this ki doing here?" you ask. Then it suddenly breaks in half! "OW OW OW! My ki! It's been cut!!"
539 | 写る | うつる | To Be Photographed | To Be In A Photograph | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means copy, but what is a copy? It is basically a photograph, which is why this word means to be photographed, or to be in a photograph. You know this one is "to be photographed" because it ends with a る. Someone thinks you're "rude" so they're photographing you. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the うつ part. You're being rude, right? That's why you got photographed. Why are you rude? You're doing beatboxing, constantly saying うつうつうつ over and over again. Say it out loud, too.
540 | 行う | おこなう | To Carry Something Out | To Perform Something | The meaning of this word is pretty strange, having very little to do with the kanji meaning you learned. This word means to carry something out. Maybe you can think of it like someone is saying "You (う) go do that task!" to get yourself to carry out the task. Whatever you do, just know this is a weird exception word, so you may have to do some extra work to remember it. \n The reading is also a strange exception. You have to remember the おこな portion. Maybe this mnemonic will help:\nYou have to carry out a task but don’t know how. “Oh, Conan!” (おこな) you shout. You always shout “Oh, Conan!” when you have to carry out something tough, because it summons the spirit of Detective Conan. He’s a genius, so his spirit can help you with anything at all. Even your WaniKani reviews. Go ahead and try it now. Shout “Oh, Conan!” Did you do it? Good. Now carry out those reviews!
541 | 死ぬ | しぬ | To Die |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means death, so the verb version is to die. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
542 | 食べる | たべる | To Eat |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means eat so the verb version is to eat. \n You have to remember the た portion if you want to be able to read this word, which uses the kun'yomi reading. Think about yourself eating some tacos (た). Imagine yourself eating it, that raw beef taste in your mouth (either like it or hate it).
543 | 直す | なおす | To Fix | To Repair\n To Fix Something\n To Repair Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fix so this vocab word means to fix. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to learn the なお part. Think of it this way. You need to fix something! It's urgent! You have to fix it now! (なお). This will also work with the similar word, 直る, which you'll learn soon if you haven't already.
544 | 首になる | くびになる | To Get Fired | To Get Sacked | The になる part means "to become," so literally this means "to become neck." If you think about it, when something becomes neck, it has to do with you getting your head cut off (at the neck). But, in today's modern society we don't do that too often. Instead, this means you lose your job, aka to get fired. \n This word contains the reading you learned with the kanji. Everything else is hiragana.
545 | 生える | はえる | To Grow | To Spring Up\n To Sprout\n To Come Out | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 生きる means "to live?" Well this is what happens right after it starts to live. It begins to grow! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen something starts to grow it also learns to laugh. Imagine a little plant growing out of the ground laughing. "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" it says, as it sprouts out of the ground.
546 | 有る | ある | To Have | To Exist | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means have and so the verb version means to have. An alternative meaning is to exist though this refers only to non-living inanimate things, not moving and living things. So really, this is similar to "to have" as well.\nThe kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo have something is very nice. But now, the only thing you possess are screams. Imagine this. You are in a totally empty room with no possessions. You open a little box and look inside. It contains screams that yell: "AAAAHHHH" (あ).
547 | 東北 | とうほく | Tohoku | Tohoku Region\n Northeast Region | The East North area of Japan is called Tohoku or the Tohoku region. It was the region hit by the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake. This can also mean northeast region when talking about China or Japan, but for other countries (and for the direction) we'd use 北東. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
548 | 知る | しる | To Know | To Learn\n To Find Out | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means know so the verb version means to know. It can additionally refer to how one comes to know something, so it also means to learn or to find out. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to know everything there is to know about sheep (し). Why? Because you are a busybody who wants to know everything. But for now, you'll settle for sheep. Right now all you know is that sheep are soft, come in many colors, and that they have 360 degree vision with their weird, rectangle eyes. There's even more to know, so you better get on it!
549 | 東京 | とうきょう | Tokyo | Toukyou | The East Capital in Japan is Tokyo. If you look on a map and compare it to 京都 (Kyoto, the other capital in history), you'll see it's East of Kyoto, making it the East Capital, Tokyo. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
550 | 今夜 | こんや | Tonight | This Evening | The now night is the current night, aka tonight. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
551 | 亡くなる | なくなる | To Pass Away | To Become Deceased\n To Die | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This word is actually two words put together, though. 亡く means "be deceased." なる means "to become." So put that all together and you have to pass away or to become deceased. It's basically a polite way to say something died (死ぬ). \n To learn to read this kanji you have to remember the な part of 亡く, though our mnemonic will use the whole thing.\nIf you're about to become deceased, you are probably knocking (なく) on death's door.
552 | 広がる | ひろがる | To Spread Out | To Extend\n To Stretch | Remember 広い? Well this is like that, except a verb. When something does the action of getting wide, it means to spread out, to extend, or to stretch.\nYou already learned 広げる, which is used when YOU spread something. 広がる, on the other hand, means that something spreads out all on its own. It's worth mentioning that lots of intransitive verbs end in がる, and this is no exception. Just think how about a girl (がる) you know can do everything all by herself. She never needs help from anyone else. \n The reading is the same as 広い, too, so as long as you knew that you knew this reading as well.
553 | 取る | とる | To Take | To Take Something\n To Get Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means take, so the verb version is to take something. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this kun'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word.
554 | 思う | おもう | To Think |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means think so the verb version is to think. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with this kanji, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case:\nYou have to remember the おも part to read this word. To do this, though, you'll have to think about that guy... hmm... what was his name? He's on The Simpsons... he's the bartender? I think? Oh! Moe (おも) is his name! Thank you. Now I remember.\nIf you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one.
555 | 向く | むく | To Turn Toward | To Face\n To Be Suitable | You know that the kanji means yonder, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means to turn toward or to face. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.\nThis word can also mean to be suitable, as in a good fit for a job, role, or situation. After all, you turn toward the things you’re most suitable for, right? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou turn to face a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says moo (む).
556 | 歩く | あるく | To Walk |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means walk so the verb version means to walk. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to remember the ある portion. Imagine yourself going to walk outside. But, as you walk, you walk like a pirate. You have a peg leg, a parrot, and a hook. Lastly, you say "arrrrr" (ある). Go ahead, say it out loud while walking around your room like a pirate. It will help.
557 | 曲 | きょく | Tune | Piece Of Music\n Song\n Melody | This almost shares the meaning with the kanji. It's essentially the same thing, though when it's alone it refers to a specific piece of music (aka a tune). \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well, so you should be able to read it.
558 | 地中 | ちちゅう | Underground | Subterranean | If you're in the middle of the ground, then you're most likely underground. Are you a moleperson? That's pretty cool. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
559 | 地下 | ちか | Underground | Basement\n Cellar | Below the ground is underground. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
560 | 不安 | ふあん | Uneasiness | Anxiety\n Unease | When you're not relaxed, what do you feel? Uneasiness is what you'd feel. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
561 | 米国 | べいこく | United States Of America | United States\n America\n USA | America is the country of rice. I guess this is from all those rolling plains and such we have. Another way to say America in Japanese is アメリカ, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka United States Of America, United States, America, or USA. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
562 | 不明 | ふめい | Unknown | Unclear\n Uncertain\n Unsure | Something that is not bright is cloudy and fuzzy. What do you think when you look into the fuzzy clouds? It is the unknown, the unclear, the uncertain. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
563 | 大文字 | おおもじ | Uppercase Letters | Capital Letters\n Uppercase | You have big writing letters. What do you think these are? THAT WOULD HAVE TO BE UPPERCASE LETTERS, RIGHT? Whoops, sorry, caps lock was on for a moment, there. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, 大 uses the kun'yomi reading and 文 is an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:\nWhenever you see an uppercase letter, you shout "おお, Moe!" (おおも). Your buddy Moe taught you the letters in the first place, so when you get stuck, you yell for him to come help you. And he always does. What a good guy.
564 | 金星 | きんせい | Venus |  | The gold star is Venus. It's the only planet in our solar system that's the same color as gold. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
565 | どの | どの | Which |  | Remember how どれ means "which one"? どの has a very similar meaning: which. Whereas どれ is used on its own, どの is used before a noun to ask "which" out of three or more options. So for example, どの本 is "which book (out of that pile)?".\nNotice how question words often start with a ど? We'll be seeing more of these!
566 | 耳打ち | みみうち | Whisper In Ear | Whisper In One's Ear | You feel your ear getting… hit? This is the feeling of a whisper in your ear; perhaps a secret, or some other confidential tidbit of information. Whatever it is it has impact, which is why it feels like a hit!\nNote that this word is more often used in writing than in casual speech. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
567 | 冬休み | ふゆやすみ | Winter Holiday | Winter Break\n Winter Vacation | The winter rest! Wait, nobody calls it that. This is a winter holiday or winter break. \n The readings for these are both the kun'yomi readings. Hopefully you learned them when you were doing vocab in the previous levels so that all you have to do now is combine the two separate words into one bigger word. Please don't take a winter break until you figure this word out.
568 | 羊毛 | ようもう | Wool |  | A sheep's fur is wool. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
569 | 手首 | てくび | Wrist |  | Your hand's neck is your wrist! \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
570 | 年下 | としした | Younger |  | When you have someone who has years below your own, this person is younger than you. \n The reading for this one is kind of strange. It is the kun'yomi reading for both of the kanji. You know the kun'yomi readings from earlier, back when you learned the vocab 年 and 下.
571 | 妹 | いもうと | Younger Sister | Little Sister | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYour younger sister is really into emotes (いもうと). Look up this word if you're not a teenage girl. Just imagine her sending you these on your phone over and over. You tell your younger sister: "HEY, STOP SENDING ME EMOTES."
572 | 以後 | いご | After This | From Now On\n After\n Since | From after, just means after this or from now on. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
573 | この辺 | このへん | Around Here | This Area | この means "this" so この辺 just means this area. \n The reading for the kanji portion is just what you've already learned with the kanji 辺 so this shouldn't be a difficult one to read for you.
574 | 先回り | さきまわり | Arriving Ahead | Going Ahead\n Anticipation | If you get there previous to something rotating (回り), you are arriving ahead, or going ahead in anticipation. \n This consists of a couple kun'yomi readings put together. You can tell it's kun'yomi because of the hiragana sticking out at the end. In previous levels, you learned both the words 先 and 回る (verb version of 回り). If you know those, you should be able to put them together to learn the reading of this word as well.
575 | 風船 | ふうせん | Balloon |  | A wind boat. This is a strange one for sure. You may assume this is like one of those giant balloons you can go ride around in, and you'd be partly right. Really, this word covers the general word balloon, though it especially has to do with the toy-style balloons (or smaller balloons). It's a little round wind ship! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
576 | 〜札 | さつ | Bill | Note | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. When you see this word after a number, it’s for physical bills of money. \n This is a suffix that takes the on’yomi reading, which you’ve learned already!\nYou'll also see this pronounced ふだ, but that's when it's a standalone word or part of a compound, rather than a suffix. So if you answer with that reading, you'll be prompted to enter the suffix reading instead.
577 | 鳥 | とり | Bird |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nWhen you think about birds, what is the most common bird you can think of? What bird do you hate the most or like eating the most? Either one will work. Now, imagine yourself going up to that bird. You did something terrible. You tore (とり) off its wing and started eating it (pretend it's cooked first, if that makes you less nauseous).
578 | 黒い | くろい | Black |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of black? It's also black. Special Note: The noun version of black also exists in Japanese. It is just 黒 with the same pronunciation, but minus the い which makes it adjective-tastic. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThink of black things. One very common black thing is the common crow (くろ). Associate those two together.
579 | 黒人 | こくじん | Black Person | Black People | A black person is simply a Black person, kind of like how a 白人 is a "White person," but a different  color. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nImagine a Black person you know well wearing coke jeans (こくじん). Yep, jeans made entirely from coke bottles. That's actually a thing. Look it up if you don't believe me.
580 | 青空 | あおぞら | Blue Sky |  | This is simply a blue sky (aka a blue sky!). \n You'd think that this word would use on'yomi readings to read it, but it doesn't (shake that angry fist at the kanji gods!). Instead, it's double kun'yomi, probably because this word is really like two separate words put together, "blue" and "sky." In the previous level you unlocked these two separate words, learning their readings. That means you should be able to read this as well.\nOne quick note is the rendaku-fication of 空 as well. It becomes ぞら.
581 | 船 | ふね | Boat | Ship | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou're riding in a boat. It's great. Imagine it being the best time you've had in your life. You tell everyone: "This is fun, eh?" (ふね). You're on a Canadian ship, which is why you add the "eh" in there. Say this out loud wherever you are right now while imagining the sea smell, the wind, and the excitement of boats.
582 | 教室 | きょうしつ | Classroom |  | The teaching room is just a classroom. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
583 | 活用形 | かつようけい | Conjugated Form |  | You know that 活用 means "conjugation" and that 〜形 means "form," so that means this is the conjugated form! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
584 | 日記 | にっき | Diary | Journal | When you write down your day (and do it every day) that's your diary. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWhen you write down your day in your diary, in fact you write only about Nicky (にっき). You love Nicky so much, your diary is full of Nicky this, Nicky that. Ah, Nicky is just the best.
585 | 〜丁目 | ちょうめ | District Of A Town | City Block\n Town District\n District | A street you can see with your eye isn't soooo big you can't see it (like a town would be), but it's still pretty big because it has a street. This section of the town is the district of a town, or a city block (though specifically one of an irregular size). \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, so use those and you'll be A-Okay.
586 | 人形 | にんぎょう | Doll | Puppet | Something that is person shaped that isn't a person? That has to be some kind of doll or puppet. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, and the reading of 形 is a bit of an oddball, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nDid you know that all dolls at Nintendo are made out of gyoza dumplings (にんぎょう)? They'll also regularly try to get you to eat them... Mmmm, gyoza dolls. Don't be afraid to take a bite!
587 | 小学生 | しょうがくせい | Elementary School Student | Primary School Student | You know 学生 is student, so what is a small student? Think young. That would be an Elementary School Student. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
588 | 象 | ぞう | Elephant |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the ぞう reading of the kanji. You're at the ぞう show. How exciting.
589 | 月末 | げつまつ | End Of The Month | Month End | You know how 月 can also mean month? If you add 末 on there you have the "month end" aka the end of the month. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWhen it's the end of the month, everybody gets mats (げつまつ). We don't pay people in money at Tofugu, but everyone gets mats at the month end instead.
590 | 魚 | さかな | Fish |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nImagine a fish. Now imagine the fish playing soccer, while wearing a nun's outfit. This is a soccer nun (さかな).
591 | 床 | ゆか | Floor |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here’s a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:\nYou look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say yucka (ゆか) because it's covered in yucca (ゆか). Plus, it's all rotten. Yucka!
592 | 必死 | ひっし | Frantic | Desperate\n Certain Death\n Sure Death | Your future consists of certain death. How would you feel in this situation? Probably very frantic and desperate.\nAnother translation for this word is simply certain death, though I'd rather you learn one of the first two before this one if you can. \n The readings are the on'yomi readings, though 必 (ひつ) gets shortened to ひっ. In your desperate situation just imagine that you're trying to get out of it, and to do so you move the つ only to find a smaller っ blocking your way. It is certain death.
593 | 自由 | じゆう | Freedom | Liberty | When you have self reason, you are able to think for yourself. When you can think for yourself, you have freedom. Very philosophical, this vocab is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
594 | 氏名 | しめい | Full Name | First And Last Name | Both of these kanji have to do with names. You have both family name and name. Both of those names together makes for a First And Last Name... a full name if you will. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
595 | 未来 | みらい | Future | The Future\n Distant Future\n The Distant Future | What has not yet come? The future.\n未来 is usually used to talk about the distant future, and it implies that the future can’t be foreseen. So you can use it to speculate about what might lie ahead, but you probably wouldn’t use it to discuss more concrete plans, goals or predictions. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
596 | 地理 | ちり | Geography |  | The reason the earth is the way it is is because of the geography of it. Though it may seem kind of strange that geography is bringing reason to the earth, if you think of geography as a study, then you can think about how you try to get reason through that, as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
597 | 金魚 | きんぎょ | Goldfish |  | A gold fish is really just gold in color, but it's still called a goldfish. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
598 | 組 | くみ | Group | Team\n Class | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. That's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're part of a special group. It is the cumin group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice or seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group.\nP.S. This can also be spelled 組み (same overall reading: くみ).
599 | 手作り | てづくり | Handmade | Homemade | When something is hand made, it is handmade! \n The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. Just think of this word as two separate words put together (手 and 作る). The る in 作る gets changed to り because it's an adjective, and the つ in つくり gets changed to づ because of the way the words are combined with each other. You should know most of the reading that is in this word, though it will probably take a little bit of thinking to sort out the little changes in those readings.
600 | 大空 | おおぞら | Heavens | Firmament\n Sky\n Skies | The big thing in the sky is the heavens. The heavens where birds and planes soar, not the one you go to after you die if you've been really good. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that そら becomes ぞら because of rendaku here.
601 | 高校 | こうこう | High School | Senior High School | The tall school is for when your kids get about as tall as they're going to get. That's high school, when most people stop growing taller. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
602 | 作り方 | つくりかた | How To Make | Way To Make\n Way Of Making | This is the way to make something. This is how to make something. You'll see this for directions on building something. \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 作る and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
603 | 船体 | せんたい | Hull | Ship Hull | A boat's body is called the hull. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
604 | 人里 | ひとざと | Human Habitation | Village | A person's hometown is a human habitation, or a village. This word has a slightly old-fashioned feel, and it's usually used for small villages in the countryside.\nIt's often combined with はなれた (separated) to talk about how far away from the nearest human habitation something is. \n This jukugo uses the kun'yomi of the kanji instead of the more usual on'yomi. You learned both of these readings when you learned the vocabulary 人 and 里. Just notice that さと becomes ざと, because of rendaku.
605 | 大きく | おおきく | In A Big Way | On A Grand Scale | This is the adverb version of the kanji big. It's a little thing you can put in front of things to say that they are "in a big way" or "on a grand scale." \n Since you already know the reading of the vocab word 大きい, you should be able to read this word as well.
606 | 内ポケット | うちぽけっと | Inside Pocket |  | Your inside ポケット is your inside pocket. \n This word uses the kun'yomi for the kanji. You learned that reading when you learned the word 内.
607 | 近々 | ちかぢか | In The Near Future | Soon | When something is close close (the 々 character repeats the kanji that was before it) it will happen in the near future, or soon.\nThis is pretty vague, and it's up to the person speaking to decide how soon soon is. Depending on the person and the situation, it could technically be used for anything up to a few years! \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading twice; that's the one you learn with the vocab word 近い from the previous level. The second 近 gets converted to ぢか, though, so take note of that. To write the character ぢ, type "di" on your keyboard.
608 | 木星 | もくせい | Jupiter |  | The tree star is the planet Jupiter. Imagine Jupiter covered in very strange trees — the kind that are able to take root in gas! It's a pretty weird image, but will hopefully help you to remember this word. Alternatively, think about how the clouds around Jupiter make patterns that look a lot like wood grain. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
609 | 先週 | せんしゅう | Last Week |  | The previous week was last week. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
610 | 以下 | いか | Less Than | Or Less\n Not Exceeding\n Below | Compared with this, it's below. That's another way to say that what you have is less than it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
611 | 手紙 | てがみ | Letter |  | A hand paper is a letter because letters are generally written by hand on paper.\nIf you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it. \n The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it がみ, not かみ.
612 | 小声 | こごえ | Low Voice | Whisper | A small voice is so small that you can hardly hear it. It's a low voice or a whisper. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because, like in 大声, the こえ becomes ごえ thanks to our old friend rendaku.
613 | 火星 | かせい | Mars |  | The fire star is Mars. This should be easy to remember, because Mars is the only planet in our solar system that's the color of fire. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
614 | 心理 | しんり | Mental State | Psychology | The reasoning of your heart decides what you do. Probably when kanji was being made people thought that the heart directed our actions, not our brains. So, if you think about it that way, the reasoning of your heart is your mental state. Nowadays that's known as psychology. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
615 | 中学生 | ちゅうがくせい | Middle School Student | Junior High School Student | You've seen 学生 (means student). Now let's look at a student who's in the middle. Perhaps we can call this a middle school student or a junior high school student, depending on where you're from. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
616 | 〜分 | ふん | Minute | Minutes | What's part of an hour? A minute, or minutes! This word is the suffix version of 分, so it goes after numbers to say how many minutes, and is used for telling the time too. \n This uses a different on'yomi than what you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:\nHow many minutes of fun (ふん) will you have today? Lots and lots of minutes, I hope!\nDepending on the number before 分, its pronunciation can change to ぷん, because of rendaku. We're looking for the original reading ふん here though!
617 | 〜氏 | し | Mister | Madam\n Miss\n Mx | The kanji means family name because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word mister. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too. \n The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.
618 | 以上 | いじょう | More Than | Or More\n That's All | Compared with something else, this is above. That's another way to say that what you have is more than something else. That's all. ;) \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
619 | 映画 | えいが | Movie | Film | It's a reflection of an image on a screen, and the image is moving! What is this? It's a movie. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
620 | ナポレオン三世 | なぽれおんさんせい | Napoleon The Third | Napoleon III | Adding "third generation" to someone's name means that they are the third generation of people with that name. In this case, the person's name is ナポレオン (Napoleon), so this means Napoleon The Third, also written as Napoleon III. \n The kanji here are pronounced exactly the same as in the standalone word 三世. That is, it's a jukugo word which uses the on'yomi for both kanji.
621 | 近く | ちかく | Near | Neighborhood\n Vicinity\n Nearly\n Shortly | This is the noun version of the kanji near. So it also means near, or in the neighborhood of something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 近い, so you should be able to read this word as well.
622 | 海王星 | かいおうせい | Neptune |  | The ocean king's star is Neptune! If you know anything about Roman mythology this should be easy to remember! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
623 | 正月 | しょうがつ | New Year | New Year's Holidays\n Japanese New Year | You correct the moon because it's a New Year. It's the beginning of a fresh year, so you gotta have the moon in the correct position.\nThis usually refers to the first few days of a new year, and it's one of the biggest holidays in Japan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both of these kanji have a couple of on'yomi readings, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:\nAt New Year, you hate your Shougun's guts (しょうがつ). He doesn't celebrate New Year, you see, so none of you get any time off. He even started a war last New Year and ruined everyone's holidays. No wonder you hate that shougun's guts.
624 | 来週 | らいしゅう | Next Week |  | The next week is the next week. It isn't last week or this week, it's the next one! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
625 | 海魚 | かいぎょ | Ocean Fish | Saltwater Fish | An ocean fish is simply an ocean fish. They also happen to be the most delicious kind of fish. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nSome people also use the kun'yomi readings, but it's much less common, and generally considered colloquial.
626 | 〜時 | じ | O'Clock |  | If there's a number before 時, it means o'clock. For example １時 is 1:00, and ２３時 is 23:00 or 11pm. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
627 | お兄さん | おにいさん | Older Brother | Guy | This word starts with an お to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji 兄 which you already know. Lastly, it has さん which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying older brother (versus plain old 兄). It can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance. \n The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the 兄 part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour (kind) older brother pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your knee (にい), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you お兄さん!"
628 | 一斤 | いっきん | One Loaf of Bread | One Loaf | One bread loaf counter is counting one loaf of bread. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening though!
629 | 一時 | いちじ | One O'clock |  | When it's one o'clock it's one o'clock. It's time to eat lunch, or take a nap, or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
630 | 以外 | いがい | Other Than | Excepting\n Except For | Compared with this, it's outside what you wanted. You'll have anything other than that. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
631 | 紙 | かみ | Paper |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.
632 | 時代 | じだい | Period | Epoch\n Era\n Time Period | You have a period of time and it's called a period or era! Simple! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
633 | 以前 | いぜん | Previously | Before | From before, just means previously or before now. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
634 | 心理学 | しんりがく | Psychology |  | The reason your heart does what it does is all psychological. The study of that is psychology. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
635 | 本当に | ほんとうに | Really | Truly | 本当 is reality or truth (level 5 vocab). If you add on に, this changes the word to an adverb, and we get really or truly. 本当に! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It shares the reading with the level 5 本当 as well, but just has a particle on the end. Really!
636 | 理由 | りゆう | Reason | Motive\n Excuse | A reason reason is a reason! How could it not be? Do you have a reason why it shouldn't be? I thought not.\nThis word means "reason" as in the reason you're studying Japanese, or the reason you're late. That's why it can also mean similar words like motive and excuse. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
637 | 〜号室 | ごうしつ | Room Number | Suffix For Room Numbers | This is a counter that can be used after numbers to let you know what number room it is. It's a room number that you use in apartments and hotels to know exactly which room you're looking for. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
638 | 失礼 | しつれい | Rude | Rudeness\n Impoliteness\n Excuse Me | When you do something that's your fault and then you say "thanks" after you do it, that's super-duper rude, wouldn't you say? Imagine doing something like this and then thinking to yourself after... wow, I was really rude.\nThis is also often used to mean excuse me, typically followed by ですが or します. Occasionally, it’s also used just on its own, usually when the speaker holds a higher or equal status to the person being spoken to. This particular usage is more prevalent among older generations and is commonly associated with masculine speech. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
639 | 同時 | どうじ | Same Time |  | The same time? Okay, let's say what we think this word means at the same time. Whoops, I just said it, sorry. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
640 | 学校 | がっこう | School |  | A study school is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a school. \n This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except 学 (がく) is shortened with a small っ to make it がっこう.
641 | 形 | かたち | Shape | Appearance\n Form | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou really want to eat food that's in neat shapes, so you decide to use a cutter (かた) on your cheese (ち) to make it a new shape. Square cheese is so boring. After you cut it up you have mouse shaped cheese! It just tastes better like that.
642 | 欠点 | けってん | Shortcoming | Fault\n Drawback | You have a lack of points. These are things about yourself you wish were better. These are your shortcomings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out because けつ is being shortened to けっ here!
643 | 雪 | ゆき | Snow |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for this vocab word. Enjoy the snow!
644 | 社会 | しゃかい | Society |  | Not to be confused with 会社, which is a company, this is society. When a company meets together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a society. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
645 | 強力 | きょうりょく | Strong | Strength\n Powerful | You have strong power. You are strong and powerful. Feel your strength. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nNothing is as strong and powerful as the きょうと lock (きょうりょく). It's a legendary lock produced in ancient きょうと, rumored to be the strongest lock in existence. What magical powers do you think lie behind the strength of the きょうと lock?
646 | 強い | つよい | Strong |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strong? It's also strong. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSo you wanna be strong huh? Well, all you have to do is eat these two yogurts (つよ). One is filled with horse steroids, the other is full of bull steroids. They will make you so strong.
647 | 夏 | なつ | Summer |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.
648 | 夏休み | なつやすみ | Summer Vacation | Summer Break\n Summer Holiday | You know that 夏 means summer and 休 means rest. What is a "summer rest" though? It's a summer break or summer vacation. \n The readings are kun'yomi readings because this word is essentially two separate words put together into one word. You should know the reading for 夏 from the kanji and the reading for 休み from the vocab.
649 | 必ず | かならず | Surely | Certainly\n Without Exception\n Always\n Definitely | This word looks like a verb but it's not (sorry!). It's an adverb. The kanji itself means certain and the vocab version means all sorts of variations on that: surely, certainly, and without exception to name a few. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nRa, the Egyptian god asks you: "Can you do it? Are you certain you can build the pyramids?"\n"Yes I can ra (かなら). Yes I can," you reply.
650 | 白鳥 | はくちょう | Swan |  | There are many white birds out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the swan. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
651 | 仕組み | しくみ | System | Structure\n Mechanism | Doing something as a group requires a system. Without some sort of structure, everyone does their own thing, and you would never be able to get stuff done as a group, you know?\n仕組み refers to the concept of a "mechanism" or "system." It includes the underlying structure, organization, or framework that governs how something works or operates, highlighting its logic, order, and other often unseen things. \n This is a word with an irregular combination of readings. 仕 uses its on'yomi reading, and 組 uses its kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this unusual combination:\nTo be more successful in doing group assignments, you came up with a system called "sheep cumin (しくみ). Why "sheep cumin"? Sheep are known to be good team players (or herd players, should I say?), so you just sticked it to the name of the group you lead, the cumin group, hoping everyone can work together better, like sheep!
652 | 高い | たかい | Tall | High\n Expensive | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of tall or expensive? It's the same: tall or expensive.\nWeird that this word means both of these things, yeah? Just imagine money piled up to be really tall. That money is tall because it needs to buy something expensive. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nBeing tall is really expensive because you have to buy a tall car (たか). If it's not a tall car then your tall body won't fit inside, and those tall cars are expensive!
653 | その | その | That | Those | Remember how それ means "that one"? その has a very similar meaning: that. It's used before a noun that's either close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you. For example, その本 is "that book", and the book in question might be in the hand of the person you're talking to, or it might be on a shelf not far from you both.
654 | あの | あの | That Over There | Those Over There | Remember how あれ means "that one over there"? Well, あの means that, and goes before a noun to point out something that is far away from both you and the person you're talking to, such as あの本 (that book over there) or あの子犬 (that puppy over there).\nNotice how these words starting with あ are far away from you? We'll be learning a few more of these, and they all follow the same pattern! What's more, you’ll notice that words ending in の tend to go before a noun.
655 | 末 | すえ | The End | End | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou've reached the end of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. Sue, eh?(すえ) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out, "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"
656 | 一体 | いったい | The Heck | In The World\n On Earth | Okay, so this one is really weird, sorry. Each of us only get one body in our lifetimes, right? Well what the heck! What if I want more than one body. Let's all be mad about this together. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because いち is shortened to いっ here!
657 | 国民 | こくみん | The People | Citizens\n National | The country peoples are the people of your country. They are the people. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
658 | 今週 | こんしゅう | This Week |  | The now week is this week. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
659 | 考え | かんがえ | Thought | A Thought | This is a noun version of think. What is "a think"? It's a thought. \n You learned this reading with 考える, just cut off the る!
