831 | 角度 | かくど | Angle |  | An angle degree is just an angle. 90 degrees? 160 degrees? They're all still angles when you come down to it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
832 | 発表 | はっぴょう | Announcement | Presentation | I'm going to express my departure. That is my only announcement. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ひょう changes to ぴょう and the はつ gets shortened, though, so just about everything about this word is weird.
833 | 記事 | きじ | Article | News Story\n Report\n Account\n News Article | When you write down a lot of stuff focusing on one thing it's called an article. If it's on something that just happened it will probably be a news story. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
834 | 仮定 | かてい | Assumption | Assume | A temporary determination is something you're not totally sure about. You've decided to think of something in a certain way, but only for now. If more information comes to light, you may change your mind. That's why this word means assumption.\n仮定 refers to making tentative assumptions about a specific situation to discuss what might happen under certain conditions, such as "if we assume I dropped my wallet here yesterday...” \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
835 | 通り | とおり | Avenue | Street\n Road\n Way | You know the word 通る hopefully by now. That is the verb version of this word, which means "to pass through." So, if this is the noun version, what is it that you use to pass through something? To drive or walk along? That would be an avenue (or street, road, etc). This is a pretty common word in Japan, and good for not getting lost. \n The reading is the same as the word 通る, so as long as you know that, you should be able to read this one as well. Mind the strange long お sound!
836 | 美しい | うつくしい | Beautiful |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. More precisely, it has しい on the end, which makes it even more likely it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of beauty? It's beautiful. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you. It's a long reading for a mnemonic, but try your best.\nYou look at someone who is beautiful. What an easy life they've lived. No hard work and all they do is pamper themselves to stay beautiful. Feel disgusted. You walk up to this person and say: "U too cushy! (うつくしい).\nSorry for adding the whole word in there for the reading mnemonic, but I thought it worked out better that way. Just know that the word isn't うつくしいしい or something weird like that. The hiragana on the end is part of the mnemonic as well.
837 | 美人 | びじん | Beautiful Woman |  | A beautiful person is a beautiful woman. Wait, why isn't this a beautiful person? In fact, this word used to have a broader meaning, but for some reason it's generally only used for women in modern Japanese. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWhere you're from, every beautiful woman wears bee jeans (びじん). That's right, jeans made out of bees. Beauty knows no pain after all!
838 | 気を付けて | きをつけて | Be Careful | Take Care | This word contains the words 気 (energy) and 付ける (to attach). So, when you attach energy to something you're focusing in on it, right? This word is a sort of "order" as well, since it's te-form there at the end. It's a set phrase people say to other people who are doing dangerous things. It's kind of like saying "Attach energy to what you're doing! Stay focused!" A simpler way to translate this would be to say this word means be careful or take care, though. Learn this word so that you can always show that you're caring for your friends! \n The readings come from the two words 気 and 付ける. So long as you know those from the previous levels, you should be able to read this one as well.
839 | 白黒 | しろくろ | Black And White | White And Black | Something is both white and black. It is black and white (you can also say white and black if you prefer). \n The readings are kun'yomi, but you should have seen both 白 and 黒い separately as vocabulary by now. It's the same readings here, so you can apply that knowledge and read this word!
840 | 体重 | たいじゅう | Body Weight |  | How heavy is your body? Figure that out and you'll have your body weight. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
841 | 本屋 | ほんや | Bookstore | Bookshop | A book shop is a shop that sells books. A bookstore. \n The readings are the ones that you learned with the kanji.
842 | 肉屋 | にくや | Butcher Shop | Meat Shop\n Meat Store | A meat shop is a place that sells meat. Who sells meat? A butcher shop. \n For 肉 you use the にく reading (which you learned with the kanji). For 屋 you use the kun'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Basically, if you learned the kanji readings, you can read this word!
843 | 交代 | こうたい | Change | Substitution\n Shift | If you mix and substitute two people, that's a change of personnel, or a substitution. Perhaps those people are even working in shifts, so they mix and substitute each other at regular intervals.\nYou'll see this word in pretty diverse contexts, because it can refer to anything from a change of political regime, to the substitution of a player during a match, to factory shifts. The underlying meaning is that one person or group is switched out with another. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nA change calls for a tie (たい). If you're the new company president, or you're going in to work to start your shift, you'd better make sure you look the part, so get that tie nice and straight.
844 | 服 | ふく | Clothes | Clothing | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji and uses the on'yomi even though it's a single word. Very strange, but convenient for you so long as you remember this exception reading word.
845 | 工事 | こうじ | Construction |  | Construction occurrences are just construction.\n工事 can refer to all kinds of construction, including the construction of roads, buildings, water and power lines, and more. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
846 | 相談 | そうだん | Consultation | Discussion\n Advice | A mutual talk. Both sides are talking to each other and the feelings are mutual. Imagine you're discussing a problem. You want to get help with it, so you get some consultation from your friend. This discussion was very helpful. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
847 | 対比 | たいひ | Contrast | Comparison | When you look at something versus something else, you compare them with one another. You look at the contrast between them and make a comparison. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
848 | 〜ヶ月 | かげつ | Counter For Months | Month Counter | Alright, so this one's a bit weird. See that oddly small ヶ there? Well, together with 月 (month), it becomes a counter for months. You'll use this when you want to talk about a specific number of months, so not when you're saying January, February, etc.\nNote that you'll run into different variants of this. While 一ヶ月 is the most common, you'll also encounter 一か月, 一カ月, and rarely 一箇月. Luckily, they're all read the same, just written differently. Speaking about reading, let's get to it. \n The little ヶ might be slightly misleading, as you'll have to read this as か. The rest is easy though, as 月 just takes a normal on'yomi reading. And since we're not talking about specific months, that means it's just げつ, making this 〜かげつ.
849 | 決定 | けってい | Decision | Determination | It's been decided and determined. The decision has been made. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened けつ in 決. It goes to けっ.
850 | 〜度 | ど | Degrees | Times | The kanji degree can mean both degree in terms of angles and degree in terms of temperature. This word is how you talk about these things. Just attach it to a number and you have yourself the number of degrees that something is. After the numbers 1, 2 and 3 (and in some other situations) this can also mean times. \n The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned. When writing out the answer to this reading, omit the 〜 as it's only there to let you know that some other word should come before it.
851 | 出発 | しゅっぱつ | Departure |  | You exit and then make a departure. This is just a departure. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゅつ gets shortened and はつ changes to ぱつ. No wonder you want to make a departure, you want to get away from crazy readings like this.
852 | 不自由 | ふじゆう | Discomfort | Inconvenience\n Disability\n Impairment\n Poverty\n Destitution | Remember how 自由 means freedom? Well when you add not it causes you discomfort and really inconveniences you. That not is in the way of your freedom. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
853 | 発見 | はっけん | Discovery |  | You make departure from your home off into the great beyond. You will go to see the unseen, and hopefully make a great discovery. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the はつ part, which gets shortened to はっ. The 見 is unlike what you learned with 見, though.\nIn order to remember that this is けん, imagine you're going out to make a discovery of some strange new lands. With strange new lands, there comes strange new people. This one has a samurai named Ken けん on it. He's trying to discover new things too!
854 | 二重 | にじゅう | Double | Dual | When you have two heavy things, you have double and dual the heavy (compared to one, at least).\nThis word is a prefix attached to other words to show that it is "double." 二重 kanji time! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
855 | 毎度 | まいど | Each Time | Every Time\n Frequently | When something happens at every occurrence and at every degree, it's something that happens frequently. It happens each time. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
856 | 楽勝 | らくしょう | Easy Victory | Easy Win\n Piece Of Cake | A win that was an ease. That is an easy victory or an easy win. Don't hope for a lot of these, though. Hope for tough wins instead, they actually make you better.\nNote that this can be used both literally, to describe an easy victory at a game or contest; or more figuratively, to describe something as “easy” in general. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
857 | 小学校 | しょうがっこう | Elementary School | Primary School\n Grade School | You've seen 学校 from a couple levels ago. Now we're adding a small to it. What is a "small school"? That's a school for small people, making it an elementary school. \n The reading is the regular on'yomi reading of 小 plus the vocab word 学校 that you've seen previously. Combine these two things for the reading of 小学校.
858 | 重要 | じゅうよう | Essential | Important\n Necessary | When something has a heavy need, you know that that thing is essential. It is important. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
859 | 丁度 | ちょうど | Exactly | Just | Okay, we're going to cheat a little bit to remember the meaning of this word. Let's say you take the temperature of the street. It is exactly one hundred degrees. That's exactly what it is. Just 100 degrees, not one degree more or less. You put your eggs on the street and watch them cook. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
860 | 試験 | しけん | Examination | Test\n Experiment | If you attempt a test, you're taking an examination. There are a lot of these in Japan, so make sure you know this word if you want to fit in with all the whining and whinging that students do, especially come the final year of high school. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
861 | 体験 | たいけん | Experience |  | Your body goes through tests and each time it does, it gains a little more experience. What has your body experienced? What tests has your body been through? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
862 | 実験 | じっけん | Experiment |  | A test that tries to find truth is an experiment. This is because you don't know the truth, so the only way to find it is to try things out and test them. Thus, experiment! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Take note that the つ in じつ is turned into a small っ, though.
863 | 事実 | じじつ | Fact | Factual\n In Fact | The occurrence of truth is a fact.\n事実 is primarily used as a noun, but it can also be used to say something is factual. Additionally, in relatively formal writing it can be used as an adverb to mean in fact. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
864 | 火事 | かじ | Fire |  | A fire matter is a fire, as in the destructive burning of something. There's a fire! Run, run away!\n火事 is often used for when houses or other buildings are on fire. If you hear someone shout 火事だ, it's probably time to get out of wherever you are. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
865 | 魚屋 | さかなや | Fish Shop | Fish Market\n Fish Dealer\n Fish Store\n Fishmonger | A fish shop is a fish shop, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important. \n The kun'yomi reading is used for the 魚 (so it's さかな) and the kun'yomi reading is used for 屋 (や). You'll have to use the reading of 魚 from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.
866 | 試食 | ししょく | Food Sample | Taste | Go ahead and try an eat. How was that little try? That little food sample? That little taste?\nYou know when you walk into the supermarket and have people offering you the tiniest cube of cheese? That's what this is. So this word is commonly used in the context of product demonstrations or food events. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
867 | 映像 | えいぞう | Footage | Video\n Image | You see reflections of a statue on a screen, and the statue reflections are moving! That means this is footage, or video.\n映像 refers to images in various forms of visual media. While it's most commonly used to describe moving images in videos or films, it can also refer to mental images — those pictures or scenes that come to mind, reflecting personal memories or imagination. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
868 | 表 | おもて | Front | Exterior\n Face\n Outside\n Appearance | This is the noun version of the kanji express. If you want to understand what something is trying to express you usually look at its front or its exterior. This word is usually used for the exterior face of buildings. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're standing in front of a building, staring at its front. You spend some time gazing at it before you realize what it is. "Oh, motel (おもて)", you say aloud. A little time looking at the exterior and you're able to figure it out.
869 | 家具 | かぐ | Furniture |  | Your house tools aren't the tools you use to build a house. They're more like the things that are a part of your house that you use like tools. Those things would be your furniture. So, remember, your house tools are just furniture. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the か reading with 家事, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:\nThe best kind of furniture is a car (か). If you think about it, anybody would be impressed to find a car inside your house. Is that a car, they'd ask. Oh, that's just a piece of furniture, you'd say, I use it as a bed. Car furniture is such a flex.
870 | ガラス | ガラス | Glass | Pane of Glass | This comes from the word glass, and it refers to the stuff used to make Cinderella's slippers, and windows, in which case it can also mean a pane of glass.\nWe'll learn how to say the other meanings of "glass" later!
871 | お客さん | おきゃくさん | Guest | Visitor\n Customer | The さん on the end is the name honorific さん. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word guest, visitor, or customer. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the お客さん, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear お客さま which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in さま and not さん). \n The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.
872 | 客室 | きゃくしつ | Guest Room |  | A guest's room is the guest room (the room you put guests in, duh!). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
873 | ハート形 | はーとがた | Heart Shaped |  | ハート is of course "heart" and you know that 形 means shape. You've probably already figured this one out. It's heart shaped.\nYou can add this kanji to all sorts of other things too to say "____ shaped." Give it a try! \n The reading for the kanji portion uses the kun'yomi reading. This is kind of like the reading you already learned for 形 just without the ち part. And rendaku happens too, so it becomes がた. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this reading too!
874 | 高さ | たかさ | Height |  | You've seen the word 高い from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like 大きい versus 大きさ, where one describes the other. In this case, the 高さ is the height of something (while 高い is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask いくらですか？ (how much is it?). \n Use the reading of 高い (たかい) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They're the same except for the hiragana at the end.
875 | 高校生 | こうこうせい | High School Student | High Schooler | You know 高校 means "high school." So, a "life" that does high school is a high school student. This is like how 中学生 are middle school students and 小学生 are elementary school students! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Use the reading of 高校 from before to learn the reading of this word as well, if it helps.
876 | 家事 | かじ | Housework | Chores | You know 事 means "occurrence," but it also means "matter." So you can think of a house matter as  as housework or chores. Housework and chores are really just house matters that you have to deal with, after all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 家 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nHousework done in a car (か) is still housework. Think of all the times you've tidied up your car. That's housework too!
877 | 何度 | なんど | How Many Times | How Often\n What Temperature | If someone asks you what occurrence or what degrees they're really trying to ask you how many times something happened. Sometimes they're asking what temperature it is too. \n The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
878 | 画像 | がぞう | Image | Picture | An image of an image is still an image. This can also be a picture.\n画像 can refer to all sorts of images and pictures, but these days it's mostly used for the digital kind. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
879 | 大事 | だいじ | Important | Valuable | You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And if something is a  big matter to someone, it must be a very important and valuable thing to them.\n大事 describes something that holds great importance or value. For example, you can use 大事 to describe something or someone that matters a lot to you. You can also use 大事 to describe a crucial task or moment. And if you want to bring up a serious topic, you may say that you have something 大事 to talk about. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nNothing in your life is as important or valuable to you as dyes (だい). You really just love dyes more than anything else. Dyes, dyes, dyes!
880 | 和風 | わふう | Japanese Style |  | The Japanese style style. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu!\nNote that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
881 | 和服 | わふく | Japanese Style Clothes | Japanese Clothing\n Japanese Style Clothing\n Japanese Clothes | Japanese style clothes (Japanese Style Clothes). We're talking kimonos and yukata and things like that. Basically, this differentiates Japanese clothing from Western clothing.\nWhat kind of clothes will you wear to the festival tonight? Oh, probably some 和服. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
882 | 和食 | わしょく | Japanese Style Food | Japanese Food | Japanese style eat ... well, let's change "eat" to "food" and you have Japanese style food. This is a good way to differentiate between an American style restaurant and a Japanese style restaurant. What kind of food you feeling like tonight? Oh, how about some 和食? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
883 | 和室 | わしつ | Japanese Style Room |  | A Japanese style room tends to be pretty small. This mainly refers to the kind of room that's covered in tatami mats, though. If you're looking for places to stay in Japan, a 和室 will be something like that. You'll pull the futon out of the closet and sleep on the floor. So comfy, these Japanese style rooms! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
884 | 仮名 | かな | Kana |  | The temporary names. These are the kana (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are kana the "temporary names" though? Maybe they were just meant to be a temporary way to write the names of the kanji you didn't know how to write yet. That's just a guess, but it should help you remember that this word means "kana." \n Okay, so 仮 uses the rare kun'yomi reading か, which you haven't learned yet, but luckily it's the same as the on'yomi you have learned! And 名 also uses a kun'yomi reading that you learned with the vocab word 名 (な). So you sort of know these readings already, but it's a lot to take in, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nThe reading is so tricky for kana that it makes you say かな… (I wonder…) whenever you try to read it. You keep thinking, "Is the reading kana, かな? Or could it be something else, かな?" You're just not sure.
885 | 空手 | からて | Karate |  | What can you do with empty hands? Karate, that's what. Karate is practiced without weapons, so with empty hands! \n This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji, and you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 空 yet. As long as you know the meaning, the reading should be easy, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:\nKarate comes from (から) Japan!
886 | 保持 | ほじ | Keep | Hold\n Maintain\n Retain | When you preserve the things you hold on to, you're keeping them. In other words, you're holding and maintaining them!\nNote that 保持 is a formal word that's commonly used in professional or official contexts. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
887 | キロ | キロ | Kilo | Kilogram\n Kilometer\n Kilowatt | キロ comes from kilo, and it can mean kilogram, kilometer, or any unit that starts with "kilo" in English.\nYou can also use abbreviations like "kg" and "km" in Japanese, and they're often just pronounced キロ too.
888 | 生保 | せいほ | Life Insurance |  | A Life guarantee is something you get on someone else. If their life ends, it's guaranteed with money. That's a life insurance policy, for yah! (A.K.A. life assurance in some parts of the world!) \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
889 | 明かり | あかり | Light |  | What makes it bright around here? It's the light!\nNow you might wonder: how is this different from 光 (ひかり)? 光 is more general, and often used specifically for sunlight. 明かり often refers to some specific source of light, like the kind that illuminates a room, so it's often used for light that comes from lamps. \n Do you remember the adjective 明るい (あかるい), meaning "bright"? As you can see, these words are quite similar! You just need to remember that the か in 明かり isn't part of the kanji, like in 明るい.
890 | 生物 | せいぶつ | Living Thing | Creature\n Organism | A life thing is a living thing, a creature, or an organism. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
891 | 名物 | めいぶつ | Local Specialty | Famous Product\n Specialty\n Famous Goods | The famous thing of an area is their famous product, but it sounds better in English if you say it's the local specialty. When you're traveling around Japan, be sure to be on the lookout for the 名物! It's always fun. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
892 | 要点 | ようてん | Main Point | Gist\n Main Idea\n Essence | The needed point is the main point. It's the gist of what you're trying to say. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
893 | 勝負 | しょうぶ | Match | Showdown\n A Gamble | Win, lose... both will happen in tonight's match! What a showdown it will be!\nNote that 勝負 can also describe situations where one takes a significant risk or makes a bold move— a gamble —with high stakes involved. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that ふ becomes ぶ because of rendaku here.
894 | 食事 | しょくじ | Meal | Diet\n Dining | A regular eating occurrence is also known as a meal.\n食事 can refer to a specific meal, like breakfast, lunch, or dinner. It can also mean your overall diet, like the kinds of foods you usually eat. 食事 can even be a verbal noun for the act of dining, so 食事する can be used to talk about having a meal. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
895 | 中学校 | ちゅうがっこう | Middle School | Junior High School | You know that 学校 means school. So, people who are in the middle school are in... wait for it... middle school.\nAnd, of course, if you're one of those people that call it junior high school you can do that too. \n The reading is a combination of 学校 and 中. Really, it's all on'yomi too, so you should be able to read this one. Take note of the がく turning to がっ, though.
896 | ほとんど | ほとんど | Most | Almost All\n Hardly | What can be eaten hot on dough (ほとんど)? Most things can. Almost all things, in fact. Hardly anything tastes bad when it's hot and served on dough.
897 | 辛子 | からし | Mustard | Japanese Mustard\n Karashi | The spicy child is the child of spicy. So, not as spicy as mamma spicy, but still a bit spicy. This child spicy is mustard. Not too spicy, but not too mild.\n辛子 generally refers to Japanese mustard, which tends to be browner and stronger than マスタード (Western mustard). Sometimes, especially as a prefix, it can also indicate spiciness from red pepper, like 辛子マヨネーズ (spicy mayo). \n The reading is 辛い (からい) and the on'yomi reading for 子 combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.
898 | 名古屋 | なごや | Nagoya |  | The place that's famous for old roofs. I don't know why, but it's the city of Nagoya. Just associate the two things together and it'll be hard to forget (so long as you've heard of Nagoya before - if not, read up about it!). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji (except for 名 and 屋, which are kun'yomi here). If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For な just think to 名前 (なまえ) which uses the な reading. The "name" (名前) of this city is what? It's Nagoya. Watch out for rendaku changing こ to ご too.
899 | 必要 | ひつよう | Necessary | Needed\n Essential | It's certain that you need it. This thing is necessary. It is needed. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
900 | 付近 | ふきん | Neighborhood | Vicinity\n Environs\n Nearby\n Locality | If you attach things near you, they end up being in the same neighborhood as you. They're attached nearby so they can't go much further. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 付 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour neighborhood is full of fools (ふ). Fools everywhere. You're probably one too, since you live nearby.
901 | 新しい | あたらしい | New |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of new? It's new. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour family buys you a new Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an Atara... a knockoff video game system :(
902 | 新年 | しんねん | New Year |  | A new year is a new year. Hope you had / have / are having a good one, depending on when you read this. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
903 | 海 | うみ | Ocean | Sea | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou visit the sea. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "um, me?" (うみ). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.
904 | 一ヶ月 | いっかげつ | One Month |  | Remember the 〜ヶ月 counter? Replace the 〜 with a one and this becomes one month. \n 一 uses the on'yomi you learned with it, but gets shortened, so watch out for that. The rest is as you learned it!
905 | 出身 | しゅっしん | One's Origin | One's Hometown\n One's Birthplace | The exit that somebody starts from is one's origin, one's hometown, or one's birthplace. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the つ of 出, which becomes っ.
906 | 元々 | もともと | Originally | From The Beginning\n By Nature | It's the origin of all origins, so it's the way it was originally, from the beginning, or by nature. You get the idea.\nNote that this is frequently written in just hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version too! \n This is just the kun'yomi reading you learned with 元, but twice, so you should be good to go!
907 | あそこ | あそこ | Over There |  | Remember how words beginning with あ show that whatever you're talking about is far away from both you and the person you're talking to? And how words ending in こ refer to places? So what do you think this means? That right, it's over there.\nJust watch out for the extra そ in this word. If you need help remembering this, imagine a sock oh (あそこ) so far over there. It's lucky that it's so far over there, because that sock stinks. You can still smell it, even though it's all the way over there in the distance.
908 | 苦しい | くるしい | Painful | Agonizing | This word ends in い, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. In fact, it ends in しい, which makes it even more likely it's an adjective. The kanji 苦 means suffering, so what could a related adjective be? This word means painful or agonizing. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEverything is really painful right now. Why? You have something heavy on top of you, crushing (くる) you.
909 | 平和 | へいわ | Peace | Harmony | The flat peace. This is a peace that will last, because there's no waves... no ripples... just flat. This is plain old peace. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
910 | 予定 | よてい | Plan | Schedule\n Estimate | Something has been determined beforehand. What is this thing? This action? It is a plan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
911 | 部分 | ぶぶん | Portion | Section\n Part | Part of a part? That's a portion, a section of that part, and even a part in itself! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
912 | 〜県 | けん | Prefecture |  | Attach this word onto the end of a prefecture place name and you have the prefecture portion of _____ prefecture. These are a lot like states or provinces. \n The reading for this is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's always attached to things (so it's like jukugo). Don't write the 〜 when you're writing in the answer, just the けん portion, and you'll get this one correct.
913 | 発音 | はつおん | Pronunciation |  | The sound that departs from your mouth is you talking. Imagine yourself saying things and words departing your mouth. They are bent in different ways and have different colors, highlighting your pronunciation of certain words and phrases. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
914 | 心強い | こころづよい | Reassuring | Heartening | Things that make your heart strong are reassuring and heartening to hear. You can practically feel your heart becoming stronger in your chest. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words 心 and 強い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just note that つよい gets rendaku'd to づよい!
915 | 返事 | へんじ | Reply | Response | You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." And if you return the matter to another person, you're giving a reply or response. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
916 | 住民 | じゅうみん | Residents | Citizens | They dwell here, these people. So what are they? They’re residents. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
917 | 部屋 | へや | Room |  | If you have a part of a roof, that part is your room. Just imagine a roof divided into sections in a house, with the sections going all the way down to the ground. Each section is its own room, right? \n 部屋 is a bit tricky because it's one of the few Japanese words that use the へ reading for 部. You'll just have to remember this one is special. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nImagine you're renting out a room, but all you hear at night is a constant "heh (へ)… heh... heh... hehehe". An incessant snickering, coming from somewhere inside your room. Hehehe.
918 | 発売 | はつばい | Sale | Selling | You want things to depart from your store so you have to sell them. You put all these things up for sale. You are selling these items. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
919 | 辛い | からい | Spicy | Hot\n Difficult\n Painful | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That being said, this can also mean difficult or painful, often in a psychological sense, though it can be physical as well. I guess if you're in a spicy situation it's going to be a difficult one. \n Depending on the context, the reading for this word could be からい or つらい.\nThe からい reading is the spicy one that you learned with the kanji, which you can remember because spicy foods give a からて chop to your mouth.\nThe つらい reading is the difficult or painful one. You can remember this because two Ras (つら) are way more difficult to deal with than one Ra.
920 | 辛口 | からくち | Spicy Taste | Dry Taste\n Dry Tasting\n Harsh | If you put something spicy in your mouth you'll end up with a spicy taste or a dry taste in there. Spice sucks up all your mouth moistness. \n This is the kun'yomi readings together. You should have learned them both by now.
921 | 立場 | たちば | Standpoint | Position | Your stand location is your standpoint or your position.\nNote that 立場 usually refers to the position somebody takes in a particular situation, but can also refer to somebody's position in society. \n This is a bit of a weird one, since it uses kun'yomi and not on'yomi. What's more, how you read 立 is slightly different from what you'd expect. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember how to read 立 this time:\nTalking about your standpoint can be a touchy (たち) subject. You should watch out since people can get touchy when you give your standpoint on things!
922 | 星 | ほし | Star |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nA star is just a whole sheep (ほし) floating in the sky. If it wasn't a whole sheep, it wouldn't shine so brightly and you wouldn't be able to see it from Earth. Don't let anyone tell you stars are made of gas. The whole thing is sheep, okay?
923 | 〜屋 | や | Store | Shop | You'll see this attached to other words... like "meat" or "fish." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ store, making this word mean store (same as the kanji). \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.
924 | 仮に | かりに | Supposing | If | The kanji itself means temporary. When you add the に, we're asking you to imagine a situation temporarily, so the meaning changes to supposing or if. \n The reading is kun'yomi, so here's a mnemonic to remember it:\nIf you don't mind, could you carry (かり) this for me? Supposing it's not too much trouble, of course.
925 | 必勝 | ひっしょう | Sure Victory | Certain Victory\n Sure Win\n Certain Win | A certain win sounds like a great thing. When these two kanji are put together, a certain victory is inevitable. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the つ in ひつ is turned into a small っ, though.
926 | 泳ぎ | およぎ | Swimming | Swim | This is the noun version of the kanji swim, so it means swimming. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
927 | 目次 | もくじ | Table Of Contents |  | Your eye is on what's next. How is this possible to see what's coming up? That's because you're looking at a table of contents. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
928 | 札 | ふだ | Tag | Amulet\n Label\n Playing Card | This word is almost the same as the kanji, but only half of it. It means tag or amulet. They're about the same shape and size as money, but you can't buy a house with them (...probably). \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou can't find your tag anywhere. It was just there, you swear, but now it's nowhere to be found. You search for it everywhere, then you realize... it was right there all along. Seriously? You're such a fool, duh (ふだ)!
929 | 受験 | じゅけん | Taking An Exam | Taking A Test | When you accept a test you are taking an exam or taking a test. Good luck! A++++! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
930 | 対談 | たいだん | Talk | Discussion\n Interview | A versus talk is when you sit down with another person and have a talk. As you're talking, it might evolve into a discussion. Or perhaps you're there to have an interview.\n対談 is usually a formal discussion between two or more individuals, often organized ahead of time, and with a specific purpose or topic in mind. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
931 | 用事 | ようじ | Task | Errand\n Things To Do | If there's a task occurrence, then there's something you have to do, a.k.a. a task or errand.\n用事 generally refers to tasks that you personally need to take care of. Often that means errands like buying groceries or paying bills. It could also mean a doctor's appointment, meeting with a friend, or work tasks like attending a meeting and finishing an assignment. It's anything on your list of things to do! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
932 | 教え | おしえ | Teaching | Instruction\n Teachings\n Lesson\n Doctrine | This is the noun version of the kanji teach. So it means teaching. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 教える, so you should be able to read this word as well.
933 | 茶屋 | ちゃや | Tea Shop | Tea Store\n Tea House | A tea shop is a tea shop. Mmm, delicious, delicious tea. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
934 | 十分間 | じゅっぷんかん | Ten Minutes |  | You've got a ten minute interval of time. That simply makes this ten minutes.\nNote that, as we mentioned on the page for 〜間, you can omit 間 and this will still mean ten minutes! You'll especially see this in conversations and more casual contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You do know all of those, but their behaviour is a little different here. 十 (じゅう) and 分 (～ふん) together actually turn into じゅっぷん here. This is sometimes the case when using ～分 to mean "minute" in combination with certain numbers, so try to pay attention to this!
935 | そこ | そこ | There |  | Remember how words beginning with そ are either close to the person you're talking to, or fairly close to both of you? And how words ending in こ refer to places? This one's no exception. そこ means there.
936 | 世界 | せかい | The World | Society\n The Universe | Both kanji mean world, so it should be easy to guess this is a word for the World. It also means society or the Universe. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the on'yomi reading for 界, but you didn't learn this on'yomi reading of 世, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nWhat's the most hated vegetable in the world? Celery (せ), probably. The world is divided into those who love celery and those who hate celery. Which one are you?
937 | 事 | こと | Thing | Matter\n Occurrence | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nAs a vocab word on its own, 事 usually refers to an intangible or abstract thing, like いい事 (good thing) or する事 (things to do).\nDepending on the context, it can also mean matter or occurrence, like 大切な事 (important matter) or きのうの事 (what happened yesterday). \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nYou've done all kinds of things in your coat (こと). If you think about it, you only wear a coat when you have things to do. Try to remember all the things you've done in a coat. It's a lot! Symbolically, your coat = all the things and occurrences you've experienced, and all the matters you've had to deal with in life.
938 | 物 | もの | Thing | Object\n Item | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Besides thing, it has the related meanings of object and item. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat game has the most things in it? Monopoly (もの). You can choose from a bunch of random things to play as, you know? And no one actually knows what those things are. What's a thimble anyway? Just call it a thing.
939 | 今度 | こんど | This Time | Next Time | In the now occurrence you'll learn your kanji, no? This word means this time. Despite being "this time" it has the feeling of next time, though. It's like saying "okay, this time we'll get it" where "this time" really means "next time," making it a little bit different from 今回. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
940 | 付く | つく | To Be Attached |  | You know that the word 付ける means "to attach" and you know that the kanji 付 means attach. So, this word probably has something to do with attaching. This is the intransitive version, though, where something is attached (and you're not doing the attaching). You can use the く as a hint. You see something attached on the wall. You say "Coo'" \n The reading can be derived from 付ける, a word you should have seen a few levels ago. If you know that word's reading you should be able to figure out this word's reading as well (and vice versa).
941 | 曲がる | まがる | To Be Bent | To Bend\n To Curve\n To Turn | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means both music and bend. In the case of this word, we're looking at "bend." So, the verb form of bend is to be bent. This is when something bends on its own, not when you're doing the bending. It's just bending. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 曲げる, so you should be good to go!
942 | 下る | くだる | To Descend | To Go Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means below, so you can guess the direction this movement verb takes: this is to descend, or to go down.\nAs a movement verb, it usually describes a gradual downward movement. For example, you'd use this verb to describe walking down a mountain, driving down a hill, or going down a river in a boat. \n This verb uses the exceptional reading that 下さい also uses. So just replace the さい with る and you're good to go!
943 | 表す | あらわす | To Express Something | To Show Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means express and the verb vocab version is transitive, meaning that it's done to something. So this verb means to express something or to show something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're trying not to say it directly, but trying to figure out how to express something. That something is that you are a wuss (あらわす). Sorry, had to be expressed.
944 | 見付ける | みつける | To Find | To Find Something | You know that 付ける means "to attach" and that 見 means "see." So, when you attach your seeing to something, it's like you're looking around trying to find something. When you find what you're looking for, imagine your eyeballs flying out and attaching to that item, then yelling "I FOUND IT!"\nYou'll usually see this word with the 付 in kana, so 見つける. \n The readings come from 見る and 付ける. If you use those readings, you'll be able to read this word too.
945 | 欠ける | かける | To Get Chipped | To Be Lacking | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means lack, and this verb has a few meanings related to that. You'll often see it meaning to get chipped, like when talking about a teacup or your teeth. I guess a chipped teacup is lacking... a piece of itself?\n欠ける can also literally mean to be lacking, as in "a good goalie is lacking from their team." You can use it like this when you're short of something, or when something is missing that would complete a set. In these situations, you'll usually see it as 欠けている! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSomething is lacking... it's a car (か). You can't stop thinking about this because you have to walk 40 miles to get to your destination. If only that car wasn't missing, this would be easier. Imagine the sweat... the pain... the thirst... all because that car's not present.
946 | 持つ | もつ | To Hold Something | To Carry Something\n To Own Something\n To Keep Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means hold and the verb version is to hold something, to carry something, to own something, or to keep something.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You hold something, like chopsticks, have something, like power, or keep something, like your friend's book over the weekend. \n If you try to hold something in your hand long enough it will mold (も). And then that mold will cover your hand, then your arm, then your entire body. Basically, you should never hold anything for too long or you'll become a mold person.
947 | 交わる | まじわる | To Intersect | To Cross\n To Mingle | You know that the kanji means mix and the word 交ぜる means "to mix," so it probably has something to do with that. This word means to intersect, which is kind of like mixing. When two things intersect with each other, they're getting mixed up, so that's where this word gets its meaning.\nTo remember that this one means "to intersect," remember the わ as walk. You're walking around, and then you intersect with some people on the street. \n The reading is almost the same as 交ぜる which you should be familiar with by now. It has the ま but it also has an extra じ in there. That じ is there because you intersect with a group of mages (まじ) that catch you on fire as you walk past.
948 | 通す | とおす | To Let Something Pass | To Put Something Through | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 通る means to pass, but this is a little different. You aren't the one passing, Sue (す) is. So you have to let Sue pass. In other words, this verb is transitive, meaning it has an object. That's why it means to let something pass or to put something through.\nThe way this verb is translated into English changes a lot depending on the noun it's paired with. For example 火を通す is literally "to let the fire pass through", and means "to heat through". 針に糸を通す is literally "to put thread through a needle", so means "to thread a needle". \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 通る. Switch the る for a す and you'll be all set!
949 | 負ける | まける | To Lose | To Be Defeated | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lose so the verb vocab version means to lose. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou lose your tournament/soccer game/whatever (you decide something applicable to you). You're sad about this. Who's there to comfort you? Your Ma (ま). She's a nice lady.
950 | 要る | いる | To Need | To Be Needed\n To Be Necessary | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means need and the verb vocab version is to need.\nThis one's a little tricky, because although it's usually translated as "to need" in English, it's used more like to be needed or to be necessary. That is, it's an intransitive verb in Japanese, so it doesn't take a direct object. \n Since the reading isn't like the one you learned, think about what you are going to need... like, what you're really going to need, more than anything. Then, think of an eagle, because you really need an eagle. You'll need to come up with the reason why you need an eagle though, so hopefully it's a good one.
951 | 道具 | どうぐ | Tool |  | The tools you use on the road of life are important to have. What is your most important tool? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
952 | 保つ | たもつ | To Preserve Something | To Keep Something\n To Maintain Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means preserve and the verb vocab version is to preserve something, to keep something, or to maintain something.\nThis is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You preserve something, like your youth. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you want to learn how to preserve something like fruits and veggies, you should start with tamots (たも), that's slang for delish tomatoes. Once they're preserved, you get to make everyone you love eat those yummy tamots. Mmm!
953 | 受ける | うける | To Receive Something | To Accept Something\n To Take Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means receive, and this verbs means just about the same thing: to receive something!\nThis is a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. But 受ける often implies passive reception, generally of intangible objects like an education, or damage. It can also mean to take something, like taking an exam or a job offer. \n There’s a creature in front of you that’s about to receive something, but what is it? It’s an uni (う), and it’s going to receive a warm welcome and an education. Picture the sea urchin receiving these things, and then going on to take an exam to prove how much education it’s received.
954 | 受け取る | うけとる | To Receive Something | To Take Something\n To Get Something | You know that 受ける means "to receive something." Combine it with 取る (to take something), and 受け取る… still means to receive something.\nHowever, while 受ける generally implies passive reception, 受け取る carries a stronger connotation of actively taking possession of something. It is used when receiving a package or gift, or even when interpreting someone's words as having a specific meaning, such as an insult or compliment. \n If you know how to read 受ける and 取る, you should be good to go.
955 | 返す | かえす | To Return Something | To Return | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return so the verb version means to return something.\nThis is more like "to return a thing" rather than returning home, which would be 帰る, a word you haven't seen yet (but will soon, I'm sure!). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to return the Car egg (かえ) you found on the side of the road. It will birth a little car, but it needs its mother. So, you try to figure out how to return it. Go ahead and think through that process in your mind. Also think about how weird a car egg would be.
956 | 乗る | のる | To Ride | To Get On\n To Board | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so the verb vocab version means to ride. \n The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji. Enjoy the ride!
957 | 売る | うる | To Sell Something |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version of that is to sell something. \n You want to sell something, but what? What can you sell that will take the least amount of work? Uni (う)! They're just hanging out in the ocean, ready for the taking. Go scoop some up, watch out for the pointy bits, and sell them for some quick cash!
958 | 送る | おくる | To Send Something | To Escort Someone | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means send, and the the vocab verb version is to send something. If the object of this verb is a person, it means "to send" in the sense of to escort someone, maybe to the station, or to the door. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to send an entire oak (おく) tree in the mail, but it's too big. Imagine yourself dragging one to the post office. They tell you that you can't send that here... Go to the oak sending facilities.
959 | 泳ぐ | およぐ | To Swim |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swim so the verb vocab version is to swim. \n The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana sticking out?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji.
960 | 試みる | こころみる | To Try To Do Something | To Attempt Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means try so the verb vocab version is to try to do something or to attempt something.\nThis verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. Here, the direct object is whatever it is that you're trying to do. \n You know how when you try to do something you put your whole heart into it? Well, think of that in Japanese. You put your whole 心 (こころ) into it.
961 | 使う | つかう | To Use | To Spend | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use so the verb version is to use. If you're talking about money, this can also mean to spend. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTwo cars (つか), are what you have to use because you're so huge you don't fit into one. You've got a British car on your left and an American car on your right, and you're driving them both at the same time.
962 | 勝つ | かつ | To Win |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means win so the verb version is to win. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat did you just win? You won a new car (か)!
963 | 実力 | じつりょく | True Strength | True Ability\n True Power | The truth behind someone's strength is their true strength. It is also their true ability. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYour true strength is sealed behind two locks. Gee, two locks (じつりょく)?! People must have been scared of your true power to seal it behind two locks!
964 | 実 | じつ | Truth | Reality | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading, same like you learned with the kanji. That is the truth, I promise.
965 | 使用 | しよう | Use | Application\n Employment | Something you use that has a use has... well, use. You can even use it for practical applications.\n使用 has a slightly more formal tone compared to 使う, and it’s preferred in situations that require a more precise and less casual choice of words. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
966 | 弱虫 | よわむし | Weakling | Coward | A weak insect. This is what people call weaklings in Japan. This is a good word to know if you're a bully, or something. \n The reading for this one is a weird one. It uses the kun'yomi readings for both, meaning you'll have to pull your knowledge of the word 弱い from earlier and apply it here. 虫 should be okay, though, as this is the reading you learned with the kanji.\nJust remember, only weak bugs use kun'yomi, and that weak bug is you in this instance.
967 | 弱々しい | よわよわしい | Weak Looking | Frail\n Weak Seeming\n Seemingly Weak | Something that is double weak is probably pretty weak. You also know that this is an adjective because it ends with い. You know that 弱い is weak, so it probably isn't that. Instead, this one is weak looking or frail. If you know the grammar らしい you can kind of use that as a hint. The しい on the end reminds me of らしい which is like "seems to be." So, "seems to be weak" = "weak looking." \n The reading is double kun'yomi, as you can probably guess due to all the hiragana involved. So, you double up on よわ and then add the しい to read this vocabulary word.
968 | 勝者 | しょうしゃ | Winner | Victor | Someone who wins is the winner / victor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
969 | 学院 | がくいん | Academy | Institute | A study institution is an academy. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
970 | 足し算 | たしざん | Addition |  | Remember how 足す means "to add?" Add calculate to that and you'll have addition! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add. \n This is the kun'yomi reading for 足 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
971 | 進行 | しんこう | Advance | Progress | When something advances and goes, it is moving forward. So this means advance or progress.\n進行 can be used to describe various situations, like when a project progresses; but also when an illness advances to a more serious stage. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
972 | 農業 | のうぎょう | Agriculture |  | What's another way to call the farming business? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it agriculture. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
973 | ちょっと | ちょっと | A Little | A Moment | You chortle (ちょっと) a little at a silly joke. You can’t help chortling for a moment. Go ahead, chortle just a little, for just a moment, to help you remember this word.
974 | 路地 | ろじ | Alley | Path\n Dirt Road | If you think about it, an earth road isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a path (you know, like a dirt path!) or a dirt road. Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an alley. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too! And remember, that it's the じ reading that you learned with 生地 here.
975 | 高度 | こうど | Altitude | High-level | Something that is tall in degrees can either refer to its altitude, or to the fact that it's quite high-level.\nNote that this can refer to any altitude, even lower ones. But when used to refer to, for example, skills or a technique, it always talks about a high level or degree. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
976 | 回答 | かいとう | Answer | Response\n Reply | How many times do I have to tell you that an answer is an answer? Well, okay, it can be a reply or a response, too. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the on'yomi for 答 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nGive me your answer and I'll take you to とうきょう. How does that sound? All I need is your reply, and we'll be in とうきょう before you know it.
977 | 算数 | さんすう | Arithmetic | Math\n Mathematics\n Maths | What is it called when you calculate numbers? That is the study of math and arithmetic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
978 | 助手 | じょしゅ | Assistant | Helper\n Aide | Remember how 手 can mean a "doer" in some words? What do you think your help doer is? It’s someone who helps you, so it’s your assistant, helper, or aid. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi reading of 手 with the vocabulary word 投手.
979 | 早速 | さっそく | At Once | Immediately\n Without Delay\n Right Away\n Right Now | Doing something both fast and early probably requires you to do it at once or immediately. Whatever it is, be sure to do it without delay. \n The reading for this one is strange. The reading for 速 (そく) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but 早 gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word at once and without delay so there's no time for any sass (さっ), just kanji learning.
980 | 心配 | しんぱい | A Worry | Concern | When you distribute your heart around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have a worry or concern. 心配しないでね！ \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the ぱい in 配 got rendaku'd from はい, as well.
981 | 自転車 | じてんしゃ | Bicycle | Bike\n Pushbike | A self revolving car. You'd think this would be a regular car, but bicycles were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
982 | 苦い | にがい | Bitter Tasting | Bitter | The kanji for 苦 means suffering. This word, however, is a bit different, but you'll see how it's related. It means bitter tasting. Think of putting the most bitter thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Obviously eating bitter tasting things will cause you to suffer. \n This reading of the kanji is unique to this meaning of the word, so here's a mnemonic to help you out!\nThe taste is so bitter tasting that you fall to your knees really, really hard. Luckily, you were wearing your knee guards (にが). Feel the relief that you were wearing them. Ack, no relief now. It's still bitter in your mouth.
983 | パン | パン | Bread |  | パン is the katakana version of the Portuguese word "pão" and means bread in English.\nIf you know the Portuguese, Spanish, or French word for bread, you shouldn't have trouble remembering this word. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou use a pan (パン) to make all your bread. It's your special bread pan, and all the bread you make with it is delicious.
984 | ビル | ビル | Building |  | ビル is the Japanese version of the English word building. It usually refers to buildings that are taller than they are wide, most commonly apartment blocks and office buildings.
985 | 千葉 | ちば | Chiba |  | There is only one place in Japan that has a thousand leaves and that's Chiba. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful. \n This is a place name and it uses the kun'yomi. You haven't learned kun'yomi for 千 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nWhile you're admiring all of the leaves in Chiba, you realize you're craving something. What goes well with watching leaves? Why, cheese (ち) of course. Delicious Chiba cheese.
986 | 親友 | しんゆう | Close Friend | Best Friend\n Good Friend | A friend who is like one of your parents is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means best friend or close friend. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
987 | 集金 | しゅうきん | Collecting Money | Money Collection | When you collect gold you are collecting money (or doing money collection). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much 集金 in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.\n集金 often refers to collecting bills, dues, or fees in person or through a designated representative. This can be carried out by a business, an organization, or even just a small group of people. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
988 | 集中 | しゅうちゅう | Concentration | Focus | When you collect to the middle of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme concentration and focus. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
989 | 調子 | ちょうし | Condition | Tone | Imagine yourself investigating a child. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the condition of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
990 | 曲線 | きょくせん | Curve | Curved Line | A bend in a line is merely a curve. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
991 | 要求 | ようきゅう | Demand | Requirement | You need this request to happen, so you don't just ask nicely, you demand it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
992 | 開発 | かいはつ | Development |  | You are now open for departure. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its development, where you will create a new world. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
993 | 〜病 | びょう | Disease | Sickness\n Illness | As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji sick to another word, you're saying what kind of sickness it is; you are mentioning what disease it is. \n Since this is attached to other words, it's treated like jukugo and gets on'yomi treatment. This is the reading you learned with the kanji.
994 | 電鉄 | でんてつ | Electric Railway |  | The electricity iron sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an electric railway. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
995 | 強調 | きょうちょう | Emphasis | Highlight\n Stress | If you use a strong tone on certain words, then you are putting emphasis on whatever it is you're talking about. It's the stress you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
996 | 終了 | しゅうりょう | End | Finish\n Close | It's the end. It's the finish. This word means end. Or finish! How convenient.\nNote that 終了 is slightly more formal than 終わる. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
997 | 進化 | しんか | Evolution | Progress | Think of things that advance and change. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like evolution? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
998 | 顔付き | かおつき | Expression | Facial Expression | The thing that is attached to your face isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your expression. \n The readings are both kun'yomi, but they're the readings you've already learned when you learned the kanji.
999 | 目医者 | めいしゃ | Eye Doctor | Oculist\n Ophthalmologist | Do you remember 医者 (doctor)? What happens when you add eye on there? You have yourself an eye doctor. \n The reading is just the vocab word 医者 (いしゃ) plus the reading 目 (め), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
1000 | 顔 | かお | Face |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is kun'yomi, since it's a kanji all alone with nothing attached. Luckily, that's also the reading you've already learned, so associate that with this vocab word.
1001 | 農場 | のうじょう | Farm |  | The place you do your farming is a farm! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1002 | 速い | はやい | Fast |  | Just like the meaning of the kanji (fast) this adjective also means fast. \n Remember how 早い means "early"? If you are early to something, it probably means you moved fast to get there. These two words share a reading (and have similar meanings, in a way, as well!).
