1003 | 一番目 | いちばんめ | First Thing | The First | You've seen 一番 (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (目) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the first thing / the first. \n The reading for this word is just the vocab word 一番 plus the word 目. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.
1004 | フランス語 | ふらんすご | French Language | French | I bet you can guess that フランス means "France." So what happens when you add language to it? You get the "France Language" aka the French Language. \n The reading is just the on'yomi reading for 語 which is the reading you learned with the kanji. This is probably because it gets added onto a lot of other words so it's treated like a jukugo. For example: 日本語 = "Japanese Language." 中国語 = "Chinese Language." スペイン語 = "Spanish Language."
1005 | 青葉 | あおば | Fresh Leaves | Greenery\n Young Leaves | A young leaf is exactly what you'd expect, although most people usually just call them fresh leaves. \n The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word 青, hopefully you can just combine it with 葉 (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. は goes to ば in this word, making it あおば.
1006 | 大学院 | だいがくいん | Graduate School | Grad School | Remember how you learned that 大学 means "college?" Well the institution you go to after college is graduate school! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1007 | 頭 | あたま | Head |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!
1008 | 重い | おもい | Heavy |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of heavy? It's also heavy. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're lifting something that's really heavy. Oof! You lift it above your head. You're so awesome. You scream: "OH! MORE!" (おも) they put more. You yell it again: "OH, MORE!" and again: "OH, MORE!" Go ahead and act this out wherever you are, pretending like you're holding a couch or two or three over your head, saying "OH MORE!"
1009 | 病院 | びょういん | Hospital |  | A sick institution is a place where sick people go. That is a hospital. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1010 | 入院 | にゅういん | Hospitalization | Hospital Admission | So you're entering an institution. But we're not talking about any institution, we're talking specifically about hospitals. So this word means hospitalization. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1011 | しかし | しかし | However |  | She cashes (しかし) in on everything. However, this time you're going to stop her. No more cashing in.\nしかし is used at the beginning of a sentence, just like "however." It's pretty formal, and you'll see it much more in written Japanese than spoken Japanese.
1012 | 工業 | こうぎょう | Industry |  | The business of industry is... well... industry. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1013 | 親しい | したしい | Intimate | Friendly\n Close | This is a single kanji with some kana and an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of intimacy? It's intimate! Depending on the context, this also means friendly or close. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThose who are most intimate with you hang out with you even when you're doing gross things, like sitting on the sh*tter (した). Gross, your family is.
1014 | 日本語 | にほんご | Japanese Language | Japanese | You know 日本 is "Japan." So, when you add language onto the end of that you have Japanese language. \n The reading is just the vocab word 日本 (にほん) plus the on'yomi that you learned for 語. Combine them together to get the reading for this word.
1015 | 日本酒 | にほんしゅ | Japanese Style Alcohol | Japanese Alcohol\n Sake | You know that 日本 is "Japan" so when you add alcohol onto the end of that you have Japanese Style Alcohol (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's sake). \n The reading for this is just the vocab 日本's reading plus the on'yomi you learned for 酒, put together.
1016 | 漢字 | かんじ | Kanji | Chinese Letters\n Chinese Characters | The Chinese letters... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is kanji, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1017 | 親切 | しんせつ | Kind | Kindness | When your parents cut you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being kind.\nJust think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1018 | 台所 | だいどころ | Kitchen |  | What place in your house has most of the machines in it? Your kitchen! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines. \n This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 台 and the kun'yomi reading for 所. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!
1019 | 研究室 | けんきゅうしつ | Laboratory | Lab Room | Remember how 研究 means “research?” Well the room where you do research is a laboratory!\n研究室 refers to a lab room, often within a larger institution like a university or college. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1020 | 言語 | げんご | Language | A Language | When you say words in a language, you are speaking a language. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1021 | 最後 | さいご | Last | End\n Conclusion\n Final | The thing that is the most after everything else is at the very end. It is the last. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1022 | 最終 | さいしゅう | Last | Final\n The Last\n The Final | The most end thing is the last thing. It is mainly used to refer to the last of an ordered sequence. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1023 | 終点 | しゅうてん | Last Stop | Final Stop\n Terminus | The end point is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the last stop. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1024 | 葉 | は | Leaf | Leaves | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1025 | 軽い | かるい | Lightweight | Light\n Light Weight | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lightweight? It's also lightweight. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the reading you'll be using here. Because of that, this word is kind of a lightweight.
1026 | 線 | せん | Line |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same for this vocab word. Enjoy it!
1027 | 楽しみ | たのしみ | Looking Forward To | Hope\n Expectation\n Anticipation\n Pleasure\n Enjoyment | You've seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means looking forward to. Why? Because it has a み on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's me! That's why I'm looking forward to it!" \n The reading is just like 楽しい, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.
1028 | 運がいい | うんがいい | Lucky | Fortunate | The いい portion means "good." So, when what you carry is good you are lucky. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!" \n The reading for the kanji in this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this.
1029 | 〜向け | むけ | Made For | Intended For\n Aimed At | You've hopefully seen 向く and 向ける by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add 向け to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's made for them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's aimed at them, it's made for them. See the connection? \n The reading is the same as the word 向く so work off of that word to be able to read this one.
1030 | 山道 | やまみち | Mountain Road | Mountain Trail\n Mountain Path | A mountain road is a mountain road! Or a mountain trail, or a mountain path. \n Both the kanji in this word use the kun'yomi, which you learned when you learned the vocabulary. When it uses this reading, it sounds casual, and is common in conversation. It can also be read using the on'yomi, though, in which case it has a more formal feel to it. That's typical of on'yomi, which tends to add formality to a word!
1031 | 近所 | きんじょ | Neighborhood |  | The place you live near is your neighborhood! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you remember the rendaku on しょ making it じょ.
1032 | 新聞 | しんぶん | Newspaper |  | The new hear is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a newspaper. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1033 | 次 | つぎ | Next |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nSomeone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try two guillotines (つぎ) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!
1034 | 番号札 | ばんごうふだ | Numbered Tag | Numbered Ticket | You know 番号 means "number" so add a tag to it and you have a numbered tag. \n This is a jukugo word (番号) with a single-word kanji added. That means you have two on'yomi readings from the jukugo word and the kun'yomi reading from the single kanji (ふだ). Put them all together and you have the reading of this kanji!
1035 | 次々 | つぎつぎ | One After Another | In Succession | When things happen in a next, next (next, next, next…) way, they happen one after another.\nImagine a factory line for item checking. The people there keep shouting "Next! Next!" because items come in succession without stopping! \n The reading is the same as the word 次 (so it's つぎ), but this time you do it twice. No strange rendaku or anything like that either, which makes everyone happier.
1036 | 一ヶ所 | いっかしょ | One Place | One Spot | Remember the small ヶ acting as a counter? Together with one and place, it makes this one place or one spot.\nJust like 〜ヶ月, you'll also run into this being written as 一箇所, 一か所, or 一カ所. \n Just like before, the little ヶ is actually read as か. The rest uses the on'yomi you already learned with the kanji. Just watch out 一 here is いっ instead of いち as it makes it easier to pronounce the whole word. Now, read it aloud and try yourself!
1037 | 開業 | かいぎょう | Opening A Business | Starting A Business | This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You open a business... aka opening a business.\nWhile this can be used for opening any sort of business, it’s commonly associated with doctors, lawyers, and other professionals opening their own practice or office. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1038 | 公開 | こうかい | Open To The Public | Releasing | When something is public open it is open to the public. You can go look at things that are 公開. You can also use this when you're releasing something to the public, which means you’re making it publicly accessible. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1039 | 頁 | ページ | Page |  | The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so they share meanings as well.\nThis word is often written in katakana as ページ, especially in informal writing and online. But you'll also see the kanji version, especially to refer to the pages of printed texts and in more formal writing. \n This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji.
1040 | 親 | おや | Parent |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nJust imagine your parents saying oh yah (おや) over and over at you. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"
1041 | 道路 | どうろ | Paved Road | Road\n Sealed Road | A road road is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a paved road. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1042 | 農民 | のうみん | Peasants | Farmers | The peoples who work in the farm are the farmers... the peasants. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1043 | 当て字 | あてじ | Phonetic Kanji | Ateji\n Substitute Character | 当てる means "to guess" or "to hit", and 字 means letter. So these are guessed letters? Kind of, they're so-called phonetic kanji, or ateji.\nThis refers to cases where kanji are used solely for their sound, but not their meaning. There are also some cases of ateji where kanji are used only for their meaning and not their sound, but this is less common. \n The readings are the kun'yomi reading for 当て and the on'yomi reading for 字. You've seen 当てる in the past, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.
1044 | 私大 | しだい | Private College | Private University\n Private Uni | You know how 私 can mean private and how 大 is the first half of 大学? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of private college or private university. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYou went to a specific private college just to study dyes (だい). You're so into dyes that you decided to go to this extremely expensive private university that specializes in dyes. Good for you!
1045 | 私鉄 | してつ | Private Railway |  | A private iron (remember how 鉄 often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a private railway. There are a good number of these in Japan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1046 | 部首 | ぶしゅ | Radical |  | Picture the part of your body that makes up your neck. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a radical! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 首 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you need a radical to make a new kanji, you just press a button and the radical comes tumbling down the radical chute (しゅ). There's definitely no rhyme or reason to radical picking, it's just whatever pops out of the ol' chute.
1047 | 線路 | せんろ | Railroad Track | Train Track\n Railway Track\n Track\n Line | A line that runs on a road is a railroad track. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a railroad track. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1048 | 読み方 | よみかた | Reading | Pronunciation\n Way Of Reading | You know that this has something to do with reading and you know that 方 means way or method. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as reading (aka the reading of a word) or pronunciation. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for. \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 読む and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
1049 | 最近 | さいきん | Recent | Latest\n Lately\n Recently | The most nearby is something that happened close to now. It happened recently. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1050 | 研究所 | けんきゅうしょ | Research Institute | Research Facility | You've seen that 研究 is "research" from previous vocab, and you might remember 所 can mean "facility." So this word means research institute or, of course, research facility. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of 研究 already.\nAlso note that 所 is normal in first reading, but gets rendaku'd in the second reading, meaning しょ becomes じょ. Both readings are valid and they don't affect the meaning, so it just comes down to personal preference!
1051 | 回転 | かいてん | Revolve | Rotate\n Rotation | You revolve X number of times. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is revolve or rotate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. P.S. Ever heard of "回転ずし?" That's the kind of sushi that's on conveyer belts, rotating around and around, bringing you delicious plates of things.
1052 | お酒 | おさけ | Sake | Alcohol | This is just the noun version of the kanji 酒 - it has an お there to be nice. This word can mean both alcohol (like the parent kanji) or sake (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days). \n The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's さけ, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.
1053 | サービス | サービス | Service | Freebie\n Giving A Freebie | This is the equivalent of the English word service. By extension, it's often used to mean a freebie. Though it's generally used as a standard noun, it can also be a verbal noun used with する. In this case, it means giving a freebie.
1054 | 近道 | ちかみち | Shortcut | Short Way | Taking the nearby road will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a shortcut, aka the short way. \n The reading is a bit weird in this one. It uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a shortcut with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have ちか for 近 (short for 近い) and you have 道 (みち), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."
1055 | 病気 | びょうき | Sick | Illness\n Sickness\n Disease | When your energy is that of sickness, you are probably sick. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1056 | 病人 | びょうにん | Sick Person | Patient | A person who is sick is a sick person. They are also a patient, at least we can hope they are, for their sake. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nEvery sick person enjoys playing on their Nintendo (にん). You have the nastiest flu, but you've still got your Nintendo, so everything is fine.
1057 | 横 | よこ | Side | Beside\n Next To\n Horizontal | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the left side," for example. That would be 左側. \n The reading for this vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, lucky you!
1058 | 歌手 | かしゅ | Singer |  | Remember how  手 can sometimes mean “doer”? What do you think a song doer is? A singer, of course \n The readings are on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already (you learned 手's on'yomi reading with word 投手), so you should be able to read this like a singer sings with a bunch of cashews かしゅ in their mouth. FAST AND LOUD!
1059 | 歌 | うた | Song |  | One of the kanji's meanings is song and this word means exactly that: a song. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThink about a song... but not just any song... think about the utter (うた) song, and make it up right now and sing it out loud. What does the utter song sound like? Why do you love utterances so much that you made a song about them?
1060 | スペイン語 | すぺいんご | Spanish Language | Spanish | You can probably figure out that スペイン is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji language on there and you have the Spanish language (or just Spanish), if you'd like. \n The reading for the kanji portion is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Since it's attached to something, it's like a jukugo word.
1061 | 速度 | そくど | Speed |  | Your fastness degree is your speed.\nYou use 速度 to talk about a specific speed of something like a car or a train. If you want to talk about speed more casually, you can just say スピード or 速さ. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1062 | 立ち飲み | たちのみ | Standing And Drinking | Drinking While Standing | The meaning is the same as the kanji. When you stand and drink, you're standing and drinking. Or indeed, drinking while standing. \n The readings are from the words 立つ and 飲む put together.
1063 | 開始 | かいし | Start | Beginning\n Opening | The open of the start is the start or beginning.\nNote that 開始 is slightly more formal than 始める. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1064 | 話 | はなし | Story | Talk\n Speech\n Conversation | The kanji version of 話 means talk. This word also means talk, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a speech or story as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my 話. \n Who tells a great story? Hana, she (はなし) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too.\nYou can also use 話す's reading to help you to remember this one, as well.
1065 | 鉄人 | てつじん | Strong Man | Badass\n Iron Man\n Macho Man\n Tough Guy | A man made of iron is a strong man... aka a huge badass. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is 料理の鉄人, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nCheck out the strong man wearing nothing but jeans (じん). He looks like a badass in his jeans, flexing his pecs. Very impressive, but also slightly terrifying.
1066 | 主語 | しゅご | Subject |  | The main thing you talk about in your language becomes the subject of the sentence. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1067 | 引き算 | ひきざん | Subtraction |  | Remember how 引く means "to subtract?" Add calculate to that and you'll have subtraction! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you subtract. \n This is the kun'yomi reading for 引 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
1068 | 地下鉄 | ちかてつ | Subway | The Underground\n The Tube\n The Metro | The ground below iron is iron under the ground. It isn't a deposit of iron, though. It's man-made. And what's made of iron? Trains. In this case, because it's underground, it's a subway. Depending on where you live, you might call it the Underground, the Tube, or the Metro \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1069 | 最高 | さいこう | The Best | Best\n Supreme | The most tall isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is the best. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1070 | 最も | もっとも | The Most | Most\n Extremely | This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is the most or just most. You can also use it as extremely. \n The reading for this is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). To learn it, let's look at a mnemonic.\nThink of the most ridiculous motto (もっと) you've ever heard. Now imagine a motto that's even more ridiculous. Here are some actual totally real mottos that are the most ridiculous: "What Can Brown Do for You?" "It's Not for Women" "If It Doesn't Get All Over the Place, It Doesn't Belong in Your Face" and of course, "Why Not Enjoy the Go?"
1071 | 今朝 | けさ | This Morning |  | Now morning is just another way of saying this morning. It's the closest morning to right now! \n This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it:\nThis morning you want a quesadilla (けさ) for breakfast. You can't wait until tomorrow morning, you NEED it this morning! Imagine eating a delicious quesadilla first thing this morning. Mmm!
1072 | 進む | すすむ | To Advance | To Go Forward\n To Progress | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means advance so the verb vocab version means to advance.\nThis is an intransitive verb, meaning that it is about something or someone advancing forward. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn order to advance, you must sue Sue for her misdeeds against you. Imagine her standing in your way, literally. She keeps saying, "You'll have to sue me if you want to get past me!" So you do. You sue Sue. Now tell her to move (む).
1073 | タバコ | タバコ | Tobacco | Cigarette | タバコ is the Japanese version of the Portuguese word "tabaco." You probably won’t be shocked to learn that タバコ means tobacco or cigarette in English!\nWatch out for the first syllable, which is タ and not ト. タバコ can also be written in hiragana, and even in kanji, but katakana is the most common by far.
1074 | 決まる | きまる | To Be Decided | To Be Settled | You've seen the word 決める before, hopefully. This is similar, except for instead of doing the action of deciding, something has just been decided (by something or someone else). You are not the decision maker, here. That's why this word is to be decided. \n The reading is the same as 決める, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.
1075 | 始める | はじめる | To Begin Something | To Start Something\n To Begin \n To Start | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means begin or start, and the verb version is to begin, to begin something, to start, or to start something.\nThis is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You start something. Like studying! You should have started studying earlier though, huh? \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nRight now it's time to begin Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). You need to start Haj right now!
1076 | 助かる | たすかる | To Be Helped | To Be Saved\n To Be Rescued | You know that 助ける means "to help" and this is related. This is when someone is being helped, and we're focusing on the person being helped, rather than the person doing the helping. In grammatical terms, this verb is intransitive, so there is no object. The かる ending is a hint, because verbs with かる as okurigana (kana added to the kanji) are usually intransitive.\nIt also can be used to talk about how you were rescued, which is like being helped, right? If you want to memorize it that way, that's fine too. \n The reading is the same as 助ける, so hopefully you know that word and can apply that knowledge over here.
1077 | 点く | つく | To Be Lit | To Be Ignited\n To Be On\n To Come On | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji 点 means point, but this verb actually means to be lit or to be ignited. Think of it this way, when a flashlight turns on, it points a beam, of light.\nYou already learned 点ける, which is for when you turn something on. 点く, on the other hand, is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself. Like, "Oh look! The lights came on! That's cool (く)!" \n You already learned this reading when you learned 点ける but here's a mnemonic just in case:\nEvery time you count to two (つ) a light comes on. How cool (く) that it does it all by itself!!
1078 | 映る | うつる | To Be Reflected | To Be Projected | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reflect. The verb vocab version means to be reflected. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (る) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you 打つ (うつ) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: うつうつうつうつ.\nYou might recall that this reading is the same as 写る and might wonder if they're related. They are! They both talk about the image of something showing up somewhere else, and use different kanji to distinguish where. In 写る's case, that would typically be in photographs, and for 映る, it's in reflections or projections (which includes the contents of screens, like those of TVs or computers).
1079 | 病む | やむ | To Be Sick | To Fall Ill\n To Be Ill\n To Come Down With\n To Suffer From | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sick, so the verb version is to be sick. It can also be used as to come down with when you have the flu or some other illness. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThere is only one time you allow yourself to be sick, and that's when the Yankees (や) are playing. You can't miss any games so you just happen to fall ill whenever they're playing so you can stay home and watch. That's pretty convenient, isn't it?
1080 | 売れる | うれる | To Be Sold | To Sell | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sell, so the verb version is to sell or to be sold. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read it! It's the same reading as 売る where you're trying to sell some Uni (う)!
1081 | 化かす | ばかす | To Bewitch | To Enchant | You've seen the word 化ける (to transform) before. Now we have a similar word. This word means to bewitch because when you cuss (かす) you are saying a magic word and bewitching the person in front of you. Imagine yourself yelling out cuss words, and every time a new enchantment falls upon your victim.\nThis verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. You bewitch someone or something. \n The reading is the same as 化ける, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.
1082 | 運ぶ | はこぶ | To Carry | To Transport\n To Move | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb version is to carry. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nImagine you have to carry a hardcore (はこ) music fan home after a concert. They spent all night moshing to hardcore sounds, and now they’re too tired to walk. But you? You’re a hardcore friend, so you’re happy to carry them.
1083 | 集める | あつめる | To Collect Something | To Gather Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means collect and this verb is transitive, meaning the action is done to something or someone. So this verb means things like to collect something and to gather something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you only have one thing, there's only one thing. Nothing is collected. But when you have two... "ah two!" (あつ). Now you're starting to collect something.
1084 | 配る | くばる | To Distribute | To Pass Out\n To Deliver | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distribute so the verb vocab version is to distribute. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to distribute some fliers to everyone. On the fliers it talks about a striptease show where kublai (くば) Khan does something naughty. Imagine this show, and imagine your shame of being the person handing out these fliers. How far the Khan has fallen.
1085 | 飲む | のむ | To Drink |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drink so the vocab verb version is to drink. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go have a drink in the great Allicrab's name!
1086 | 運転する | うんてんする | To Drive |  | A thing that carries rotations (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means to drive. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1087 | 終わる | おわる | To End | To Be Over | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means end and so the verb version of this is to end or to be over.\nIt's an intransitive verb, meaning it happens on its own. Something ends, but you don't cause it to end. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThis situation has to end. You're the ower (おわ) of a lot of money. For this to end, you need to pay back all that money. Try to think of ways to stop being an ower so this stressful situation can end!
1088 | 楽しむ | たのしむ | To Enjoy Something | To Have Fun | You've hopefully seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is basically the verb version (ends in an う sound, right?) of that. That means this is to enjoy something, or just to have fun. \n The reading is the same as the word 楽しい, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.
1089 | 落ちる | おちる | To Fall Down | To Fall\n To Drop\n To Fail | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fall and the vocab verb version means to fall down, to fall, and to drop. It can also mean to fail, in the sense of failing an exam. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you start to fall down, what do you yell? "OHHHH (お)!"
1090 | 乗せる | のせる | To Give Someone A Ride | To Place Something On\n To Load Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ride so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (乗る which means to ride). This particular one is transitive, meaning there is a direct object. The action is done to someone or something. So this means to give someone a ride when it's used for people, and to place something on, or to load something when it's used for things.\nUse the せ as a hint. The せ is a "sail" (せ) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you. \n The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be okay with this. Allow me to give you a ride to the next item to study.
1091 | 聞く | きく | To Hear | To Ask\n To Listen | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hear so the vocab verb version is to hear. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to hear something very important, but you can't. In order to hear, you have to take a key (き) and unlock the doors covering your ears. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing that, focusing on the key.
1092 | 調べる | しらべる | To Investigate | To Examine\n To Research\n To Look Into | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means investigate so the vocab verb version means to investigate. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou are hired to investigate someone's wife. It is said that she loves (しら) another man... but you need to investigate her to find out if that's true, for her husband of course.
1093 | 習う | ならう | To Learn | To Take Lessons In | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means learn so the vocab verb version means to learn or to take lessons in something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to learn about Nara, the city of deer... lots and lots of deer. If you don't know about it, how about learning about it?
1094 | 教わる | おそわる | To Learn Something From Someone | To Be Taught Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means teach, and this verb means to learn something from someone or to be taught something. When you use this verb, you're not learning something by yourself, you're being taught by someone else. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this kun'yomi yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you want to learn something from someone, you say "Oh, so..." (おそ) and repeat what you've just learned. Saying "oh, so…" helps you make sure you're understanding correctly, and shows you're really paying attention. That's important when you're learning from someone!
1095 | 去る | さる | To Leave |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means past, and this verb means to leave. It should be easy to remember because you know what people say — you leave past in the past. \n You will want to leave, if you see a saw (さ) pointing at you. You know saws can be deadly weapons, you should immediately leave when someone is brandishing one at you!
1096 | 鳴く | なく | To Make An Animal Sound | To Bark\n To Chirp | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chirp but the verb has the broader meaning to make an animal sound. Variations of this include to bark or to chirp, but this can be used for any animal sound. \n The reading is the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. So, spend more time chirping and less time memorizing, okay?
1097 | 出会う | であう | To Meet By Chance | To Meet Unexpectedly\n To Come Across\n To Encounter\n To Run Into | You exit your house and you meet someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means to meet by chance. \n The reading is that of the word 出る and the word 会う, both of which you've hopefully seen. The 出 portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why 出 uses the vocab reading.\nOh by the way, this word can be written like this too: 出合う. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!
1098 | 口調 | くちょう | Tone | Tone Of Voice\n Verbal Expression | When your mouth makes tones we call it your tone or tone of voice. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 口 yet. Remember when you learned the vocabulary word 口? Just take the ち off and you get its other on'yomi reading く. That's easy, right?
1099 | 開ける | あける | To Open Something |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means open and the verb vocab version is to open something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou go to open the door. When you do, a huge scream comes out: "AAAHHH!" (あ). Imagine giant あ characters flying out of the door you opened as well.
1100 | 読む | よむ | To Read |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means read so the verb vocab version is to read. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.
1101 | 代える | かえる | To Replace Something | To Substitute Something\n To Exchange Something | You know the kanji is substitute, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means to replace something. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace something" focus in on the え. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).\nThis verb is transitive, meaning it has a direct object. You replace something, like that egg! \n The reading for this one is the same as 代わる which you learned in a previous level. As long as you know that one you should be able to learn this one's reading as well.
1102 | 転がる | ころがる | To Roll | To Tumble\n To Lie Down\n To Be Scattered About | You know that the kanji here means revolve. The verb version of this is similar. It means to roll or to tumble. When something is doing these things it is revolving, right? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat should you do when you want to roll down a hill? Become a bottle of Corona (ころ). Just imagine yourself as a bottle of Corona, rolling down a hill. You're a Corona bottle, so you roll super easily. Now feel the grass under your glass as you roll down that hill. Nice, isn't it?
1103 | 語る | かたる | To Talk | To Tell\n To Recite | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means language, so when you do language you're going to talk about something. Maybe you're going to tell a story, or the truth.\nThis verb is transitive, so it generally takes a direct object in Japanese, even though the English translations might not. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSometimes when you're trying to talk about something, there will be that one person who always cuts you off to tell their own story. We call them language cutters (かた). They cut you off and make everyone pay attention to what they're saying. Don't be a language cutter.
1104 | 投げ付ける | なげつける | To Throw Against | To Throw At | You know that you're throwing something that is attaching to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say to throw against or to throw at. \n The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: 投げる and 付ける. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.
1105 | 起きる | おきる | To Wake Up | To Get Up\n To Occur | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wake up so the verb vocab version is to wake up or to get up.\nThis word also has a secondary meaning of to occur. Think of it this way: when an action "wakes up", in a way it is occurring as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so tomorrow when you wake up you hopefully won't have to relearn this vocab's reading.
1106 | 求める | もとめる | To Want Something | To Request Something\n To Demand Something | What's the verb form of request? It's to request. It also is for when you want something (to want something), because if you're going to request something, you probably want it. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is it that you want? You want a moat (もと) around your home. Your neighbor's cats keep pooping on your lawn, but if you had a moat they wouldn't be able to get to your lawn in the first place, since cats hate water (and alligators). You request a moat!
1107 | 役場 | やくば | Town Hall | Town Office\n Public Office | A service location is a place that people go when they're in need of a service. The best place for this is the town hall. Everyone goes to this one location to voice their complaints, and in return their needs are serviced by the officials in the town hall.\n役場 specifically refers to the administrative office of a town (町) or village (村) rather than a city (市). Depending on the location, it may be also be called a 町役場 or 村役場. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. That's all you have to remember, though, because you've seen both of these readings before!
1108 | 転送 | てんそう | Transfer | Forwarding | You revolve something, making it roll, and then send it off somewhere. This means you’re transferring or forwarding it to someone else.\n転送 is often used in the context of logistics or communication systems, like transferring packages or forwarding e-mails. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1109 | 思わず | おもわず | Unintentionally | Reflexively\n Spontaneously\n Involuntarily | This is a negative form of the verb 思う which is used as an adverb. If you do something without thinking, you do it unintentionally. As an adverb, you can put this in front of things to say that you did them involuntarily. \n The reading for this is the kun'yomi reading which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word as well.
1110 | とても | とても | Very |  | Look at this totem, oh (とても)! It's very, very, very, very lucky, as all totems should be.\nThis word has a slightly formal feel to it, and you’ll come across it most in writing.
1111 | 作業 | さぎょう | Work | Task\n Operation | If you want to make a business successful you need to be prepared to do a lot of work. Be ready to handle many tasks and operations!\n作業 often focuses on individual, hands-on tasks that are undertaken to accomplish a specific objective. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYou love the work involved in sawing gyoza (さぎょう). There's something about taking a piece of gyoza and sawing right through it that you just love so much.
1112 | 入所 | にゅうしょ | Admission | Entrance\n Imprisonment\n Internment | You enter a facility. So this is your admission or entrance into that facility.\n入所 is for entering facilities or institutions, often those with names ending in 所, like a 研究所 (research institute). It's also used in prison contexts. You might gain "admission" to prison for not doing your WaniKani reviews, for example, at least in countries ruled by Crabigators... \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1113 | 上級 | じょうきゅう | Advanced Level | High Grade\n Advanced Grade\n High Level | When you are at an above rank, you are at an advanced level. This is referring to things like proficiency in Japanese, or things like that. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1114 | 味方 | みかた | Ally | Supporter\n Friend | The flavor of this direction is one I'd like to follow and go in, along with you. You have a good flavor and you're going in a good direction. Will you be my ally? I'll be your supporter. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for 味 and the kun'yomi reading for 方. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to read this word!
1115 | 売り上げ | うりあげ | Amount Sold | Sales\n Proceeds | The selling that you've raised (上げ) is the amount sold or number of sales. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things. \n The reading for 売 is the one you learned with 売る. The reading for 上げ is the same as the reading for 上げる, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things, you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.
1116 | 不良 | ふりょう | Bad | Substandard\n Delinquent | Something that's not good is bad or substandard. This usage is more formal and frequently paired with other kanji compounds. Alternatively, it can refer to someone who is a  delinquent, in which case it is often used as a standalone word. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1117 | 初歩 | しょほ | Basics | Rudiments\n Elements\n ABCs | The first thing you walk through when you learn something new will always be the basics. You never start by running, you always have to start slow and work your way through the ABCs before you start to run. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1118 | 戦い | たたかい | Battle | Fight\n Conflict | Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in い, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in war. Those things are battles, fights, and conflicts. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn a fierce battle, there's always a lot of collateral damage. One of the things that gets destroyed is your car. But you can't do anything about it, it's battle time! So you wave goodbye to your car saying, "Ta-ta car (たたか)!" as you punch some jerk in the face.
1119 | 戦場 | せんじょう | Battlefield | Battleground | A war location is the battlefield. That's where the wars are fought, anyways. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1120 | 予め | あらかじめ | Beforehand | In Advance\n Previously\n Ahead Of Time | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat did you do beforehand? You had a raw casual (あらかじ) encounter with a raw Cage, Nic Cage. You probably should have planned something better ahead of time.
1121 | 初級 | しょきゅう | Beginner Level | Elementary Level\n Beginning Level | The first rank of something is the beginner level. Compare this to 中級 and 上級 (vocab from this level) to get a fuller understanding. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1122 | 伝記 | でんき | Biography | Life Story | If you want to transmit the story of someone's life, you have to write down all of it in a biography. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1123 | 生物学 | せいぶつがく | Biology |  | Remember how 生物 means "living things?" Well when you study living things you're studying biology. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1124 | 乗り場 | のりば | Bus Stop | Taxi Stand\n Train Platform\n Boarding Area | You've seen the word 乗る by now, hopefully, and know it means "to ride." So this word has to do with a "riding location." Where do you go to get a ride somewhere? Most likely, it's a bus stop or taxi stand. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you've learned already. Also, use 乗る to help you to remember the reading for 乗り.
1125 | 注意 | ちゅうい | Caution | Attention\n Warning | When you pour your ideas into something, you're thinking a lot about it. You're paying close attention and using caution. You'll see this on a lot of warning signs marking dangerous things in Japan, so be sure to pay attention to them! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1126 | 洋服 | ようふく | Clothes | Western Clothing\n Western Style Clothes | Western style clothes is just Western clothing (or Western style clothes). But nowadays, because Japanese people wear Western clothing all the time, we use it to just mean clothes. We're talking things that aren't kimonos, etc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1127 | 共通点 | きょうつうてん | Common Point | Common Feature\n Commonality | We pass through this point together. This point is our common point. It is where our ideas, philosophies, and bodies pass through each other. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1128 | 仲間 | なかま | Companion | Comrade\n Associate | Your relationship intervals... this doesn't make much sense at first, but if you think about it, at certain intervals from within your friends, you'll run into someone who's your companion... not just any old friend. Something better. Something part of your group. \n The reading for 仲 is the one you learned. When you learned the kanji 間, we didn't give you a mnemonic for the (ま) reading, so here's one now:\nThink through all your companions in your life. Imagine one of them is your Ma (ま). She's on your pirate crew, and a pretty awesome pirate.
1129 | 競争 | きょうそう | Competition |  | When you compete to the point of conflict, you know that this person / entity is your competition. Gotta beat out that competition. For example, in order to beat out the competition, WaniKani has a mascot that can eat every other small furry animal that the competition has for their mascot. Case closed. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1130 | 便利 | べんり | Convenient | Handy\n Useful | When you profit from your convenience, that means you have something very convenient or handy. Remember, you can profit in other ways besides money. This convenience could be giving you a profit in happiness or extra time as well. All these things are very handy to have. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1131 | 共同 | きょうどう | Cooperation | Collaboration\n Joint | People working together on the same thing is cooperation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1132 | 〜部 | ぶ | Department | Club\n Category | You'll see this attached to other words... like "sales" or "tennis." When you see this, you'll know it is a ___ department, or a ___ club, making this word mean department or club, similar to the kanji meaning. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading. Don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached to this word.
1133 | 別 | べつ | Different | Separate | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1134 | 別人 | べつじん | Different Person | Changed Person\n Changed Man | A separate person is someone who is different from who they were before. I saw you a year ago and you were someone else. Now you're a different person, in a good way! You're a changed man. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1135 | 教育 | きょういく | Education |  | Teach and nurture. That's what your education is supposed to do. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1136 | 入学試験 | にゅうがくしけん | Entrance Exam | Entrance Examination\n Admission Test\n Admission Exam\n Admission Examination\n Entrance Test | For school admission (入学) you're taking an examination (試験). What exams do you have to take to get into a school? How about entrance exams? The Japanese ones are pretty hard. Another word for them is "hell tests." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It'll also help if you know the two separate words that make up this longer word.
1137 | 特に | とくに | Especially | Particularly | Something is towards (に) special. That thing is especially special, wouldn't you say? \n The reading is the same reading you learned for this kanji.
1138 | 運命 | うんめい | Fate | Destiny | Everyone has to carry their fate. So what is the thing you're carrying? It's your fate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1139 | 気持ち | きもち | Feeling |  | The energy you hold in your body is your feelings. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling." \n 気 is on'yomi and you learned that with the kanji. 持ち, though, is kun'yomi, which you learned with the word 持つ. One of those weird exception readings, but the ち on the end of 持ち is a clue that it uses the kun'yomi.
1140 | 心持ち | こころもち | Feeling | Mood\n Somewhat\n Slightly | Your heart holds a lot of feelings. They can be overwhelming and sometimes it feels like there are none in there at all, but that doesn't mean they aren't there in your heart. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the words 心 and 持つ, so you should be able to read this on your own.
1141 | 指 | ゆび | Finger | Toe | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. The only difference is that this word can mean finger or toe. What are toes but small, walking fingers? \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nWhat do you use your finger for the most? For pointing, of course! Imagine going up to people and saying, "What will you be (ゆび) when you grow up?" Point your finger at the next person, "What will you be?" Keep going until you're just saying, "You be? You be?" with your finger out.
1142 | 一位 | いちい | First Place | First Rank | When you are number one in rank, you're in first place. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1143 | 首位 | しゅい | First Place | Head Position\n Leading Position\n First Position | If you’re at neck rank you’re in first place. Haven’t you ever heard the phrase, “neck and neck” when two people in a race are both super close to first place? Just remember that and you’ll never forget this word. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned this reading for 首 when you learned 部首, and the reading for 位 is the one you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
1144 | 昔話 | むかしばなし | Folk Tale | Legend\n Old Story\n Folklore | Long ago people used to talk about all sorts of things. Most of them weren't true. Long ago people liked to lie a lot. Now we call those things they talked about folk tales and legends. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for the rendaku of はなし to ばなし.
1145 | 食べ物 | たべもの | Food |  | An eat thing (aka "a thing you eat") is food. Eat those things. Eat that food. Because it's a "thing" you know it's a noun. Interesting how this kanji can turn a verb like this into a noun, right? Look out for it because this pattern will show up with other verbs as well! \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
1146 | 友好 | ゆうこう | Friendship |  | If you have a friend you like, well, that's true friendship! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1147 | 仕返し | しかえし | Getting Even | Getting Back At\n Retaliation\n Revenge | When you return the doings of another person, you're doing it to get even (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing). \n The readings are a bit weird, here. 仕 gets its on'yomi reading... you should be okay with that. 返し gets the kun'yomi reading, though, which is the reading you saw with the word 返す in level 9. You can tell this part uses the kun'yomi vocab reading because it has that hiragana attached to it. Just remember to distinguish between the two parts of the word to remember the readings.
1148 | 神 | かみ | God | Gods | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nDo you know the word "Kamikaze"? Also, do you remember the word 風 from a previous level? Kamikaze means "divine winds" or "godly winds." If you know the word "Kamikaze" you can apply it to this single word, that means "god" or "gods." Use your prior knowledge to remember this reading.
1149 | 良い | よい | Good |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of good? It's also good. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nA good way to pass the time is with a yo-yo (よ). But it better be a good yo-yo. A bad one will just fall apart.
1150 | 気持ちいい | きもちいい | Good Feeling | Feeling Good\n Feels Good | When you have a "feeling" (気持ち) that is いい (that means "good" by the way), you have a good feeling. \n The reading comes from the vocab word 気持ち, so if you know that (or the vocab words 気 and 持ち) you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even feeling good about it?
1151 | 努力 | どりょく | Great Effort | Exertion\n Grueling Effort | You toil and use your strength. Ugh! How difficult. You really put in a great effort. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1152 | 苦労 | くろう | Hardship | Troubles | Suffering and labor. Sounds like the kind of thing these soft hands wouldn't want to deal with. These are hardships and troubles. Hopefully you don't have too much of this with kanji anymore! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1153 | 苦手 | にがて | Hard To Deal With | Weak Point\n Poor At\n Not Very Good At\n Bad At | A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words 苦い (bitter) and 手 (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely hard to deal with. \n The reading is that of 苦い (にがい) plus regular old 手 (て). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange にがい reading.
1154 | 高級 | こうきゅう | High-Class | High Grade\n High Level | A tall grade item is really just a high grade or high-class item. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1155 | 平仮名 | ひらがな | Hiragana |  | Remember how you learned that 仮名 means "kana?" Well this is flat kana. Flat kana is just hiragana. \n You should know the reading for this word because it's the same as the English meaning.
1156 | 使い方 | つかいかた | How To Use | Way Of Using | You've seen the word 使う hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the way to use something is the way of using (aka how to use). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something. \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 使う and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
1157 | 〜付き | つき | Including | Included\n Furnished With\n Attached To | You know that the kanji 付 means attach and words like 付く mean "to be attached." This has the same idea. When you see this attached to another word, for example, you might know that something is attached to something else, or perhaps included with it. For example, if you stay at a hotel room, maybe it is a breakfast付き, i.e. "including breakfast." \n The reading comes from the reading of the kanji as well as from words like 付く and 付ける.
1158 | 不便 | ふべん | Inconvenient | Not Convenient | Something that is not convenience is inconvenient. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1159 | 中級 | ちゅうきゅう | Intermediate Level | Intermediate Rank\n Intermediate Grade | Something at the middle rank or grade is at an intermediate level. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1160 | 始めに | はじめに | In The Beginning | To Begin With\n To Start With | Remember how 始める means "to begin something"? 始め is its noun version and means "beginning," as in the start of an action or process. に marks a point in time. So 始めに means in the beginning.\n始めに can also mean to begin with or to start with when introducing an opening action, like 始めに、ウォーミングアップをしましょう (let's begin with some warm-up exercises). \n The reading is kun'yomi (look at all that hiragana!) but that's the reading you learned with the word 始める, so have no fear, you got it!
1161 | 仕事 | しごと | Job | Work\n Occupation | You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "thing." So when you're doing things all day, what are you probably doing? A job! All jobs really just amount to doing things. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for 仕 and the kun'yomi reading for 事. Please note that 事 uses the reading こと, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced ごと.
1162 | 丁度いい | ちょうどいい | Just Right | Exactly Right | If 丁度 is "exactly", then "exactly good" is going to be just the right amount, aka just right. \n If you know the reading for 丁度 you'll know the reading for this too. Your knowledge should be just right, as they say inside my head.
1163 | 労働者 | ろうどうしゃ | Laborer | Blue Collar Worker\n Manual Laborer | Someone who does labor for work is a laborer. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1164 | 命 | いのち | Life |  | A vocab made from a single kanji all alone usually keeps at least one of the meanings of its kanji parent. In this case, that's life. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThe Book of Enoch (いのち) has passed down your fate and told you how to use your life. You must read the book of Enoch and find out what you're supposed to do.
1165 | 好き | すき | Like | Love\n Likable\n Lovable | You know that 好 means like and this vocab word means the same thing: like or love!\nThis word is an adjective in Japanese, so a more literal translation is likable or lovable. Still, it usually sounds more natural to translate it as a verb in English. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho do you like more than anyone? Your friend Sue. If you know someone named Sue, pretend you like her. If you don't, think of a famous person you know named Sue and use her, pretending you're good friends that like each other a lot.
1166 | 文字通り | もじどおり | Literal | Literally\n To The Letter | Remember how you learned the words 文字 and 通り? Well an "avenue" made of "letters" is literally to the letter. Wink. \n This is a combination of the words 文字 and 通り, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this one. Just make sure you remember that とおり becomes どおり because of rendaku.
1167 | 昔 | むかし | Long Ago | Long Time Ago | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is a good way to start stories, by the way: 昔々に… (Long, long ago). \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. むかし sounds like a kun'yomi reading, doesn't it? It's so long.
1168 | 負け犬 | まけいぬ | Loser |  | You've hopefully come across 負ける by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a loser. \n The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with 負ける and of course 犬 well enough to learn the reading here.
1169 | 低い | ひくい | Low | Short | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of low? It's low. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou look down and very low to the ground is a man, looking up at you. Your friend is there too, but you don't know this little man. Your friend says "He coo', he coo," referring to the low to the ground man.
1170 | 労働 | ろうどう | Manual Labor | Labor\n Work | The labor work is when you're doing work with your body, right? That's manual labor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1171 | 意味 | いみ | Meaning |  | The flavor of an idea, what is that? Imagine yourself licking an idea to figure out what it tastes like. What do you think you'll be tasting? Probably the meaning of said idea. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1172 | 新た | あらた | New | Fresh\n Novel\n Newly\n Freshly | This is the adverb version of the kanji new, so it means new too. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour parents put a newly wrapped present under the Christmas tree. You don't want to wait to see what new thing they got you so you rip it open to find they got you a raw (あら) steak. Getting a new steak is cool and all, but a raw steak is pretty gross. It's dripping blood all over the place.
1173 | 別に | べつに | Not Particularly | Not Really\n Separately\n In Addition To | If someone asks if you want a separate knee (に), you'll say not particularly. I mean, you've never thought about it, but do you really need more knees? Not really...\nIn this first meaning, 別に is often used on its own, or with a negative verb or adjective, as in 別に長くない (not particularly long).\nHowever, when 別に is used with a positive verb, it often simply means separately, or in addition to. After all, when you have to do something separately, you have to do it in addition to something else. Like learning this meaning in addition to the first one. What a chore! \n The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. Well done!
1174 | 発売中 | はつばいちゅう | Now For Sale | In Stores Now\n Now Available | You have 発売, which means "for sale," and then you have 中 which is middle. An item that is in the middle of being for sale is now for sale, in stores now or in other words now available.
