You'll see this for items which have recently been released or when a shopkeeper wants to let you know that they're selling something now, finally, or whatever. \n The reading comes from 発売 and 中 (kanji reading) put together.
1175 | 老人 | ろうじん | Old Person | Elderly Person | An elderly person is an old person (or an elderly person). Don't call a person a 古い人, though. 古い is used for things, not people. Be nice, they're your elders. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nEvery old person has roe jeans(ろうじん), a special pair of jeans smeared with roe that they wear when they go out on the town. Some elderly people have cod roe jeans, some have salmon roe jeans… But tofugu roe jeans (adorned with the roe of the lesser spotted tofugu) are the most fashionable of all.
1176 | 意見 | いけん | Opinion | View | The idea you see in your head is your opinion. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your 意見, man." \n The reading is all on'yomi, meaning 意 is just fine. 見's on'yomi (けん) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with 発見 a couple levels ago, so that should help. Still, here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nIn this case, just think about how Ken the samurai has an opinion on everything. Ken is such a know-it-all, and you're better off agreeing with his opinions. He's a samurai after all!
1177 | 注文 | ちゅうもん | Order | Request | You pour writing onto a form. You're filling out this form to order something new for yourself. It's a formal request to get this new thing (imagine it being something you're excited about ordering right now, and imagine yourself ordering it by pouring writing onto an order form). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1178 | 命令 | めいれい | Order | Command | Your fate orders are the orders you get from above. You are ordered and commanded to carry out said orders. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1179 | 太平洋 | たいへいよう | Pacific Ocean |  | The fat peace ocean is the Pacific Ocean. The Japanese language thinks this ocean is peaceful, just like English does (the word 太平 actually means "peace").\nNote that we're using the alternative meaning of 洋 here! If you didn't learn that with the kanji, just imagine that to get to Western Style places you need to cross the ocean from Japan! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1180 | 用意 | ようい | Preparation | Getting Ready | When you have an idea for a task you are in preparation for actually doing it. Because it's still just an idea you're still getting ready. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1181 | 公共 | こうきょう | Public | Community | When the public comes together you have yourself a nice community made up of the public. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1182 | 〜位 | い | Rank |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the on'yomi reading, which you learned. This is probably because you'll see this word attached to other words, showing the rank of that thing.
1183 | 本物 | ほんもの | Real Thing | Real Deal\n Genuine Article | The real thing is the real thing, aka the real deal.\nIf you learned 本 as book you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million. \n The readings are on'yomi plus kun'yomi (kun'yomi is 物). You learned the reading of the kanji 本 and also the vocabulary reading of 物, so you should be able to read it.
1184 | 電波 | でんぱ | Reception | Radio Wave\n Electromagnetic Wave | The electricity wave is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words you can use to describe this, but the easiest one is reception (like the reception on your phone, for example).\nOther more technical meanings are radio wave and electromagnetic waves. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T, otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more… \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The は from 波 rendakus to ぱ, so be careful. Maybe it's your pa who has bad reception every time you try to call him?
1185 | 受付 | うけつけ | Receptionist | Reception | Imagine someone accepting something and then attaching something. This person is a receptionist, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available." \n For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely 受ける and 付ける. Then just drop off the るs and put them together. 受 becomes うけ and 付 becomes つけ and you're left with うけつけ. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!
1186 | 仲直り | なかなおり | Reconciliation | Making Peace\n Making Up | A relationship fix is reconciliation, making peace, or making up with someone. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 仲 you're fine. That's what you learned with the kanji. For 直り think back to the vocab word 直る. That's what's going on here.
1187 | 仲 | なか | Relationship | Relation | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading since it's a single kanji, all alone, but this is the reading you learned with the kanji, so you should be okay and have a great relationship with this word going forward.
1188 | 金持ち | かねもち | Rich Person | Rich\n Wealthy | When you hold gold you are a rich person. \n Do you remember the word お金? This is the 金 in that word. The reading for 持ち is the も you learned with 持つ. So, combine the かね of お金 and the 持ち and you have the reading of this word. Note that just like お金, you'll often see this with the honorific prefix お in front of it as well.
1189 | 屋上 | おくじょう | Rooftop | Housetop | Above the roof is the rooftop. What else would be up there? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 屋 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nOne place in the world has more rooftops than any where else, and that's Oklahoma (おく). They get so many tornadoes that they need extra rooftops for when the first few blow off.
1190 | 海岸 | かいがん | Seashore | Coast\n Seacoast | The ocean/sea coast is the seashore. Then again, it could also be the coast as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1191 | 秒 | びょう | Second |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well - that is the unit of time, second. \n The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji. It's presumably because it's usually attached to other things, like numbers, making it act more like a jukugo word would. Anyway, you should only need a second to learn this reading, since you should already know it.
1192 | 安売り | やすうり | Sell Cheaply | Discount\n Bargain Sale\n Sale | When you sell something cheap, you're selling it at a discount. Alternatively you can remember this word as sell cheaply or bargain sale. These are good deals! \n The hiragana on the end hints that the readings are the kun'yomi readings. Use your memory of 安い and 売る to help you to remember how to read this.
1193 | 売り手 | うりて | Seller | Vendor | Remember how 手 can mean “doer”? Here, we have a sell doer. Who might that be? It’s someone who does selling – a seller or vendor.\n売り手 is usually used when talking about sellers versus buyers. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too! One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.
1194 | 別の | べつの | Separate | Different\n Another\n Separate Thing\n Different Thing\n Another Thing | The の is there to indicate that it is the difference of something. For example this is like saying "the separate ______" or "the different _____" or "another ______". 別 by itself just means separate, different, or another. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned. Move on to a 別の漢字, ok?
1195 | 別々 | べつべつ | Separately | Individually | When you separate separate you're putting things off into their own areas. You're marking them off separately and individually. \n The reading is just the べつ reading you know, twice.
1196 | 共有 | きょうゆう | Shared | Co Ownership\n Joint Ownership\n Share | The things you together have are the things that are shared. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1197 | 神道 | しんとう | Shinto | Shintou | The way/road of the god(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's Shinto. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help. \n The reading is a bit wonky. 神 should be no problem. 道 on the other hand is almost the one you learned (どう) but now it's とう for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it とう, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.
1198 | 神社 | じんじゃ | Shinto Shrine |  | A God company... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a Shinto Shrine because of the しん in the 神. \n But wait! 神 is read じん in this word for some reason. Darn them gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto Shrine. You are praying to the Gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains Ginger (じんじゃ). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.
1199 | 買い物 | かいもの | Shopping |  | You've hopefully seen 買う by now and know it means "to buy." So, 買い is going to be similar to that. Add that to thing and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes shopping. \n The readings are the kun'yomi, which is usually the case when there's hiragana in the middle. You learned the reading for 買い when you learned the kanji, as well as the word 買う, and you learned this reading of 物 in the word 物!
1200 | 辺 | へん | Side |  | One of the kanji meanings is side, and as a standalone word this also means side, as in the sides of a shape. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1201 | 見物 | けんぶつ | Sightseeing | Sightseer\n Watching | If you try to see a bunch of things at once, you are probably sightseeing or watching. This can also refer to the person doing the action, so it can sometimes mean sightseer too. \n The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read 物. 見's on'yomi (けん) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with 発見 a couple levels ago, so that should help. Just imagine taking the samurai Ken on an epic sightseeing trip. Think of all the things you and Ken will visit!
1202 | 売り切れ | うりきれ | Sold Out | Out Of Stock | When the selling is cut, that means something is sold out. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able! \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
1203 | 時々 | ときどき | Sometimes | At Times | You know the single word 時, right? It means time. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen sometimes. \n The reading is the vocab word 時 twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.
1204 | 特別 | とくべつ | Special |  | Something that is special and separate from the rest is, well, special. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1205 | 見事 | みごと | Splendid | Magnificent\n Beautiful\n Admirable\n Praiseworthy Act | Learner, if you see a thing, then it must be splendid. You saw it, after all, so of course it's magnificent. You only see the beautiful things in this world. And that's an admirable quality. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that there is rendaku on こと and it becomes ごと.
1206 | 成功 | せいこう | Success |  | When you become achievement, you have probably gained plenty of success. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1207 | 作戦 | さくせん | Tactics | Strategy\n Operation | When you make war, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make strategy, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome tactics for your operation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1208 | 物語 | ものがたり | Tale | Story\n Legend | A language about things. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means tale or story or legend (not the Tom Cruise one, though). \n Both kanji take the kun'yomi here. For 物, that's もの, which you learned with the vocabulary 物. You learned the kun'yomi for 語 with the verb 語る, but here it becomes がたり because of rendaku, and the り is tucked inside the kanji.\nMaybe you've already heard the word ものがたり too. It's in some film and book names. If you haven't, and you find this reading hard to remember, think of a story about an infamous Gatling (がたり) gun that wandered the land, mowing everything down in its path. It's a terrible legend, but what if it were true???
1209 | 戦車 | せんしゃ | Tank |  | A war car is probably a little more dangerous than the Honda you drive. No, a war car is a tank. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1210 | 味 | あじ | Taste | Flavor | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou may have the ability to taste things now, but just wait until you get up there in age (あじ). You'll find that the tastes and flavors you once liked will become bland, and you'll need a lot of Sriracha to make things taste better.
1211 | 最初 | さいしょ | The First | First\n Beginning\n Outset | The most first thing is the first thing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1212 | 初回 | しょかい | The First Time | First Time | The first of something you'll do several or many times is the first time. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1213 | 最低 | さいてい | The Lowest | The Worst\n The Minimum\n Nasty\n Terrible | The most low is the lowest or the minimum. It's also what you call something when you think it's the worst or just plain terrible. Try yelling this out when you're disgusted about someone or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1214 | 西洋 | せいよう | The West | Western Countries\n Western | The Western styled West is still known as the West. The one everyone refers to over in Asia when they talk about Western countries in Europe and North America. This is the place you'll hear people say you're from if you live in Canada or something. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1215 | 進める | すすめる | To Advance Something | To Move Something Forward | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means advance, and this verb means to advance something or to move something forward.\nThis is a transitive verb, so you act upon something else. You advance something. You move something forward. Like a school project, or your plans for taking over the world. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help:\nYou are moving your lawsuit forward against Sue. But now she says that YOU'RE the problem. "Sue, sue me," (すすめ) you say as you continue to advance the lawsuit. Make sure to say "me" like "mehh," in a really snobbish way.
1216 | 指定する | していする | To Appoint | To Assign\n To Designate\n To Specify | When you determine and use your finger to point at someone or something, you're going to appoint them. Just imagine yourself determining who's the best for the job then pointing with your finger. That is who you will appoint. The する on the end makes it a verb, so 指定 would be "appointment" or "designation" or something along those lines. Cool how する works. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1217 | 成る | なる | To Become |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means become so the vocab verb version would be to become.\nWhile the kanji version is worth knowing, be aware that you'll usually see this verb written in hiragana. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are starting to become something else. You're transforming, but you're not sure what it is. First, you get fins... uh oh, something in the water. Then, you gain a tail and rubbery skin... hmm, something sea mammal-like. Oh, and then a huge horn flies out of your nose. You are going to become a narwhal (な).
1218 | 育つ | そだつ | To Be Raised | To Be Brought Up\n To Grow Up | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means raise so the verb vocab version means to be raised.\nP.S. This word is for when you are being raised, not when you are doing the raising of someone. That's 育てる. You'll learn it later. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you were raised, you were raised completely on soda (そだ). That's all you drank. No water, no juice... just tons and tons of soda. Imagine this.
1219 | 返る | かえる | To Be Returned | To Return\n To Come Back | You hopefully know the word 返す, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning it). Use the る to help you to remember this. る the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means to be returned.\nNote this word is often combined with くる (to come), which reinforces the aspect that something is coming back to you. \n The reading is the same as 返す, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.
1220 | 放送する | ほうそうする | To Broadcast Something |  | You are going to release and send something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going to broadcast something to the world!\nThe する is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the する it would be the noun "broadcast." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1221 | 追う | おう | To Follow | To Chase | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means follow so the verb version is to follow (it's also to chase, because when you follow something you are chasing it too). \n You've learned this reading already, so you should know how to read this word!
1222 | 通う | かよう | To Commute | To Attend\n To Go Back And Forth | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means pass through but we already know the word 通る which means to pass through. This word means a different kind of passing through, like how you pass through the halls of your school everyday. But we don't say to pass through school, we say to attend school, or to commute to school. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou live in the middle of three different school districts so you need to decide which of the three schools you want to attend. You decide you don't mind that you have to commute to the farthest of the three because their mascot is Wile E. Coyote (かよ). He's your favorite Looney Toon because he always has the energy to go back and forth after that road runner.
1223 | 比べる | くらべる | To Compare |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compare so the verb vocab version is to compare. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Look at this cooler (くら). Now look at this other cooler. We need to  compare the two coolers. Think about all the features each one has and really compare, like you have a list or something.
1224 | 争う | あらそう | To Compete | To Argue\n To Quarrel | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conflict so the vocabulary means to compete, to argue, or to quarrel. Your views conflict with someone else's so you're going to compete with them to see who's right. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're starting to compete and to argue with someone, who is yelling at you: "You are so (あらそ) stupid!". You might want to imagine this in an accent that gets you closer to the Japanese pronunciation.
1225 | 競う | きそう | To Compete |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compete so the verb vocab version means to compete. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou really have to compete for key soap (きそ). These days everyone wants their keys as clean as possible, and the special key soap they use is pretty hard to come by. Whenever it's in stock again people try to compete over it. Just imagine all those shoppers fighting over some key soap…
1226 | 集中する | しゅうちゅうする | To Concentrate | To Focus | You collect and focus in on the middle. Really zoom in on it. When you do this, you're concentrating on this spot, thus making the meaning of this word to concentrate or to focus. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1227 | 決定する | けっていする | To Decide | To Determine | A 決定 is a "decision." So, when you add する to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means to decide. \n The reading is the same as 決定 with する added. Make sure you know 決定 and you'll know this word as well.
1228 | 欠かす | かかす | To Do Without | To Miss An Event\n To Fail To Do | Remember how 欠 means lack? This verb is related. The 欠かす form is a little tricky, but it's sort of like you're causing yourself to lack something. So it means to do without. Depending on the context, it can also mean to miss an event or to fail to do something. Just keep in mind this word is most often used in the negative, like 欠かせないもの (things you can't do without) or 朝のコーヒーは欠かさない (never go without morning coffee).\nYou can remember 欠かす this way: Since you cause yourself to lack something with this word, it's all your fault. That's why you want to cuss (かす). You made yourself miss out on something. Well, $*%!!! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1229 | 便所 | べんじょ | Restroom | Bathroom\n Toilet | *Ahem.* This is the convenience facility. What place above all others should be convenient to get to? You know, just in case? That would be the restroom. You might also call it the bathroom, the toilet, the lavatory, or the facilities.\nThis word is casual and can often sound gruff, so you won't normally see it on official signs or hear it in polite conversation. It's worth knowing so you can understand it in casual speaking and writing though. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the rendaku.
1230 | 保持する | ほじする | To Keep | To Hold\n To Maintain\n To Retain | This is the verb version of 保持 (keep), so this means to keep, to hold, or to maintain.\nNote that this is a formal word that's commonly used in professional or official contexts. \n The reading is the same as 保持, so if you know that word's reading, you know this one too.
1231 | 欠く | かく | To Lack Something |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means lack, and this verb means to lack something. Pretty simple in English, but 欠く is actually kind of advanced and formal in Japanese, so it's mostly just used in writing.\nAlso keep in mind this is a transitive verb, so 欠く takes a direct object — maybe someone lacks knowledge, for example, or you lack concentration. This is a bit different from saying "your concentration is lacking," at least grammatically. (For that, you'd use 欠ける.) \n You learned this reading when you learned 欠ける, but here's a mnemonic just in case:\nYou never know when you're going to lack something. Like a car (か). Did you plan for it to break? NO! But it happened and now you lack a car in a big way. Not cool (く)!
1232 | 開放する | かいほうする | To Open Something Up | To Throw Something Open\n To Open Something To The Public | When you open then release, say, a door, you're opening it up for everyone to come in. That's why it means to open something up or to throw something open. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1233 | 拾う | ひろう | To Pick Something Up | To Find Something\n To Gather Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pick up so the verb vocab version is to pick something up. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done!
1234 | 指す | さす | To Point | To Point At\n To Indicate\n To Refer To | The kanji means finger. So, if you "to finger" something, what are you doing? You're pointing. That's why this word means to point. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou are pointing at something in fear. It is a saw (さ). Thing is, you're pointing at this saw with a missing finger. It just cut off your finger and you're freaking out, trying to point with a bloody non-finger.
1235 | 注ぐ | そそぐ | To Pour |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pour so the verb vocab version is to pour. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou are going to pour some sauce (そそ).
1236 | 気付く | きづく | To Realize | To Notice | When you attach your energy (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), you have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means to realize or to notice.\nDon't confuse this with 気を付けて which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on. \n The readings come from the 気 kanji (which you know) and the word 付く which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the 付く part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.
1237 | 放す | はなす | To Release | To Let Go\n To Release Something\n To Let Go Of Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means release so the verb vocab version is to release. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you are going to release something. It is a 花 (はな). You release it from your hand and it falls, hitting the ground in slow motion. You have the power to release and you are doing the releasing (versus 放れる where something is just released). You can remember this because even though you did the releasing of the flower, you're going to sue the pavement company for breaking your flower. It's all a big scam you're running.
1238 | 転がす | ころがす | To Roll Something | To Turn Something Over | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means revolve, and the verb version is when you make something revolve. You roll it. That's why this verb is to roll something.\nThis is a transitive verb. That means you roll something else, like a ball. Or, if you're a dung beetle, poop. 💩 Not to be confused with 転がる, which is intransitive, like so many verbs ending in がる. \n You learned this reading when you learned 転がる, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case:\nWhen you try to roll something, the outside bits may be moving, but its core (ころ) stays still. Picture yourself making the earth roll across the floor. The outside parts where the people live are spinning round and round, but the earth's core is in exactly the same place.
1239 | 見送る | みおくる | To See Off | To Put Off\n To Pass On | You know the words 見る and 送る by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is to see off. This can also mean to put off or to pass on, since it's as though you're just passively seeing someone (or something) off rather than taking action and going with them. \n The readings come from the vocab words 見る and 送る. Make sure you know those and you'll know this word's reading as well.
1240 | 苦しむ | くるしむ | To Suffer | To Struggle | You've already been introduced to the word 苦しい. That word means painful, or agonizing. So, if you turn that into a verb, you have to suffer or to struggle. \n The reading comes from 苦しい, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.
1241 | 伝える | つたえる | To Transmit | To Tell\n To Pass Down\n To Convey | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transmit, so the verb version is to transmit or to tell something. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to transmit a signal to the stars (つた)! Trying to tell your message to anyone on earth would be too boring and too easy. Aim your message at the nearest star and transmit it into space!
1242 | 試す | ためす | To Try Something Out | To Give Something A Try | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attempt or try. The verb vocab version is to try something out or to give something a try. Why don't you try out the meaning of this verb, while you're at it? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Okay. Here's the deal. We have this wild animal. I want you to attempt to tame (ため) it. Now, imagine trying to tame this wild animal. Yeehaw!
1243 | 働く | はたらく | To Work | To Labor\n To Commit | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means work, and the verb version means to work, to labor, and sometimes to commit (a crime). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are as mad as a hatter you'll need to work very hard to regain your sanity. You know The Hatter from Alice in Wonderland? Imagine how hard he would have to work to be considered "normal".
1244 | 利く | きく | To Work Well | To Be Possible\n To Be Effective | You know the kanji means profit. When you make it into a verb, though, it means to work well. If you think about it, when something works well it makes you a profit. \n What works so well? Your special key (き) that can unlock anyone and anything's potential. Imagine putting it into a key slot in someone's back. Someone who's a good for nothing can't-do-anything is now an effective member of society! Go around using your key on other non-effective things and show them that anything is possible!
1245 | 意外 | いがい | Unexpected | Surprising | Something outside your normal idea of how things work will come as unexpected or surprising to you. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1246 | 乗り物 | のりもの | Vehicle |  | You know that 乗り has something to do with riding and that 物 is a thing. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a vehicle. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
1247 | 勝ち | かち | Victory | Win\n A Victory\n A Win | You've hopefully seen 勝つ by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's a win or a victory. \n The reading comes from 勝つ. So as long as you have some understanding of that reading, you should be able to read this one as well.
1248 | 戦争 | せんそう | War |  | You have war and conflict. Of course, conflict comes with war, so this word just means war. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1249 | 波 | なみ | Wave |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nYou jump on a wave and ride around the world on it. As you ride this wave, it gets bigger and bigger, until it reaches tsunami (なみ) proportions. Imagine looking down from the tsunami at the vast, blue sea all around you. That's quite a wave you're riding.
1250 | 洋食 | ようしょく | Western Food | Western Style Food | The Western eats are Western food. Mmmm, 'dem hamburgers. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1251 | 洋風 | ようふう | Western Style |  | Remember how 風 can mean "style" as in 和風? Well, this is now Western style style, more simply put as Western style. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1252 | 洋室 | ようしつ | Western Style Room |  | A Western style room is a Western style room. We're talking something that's not a tatami mat filled room. Good to know this word if you're staying in hotels or ryokans and prefer not to sleep on a futon, etc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1253 | 誰 | だれ | Who |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1254 | 行動 | こうどう | Action | Behavior | When you go to move you're actually making an action. This word can also mean behavior, since your actions are what make up your behavior. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1255 | 活動 | かつどう | Activity |  | The lively moves you make are your activity.\n活動 includes all kinds of activities, including nature activities, club activities, economic activity, and so on! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1256 | 空港 | くうこう | Airport |  | Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A sky harbor is an airport, nothing more. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1257 | 全員 | ぜんいん | All Members | All Hands\n Everyone\n Everybody | All members means all members. This is also a fancy way to say everybody. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1258 | もう | もう | Already | Soon\n Yet\n Anymore | You've mowed your lawn (もう) already? Wow, you're ahead on your mowing. Good work. You'll have to do it again soon, though.\nThis can also mean yet in a question, and anymore with a negative.
1259 | 動物 | どうぶつ | Animal |  | A moving thing... think about the "things" that move. Technically it could be a lot of things (aka basically anything), but in this case we are talking about moving living things. We won't include humans, because humans are too good to be called things. This refers to animals instead. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1260 | 鳴き声 | なきごえ | Animal Cry | Animal Sound\n Animal Noise\n Chirp\n Tweet\n Roar\n Bark\n Meow | The chirp voice is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an animal cry. \n The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. 声 gets changed to ごえ, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.
1261 | 勝手 | かって | As One Pleases | One's Own Convenience\n One's Own Way\n One's Way | The hand (or person, as you know 手 often refers to a person) that wins gets to do as one pleases without regard for anyone else. \n The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do as one pleases you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small っ in there before 手, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.
1262 | 悪い | わるい | Bad | Poor\n Wrong | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of bad? It's also bad. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nDo you know how in the Mario universe all the bad versions are called "WARU" (わる)? For example: "WARUIJI" and "WARIO." That's because they are bad. They come from this kanji. So, if you ever need to remember this reading, just think back to Wario and Waruigi.
1263 | 悪人 | あくにん | Bad Person | Villain\n Evildoer\n Bad Guy\n Wicked Person\n Evil Person | A bad person is a bad person. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1264 | 野球 | やきゅう | Baseball |  | Field Sphere! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, baseball. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1265 | 飲み物 | のみもの | Beverage | Drink | A thing you drink is a beverage. \n These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!
1266 | 酒飲み | さけのみ | Boozer | Drunkard | We have alcohol and a variant form of 飲む (to drink). So you know this has to do with drinking alcohol. It means a boozer or a drunkard, someone who drinks a lot of alcohol! \n The readings are the vocab words お酒 and 飲む combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the み on the end of 飲, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).
1267 | 親分 | おやぶん | Boss | Kingpin\n Chief\n Head | Who is part parent to you? Your boss! They make it so you can take care of yourself by paying you, don't they? They'll break the legs of someone who crosses you. But they won't help you get back to sleep after you have nightmares. So they're only part like a parent. \n This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 親 and the on'yomi reading for 分. You've learned both of these so you should be able to read this already!
1268 | 息 | いき | Breath |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You smell someone's icky (いき) breath. It's gross. Your skin crawls and your eyes roll back in your head from the icky, icky smell. You might die.
1269 | 商売 | しょうばい | Business | Commerce\n Trade | Selling merchandise is business, commerce, or trade. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've learned them both already!
1270 | 心配事 | しんぱいごと | Cares | Worries\n Troubles | Remember how 心配 means "a worry" and 事 can mean "thing"? Well, if you have a worry over some specific thing, then you probably have some cares and worries. What are your 心配事 these days? \n The reading is the reading of 心配 (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and 事 using the (こと) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the ごと (just another 心配事, amiright?).
1271 | 虫歯 | むしば | Cavity | Decayed Tooth\n Tooth Decay | A tooth bug... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a cavity. \n The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that は turns to ば, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.
1272 | 第二章 | だいにしょう | Chapter Two | Second Chapter | The ordinal number prefix two chapter has a much simpler way of describing it, which is chapter two. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1273 | 陽気 | ようき | Cheerful | Jovial\n Merry\n Lively\n Spring Season\n Warm Weather | If you have a spirit of sunshine you're a really cheerful person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1274 | 童話 | どうわ | Children's Story | Fairy Tale | Don't think of this as a juvenile talk. Think of 話 the vocab word, which means "story." If you do that, you get a "juvenile story." What's a juvenile story? It's a children's story. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1275 | 音読み | おんよみ | Chinese Reading | On'yomi | The sound reading. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the Chinese reading, aka the on'yomi. Sounds familiar? \n The reading for 音 is the 音読み. 読み uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.
1276 | 都市 | とし | City | Municipality | A metropolis city is a city. When you're referring to just a plain ol' city, sans name, you can use this word. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1277 | 部室 | ぶしつ | Clubroom |  | A club room is a clubroom! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1278 | 寒い | さむい | Cold |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cold? It's cold.\n寒い is used specifically for when you feel cold. You can say it when you're outside on a chilly winter day, for example, or when you walk into a cold room. It can even be used as a response to unfunny jokes that leave you cold. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (Samurai (さむ)). Remember?
1279 | 会社員 | かいしゃいん | Company Employee | Office Worker | A "company" (会社) member is someone who works at a company. This is a company employee. There are many of these in Japan. Most of them are drunk. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1280 | 落ち | おち | Conclusion | Final Result\n The End\n Punch Line\n Slip\n Omission\n Outcome | When you're talking or writing a paper, the part that falls at the end is the conclusion. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1281 | 大根 | だいこん | Daikon | Japanese Radish | This will be easier if you've seen or heard of daikon before. It's a really big root in the ground that's pretty delicious. It's known as daikon in the grocery stores for the most part, though occasionally you'll see it as Japanese radish instead. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 大 uses the だい reading because if you try to put the whole thing in your mouth at once you'll probably end up choking and dying.
1282 | 深い | ふかい | Deep |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of deep? It's also deep. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Because the reading sounds just like a dirty word, and there may be innocent children about, I'll let you come up with your own mnemonic for this one. Maybe someone pushes you into a deep hole that will surely kill you so you yell something out as you fall down it?
1283 | 最深 | さいしん | Deepest | The Deepest | The most deep is the deepest.\n最深 is a formal word used in geology to describe the deepest point of things like caves and oceans. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1284 | 歯医者 | はいしゃ | Dentist |  | You know that a 医者 is a doctor. So what is a tooth doctor? A dentist. Seriously, don't forget to floss. 歯医者 hate when you forget to floss. \n You know how to read 歯 and 医者, so you should be good to go!
1285 | 消化 | しょうか | Digestion |  | What is something that will first extinguish something and then change it? One thing I can think of is your body. It takes in food, extinguishes it in your stomach, then changes it into things your body can use (and then excrete). That's why this "extinguish-change" process is your digestion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1286 | 二倍 | にばい | Double | Two Times\n Twice\n Twofold | Something that is two times is double (or it is just simply two times). Of course, this all works with things like 三倍, 百倍, and 四十二倍 as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1287 | 運転手 | うんてんしゅ | Driver |  | You know that 運転 has to do with driving, right? And you know that 手 often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A driver. \n The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of 手 by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.
1288 | 社員 | しゃいん | Employee | Staff\n Company Employee\n Company Staff | The company members are the employees and the staff. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1289 | 民族 | みんぞく | Ethnic Group | Ethnicity\n Race | A peoples tribe (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single ethnic group. What's your 民族? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1290 | 運動 | うんどう | Exercise | Sport | When you carry your movements (or carry something along with your movements, like weights, for example) you are doing exercise. Speaking of which, perhaps you've been studying kanji a little too much lately. Time to get up and do some squats. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1291 | 期待 | きたい | Expectation | Anticipation | For a period of time you have to wait. During this waiting period, you’re building up an expectation or anticipation for something to happen a certain way. Waiting, expecting, waiting, expecting…\n期待 specifically refers to the feeling of expectation or anticipation for a desired outcome. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1292 | 落ち葉 | おちば | Fallen Leaves | Fallen Leaf | The leaf that falls are fallen leaves. \n The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of 落ちる and use that for the first half. Then, 葉 is rendaku'd to ば. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).
1293 | 家庭 | かてい | Family | Household\n Home | The essence of your house and garden is your family, household, or home. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1294 | 家族 | かぞく | Family | Immediate Family | Your house tribe is your family. They live in the same house as you and they're part of your "tribe." This is closer than family, though (depending on how you look at family). This is your immediate family because these are the people you live with and give birth to, etc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1295 | 父親 | ちちおや | Father | Dad | Your father parent is your father. \n The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is 父 (ちち) and 親 (おや).
1296 | 疲労 | ひろう | Fatigue | Weariness | You're tired from labor. From this, you're showing fatigue and weariness.\n疲労 is a little formal, so you might encounter it more often in writing than in conversation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1297 | 祭 | まつり | Festival |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n While at a festival, a guy named Matt has to go to the bathroom. Matt’s urine (まつり) has been filling up his bladder ever since he began drinking that 64oz cup of soda. Matt’s urine is ready to bust out at any moment. He really has to go to the bathroom.\nThis word can also be written 祭り, and the pronunciation stays the same.
1298 | 祭日 | さいじつ | Festival Day | National Holiday | A festival day is obviously a festival day. This word technically refers to days for Shinto festivals or rituals, but sometimes people also use it to mean a general national holiday. This is because some of the Japanese national holidays are based on those traditional Shinto festival days! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1299 | 一階 | いっかい | First Floor | Floor One\n Ground Floor\n First Story | The one floor is the first floor (or floor one). In Japan, that means the ground floor. Pretty simple. \n The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo kanji. Be careful of the 一 though. It gets shortened and has a little っ in there.
1300 | 第一位 | だいいちい | First Place | First Rank | You have the ordinal number prefix and 一位 (first place). By adding the prefix 第, you can make it a little more formal, but it still means first place. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1301 | 一流 | いちりゅう | First Rate | First Class\n Top Notch\n Top Grade | This is a weird one. You have one stream. This is first rate stream material we have here, though. If you think about it, if you only have one stream (instead of a ton of streams), you can put all your effort and energy into it. When you do that, you're making sure it is a first rate stream in terms of quality and anything else. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1302 | 〜階 | かい | Floor | Story\n Storey | You know that the kanji refers to a floor (as in the "fifth floor"). This word represents the version that comes after a number, shown with a 〜. Essentially, this has the same meaning as the kanji you learned, making it nice and easy.\nNote that floor-counting systems can vary across different countries. In Japan the ground floor is generally called 一階, with the floors above being 二階, 三階, and so on. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Don't type in the 〜 or you'll get it wrong!
1303 | 四十二階 | よんじゅうにかい | Forty Second Floor | Floor Forty Two\n Forty Second Story | You know that 四十二 means "forty two." So, as long as you know floor you'll know this means forty-second floor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1304 | 庭 | にわ | Garden | Yard | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add the meaning yard to your memory bank as well, if you'd like. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your garden. It doesn't meet your expectations so you decide it's time to get a newer (にわ) garden. Tear it all down, folks! Getting a newer garden, here!
1305 | 集まり | あつまり | Gathering | Meeting\n Assembly\n Party\n Collection\n Get Together | This is the noun version of the kanji gather, so it means gathering. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1306 | 大学院生 | だいがくいんせい | Graduate Student | Grad Student | Remember how you learned that 大学院 means "graduate school" and 大学生 means "college student?" Well smush them together and you have a  graduate student! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1307 | 港 | みなと | Harbor | Port | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This is a single kanji with no okurigana, so it's using the kun'yomi reading. You don't know this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou go down to the harbor and speak the secret password me natto (みなと) to buy some fresh natto. Imagine the salty air hitting your face as you whisper, "me natto." Now eat that yummy natto by the water! Mmmm!
1308 | 彼 | かれ | He |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1309 | 聞こえる | きこえる | Hearable | Audible\n To Be Able To Hear\n To Be Heard\n To Be Audible\n Can Hear | You've seen 聞く by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means hearable (or to be audible). Just think about that こえ hanging off there as the voice you can hear. \n The reading comes from 聞く, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.
1310 | 広島 | ひろしま | Hiroshima |  | The wide island... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is Hiroshima (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.
1311 | 温泉 | おんせん | Hot Springs | Onsen | A warm spring (like the water kind of spring) is a hot spring. These are really nice. You should go to them in Japan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1312 | 湯 | ゆ | Hot Water |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1313 | 暑い | あつい | Hot Weather | Hot | This is the adjective form of hot... but we're going to call it hot weather. Why? Because there's a difference between something that's hot and the weather or atmosphere being hot. This is that kind of hot, as in..."Damn, man, it's hot out here!" \n This uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji, so you're good to go here!
1314 | 僕 | ぼく | I | Me | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well! \n This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.  I certainly like that and I bet you do too.
1315 | 利息 | りそく | Interest |  | You receive profit at every breath. What kind of profit is this? It's interest. As time goes by and as you take more breaths you gain more bank interest. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1316 | 島 | しま | Island |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1317 | 顔文字 | かおもじ | Kaomoji |  | Remember how you learned that 文字 can mean "characters?" Well make a face out of those characters and you've made a kaomoji! ʅ(◔౪◔ ) ʃ \n This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 顔 added to the jukugo word 文字 that you already learned. You've learned these readings before, so reading this word should be nice and easy!
1318 | 京都 | きょうと | Kyoto | Kyouto | The capital metropolis back in the day was Kyoto. Now of course the capital is Tokyo, but kanji doesn't know this. That's why Kyoto is the capital metropolis! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1319 | 終電 | しゅうでん | Last Train | The Last Train | We've seen a few times where 電 refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the end train for this word would refer to the last train. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1320 | 一代 | いちだい | Lifetime | One Lifetime\n Generation\n One Generation | This word has the kanji for one and period. You only have one period to live in so this is the only lifetime you get. Unless you're reborn, but that will probably be in the next age, not this one. So one lifetime for you! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1321 | 運 | うん | Luck |  | This takes the luck meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of luck because of it. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... luck-filled?
1322 | 本流 | ほんりゅう | Mainstream |  | The origin stream, that's where everything comes from. That is the mainstream. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1323 | 会員 | かいいん | Member | Membership | If you meet enough members you will become a member yourself! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1324 | 商人 | しょうにん | Merchant | Trader\n Shopkeeper\n Tradesperson | A merchandise person is a merchant. You want to buy something or you just looking? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1325 | 深夜 | しんや | Middle Of The Night | Late At Night | The deep night is the middle of the night. It doesn't get any deeper than that before you start coming out of the night to start the next day. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1326 | 母親 | ははおや | Mother | Mom | The mother parent is the mother. \n The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of 母 and 親. If you do, you should be able to read this too.
1327 | 登山 | とざん | Mountain Climbing |  | Climb a mountain. That is mountain climbing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative と reading, not to be confused with とう (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your toe off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short と because your toe is now short. And さん becomes ざん thanks to our old friend rendaku.
1328 | 都合 | つごう | One's Convenience | Circumstances | This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you join together with someone at a metropolis, you do it at your convenience. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.\nThis word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!" \n The reading for 都 is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going to go (つごう) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience.\nThe 合 (ごう) part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel ごう.
1329 | 根気 | こんき | Patience | Perseverance\n Persistence | The root of your energy. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough patience to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1330 | 期間 | きかん | Period | Term\n Interval | A period of time interval is still a period or interval of time. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1331 | 植物 | しょくぶつ | Plant | Vegetation | Plant things are plants or vegetation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
1332 | 屋根 | やね | Roof |  | The root of your roof is still your roof. If it helps, imagine roots growing out of your roof. They protect you from the rain. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings. The kun'yomi for 根 is ね. For a mnemonic, we'll use the sound a horse makes, neigh (ね). Why is the horse neigh-ing? It's stuck on the roof.
1333 | 根 | ね | Root |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nThis is a magic root that turns you into a horse. You take a bite and let out a loud neigh (ね)!
1334 | 根本 | こんぽん | Root | Source\n Origin\n Foundation | The root origin is the root of something. Possibly even more root than root, but we'll stick with root. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful, 本 is ぽん, which is a weird rendaku.
1335 | 船員 | せんいん | Sailor | Seaman\n Mariner\n Crewman | A member of a boat is called a sailor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1336 | 学期 | がっき | School Term | Semester | The study period of time isn't the pitiful amount of time you spend studying. It's something much bigger: the school term. Ugh, how much longer is this study period of time??? \n The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but がく gets shortened to がっ, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened がく like that?
1337 | 二階 | にかい | Second Floor | Floor Two\n Second Story | The two floor is the second floor. In Japan, that means the floor above the ground floor. Going up! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1338 | 店員 | てんいん | Shop Staff | Store Staff\n Store Employee\n Shop Employee\n Clerk\n Shop Assistant | The shop member is someone who is a "member" (aka employed by) the shop. This is the shop staff. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1339 | 短い | みじかい | Short |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of short? It's short.\nThis word is used to describe things that are short in length, not in height. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho has short hair and always wears shorts? It's Ms. Carr (みじか)! Everyone always recognizes Ms. Carr because she's the one with the short hair and shorts, no matter the weather. Ms. Carr, the ultimate short style icon!
1340 | 短期 | たんき | Short Period | Short-Term | The short period of time is the short term. You know not to think short term anyways, right? You're learning kanji, after all. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1341 | 短刀 | たんとう | Short Sword | Dagger\n Tanto | The short sword is the short sword. What's another word for a short sword? It's a dagger. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1342 | 誰か | だれか | Someone |  | 誰 is who, 誰か is like asking "who?" If you don't know who it is, you just know it's someone. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
1343 | 息子 | むすこ | Son |  | The breath child (that lets you release your breath when it's born) is a son. Nowadays it's cool to have a girl, but back in the day you wanted a son to carry on your underwater basket weaving legacy. That's why this is a son. \n The reading of this is messed up. 子 is こ, that should be okay. 息 is むす for some reason though. Why? Because you gave birth to a son, but he was a moose (むす). You better hold that breath again, because this is not what you wanted.
1344 | 球 | たま | Sphere | Ball\n Sports Ball | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n球 has a slightly technical sound and highlights the sphere shape of the object you're talking about. It's most commonly used to refer to sports balls (as a more formal alternative to ボール). \n This word is made up of a single kanji, so it should use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou see a sphere in Tamara's (たま) hand. You're not totally sure what it is, but it's really spherical. Maybe it's some kind of sports ball. Remember Tamara, the local ball girl? It would totally make sense for Tamara to be holding either a sphere or a sports ball, since that's kind of all she does.\nYou might notice 球 has the same reading as the vocab word 玉. Their meanings are kind of similar too, so this reading should be a bit easier to remember!
1345 | 泉 | いずみ | Spring | Fountain | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural spring in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "izumeeeee (いずみ), Mario!"
1346 | 着々 | ちゃくちゃく | Steadily |  | Something you wear, and wear again, is something you steadily wear. You do it so often, it's reliable. Also, if you wear something this much it's steadily wearing away too. \n This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.
1347 | 湯気 | ゆげ | Steam | Vapor | Hot water's energy isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the steam and vapor. \n The ゆ part of the reading makes sense. The げ part for 気 is a bit of an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help with that:\nNo creature likes steam and vapor more than geckos (げ). Geckos live in hot places, so wherever you see steam, you'll be sure to see at least one gecko nearby, if you look hard enough.
1348 | 勉強 | べんきょう | Studies | Study | Your exertion is strong. You'd think this means you're working hard or something, but it means studies (like studies you have for a test or something). So for this, just imagine yourself exerting yourself really strongly on your homework. These are your studies / what you study. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1349 | 太陽 | たいよう | Sun | The Sun\n Sol | The fat sunshine thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the sun. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1350 | 水泳 | すいえい | Swimming | Swim | When you're doing a water swim, you're really just… well, swimming.\nNote that 水泳 will usually refer to swimming as a sport or organized activity. When talking about swimming as a general action, 泳ぎ and 泳ぐ are more commonly used. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned this reading for 水, but not for 泳, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe only way you can swim is by chasing after acorns (えい). If somebody isn't dangling an acorn on a stick right in front of your face, you'd never get the motivation to swim. Good thing you're this into acorns.
1351 | 茶の湯 | ちゃのゆ | Tea Ceremony |  | The hot water of tea. That is part of the ceremony that goes into the tea ceremony. \n The readings are both the readings you learned with the kanji. Now you can spend a little more time drinking tea at a tea ceremony and a little less time trying to remember kanji readings.
1352 | 気温 | きおん | Temperature | Air Temperature | The energy of the warmth will cause the temperature to go up and down. Energy goes up? Higher temperature because of more movement and activity. Energy goes down? Well, temperature gets colder and slower. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1353 | 温度 | おんど | Temperature |  | The warm degrees is how many degrees warm it is in here. Of course, there can be very few warm degrees as well, making it very cold. What is all this? It's the temperature. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1354 | 地球 | ちきゅう | The Earth | The Globe\n Earth | The earth sphere! It's where we live and the planet we call home. It's the earth! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1355 | 終わり | おわり | The End | End\n The Finish\n Finish | By now you should know that 終わる means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be the end or the finish. \n The reading comes from 終わる. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!
1356 | 第一 | だいいち | The First | First\n Number One\n Best | The ordinal number prefix one refers to the first thing. This is the number one place you can get. In fact, it's simply the best. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1357 | 最悪 | さいあく | The Worst | Worst | The most bad is the worst. At least it can’t get any worse… \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1358 | 彼ら | かれら | They |  | This is he but plural. The "ra" makes it plural, making it "they" or "them." While this gennnnnnerally refers to a group of males, it can include ladies too. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1359 | 三番目 | さんばんめ | Third Thing | The Third | Remember 一番目? This is just like that, but with three, making it the third thing or simply the third. \n Use your knowledge of the reading for 一番目 to remember the reading for this word as well.
1360 | 時期 | じき | Time | Season\n Period | The time period of time is a period of time of time. If anything, just notice how many times the word "time" is used and you'll remember this word means time. The meaning is a specific type of time, though. This is talking about a season or period of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be 時間 or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
