1361 | 〜倍 | ばい | Times | Fold | Throw this onto a number and you have yourself the number of times something has increased. For example, ３倍 means something increased "three fold." \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Omit the 〜 when writing out the answer, though. That just represents that there should be something before the kanji in this word when being used.
1362 | 始まる | はじまる | To Begin | Something Begins\n To Start\n Something Starts | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something starts. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to start. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 始める.
1363 | 伝わる | つたわる | To Be Transmitted | To Be Told\n To Be Handed Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something is transmitted. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to be transmitted. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 伝える.
1364 | 登る | のぼる | To Climb | To Ascend | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means climb so the verb vocab version would be to climb (or to ascend), if that's the kind of thing you're into. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as 上る which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!
1365 | 取れる | とれる | To Come Off | To Be Removed\n To Fall Off | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means to come off or to be removed. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 取る.
1366 | 集まる | あつまる | To Come Together | To Gather\n To Be Gathered | I bet you remember 集める which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's to come together. You can remember this because a herd of Marus (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there. \n The reading is the same as 集める so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.
1367 | 要求する | ようきゅうする | To Demand Something |  | You hopefully remember that 要求 means "demand" . When you make that a verb, it becomes to demand something. \n The reading is just the vocab word 要求. It's also the regular on'yomi jukugo reading.
1368 | 落とす | おとす | To Drop Something | To Let Something Fall\n To Lose Something | You've seen how 落ちる means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of toss (とす) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean to drop something. \n The reading comes from 落ちる. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.
1369 | 消す | けす | To Extinguish Something | To Erase Something\n To Turn Something Off | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extinguish so the verb vocab version is to extinguish something. You can also use this word to say to erase something, like data, and to turn something off, like the lights or the power. Technically you're extinguishing the data, as well as the lights or power, right? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to extinguish the fire! The kettle (け) got too hot, and it caught on fire.
1370 | 転ぶ | ころぶ | To Fall Over | To Fall Down | Do you remember the word 転がる? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means to fall over or to fall down. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a ぶ sound. \n The reading comes from 転がる. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.
1371 | 終える | おえる | To Finish Something | To End Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means finish, so the verb version is to finish something or to end something.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning you finish something, like a long day at work!\nYou need to differentiate this from 終わる, which is when something just ends on its own. 終える is about when you make something end. Remember it like this: Canadians always end their sentences with "eh" え, right? Well that's how you know they're ending their sentence. Just listen for the "eh," eh? \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou finally finished your school project. "Oh, A!" (おえ) you say to yourself, as though you can grade your own project.
1372 | 流す | ながす | To Flush Something | To Pour Something\n To Set Something Afloat | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream. If you're streaming water, it might be to flush something. Alternatively, to pour something makes a stream of liquid, and to set something afloat is to make something flow in the stream. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat do you do with someone who is a nagger (one who nags)? You have to flush them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.
1373 | 苦しめる | くるしめる | To Hurt Someone | To Torment\n To Harass | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means suffer, and the verb is all about when you make someone else suffer. That's why it's to hurt someone, to torment, or to harass.\nYou need to differentiate this from 苦しむ, which is about when YOU suffer. You can remember that 苦しめる is about making someone else suffer with this mnemonic: Who made you suffer? She made (しめ) me suffer! She's so mean! \n By now, you've learned 苦しい and 苦しむ. The kanji in these words all use the same reading! Yay!
1374 | 東京都 | とうきょうと | Tokyo Metropolis | Tokyo Metro\n Tokyo Metropolitan Area\n Tokyo Metro Area | The Tokyo Metropolis is, of course, the Tokyo Metropolis. Technically this is one of Japan's prefectures, but it's called a "Metropolis" instead. It's the capital and the largest city in all of Japan! \n The reading is just 東京 and 都 (と). Really it's all just the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so you can think of it that way as well.
1375 | 動く | うごく | To Move | To Function | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means move so the verb vocab version is to move. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is telling you to move. They are saying "you go (うご) over there. Move! Move!" If it helps, have them pronounce "You go" more like "Ugo."
1376 | 起こる | おこる | To Occur | To Happen\n To Take Place | You know that 起きる means "to wake up", but did you learn its secondary meaning, "to occur"? Well, this word means only to occur. Just imagine an incident occurring involving a uranium core (こる) to remember that this means to occur. After all, uranium core incidents don't wake up, do they? \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as 起きる too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.
1377 | 開く | あく | To Open | To Be Open | You should know 開ける by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also to open. \n Do you remember the reading for 開ける, which you learned in level 10? That's right, it's あける! So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.\nJust a quick side note — 開く can also be read as ひらく, but we're going to focus on the あく reading here. Since ひらく has slightly different meanings, we won't accept it as a reading for this word, so be sure to enter あく!
1378 | 歯 | は | Tooth | Teeth | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading that you learned with the kanji is the same as this one. HA! Take that, kanji.
1379 | 植える | うえる | To Plant Something | To Grow Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plant, so the verb version is to plant something or to grow something. \n You haven't learned this reading for 植 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou decided to plant an uni (う) tree in your backyard. That's right, you can plant sea urchins and they'll grow like fruit off a really spiky tree. Just picture it. And then you'll get to eat all the uni you want!
1380 | 映す | うつす | To Project | To Reflect | You know that 映る is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is to project. \n The reading is the same as 映る. So long as you know the reading of 映る you should be able to read this one too.
1381 | 鳴る | なる | To Ring |  | This is a lot like 鳴く, which means "to chirp" (or some other animal noise). This has to do with noises too, but not so much animal and more like bells (including telephones). This word means to ring. If it helps, think of the る as a hint, kind of like the first sound of the word "ring" (る). So, る = "ring" and it's a verb, so to ring. \n The reading can come from 鳴く. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.
1382 | 歌う | うたう | To Sing |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. One of the kanji's meanings is sing so the verb vocab version of this is to sing. \n Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words 歌. Just throw the う onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO ♬!"
1383 | 合う | あう | To Suit | To Come Together\n To Meet\n To Match | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suit so the verb version is to suit.\nThis word also means to come together as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well). \n You want to find a pet to suit your personal style, so you get matched with an aardvark (あ). An aardvark will match the ant mounds you use for chairs and couches, it's the perfect match.
1384 | 待つ | まつ | To Wait |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so the verb version is to wait. \n You need to wait for your mama (ま) all the time. You want to go out? You have to wait for mama to drive you. Want to eat dinner? You have to wait for mama to make you food. Hmm. Maybe all this waiting is really a you problem.
1385 | 着る | きる | To Wear | To Put On | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wear so this word means to wear or to put on. You'll need to differentiate it from 着く which means (to arrive), though. Just think of how the る is the rude guy trying to get you to wear things you don't like wearing. \n What do you want to wear today? How about a dress made entirely of keys (き)? Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on. Maybe just stick with wearing a single key around your neck next time.
1386 | 心配する | しんぱいする | To Worry | To Be Concerned\n To Be Anxious | You know that 心配 is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be to worry. \n The reading comes straight from 心配 so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.
1387 | 流行 | りゅうこう | Trend | Fad\n Craze\n Prevalence | Where the stream is going is where everyone's going. That's what tends to be the trend of things. Imagine a trend going on in your society right now. Imagine it going down a stream with everyone following it. This word is also used for less desirable trends, like the prevalence of infectious diseases. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1388 | 旅 | たび | Trip | Travel | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You are going on your trip but you need to bring your little tabby (たび) cat with you to keep you company. This cat keeps you calm and lets you leave your house, but the airlines won't let you take it on this trip. What to do?
1389 | 旅行 | りょこう | Trip | Travel | When you go on a trip you're taking a trip. This is travel. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice 旅行 to Japan? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1390 | 都会 | とかい | Urban Area | City | When metropolises meet they become an urban area. This word is often used to mean city as opposed to the country or rural areas. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1391 | 温かい | あたたかい | Warm |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTouch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "AH ta-ta! (あたた). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.\nPeople often pronounce this as あったかい, especially in casual, spoken Japanese. The "correct" reading is still あたたかい though, so keep that in mind when you're trying to type the kanji or taking an important test!
1392 | 水深 | すいしん | Water Depth | Depth Of Water | The water deepness is the water depth. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1393 | 話し方 | はなしかた | Way Of Speaking | Speaking Style\n Way Of Talking\n Talking Style | The way of speaking is your way of speaking (or it could be your speaking style). This is how someone talks. Some people have an interesting speaking style, after all. \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 話す and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
1394 | 言葉 | ことば | Word | Language\n Manner Of Speech | A leaf of the things you say is like a leaf from a tree of speaking. That leaf is a part of the whole language, it is a single word, though it can add up to be a language or manner of speech. \n The reading for 言 is one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nNow imagine that there are words all over your coat (こと). It's completely covered in words. Which language are these words in? Why Japanese, of course! Think about which Japanese words you would want written on your coat.
1395 | 文章 | ぶんしょう | Writing | Sentence\n Composition | A writing chapter is just another name for a piece of writing, a.k.a. a composition. Even if it's only a single sentence! 文章 covers just about every type of writing there is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1396 | 感心 | かんしん | Admiration |  | Your feelings are in your heart. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel admiration for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1397 | 入館料 | にゅうかんりょう | Admission Fee | Entrance Fee\n Entry Fee | The fee for entering a public building is the admission fee. Gotta pay it if you want to get inside. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1398 | 養子 | ようし | Adopted Child |  | A foster child you bring into your family is your adopted child. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1399 | マンション | マンション | Apartment Building | Apartment | マンション comes from the English word "mansion," but it just means an ordinary apartment building in Japanese. Depending on context, it can also mean an individual apartment. Either way, it’s definitely not a big, luxurious house in Japanese!
1400 | 整理 | せいり | Arrangement | Sorting\n Organization\n Adjustment | When you arrange something according to reason, the result is an arrangement. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1401 | 〜放題 | ほうだい | As Much As You Want | All You Can | Just release the topic... let it go free! Let it do whatever it wants. Sometimes the topic will be food... if that's the case, just release yourself and do whatever you want with the food (eat it all!). If it's drinks, drink it all! This word has to do with doing whatever you want and as much as you want. You'll see this attached to "all you can ____" words, so look out for them in the next  couple levels. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1402 | 暗殺 | あんさつ | Assassination |  | A dark kill is an assassination. It's done by someone who is in a ninja outfit and dark, hiding in the shadows for his moment to strike. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1403 | 想定 | そうてい | Assumption | Expectation | When you imagine something that's somewhat determined, that means you already have some sort of assumption or expectation about it.\n想定 usually refers to assumptions made in advance about certain conditions or situations. It’s often used when talking about preparing for or anticipating future events, especially ones where planning might be required, like natural disasters. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1404 | 初めに | はじめに | At First | In The Beginning | You know 初 means first, and に can mark a point in time. So 初めに means at first or in the beginning.\n初めに has a lot of overlap with 始めに. But while 始めに is for the beginning of some larger process, 初めに refers more to doing something first or to the initial point of a certain time frame. You might say 初めにアクビをしたのは私です (I was the one who yawned first), for example, or 今年の初めに (at the start of this year). \n This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).
1405 | 銀行 | ぎんこう | Bank |  | Time to go get your silver from the bank. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1406 | 彼氏 | かれし | Boyfriend |  | A he mister is not just he, it's "mister he," and mister he is your he, your boyfriend. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
1407 | 橋 | はし | Bridge |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! No need to burn any 橋s with this word and its kanji.
1408 | 缶ビール | かんびーる | Can Beer | Canned Beer | A can of beer (ビール) is a can beer or canned beer. Not a bottled one. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
1409 | 賞金 | しょうきん | Cash Prize | Prize Money | A prize of gold is so old fashioned. We use cash now, which is why this word means cash prize. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1410 | 事情 | じじょう | Circumstances | Reason\n Situation | Occurrences and feelings make up your circumstances.\n事情 is used to describe the reasons or situation behind a particular event or action. If you can't go to a party, for example, you might explain your 事情 by saying that something came up or you aren't feeling well. And if your coworker is expecting a baby, you might consider her 事情 and help reduce her workload. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1411 | 器 | うつわ | Container | Bowl\n Capacity | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n器 refers to a container or a bowl and is often used in culinary contexts. It can also be used metaphorically to describe someone's capacity for certain things. For instance, when someone has a small 器, it means they have a limited capacity to handle pressure, stress, or difficulties. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:\nYou have this container. It's upside down with a stick holding it up and a string on the stick. You're going to catch some U2s (like, the band). You put some food under it and wait. Then, out of the bushes comes Bono. He sniffs around for a bit and then goes under the container. You pull! U2 walked (うつわ) right into the trap! Haha!
1412 | 大会 | たいかい | Convention | Tournament\n Event | When you have a big meet there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a convention or some kind of tournament or event. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nDid you know that Japan has entire conventions on tie kayaking (たいかい)? They regularly hold tournaments where they go kayaking using nothing but ties! Sounds pretty exhausting...
1413 | 暗い | くらい | Dark |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dark? It's dark. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: \nYou're thrown into something dark and small. A lid is closed on top of you, and you are confused. What have you been thrown in? You find out you've been thrown in a cooler (くら). Feel afraid like you would be if you were thrown in such a dark cooler like this. Is it cold?
1414 | 器用 | きよう | Dextrous | Skillful | Your task is to open this pickle container. Why you? Because you are so dextrous and skillful when it comes to opening pickles. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1415 | 疑問 | ぎもん | Doubt | Question | A doubt problem is caused by having too much doubt. Just think about it. Don't doubt yourself, it's why you're getting those vocab words wrong! :P \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1416 | ワンピース | ワンピース | Dress |  | ワンピース comes from the English word one-piece, but it generally refers to a casual dress in Japanese.
1417 | 酒好き | さけずき | Drinker | Alcoholic | When you like alcohol a lot, you're probably a heavy drinker. \n The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (酒 and 好き) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of すき to ずき.
1418 | 飲み会 | のみかい | Drinking Party |  | You know that 飲む is drink, so this has to do with drinking. Also, 会 means meet, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a drinking party! \n The readings come from the 飲む vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for 会. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!
1419 | 空き缶 | あきかん | Empty Can |  | A sky can is a can that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty can. \n The reading for 空き isn't one you've seen before. Remember how 開く means "to open"? Well, this can is also open, because nothing is filling it. The readings are the same between the two, as well. 開く and 空く, though in this case it becomes the stem form: 空き.
1420 | 熱心 | ねっしん | Enthusiasm | Passion\n Zeal | When your heart is feverish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of enthusiasm about. Think about the things you've enthusiasm for. Then, imagine your heart beating and getting all hot from thinking about it. Why else would people get so upset when talking about religion and politics. It's their feverish heart! Their enthusiasm! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the ねっ portion (normally is ねつ).
1421 | 全然 | ぜんぜん | Entirely | Completely\n Not At All | It's all nature out there. It's entirely nature and not at all city.\nThis word is weird. It means two opposite things. Thanks Japanese! Just look out for a negative word after the 全然. If it is negative it's "not at all" if it's not negative it might be "entirely." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1422 | 皆さん | みなさん | Everyone | Everybody\n All | Everyone + さん (normal name ender). This is the normal way to say everyone \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1423 | 予想 | よそう | Expectation | Prediction | If you consider the future beforehand and imagine how things will turn out (based on some facts), you will have an informed expectation or prediction for it.\n予想 refers to an expectation or prediction about the future based on current information or trends, like predicting which candidate will win an upcoming election or estimating future economic conditions. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1424 | 表情 | ひょうじょう | Facial Expression |  | When you express a feeling it shows on your face. This is called a facial expression. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1425 | 料金 | りょうきん | Fee | Charge\n Rate\n Price | The fee gold (or money) you have to pay is a fee or a charge.\nYou've learned 代金, which generally refers to the money paid for physical goods, but 料金 refers to a fee or charge for using a service — think bus fares, highway tolls, entrance fees, monthly service charges, that kind of thing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1426 | 感じ | かんじ | Feeling | Sense\n Impression | This is a noun version of the kanji feeling. What is that? It's a feeling as well. \n The reading for both on'yomi and kun'yomi of this kanji are the same, actually. So long as you learned the reading that was with the kanji, you can't go wrong. Feel good?
1427 | 感情 | かんじょう | Feeling | Emotion | Feeling + feeling = feeling! It can also mean emotion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1428 | 熱 | ねつ | Fever | Heat | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so don't get all feverish over this one.
1429 | 指先 | ゆびさき | Fingertip | Tip Of The Toe | You know that previous part of your finger? The part I just chopped off? Well that was your fingertip! I only had time to get the tip. It used to be on your finger and now it's right here, in my hand. Sorry, I guess. Oh, but don't worry, I'll even things out and get the tip of your toe real quick too. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
1430 | 〜様 | さま | Formal Name Ender | Formal Name Title\n Sama | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nYou can add this onto the end of someone's name. It's probably too polite, to be honest, unless you're talking to one of your customers or something. It's good to know, but you're probably not going to use it much, despite seeing and hearing it fairly often. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
1431 | 初めて | はじめて | For The First Time | First Time | You know that 初 means "first" This word means for the first time. Think of めて as "meet." Then think "when we met for the first time ____ happened." \n This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).
1432 | 仲良く | なかよく | Friendly | Good Terms | When the relationship is good, that means you're friendly with that person. You're also on good terms. \n The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned already, so hopefully we can stay on good terms, right?
1433 | 駅前 | えきまえ | Front Of Station | In Front Of Station\n Front Of The Station\n In Front Of The Station\n Station Front | The station front is the front of station. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way. \n This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for 駅 in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word 前 by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself front of station.
1434 | 会 | かい | Gathering | Meeting\n Group\n Party | This is the noun version of the kanji meet, and it means a gathering or a meeting, as you’d expect! It isn’t really used for the kind of meeting you have at an office, though. It’s more in the sense of a people coming together for a specific purpose, like volunteer group, or a birthday party. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1435 | 目標 | もくひょう | Goal | Target\n Objective | The signpost you have your eye on is your goal, target and objective. Just imagine looking at this signpost in the distance. You know you have to get to it from where you are. That is the goal of your journey. \n You've had the on'yomi reading of 目 with 目次 way back in level 6. For this vocab, you're trying to get to your goal, that signpost in the distance. As you're trekking towards it there are people standing to the side mocking you, telling you you'll never make it to your goal. Imagine this happening.
1436 | 神様 | かみさま | God | Gods | God (formal name ender) is God! Or the gods, if you're talking to more than one. You have to be polite to them, so you add that ender on there. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too!
1437 | 女神 | めがみ | Goddess | Female Deity | A woman who is also a god is a goddess. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 女 yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThis goddess has the most beautiful 目 (め) you've ever seen. You can't stop staring into them. This must be how people know they've met a god.
1438 | 仲良し | なかよし | Good Friend | Intimate Friend\n Close Friend | You have a good relationship with someone. This is someone who is your good friend or intimate friend. \n The readings are kun'yomi as you probably guessed from the hiragana sticking out, but that doesn't matter because you learned the kun'yomi readings already.
1439 | 緑色 | みどりいろ | Green | Color Green\n Green Color | The green color is the color green. \n The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji, combined!
1440 | 緑 | みどり | Green |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1441 | 宿題 | しゅくだい | Homework |  | The lodge you're staying in has a topic around it. Think of it as a theme. This theme is doing your homework. So yeah, you just went to a nice lodge for vacation only to have to do homework everywhere. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1442 | 熱い | あつい | Hot Thing | Hot | This is for when a thing is hot, making this word hot thing. When the weather is hot that's 暑い. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as 暑い, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji 暑 at least. That uses the reading あつ. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.
1443 | 人情 | にんじょう | Human Feelings | Humanity\n Empathy\n Kindness\n Sympathy | The person (people) feelings are human feelings that every person has. That is what humanity is all about, and often refers to feelings of kindness and empathy for others. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1444 | 億 | おく | Hundred Million |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, presumably because it's normally attached onto other numbers to signify how many hundred millions of ____ there are.
1445 | 俺 | おれ | I | Me | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nKeep in mind that 俺 has a more informal and masculine sound than neutral options like 私 and 僕. While it carries a rougher vibe, it's not solely reserved for tough personalities and is very common in casual chats among buddies. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1446 | 思想 | しそう | Ideology | Thought\n Idea | When you think and contemplate deeply, you're producing something larger, like an ideology. This means having a group of, or a single larger, thought(s) or idea(s).\n思想 refers to the big ideas or beliefs an individual holds about the world and life. It’s often used to talk about one’s thoughts about philosophy, politics, religion, or other such beliefs. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 思 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAll your thoughts and ideas are about sheep (し) right now. You just can't stop thinking about sheep. Are you thinking about sheep right now? What kind of sheep are they?
1447 | 感想 | かんそう | Impressions | One's Impressions\n Thoughts | The feelings you contemplate about a subject are your impressions and thoughts on it.\n感想 is all about what you think or feel after experiencing something, like after reading a book, watching a movie, or going to an event. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1448 | 旅館 | りょかん | Japanese Inn | Japanese Style Hotel\n Ryokan | When you’re taking a trip to a public building, you might be staying at a Japanese inn. Those were very much public buildings for all kinds of travellers back in the day, when you think about it.\nAlternatively, you could call this a Japanese style hotel, or just by its Japanese name, ryokan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1449 | 神風 | かみかぜ | Kamikaze | Divine Winds | Wind of the gods. These are divine winds. More popularly, this is a word known as kamikaze, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky. \n The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of 風 from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word 神 to be able to read the rest.
1450 | 王様 | おうさま | King |  | The king (formal name ender) is the king, and you're talking to him politely. He's the king after all! If you don't he might behead you! \n This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 王 and the kun'yomi reading for 様. You've learned them both so you should be able to read this word too!
1451 | 左利き | ひだりきき | Left Handed |  | If you profit from the left, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably left handed. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words 左 and 利く together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.
1452 | 小指 | こゆび | Little Finger | Pinky Finger\n Pinky\n Little Toe\n Pinky Toe | The small finger is your little finger or pinky finger. Makes sense, but it's also used for the pinky on your feet. You know, your pinky toe. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!
1453 | 宿 | やど | Lodging | Inn\n Hotel\n Lodge | A lodge is a form of lodging. It is also considered to be an inn or hotel. \n Yah do (やど) what you must to get lodgings for the night. Whether that's an inn or hotel or whatever. Yah do what you gotta do.
1454 | 暗記 | あんき | Memorization | Memorize | In the dark if you try to write down something it won't work very well. You can't see. So, how can you "write something down" in the dark? You write it down in your mind. This is memorization! Recognize this word? The SRS application "Anki" comes from this word, I'm guessing! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1455 | 水銀 | すいぎん | Mercury | Quicksilver | This is a fun one. Water silver is mercury, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's mercury! Or quicksilver, if you prefer. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Stick that up the next time someone makes you mad. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know them both already, so now you know this too!

1459 | 殺人 | さつじん | Murder |  | When a person is killed, you have yourself a murder. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1460 | 楽器 | がっき | Musical Instrument |  | Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 and meant "music"? Well this is that 楽 again. A music container is something that can produce music. It is a musical instrument. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.\nYou have already learned the reading for 器 but 楽 uses the secondary reading so you may not have learned it.  However, you learned this reading in the word 音楽. Just bear in mind that the がく shortens to がっ.
1461 | 当然 | とうぜん | Natural | Obvious | Something that's naturally right is something that's very obvious and natural. You know that, right? 当然! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1462 | 自然 | しぜん | Nature | Natural | Self nature is nature itself. That is nature, like all those green things and 青葉 outside. Many apologies if someone hundreds of years from now is reading this. It used to be pretty green outside before the robots.\nIf you call this "natural" then you are using the な adjective 自然な, but I thought it pertinent to add that in here too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! Except 自 is し and not じ! That is because when you add the little dakuten you are adding to the し. When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that nature intended.
1463 | 一億 | いちおく | One Hundred Million |  | One hundred million is one hundred million. That's a lot of zeros. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

1465 | 情熱 | じょうねつ | Passion | Enthusiasm | If you're feeling the fever, you're getting so into something that your body is heating up. You have a ton of  passion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1466 | 体育 | たいいく | PE Class | PE\n Physical Education\n Gym Class | Remember how 教育 means "education?" Well, the 育 here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a body education. What do you call the body education at school? Physical education or PE. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1467 | 情け | なさけ | Pity | Sympathy\n Mercy\n Compassion | You have your feelings... these are the feelings humans have. When you ask someone to have feelings (Have feelings, KAY?? (け at the end)), you are asking them to pity or have mercy on you. Please! Have those human feelings that people have, like sympathy or pity. Don't kill me, man! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you begging to have pity on you? It's NASA. They have you hanging outside of the space station and they're going to push you towards earth where you'll burn up in the atmosphere. You don't want that, so you beg mission control for some pity. What will they do? You decide.
1468 | 詩 | し | Poem |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji as well! You are so happy that you could write a poem all about this...\nThe vocab reading\nIs the same as the kanji\nCrabigator love\nHow was that?
1469 | 詩人 | しじん | Poet |  | A poem person is a poet. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1470 | 詩歌 | しいか | Poetry |  | A poem song is poetry. It's not quite a song but I think you can make the connection.\n詩歌 used to be for two kinds of poetry called kanshi and waka, but nowadays it's also used for other traditional Japanese poetry forms like tanka, haiku, senryu, and more. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know these readings, but there's usually an extra い in the middle. Don't worry, しか is totally fine too, but しいか is more common. You got this!
1471 | 練習 | れんしゅう | Practice | Training\n Drill | You practice something to learn it. That's still called practice! The important part about this is that you're learning while you practice too. It's right in the word. So, when you practice kanji and Japanese vocab, make sure you're learning as well as practicing. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1472 | 選手 | せんしゅ | Pro Athlete | Sports Player\n Professional Athlete | Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? Well this is one of them. In sports, you must choose the best doer for your team. In the world of sports, these "chosen doers" are the  pro athletes and  sports player s. \n The reading for 選 is what you'd expect. 手 is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen 手 using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.
1473 | 問題 | もんだい | Problem | Question | The problem topic is the problem or question you have to answer. If you think about it, topics as problems tends to be a school-related thing. So, when you have to answer a problem in school, that's 問題. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1474 | 実感 | じっかん | Realization | Real Feeling\n Actual Feeling | Your truth feeling is when you feel something is true. You have the realization this is a real feeling! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading for 実 gets changed to じっ so be careful!
1475 | 大好き | だいすき | Really Like | Love\n Like A Lot\n Lovable | You've hopefully seen 好き by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a 大 (big) like? You really like, like a lot, or love something.\nThis is the same as 好き in that a more literal translation would be lovable, but it's generally translated as a verb in English. \n The reading comes from 好き which you've hopefully seen. Then, 大 is the reading you learned with the kanji.
1476 | 回想 | かいそう | Reminiscence | Recollection | The past events revolve around your mind as you imagine them. That's a reminiscence or recollection of those times.\n回想 refers to the reminiscence or recollection of past experiences or events. It's often used to describe flashback scenes in movies or dramas, as well as moments in literature where characters think back on their past. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1477 | 右利き | みぎきき | Right Handed |  | The right side of your body is the side you profit most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're right handed. \n Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words 右 and 利く to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.
1478 | 輪 | わ | Ring | Wheel\n Loop\n Circle | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the ring you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special Walken(わ) ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.
1479 | 学問 | がくもん | Schooling | Study\n Learning\n Scholarship | How can you solve your study problem? With a little extra schooling, study, and learning. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1480 | 課長 | かちょう | Section Manager | Section Chief | Remember how 社長 is the company president? This uses the same 長 meaning (where it means something like "boss"). Since 課 means section, this is the section manager. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1481 | 彼女 | かのじょ | She | Girlfriend | A he woman is she. Also could mean girlfriend, depending on how it's used. \n The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the 彼 portion. Just think about how she (your girlfriend) is a canoe (かの), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.
1482 | 新宿 | しんじゅく | Shinjuku |  | The new lodge area is Shinjuku, a popular district in Tokyo. Perhaps there are many places to stay in Shinjuku. Either way, you should visit, it's fun! It will help if you've heard of Shinjuku before, too. Do some research about Shinjuku if you've never heard of it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be careful of the しゅく changing to じゅく. Once again, will help if you've heard of Shinjuku.
