1672 | 紀元後 | きげんご | Common Era | CE\n Anno Domini\n AD | What does the narrative origin have coming after it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is the Common Era, aka AD, or anno Domini.\nJust in case you don't know what narrative we're talking about: it's the narrative of Jesus's birth, which is the year that we say the Common Era started. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1673 | 自信 | じしん | Confidence | Self Confidence | When you believe in your self you have plenty of confidence (or self confidence). This is a good thing to have! \n How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1674 | 勇気 | ゆうき | Courage | Bravery\n Valour\n Valor | That feeling of courage is courage. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1675 | トランプ | トランプ | Deck Of Cards | Playing Cards\n Cards | トランプ comes from the English word "trump", as in "a trump card", but it means deck of cards or playing cards in Japanese.\nThe Japanese meaning probably comes from card games played by English-speaking Westerners back in the day. Japanese people heard the word "trump" a lot, and assumed it meant a deck of cards.
1676 | 地区 | ちく | District | Area\n Zone | The earth district isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a district, area, or zone. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1677 | 区 | く | District | Ward | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
1678 | 不信 | ふしん | Distrust | Mistrust\n Discredit\n Unfaithfulness | When you can't (not) believe in someone, it's because you distrust them. Maybe someone discredited them and now you mistrust everything they say. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1679 | 英会話 | えいかいわ | English Conversation |  | English meeting and talking with each other. This is English Conversation. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1680 | 英和 | えいわ | English Japanese |  | This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an English and Japanese (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is English Japanese. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1681 | 英語 | えいご | English Language | English | The English language is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the English language. It is English. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1682 | 英文 | えいぶん | English Writing | English Composition | England writing is English Writing (or if you want to be fancy, English Composition). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1683 | 毎晩 | まいばん | Every Night | Nightly | Every night is simply every night. What do you do every night? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1684 | 信心 | しんじん | Faith | Belief | What you believe in your heart, and not in your head, is your faith. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all faith. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.
1685 | 美術 | びじゅつ | Fine Art | Art | When you create beauty with your techniques, that’s fine art, or simply art. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1686 | 食中毒 | しょくちゅうどく | Food Poisoning |  | If you eat and find yourself in the middle of poison, you've probably got food poisoning. No fun when you get this :( \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1687 | 四匹 | よんひき | Four Small Animals |  | Four small animals is four small animals. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1688 | 福島 | ふくしま | Fukushima |  | The luck island wasn't actually too lucky. This is Fukushima where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think. \n The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.
1689 | 大仏 | だいぶつ | Giant Buddha Statue | Daibutsu\n Great Buddha | A large Buddha doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the Great Buddha or Giant Buddha Statue. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1690 | 今晩は | こんばんは | Good Evening |  | This word is made of now and night with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying good evening.\nJust keep in mind that writing 今晩は is pretty old school. These days it's almost always written as こんばんは. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.
1691 | 文法 | ぶんぽう | Grammar |  | The method of writing is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be grammar. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.
1692 | 丈 | たけ | Height | Length | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing height and length. \n The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!
1693 | 乗馬 | じょうば | Horseback Riding | Horse Riding | If you ride a horse, that's horseback riding or, in some parts of the world, simply horse riding. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nKnow who loves horseback riding? That's right, Joe (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.
1694 | 夫 | おっと | Husband |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (おっと) shop.
1695 | 不法 | ふほう | Illegal | Unlawful | A not law is something that's against the law. It's illegal or unlawful. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1696 | 事変 | じへん | Incident |  | An occurrence that causes change somehow can also be called an incident.\n事変 is a formal word for big, unexpected incidents that are disruptive and chaotic. This can involve natural disasters, sudden riots, or other large-scale disturbances that need military intervention. It can also refer to unannounced warfare.\nYou'll most likely see this word used in names for historical events, like the Manshuu Jihen (満州事変), or the Manchurian Incident. The 変 kanji suggests "change," so you know 事変 is only used for historical incidents big enough make things change! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1697 | 伝 | つて | Intermediary | Connections\n Contacts\n Go Between | When you get someone to transmit information, they're a type of intermediary, a go-between, if you will. \n When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nWhen the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.\nLittle side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!
1698 | 子猫 | こねこ | Kitten | Kitty | A child cat is an adorable kitten. D'awww! \n The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).
1699 | 昨年 | さくねん | Last Year |  | Yesterday's year was actually last year. Today must be New Years then! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1700 | 列 | れつ | Line | Queue\n Row | When things are put in a row they end up forming a line. This can be a line of people or a line of random stuff. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1701 | 昼休み | ひるやすみ | Lunch Break | Noon Break | Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at noon it's your lunch break! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a noon break instead. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!
1702 | 飯 | めし | Meal | Cooked Rice\n Food | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to cooked rice, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.\nThis word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.
1703 | ご飯 | ごはん | Meal | Cooked Rice | The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?
1704 | 方法 | ほうほう | Method | Way | The way method or the method way is the method or way. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you... \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1705 | 情けない | なさけない | Miserable | Pathetic\n Shameful\n Deplorable\n Wretched\n Sad\n Pitiable | You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning pitiable and miserable. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1706 | 人殺し | ひとごろし | Murder | Murderer | When you kill a person that's murder. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.
1707 | 殺人者 | さつじんしゃ | Murderer | Killer | You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, someone who does murder is what? A murderer. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1708 | 海軍 | かいぐん | Navy |  | The sea army are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The navy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1709 | 晩 | ばん | Night | Evening | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!
1710 | 昼 | ひる | Noon | Lunch | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can also mean lunch, especially when used with the honorific prefix お, as in お昼. \n The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!
1711 | オノマトペ | オノマトペ | Onomatopoeia | Mimetic Word | オノマトペ comes from the French word “onomatopée” which, as you can probably guess, means onomatopoeia.\nオノマトペ has a wider meaning than its English equivalent, and it also covers mimetic words, which are words that evoke ideas and actions rather than sounds.
1712 | 由来 | ゆらい | Origin | Source\n Coming From | What's the reason that something comes into being? Its origin, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a source, because it's always coming from somewhere. \n You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe best way to get close to the origin or source of something is to move into a yurt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.
1713 | 相手 | あいて | Partner | Companion\n Opponent | Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your mutual doer might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your partner, companion, or even an opponent in certain situations. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way:\nYour partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."
1714 | 乗客 | じょうきゃく | Passenger |  | If you take a ride as a guest (or a customer), that makes you a passenger. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:\nYou notice a passenger getting on at your stop. Who is it? The distinct smell of barn animals and manure gives it away immediately: it’s Joe (じょう), the farmhand!
1715 | 計画 | けいかく | Plan | Planning\n Project | You need measurements and images to make a plan. You can't follow a plan without measurements and images to refer to, right? Any good plan has measurements and drawings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.
1716 | 毒 | どく | Poison |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.
1717 | 毒ガス | どくがす | Poison Gas |  | Poison Gas is a nasty thing. It is poison gas. \n The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."
1718 | 中毒 | ちゅうどく | Poisoning | Addiction | You're in the middle of poison, meaning you have poisoning. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1719 | 有毒 | ゆうどく | Poisonous | Toxic\n Venomous | When something has poison it is poisonous and toxic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1720 | 比例 | ひれい | Being Proportional | Proportion | You compare examples, trying to figure out in which way they're being proportional. You know these examples you're comparing are in proportion to one another, you just need to figure out how.\nUse 比例 when talking about how one thing changes in proportion to another. Like the price of a good in proportion to its supply and demand, for instance. Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some examples! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1721 | 返信 | へんしん | Reply | Answer | You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1722 | 指輪 | ゆびわ | Ring |  | A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context. \n The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ゆびわ.
1723 | 輪ゴム | わごむ | Rubber Band | Elastic Band | A ring of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band. \n The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word わゴム.
1724 | 大変 | たいへん | Serious | Terrible\n Very\n Difficult\n Hard\n Hectic | A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event.\nAlso, in more recent history this has come to mean very as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1725 | 浅い | あさい | Shallow |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this あさい
1726 | 単に | たんに | Simply | Merely\n Only | If you're moving towards (に) simple, you're saying simply, merely, or only. \n If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1727 | 技能 | ぎのう | Skill | Ability | Your skill and ability are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your skill and ability. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1728 | 坂 | さか | Slope | Hill | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.
1729 | 〜匹 | ひき | Small Animal Counter | Counter For Small Animals | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
1730 | 軍人 | ぐんじん | Soldier | Military Personnel | An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1731 | 頑丈 | がんじょう | Solid | Firm\n Stout\n Sturdy | A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1732 | 初耳 | はつみみ | Something Heard For The First Time | News | The first time something reaches your ear, it's something heard for the first time. If it's never entered your ear before, it's news to you! \n This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because 初 behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read 耳, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for 初 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nWhatever it is, this something heard for the first time, be sure to hold onto your hats (はつ)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be news to me, too.
1733 | 特技 | とくぎ | Specialty |  | Your special skill is your specialty. So, what is your 特技? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1734 | 春 | はる | Spring |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.
1735 | 春休み | はるやすみ | Spring Break | Spring Vacation\n Spring Holiday | You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation. \n The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.
1736 | 変 | へん | Strange | Weird | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！ \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.
1737 | 丈夫 | じょうぶ | Sturdy | Firm\n Healthy | With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
1738 | 同期中 | どうきちゅう | Syncing | Synchronizing | You're making things in two different places be exactly the same for a period of time. You're in the middle of a process called syncing. You can see 同期中 a lot in computery contexts, or if you change your device language to Japanese. (Not that I recommend that...) \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1739 | 美味しい | おいしい | Tasty | Delicious | Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty or delicious. Mmmm, yum!\nWhile 美味しい mostly describes tasty food, you may also occasionally see it being used for a sweet deal or situation that benefits you. \n The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"
1740 | 技 | わざ | Technique | Art\n Skill | What is a skill? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a technique that you can make happen with ease. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your technique on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He was (わざ) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's Woz, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!
1741 | 寺 | てら | Temple |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local お寺.
1742 | 昨今 | さっこん | These Days | Nowadays\n Recently | Previous from now are the times around now. They're these days, nowadays, or recently. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that さく changes to さっ as many K-column sounds do in situations like this.
1743 | 受け入れる | うけいれる | To Accept Something | To Take In | Remember 受ける (to receive something) and 入れる (to put in)? This just combines those two. You receive something, and put it into your heart. You accept it. So this verb means to accept something or to take in.\nYou can use this verb for all kinds of acceptance, such as accepting an apology, accepting exchange students to your school, etc. \n You should know how to read both 受ける and 入れる, so you should be good to go!
1744 | 整える | ととのえる | To Arrange | To Put In Order | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means arrange, and the verb version also means to arrange or to put in order. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEverything in your room has finally been put in order. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "Toto no (ととの)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  to arrange  it all over again. Dammit Toto.
1745 | 好む | このむ | To Be Fond Of | To Like | You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be to be fond of or to like. \n The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this:\nWhat’s something easy to be fond of? 子? No (この), not for you. You’re always saying “子? No!” Most people are fond of kids, at least their own, but not you. Noisy, germy, needy 子? No, no thank you!
1746 | 信じる | しんじる | To Believe | To Trust In | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means believe so the verb vocab version is to believe. \n The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.
1747 | 変える | かえる | To Change Something | To Change | The kanji is change, and this verb is to change something. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going to change it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.\n変える and 代える sound the same and are sometimes used in similar contexts, but are different in nuance. 変える refers to the act of making something different, and involves altering the nature or state of something. For example, changing the layout of a room or changing one's perspective on an issue. 代える means to substitute or exchange one thing for another that is expected to fulfill the same role, use or purpose, such as replacing a worker with a substitute. \n This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out.\nI don't like this car. I would like to change it for another car (か).
1748 | 晴れる | はれる | To Clear Up | To Become Sunny | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means clear up, so the verb vocab version is to clear up. It also means to become sunny as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. One of those words where the kun'yomi's going to be more useful.
1749 | 泣く | なく | To Cry |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cry so the verb vocab version is to cry. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember the kanji reading you'll have no problem with this word.
1750 | 外す | はずす | To Disconnect Something | To Miss Something\n To Exclude Something\n To Remove Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji 外 means outside, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means to disconnect something. Think of it like this, if you disconnect a plug from a socket, you are taking the plug "outside" of the socket, right? Depending on the context, this verb can also mean to miss something (like the target during archery practice), to remove something, or to exclude something.\nThis is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You disconnect something, like a plug, or remove something, like your dog's leash. It's worth mentioning that most verbs ending in す are transitive, so you'll start seeing this pattern as you learn more! \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you're going to disconnect something, it has (はず) to be the right thing! Don't go disconnecting the wrong plug, you'll cause no end of trouble!
1751 | 疑う | うたがう | To Doubt | To Suspect\n To Be Suspicious Of | The kanji means doubt, so this is just that as a verb. So this means to doubt, to suspect, or to be suspicious of. \n There's reason to doubt that you can teach an uni Tagalog (うたが), but once you try, it's actually not that hard. They're very good listeners after all.
1752 | 放つ | はなつ | To Fire | To Hit\n To Emit\n To Set Free\n To Break Wind | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned the verbs 放す and 放れる but this one is a little different. This is a specific kind of releasing. It means to fire an arrow, to hit a baseball, or to emit light. It even works when you're releasing a fart. Yes, it means to break wind too. What a great word! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1753 | 下りる | おりる | To Go Down | To Descend\n To Be Issued | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means below, which is a clue to the direction this movement verb takes: this is to go down or to descend. In some cases, this can also mean to be issued, mostly in situations where some sort of grant or allowance is issued by an authority.\nYou might notice that this is similar to 下る (くだる), and you can use either to describe going down a mountain. The difference is that 下る implies a gradual sloping motion, like floating down a stream, whereas you'd say 下りる if you’re jumping out of trees! \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're stuck on a huge mountain, and the only way to go down is by using your obi (お). So you'll have to descend this entire mountain with nothing but your obi, acting as a rope. Good luck!
1754 | 暗記する | あんきする | To Memorize |  | Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have to memorize. \n The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.
1755 | 払う | はらう | To Pay | To Brush Off | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pay so the verb vocab version is to pay.\nThis word also means to brush off, like when you brush dirt or dust off of something. \n The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.
1756 | 練習する | れんしゅうする | To Practice |  | You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have to practice. \n The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!
1757 | 帰る | かえる | To Return Home | To Return\n To Go Home | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return home so the verb vocab version is to return home, to return, or to go home. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word!\nThis word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the る ending. Just imagine how rude (る) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!
1758 | 見返す | みかえす | To Show Someone What One Can Do | To Show Someone\n To Look Back Over Something\n To Return Someone’s Stare | When you see someone doubting you and return something successful instead, that is to show someone what one can do or more simply to show someone. In other words, you show someone who doubted you or treated you unfairly what you’re really capable of.\nThere are a couple of other meanings, too. It can mean to look back over something, like the answers to your kanji test you want to double check, and sometimes to return someone’s stare. You can see how all of these meanings relate to the kanji, right? \n The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.
1759 | 合計 | ごうけい | Total | Sum | When you join all your measurements together you have yourself a total. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1760 | 信号 | しんごう | Traffic Light | Signal\n Traffic Signal\n Stoplight\n Semaphore | If you believe in the numbers, there will be no traffic because the traffic light will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1761 | 信用 | しんよう | Trust | Confidence | Your task is to believe. In order to do that, you have to have plenty of trust in what you believe in... not to mention confidence. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1762 | 変事 | へんじ | Unexpected Incident | Unusual Incident | You know 変 means "change," but it can also mean "strange." So a strange occurrence is an incident that is unlikely. In other words, an unexpected incident or an unusual incident.\n変事 is a formal word used to describe sudden and unusual occurrences that disrupt normal conditions, such as natural disasters, emergencies, or crises. You won't see this word often, but may still come across it in formal writing.\nWith 変事, think of how the 変 comes first to emphasize the strangeness of the incident. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1763 | 変死 | へんし | Unnatural Death | Accidental Death | A strange death is one that doesn't seem right. It's an unnatural death, and probably an accidental death (ie wasn't caused by natural causes). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1764 | 様々 | さまざま | Various |  | This one's kinda tricky. You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean "manner," as in the manner you do something in. So if you've got multiple manners, you've got lots of various ways of doing things! \n The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ざま however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read さま in this word!
1765 | 時計 | とけい | Watch | Clock | A thing that gives you time measurements is a watch or clock. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now. \n The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your watch is a walky talky (とけい) and run with that?
1766 | 単語 | たんご | Word | Vocabulary | The simple bits of language are the individual words. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is word.\nSo what’s the difference between this and 言葉? Well, 言葉 can cover any meaningful set of words – anything from words, sentences and paragraphs, to whole texts and even languages. 単語, on the other hand, is a subset of 言葉 that specifically refers to single, distinct words. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1767 | 作家 | さっか | Writer | Author\n Creator | This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You make a house. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means writer. Think of it this way: A writer makes (writes and creates works) in their home. Writers don't make their word magic in a corporate office!\n作家 is generally used to refer to someone who writes professionally as an occupation, especially in the field of literature. It can also be used more broadly to refer to a creator who produces individual works of art or craft. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the さく reading of 作 becomes さっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:\nWriters love soccer (さっか). In fact, playing soccer is how they get their inspiration. Try playing some soccer, maybe you'll become a creator too!
1768 | 昨日 | きのう | Yesterday |  | The yesterday day is yesterday. What a blast from the past! \n Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played keno (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?
1769 | 留守 | るす | Absence | Away From Home | You have gotten a mission. You must go out and detain a dangerous criminal to protect your country. While you go do that, you will be away from home and have an absence from society. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1770 | 料理人 | りょうりにん | A Cook | Cook\n Chef | You've seen 料理 and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a person who does cooking? That is a cook or chef. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1771 | 入門 | にゅうもん | Admission | Entrance\n Introduction\n Apprenticeship | If you are able to enter the gate then you have gained admission and entrance to the facility.  Sometimes you do this to start an apprenticeship, where you get an introduction to some sweet new skills, like how to make an entrance. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1772 | 冒険 | ぼうけん | Adventure |  | You dare to do something risky. It's adventure time! Imagine yourself daring yourself to do risky things. Is this an adventure? If not, make it so! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1773 | 記念日 | きねんび | Anniversary | Memorial Day | You should write down all your thoughts on this day, because it's not just any day — it's an anniversary!\nWondering how 記念日 differs from 周年? 周年 is usually for a numbered anniversary, like 十周年 (10th anniversary), whereas 記念日 refers to the specific date on which a memorable event took place in the past. \n The reading is a combination of on'yomi for the first two and kun'yomi for the last one. That being said, all of the readings for all of the kanji are the readings you've learned already, so you should be able to read this word too. Just watch out because ひ is rendaku'd into び.
1774 | 品 | しな | Article | Item\n Goods | This is the same as the kanji, at least in regards to the article or goods meaning, which means you can use this word to mean article or goods. \n When this kanji is used as a single-character vocabulary word, it is usually read as しな. You'll see it read as ひん more often in kanji combination words. That said, there is an expression, 品がない, which means "unrefined" or "lacking taste," and the kanji is read ひん in this case. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the しな reading:\nThink of it like a video game. The first time you see new goods there's a sheen (しな) about it. But when you bring it back to your place, the sheen is gone. Then when you go back to the store, wow! All the goods you don't already own have that sheen! Gotta buy them!
1775 | 芸術家 | げいじゅつか | Artist |  | You know that 芸術 is art so you'd think that 芸術家 would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the artist. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1776 | 自動的 | じどうてき | Automatic |  | An automatical (自動 + 的) thing of course isn't "automatical." A better way to say it is to cut off the -al and call it automatic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the reading of 自動 as well.
1777 | 自動車 | じどうしゃ | Automobile | Car | You know that 自動 is automatic. So what is an automatic car? That is an automobile, or simply a car. \n The reading comes from 自動 and the kanji 車's readings, combined.
1778 | 作品 | さくひん | A Work | Work\n Production | If you make a product, it's not really a product anymore, but a work. It's your work of art or literature, or maybe a theater production.\nThis can be any kind of artistic creation: a book, a composition, a painting, a movie, a play... It doesn't mean "product" (you'll learn the word for that later!) but it can be used for a product when you want to highlight the artistic talent behind it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1779 | 弁当 | べんとう | Bento | Box Lunch | You know how 弁 means dialect and 当 means success? Well, this isn't going to help you much, because this means bento or box lunch. Chances are, though, you know the word "bento" from English. So, if you read this word (which you should be able to) you can figure out it's べんとう. If you do that, you can realize this word means bento too! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1780 | 箱 | はこ | Box |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1781 | 新品 | しんぴん | Brand New | New Item\n New Product | A new product is something that's brand new or a new item. I like looking around the store for the brand new stuff because it's interesting! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice though that ひん changes to ぴん. This is because you're buying some brand new pins?
1782 | 仏典 | ぶってん | Buddhist Scriptures | Buddhist Writing | Buddha transcribed all of the rules of Buddhism in the Buddhist Scriptures and Buddhist Writings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ぶつ gets shortened to ぶっ.
1783 | 天井 | てんじょう | Ceiling |  | The heaven well is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a ceiling. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 井, so we've got a mnemonic to help you out with that. Just note that the on'yomi for 井 isn't actually じょう, but rather しょう, it just ends up getting rendaku'd here!\nFixing up ceilings is a tricky task, but you've got just the man for it: Joe (じょう). Your local farmhand that does it all, nothing is too tricky or out of reach for him, you're starting to think that this man can do just about anything. What a handy person to have around.
1784 | 字典 | じてん | Character Dictionary | Kanji Dictionary | Letter rules can be found in a character dictionary. In Japanese, one kanji "letter" or "character" can hold a lot of information, so you have dictionaries dedicated to kanji meanings. That's what this is.\nThis word is a little old-fashioned these days, so you might also see 漢字辞典 used for a character dictionary. (You'll learn 辞典 soon, if you haven't already!) \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1785 | 古典的 | こてんてき | Classical |  | When something is "old rules-like," it is not very modern. It is in the past. It is classical. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1786 | 全治 | ぜんち | Complete Recovery | Completely Healed\n Fully Recover | All cured! That means you've made a complete recovery! You're completely healed! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1787 | 関心 | かんしん | Concern | Interest | The things related to your heart are the things that concern and interest you the most. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1788 | 関係 | かんけい | Connection | Relation | A connection related to another connection obviously has some kind of connection, at least between all those meanings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1789 | 保守的 | ほしゅてき | Conservative |  | Who are all like "I want to preserve and protect what I have, get out of my business, government!"? Conservative people, of course. \n The reading doesn't match up for this word's 守. The reading is しゅ, but you can remember that because the conservatives want to protect and preserve their hoes (ほ) and their chutes (しゅ) from the government. For some reason those get taxed a lot.
1790 | 取材 | しゅざい | Covering An Event | Data Collection\n Interview | Your job is to take materials from a bunch of different people because you're covering an event. This data collection needs to be thorough, so you try to take all the materials you can from as many people as you can find. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi of 取 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're covering an event featuring all kinds of chutes (しゅ). They have the whole range, from laundry chutes and garbage chutes, to evacuation chutes and so much more. You'll be doing some data collection and interviews about all these chutes, and you can't wait!
1791 | 下品 | げひん | Crude | Vulgar\n Vulgarity | Things that are below normal products are the cheap knockoffs and bad quality items. These items are incredibly crude and vulgar in their manufacturing and design. So much vulgarity! \n You haven't seen this reading for 下 yet (sorry there's so many for this kanji!) so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThose items are so crude that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be. Honestly they all just look like statues of lumpy geckos (げ). That says it's a lamp but it looks more like a gecko looking at the sky. That chair? Definitely a bunch of geckos having a pool party. Are you sure you didn't get this stuff from a weird gecko artist?
1792 | 危ない | あぶない | Dangerous | Risky | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dangerous? It's dangerous. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is in danger! It's poor old abe (あぶ) Lincoln. You try to save him, yelling out 危ないよ！！！！, but he gets shot in the back of the head anyways.
1793 | 曜日 | ようび | Day Of The Week | Weekday | The weekday day is the day of the week, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn 曜日 to get you prepared. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for 曜 and the kun'yomi reading for 日. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because ひ of 日 changes to び here.
1794 | 悪化 | あっか | Deterioration | Getting Worse | A bad change is exactly what it sounds like: deterioration, aka getting worse . \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The on'yomi readings of the kanji are あく and か, but here they become あっか, to make the word easier to pronounce. Try and say it out loud to see if you agree.
1795 | 〜弁 | べん | Dialect |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The 〜 is there to show this attaches onto things, like 東京弁, meaning "Tokyo Dialect." \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Because it's normally attached to other words it uses the on'yomi reading like a jukugo word normally would.
1796 | 辞書 | じしょ | Dictionary |  | Take all the words you use in writing, put them together and you have a dictionary! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1797 | 辞典 | じてん | Dictionary | Lexicon | You need to know the word rules of the language you're learning, don't you? Then you need a good dictionary that can explain its lexicon! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1798 | 事典 | じてん | Encyclopedia | Dictionary | If you come across a matter in which the rules aren’t clear, you’ll need to have a look in an encyclopedia! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1799 | 証 | あかし | Evidence | Proof | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: \nYour relentless search for evidence has finally uncovered the existence of a car sheep (あかし)! It's a bizarre hybrid, having a car's body but a sheep's head and legs. "Ah, car sheep! I've finally found the evidence proving you're real!"
1800 | 遠足 | えんそく | Excursion | Outing\n Trip | Far feet are feet that have gone on long excursions. These feet have been on some trips, man. They've seen some things. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1801 | 生存 | せいぞん | Existence | Life\n Survival | Existing life is in existence on this planet... What would that say about life and survival in such an unforgiving place? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1802 | 急行 | きゅうこう | Express |  | Things that hurry and go faster than the other things are express. This is often used with trains or subways, so look out for it if you're looking to get somewhere in a hurry. Also be careful in case it doesn't stop at your stop, because 急行 trains don't stop at every station (which is what makes them express!). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1803 | 外面 | がいめん | External Appearance | Outward Appearance\n Surface | The outside face to something is the external appearance of that thing.\nWhile 外面 can refer to the outer surface of an object, it’s more commonly used to describe someone's outward appearance, behavior, or demeanor on the surface. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, so this is がいめん. But note that this can also use the kun’yomi readings, which makes it そとづら.\nWhile がいめん is neutral, そとづら is a bit negative, often implying that the person's outward appearance might be deceptive, hiding their true nature.
1804 | 顔面 | がんめん | Face Of A Person | Person's Face\n Face | The face of a face is a face, but more specifically the face of a person. Probably because the most face-like thing you can ever have is a human's face... at least in our eyes (by "our" I mean the human race's eyes, because I am totally with you guys on that one). \n The reading for 顔 isn't the one you learned with the kanji. But, we're going to learn that reading right now.\nThe worst thing that can happen to a face is if a face disappears. If it becomes totally gone (がん). A man that is walking up to you with no face, is a man with a gone face. Those men are men who are a part of the gone men (がんめん). Faces, totally gone!
1805 | 不合格 | ふごうかく | Fail A Test | Failure\n Rejection | You know that 合格する is "to pass a test," so what's the opposite of that? Fail a test or failure. \n If you know the reading for 合格, all you have to do is add 不 to it! You've learned all these readings, yay!
1806 | 遠い | とおい | Far | Far Away | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of far? It's also far (or it's far away). \n You want to go far, far away when you see a toe... oh (とお)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)
1807 | お世辞 | おせじ | Flattery | Compliment | When you quit your current generation to join an older one, you'll need to use all kinds of flattery. Older people love being flattered; so be nice and give them some compliments. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Just watch out, as the 世 gets shortened from せい to せ! You can memorize this by remembering to be short and sweet with your flattery, don't make it too long and overcomplicated!
1808 | ふわふわ | ふわふわ | Fluffy | Floating Lightly\n Light-Headed | Who are who are (ふわふわ) fluffy? I’m thinking puppies, but ask yourself, "who are the fluffiest creatures I know?"\nThis is an オノマトペ meaning fluffy, like a puppy, a cloud, or a cotton ball. It can also describe the movement of a dandelion puffball or a jellyfish, floating lightly in the air or the water. And if you’re feeling lightheaded, that’s called ふわふわ too. Basically, anything with light or fluffy vibe!
1809 | 折り目 | おりめ | Fold | Crease | A fold you can see with your eye is a fold or crease in something. \n The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings. You should have seen 折る by now which should help you to read 折り. Then there's 目, which I'm guessing you won't have a problem with.
1810 | 前面 | ぜんめん | Front | Front Side\n Fore\n Forefront | The front face of something is the front or the front side of it (kind of like how 外面 is the exterior because it's the outside face). This also means fore or forefront, especially when used metaphorically. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1811 | 基本的 | きほんてき | Fundamental | Basic\n Standard | The things that are basics (基本) like (的) are basic and fundamental. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing how to read the word 基本 will be helpful too.
1812 | ゴミ箱 | ごみばこ | Garbage Can | Garbage Bin\n Trash Can\n Trash Bin\n Waste Can\n Waste Bin\n Rubbish Bin\n Bin | ゴミ means "garbage." Add a box to it and you have a garbage box aka a garbage can or garbage bin. \n The reading is just the kun'yomi reading, the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku though. はこ changes to ばこ.
1813 | 門 | もん | Gate |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1814 | 幸運 | こううん | Good Luck | Fortune | When you carry happiness with you, you look at the good side of everything and end up having really good luck. Someone who carries happiness will be really lucky in life. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1815 | 政府 | せいふ | Government |  | Politics and government. They are needed to keep the government rolling. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1816 | 卒業式 | そつぎょうしき | Graduation Ceremony | Graduation | You know that 卒業 is graduation so what about when you add ceremony to it? That makes it a graduation ceremony. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 卒業 already as a word, too.
1817 | 食料品 | しょくりょうひん | Groceries | Foodstuff | Products you're paying a fee to eat later are your groceries. Buy them now, eat them later, yum! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1818 | 地面 | じめん | Ground | Earth's Surface | The ground/earth face is the surface that makes up the ground or the Earth's surface. \n The reading for 面 is what you'd expect. 地 on the other hand is じ, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of Jesus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.
1819 | 保証 | ほしょう | Guarantee | Assurance\n Warranty | Giving evidence (or a guarantee) that you will preserve something, is giving a guarantee, assurance, or warranty.\nThis word is used when the emphasis is on taking responsibility for something, as in a guarantor, a product warranty, or quality assurance. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1820 | 阪神 | はんしん | Hanshin |  | The slopes of the gods! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as Hanshin. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: 大阪 + 神戸 = 阪神! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1821 | 幸福 | こうふく | Happiness |  | With a little happiness and luck you can achieve happiness, though that goes without saying.\n幸福 is often used to discuss happiness in a broader, more abstract sense, like the happiness of a population or the concept of happiness in philosophical contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1822 | 幸せ | しあわせ | Happiness |  | This is the noun version of the kanji 幸. The kanji means happiness and the vocab word means happiness.\nCompared to 幸福, 幸せ is more commonly used in everyday language and refers to a more immediate, personal sense of happiness or contentment. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nOn your quest for true happiness, you meet a happiness guru. She always says (しあわせ), "just be happy!" She always says that, and you always listen. You can't believe how simple yet profound her approach is!
1823 | 不完全 | ふかんぜん | Incomplete | Imperfect | You know that 完全 means "complete" or "perfect." So, a not "complete" or "perfect" is something that is incomplete or imperfect. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also will help if you can read 完全.
1824 | 不治 | ふじ | Incurability | Incurable | When you can not cure something, this is a problem of incurability. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1825 | 保険 | ほけん | Insurance |  | When you are able to guarantee against risk, it's probably because you bought some good insurance! What do you use? The gecko 保険? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1826 | 面白い | おもしろい | Interesting | Amusing\n Funny | The face of this object is so white! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so interesting... \n The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the 面 part (白い is just like the vocab word 白い). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "Oh mo!" (おも) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.
1827 | 冗談 | じょうだん | Joke |  | When you have a superfluous talk you aren't being serious, you're telling a joke. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1828 | 関西 | かんさい | Kansai |  | The Kansai region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually connects the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai." \n Urgh, what a confusing reading! The 西 is さい instead of せい. Readings like this just make you want to sigh (さい), no?
1829 | 図書館 | としょかん | Library |  | A public building where written things are all diagramed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a library to me! \n The 書館 part should be readable by you, but it's the 図 that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human toe (と). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to show Khan (your buddy) your smashed toe.
1830 | 特急 | とっきゅう | Limited Express Train | Limited Express | Something that's special and in a hurry must be special indeed. This refers to limited express trains in Japan. They go fast, they stop at fewer stops (because they're special!) and they hurry. Look out for these if you want to get somewhere in a jiffy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the とく goes to とっ.
1831 | 行列 | ぎょうれつ | Line | Queue\n Matrix | You know the two words that make up this word, 行 and 列, and they both have similar meanings: a line and a row. Put them together and you have a line or a queue.\nThis usually means a line of people waiting for their turn, for example to enter a restaurant. It can be also used for a line that marches, like a line in a parade. In a mathematics context, it can refer to a matrix, which makes sense because they're lines and rows of numbers and stuff. \n This word takes the readings of the two words that make it up, so you should be lining up to read it!
1832 | 荷物 | にもつ | Luggage | Baggage\n Load | A luggage thing is your luggage. It's also your baggage and load too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You'll need to remember the 物 reading as もつ, though. Why? Because all your luggage just got thrown into various moats along the countryside. It's going to take you forever to collect your luggage from these moats and by then it'll be all soggy. Dangit...
1833 | 仮面 | かめん | Mask |  | A temporary face is something you put over your face to cover it. It's a mask. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1834 | 明治 | めいじ | Meiji Era | Meiji Emperor\n Meiji | It’s the era of Bright Rule! If this doesn't make sense, don't worry about it. Focus more on the reading, which is めいじ. Sound familiar? This is the famous Meiji Era or Meiji Emperor. If you don't know about it consider reading up, it's interesting history! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1835 | 商品 | しょうひん | Merchandise | Product\n Goods | Articles of merchandise are still merchandise. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1836 | 美術館 | びじゅつかん | Museum | Art Museum\n Art Gallery | You know 美術 is fine art. So what is a public building that contains said fine art? It's a museum. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1837 | 折り紙 | おりがみ | Origami | Art Of Paper Folding | You know that 折る is "to fold," so what about "to fold paper"? Ever heard of something that involves lots of folding of paper that is Japanese? Most likely you have. This is origami, aka the art of paper folding. \n The reading comes from 折る and the vocab word 紙. As long as you know those you should be able to read this. Also, you probably already know this reading because it's an English word, too.
1838 | 大阪 | おおさか | Osaka | Oosaka | The big heights. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is Osaka. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo. \n The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The 大 reads like おお from おおきい. Then, 阪 uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like 坂, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen 坂 you can apply that reading over to here, making おおさか. Then again, if you know this word means Osaka you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double おお though!
1839 | 外来 | がいらい | Outpatient | Foreign\n Imported | From foreign lands, you have come to this hospital. That makes you an outpatient.\n外来 describes something or someone that comes from elsewhere. You’ll see it most often in hospitals, where it means outpatient, but it’s also used in formal contexts to talk about foreign species or imported words. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1840 | 支払い | しはらい | Payment |  | The pay that supports you is made in payments. Whether you make payments to keep your house or your car, or you get payments from your boss, they keep you going. \n This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 支 and the kun'yomi reading of 払. You've learned them both, so you know this too!
1841 | 写真 | しゃしん | Photo | Photograph\n Picture | A copy of reality is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a photo. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1842 | 真っ黒 | まっくろ | Pitch Black | Pure Black | The reality is that it's black. Like, so black that it's beyond fake black, it's reality black. This is so black it's pitch black. \n The reading for the 真 is the vocab kun'yomi reading. Think of what is pitch black. It's your poor Ma (ま). She is so dark that she sucks in light, like a black hole... wait, she is a black hole, it explains why your Ma is pitch black.
1843 | 企画 | きかく | Plan | Planning\n Project | Take your plan and add some images to it. This is your plan.\nWhile 計画 refers to plans in general, 企画 specifically refers to the planning of events, projects, or initiatives, as well as the actual projects being planned. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.
1844 | 政治 | せいじ | Politics | Government | If you want to cure the government, you have to get into politics. Gotta join 'em to fix them... but can you survive that long without being corrupted yourself? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1845 | 保存 | ほぞん | Preservation | Conservation\n Saving | We try to preserve anything we want to exist with preservation. Want a special sea creature or bird to exist? Up conservation efforts! And, if you want to save data (like on a computer), you can use this word for that kind of saving, as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1846 | 首相 | しゅしょう | Prime Minister |  | The neck minister? This meaning prime minister makes sense if you think about the neck being the most important part of the body, kind of like the head! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It also uses a reading for 相 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe first prime ministers of Japan were actually the shoguns (しょう)… kind of.
1847 | 証明 | しょうめい | Proof | Prove\n Verify | Is the evidence bright enough to convince me? Is this really proof enough to prove it? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1848 | 治安 | ちあん | Public Order | Public Safety\n Public Peace | If your people can relax because you rule over them so well, there is public order. You don't want the people you rule being upset or stressed out, you want public safety and public peace for all! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1849 | 公園 | こうえん | Public Park | Park | A public park is a park that is public. It's a public park. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1850 | 危険 | きけん | Risky | Unsafe\n Dangerous\n Danger\n Peril\n Hazard | Something that is dangerous and risky is probably pretty risky, dangerous, and unsafe. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1851 | 場面 | ばめん | Scene | Setting\n Locale | Everything on a location's surface is really just a part of the scene before you. This is the kind of scene that would be set in a novel. It's the setting. \n The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
1852 | 画面 | がめん | Screen | Monitor | The image surface is a screen. Just imagine your computer screen. There's an image on the surface, right? It just happens to move around all the time, like most images on screens these days. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1853 | 手軽 | てがる | Simple And Easy | Convenient\n Quick | Your hands are light because it was a simple and easy task, so you didn't get your hands full. This word describes something that's hassle-free and doesn't take much effort, time, or sometimes cost to do. \n Both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word, which you've already learned. Just make sure you rendaku the 軽.
1854 | 笑顔 | えがお | Smile | Smiling Face | A laughing face is a  smiling face (or just a smile!). 笑顔s all around! \n The reading for this word won't make you smile, though. You were smiling, but then you heard about the reading of this kanji. It made you yell out "EH??" (え). Just watch out for the rendaku of かお to がお.
1855 | 専門 | せんもん | Specialty | Speciality\n Area Of Study\n Major | Your specialty gate is the thing you open to let out your specialty. Imagine the thing you're best at (your specialty). Now imagine opening a gate in your chest that lets it out, allowing you to be good at it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1856 | 仏像 | ぶつぞう | Statue Of Buddha | Image Of Buddha | You have Buddha's image. What is that? It's a statue of Buddha. It can also mean an image of Buddha. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1857 | 留学 | りゅうがく | Study Abroad | Studying Abroad | You detain your study and take it away to a foreign place. That foreign place is having you study abroad. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 留 is the りゅう version. You can remember this because Ryu (りゅう) from street fighter is doing a study abroad program to learn more karate.
1858 | 急 | きゅう | Sudden | Urgent\n Emergency\n Steep | This takes its meaning from the sudden part of the kanji, meaning it's sudden, urgent, or an emergency! \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1859 | 急死 | きゅうし | Sudden Death |  | A sudden death makes for just that, a sudden death. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1860 | 急に | きゅうに | Suddenly | Immediately\n Abruptly | Something that happens in a sudden way happens suddenly, immediately, or abruptly. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Suddenly you can read a new word!
1861 | 日光浴 | にっこうよく | Sunbathe |  | You know that 日光 is sunlight so when you add bathe you get "sunlight bathe" ... but that sounds dumb, so let's call this word sunbathe instead! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1862 | 荷札 | にふだ | Tag | Shipping Label\n Label | A luggage tag is a tag you put on luggage. It's also a label you can put on a package before you send it, like a shipping label. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji. You've learned both of these readings already, so you should be able to read this word too.
1863 | 技術 | ぎじゅつ | Technique | Craft\n Technology\n Skill | You've seen 技 as a vocab word meaning "technique," and the kanji 術 means technique. So this means technique! Your technique is also your craft, and what’s needed for technology. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1864 | 証言 | しょうげん | Testimony | Verbal Evidence | Evidence that you say is testimony. You could also say you're providing verbal evidence. Hopefully you won't have to give too much of this in your lifetime. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
