1865 | 教科書 | きょうかしょ | Textbook |  | The thing you use to teach a course with writings is a textbook. It's a book of writings you use to teach your course! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1866 | 浴びる | あびる | To Bathe In | To Be Exposed To | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bathe so the verb vocab version is to bathe in.\nThis verb is transitive, and the object is whatever you're "bathing in". It could be a bath or a shower, but it could also be the sun. So you can both シャワーを浴びる and 日の光を浴びる. More negatively, this can also mean to be exposed to something, such as criticism or radioactivity. \n You want to know the best way to bathe in something? With a bunch of aardvarks (あ) in the water. They use their sticky little tongues to clean all your cracks and crannies.
1867 | 関する | かんする | To Be Related To | To Be Concerned With\n To Pertain To | You know that 関 means related. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to be related to. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
1868 | 折れる | おれる | To Break | To Snap\n To Fracture | You already learned how 折る means "to fold something" or "to break something". This is the intransitive version of that, which just means it has no object. You just folded something too far, and now it's starting to break. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 折る, so you should know this one too!
1869 | 閉める | しめる | To Close Something | To Shut Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means closed so the verb vocab version is to close something.\n閉める primarily means to shut something in a physical sense (often with a sliding or twisting motion), like when you close doors, windows, curtains, faucets, and so on. Additionally, it can also be used for closing shops, either for the day or permanently. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you want to close something, use a sheep (し). Sheep are famously good closers. Doors, windows, curtains, you name it. Sure, they'll bleat on and on about how they're not your personal closer, they have their own doors to close, and bah bah blah, but they secretly love having the chance to shut something for you.
1870 | 妥協する | だきょうする | To Compromise |  | You know that 妥協 means compromise. So, what happens when you make it a verb? It becomes to compromise. \n The reading is the same as the vocab word 妥協, so if you know that you should be good (also, just the reading of the kanji works too).
1871 | 卒業する | そつぎょうする | To Graduate |  | You know that 卒業 is "graduation." Make it a verb, and you have to graduate. \n The reading is just the same as the vocab word 卒業.
1872 | 急ぐ | いそぐ | To Hurry |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hurry so the verb vocab version is to hurry. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying to hurry is someone who is not at ease (いそ).
1873 | 問い合わせる | といあわせる | To Inquire |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The first kanji is question. And you learned 合わせる is "to join together." What's "to join questions together"? It's to inquire. When you inquire, you ask all your questions together, right? \n You know how to read 合わせる already, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember the reading of 問:\nYou love to inquire with your toes (と). By that, you mean you love to type on your keyboard with your toes. There's no particular reason for this besides that you like the feel on your toes when you type up an inquiry.
1874 | 存じる | ぞんじる | To Know | To Be Aware Of\n To Believe | This is like a very formal and humble way of saying to know or to believe. Sure, the kanji means suppose, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know" or "I believe." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why 存じる means to know or to believe.\nNote this word is typically used in the polite ます form. When you’re humble, you may want to be as polite as possible, I suppose! \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!
1875 | 東京弁 | とうきょうべん | Tokyo Dialect |  | You know that 東京 is Tokyo, and you know that 弁 is dialect, so you have yourself Tokyo dialect. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 東京 already, which you should.
1876 | 笑う | わらう | To Laugh |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means laugh so the verb vocab version is to laugh. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can laugh freely, now!
1877 | 残す | のこす | To Leave Behind | To Leave Over | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about to leave behind. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of す. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would sue you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this. \n The reading for this word can come from level 14 item 残る. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.
1878 | 固める | かためる | To Make Something Hard | To Harden Something\n To Strengthen Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hard so the verb vocab version? To make something hard. You need to differentiate this from 固まる, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make something hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "mail" (める) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you. \n Since the reading for 固 (かた) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhy would you want to make something hard? Obviously because you want to put it in a catapult (かた). There's no point putting soft things in catapults, after all.
1879 | 生じる | しょうじる | To Occur | To Arise\n To Cause Something | Remember how 生まれる means "to be born"? This word is similar, but it's used for when non-living things are "born". So as an intransitive verb, this means to occur or to arise. When used transitively, it means to cause something. You'll probably encounter the intransitive use much more, though. \n You'd think this would use kun'yomi, but it actually doesn't! Like other verbs ending in じる, this takes the on'yomi reading of the kanji. 生 has two of those, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nIf you wanted anything to occur in medieval Japan, you needed to talk to the Shougun. You always needed the Shougun's help to cause something. Without the Shougun, nothing would ever happen!
1880 | 約束する | やくそくする | To Promise |  | 約束 is a “promise.” So when you add する to it you’re making it a verb, meaning to promise. Now promise you’ll remember! \n The reading is the same as 約束 with する added. Make sure you know 約束 and you'll know this word as well.
1881 | 守る | まもる | To Protect | To Defend\n To Obey | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means protect so the verb vocab version is to protect and also to defend. This can also mean to obey, in the sense of obeying the rules. \n You need to protect against breast cancer, so you get yourself a mammogram (まも).
1882 | 辞める | やめる | To Quit | To Resign As | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quit so the verb vocab version is to quit. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going to quit?" "Yah (や) man, I'm going to quit."
1883 | 帰す | かえす | To Send Someone Back | To Send Someone Home | The hiragana ends with an う sound, so you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means return, and this verb is transitive, meaning it takes a direct object. You send someone back. You send them home. And tell them to never come near you again. So this means to send someone back or to send someone home.\nIn fact, most verbs ending in す are transitive. To help you remember that, think of suing (す) someone to make sure they go home! \n The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Yay! But since this word has a pair verb, let's think of a way to remember the ending:\nWhat's the most surefire way to send someone home? Threaten to sue (す) them if they don't!
1884 | 重ねる | かさねる | To Stack | To Pile Up\n To Accumulate | You've got lots of heavy things, so the only logical thing is to stack them all up.\nBesides heavy physical things, you can also use this word when you're going to accumulate things like experience, practice, or years on your back. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAll the things you've stacked up were in preparation for your new casa (かさ). With everything inside boxes and neatly piled up, you're finally ready to move into your new casa. Hooray!
1885 | 希望する | きぼうする | To Wish | To Request\n To Hope\n To Seek | You know that 希望 is a "wish." When you "do a wish," that means to wish, to request or to hope.\nThis is a formal way to say that you wish for something, so you might use it at work to request an opportunity to work abroad, or let them know politely that you're resigning. \n The reading comes from 希望. It's also the on'yomi jukugo reading as well, if that helps any.
1886 | 書く | かく | To Write |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means write so the verb version means to write. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the on'yomi one, but this word is read with the kun'yomi, か. So just be sure to remember the kun'yomi reading to read this word in the car (か) ... or to write it, or whatever.
1887 | 真実 | しんじつ | Truth | Reality | The reality of the truth is nothing more than the truth and the reality. Doesn't get any more real than this. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1888 | 不幸 | ふこう | Unhappiness | Misfortune\n Misery\n Death | When you do not have happiness, you have unhappiness, misfortune and misery. This can also mean death, usually of a family member. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1889 | 待合室 | まちあいしつ | Waiting Room |  | A room where you join other people to wait. This is a waiting room. \n Remember how you learned 待合 already? Well throw the on'yomi for 室 on the end of that and you have your reading!
1890 | 証人 | しょうにん | Witness |  | An evidence person is a witness, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1891 | 動物園 | どうぶつえん | Zoo | Zoological Gardens\n Menagerie | Remember how 動物 means animal? Well when you add park it becomes a zoo. It's a park for animals. Except the animals can't leave. Ever. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1892 | 欠席 | けっせき | Absence | Nonattendance | When a seat is lacking the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an absence. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the けつ is shortened to けっ as つs often are when in a situation like this.
1893 | 是非 | ぜひ | Absolutely | By All Means\n Right And Wrong | Absolutely an injustice! We must absolutely punish the perpetrator, by all means. First, though, we should probably define right and wrong.\nThis word means "absolutely" when it's used as an adverb, and that's the use you'll hear most in conversation. However, as a noun it means "right and wrong", as in whether something is right or wrong, or good or bad. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1894 | 結局 | けっきょく | After All | Eventually\n In The End | If you tie the bureau up with your delays this may not get done this year after all.\nThis word carries the nuance that despite the various events or factors leading up to it, the final outcome just is what it is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the けつ gets changed to けっ as つs in this situation often do.
1895 | 愛知県 | あいちけん | Aichi Prefecture |  | The Love Know Prefecture! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is Aichi Prefecture (jump to the reading to figure this out). \n The reading here is all the on'yomi jukugo madness you can handle. If you learned the kanji, you should be able to read this. If you can read it, you can translate it to "English" even though only half of it is English.
1896 | 常に | つねに | Always | Constantly\n Continually | The particle に here is a clue that this word is an adverb. An adverb describes actions, so what's a normal action? It's one you're always, or constantly, doing. That's what makes it normal! \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this:\nI always tune (つね) my violin, but today I didn't tune it. So, now I sound terrible. Imagine how terrible my untuned violin sounds, compared to how it always sounds.
1897 | 無名 | むめい | Anonymous | Unknown | Someone with "nothing" for their name is either trying to remain anonymous or is simply unknown. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1898 | 兵器 | へいき | Arms | Weapons | The containers that soldiers use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their arms and weapons. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1899 | 相変わらず | あいかわらず | As Usual | As Ever\n The Same\n As Before | A mutual change you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working as usual. It will be like everything is the same as it was before because the change was mutual. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
1900 | 原子 | げんし | Atom |  | The original child of everything is the atom. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1901 | 出席 | しゅっせき | Attendance |  | The people who exit their seats at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true attendance. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the しゅつ gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.
1902 | 不味い | まずい | Bad Tasting | Unappetizing\n Unskillful | You've seen 美味しい by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of 美 you have 不 (not), so something that does not have flavor is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something bad tasting. This can also refer to someone who's unskillful at something as well. \n The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's まずい. Think about how you're going through this really long maze (まず) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so bad tasting you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly unappetizing cheese.
1903 | 紀元前 | きげんぜん | Before The Common Era | BCE\n Before Christ\n BC | Remember how 紀元後 is "Common Era", or "anno Domini"? Well, this is the opposite because it has before (前) instead of 後. It's Before the Common Era or Before Christ. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 紀元後 already, because then you'll just have to remember the 前.
1904 | 両側 | りょうがわ | Both Sides |  | Both sides is both sides. Which side? Both sides. \n The first kanji takes the on'yomi reading and the second takes the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you know both of them already!
1905 | 底 | そこ | Bottom |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!
1906 | 心底 | しんそこ | Bottom Of One's Heart | Bottom Of My Heart | The heart bottom is the bottom of one's heart. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from 心底? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!
1907 | 朝ご飯 | あさごはん | Breakfast |  | The morning meal is the meal you eat in the morning. That is breakfast. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: 朝 is like the vocab version, あさ and ご飯 is like the word you learned, ごはん.
1908 | 食堂 | しょくどう | Cafeteria | Dining Hall\n Diner | An eating hall is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a cafeteria, a dining hall, or a diner? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1909 | 原因 | げんいん | Cause | Origin\n Source | The original cause is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first cause is the origin and source of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1910 | 喜劇 | きげき | Comedy |  | Rejoice drama isn't so much drama as it is comedy, since it makes you rejoice. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1911 | 常識 | じょうしき | Common Sense | Common Knowledge | Normal discerning is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are common sense. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1912 | 完結 | かんけつ | Conclusion | Completion\n Ending\n Consummation | The perfect way to tie up a research paper is with a conclusion. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1913 | 意識 | いしき | Consciousness | Awareness | Your ideas while discerning things show your consciousness and an awareness of your surroundings. You not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1914 | 泣き虫 | なきむし | Crybaby |  | You've seen that 泣く is to cry, so you can probably guess that 泣き is just "cry." You've also seen how 虫 is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a crybaby? \n The readings come from 泣く and 虫. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.
1915 | 泣き声 | なきごえ | Crying | Sob | A cry voice is a sound of crying or a sob. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday! \n The reading comes from the vocab words 泣く and 声. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!
1916 | 一昨日 | おととい | Day Before Last | Day Before Yesterday | Remember how you learned that 昨日 means "yesterday?" Well one day previous to that day is the day before last. \n This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it:\nThe day before last you bought an "O" toe toy (おととい). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the day before yesterday to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!
1917 | 詳しい | くわしい | Detailed | Expert | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of detailed? It's also detailed. \n When something is detailed it is made up of a huge quantity (くわ) of little things. And if you're an expert on something, you'll have a huge quantity of knowledge, too.
1918 | 詳細 | しょうさい | Details |  | Things that are detailed and... detailed are, well, the details. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1919 | 晩ご飯 | ばんごはん | Dinner | Supper | The night meal is the meal you eat at night. That is dinner. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1920 | 外交官 | がいこうかん | Diplomat |  | Someone from the outside who comes in to mix with the government is a diplomat. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1921 | 劇 | げき | Drama | Play\n Show | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (drama). Can also mean play or show as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?
1922 | 劇的 | げきてき | Dramatic |  | Something that is drama al is dramatic. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1923 | 薬物 | やくぶつ | Drugs | Medicine | These medicine things are of the bad kind, they're drugs!\nAs a standalone word, 薬物 generally refers to (often) illegal drugs that cause addiction or have a stimulating effect. Depending on the context, it can also refer to pharmaceutical drugs (aka medicine), but in that case, it's usually used in compounds like 薬物アレルギー (drug allergy). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1924 | 干天 | かんてん | Dry Weather | Drought | Remember how 天気 is weather (and how 天 often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have dry weather.\nNote that 干天 is quite old-fashioned and you'll find it mainly in formal writing and advanced set expressions. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1925 | 東側 | ひがしがわ | East Side | East | The East side is the East side. \n Remember how 東口 read as ひがしぐち? This word is like that too, with 東 being read as ひがし. 側 is read like you learned it with the kanji.
1926 | 非常 | ひじょう | Emergency | Extreme\n Unusual | When an injustice to what's normal is being committed, that makes it an emergency!\nAlthough it's less common, this can also be used as a な adjective. In that case, it means extreme or unusual. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1927 | 日常 | にちじょう | Everyday Life | Normal Life\n Daily Life\n Ordinary\n Regular\n Everyday\n Usual | Normal days are what you have in your regular everyday life. This is your normal life. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1928 | 説明 | せつめい | Explanation |  | When you make your theory bright (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with an explanation for it. Before it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you give your explanation, it gets bright and easy to understand! Yay! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1929 | 失敗 | しっぱい | Failure | Mistake | A fault and a failure, all in one. This must have been one big failure and mistake you've made. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 失 gets shortened, and 敗 gets rendaku'd, though. Don't make that 失敗.
1930 | 幻想 | げんそう | Fantasy | Illusion | An illusion that you imagine is your big fantasy (it's also an illusion). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when you imagine it, it becomes your fantasy! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1931 | ペラペラ | ペラペラ | Fluent | Paper Thin\n Leafing Through A Book | Parrot, parrot (ペラペラ), your speaking is so fluent!\nペラペラ is an オノマトペ that describes someone speaking a language fluently, or simply being a real chatterbox.\nRelated to this, ペラペラ also means leafing through a book. And in an extension of that meaning, it can describe something paper thin or flimsy, like a piece of paper from that book you're leafing through.
1932 | 外来語 | がいらいご | Foreign Word | Borrowed Word\n Loanword | You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for language and you have an imported word, aka a borrowed word. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1933 | 無料 | むりょう | Free | Without Charge | When the fee is nothing it is free and without charge! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1934 | 果物 | くだもの | Fruit |  | A fruit thing is just fruit. \n The reading for this is an exception, at least for the 果 portion. To remember this part, imagine yourself asking for some fruit. Could I (くだ) have some fruit, please?
1935 | 官金 | かんきん | Government Funds | Government Money | Government gold (aka money) is what makes up government funds. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1936 | 幻覚 | げんかく | Hallucination |  | An illusion you have when you're awake is a hallucination. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1937 | 失恋 | しつれん | Heartbreak | Broken Heart\n Unrequited Love | The fault of romance isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience heartbreak or unrequited love. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1938 | 鼻歌 | はなうた | Humming |  | Try singing a nose song. How does it sound? Like humming perhaps? \n The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a 鼻 is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know 鼻's reading from the kanji (はな) and you know 歌's reading from the vocabulary word 歌 (うた). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, はなうた.
1939 | 仮説 | かせつ | Hypothesis |  | A temporary theory isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a hypothesis.\nThis word is generally used when referring to research or some sort of investigation where a hypothesis is put forward that needs to be tested and validated through evidence and experimentation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1940 | 無知 | むち | Ignorance | Ignorant | When you know nothing (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is ignorance, it's being ignorant. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1941 | 幻 | まぼろし | Illusion | Phantom\n Apparition | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add phantom to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like illusions. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy illusion. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a mob of Roshis (まぼろし). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.
1942 | 図説 | ずせつ | Illustration | Explanatory Diagram | A diagram theory is an illustration that is used as an explanatory diagram. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1943 | 無理 | むり | Impossible | Unreasonable\n Overdoing | If you can do nothing within reason, then what you're trying to do is unreasonable and probably downright impossible. If you still try, you're probably just overdoing it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
1944 | 察知 | さっち | Inference | Infer\n Sense | Okay, so you guess but you also kind of know. You can make an inference as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 察 gets shortened to さっ.
1945 | 内側 | うちがわ | Inside |  | The inside side is the inside. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 側 you've already learned it. With 内 you've also already learned the reading. Combine them together and you have うちがわ. In case you've forgotten, here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky うち portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "Oo, cheese!" (うち) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"
1946 | 干渉 | かんしょう | Interference | Intervention | When you're fording a stream, and you suddenly feel dry feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an interference. It's an intervention trying to stop you from fording. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1947 | 無茶 | むちゃ | Irrational | Reckless\n Excessive | Imagine having nothing but tea for an entire week. Sounds completely irrational, right? Such a reckless diet plan seems excessive.\n無茶 is often used to point out that something goes against common sense; or to criticize or disapprove of some actions or situations that might be seen as reckless or excessive. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1948 | 知識 | ちしき | Knowledge | Information | You're discerning about what you know. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your knowledge. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1949 | 左側 | ひだりがわ | Left Side | Left-hand Side | The left side is the left side. Simple as that. \n The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab 左 and add it to 側 to have yourself ひだりがわ.
1950 | 伝説 | でんせつ | Legend | Legendary Story | When people transmit a theory through the ages, it can turn into a legend, or legendary story. Kind of like how the "theory" of King Arthur's sword turned into the legend of Excalibur. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that 伝 is read as でん in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your den (でん) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great legend.
1951 | 敗者 | はいしゃ | Loser | The Defeated | The defeated someone is the loser or the defeated. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1952 | 愛 | あい | Love |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji love.
1953 | 愛情 | あいじょう | Love | Affection | Those love feelings you're having mean you're in love! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1954 | 恋愛 | れんあい | Love | Romance | When you have romance and love all in the same package. Well, that is love! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1955 | 恋 | こい | Love |  | When you have romance you also have love! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your love isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant Koi (こい) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!
1956 | 愛人 | あいじん | Lover | Mistress | The person you make love to is your lover. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1957 | 昼ご飯 | ひるごはん | Lunch |  | The noon meal is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious lunch. \n The readings come from the words 昼 and ご飯. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.
1958 | 主因 | しゅいん | Main Cause | Primary Cause | The main cause is the main cause or the primary cause. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1959 | 薬用 | やくよう | Medicinal | Medicinal Use | Something that's used for medicine is medicinal. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1960 | 薬 | くすり | Medicine | Drug\n Drugs | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some medicine, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you cuss yuri (くすり) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.
1961 | 兵員 | へいいん | Military Personnel | Military Strength | A soldier member (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the military personnel. It also shows the amount of military strength an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1962 | 水兵 | すいへい | Navy Sailor | Sailor\n Seaman | A water soldier is a soldier that is out to sea. In other words, a navy sailor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1963 | 交渉 | こうしょう | Negotiation |  | When you ford into the thick of things and mix everything up, you're getting involved in a negotiation. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1964 | 無休 | むきゅう | No Holidays | Always Open\n Nonstop | If rest is nothing then there are no holidays. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is always open, nonstop. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1965 | 鼻 | はな | Nose |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji. Smells nice, right?
1966 | 鼻血 | はなぢ | Nosebleed | Bloody Nose | A nose with blood is a nose with a nosebleed. It is a bloody nose. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know 鼻's reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of 血 as well. Put them together and you have はなち, though you want to change the ち to ぢ. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as はなじ. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.
1967 | 小説 | しょうせつ | Novel |  | A small theory is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a novel? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1968 | 願い事 | ねがいごと | One's Wish | Prayer\n Wish | You know that お願い means "a request," and 事 can mean "thing." Well, a request for some specific thing can also be called one's wish or a prayer. Do you have any 願い事 in your heart right now? Of course you do! Don't worry, you can tell me. \n The readings come from the words お願い and 事. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too. Just remember that 事 is rendaku'd, so it's read as ごと.
1969 | 空席 | くうせき | Open Seat | Empty Seat\n Free Seat | A sky seat is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an empty seat or open seat. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1970 | 歌劇 | かげき | Opera |  | A song drama. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an opera. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1971 | 原作 | げんさく | Original Work |  | The original thing you make is the original work. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1972 | 外側 | そとがわ | Outside | Outer Side\n Exterior | The outside side is the outside. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for 外 with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.
1973 | 愛国心 | あいこくしん | Patriotism |  | When you have love for your country deep within your heart, that is patriotism. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1974 | 警察 | けいさつ | Police |  | They warn you and they guess when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the police. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1975 | 無力 | むりょく | Powerless | Powerlessness\n Helplessness | When your power is nothing you are powerless. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You also can know that 力 uses its りょく reading because when you tried to pick up a tiny rock (りょく) you couldn't, because you were powerless.
1976 | 結果 | けっか | Result |  | You tie up all the fruit because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the result of the big monkey election. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 結 gets shortened to けっ.
1977 | 右側 | みぎがわ | Right Side | Right-hand Side | The right side is the right side. \n The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word 右 by now. Also, the 側 reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word 側.
1978 | 川底 | かわぞこ | Riverbed | River Bottom | The river bottom is the river bottom, also known as the riverbed. \n The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for 底!
1979 | 無事 | ぶじ | Safe And Sound | Safe\n Without A Hitch | A nothing occurrence is an occurrence where nothing happens to you, or at least nothing too bad — that means you're safe and sound. Phew!\nIn addition to meaning safe, 無事 can also describe a situation where everything goes off without a hitch. \n One thing that's not safe and sound is the reading of the 無 in this word. Instead of む it's ぶ. Why? Because you thought it was safe and sound, but you were fooled. There are ghosts everywhere, all jumping out and screaming Boo! (ぶ) at you. Feel the surprise. You thought it was safe and sound!
1980 | 塩 | しお | Salt |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.
1981 | 塩水 | しおみず | Salt Water |  | Water with salt in it is salt water. Best not to drink 塩水. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know 塩's from the kanji and you know 水's from the vocab word 水. Combine them together and you have しおみず.
1982 | 塩味 | しおあじ | Salty Taste | Tastes Salty\n Salty\n Salty Flavor | The taste of salt is a salty taste (it's also when something tastes salty). \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of 塩 (you learned the reading with the kanji) and 味 and you have yourself しおあじ.\nIf you happen to be a cooking show fan, you might also hear the on'yomi reading of this word - えんみ. This word can also be read as しおみ, which has more or less the same meaning as the primary reading you learned.
1983 | 席 | せき | Seat |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.
1984 | 自愛 | じあい | Self Love | Taking Care Of Oneself | If you love your self that is self love. You’ll mostly see this word as part of the set phrase ご自愛下さい, which is used in emails and the like to remind the recipients to be good to themselves. Other variations include ご自愛くださいませ, ご自愛を, and ご自愛のほどを. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.
1985 | 感覚 | かんかく | Sense | The Senses\n Sensation | You know how we use feelings to memorize things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your senses, because feelings are memorized best when you use the senses. This can also refer to any particular sensation or even somebody's sense of humor or fashion! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1986 | 側 | そば | Side | Side Of Something\n Part | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n You've learned the がわ as the reading for this kanji, but when its used on its own as a vocabulary word, it is read as そば. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nHaving a sober(そば) person by your side is important when you're drunk.\nThink of other vocabulary words that use がわ. In these words, 側 is a suffix, so it will have another kanji that comes before it.
1987 | 署名 | しょめい | Signature |  | When you write your name for a government office, they require you to write out your signature. Printing won't do for official government office business. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1988 | 無言 | むごん | Silence |  | When you have nothing to say you sit in silence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 言 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nNothing cuts through silence like a gong (ごん). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.
1989 | 鼻くそ | はなくそ | Snot | Boogers | Maybe you didn't know this, but if you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the cuss words first. くそ is sh*t / garbage, though it's not really a "bad" word in Japanese like it is in English. So, what is your nose sh*t? It's your snot and boogers. Ewwww, stop eating them! \n The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. はなくそ.
1990 | 兵士 | へいし | Soldier |  | A soldier samurai is still just another soldier. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1991 | 兵 | へい | Soldier | Army\n Troops | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
1992 | 薬学 | やくがく | Study Of Pharmacy | Pharmacology\n Pharmaceutics | People who study about medicine are studying the study of pharmacy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
1993 | 劇場 | げきじょう | Theater | Theatre | A drama location is where people do drama. This is a theater. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
1994 | 細い | ほそい | Thin | Slender | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thin? It's also thin, though it can be slender as well. \n If your garden is too thin, just get out the hose (ほそ)! How about if your hair is thin? Point the hose at your head! Hoses can cure any thin issues you may have.
1995 | 鼻先 | はなさき | Tip Of The Nose | Tip Of Nose\n Nose Tip | You know the previous part of your nose? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the tip of the nose. Time to cut off the rest, next! \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With 鼻 you learned that with the kanji. With 先 you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.
1996 | 変わる | かわる | To Be Changed | To Be Transformed\n To Be Altered | You've seen how 変える means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, so it means to be changed or to be altered.\n変わる refers to the act of changing into something different, and involves alterations in nature, appearance, or state. For example, it can describe changes in weather or the season, someone undergoing a noticeable change in appearance or behavior, or one's feelings or thoughts evolving over time.\nSince 変わる means "becoming something different," you can also use 変わった and 変わっている to describe someone or something that's "different from what's normal." For example, you can say 変わった人 or 変わっている人 to mean "an odd person." \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
1997 | 敗れる | やぶれる | To Be Defeated | To Be Unsuccessful | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means defeat, so this means to be defeated, but also to be unsuccessful. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "Yah, Boo" (やぶ) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!", you reply back. "Yah boo", they say again.
1998 | 悲しむ | かなしむ | To Be Sad About | To Be Saddened By | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sad and this verb is transitive, so it means to be sad about something. Boohoo. \n If you're going to be sad about something right now, it will be kana (かな). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.
1999 | 治す | なおす | To Cure | To Heal\n To Ease | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means cure, and this verb means to cure, to heal or to ease something. This particular verb is when someone does the curing. The illness or injury doesn't just get better by itself. How can you remember that? Because when you try to heal someone and you mess up, they can try to sue (す) you. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nI need you to heal him, and I need you to heal him right now (なお). NOW NOW NOW!\nThis also shares the reading for 直す, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word なおす was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.
2000 | 干す | ほす | To Dry Something | To Hang Dry Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry and the verb vocab version is to dry something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need to dry something? Because someone used a hose (ほす) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...
2001 | 果てる | はてる | To End | To Die | If you tear (てる) up a fruit, its life is going to end. In other words, the poor thing is going to die. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe fruit's life is about to end and you laugh, "Hahahaha (は)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...
2002 | 察する | さっする | To Guess | To Sense\n To Presume\n To Infer | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means guess so the verb vocab version is to guess. Alternatively, you can learn this as to sense or to presume. \n The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the さつ is shortened to さっ. If you had to guess be sure to guess with the shorter つ.
2003 | 愛する | あいする | To Love |  | You know that 愛 means love. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to love. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
2004 | 喜ぶ | よろこぶ | To Rejoice | To Become Happy\n To Be Glad | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rejoice so the verb vocab version is to rejoice. Though to become happy probably sounds a little more natural. \n You start to rejoice by saying, "Yo, rock on (よろこ)!" Now you know how to rejoice from now on. At church or temple? "Yo, rock on!" Perfect.
2005 | 悲劇 | ひげき | Tragedy |  | A sad drama always ends in tragedy. That's what makes it sad. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2006 | 梅 | うめ | Ume | Japanese Plum | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It's also the same as the meaning of the kanji / vocab, though you can think of this as  Japanese plum as well if you want.
2007 | 梅酒 | うめしゅ | Ume Wine | Plum Wine\n Plum Liquor\n Umeshu | Alcohol that comes from ume is ume wine. It can also be called plum wine or plum liquor. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice! \n The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!
2008 | 不詳 | ふしょう | Unknown | Unidentified | Something is not detailed at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally unknown entity. It's unidentified. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2009 | 米兵 | べいへい | US Soldier | American Soldier | Remember how 米国 is "America." Well, more of that again. With 米 representing "America" you can combine that with 兵 (soldier) to have yourself a US soldier / American soldier. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2010 | 勝敗 | しょうはい | Victory Or Defeat | Win Or Lose\n Outcome | You have win and you have defeat. When you are talking about both in one word, you have victory or defeat. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2011 | 西側 | にしがわ | West Side | West | The West side of something is known as the West or the West side. Sorry, I have no story to go along with your West side. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You should know both of them, with 西 being にし and 側 being がわ (what you learned with the kanji).
2012 | 無し | なし | Without | With No | This is the noun version of the kanji nothing, so when you have nothing, you are without. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you are without you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up gnashing (なし) your teeth together instead.
2013 | 青春 | せいしゅん | Youth | Adolescence\n Springtime Of One's Life | The time of young spring for humans is really just their youth. Just like plants in spring, your adolescence is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's the springtime of one's life.\nThis generally refers to the period when you’re an energetic teenager and young adult. It can have connotations of exhilarating experiences and bittersweet feelings, as well as nostalgic memories. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 春 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nDon't let your youth go to waste, because it will be over soon (しゅん)!
2014 | 予告 | よこく | Advance Notice | Prior Notice\n Trailer\n Preview | If you announce something beforehand you will have advance notice. Advance notice is always nice to give.\nYou'll also see this used as an abbreviation of 予告編, meaning trailer or preview. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2015 | 広告 | こうこく | Advertisement | Ad\n Advert | When you announce something to a wide audience, you're just throwing your message out there for everyone to hear. This is just a big wide advertisement. \n Sorry, you only learned the kun'yomi reading with 広. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big advertisement to advertise how terrible a person こういち is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.
2016 | 笑い | わらい | A Laugh | Laugh | You know that 笑う is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the う in 笑う turns to い (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's a laugh. \n The reading is the same as 笑う, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

One person holds the bow, the other fires the arrows. Teamwork makes the dream work. Even for shooting bows. Just you 'n' me.

2027 | 喫茶店 | きっさてん | Cafe | Tea House\n Coffee Shop\n Coffee House | If you consume tea in a shop, it could either be a cafe, a tea house, or slightly confusingly, a coffee shop. Welcome! Sit down. Relax. Have some tea (or coffee).\nThis word often refers to cafes with a retro feel to them, though they can be modern too. These places usually serve a variety of drinks and light meals. \n The readings are what you'd expect except for きつ getting shortened to きっ and 茶, which has this strange さ reading. To remember that it's さ instead of ちゃ, think of this tea house you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a saw (さ) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.

If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that cowはいい" (かわいい), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
2077 | 報道 | ほうどう | News Report |  | News travels down the road by way of a news report.\n報道 specifically refers to information put out by news organizations or the press in the form of newspaper articles, radio or television broadcasts, etc. Notice that it's different from 報告, which is more general and means the reporting of information by anyone. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2078 | 禁煙 | きんえん | No Smoking |  | If smoke is prohibited you probably shouldn't smoke. Aka no smoking, okay? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2079 | 枚数 | まいすう | Number Of Sheets | Number Of Flat Objects | You have flat objects. You have a number of them. These flat objects are flat things, right? Flat things like sheets of paper, perhaps (or other sheets of things). So, this word is number of sheets. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2080 | 大阪弁 | おおさかべん | Osaka Dialect |  | Remember 大阪 (Osaka)? This is the dialect they speak, making this word Osaka dialect. \n If you know how to read 大阪 you can just add 弁 to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in Osaka dialect. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.
2081 | 許可 | きょか | Permission |  | I permit that it is possible. So, go ahead, do it. I give you permission. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2082 | 〜達 | たち | Pluralizing Suffix |  | You'll see this attached to other words to make them plural. That's why it's called a pluralizing suffix.\nNote that you can only attach this to people and animals to make them plural. It can also be used with a person's name, like マリアたち. In that case, it refers to Maria and the group of people she's with! This might sound a little complicated, but you'll get the hang of it with a little practice! \n This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember たつ? Well this is read たち. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nIf you want to pluralize something, touch (たち) it to something else. One friend touches another friend, well now they're friends. Plural friends! All thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch!\nOh, and don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached in front of this word.
2083 | 可能 | かのう | Possible |  | The ability is there, so it is possible... wait, there's enough ability to make this possible? Let's do it! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2084 | 葉書 | はがき | Postcard |  | A writing that you put on a leaf is like something else. Instead of a leaf, think about writing you put on a leafish sized item. A postcard perhaps? \n The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for 葉 is the は you know and love. Then, 書 is かき despite not having a き on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the 書き reading, but keep in mind that 書き gets rendaku'd.
2085 | 静か | しずか | Quiet |  | This is the な adjective form of quiet, which is kind of just like the noun, anyways. What is the adjective version of quiet? It's also quiet. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be quiet. She's (しず) being nice and quiet, unlike you!
2086 | 人種 | じんしゅ | Race Of People | Race | A kind or type of person is when you categorize a person into different types. How do we do that? Well, you categorize by race of people (or more simply by race). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2087 | ドキドキ | ドキドキ | Racing Heart | Excited\n Nervous | Doc, Doc (ドキドキ), listen to my racing heart. I'm so excited, but I'm also a bit nervous.\nドキドキ is an オノマトペ used to describe the feeling of your heart beating fast. When does your heart race? When you get excited or nervous, so ドキドキ also expresses those feelings!
2088 | 洗練 | せんれん | Refinement | Polish | You take your practice and you wash it. Slowly chunks fall off and it becomes more and more simple. You are washing away the gunk on the outside to attain refinement and polish yourself, via practice. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2089 | 親類 | しんるい | Relatives |  | These people are kind of like a type of parents. Not quite parents, but kind of, in a pinch anyways. These are your relatives. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2090 | 借家 | しゃくや | Rented House | House For Rent\n Renting A House | When you borrow a house it's a rented house. This could also be a house for rent.\nYou can use 借家 in conversation to formally refer to a rented house or a house for rent. But it's more commonly found in legal contexts, like in laws and regulations. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read with either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. This uses a less common kun'yomi of 家, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you live in a rented house, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. And when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a shack, yah (しゃくや) house renter! Enjoy!"\nBy the way, in the secondary reading しゃっか, the しゃく changes to しゃっ. This reading is mostly used in legal contexts though, so しゃくや is more common.
2091 | 報告 | ほうこく | Report | Information | News that you announce becomes a report. When someone announces news on a topic, they are giving you a report on the information.\n報告 is a report given by someone after they've done some investigation or research into the topic. It can be used for class presentations on a topic or a report given to your boss. This differs from 報道, which is a report released by news organizations. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2092 | 下書き | したがき | Rough Draft |  | Something below your writing isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a rough draft. \n The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words 下 and 書く separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading. Just don't forget the rendaku here!
2093 | 大丈夫 | だいじょうぶ | Safe | All Right\n Okay | The big height of your husband makes everything safe and all right. Nothing you need to worry about when you have your super giant husband around to protect you. This is a really useful word, and it is used all the time. If someone asks: "Are you alright?" you could say in response "大丈夫" to mean you're doing all right. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
2094 | 土曜日 | どようび | Saturday |  | This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The earth day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is Saturday. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
2095 | 座席 | ざせき | Seat |  | A sit seat is probably going to be a seat. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2096 | 正座 | せいざ | Seiza | Traditional Japanese Sitting | The correct way to sit is this way: traditional Japanese sitting (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). 2097 | 煙 | けむり | Smoke |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a smoke machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "Kay, Murray (けむり), it's time to stop that," you say.

2099 | 汽船 | きせん | Steam Ship | Steam Boat | A steam ship is a steam ship or steam boat. So fancy back in their day! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2100 | 汽車 | きしゃ | Steam Train | Steam Engine Train\n Steam Engine | A steam car is a car that runs on steam. No regular car runs on steam, but what thing that has things called "cars" does run on steam? How about a steam train? You can also think about 電車s, which are electric cars (but means "train"). This is similar to that, but now it's run with steam, making it a steam train. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2101 | 静止 | せいし | Still | Standstill\n At Rest\n Stationary | Everything is quiet and stopped. The world is still and everything is at rest. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2102 | 飴細工 | あめざいく | Sugar Sculpture | Candy Sculpture\n Sugar Animal | Candy made into a thin construction is a sugar sculpture or a candy sculpture. It's usually a sugar animal, but it can be anything, really. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for 工 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want your sugar sculptures to be made into cookies (く)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best.\nAlso, watch out for the rendaku on 細, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.
2103 | 日焼け | ひやけ | Sunburn | Suntan\n Tan | When the sun burns something, and that something is you, it's giving you sunburn. \n The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ひ for 日 and や for 焼け (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the sunburn.

2105 | 夕焼け | ゆうやけ | Sunset | Evening Glow | When the evening is burning with sun, it is the sun going down, getting all close to the horizon and earth. This is the sunset, or more specifically, the evening glow you can see during a sunset. \n The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine 夕 and 焼け (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have ゆうやけ.

2108 | 喉 | のど | Throat |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading.
