In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "No Do- (のど)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...
2109 | 木曜日 | もくようび | Thursday |  | This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The tree day of the week is Thursday. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
2110 | 告げる | つげる | To Announce | To Tell | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means announce so the verb vocab version is to announce. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like to announce... we're not having one baby, we're having two (つ) babies!
2111 | 達する | たっする | To Attain | To Reach\n To Get To\n To Arrive At | You know that 達 means attain. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means to attain. \n This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for 達 is たつ, but here it's shortened, to just たっ. So make sure you remember.
2112 | 焼く | やく | To Bake | To Burn Something\n To Grill | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bake or burn. So, the verb vocab version is to bake, to burn something, or even to grill.\n焼く means to apply heat to something to change it in a physical way. It can refer to lightly toasting something, charring it, or even burning it to ashes depending on the context. It's commonly used in cooking contexts to describe baking, grilling, or roasting food. But it can also be used with pottery, film photography, and even sun-tanning. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
2113 | 閉まる | しまる | To Close | To Shut | If 閉める is "to close something" or "to shut something," then this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something closes on its own. That's why this is to close or to shut. You remember this because the door keeps shutting on your hand, marring (まる) it over and over again. Ouch. \n The reading is the same as 閉める.
2114 | 繋がる | つながる | To Be Connected | To Be Tied Together\n To Lead To\n To Be Connected To | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this is a verb. The kanji itself means connect, which makes this to be connected to. In other situations, this can also mean to be tied together, or to lead to. \n You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!
2115 | 関わる | かかわる | To Be Involved | To Be Related\n To Be Connected | You know that the kanji means related. As a verb, this often means to be involved, to be related, and to be connected. Basically, things that have to do with being related to something else. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEver heard of the "Kaw Kaw (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want to be involved with them.
2116 | 借りる | かりる | To Borrow |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means borrow so the verb vocab version is to borrow. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your car (か)? Please?
2117 | 苛める | いじめる | To Bully | To Pick On\n To Tease\n To Torment | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frustration. What do frustrated people do? They tend to bully, to pick on, to tease, and to torment other people. \n This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.
2118 | 配達する | はいたつする | To Deliver |  | You distribute the goods, they attain the goods. You are going to deliver to everyone. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2119 | 忘れる | わすれる | To Forget |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forget so the verb vocab version is to forget. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what was (わす) the reading? I forget... What was it?
2120 | 治る | なおる | To Get Better | To Get Well\n To Heal | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji 治 means cure, but this verb refers to the natural process of getting better: to get better, to get well, or simply to heal. This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own. Nobody cures you, you just get better. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nWhen you get sick, your mom calls every day to ask, "Are you better now (なお)?" How about NOW!? How about NOW!? Jeez Mom, just let me rest!
2121 | 固まる | かたまる | To Harden | To Solidify\n To Become Firm\n To Become Certain | You've seen how 固める means "to make hard." This word means that something hardened by itself, it means to harden or to solidify. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
2122 | 許す | ゆるす | To Permit | To Forgive\n To Allow | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means permit so the verb vocab version is to permit. It also means to forgive, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for 許さない in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!" \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. You're (ゆる) allowed to do it this one time, okay?
2123 | 禁じる | きんじる | To Prohibit | To Forbid | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prohibition so the verb version means to prohibit or to forbid. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
2124 | 報じる | ほうじる | To Report On |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means news report so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "to report on," however. \n The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.
2125 | 書き直す | かきなおす | To Rewrite |  | If you take your writing and fix it, you are taking your writing and rewriting it. This word means to rewrite, because the fixing is really heavy, so regular revisions won't do. \n The readings come from 書く and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!
2126 | 座る | すわる | To Sit |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sit so the verb vocab version is to sit. \n The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going to sit down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking sewer (すわ). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.
2127 | 叩く | たたく | To Strike | To Tap\n To Hit\n To Knock\n To Beat | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tap or strike, and the verb version is to strike, to tap, to hit, to knock, or to beat.\nThis verb can be used for both things and people, and the English translation will change depending on what it is you're striking. You'll always have some kind of object, though, since this is a transitive verb. So you might tap someone on the shoulder, knock at a door, or beat a drum. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you're going to strike something over and over it makes a ta-ta (たた) sound. Imagine you're about to beat a steel drum, for example. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it?
2128 | 洗う | あらう | To Wash |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wash so the verb vocab version is to wash. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to wash a rock (あら) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.
2129 | 書き入れる | かきいれる | To Write In | To Fill In | To insert what you write into something is to write in or to fill in. \n The readings come from 書く and 入れる. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.
2130 | 訓練 | くんれん | Training | Practice | You've got your instruction and you have your practice. Time to start your training, or simply your practice. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2131 | 駅弁 | えきべん | Train Station Bento | Station Bento | Remember how 弁当 is "bento"? Well, the 弁 in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a train station to go along with the bento, you have a train station bento. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

2133 | 火曜日 | かようび | Tuesday |  | This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The fire day of the week is the day after the worst day of the week (monday). You set fire to everything because you're so pissed off about yesterday, which makes today Tuesday. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
2134 | 警告 | けいこく | Warning | Advice\n Caution | When you announce something to warn somebody, you're warning them. Sometimes you're just trying to give them some helpful advice. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2135 | 書き方 | かきかた | Way To Write | How To Write\n Way Of Writing | This is the way of writing (kind of like how 見方 is the way of seeing). So this means way to write or how to write. How's your 書き方 for kanji? Mine is terrible. \n This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 書く and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
2136 | 水曜日 | すいようび | Wednesday |  | This is a day of the week. You know this because it has 曜日 in it. But what day of the week is it? The water day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is Wednesday. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
2137 | 忘年会 | ぼうねんかい | Year End Party | End Of Year Party | Time to get together and forget the year... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a year end party. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2138 | 座禅 | ざぜん | Zen Meditation | Zazen | When you sit and do zen you are probably doing zen meditation. Hummmmm. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2139 | 禅僧 | ぜんそう | Zen Priest |  | A Zen priest is a zen priest. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2140 | 禅寺 | ぜんでら | Zen Temple |  | A zen temple is just what it sounds like, a zen temple. Sounds nice. \n The reading is the two words 禅 and 寺 put together. The てら gets changed to でら, though.\nIn terms of when it's pronounced ぜんじ, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a 禅寺 the pronunciation changes to ぜんじ. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.
2141 | 学歴 | がくれき | Academic History | Academic Background\n Academic Record | A continuation of studying is the time that passes that we study. This is academic history, so pay close attention! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2142 | 形容詞 | けいようし | Adjective |  | A part of speech that creates the shape and form of a word is something that is descriptive (its shape and form are in there, after all!). This shape and form part of speech is an adjective. You are so beautiful! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2143 | 五十音順 | ごじゅうおんじゅん | Aiueo Order | Syllabary Order | This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have fifty sounds. Then, they're in a certain order. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up aiueo order, where the "aiueo" is あいうえお representing the five columns. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2144 | 流石 | さすが | As Expected | Just Like\n Naturally | A stream containing stones is like… the most natural thing ever. It's just as expected.\nNote that you'll encounter this being written in kana as well, but the meaning is the same. \n Unfortunately, the reading for this is a total exception that you'll just have to memorize, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nJust as expected, I saw Suga (さすが) at the bar again last night… Mr. Suga spends a little too much time at the bar, and we're starting to get worried for him. 流石に Mr. Suga…
2145 | 猫舌 | ねこじた | Aversion To Hot Foods |  | A cat's tongue is for some reason associated with an aversion to hot foods. I guess I haven't seen a cat drinking up boiling milk, but whatever. Just imagine a cat licking up something super hot and freaking out. Cats don't like hot things, which is why this is an aversion to hot foods. \n The reading is the two vocab words separately put together, just as you'd expect from a body-part related kanji. So, 猫 plus 舌 = ねこじた. Just remember that 舌 is read here as じた, and not した.
2146 | 焼き芋 | やきいも | Baked Sweet Potato | Roasted Sweet Potato | Baked potato is actually baked sweet potato (or roasted sweet potato). Although it's literally just potato, most Japanese speakers will automatically think of sweet potato when they hear this word. Yum! 🍠 \n The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.
2147 | 信徒 | しんと | Believer | Follower | A junior believer is a believer or follower. They certainly aren't the leader or anything because of their junior status, but at least they're there, and at least they're believing. Oh, and excuse me, may I take a moment of your time? I'd like to tell you about the glory that is the Crabigator.... \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2148 | 得 | とく | Benefit | Profit\n Advantage\n Gain | When you are able to acquire whatever you want, you start to see the benefits of everything around you and begin to profit from them. Aren't you so amazing? \n The reading for this is the same as with the kanji you learned. とく!
2149 | 毛布 | もうふ | Blanket | Wool Blanket | A fur cloth isn't something you'd just throw away. You'd probably turn this warm fur cloth into a nice blanket.\n毛布 usually refers specifically to a wool blanket, as opposed to comforters for example. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2150 | 〜冊 | さつ | Book Counter | Counter For Books | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).
2151 | 仏教徒 | ぶっきょうと | Buddhist |  | You know 仏教 means “Buddhism” so a follower of Buddhism is a Buddhist. \n Add the on’yomi reading for 徒 to the word you already know. Done!
2152 | 多忙 | たぼう | Busy |  | If you've had many busy days, then you're even more busy than you thought! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2153 | 忙しい | いそがしい | Busy |  | This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of busy? It's also busy. \n You're busy because you have to take care of your friend's ice ogres (いそが) this weekend. You don't know why you agreed to this, you were busy enough, but now you'll never get anything done running around taking care of these little ice ogres.
2154 | 年代順 | ねんだいじゅん | Chronological Order |  | You put years in order of the period they come in and you're really putting them in chronological order. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2155 | 布 | ぬの | Cloth | Fabric | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your cloth and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at noon (ぬの) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.
2156 | 混乱 | こんらん | Confusion | Disorder\n Chaos | There's a riot and everything's getting all mixed up! Within that, there is of course a ton of confusion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2157 | 内容 | ないよう | Contents | Substance | Inside that form... there is something inside there. What are the contents? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2158 | 大きい順 | おおきいじゅん | Decreasing Order | Descending Order\n Largest First | When the order is from big (to small), you are talking about decreasing order. That's largest first. \n The reading is the word 大きい plus 順's reading you learned with the kanji.
2159 | 細かい | こまかい | Detailed | Fine\n Small\n Trivial | This is an adjective utilizing the second meaning of 細, detailed. So, this just means detailed or fine!\nYou can remember that this one is "detailed" or "fine" because the かい makes you think of coyotes. Your hobby is making extremely detailed and fine model railroads out of nothing but raw meat. This, however, means that coyotes regularly come in and destroy all of your fine handiwork. \n This word has a different reading from the ones you've learned so far, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAfter the coyote wrecks your model railroad, he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite coma (こま).
2160 | 劇団 | げきだん | Drama Troupe | Theatrical Company | A drama group is a drama troupe or theatrical company. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2161 | 飲酒 | いんしゅ | Drinking Alcohol | Drinking | Drink alcohol is drinking alcohol, or just drinking. This always refers to alcohol though. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading of 飲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhere's a good place for drinking alcohol? An inn (いん), of course!
2162 | 容易 | ようい | Ease | Easily\n Easy\n Simple | The form in front of you is easy. Whatever it is, you'll be able to do it with ease. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2163 | 易しい | やさしい | Easy | Simple To Do | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of easy? It's also easy. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is so easy for you to do. Why? Because you don't do anything yourself. You ask others. You say things like "Hey, can you get me some water?" They say "yassah!" (やさ) very enthusiastically.
2164 | 八冊 | はっさつ | Eight Books | Eight Volumes | When you have eight books you have eight books. This is an example of how to count books, so if you have eight of them this is what you'd say. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はち part gets shortened as it often does when put into situations like this, making it はっ. The 冊 is all normal, and to the "book(s)." Har!
2165 | 非常口 | ひじょうぐち | Emergency Exit |  | You know how 非常 means emergency and how 口 can be some kind of doorway (like in 入り口, for example)? Well, if that's the case, then you have an emergency doorway. Usually you run away from emergencies, though, making this an emergency exit. \n The reading is the words 非常 and 口 combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.
2166 | 入団 | にゅうだん | Enrollment | Joining\n Enlistment | If you enter a group, it's called enrollment or enlistment. You're joining the group. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2167 | 連日 | れんじつ | Every Day | Day After Day\n For Days On End\n Daily\n Prolonged | What happens when you take along a day? It becomes every day. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2168 | 笛 | ふえ | Flute | Whistle | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Pretend you're trying to whistle, but you can't. All that comes out is air. You make a "Fuuuuuuueh" sound over and over, because you can't get the whole whistling thing down. Go ahead and pretend to do that (or do it for real).
2169 | 二枚舌 | にまいじた | Forked Tongue | Duplicity | You have two flat objects that make up your tongue. What kind of tongue is made up of two of anything? That's a tongue that's split, that's a forked tongue. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for the first two kanji, but 舌 actually uses the kun'yomi. Not only that, it's read here as じた, and not した.
2170 | 布団 | ふとん | Futon | Bedding\n Sleeping Mat\n Duvet | Put some cloth in a group and you get a futon. It’s just the kind of nice, soft bedding or sleeping mat you’d like to curl up on.\nKeep in mind that this word is different from the English version. We’re not talking about sofa-beds for your dorm room here. In Japanese, your 布団 is the traditional bedding you lay out on the floor at night and put away in the daytime. 布団 can refer to the sleeping mat, the duvet that covers it, or both items as a set. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 団 is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.

2177 | 小さい順 | ちいさいじゅん | Increasing Order | Ascending Order\n Smallest First | When something goes from small and goes in order it's in increasing order, or smallest first. \n The reading is the word 小さい plus the reading for 順.
2178 | 昆虫 | こんちゅう | Insect | Bug | An insect insect is... you guessed it! An insect. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of the kanji. You learned this reading for 昆 when you learned the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi for 虫 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nDid you know that insects are Chewbacca's (ちゅう) favorite thing? He's fascinated by all types of insects, and keeps them in boxes as pets. There are a good few of them crawling around in his fur, too.
2179 | 自動詞 | じどうし | Intransitive Verb |  | Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb's action happens by itself or to the subject itself, it's an intransitive verb.\nIn other words, it doesn't need a direct object to complete its action. These are verbs like  行く or  着く or  消える. They're doing something, but they're not doing it to anyone or anything. Can you think of other  自動詞 in Japanese? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2180 | いい加減 | いいかげん | Irresponsible | Pointless\n Unfounded\n Careless | You add and you subtract. This brings you back to zero. There was absolutely no point in doing those actions. Completely pointless. In fact, I'd say that was downright irresponsible of you. The extra いい is there to mean "good," as in "good, you've figured out how pointless that was, now stop." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2181 | 求人 | きゅうじん | Job Posting | Seeking Workers | When you're requesting people, you put up a job posting because you’re seeking workers. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nAs you're looking at job postings, you notice they're all looking for people with cucumbers and jeans (きゅうじん). That's the only qualification they're after, cucumbers and jeans.
2182 | 喜び | よろこび | Joy | Delight\n Glee\n Rapture | This is the noun version of the kanji rejoice, so it means joy and delight. You rejoice because there are lots of reasons for your glee. \n You already learned this reading when you learned 喜ぶ so you should be able to read this one too!
2183 | 昆布 | こんぶ | Konbu | Kombu\n Konbu Seaweed\n Kombu Seaweed | Insect cloth is actually konbu. Konbu seaweed is very common in Japan, and it's delicious. And insects happen to love using it as cloth, too. They make all their clothes out of konbu. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 布 part gets changed to ぶ, probably because if a food doesn't have konbu you say boo (ぶ).

Two words coming together like two people coming together. Rawrs.

2198 | 履歴書 | りれきしょ | Personal History | Resume\n Resumé\n Curriculum Vitae\n CV | Think about all the important places your footwear has touched, one place to the next in continuation, and write it all down. What you'd get is a personal history or a resume. I guess you can think of it as a history of the schools and jobs you've left your footprints at. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2199 | 説得 | せっとく | Persuasion | Convince | You acquire theory after theory. In doing this, you have a lot of theories in your head. You use all these theories as tools for persuasion. These theories will allow you to convince anyone of anything. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 説 gets shortened to せっ.
2200 | 梅干し | うめぼし | Pickled Plums | Pickled Ume\n Umeboshi | You know 梅 is a Japanese plum, and 干す means "to dry something." So when you combine them as 梅干し, you get dried plums, right? Well, sort of. You have to pickle them before you dry them, so we can say 梅干し means pickled plum or pickled ume. And if you know the Japanese name, you can call it by that too: umeboshi. \n The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of tricky. It uses two kun'yomi readings that you've learned before. So you have うめ plus ほし, which comes from 干す but gets rendaku'd to ぼし here. In other words, うめぼし. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. But you'll just have to deal with it, because this food is as common as it is tasty!\nAlso, you might often see this written as 梅干, where the し gets shy or something and hides, but the reading stays the same: うめぼし.
2201 | 財閥 | ざいばつ | Plutocrats | Financial Clique\n Zaibatsu | A wealth clan is a group of people who do whatever they can to get their money. These are the plutocrats of the world, but you can also call them financial clique or even the Zaibatsu (sometimes brought up in English language history / economic books regarding Japan). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This time you have someone from the government trying to warn you about the bad things you do. This person, like 警察 is a police officer. It's kind of informal, so you might also say this means cop. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2203 | 警察署 | けいさつしょ | Police Station |  | A government office for police (警察) is a police station, because that's where they hang out, right? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2204 | じゃが芋 | じゃがいも | Potato | White Potato | A じゃが potato is a potato. More specifically, a white potato. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
2205 | 芋 | いも | Potato |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

2208 | 果たして | はたして | Really | As Was Expected\n Just As I Thought\n As Expected | So this doesn't really make much sense in terms of the kanji and word, but it is what it is. Let's remember it this way:\nThe kanji is fruit so the meaning is really? Like, really really? Because it sounds like you made that up. I really doubt it means really.\nIt can also mean as was expected or just as I thought, but usually we use it as a way to say, "Really? I don't really believe you..." \n To remember the reading, just imagine yourself snorting out a sharp "HA!" (は) right before saying the phrase: "HA! Just as I thought."

2227 | 得る | える | To Acquire | To Gain\n To Obtain | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means acquire so the verb vocab version is to acquire. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to acquire an elephant (え) for your elephant collection. If you don't acquire an elephant, you'll look like an idiot in front of your elephant collecting friends.
2228 | 暴れる | あばれる | To Act Violently | To Rage | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means violence. "To violence" doesn't sound great, so instead this word is to act violently or to rage. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to rage all over the place. You're going nuts. You're going to act violently. Then, a calm wizard steps in front of you and mutters "abara kadabara," (あば) causing you to calm down immediately.
2229 | 加える | くわえる | To Add | To Include | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means add and this word is the verb version of that: to add.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning that you are doing the adding to something else. You add a nose to your snowman, for example. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou decide to add something and then to add something else, and you end up with quite a quantity (くわ) of things. 2230 | 外れる | はずれる | To Be Disconnected | To Come Off\n To Be Off | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji 外 means outside, but this word means to be disconnected, to come off, or to be off. It's used when something separates from or comes off of something else. It's intransitive, meaning that it happens on its own. You don't do it, but it just disconnects itself.\nYou already learned 外す, which is used when YOU disconnect something. Like many transitive verbs, that one ends in す. 外れる, on the other hand, means that something disconnects all on its own. To help you remember the difference, imagine yourself walking up a flight of stairs and the rail (れる) coming off in your hand. Oops! You didn't do that, it happened all by itself. \n That rail has はず to be fixed, otherwise it's going to come off again, someone's going to get hurt.
2231 | 乱れる | みだれる | To Be In Disorder | To Be In Disarray\n To Be Disordered\n To Be Disturbed | The kanji means riot, but this verb version word doesn't really mean "to riot." It's more like to be in disorder. But if you think about it, when things are rioting and crazy, they definitely are in disorder, so you can think of it that way. You can differentiate this from the future word 乱す because with れる you know it is rare for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it. \n When everything is in disorder it's finally your chance! You run to the bar, break the windows, and grab all the mead (みだ) you can carry.
2232 | 絡む | からむ | To Be Involved With | To Get Tangled\n To Entwine | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means entangle, but this verb version is usually used in a figurative sense, so it means to be involved with, as in 事件に絡む (to be involved with an incident).\n絡む can still describe something thread-like winding around something else though, like ツタが木に絡む (the ivy twines around the tree), so it also means to get tangled and to entwine. Note that this use is still intransitive because it focuses on the state of things being entwined, and に marks the location of the action, not a direct object.\nTo remember that this is intransitive, imagine suddenly hearing a lot of mooing (む) and turning around to find that your cows have somehow gotten entangled. They're all just suddenly in a knot. HOW?? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThere's an accident you happen to be involved with in karate (から) class, where it's common to get tangled up during sparring. This time you and your partner's limbs are literally in a big entangled mess. Good luck getting out of that.
2233 | 重なる | かさなる | To Be Piled Up | To Coincide\n To Overlap\n To Accumulate | If you remember 重ねる, then you'll recognize this as the intransitive version of that verb. Literally, this means to be piled up, but it's often used to mean to coincide, to overlap or to accumulate.\nAs is often our recommendation for more complicated or hard-to-translate words like this one, check out our common word combinations and context sentences to see how this word is used! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with 重ねる, but in case it's slipped your mind, here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nAll these boxes that are piled up are here because you've just moved into your new casa (かさ). Congratulations! Now it's time to unpack every single box you've accumulated. Have fun.
2234 | 埋める | うめる | To Bury | To Fill | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bury so the verb vocab version is to bury as well.\n埋める can also mean to fill, and can refer to filling a hole, vacancy, or gap. Note that this word can be used to refer to filling in figurative holes and gaps too, like a hole in one’s finances! \n You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!\nHowever, you might notice that in addition to うめる, there's another reading too: うずめる. うめる is used for the act of burying something or filling in a hole, while うずめる is used when describing the covering or concealment of something, or when burying one's face in something (like a fluffy cat!)
2235 | 改める | あらためる | To Change Something | To Revise Something\n To Correct Something\n To Check Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means renew, and this verb's meaning isn't far off. It's transitive, meaning it is done to something. What do you do if you renew something, usually to make it better? You're going to change something, to revise something, or to correct something. This can also mean to check something, like train tickets, or the change you've been given. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWe all want to change something. Probably a lotta (あらた) things! Think about all the things you want to change. Your name? Your habits? Your plans? The rules? The government? I bet you can think of a lotta things you want to change.

2242 | 通じる | つうじる | To Pass Through | To Be Understood | You have pass through, so this is to pass through.\nThis word has a bunch of different meanings, and translations will vary depending on context. In short, it's mostly used figuratively to mean that something, like communication, is passing or coming through successfully. Have a look at our common word combinations and context sentences for some example usages! \n Like other verbs that end in じる, this actually uses the on'yomi of the kanji, not kun'yomi! 2263 | 留守番電話 | るすばんでんわ | Answering Machine |  | You hopefully know that this has something to do with housesitting (留守番). So, a telephone (電話) that does housesitting for you is what? It's your answering machine. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2264 | 人類学 | じんるいがく | Anthropology |  | The study of mankind (人類) is known as anthropology. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2265 | 議論 | ぎろん | Argument | Discussion\n Controversy | There is much deliberation and theory exchanging when you are trying to present an argument. Of course, it's a very nice one. Lots of thinking and stuff, you know? That's why there's deliberation and theories instead of just screaming. That kind of "argument." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2266 | 倒産 | とうさん | Bankruptcy | Go Bankrupt | If someone overthrows your property, it'll end in bankruptcy. Without property you're sure to go bankrupt, unfortunately. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2267 | 血圧 | けつあつ | Blood Pressure |  | Check the pressure of your blood. It's your blood pressure. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2268 | 借り手 | かりて | Borrower | Tenant | Remember how 手 can mean "doer" in some words? So here, you have borrow doer, or more simply borrower.\nThis word is often used to specifically refer to borrowers in contrast to lenders. \n You'll want to know the words 借りる and 手 to be able to read this one. Combine them to know the reading.
2269 | 弓矢 | ゆみや | Bow And Arrow |  | A bow and an arrow. Put them together and you have a bow and arrow. \n The reading is the vocab readings, 弓 and 矢, put together. This is probably because this word is like two separate words put together, thus the "and" in the middle of the English translation.
2270 | お尻 | おしり | Butt | Buttocks\n Bottom | The お is just there to be nice to your butt. This word simply means butt (or any other word for it, like buttocks or bottom). \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2271 | 確かに | たしかに | Certainly | Surely | This is an adverb, but it has the same meaning (basically) as the kanji. It means certainly, and it can also mean surely. \n The reading for this one is certainly weird. To remember the reading for this word, just think how you're certain that if you stash the treasure, nobody will find it here.
2272 | 議長 | ぎちょう | Chairman | Chairperson\n Speaker | The person in charge of long discussions is the chairman, or the speaker. They also say who gets to talk and for how long. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2273 | 会議室 | かいぎしつ | Conference Room | Council Room\n Meeting Room | A room where you meet for discussions is known as a conference room. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2274 | 穴子 | あなご | Conger Eel | Anago | A hole child isn't some kind of creepy hole child (not sure how else to describe it). It's a conger eel, a type of tasty eel eaten in Japan. It might be easier to learn the reading first, though, and use that, because the second meaning option is anago, the Japanese word for it (also used in English). \n The reading is the two kun'yomi vocab readings combined. So, 穴 and 子 to combine make あなご. Just watch out for rendaku, which changes the reading of 子 from こ to ご.
2275 | 喉飴 | のどあめ | Cough Drop | Throat Lozenge | Throat candy is the kind of candy that should make your throat feel better. That's right, it's a cough drop or a throat lozenge. Don't just eat regular candy when your throat hurts! Use the right kind. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
2276 | 夢中 | むちゅう | Crazy About | Absorption\n Frantic | Even in the middle of your dream you're thinking about your body pillows. You're crazy about them, wrapped in absorption.\nAlternatively, this describes doing something frantically, like running away from somebody or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2277 | 犯罪 | はんざい | Crime |  | You have crime and you have guilt. Sounds like you did the crime. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2278 | 犯人 | はんにん | Culprit | Criminal | A crime person is a culprit, or a criminal.\nJust note that 犯人 is mostly used to talk about the culprit of a specific crime, not criminals in general. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2279 | 危機 | きき | Crisis |  | A dangerous machine is walking through your town, destroying everything. This is a huge crisis! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2280 | 非難 | ひなん | Criticism |  | A difficult injustice to take from someone is a criticism. Ugh, what a pain to be criticized! So difficult, and besides, it's an injustice, because I'm perfect! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2281 | 被害 | ひがい | Damage | Harm\n Injury | Incuring damage creates damage,  harm and injury. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2282 | 議会 | ぎかい | Diet | The Diet\n Congress\n Parliament\n Assembly | The place you meet for deliberation in Japan is called the Diet. It's their version of congress. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2283 | 難しい | むずかしい | Difficult | Hard | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of difficult? It's also difficult. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It's awfully difficult to load a cow into your Moo-zooka (むずか). Click. Boom!
2284 | 災い | わざわい | Disaster | Misfortune | This is the noun form of disaster, so it means disaster or misfortune. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThink about how, the last time disaster struck, it was a while (わざわ) before things got back to normal.\nBe careful of the い on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.
2285 | 嫌悪 | けんお | Disgust | Hate\n Repugnance | You dislike someone so badly that it turns to disgust and hate. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 悪 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you feel disgust for someone all you can manage to say when you see them is, "Oh... (お), it's you." Feel the anger when you see their face, "Oh, you again. Bleh."
2286 | 皿洗い | さらあらい | Dishwashing | Doing Dishes\n Washing Dishes | You know the word 皿 (plate) and the word 洗う (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of dishwashing, AKA doing dishes, or washing dishes. \n The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for 皿 and 洗う combined.
2287 | 嫌い | きらい | Dislike | Hate\n Dislikable\n Detestable | You know that 嫌 means dislike and this vocab word means the same thing: dislike or hate!\nThough this word is an adjective in Japanese, it usually makes sense to translate it as a verb in English, because of the difference in sentence structure. However, a more literal translation would be dislikable or detestable. \n Of all the things out there to dislike the thing I dislike the most is the killer (きら) of people. People should never kill people.
2288 | 嫌 | いや | Dislike | Eww\n Gross\n Reluctant | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. The vocab has the added meanings of eww, gross, and even reluctant. \n The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the 嫌い word you will see in this level too. It is いや, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "iyah, I dislike it." Also, think about that eww feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.
2289 | 立入禁止 | たちいりきんし | Do Not Enter | No Entry\n Off-Limits | Standing and entering are both 禁止 (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying do not enter or no entry. \n The reading for 立入 is a bit strange, but it might help you to know that it can also be written 立ち入り. The 立ち is the same one you learned with 立ち飲み and the 入り is the reading you learned with 入り口. In our version of the word, the hiragana isn't visible (it's sort of pushed into the kanji), but the word is still pronounced the same way: たちいり.\nAnd 禁止 doesn't have any weirdness going on, so at least you have that!
2290 | 夢 | ゆめ | Dream |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy dream. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "you may" (ゆめ). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.
2291 | 地震 | じしん | Earthquake |  | An earth earthquake is just another way to say earthquake. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Notice that 地 is read as じ instead of ち. You've seen this happen a few times before, so just try to remember that this is the case here.
2292 | 震災 | しんさい | Earthquake Disaster |  | An earthquake disaster is just that, an earthquake disaster. These are no good. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 災 is the さい reading because *sigh* earthquakes suck man.
2293 | 震度 | しんど | Earthquake Intensity | Seismic Intensity\n Seismic Scale | The earthquake degrees is how you measure an earthquake. The 震度 is the earthquake intensity, AKA earthquake magnitude, seismic intensity, or seismic scale. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2294 | 電子機器 | でんしきき | Electronic Device | Electronic Equipment\n Electronics | You have an electronic (電子) container machine. This is just a machine that contains electricity and electric parts. So basically, an electronic device, or more generally, electronic equipment or electronics.\n電子機器 refers to complex electronic devices like computers, smartphones, medical devices, control systems, and more. So while it can be used to refer to a wide range of electronic devices, it's usually not used for things like simple household appliances like toasters or kettles. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2295 | 最後尾 | さいこうび | End Of A Line |  | You already know that  最後 means "end" so the tail end is the end of a line. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It isn't the same as 最後 though, so watch out for that! It uses the other on'yomi reading you learned with the kanji!

You can't remember! It's become a forgotten item!

It means you can handle things comfortably, without feeling stressed or overwhelmed, whether it's about money, time, or just mentally. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2320 | 鼻の穴 | はなのあな | Nostril | Nose Hole | What's your nose's hole? How about your nostril? \n The reading is the readings for 鼻 and 穴. Smell that fresh air through your nose hole.
2321 | 一個 | いっこ | One Small Thing | One Thing\n One Small Object\n One Object | The counter 個, which means individual on its own, refers to "an individual thing." This is usually a small thing, so it's used to count small things. This word here talks about one individual. A better way to translate that would be to call it one small thing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The いち gets shortened, but I bet you knew that already.
2322 | 音訓 | おんくん | On'yomi And Kun'yomi | Chinese And Japanese Readings | You've seen (hopefully) 音読み and 訓読み. This is a combination of the two. 2323 | 在外 | ざいがい | Overseas | Abroad | When you exist outside (outside of what? Japan, of course), you are overseas or abroad. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2324 | 人達 | ひとたち | People |  | The kanji 達 pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a plural amount of a person you have more than one person, you have people.\nTake note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, あの人達 (those people over there). Other examples: 男の人達, その人達, 向こうの人達, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about. \n The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word 人 and the だち of 友達, though now it's たち because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to touch (たち) people, you perv.
2325 | 比率 | ひりつ | Ratio | Proportion\n Percentage | You compare the percentage, figuring out the ratio or proportion of one thing to another. This can also be expressed as a percentage!\n比率 usually shows up in cases where you compare two numbers with each other, like the number of male and female students in a classroom. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2326 | 個人 | こじん | Personal | Individual | In terms of an individual person... well, that's personal, and depends on the individual. Whatever it is, an individual person has personal tastes, so make sure to think of that. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2327 | 公害 | こうがい | Pollution |  | Public damage is something that affects everyone, the whole public. What is in the air and gets into everything no matter where you are? How about pollution? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2328 | 一夫多妻 | いっぷたさい | Polygamy | Polygyny | One husband, many wives. Sounds a bit sketchy. This is polygamy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 一 gets changed to いっ and the 夫 gets changed to ぷ from ふう for some reason. You can imagine that this is because when you are the type that has many wives, you're probably the type who makes them clean up your poo for you as well.
2329 | 可能性 | かのうせい | Possibility | Likelihood | The possible (可能) range of gender extends beyond two options. It means there's a possibility to identify with many different gender identities. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to be able to read 可能 as well.

2335 | 静々 | しずしず | Quietly | Calmly | Quiet quiet! Do it quietly, please. \n You know how 静か is しずか? Well, this is the same reading as that. Say it in a whisper with me: "しずしず." Shhh!
2336 | 読者 | どくしゃ | Reader |  | The reading someone is someone who is reading. They are the reader (of a book, blog, article, etc). \n The reading for 読 is the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. This reading is どく, and you can remember it by thinking about how you are the reader, and as the reader you choose where to read. For you, the best place to read is a peaceful dock (どく). Sit on the dock and relax. Be the reader.
2337 | 実在 | じつざい | Reality | Real Existence | The truth is that you exist in reality. This is your real existence. Well, that makes sense, I suppose. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2338 | 在留 | ざいりゅう | Residence | Staying In A Foreign Country | Where you exist is the place you're detained. As long as you're in this place, this will be your residence, even if you're staying in a foreign country.\n在留 is an official term used for people residing in a foreign country. You'll find it in phrases like 在留カード (residence card) or 在留外国人 (foreign resident). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2339 | 経路 | けいろ | Route | Course | If you pass through the roads, you are figuring out which roads to use, when to use them, and essentially coming up with the route and course to take to get to wherever you're going. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2340 | 種 | たね | Seed | Source | What kinds of seeds are you going to sow? Think about all the different kinds of seeds, and the kinds of plants they'll grow into.\nThis can also mean source, as in a source of worry or joy, or even of a good story. \n Choose your seeds carefully, because you love to have a tan eh? (たね). You love tanning, so you don't want to plant anything that will grow tall and create shade. Choose those seed types carefully, and don't forget about your tan, eh?
2341 | 自覚 | じかく | Self-Awareness | Realization\n Awareness\n Consciousness | What does self and awake mean in combination? This refers to self-awareness, consciousness of yourself, or a realization.\nWondering about the difference between 意識 and 自覚? 意識 refers to a general state of awareness or consciousness, while 自覚 specifically relates to self-awareness. It implies clearly recognizing one's own actions, abilities, or circumstances, and is often used in contexts relating to personal growth. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2342 | 高等学校 | こうとうがっこう | Senior High School | High School | Remember when you learned that 高等 means "high class" and 学校 means "school?" Well put them together and you have senior high school! It's the most high class school you've got (unless you go to university, but that's considered to be separate).\nFun fact: 高校 is the abbreviation of this word. Neat, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2343 | 指圧 | しあつ | Shiatsu | Finger Pressure | When someone applies finger pressure, they're probably practicing shiatsu.\nShiatsu is an alternative therapy from Japan, which involves applying pressure with the fingertips to specific spots on the body. This word can also refer to any kind of finger pressure, logically enough! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2344 | 罪 | つみ | Sin | Crime | If you have guilt then you have committed a sin or crime. Come here and confess to Father Koichi. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: When you come to confess your sin to me, you start claiming it wasn't you. You say it was some other version of you! What? How could this be? Well, you say "there are two mes (つみ) out there!" One is doing the bad stuff, and the other is you, and you haven't done any sins!
2345 | 煙い | けむい | Smoky |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of smoke? It's smoky. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You sort of did learn this reading with the vocabulary word 煙, but this one is just different enough where we thought we should make a mnemonic for this one:\nAll this smokiness is from a terrible chemical (けむ) spill that happened nearby. It was acid, so it burned everything up real good, causing the air to get pretty smoky.
2346 | 臭い | くさい | Stinky | Stinking\n Smelly | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stinking? It's also stinking (or stinky). \n The reading you learned with the kanji can be used here, too.
2347 | 嫌疑 | けんぎ | Suspicion |  | I dislike him and I have doubts about him. I therefore have much suspicion against him as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2348 | 尾 | お | Tail |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou look down and you've sprouted a tail! You're so shocked that all you can say is "Oh. (お) Oh okay..." This your life now. A life with a tail.
2349 | 理論 | りろん | Theory |  | You have reason behind your theory, making it a real theory (unlike those that don't have reason, I guess?). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2350 | 論文 | ろんぶん | Thesis | Paper\n Article\n Essay | A writing of your theory is usually a thesis. Remember how school teachers always wanted you to present theories in writing? And to make sure you have a thesis in that paper? I do. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2351 | 厚い | あつい | Thick |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of thick? Also thick.\nThis is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No thick books needed to understand this reading, yeah?
2352 | 三個 | さんこ | Three Small Things | Three Things\n Three Objects\n Three Small Objects | Three individuals is three small things. The kanji 個 can be used to count small objects, just like this! Try other numbers as well. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2353 | 産まれる | うまれる | To Be Born |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. That means that it just happens, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means to be born. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nYou know another word that means "to be born" (生まれる), and they both have the same reading!
2354 | 困る | こまる | To Be Distressed | To Be Troubled\n To Be Perplexed\n To Be Annoyed | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distressed and troubled. The verb versions of those are to be distressed and to be troubled. \n If someone seems to be distressed maybe someone they know is in a coma (こま). Not too many things are more distressing and troubling than that.
2355 | 無くなる | なくなる | To Be Gone | To Run Out\n To Be Lost\n To Disappear | Here we have nothing, followed by the verb なる. A verb that means "become nothing"? That'll be to be gone, to run out, to be lost, or to disappear.\nThis can be translated in various ways depending on the situation, but just remember that it always refers to something changing from being there, to not being there. \n This uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned with 無し, so you should be good to go.
2356 | 余る | あまる | To Be In Surplus | To Remain Left Over\n To Be In Excess | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surplus so the verb version would be to be in surplus, to remain left over, or to be in excess. Too much! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "I have a surplus of kittens from that last batch we made, Reddit. AMA (ask me anything, あま)."
2357 | 改まる | あらたまる | To Be Renewed | To Be Formal\n To Be Altered\n To Be Revised | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means renew so the verb vocab version is to be renewed. Like most verbs ending in まる, this is an intransitive verb, meaning it happens all on its own. Nobody is doing the renewing, it's just happening (as renewing often does). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You probably learned this reading with this verb's transitive other half 改める, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case:\nTo be renewed you decide to go to a spa. You get in a bathtub and they pour in a lotta (あらた) leeches and eels to help you to be renewed. Feel the fear. There are a lot of them! Alternatively, you can imagine them pouring in a lotta Maru cats, because that's way fuzzier.
2358 | 築く | きずく | To Build Something | To Construct Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means construct and the verb version is to build something or to construct something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to build something called a key zoo (きず). Which is a zoo for keys instead of animals. So it's a bunch of keys in cages, basically. Hmm, how artsy of you... Hopefully people get it. Isn't it a bit avant-garde to construct something like a key zoo?
2359 | 閉じる | とじる | To Close Something | To Close | Another verb version of the kanji 閉! This is a special one that can be either transitive or intransitive, so 閉じる means to close something or to close.\n閉じる is for returning things that have expanded open back to their closed state. It's used for books, umbrellas, web browsers, and even eyes and mouths. There are some overlaps with 閉める (you can 閉じる or 閉める a gate, for example) but 閉める is mostly used for things like doors, windows, and curtains. \n The reading is different from 閉める or 閉まる. Instead, 閉じる is read とじる.\nWhy? Because to close something that's expanded or spread open, you always use your toe (と)! It's easy enough with books, but umbrellas are a real challenge… But you, you can do it! You have the toe-tal control and can close anything expanded to the way it was before.
2360 | 犯す | おかす | To Commit A Crime | To Make A Mistake | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crime and the verb vocab version can mean to commit a crime, to make a mistake, or to rape, depending on the context. \n You go to commit a crime. How did it go, you think? Well, I thought it went okay (おか). Imagine yourself committing a crime and it going just okay. Not great, not bad... meh. Okay.
2361 | 繋ぐ | つなぐ | To Connect Something | To Tie Something To\n To Maintain Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means connect, and this verb means to connect something or to tie something to something else. Like connect people, hold hands, connect a cable to a charger, etc.\nFiguratively, when you want to connect something over time, like a conversation, then you want to maintain something over time as well. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you already know from the kanji.
2362 | 防ぐ | ふせぐ | To Defend Against | To Protect Against\n To Prevent | You're doing a prevention. When you prevent something, what are you really doing? You're trying to defend against something from happening. That's why this verb is a little weird and means to defend or to protect against. It can also be to prevent, too, but just make sure you're thinking of it more like you're defending something with your prevention. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to defend against the enemy? You should probably put out that fuse (ふせ) attached to that giant bomb first then.
2363 | 飛ぶ | とぶ | To Fly | To Jump | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fly, and the verb vocab version is also to fly. In addition to flying, the verb also means to jump. Just think of jumping as being some sort of... smaller version of flying, and this'll make sense. \n When you try to fly, the main thing holding you back is your toe (と). It's like forty pounds and holds you down.
2364 | 焼ける | やける | To Get Baked | To Get Burnt\n To Get Grilled | Remember how 焼く is "to bake," "to burn something," or "to grill"? 焼ける is just the intransitive version. That means no direct object needed! So this verb means to get baked, to get burned, or to get grilled.\n焼ける is used when something is heated and transformed by the heat. Depending on the context, it can refer to anything from a muffin getting baked, fish being grilled, or pottery being fired. You can even use it when your skin gets a tan or a house burns down. Well, that last one is kinda sad. I hope it never happens.\nYou can distinguish 焼ける from 焼く because when cooking, you always care (ける) to ensure the food gets baked or grilled really well. You want to make sure it's properly 焼ける'd (heated through) to be safe! \n The reading is the same as 焼く, so just use that knowledge and apply it here to be able to read this too.
2365 | 混ざる | まざる | To Get Mixed | To Be Mixed\n To Be Blended With | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mix so the verb vocab version is to get mixed or to be mixed. This is when something is just getting mixed and you're not directly doing the action of mixing anything. You can remember this because the Tzar (ざる) of Russia is very impressed that things mix on their own and you're not doing the mixing.\nThe connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're not doing the mixing, in order for things to get mixed you call your ma (ま) up and ask her to mix it. What a terrible lazy child you are.
2366 | 倒す | たおす | To Knock Over | To Knock Down\n To Bring Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means overthrow or collapse, and this verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in す, so you are doing those things to something else. So, this verb means things like to knock over, to knock down, and to bring down.\nThis word can be used to talk about physically knocking something over, as well as bringing something or someone down, like a government. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You use the power of the Tao (たお) to do all of your knocking down. Imagine yourself contemplating Tao philosophy, then using those pleasant thoughts to knock everything over around you. BLAM!
2367 | 被る | かぶる | To Put On | To Wear\n To Cover Oneself With | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You learned this kanji as "incur," but it can also mean cover. So 被る means to put on, to wear, or to cover oneself with.\n被る is used when you wear things that cover your head or face, like hats, helmets, and masks, or when cover yourself with something, like pulling a blanket over yourself.\nFiguratively, 被る can mean taking on a burden or blame, like you're "covering" yourself with responsibility. It can also refer to overlapping events — think of it like one event "covering" another on a timeline. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe hat you want to put on is way too heavy for you. It falls off your head and hits the ground with a loud KABOOM (かぶ). You try to wear the hat again and pull it down tight, but this time it pulls you to the ground with an even louder KABOOM!
2368 | 刺す | さす | To Stab | To Pierce\n To Sting | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version is to stab.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning that you are the one doing the stabbing... should I be afraid of you? 😅 \n The reading you learned for this kanji is the kun'yomi one. Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Guess what? That means you already know it!\nBut in case you've already forgot the reading, here's a mnemonic to refresh your memory:\nIf you're going to stab someone, use a saw (さ). It may seem more difficult to stab them with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize saws are the ideal stabbing tool.
2369 | 面倒 | めんどう | Trouble | Difficulty | When you're looking straight into the face of a collapse it means trouble and difficulty coming soon. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The とう goes to どう, though. Agh, what a 面倒.
2370 | 余計 | よけい | Unneeded | More Than Needed\n Too Much | The surplus is measured and it's all unneeded. Yeah, it's definitely more than needed. Maybe we should get rid of all this surplus?\n余計 usually carries a negative connotation, meaning there's too much of something, or it's not needed and could be left out. It could be too many things, or unnecessary words or actions it would be better not to say or do. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You learned this reading for 経 with the kanji, and you learned this reading for 由 with the word 由来. Wherever it is you're going via, you can't go wrong if you stay in a yurt.

If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
