2396 | いい加減にしろ | いいかげんにしろ | Cut It Out | Cut The Bs\n That's Enough | You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you add and then decrease you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to cut it out or cut the BS! \n The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.
2397 | 定義 | ていぎ | Definition |  | Please determine what righteousness means. I want the definition for it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2398 | 飲酒運転 | いんしゅうんてん | Drunk Driving | Drinking And Driving | You know that 飲酒 is "drinking alcohol" and 運転する is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means drunk driving, or drinking and driving. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2399 | 任務 | にんむ | Duty | Task\n Mission | You have a duty. You have a task. You have both a duty and a task to do. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2400 | 経済 | けいざい | Economy | Economics\n The Economy | When a passage of time comes to an end, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all economics, baby (that's money, baby!). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.
2401 | 選挙 | せんきょ | Election |  | You have to choose someone and raise them up to office. This is an election. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2402 | 敵 | てき | Enemy |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nてき and かたき, however, have slightly different nuances. てき simply means “enemy”, whereas かたき typically refers to someone you hold a deep grudge against, often on behalf of another. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. No enemies here!
2403 | 羨望 | せんぼう | Envy | Jealousy | Envy consumes your hope turning it all to envy and jealousy. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
2404 | 解説 | かいせつ | Explanation | Commentary | When you untie a theory for someone, you're taking it apart and making it more understandable to them. You are doing an explanation of something for them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2405 | 外れ | はずれ | Extremity | Furthest Point\n End\n Outskirts\n Outer Limits\n Edge\n Miss\n Failure | The kanji 外 alone means "outside." This word means extremity. How can you remember this? Just think of the れ as a "ray of sunshine." Where you are, in the extremity of space, even the れs of the sun cannot be seen. So, when 外 is combined with れ just think of this. \n Let's continue the previous story: You're off in the extremity of space and your friend is running low on Vitamin D. He has (はず) to get some sun れs on his skin! How's that supposed to happen with those spacesuits on, though?
2406 | 履き物 | はきもの | Footwear | Shoes | Remember how 履く is "to put on shoes" and 物 means "thing"? Well, combine them and you have a word for things you put on your feet, a.k.a. footwear or shoes.\nYou might know that 履く is used for lots of different clothes you wear below the waist, but be careful: 履き物 only refers to footwear and shoes. \n The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.
2407 | 資金 | しきん | Funds |  | The resources of gold that we have are our current funds.\n資金 is specifically for monetary funds, not other types of assets. That 金 kanji can mean money, so it should be easy to remember. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2408 | 立派 | りっぱ | High Class | Splendid\n Admirable | The sect that stands the highest are those who are high class, splendid, and fine. 立派だ! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.
2409 | 人権 | じんけん | Human Rights |  | People Rights are human rights. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

It's an incident or case.\n事件 often refers to significant or serious occurrences like crime cases or accidents. It can also be used playfully — "There was a 事件 at the party!" — to dramatize an event like someone asking out your classmate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

2420 | 〜務省 | むしょう | Ministry Of |  | Let us conserve our tasks. We will give it to the Ministry Of Tasks! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2421 | 形容動詞 | けいようどうし | Na Adjective |  | A 形容詞 is an adjective. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a na adjective. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say nah, I don't care about this anymore. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.

2423 | 事務所 | じむしょ | Office |  | When the occurrence of your tasks is in the same place every day, that place is probably an office.\n事務所 is often for office spaces that handle back-office 事務 (administrative or clerical work). It can also be used for offices that offer more specialized services, like a 会計事務所 (accounting firm) or 芸能事務所 (talent agency). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2424 | 岡山県 | おかやまけん | Okayama Prefecture |  | Okayama (岡山) Prefecture is a prefecture in Japan. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!
2425 | 判子 | はんこ | One's Seal | Seal\n Personal Seal | The child of a judge is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? You just have to remember to use it here.

2434 | 資格 | しかく | Qualifications | Capabilities\n Requirements | The credible resources that determine your professional status are your qualifications. 2435 | 素材 | そざい | Raw Material | Material\n Ingredient | When you want to use the most basic elements of a material, you end up with raw materials. Maybe it's the raw materials you're going to use to build a house. Maybe it's the raw materials you need to make a good soup. Either way, they haven't been touched much (yet). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to sew the building together using these raw materials.
2436 | 反省 | はんせい | Reconsideration | Reflection\n Regret | If you're anti conserve, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy reconsideration and reflection, and see if that's really the right way to be. If you change your thinking, you might even end up showing regret. \n The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nI'm standing in front of you, forcing a reconsideration of your anti conserve stance, with my saber (せい) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.
2437 | 責任 | せきにん | Responsibility |  | You can blame duty all you want, but you still have a responsibility as well, no matter what your duty dictates. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2438 | 刺身 | さしみ | Sashimi |  | Remember how 身 can mean "animal flesh"? Well, when you stab some animal flesh and eat it raw, you're having sashimi. Yum! \n The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.
2439 | 自制 | じせい | Self Control | Self Restraint | Self control is self control and self restraint. Have some! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2440 | 義理 | ぎり | Sense Of Duty | Social Obligation\n In-Law | You have righteousness and then a reason behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your sense of duty. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.\nThis word can also mean in-law like your mother-in-law, because they're your mother in the social obligation sense only, not by blood. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2441 | 派手 | はで | Showy | Flashy\n Gaudy | This is a weird one. Just think about the sect of hands. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all showy and flashy. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.
2442 | 際 | きわ | Side | Edge\n Brink | Even though the kanji mainly means  occasion, for some reason this word means side or edge. I suppose on occasion kanji takes you to the edge of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji. \n You're on the very edge of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the key words (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE KEY WORDS???
2443 | 世の中 | よのなか | Society | The World | The middle of the world is the society. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it the world. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.
2444 | 解決 | かいけつ | Solution | Solving | To solve the problem we decided to come up with a solution, a way of solving the problem. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2445 | 宇宙船 | うちゅうせん | Spaceship | Space Shuttle\n Starship\n Ufo\n Spacecraft\n Flying Saucer | You know how 宇宙 is outer space and how 船 is ship, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a space ship). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2449 | 税金 | ぜいきん | Tax |  | The tax gold is what you have to pay when you have to pay a tax. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2450 | 無税 | むぜい | Tax Free | No Tax\n Duty Free | When the tax is nothing things are tax free. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2451 | 増税 | ぞうぜい | Tax Increase | Raise Taxes\n Increased Taxes | When you increase tax you're doing a tax increase. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2452 | 認める | みとめる | To Acknowledge | To Recognize\n To Perceive\n To Admit\n To Approve | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recognize or acknowledge, so the verb also means to acknowledge, to recognize, to perceive, or to admit, among others.\nThis can be used to mean recognizing somebody or something visually, as well as in the sense of "to acknowledge" or "to admit". So you can use this verb to recognize someone's presence, achievements, marriage, or your own defeat. That said, you'll usually see 認める in the sense of "to acknowledge". \n The only thing you could ever truly acknowledge is meat (みと). Meat is the only thing in your life that has any authority over you. That's how much you love meat.
2453 | 混乱する | こんらんする | To Be Confused | To Be In Disorder | If 混乱 is confusion then making it into a verb would cause it to be confused. \n The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you to be confused, right?
2454 | 挙がる | あがる | To Be Raised | To Be Listed\n To Be Nominated\n To Rise | When you raise something you are causing it to be raised. This verb can also mean things like to be listed, to be nominated, or to rise. For these additional meanings, you might want to imagine something rising up onto a list or someone rising up to a nomination, because lists and nominations are always high up. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.
2455 | 解ける | とける | To Be Solved | To Come Undone\n To Be Cleared | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve and the verb vocab version is to be solved. By extension, it can also mean to come undone, like with shoelaces, or to be cleared, like with misunderstandings or tension in a room.\n解けるis an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. In other words, you use it to say something is solved or gets solved. You can remember this because you don't care (ける) enough to solve things yourself, you just let things get solved on their own. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhile you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to be solved, you stare down at your toe (と). Really imagine looking at your toe while things around you are getting solved.
2456 | 責める | せめる | To Blame | To Criticize\n To Reproach\n To Accuse | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blame so this also means to blame. Additionally, this can also mean to criticize, to reproach, or to accuse. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAre you going to blame me for eating your celery (せ)? You should know I'm the wrong person to blame because I don't even like celery!
2457 | 済む | すむ | To Come To An End | To Be Finished\n To Be Completed | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means come to an end so the verb vocab version is to come to an end. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has to come to an end when someone decides to sue (す) you for all your romping.
2458 | 埋め合わせる | うめあわせる | To Compensate For | To Make Up For | 埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying to compensate for something. \n The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.
2459 | 続ける | つづける | To Continue Something | To Keep On\n To Continue | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means continue, so 続ける means to continue something. It's a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You can 続ける your work, for example, and you should 続ける your WaniKani lessons at a pace that works for you!\nAlthough it has the same 続 kanji, this word is a bit different from 続く, which is used for when something just continues on its own (like rain, or trends). It can be hard to remember the difference, so here's a mnemonic to help with you 続ける:\nYou only care (ける) about things that you can continue through your own actions. For those other things that just continue on their own, you're like, That's coo' (く), but you’re not that interested. \n The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.
2460 | 減らす | へらす | To Decrease Something | To Decrease\n To Reduce\n To Reduce Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decrease so the verb vocab version is to decrease something. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The rush (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins. \n The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.
2461 | 羨む | うらやむ | To Envy | To Be Envious Of\n To Be Jealous Of | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means envy so the verb version is to envy someone. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're really starting to envy those uranium Yankees (うらや). That's the new Yankees team hopped up on uranium that were created in a lab. Even though they're gross and hulk-ish, they're really good at baseball, so you're jealous of them.
2462 | 設ける | もうける | To Establish | To Set Up | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means establish so the verb vocab version is to establish, or to set up.\n設ける is a formal word that suggests setting up something in order to prep for future needs or events. If you want to ensure smooth operation or governance, for example, you might set up rules (ルールを設ける) or establish an office (オフィスを設ける). You can even use it to say you’ll arrange a drinking party (酒の席を設ける), in which case it probably means the party has a more formal purpose like networking or discussion. \n What are you going to establish? How about a system for mowing (もう) lawns? It's very important that lawns are mowed according to an established system, you know. How do you mow yours?
2463 | 苛々する | いらいらする | To Get Irritated | To Get Annoyed\n To Grow Impatient | Double frustration would cause anyone to get irritated, to get annoyed, or to grow impatient. \n This isn’t the reading you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou don’t just get irritated, you get ira-ira-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated.\nThis word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!
2464 | 無くす | なくす | To Get Rid Of Something | To Do Away With Something\n To Lose Something | This word ends with a う sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means nothing, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to to get rid of something, to do away with something or to lose something.\nThis verb is transitive, so the action is happening to something. So maybe you're getting rid of debt, or discrimination, or stress... Whatever it is, there's a direct object with this verb! \n This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word 無し.
2465 | 産む | うむ | To Give Birth |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give birth so the verb vocab version is to give birth.\nYou know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know. \n You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!
2466 | 増える | ふえる | To Increase |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means increase, so the vocabulary verb version means to increase. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to err (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).\nThis is an everyday word that refers to an increase in number or quantity, but keep in mind that it cannot be used to express an increase in degree. \n It would be foolish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.
2467 | 検問する | けんもんする | To Inspect | To Examine\n To Check | You examine the problem. In order to do this, you need to inspect it or to examine it. And if you're inspecting people like this, you're probably the police. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2468 | 立ち去る | たちさる | To Leave | To Walk Away\n To Depart | You 立ち and then 去る. Makes sense, as in order to leave, you'll have to stand up first. \n This combines the readings of two verbs you already know, so you should be good to go here!
2469 | 省く | はぶく | To Omit | To Eliminate\n To Skip\n To Leave Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conserve... but why stop there when you could try to omit everything and to eliminate everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else. \n You have (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.
2470 | 参加する | さんかする | To Participate |  | You know how 参加 is participation? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself to participate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.
2471 | 説得する | せっとくする | To Persuade | To Convince | You know that 説得 is persuasion, so what is the verb version of that? To persuade. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.
2472 | 企てる | くわだてる | To Plan | To Scheme\n To Attempt | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plan so the verb vocab version is to plan. \n You say you have something you need to plan? Cool, whaddaya (くわだ) gonna do?
2473 | 祈る | いのる | To Pray For |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pray and this verb is transitive, so it means to pray for. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray for Christmas presents if you want Santa to bring you some!" "I know (いの), I know," you reply as you begin to pray for presents. You should say this out loud to remember it better.
2474 | 乱す | みだす | To Put In Disorder | To Throw Out Of Order\n To Disturb | You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going to put in disorder, to throw out of order, or to disturb whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to sue (す) you for your actions. \n The reading is the same as 乱れる, so hopefully you know it already.
2475 | 断る | ことわる | To Refuse | To Reject | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going to refuse them whatever it is they want. \n Deciding to refuse something unfortunately starts a coat war (like a pillow fight, but everyone hits each other with coats instead of pillows). Coats to the ready, and let the coat war commence!
2476 | 設定する | せっていする | To Set | To Set Up | What do you establish and determine in your every day life? A setting. When you make that into a verb, you have the word to set, as in setting the temperature of the AC, setting your password, or setting your computer to dark mode.\n設定する is a little formal, but does get commonly used for device, system, and game settings. It's also often used in more official contexts, like for setting prices for products or establishing project goals. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.
2477 | 目覚める | めざめる | To Wake Up | To Awaken | If your eyes are awake then you're going to wake up. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know?\nThis word can also mean to awaken but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 覚 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you start to wake up in the middle of the night, it's because of the wake up wizard (ざ). He sneaks into your house when you're sleeping and pokes you with his wand. Wizards like when you wake up. They're weird.
2478 | 務める | つとめる | To Work As | To Serve As\n To Be Employed As | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means task so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going to work as or to serve as something to do that task. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo work as my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me two toes (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want to serve as my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!
2479 | 他動詞 | たどうし | Transitive Verb |  | Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb is done to some other thing, it's a transitive verb.\nThat means it takes a direct object. Verbs like 食べる, 使う, and 上げる are transitive verbs because they need a direct object, an "other" thing, to receive their action. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

2482 | 無敵 | むてき | Unrivaled | Invincible | You have nothing when it comes to enemies. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are unrivaled and invincible. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2483 | 口笛 | くちぶえ | Whistling |  | A mouth flute... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By whistling. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.

2488 | 建築 | けんちく | Architecture | Construction | When it comes to building and constructing, the thing that encompasses both of them is architecture.\n建築 refers to the design and construction of buildings. Occasionally it can also refer to a physical building itself, but for that it's more common to use 建築物. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2489 | 反応 | はんのう | A Reaction | Reaction\n A Response\n Response | Whoops, this one comes out weird. You have anti respond though the meaning of this word is a reaction. Maybe you're "anti respond" but you have no choice, you have to give a response despite that fact? \n The 反 reading is all good and merry, but the 応 reading gets a bit wonky, turning おう into のう. This is probably because it's just way easier to say はんのう and sounds basically the same too. So, はんおう goes to はんのう and everyone's happy. Do you have a response?

2493 | 赤ん坊 | あかんぼう | Baby | Infant | Here's a weird one for you. You have a red monk. What is this? It's a baby. Think about it. Babies, when they come out, are all red. Also, they have a shaved head, just like a monk would. So, a "red monk" is really just a baby. I wonder who's getting the shorter end of the stick here, the monk or the baby? Probably the monk. \n The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of 赤 (you learned this with the kanji) and the reading you learned for 坊 as well.

2508 | 大勢 | おおぜい | Crowd | A Large Number | A large force is a group of people. Just think about when this word was probably made up... a long time ago, and the biggest force you could have was a huge group of people. This group of people force is also known as a crowd, or a large number of people. \n The reading for 大 is the おお reading (like 大きい). Nothing you can do about that but remember it. Then, 勢 is rendaku'd to become ぜい. Also something you'll just have to remember. Say this word a few times in your head, then you'll be able to come up with an idea of what sounds right and what sounds wrong so that you can figure it out next time this word comes up.

Don't confuse this with 各々 though. That one does use the kun'yomi reading, which is strange when you consider this one doesn't. Every kanji has its own "perks" I suppose.

Its translation varies based on context and can include to some extent, more or less, or just in case. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2529 | 宮 | みや | Imperial Palace | Imperial Family | This Shinto shrine you're visiting? Turns out if you go inside it's magically turned into the imperial palace. Wow! Feels like I’m a member of the imperial family now.\n宮 is a historical word that generally refers to Japanese imperial palaces, the Japanese imperial family, or the imperial family members. Depending on the context, it can also refer to a Shinto shrine or its buildings. \n The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.
2530 | 不可能 | ふかのう | Impossible | Not Possible | You already know how 可能 means possible. So when you add not it becomes impossible. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 可能 first as well.
2531 | 産業 | さんぎょう | Industry | Heavy Industry | What will give birth to business? Well, some kind of industry, probably. Though heavy industry is pretty good too. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2532 | 勢力 | せいりょく | Influence | Force | Your force and power combine together to create an influence (or a force). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2533 | 指示 | しじ | Instructions | Directions\n Advice | Use your finger to indicate some things. These are your instructions. Okay, do this (point), do that (point), and then finally do this (point). \n The readings are the on'yomi readings. You've learned them both already, good for you!
2534 | 寝不足 | ねぶそく | Lack Of Sleep |  | Remember how 不足 is a physical shortage? Well, now you have a physical shortage of sleep. That's a lack of sleep. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. However, the first kanji 寝 actually uses its kun'yomi ね. 不足 is on'yomi as you'd expect, but the ふ in 不 changes to ぶ, so hopefully you've been getting enough sleep.
2535 | 地価 | ちか | Land Value |  | The ground's value is the land value. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2536 | 素敵 | すてき | Lovely | Dreamy\n Beautiful | The element of enemy isn't something you should think of as bad. You have to have the "enemy element" if you are to have lovely, dreamy, and beautiful things too. This is a good word when you're talking about some dude you think is hawt. Doesn't work as well with girls. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 素 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nOh wow, you look really lovely in that suit (す). Yes, I can see you through the Internet, and I have to say, that suit is just dreamy! Don't ever take it off.
2537 | 坊さん | ぼうさん | Monk |  | さん is what you put on people's names. It's like "Mr." sort of. So a "Mr. monk" is a monk. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. ぼうさん！
2538 | 昼寝 | ひるね | Nap |  | A noon sleep is sleep you do during the day, also known as a nap. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
2539 | 新築 | しんちく | Newly Built | New Building\n New Construction | Something that's newly constructed is something that's newly built. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2540 | 年賀状 | ねんがじょう | New Year's Card | New Year's Greeting Card | A year congratulations condition is when you tell the world about your condition for the new year. What's a better way to tell them than by using a New Year's Card? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2541 | 脱字 | だつじ | Omitted Character | Omitted Letter | You've got an escaped letter, in other words, an omitted character or omitted letter. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2542 | 態と | わざと | On Purpose | Deliberately\n Intentionally | So this doesn't quite make sense in terms of the meaning of the kanji... but you'll be okay. This means on purpose. Perhaps when you do something that has the appearance of doing what you wanted to do, you're doing it on purpose.\n態と is usually written in kana in modern writing, but you'll occasionally see it in kanji too. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You did that to me on purpose? Whazapp with that?"
2543 | 機会 | きかい | Opportunity | Chance | When the machines meet, you finally have the opportunity to take them all out at once. DIE MACHINES! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2544 | 寝坊 | ねぼう | Oversleeping | Late Riser | You sleep like a monk, as in you never stop sleeping (because you sleep while you meditate). When you sleep like a monk like this you're constantly oversleeping, probably because you're up late doing sutras or something. You're a late riser. \n These are the readings you learned with the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2545 | 過去 | かこ | Past | The Past | If you surpass the past then you're going backwards in time (at least if you're coming from the "present"). If this is the case, then you are definitely in the past. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But 去 has two on'yomi readings and you haven't seen this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nIn the past, you were a 子 (こ). You're not really a 子 anymore, but in the past you definitely used to be a 子!
2546 | 罰 | ばつ | Penalty | Punishment | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji... and you thought I was about to punish you because it was a single kanji vocab word. Now get over here. Time for a dirty spanking for thinking such a thing.
2547 | 変態 | へんたい | Pervert | Abnormal\n Transformation\n Metamorphosis | Your appearance is strange. You're abnormal. Oh, and you're a pervert because you look so abnormal. Though you could just be a caterpillar going through your metamorphosis to become a butterfly. You just look really weird while the changing is going on. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2548 | 政策 | せいさく | Policy | A Policy | A plan made by the government is usually known as a policy. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

2551 | 大統領 | だいとうりょう | President |  | When you big rule over a territory, you're probably a pretty great leader. A president, perhaps? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well
2552 | 価格 | かかく | Price | Value\n Cost | When you value status you really care about the price of things. And usually the higher the value, the higher the cost.\n価格 refers to something's market value, or to product pricing in a broader sense. It's sort of a formal word, so you might see it on fliers or in business and economic discussions about pricing strategies, for example. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2553 | 物価 | ぶっか | Prices | Prices of Commodities\n Cost Of Living | Things with value have prices.\n物価 refers to the prices of goods and services in a place — the prices of commodities, a.k.a. the cost of living. It's used when discussing how expensive it is to live somewhere or when talking about inflation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぶつ changes to ぶっ, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.

If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

2564 | 袖 | そで | Sleeve |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so you should be good to go!
2565 | お土産 | おみやげ | Souvenir | Present | Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some dirt and bring it back with you. Then pretend to give birth to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special souvenir! It's the best present you could ever give someone! \n These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.
2566 | 待機 | たいき | Standby | On Call | A waiting machine is a machine on standby.  This word doesn’t always apply to machines though. It could be a person who’s on standby, in which case you might also say they’re on call. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2567 | 主観 | しゅかん | Subjective View | Subjective Opinion\n Subjective | What is your main view? Your subjective view, of course! This can be your own subjective opinion, and also refers to the idea of the subjective in general (as opposed to the objective). It can be hard to step back and look at things without your own unique biases and perspectives. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

2570 | 応援 | おうえん | Support | Root For\n Aid | You must respond with aid in order to show your support for someone who needs it. 2571 | 支援 | しえん | Support |  | To support and aid is to support. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2572 | 尻尾 | しっぽ | Tail |  | Your butt tail is just your tail, though I wonder why they had to specify that it was your butt tail. Where else do you have a tail, I wonder? \n The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for 尻 from the kun'yomi しり you learned already. Here it gets shortened to しっ. The reading for 尾 is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe animal with the best tail in the world is the polar (ぽ) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!
2573 | 領土 | りょうど | Territory |  | The soil that makes up your territory is your territory. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2574 | 有り難う | ありがとう | Thank You | Thanks | Some people have a difficult time saying thank you. But not you now that you know how!\nThis is often written in kana, so you don't need to use the kanji when writing. But you'll sometimes see the kanji used so it's important to be able to recognize them! Did you know this is an abbreviation of 有難うございます? You can also spell it like this: 有難う. \n You've heard people say ありがとう before right?!
2575 | 混む | こむ | To Be Crowded | To Be Packed | This one is a little strange. You have 混じる (to get mixed up in), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混む, to be crowded. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other 混 words? Just think of how cows muuuuu (む) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded. \n Hey, come (こむ) out of that crowd of cows. It's going to be crowded in there.
2576 | 刺さる | ささる | To Be Pierced | To Get Pricked\n To Be Stabbed | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb, meaning that the piercing just happens, without emphasis on what makes it happen. That's why this verb means to be pierced, to get pricked, or to be stabbed. This is a tricky one because the English translations often end up being transitive, but in Japanese we always use this with the particle に, not を, so it's intransitive. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 刺す.
2577 | 非難する | ひなんする | To Criticize | To Blame | Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.
2578 | 検査する | けんさする | To Examine | To Inspect\n To Check | You know that 検査 is inspection, so the verb version of that would be to inspect. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 検査 already as well.
2579 | 存在する | そんざいする | To Exist |  | Know how 存在 is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2580 | 倒れる | たおれる | To Get Knocked Over | To Get Knocked Down\n To Collapse | You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself. \n The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.
2581 | 諦める | あきらめる | To Give Up | To Abandon | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give up or abandon so the verb version is to give up or to abandon. \n You hopefully learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder just in case:\nJust before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!". You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!
2582 | お手洗い | おてあらい | Toilet | Restroom\n Bathroom\n Lavatory | You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poop goes there. \n The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!
2583 | 示す | しめす | To Indicate | To Show Something\n To Demonstrate | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This is used in contexts like "a study shows that learning Japanese is fun" and "I demonstrated my willingness to learn kanji". \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nStudies seem to indicate and to show that sheep men (しめ) are better than regular men in every way. The sheep/man combo is a powerful thing. Or so studies indicate.
2584 | 判断する | はんだんする | To Judge | To Conclude | 判断 is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have to judge, or to conclude. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 判断 before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).
2585 | 飛ばす | とばす | To Let Something Fly | To Send Something Flying\n To Skip Over Something | Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let something fly or to send something flying. It also means to skip over something, such as someone's turn or a question on a test. \n The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part:\nYou can use your strength to let something fly, and that something is a bus (ばす). You're that buff!
2586 | 確かめる | たしかめる | To Make Sure Of | To Verify\n To Confirm | Like with 確か, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something. \n This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!
2587 | 圧倒する | あっとうする | To Overwhelm |  | The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the あつ goes to あっ, as you'd probably expect.
2588 | 経つ | たつ | To Pass | To Elapse | You know how 経 means passage of time, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means to pass or to elapse. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins to pass you by? "Ta ta (た), Time!"
2589 | 過ぎる | すぎる | To Pass | To Be Over\n To Be Too Much | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass, but this verb is intransitive, meaning we’re not focussing on who did the action, but on the action itself. So this means to pass, as in “the storm passed”, to be over as in “winter’s over”, or to be too much. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn order for the storm to pass you’re going to have to sue (す) it. Sadly storms won’t pass unless you take legal action these days.
2590 | 罰する | ばっする | To Punish | To Penalize | When you do a  penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the つ becomes a small っ so I don't have to punish you.
2591 | 置く | おく | To Put Down | To Set Down\n To Place\n To Put | When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (お). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.
2592 | 在留する | ざいりゅうする | To Reside | To Stay\n To Remain | If 在留 is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside.\nLike 在留, this is also a more formal term. You might encounter it at the immigration office, but you probably won't hear it in everyday conversation. \n The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!
2593 | 応じる | おうじる | To Respond | To Comply | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond.\n応じる is a formal word that describes acting favorably in response to a call, request, or demand. For example, 注文に応じる goes beyond just taking orders; it means adapting appropriately and fulfilling them. \n The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.
2594 | 営む | いとなむ | To Run A Business | To Manage A Business | The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to run a business. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU EAT NOW!" (いとな).
2595 | 震える | ふるえる | To Shake | To Shiver\n To Quake\n To Tremble\n To Quaver\n To Quiver | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earthquake so the verb means to shiver and to shake, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!
2596 | 寝る | ねる | To Sleep | To Go To Bed\n To Lie Down | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lie down so the verb vocab version is to lie down, but what you're really doing is trying to sleep. \n The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.
2597 | 吸う | すう | To Smoke | To Suck\n To Inhale | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suck so the verb vocab version is to suck, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is to smoke. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to sue (す) the cigarette makers.
2598 | 観る | みる | To View | To Watch\n To See | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means view so what is the verb vocab version? It's to view or to watch. \n The reading here is actually the same as 見る. This is easy to remember because the meanings are so similar too, not to mention it has a 見 right inside the kanji itself!
2599 | 伝統 | でんとう | Tradition |  | When you transmit something that unites the people, you are probably pulling on tradition. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your 伝統?\n伝統 means "tradition" in the sense of customs, practices, or rituals that are passed down within a culture or community. These traditions bring people together across generations and keep our shared culture alive. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2600 | 面倒臭い | めんどうくさい | Troublesome | A Bother\n Annoying | Something is a trouble (面倒) and it is smelly (臭い). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's troublesome or a bother, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose. \n The reading is the words 面倒 plus 臭い added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!
2601 | 脱衣 | だつい | Undressing |  | If you undress from clothes you are undressing. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2602 | 案外 | あんがい | Unexpectedly | More Than Expected | Something that happens outside the plan is something that happens unexpectedly. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2603 | 統合 | とうごう | Unification | Integration\n Consolidation | Unite and join together. It is unification time. Integration and consolidation! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Unify them.
2604 | 嫌悪感 | けんおかん | Unpleasant Feelings | Disgust | Bad feelings that you dislike are unpleasant feelings. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!
2605 | 価値 | かち | Value | Worth\n Merit | A value and a value. Obviously this is something that has much value. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2606 | 値 | あたい | Value | Price | A value is a value, but only in the mathematical sense.\nDepending on the reading, this can also mean price. \n Imagine a numerical value written on a tie (あたい). Now imagine that it’s the price of a neigh (ね) from your favorite horse. It’s a pretty high price, but you’ll do anything to hear that horse neigh.\nGenerally, あたい refers to a numerical value in math, while ね is a formal word for “price.”

WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE??? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 被害 as well.

Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.

You'll be learning that word very soon! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Because there are many of them! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. 2618 | 新幹線 | しんかんせん | Bullet Train | Shinkansen | This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. 2627 | 保守主義 | ほしゅしゅぎ | Conservative | Conservatism | You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to protect and conserve their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's conservatism and they're conservative people. \n This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.
2628 | 鬼 | おに | Demon | Ogre | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nDemons are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the "O" knee (おに).

If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2630 | 割り算 | わりざん | Division |  | Divide and calculate? Why, that's just division! \n This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

2635 | 作用 | さよう | Effect | Action\n Operation | When you make a task you're looking for a certain effect or action. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nWhat's the effect of a saw on yogurt (さよう)? What will the action of the saw on the yogurt do? Seems futile, but you're going to try anyway. For science.

If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nYou might sometimes see せこう as an alternative reading, but しこう is the more common version.

They're the new Yankees team that was manufactured in a lab and fed uranium. Their skills are unparalleled because of their metallic strength. It can go after someone’s name to say whose house it is, as in 山田宅 (Yamada’s house), and after words that give more information about the house, such as 女性宅 (women’s homes). \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. 2657 | 長崎 | ながさき | Nagasaki |  | This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, Nagasaki. \n The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have ながさき. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of Nagasaki, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.
2658 | 乳首 | ちくび | Nipple |  | What is a milk neck? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a nipple. \n The reading for this one is an exception, at least for the 乳 part. It's read as ち, and 首 is read as くび. You can remember the reading of nipple by thinking of a very special "nipple" you have on your face. A bee has burrowed into your cheek, and it squirts out milk from its butt, which sticks out of your cheek. You can't get it out, so you've decided to call this little cheek bee nipple your cheek bee (ちくび). Buzz buzz *milk*

2663 | 町外れ | まちはずれ | Outskirts Of Town | Outskirts | You already know that 町 means "town" and that 外れ means "extremity" or "outskirts", and this is just a combination of the two. So this means the outskirts of town. \n You've already learned both 町 and 外れ, so just combine the two and you get 町外れ not only in meaning, but also in reading!
2664 | 上演 | じょうえん | Performance | Presentation\n Production\n Staging\n Mount | What's above the stage and involves acting? A performance!\nThis word does not refer to an actor's acting on stage. Instead, it usually refers to a theatrical or musical presentation in its entirety, so is used in contexts relating to the act of staging an artistic or dramatic production, or features of the production itself, like its start time or running time (as in 上演時間). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Welcome to Broadway!\nThis word is more traditional and isn't used very much these days. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2666 | 職員 | しょくいん | Personnel | Staff\n Employee | The employment members of a workplace are the personnel or staff. Pretty straightforward!\n職員 and 社員 are two similar terms, but have different meanings. 社員 generally refers to employees of private companies, while 職員 refers to employees who work in various fields such as civil service, education, government, non-profits, and more. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2668 | 職場 | しょくば | Place Of Work | Workplace\n Place Of Employment | Your employment location is your place of work or place of employment. It's also your workplace.\nAre you using WaniKani at your 職場 right now? Wouldn't that be funny. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. That's all you have to remember, though, because you've seen both of these readings before!
2669 | 停電 | ていでん | Power Outage | Cutoff Of Electricity\n Power Cut | When you halt electricity you experience a power outage. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2670 | 準備 | じゅんび | Preparation |  | When you follow standard procedure to provide what's needed, you make the perfect preparation!\nBoth 準備 and 用意 mean "preparation," but 準備 means preparing in advance for an event, whereas 用意 implies taking appropriate measures. So, 準備 is better for planning a party, while 用意 fits well when making sure you have enough snacks for your guests. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2671 | 現在 | げんざい | Present | Now\n Current | In the present time we exist. What time is it? It's present and now. It is the current time! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2672 | 優先 | ゆうせん | Priority |  | It was superior previously, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest priority. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2673 | 紫 | むらさき | Purple | Violet | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.
2674 | 紫色 | むらさきいろ | Purple | Violet | A purple color is purple. Simple as that! \n The reading for 紫 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.
2675 | 割合 | わりあい | Ratio | Percentage\n Comparatively\n Fairly | Divide something into its parts and then join them back together, and you'll be able to see each little ratio or percentage of the whole. Imagine a whole thing neatly separated into its individual parts, making them visible but not changing the thing as a whole.\n割合 usually refers to the ratio of a certain part when compared to the whole, often expressed as a percentage. When used this way it's similar to 比率, but 割合 is more common in everyday language.\nNote that 割合 can also be used as an adverb, where it means comparatively or fairly. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
2676 | 現実 | げんじつ | Reality |  | The present is the truth. It is what's going on right now. It is reality. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2677 | 領収書 | りょうしゅうしょ | Receipt |  | I obtain some territory, so I want a written record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a receipt? Emailing one will do just fine. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2678 | 評判 | ひょうばん | Reputation | Fame | When people evaluate and judge you at every turn, it means you have quite a reputation, and indeed fame. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This uses a slightly different reading from what you learned for 判, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour reputation is incredibly important to you, so don't let anybody know that you've been banned (ばん) on the WaniKani forums before. Wouldn't want anyone to find out. What, this is going to be published as a reading mnemonic on WaniKani?! What are you talking about? Oh sh-...
2679 | 辞職 | じしょく | Resignation | Quitting | If you quit your place of employment, you are quitting, aka putting in your resignation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2680 | 革命 | かくめい | Revolution |  | Leather's fate is in the hands of a revolution. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2681 | 役割 | やくわり | Role |  | Let's divide the duty up amongst various people. Each person will have their own role in completing this duty. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.
2682 | 現場 | げんば | Scene | Spot\n Site | Your present location is the scene of the crime! And you're on the scene to check out what's currently going on. \n The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.
2683 | 責任感 | せきにんかん | Sense Of Responsibility |  | 責任 is responsibility. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is sense of responsibility. Do you have one? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2684 | 棚 | たな | Shelf | Cabinet | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2685 | 雨戸 | あまど | Shutter | Sliding Storm Shutter | A rain door is really just a shutter. In Japan, having shutters for rain protection is very common. When there were no glass windows, the shutters were simply like exterior doors in Japan, so "rain door" kind of makes sense as "shutter"!\nThis word is usually for sliding storm shutters. For other types of shutters, you can just say シャッター. \n This is a jukugo word, but it actually uses kun'yomi for both 雨 and 戸. Additionally, the reading for 雨 is actually slightly different from what you've learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nHave you ever thought a shutter is like an armor (あま) for a window? They're both protections, and are usually made from metal. Kind of makes sense, right?
2686 | 台詞 | せりふ | Speech | Words\n One's Lines\n Remarks | A part of speech machine spits out speeches and words. It's all the machine is programmed to do. \n The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (せりふ).
2687 | 基準 | きじゅん | Standard | A Standard | The foundation of your standard is where you place your standard. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of.\nThis word generally refers to a quantitative "standard" that’s a basis for evaluation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
