2692 | 教師 | きょうし | Teacher |  | A teaching expert/teacher is a teacher.\n教師 is a relatively formal word for teachers. Unlike 先生, this word is specifically for people in the teaching profession and cannot be used as a name ender. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2693 | 一割 | いちわり | Ten Percent |  | One division is ten percent. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on. \n The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.
2694 | 現れる | あらわれる | To Appear | To Emerge | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means appear, so this word means to appear or to emerge. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going to appear in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "Are what??" (あらわ) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.
2695 | 加わる | くわわる | To Be Added To | To Join In | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji 加 means add, and this verb means to be added to or to join in.\nIt is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in わる. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic? \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.
2696 | 埋まる | うまる | To Be Buried | To Be Surrounded\n To Overflow\n To Be Filled | Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means to be buried.\n埋まる can also mean to be filled, like a pond being completely filled by dirt from a landslide or seats being filled at an event. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
2697 | 建てる | たてる | To Build | To Construct | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? たてる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!
2698 | 呼ぶ | よぶ | To Call | To Call Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call so the verb vocab version is to call or to call out. As in "HEY, YOU!" \n The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself  calling out to someone: "YO (よ)! You!"
2699 | 確認する | かくにんする | To Confirm | To Verify | 確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have to confirm or to verify. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word 確認 already as well.
2700 | 保護する | ほごする | To Conserve | To Protect | To preserve and defend something is to conserve and to protect. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying to protect! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2701 | 批判する | ひはんする | To Criticize |  | 批判 is criticism so the verb version of that would be to criticize. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.
2702 | 断つ | たつ | To Cut Off | To Quit Doing Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off so the verb vocab version is to cut off.\nThis is often used metaphorically to describe cutting off things that tie us down mentally or societally. This includes ending bad habits, so it also means to quit doing something.\nDon't confuse this with 断る which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the つ, which hints that you have had two (つ) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off. \n URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. to cut off is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater tots (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have to cut off tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.
2703 | 割る | わる | To Divide | To Split Something\n To Break Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means divide so the verb vocab version is to divide or to split something.\nIt can also mean to break something, as in ワイングラスを割る (to break a wine glass). After all, you’re technically dividing the object into parts if you break it, right? \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.
2704 | 選挙する | せんきょする | To Elect |  | Election is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have to elect. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.
2705 | 脱走する | だっそうする | To Escape | To Flee | You escape and run the hell out of there. Basically, you're trying to escape or to flee. Pretty simple. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.
2706 | 秀でる | ひいでる | To Excel | To Surpass | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means excel so the verb vocab version is to excel. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\n"He-e (ひい) is going to excel," you stutter. "He-e is!"
2707 | 済ます | すます | To Finish Something | To Settle Something | Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is to finish something or to settle something, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno mas (ます) time. This is the last time. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with 済む, so if you know that you'll be able to finish this vocab.
2708 | 収まる | おさまる | To Fit Inside | To Settle Down\n To Be Finished | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nIf you obtain something, you'll want it to fit inside your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? When talking about problems or emotions, this verb can also mean to settle down and to be finishedlike a dispute settling down or someone’s anger calming down.\nLike most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty old saws (おさ) and chop off your footboard.
2709 | 混じる | まじる | To Get Mixed Up In | To Get Mixed\n To Be Mixed | This one is a little strange. You have 混む (To Be Crowded), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混じる, To Get Mixed Up In. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine Jesus (じ) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers. \n The reading is the same as (almost) all the other 混 verbs. All about mamamamama!
2710 | 降りる | おりる | To Get Off | To Step Down | The kanji is descend, but this verb vocab word is to get off, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the real (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train.\nFiguratively, this word also means to step down, as in "to give up" or "to resign” from something. For example, you can say ニュース番組を降りる (to step down from a news program) or ゲームを降りる (to drop out of a game). \n The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have to get off at O-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just O-Station (お).
2711 | 増やす | ふやす | To Increase Something | To Increase | Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means to increase something. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself. \n The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.
2712 | 裁く | さばく | To Judge |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means judge so the verb version is to judge. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you go to judge people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the sobber (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.
2713 | 心得る | こころえる | To Know | To Understand\n To Be Aware Of\n To Consent\n To Agree | Remember how you learned that 心得 means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is to know. (You know it deep in your heart.) \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
2714 | 導く | みちびく | To Lead | To Guide | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lead so the verb vocab version is to lead. \n The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a 道 Bee (みちび)!
2715 | 演ずる | えんずる | To Perform | To Play | If 演 is performance then the verb version of this would be to perform. \n The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.
2716 | 備える | そなえる | To Provide | To Furnish\n To Equip\n To Prepare For | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.
2717 | 挙げる | あげる | To Raise Something | To Cite Something\n To Hold Something | The kanji means raise, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means to raise something. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of to cite something, like an example. It can even mean to hold something, like an event. \n The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.
2718 | 解く | とく | To Solve | To Solve Something\n To Untie Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to solve. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super coo' (く) to solve things. \n The reading is the same as 解ける, so if you know that you can read this one too.
2719 | 張る | はる | To Stretch Over Something | To Spread Out\n To Swell\n To Be Taut | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch, and the verb version means to stretch over something, to spread out, or to be taut, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout.\nThis word is both transitive and intransitive. When it follows を, it emphasizes the physical act of extending something over an area, like stretching a canvas over a frame, unfurling a sail on a ship, or roping off a crime scene. When following が, it expresses the resulting state of having been stretched or spread, like a bloated stomach, a swollen muscle, or a spider web. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nImagine yourself trying to stretch your favorite toy figurine, seeing just how far you can stretch it. With every stretch, you start laughing uncontrollably, HA (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Seems a bit cruel. Are you okay?
2720 | 理解する | りかいする | To Understand | To Comprehend | 理解 is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.
2721 | 幹 | みき | Tree Trunk |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nWhen you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.
2722 | 裁判 | さいばん | Trial |  | You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:\nAfter your ban (ばん) on the WaniKani forums, you now face trial before none other than Judge Koichi. He's going to decide whether your ban will be lifted or not. Good luck, there's a lot at stake.
2723 | 節目 | ふしめ | Turning Point | Critical Juncture\n Milestone | What seasons should you keep an eye on? The seasons that are turning points in your life. Owning a few sheep was a true milestone for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!
2724 | 無職 | むしょく | Unemployed | Unemployment | When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably unemployed. 2725 | 吸血鬼 | きゅうけつき | Vampire |  | A demon that sucks blood? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a vampire? Them Sparklzzzz! \n 吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?
2726 | 優勝 | ゆうしょう | Victory | Championship | The superior person wins. 2727 | 素晴らしい | すばらしい | Wonderful | Splendid\n Magnificent\n The Best | An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome. \n The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.
2728 | 上述 | じょうじゅつ | Above Mentioned | The Above Mentioned | Above mentions are above mentioned. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay?\nNote that 上述 is a word commonly used in formal writing such as reports, academic papers, or business documents. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2729 | 年額 | ねんがく | Annual Amount | Yearly Amount | The year amount is the yearly amount. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2730 | 触角 | しょっかく | Antenna |  | The angle of the touch is important with an antenna. Think about antennae. An ant's antennae wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennae touching your arm to figure out who you are.\nNote that 触角 refers to the antennae of insects, crustaceans, and certain other arthropods, rather than to TV or radio antennas. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. しょく goes to しょっ.
2731 | 腕 | うで | Arm |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2732 | 誕生日 | たんじょうび | Birthday |  | Remember how 誕生 is birth? If you add day on there, you have a birthday. Happy birthday! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word 日 uses the kun'yomi ひ, which is turned into び due to rendaku.
2733 | 輸血 | ゆけつ | Blood Transfusion |  | Transport of blood. Only time you do this is during a blood transfusion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2734 | 血管 | けっかん | Blood Vessel | Vein | The pipes that hold your blood are your blood vessels, or your veins. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ goes to けっ.
2735 | 両腕 | りょううで | Both Arms |  | Both arms are both arms! \n This is a combination of the on'yomi reading of 両 and the kun'yomi reading of 腕. You've learned them both, so you know this too!
2736 | 境 | さかい | Boundary |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.
2737 | 境界 | きょうかい | Boundary |  | The boundary separates worlds. It is a boundary. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2738 | 建物 | たてもの | Building | Structure | This is a build thing, or perhaps a building thing. In other words, a building or structure.\n建物 is a very general word that can refer to any kind of building, including residential buildings, commercial buildings, or public facilities. \n The reading might look a little strange, but makes sense once you get it. You already know that the verb 建てる means "to build", and that a もの is a "thing". Now just remove the る part from the verb to make it a noun, combine it with もの, and we get たてもの! Just remember that it’s all kun’yomi since it comes from the verb 建てる.
2739 | 負担 | ふたん | Burden | Responsibility | You lose. Because of that, you have to carry this burden and responsibility. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2740 | 可燃ゴミ | かねんごみ | Burnable Garbage | Burnable Trash\n Burnable Rubbish | Possible to burn ゴミ (garbage). This is burnable garbage. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2741 | 特質 | とくしつ | Characteristic | Trait | Your special quality is your characteristics or your traits.\nThis is a formal word that refers to special properties that only a certain thing possesses, like the properties of steel as a material, or a certain person’s nature. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2742 | 子供 | こども | Child | Kid\n Children\n Kids | A child servant is a child. Children are basically like little servants anyways, what else are they good for? \n The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is just こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun.\nAlso, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.
2743 | 親展 | しんてん | Confidential |  | If intimacy expands to something, that thing is confidential. Try visualizing intimacy as a sort of gooey liquid, expanding and covering a letter, and making that letter confidential.\n親展 is generally written on the front of envelopes to indicate that only the intended recipient should read its contents. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2744 | 対策 | たいさく | Counter Plan | Countermeasure | Your versus plan is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your counter plan. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

It's difference. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.

Similarly, it can just mean picture or frame too. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
2755 | 燃料 | ねんりょう | Fuel |  | A material you can burn is called fuel! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2756 | 更に | さらに | Furthermore | Further\n Again | When you're renewing what you're saying, you're adding onto it, which makes this furthermore or further.\nThis is one of those good paragraph or sentence-starting essay words, which is how you'll often see it used! \n The kanji stands by itself with a particle, meaning that this uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou know a person that starts every other sentence by saying "Furthermore," and that's... Sarah (さら). Really feel yourself getting annoyed with this Sarah for starting every other sentence with "Furthermore, ...!"\nJust note that 更に is often written in kana, as さらに, especially in casual writing!

2807 | 規則 | きそく | Rule | Regulation | A standard rule is just one of the rules or regulations. Nothing weird about these rules. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2808 | 規律 | きりつ | Rule | Law\n Discipline | A standard law is the rule or law you have to follow. With these standard laws comes discipline. If you don't have these it will be chaos! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2809 | 販売 | はんばい | Sales | Selling\n Marketing | Sell, sell, sell. This is the attitude you need if you want to work in sales or do sales. You have to work on your selling. \n This is a jukugo word, which means you need to know the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both, hurray!
2810 | 武士 | ぶし | Samurai |  | A military samurai is a samurai. This is how most people say "samurai" in Japanese. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2811 | 視覚 | しかく | Sense Of Sight | Sight | You look at things and memorize them via your sight, using your sense of sight. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2812 | 半袖 | はんそで | Short Sleeves |  | Half sleeves is just another name for short sleeves. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for 半 and the kun'yomi reading for 袖. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.
2813 | 肩 | かた | Shoulder |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2814 | 株式 | かぶしき | Stock | Share | A stock ritual is the dance we do in the modern world around stocks and shares of different companies. Buy! Sell! Buy! Sell! \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
2815 | 株 | かぶ | Stock | Share | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji.
2816 | 主観的 | しゅかんてき | Subjective |  | 主観 is subjectivity. So when something moves towards subjectivity it is becoming subjective. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know 主観.
2817 | 対象 | たいしょう | Target | Subject | The versus phenomenon is what you're going up against. It's your target because you're heading towards this phenomenon you're versusing against. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2818 | 時差 | じさ | Time Difference |  | The time distinction is how you tell apart time zones. It is the time difference. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2819 | 援助する | えんじょする | To Assist | To Aid | You know that 援助 is assistance or aid. So the verb vocab version is to assist or to aid. \n The reading is the same as 援助. It is also just the readings you learned with the kanji.
2820 | 届く | とどく | To Be Delivered | To Arrive\n To Reach | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deliver so the verb vocab version here is to be delivered or to arrive. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (く), it arrived. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!
2821 | 違う | ちがう | To Be Different | To Be Wrong\n To Be Mistaken\n To Vary\n To Differ | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means different so the verb vocab version is to be different... and of course, to be different is also to be wrong in Japan. Don't be different! \n The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.
2822 | 載る | のる | To Be Placed On | To Be Recorded\n To Be Loaded On | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's also an intransitive verb, meaning the action happens on its own, you don't do it. The kanji itself means place on, and this means to be placed on.\n載る is also often used to refer to something being included in a written document or publication and so can also mean to be recorded, as in 新聞に載る (to be recorded in a newspaper) or 教科書に載る (to be recorded in a textbook). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nA reporter asks for your conversation to be placed on record, to which you respond "NO (の)!" Koichi doesn't want everyone to know that he didn’t notice a cactus had been placed on his seat until…
2823 | 燃やす | もやす | To Burn Something | To Set On Fire | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burn and the verb vocab version is to burn something, or to set on fire. \n This is when you're burning something. To remember this meaning, you have to remember the も part. So, just think of your friend Moe (も), and how you're going to burn him... uh... just a little bit.
2824 | 担ぐ | かつぐ | To Carry | To Shoulder | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carry so the verb vocab version is to carry. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou love to carry things, especially cats (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.
2825 | 祝う | いわう | To Celebrate |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means celebrate, so the verb vocab version is to celebrate. When you burn this word, you should 祝う! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEveryone's here to celebrate, and all you can say is "Eek, wha...!?" (いわ). All your friends and family have come to celebrate your birthday, but you had no idea. Still confused and processing the situation, you keep saying, "Eek... what?" The surprise was a complete success!
2826 | 発展する | はってんする | To Develop |  | Let's depart from this place and expand it out. To do that we'll have to develop it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はつ gets shortened to はっ, though.
2827 | 無視する | むしする | To Ignore | To Disregard | I will look at nothing. I am going to ignore you. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2828 | 供える | そなえる | To Make An Offering | To Offer | You don't servant something... but what do servants do? You are their god, so they have to make an offering to you every day. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It shares its reading with the word 備える, which you learned a level ago, but in case you need a reminder, here it is:\nWhat's the best way for your servants to make an offering? When they offer up their sauna (そな)! You really value a warm and relaxing sauna session at the end of the day.
2829 | 量る | はかる | To Measure | To Weigh | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means quantity, but you don't "to quantity." To figure out the quantity, however, you have to measure / to weigh whatever it is you want to get the quantity of. \n You need to measure the quantity of something, but don't have a scale or anything. Luckily, you are quite the hacker (はか) and hack together a scale using only rubber bands and beans.
2830 | 述べる | のべる | To Mention | To State\n To Explain | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means mention so the verb vocab version is to mention.\nThis is a formal word often used in writing. \n I have to mention this thing... "NO," (の) you quickly respond. I don't want you mentioning that here and now.
2831 | 過ぎ | すぎ | Too Much | After\n Past | 過ぎる is to pass. When you pass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: too much. This can also mean after, as in "after 5pm", and past, as in "past sixty". \n The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know too much. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.
2832 | 寝坊する | ねぼうする | To Oversleep |  | 寝坊 is oversleep. Make that into a verb and you have to oversleep. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.
2833 | 指差す | ゆびさす | To Point At | To Point To | When you want to use your finger to explain the distinction between more than one thing, you need to point at it. Otherwise the person you're talking to won't be able to tell which one you're talking about.\nIn general, 指差す specifically means using one’s index finger to physically point at something or someone. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
2834 | 提案する | ていあんする | To Propose |  | You remember 提案, which means proposition? Make that into a verb and you have to propose. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2835 | 応援する | おうえんする | To Root For | To Cheer On\n To Cheer For | 応援 is aid and root for, but for this verb the "root for" one is going to be more on the money. You can call this to root for, to cheer on or to cheer for. \n The reading comes from 応援. It's also just the on'yomi readings you learned.
2836 | 営業する | えいぎょうする | To Run A Business | To Manage A Business | The word 営業 is business. The verb version of that (to do a business) becomes to run a business. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.
2837 | 差す | さす | To Shine At | To Shine On | The kanji is distinction. To distinct something would be nice, but this is used more like to shine at or to shine on, like when a light shines on someone on a stage, distinguishing them from everyone else. \n The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).
2838 | 突く | つく | To Stab | To Poke\n To Jab | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version must also be to stab.\nWondering how it’s different from 刺す? 突く refers to the act of pushing or pressing something with a tip of an object, often done forcefully and swiftly. So when you use 突く as in “to stab,” your focus is on the forcefulness of the action. On the other hand, 刺す focuses more on the actual act of piercing into something or someone with a sharp thing.\nThis is why 突く can be be translated many ways, like to poke, to jab, and many more. \n If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed two (つ) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.
2839 | 支援する | しえんする | To Support | To Back\n To Aid | To support and aid is to support. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2840 | 全額 | ぜんがく | Total | Full Amount\n Sum\n Total Amount\n Entirety\n Grand Total | All of the amount is your total. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2841 | 触る | さわる | To Touch Something | To Touch | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means touch so the verb vocab version is to touch something.\n触る is used when someone does the touching. It's not used to describe objects touching each other.\nNote that 触る can be used with either the particle に or を, like 手に触る or 手を触る (to touch a hand). Using に simply marks the location you touch, while using を highlights your action of touching that specific area or object. So the former is intransitive and the latter is transitive, though there's some debate about that. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're an idiot. You try to touch a saw (さわ).
2842 | 感触 | かんしょく | Touch | Touch Sense\n Feel\n Feeling | Your feeling of touch is your touch sense (or simply just touch). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2843 | 脱ぐ | ぬぐ | To Undress | To Take Off Clothes | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means undress and the verb is to undress. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to undress your goal is to become nude (ぬ).

2858 | 記述 | きじゅつ | Writing Down | Description\n Account | When you Write down and mention what happened, you're writing down a description and account of it.\n記述 simply means writing things down (whether by hand or by typing), usually to have an objective written record about something. 記述 can also refer to the text that's been written. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2859 | 絶対 | ぜったい | Absolutely | Without Fail\n Unconditionally | Extinction will happen as you go versus extinction. It will happen absolutely. It will happen without fail. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, 絶 is normally read as ぜつ, but in this case it is shortened to ぜっ.

You suck. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2861 | 現役 | げんえき | Actively Working | Active | At the present time you're providing a service, so you're actively working. 現役 means you have a certain role (such as school teacher or a high school student, etc.) and you're still active in that role, as opposed to being retired or having graduated.\nThis word is also often used to describe students who are taking or have passed a university entrance exam while they were still high school students. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You learned the readings for both of these, but 役 uses a less common reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:\nYou're actively working at the 駅 (えき) and you plan to remain active there forever! You sure do love that 駅, it's like you're inseparable.

2867 | 賞与金 | しょうよきん | Bonus |  | It's a prize where you are given gold. In business, this is called a bonus. 2868 | 名刺 | めいし | Business Card |  | Take your name and stab someone with it... using your business card. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 2869 | 景況 | けいきょう | Business Climate | Economic Climate\n Situation | Take a look at this scene and the condition it’s in. This is the climate of the situation, but more specifically the business climate. 2871 | 気候 | きこう | Climate |  | The energy of the climate is the climate. High energy? Climate. Low energy. Climate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2872 | 衣 | ころも | Clothes | Coating\n Breading | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nIn modern Japanese, 衣 is more often used to describe the clothes your food is wearing, i.e. the coating on tempura or the breading on deep-fried foods. \n What are clothes, really? Some people say clothes are the chromosomes (ころも) of your personal style — each garment carries information about your unique identity. Other people say clothes are simply the key to not being nude (きぬ). What do you think?\nBoth ころも and きぬ mean "clothes," but these usages are old-fashioned. Also note that the more modern meaning of "coating" or "breading" uses only the ころも reading!
2873 | 構成 | こうせい | Composition | Structure | If you set up something so that it becomes a certain way, that's the composition of this thing. That's its structure.\n構成 refers to the process of assembling several elements to create a cohesive whole or the assembled whole itself. It can be applied to various contexts, such as social structures, family compositions, artistic works, or the configuration of materials. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2874 | 状況 | じょうきょう | Condition | Circumstances\n Situation | The condition condition is the condition. It's also the circumstances if you can remember that. It's like saying "What's the condition!??" which is similar to saying "What's the circumstances?" \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2875 | 涼しい | すずしい | Cool | Refreshing | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cool? It's cool.\n涼しい is used to describe a comfortable level of coolness, particularly one that's pleasant and refreshing. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too. If you need a refresher, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nLooking for a place that's cool and refreshing? Go to the Sue Zoo (すず). Imagine swimming with Sue the penguin in the refreshing water of her pool. Feels good!
