2877 | 習慣 | しゅうかん | Custom | Habit | I've learned to be accustomed to this. It has become my custom and habit. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2878 | 期限 | きげん | Deadline | Term\n Due Date | The period of time limit is the deadline for a certain thing. Alternatively, this can describe a term for something, like the repayment of debts, or some sort of due date. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2879 | 絶望 | ぜつぼう | Despair | Hopelessness | When hope has died out, you have no more hope, only despair. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2880 | 割引 | わりびき | Discount |  | Divide that price and pull it apart. You only have to pay for one part! What a discount. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. き from ひき kind of just gets stuffed into the 引 and hidden away like that strange collection of fingernails you have hidden in your closet drawer inside of a 35mm film container. Also remember that the reading gets changed to びき here because of that pesky rendaku.
2881 | 区分 | くぶん | Division | Section\n Classification | Think about a part of the district. Separate them out in your mind (these parts). Each part is a division of the district. You can also take each division and create a classification of them. Go ahead and classify each one. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2882 | 地 | ち | Earth | Ground\n Land | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n地 is often used in formal contexts or literature to refer to the Earth's surface, the ground, or land in a more abstract or overarching sense. To say "earth" or "ground" casually, use 地面. For "land," it's 土地. \n Although this is a single kanji all alone, it uses the on'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.
2883 | 反響 | はんきょう | Echo | Reverberation\n Influence\n Repercussion\n Reaction | An anti echo is still an echo! It's just going back and forth with a normal echo. Together they get a weird reverberation going. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2884 | 効率 | こうりつ | Efficiency |  | Your effective percent shows how effective you are. If you're at an effective percent of 80%, that's your efficiency. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2885 | 年輩 | ねんぱい | Elderly Person | Old Person\n Elderly | Someone who is a comrade with years has been around a lot of said years. They are an elderly person. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はい goes to a ぱい, because elderly persons love pie, right?
2886 | 結構 | けっこう | Fine | Fairly\n Quite\n Sufficient | Bind and set up everything so it is fine and fairly sufficient.\nThis word is often used to express that something is adequate or satisfactory, to politely decline an offer or invitation, or to indicate a relatively high degree or extent of something, like:\n"No thank you" 結構です\n"That's fine, no more" もう結構です\n"It's fairly big" 結構大きい\netc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The けつ shortens to けっ.
2887 | 防火 | ぼうか | Fire Prevention | Fire Fighting\n Fire Proof | Trying to prevent fire? Better get into fire prevention. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2888 | 上巻 | じょうかん | First Volume |  | The above scroll is the top scroll, the one you read first. It's the first volume. Many Japanese books come in parts, so look for this if you want to get the first one. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2889 | まぐれ | まぐれ | Fluke | Chance | Somebody tried to mug Remi (まぐれ), your friend, but by chance they managed to escape! Their escape was a fluke, but what a relief they didn't get mugged.\nThis word can be written in kanji, but the kana version is way more common. In fact, it'd be quite a fluke if you saw it in kanji.
2890 | 〜毎に | ごとに | For Every | At Intervals Of\n Once Every | Add a に to every and you get for every. This means something happens at intervals of a certain time frame or milestone, like once every year, month, day, etc.!\nNote that this is very frequently written in hiragana, but you'll encounter the kanji version as well, especially when it follows a number. \n This uses the kun'yomi reading of 毎, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nFor every kanji you burn, you go to (ごと) Tokyo Disneyland as a reward. It's a bit of an expensive habit, but I think you deserve it.
2891 | 新鮮 | しんせん | Fresh |  | New and fresh is fresh (has to be new if you want it to be fresh, after all).\nThis word is used to describe fresh vegetables, fish, air, and new ideas or experiences, but is not commonly used to describe freshly made food or drinks. This is because the word emphasizes the inherent freshness of the thing being described, rather than its recent production. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2892 | 鮮魚 | せんぎょ | Fresh Fish |  | Fresh fish is fresh fish (and the best fish, nom nom nom).\nThis is a fairly specialized word that you’d mostly see at a market. To describe fresh fish more generally, you can just say 新鮮な魚. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2893 | 満員 | まんいん | Full House | No Vacancy\n Jam-Packed | Full of members, so sorry, no more room. This place is a full house. That means there is no vacancy here. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2894 | 満月 | まんげつ | Full Moon |  | The full moon is a full moon. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2895 | 公用 | こうよう | Government Business | Official Business | A public task is going to be government business. You have to think of this public as government to know the meaning of this word easily. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2896 | 素直 | すなお | Honest | Upfront\n Obedient | All your dishonest elements are fixed, making you more honest than ever.\nThis is mostly used to describe people as being honest and upfront about their thoughts and emotions. While mostly being positive, it can also be used in a slightly negative way to describe people as being obedient and compliant, following instructions and rules without resistance. \n The reading for this is a bit of a weird one. It uses on'yomi for 素, then it uses the kun'yomi for 直. You know both readings, but it's all a little strange, so here's a mnemonic help you:\nTo present yourself as an honest person, you should hurry up and change into a suit now (すなお). We all know that people in suits look more honest and upfront, so go get suited up now!
2897 | 光栄 | こうえい | Honor | Privilege | When a light shines on how much you've prospered, it's a great honor. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2898 | 莫大 | ばくだい | Huge | Enormous | Something that is endlessly big isn't just big, but huge and enormous.\nThis word is often used in contexts that involve money, but it can also be used for other things like time, energy, and data. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2899 | 含意 | がんい | Implication | Hint At\n Connotation\n Suggestion | Include your ideas here, but think about the implications they will result in too, especially considering you're just including them now. They have implications!\nThis word is quite formal, and therefore commonly used in academic or professional contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2900 | 無限 | むげん | Infinite | Limitless | The limit is nothing. What? No limit? That means it will never stop! It is infinite! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2901 | 影響 | えいきょう | Influence |  | In the shadows you still echo. Your echo leaves the shadows and hits people, creating an influence on them. You're like the shadow person pulling the strings, making things do what you want... influencing them. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2902 | 不規則 | ふきそく | Irregularity | Irregular\n Disorderly | You know that 規則 means "rule" or "regulation." So a not "rule" or "regulation" is an irregularity. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2903 | 後輩 | こうはい | Junior | One's Junior | The comrade who's behind you is your junior. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 後 is the long こう reading, though. Just think of your junior being こういち.
2904 | 下巻 | げかん | Last Volume | Final Volume | The scroll that's below is the last scroll you read, making it the last volume. \n The 下 uses the alternative reading of げ but 巻 is all good and normal.
2905 | 訴訟 | そしょう | Lawsuit | Litigation | If you sue and bring about a lawsuit, you are bringing about a lawsuit. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2906 | 革ジャン | かわじゃん | Leather Jacket |  | 革 is leather and ジャン is short for ジャンパー (Jumper, like a jacket). So, put those together and you have a leather jacket.\nThis word is getting somewhat outdated. The trendier term now is レザージャケット. \n The reading is the same as the vocab word 革, because this word is like two separate words put together (so it's treated as single words too, giving it that reading).
2907 | 限界 | げんかい | Limit | Limitations | As you reach the limit of your world, you face your limit and confront your limitations.\nThis word refers to the maximum extent or limit that something can reach or endure. It conveys the idea of reaching the utmost point beyond which a situation or condition cannot be sustained. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2908 | 肥料 | ひりょう | Manure | Fertilizer | Your fee for being obese is lots of manure coming out of your butt. If you eat a lot you'll poop a lot of manure. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2909 | 金属 | きんぞく | Metal |  | Even gold belongs to a family... the family of metals! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2910 | 掛け算 | かけざん | Multiplication |  | If you try to calculate something, but instead you feel the urge to hang your teacher, you know you're doing multiplication. It's hard, guys. Like really hard. The hardest kind of math of them all. But you can do it! No one needs to get hanged. And don't hang your head in defeat either. Multiply those numbers like a boss! Hang the numbers instead!! \n This is the kun'yomi reading for 掛 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
2911 | 絞殺 | こうさつ | Murder By Strangling | Strangling To Death | A strangle kill is murder by strangling, or strangling to death.\nThis is a pretty formal word that you’d see most in police reports and detective novels. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2912 | 長崎県 | ながさきけん | Nagasaki Prefecture |  | Long Cape Prefecture. This will make more sense when you look at the reading. Hint: It's Nagasaki Prefecture. \n The readings are 長 from 長い, normal 崎 and normal 県.
2913 | 肥満 | ひまん | Obesity |  | Does being obese mean you're always full? Of course not. But clearly that's what the people who coined the Japanese word for obesity thought... You can see there are some implicit biases in these kanji! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2914 | 岡山城 | おかやまじょう | Okayama Castle |  | This is the same 岡山 that you learned with 岡山県. So what's Okayama castle? Yep, Okayama Castle! \n When 城 is added to a place name like this, it takes the on'yomi. You haven't learned this yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe lord of Okayama Castle is none other than Joe (じょう), your local farmhand friend. How a farmhand like Joe managed to become the lord of a Japanese castle is beyond even us, but it's Lord Joe to you now.
2915 | 一巻 | いっかん | One Volume | First Volume | One scroll is one scroll back in the day, but now it refers to books and means one volume. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.
2916 | 模様 | もよう | Pattern |  | 様 uses its alternative meaning "manner" here, so we have an imitation manner. An imitation of the same manner over and over creates a pattern. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you didn't learn the on'yomi for 様 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. You see a pattern in your yogurt (よう). The yogurt is an imitation of life. So deep, man. So deep.
2917 | 減給 | げんきゅう | Pay Cut |  | A decrease in salary is a pay cut. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2918 | 満点 | まんてん | Perfect Score |  | Full points are when you get a perfect score.\n満点 can also be used to describe a state of being at the pinnacle of a certain quality or standard, such as サービス満点 (excellent service) or 栄養満点 (highly nutritious). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2919 | 模型 | もけい | Plastic Model | Model\n Dummy\n Scale Model | An imitation model is obviously not the real thing. It's (usually) a plastic model or just a model figure or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2920 | 豊満 | ほうまん | Plump | Full-Figured\n Voluptuous | If you're plentiful and full, you could say you're plump or full-figured... in other words, you're not a snack, you're the Whole. Damn. Meal.\nThis is a literary expression used to describe the physical appearance of a woman's body, often focusing on a well-endowed chest. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2921 | 受領書 | じゅりょうしょ | Receipt | Delivery Confirmation Slip\n Docket | Please accept this territory. Oh, you want some writing to make the deal official? Okay, here's a receipt.\nThis word refers to a document which serves as proof of receiving goods, services, or money in an official setting, like a business transaction. If you’re just talking about the receipt you get while shopping, you can simply say レシート or 領収書. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2922 | 不況 | ふきょう | Recession |  | A "not condition" is where nothing is going well. How are things going? Not well. The condition is bad. We're in a recession. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2923 | 規則正しい | きそくただしい | Regular | Orderly\n Systematic | This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, that you learned already. If you follow the rules in the correct order, everything will stay regular and orderly.\nThis word means that something follows a regular pattern or schedule. It’s commonly used to describe disciplined lifestyles, such as with regular sleep, exercise, and healthy eating habits, and implies that the regularity is desirable. \n This is a combination of the words 規則 and 正しい, which you learned already, so you should be able to read this word too.
2924 | 隠居 | いんきょ | Retirement | Retreat | You hide away but you're alive. You've lived your life, so now it's time to hide and enjoy your retirement by making your retreat from working life.\nThis word refers to life after someone retires, and usually implies being retired from active life and having a quiet, maybe even secluded, lifestyle. It can also imply handing over the reins to your successors. The word is a little old-fashioned, but you'll still see it in modern writing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2925 | 革命家 | かくめいか | Revolutionary | A Revolutionary | A person who lives in a revolution (革命) house is a revolutionary. They want government change! They want to take down the people in power! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 革命 already as well.
2926 | 豊か | ゆたか | Rich | Plentiful\n Abundant\n Wealthy | This is the same as the kanji 豊, making it plentiful and abundant. It can also mean rich or wealthy.\n豊か is a versatile and nuanced word that conveys a sense of abundance and richness in various aspects of life. It implies a positive and prosperous state, going beyond just material wealth or great quantity, and encompassing overall well-being and fulfillment. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou discovered plentiful yurt tacos (ゆた) inside the yurt you’re staying in. Picture yourself savoring the richly flavored yurt tacos beside your yurt while being immersed in the abundant nature around you.
2927 | 給料 | きゅうりょう | Salary | Wages\n Pay | Your salary fee are the moneys you get for your salary. These are your wages and pay. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2928 | 満足 | まんぞく | Satisfied | Totally Satisfied\n Satisfaction | I am full and sufficient. I am satisfied. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the reading for 足 in this one is ぞく because of that pesky rendaku.
2929 | 光景 | こうけい | Scene | Spectacle\n Sight | When sunlight shines on a scene, it’s still a scene. The sunlight is here to create some drama, also making this a spectacle. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2930 | 景色 | けしき | Scenery | Landscape\n View | The scene's color is the scenery, landscape, and view. Looking good, scenery! \n You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember them:\nYou're admiring the scenery and you notice key marks all over everything. You realize it's that girl who keys everything and you say to yourself kay she keyed (けしき) that, kay she keyed (けしき) this.
2931 | 時候 | じこう | Seasonal Climate | Seasonal Weather\n Season | The time's climate is the seasonal climate, or seasonal weather.\nYou’ll almost always see this word used in the context of 時候のあいさつ (seasonal greetings). It's a customary practice to start a letter by discussing something related to the current season before addressing the main topic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2932 | 二巻 | にかん | Second Volume | Two Volumes | The number two scroll is the second volume. With Japanese books, they often come in pieces with groups of three being common. This represents the second volume. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2933 | 先輩 | せんぱい | Senior | Older Graduate\n Superior | My comrade who came before me is my senior, my senpai (せんぱい). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well, but just remember that the second kanji is read as ぱい because of the rendaku on はい.
2934 | 影 | かげ | Shadow |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Just imagine the shadow of a cage (かげ). Lots of long bars. Looks good.
2935 | 肩こり | かたこり | Shoulder Stiffness | Stiff Shoulders\n Stiff Neck | When your shoulders get a little こり, it means you've got shoulder stiffness or a stiff neck.\nThe こり here is a nominalized version of the verb こる, which means "to become stiff," so maybe that'll help you remember this! \n You already know the reading of 肩, and this is just that with some hiragana added on!
2936 | 天候 | てんこう | The Weather | Weather | Heaven's climate is the weather.\nCompared to 天気, this is a more formal term used to describe the weather over the period of one day, multiple days, or even weeks. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2937 | 吸収する | きゅうしゅうする | To Absorb |  | If 吸収 is "absorption" the verb version is to absorb. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2938 | 建つ | たつ | To Be Built |  | You know that 建てる is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word means to be built. You can remember that by thinking about how two (つ) buildings were built without you noticing. These two buildings just seemed to pop up out of nowhere and, unfortunately, they're now blocking your view. \n The reading is shared with 建てる, so if you know 建てる then you should be able to read this word as well.
2939 | 呼ばれる | よばれる | To Be Called |  | If 呼ぶ is "to call" then this is something similar. This is when you are called by someone (and you're not doing the calling). This word is to be called. \n The reading is shared with 呼ぶ, so remember that and you'll be able to read this too.
2940 | 捕まる | つかまる | To Be Caught | To Get Caught | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the intransitive verb vocab version is to be caught. This is a literal, physical catch. So, for example, you can catch a criminal using this verb but not catch the drift of an idea, which would be 捕える, coming up in level 27. \n The reading is つか, so to remember that with to be caught, think about how you're a police officer trying to catch some criminals. Unfortunately, they have split up into two cars (つか) meaning you won't catch both of them, since you only have one car.
2941 | 慣れる | なれる | To Become Accustomed To | To Get Used To | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accustomed so the verb vocab version is to become accustomed. \n What have you become accustomed to? All the Narwhals (な) you hang out with. They take some getting used to.
2942 | 割れる | われる | To Be Divided | To Be Split\n To Break | Remember how 割る is "to divide"? Now you're learning the intransitive version. Instead of you doing the dividing, something just gets divided or split up. So this is to be divided or to be split.\nIt can also mean to break, as in ワイングラスが割れる (the wine glass breaks). After all, when an object breaks, it’s divided into parts, right? \n The reading is shared with 割る.
2943 | 効く | きく | To Be Effective | To Work Effectively | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means effective. The verb vocab version is to be effective or to work effectively (since "to effective" doesn't make sense).\nThis word is used to describe something that works effectively and as intended, such as medicine that achieves the desired effect or brakes that effectively stop the car. \n What is particularly effective? It's your key (き). It's effective at opening your house door.
2944 | 係わる | かかわる | To Be Involved | To Be Related\n To Be Connected | You know that the kanji means connection. This is a verb, so one meaning is to be connected. It can also mean to be involved and to be related. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.\nDoes this all sound familiar? In fact, this is another way to write 関わる, which you already learned! The two have exactly the same meaning, but this version is a bit less common. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. It's exactly the same as the reading for 関わる, so here's a reminder of that mnemonic to help you:\nRemember the "Kaw Kaw (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw"... You don't want to be involved with them.
2945 | 構う | かまう | To Care About | To Mind | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means care so the verb vocab version is to care about.\nThis word generally implies a more direct physical or verbal expression of care, rather than just mentally caring about someone or something. The exception is when it's used in the negative, like 構わない (I don't mind). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you care a lot about grammar? I don't care, unless it has to do with commas (かま). Then I do flip out.
2946 | 捉える | とらえる | To Catch | To Grasp\n To Perceive\n To Captivate | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means catch so the verb version is to catch.\nTry to remember the mnemonic from the kanji with this one, because this word isn't used for physically catching things, but for ideas or meanings that you are able to grasp, metaphorically speaking. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
2947 | 渡る | わたる | To Cross | To Cross Over\n To Go Across | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, which is just another word for crossing through or crossing over. That's why this word is to cross or to cross over. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2948 | 響く | ひびく | To Echo | To Reverberate\n To Resound | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means echo so the verb is to echo. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing... He be (ひび) echoing...
2949 | 居る | いる | To Exist | To Be | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means alive and the verb version means to exist or to be, for anything that is alive and moving, like people and animals.\nThe kanji isn't used too often for this word, so when you're writing just use the kana. But you'll see the kanji used sometimes so it's important to be able to recognize it! \n Do you know the word いる? This is the kanji version! If you've been studying Japanese up to this point you probably already know that word. You can associate these two things together into one and remember the reading at the same time!
2950 | 掛ける | かける | To Hang Something | To Hang Up Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hang so the verb vocab version is to hang something or to hang up something (as in to hang it up by a hook).\nYou can remember this because you must care (ける) about the way you hang something up. Without care, it won't stay hanging for long. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
2951 | 隠す | かくす | To Hide Something | To Conceal Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hide and the verb vocab version is to hide something or to conceal something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Hide your cock (かく)! You have a ton of roosters but you don't want people to know about them, so you gotta hide your cocks. What did you think I was talking about?
2952 | 含む | ふくむ | To Include | To Contain | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means include so the verb vocab version is to include or to contain.\nWhile 含む can be used in everyday conversation, it’s a relatively formal word that is generally used in explanatory sentences. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThey don't want to include you in their game? Well, "F*** (ふく) you!" you yell at them, because they wouldn't include you.
2953 | 増す | ます | To Increase | To Grow | It's another verb with the kanji 増! This one means to increase too! But!\nJust like 増える, this is when something is just increasing on its own. You can use this word to talk about an increase in number, quantity, or degree, but it’s more literary and less common than 増える, except when referring to an increase in degree. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat increases with time? Your love for your mama (ま)! Your love for her will grow and grow the older you get! I love you, mama!
2954 | 限る | かぎる | To Limit | To Be Limited | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means limit so the verb vocab version is to limit. It is often used in the passive form 限られる, which means to be limited, implying that the limiting is being done by someone else.\nThis is a formal word used to define the limits of time, space, or quantity, or to set restrictions on things. It is also used casually when emphasizing something in particular or considering something to be the best. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: to limit things, you have something called a car (か) guillotine (ぎ) which you drive around limiting everything with.
2955 | 見渡す | みわたす | To Look Out Over | To Survey\n To Glance Over | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji mean see and transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are going to transit your eyes over an area to take in what you see. So you're really going to look out over everything. This word is usually used when you're looking at landscapes or a really large area. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
2956 | 今更 | いまさら | Too Late | Now | Now isn’t good enough for renewal. It’s already too late. The time has passed now. \n You might be tempted to read this with on’yomi, but this is actually 今 and 更に put together, just without the に particle at the end. Try to remember it in this way, or just make a mental note to use kun’yomi here!
2957 | 頑張る | がんばる | To Persevere | To Do One's Best | 張る is to stretch. You're stubborn and want to stretch out what you're doing right now. Although you're stubborn, you keep doing it. You persevere. That's why this word is to persevere or to do one's best. \n The reading for this word is the reading for 頑 and 張る put together but the 張る part gets rendaku'd so keep that in mind.
2958 | 準備する | じゅんびする | To Prepare |  | You've seen that 準備 is preparations. This is the verb version, so you get yourself to prepare. \n The reading is the same as 準備.
2959 | 抜く | ぬく | To Pull Something Out | To Pluck | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pull out so the verb vocab version is to pull something out.\nThis word often implies that the pulling out requires force or effort. It's a pretty versatile word, and can also cover things like letting the air out of something, draining the water out of something, and even overtaking someone or pulling through difficulties. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Just go ahead and extract it out of your memory so you can use it here.
2960 | 問う | とう | To Question Something |  | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means problem and this verb means to question something. That's because when you want to get to the bottom of a problem, you question things.\nNote that this is a bit of a formal word, so watch out for the contexts it's used in! \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:\nIt's okay to question something, but you should be careful not to step on someone else's toes (と) by doing so. Questioning certain things can offend people, especially when they have strong feelings about it! So be careful about those toes.
2961 | 替える | かえる | To Replace | To Substitute\n To Switch\n To Exchange | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace so the verb vocab version is to replace. You know that you're doing the replacing because of the air (える). You're replacing the air as quickly as you can because if you don't you wouldn't be able to breathe in this small room.\n替える means to replace something with another item of the same kind or equivalent, rather than changing its state. Wondering how it differs from 代える? While 代える stresses that you’re using someone or something “in place of another,” 替える simply indicates the act of swapping one thing for another similar thing. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
2962 | 巻く | まく | To Roll | To Wind\n To Wrap\n To Coil | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scroll. But, you don't "to scroll." What do you do to scrolls, though? You roll them up, making this word "to roll."\nThis word can also mean to wind, like when winding thread or a watch, or to wrap when involving a rolling or coiling motion, like wrapping sushi in seaweed or wrapping a cozy scarf around your neck. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you are rolling up is your ma (ま). She's going wild again, so you throw her into a blanket and roll her up to hold her down.
2963 | 捜す | さがす | To Search For | To Seek | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means search so the verb vocab version is to search for or to seek. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're searching all around for a "sagger" (さが) on your body. This is a flap of skin that is sagging on your body really far, and you probably should get it removed.
2964 | 現す | あらわす | To Show | To Reveal | This is the transitive version of 現れる (to appear), so rather than something appearing on its own, you’re making it appear. So this word means to show or to reveal, but it’s usually used in set phrases like 姿を現す (to show up) or 正体を現す (to reveal one's true nature). \n Do you remember learning 現れる? This has the same exact pronunciation!
2965 | 収める | おさめる | To Store | To Achieve\n To Score | When you obtain something you need to keep it safe, so you decide to store it somewhere. Then you can always go back and look at the thing you managed to achieve or  to score, and no one can take it from you.\n収める means "to store" with an emphasis on placing something in their proper location. This nuance extends to convey a sense of accomplishment, such as "achieving a favorable outcome.” \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with 収まる, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:\nYou need to store all of the old saws (おさ). You were able to finish and to achieve everything you wanted with them, so it's time to put them away so they'll be safe.
2966 | 絞める | しめる | To Strangle |  | The kanji means strangle and this vocab is the verb version of that: to strangle. It’s usually used in the phrase 首を絞める, which also means “to strangle.”\nThere is another word, 絞る which means "to wring out" that looks very similar. You know that this one is "to strangle" because it has める sticking out of it. Imagine that in the mail (める) you get a letter that says "I'm going to strangle you!" When you get this in the mail, you know it's about strangling. \n The thing that is threatening to strangle you is actually a sheep (し)! The sheep comes to your house and says, "here's the sheep mail!" and then tries to strangle you. It puts its hard feet on your neck though it's pretty ineffective.
2967 | 訴える | うったえる | To Sue | To Accuse\n To Appeal\n To Complain | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sue so the verb vocab version is to sue. \n YOU TAKE (うった) MY THINGS, I AM GOING TO SUE YOU!
2968 | 補う | おぎなう | To Supplement | To Compensate For | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supplement so the verb vocab version is to supplement.\nNote that this word is generally considered relatively formal in tone. \n Oh, gee, now (おぎな) you're going to supplement it? That would have been helpful earlier. Might help to say "oh gee now" with a ぎ sound instead of "ji" sound out loud, too. This is a tricky reading, won't be learned too easily, so think about it a bit now.
2969 | 優れる | すぐれる | To Surpass | To Excel | This is the verb version of the kanji superior, so it means to surpass. Someone who is superior is always going to surpass and to excel beyond others. That's what makes them so superior in the first place!\nThis is a formal word that is often used in writing or formal speech. \n Remember how 今すぐ means "at once"? Well that's the key to surpassing others. You have to do everything 今すぐ!!!
2970 | 降ろす | おろす | To Take Down | To Launch\n To Drop\n To Lower\n To Bring Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned that 降りる means "to get off." This is when you're helping something else descend down from something, not when you yourself are getting down. So it means to take down or to lower. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you already learned. Go you!
2971 | 投票する | とうひょうする | To Vote |  | Throw a ballot in the ballot box to vote. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You may have to think back to some other words using 投 to remember the on'yomi reading, 投資 for example.
2972 | 絞る | しぼる | To Wring Out | To Squeeze\n To Narrow Down | You've learned that the kanji 絞 means strangle. 絞る, on the other hand, means to wring out or to squeeze something like a towel, or to narrow down ideas. \n Your friend wants to wring out a towel, but before she does so she bows (しぼ) to the towel to show her respect for it.
2973 | 家庭教師 | かていきょうし | Tutor | Coach\n Private Teacher | This is a combination of the words 家庭 and 教師. A "teacher" who only teaches when you're with your "family" is known as a tutor. They don't teach you at school, they're a private teacher that comes to your home to help you learn. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2974 | 鮮やか | あざやか | Vivid | Splendid\n Brilliant | Alright, so it's not quite the same, but something that is fresh is also vivid and splendid. I know those are a couple things I'd associate with freshness. Try to make the connection here before moving on. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This vivid and splendid fresh fish is MINE! You grab the other (あざ) one that's not as vivid and splendid. This one is mine.
2975 | 防水 | ぼうすい | Waterproof | Watertight | Something that prevents water is waterproof and watertight. Time to take a bath with my 防水 cell phone... \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2976 | 人狼 | じんろう | Werewolf |  | A person wolf  is a werewolf. This word is less common than 狼男, but it's used more and more thanks to the card game of the same name! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 狼 (wolf) yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that, as well as which on'yomi to use for 人:\nThere's a werewolf in front of you wearing  jeans and eating roe (じんろう). This is typical behavior for werewolves, as I'm sure you know.
2977 | 事故 | じこ | Accident | Mishap | An occurrence that only results because of circumstances is also called an accident. You didn't want this bad thing to happen, it was just an occurrence of circumstance! Everything aligned in the worst way.\n事故 is mostly used to refer to physical accidents, like traffic accidents (交通事故) or construction accidents (建設事故). Sometimes other kinds of mishaps get the 事故 label too, like broadcast mishaps (放送事故), where something inappropriate or unplanned happens on air. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2978 | 針医 | はりい | Acupuncturist |  | Needle medicine is when you stick needles into people to cure them. This is done via an acupuncturist. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 針 and the on'yomi reading for 医. You haven't learned this reading for 針 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you do acupuncture and stick a bunch of needles in your back it's going to look really hairy (はり). Needles look just like metal hairs when they're coming out of someone. Just picture hairy little needles all over your body and you'll never forget this reading!
2979 | 再度 | さいど | Again | A Second Time | Again with that occurrence? That occurrence has now happened again.\nNote that this word is relatively formal. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!
2980 | 独り | ひとり | Alone | Solitude\n Single | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nWhile 一人 simply means "one person," 独り carries a stronger sense of being alone, often with connotations of solitude. It can also mean someone is single (as in not married). \n The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude.
2981 | 間違い | まちがい | A Mistake | Mistake | We waited an interval of time, and at each interval it was different. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of mistake? \n Take the reading of 間 (ま from 間に合う) and 違う and you'll have the reading for this word too.
2982 | 獣 | けもの | Beast | A Beast | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nA beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.
2983 | 獣類 | じゅうるい | Beasts | Animals | Things that are of the beast type or animal type are within the beasts and animals category.\n獣類 refers to four-footed mammals with fur. It’s a technical term generally used in the fields of biology and zoology to categorize animals. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2984 | 大違い | おおちがい | Big Difference |  | 違い is difference, so a big one of those is a big difference. \n The reading is 違う plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.
2985 | 酒造 | しゅぞう | Brewing | Distilling | The act of alcohol creation is done via brewing and distilling. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2986 | 運河 | うんが | Canal |  | It can carry a river. It's a canal. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The か goes to が, probably while floating down said canal.
2987 | お祝い | おいわい | Celebration | Congratulatory Gift | This is the noun version of the kanji celebrate, so it means celebration!\nお祝い is also used to mean a congratulatory gift itself. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
2988 | 特徴 | とくちょう | Characteristic | Distinctive Feature | A special indication on something or yourself is a special characteristic. It's a distinctive feature that exists. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2989 | 比較 | ひかく | Comparison |  | A compare and contrast will give you a comparison of something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2990 | 株式会社 | かぶしきがいしゃ | Corporation |  | This company (会社) has done the ritual required to create stocks for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a corporation. \n The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version in romaji when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.
2991 | 気違い | きちがい | Crazy |  | Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually.\nWARNING: We're teaching you this word because it's used quite a bit still (especially online) and we want you to be able to understand it if you see it. But please keep in mind that this is considered to be a discriminatory word against people with mental illnesses, so we strongly recommend you do not use or direct this word toward anyone. Think of it like a really inappropriate swear word that makes you really uncool if you say it. Please!\nWhile you still see the kanji version, this word is commonly written in katakana. \n The reading is 気 plus 違い.
2992 | 創造 | そうぞう | Creation |  | Create! Create! If you do this, you are doing creation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2993 | 討論 | とうろん | Debate | Discussion | I'm going to  chastise you about this theory. When I do this, this is a debate. Doesn't it feel like you're being chastised when people are debating with you sometimes, especially with your own theories? I think so. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2994 | 独裁 | どくさい | Dictatorship | Despotism | When one person is in a position to judge everyone alone by themselves, they're definitely a part of a dictatorship. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
2995 | 直接 | ちょくせつ | Direct |  | I'm going to direct and adjoin the routes together. No more multiple stops. This is direct. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2996 | 障害 | しょうがい | Disability | Handicap\n Obstacle | There is damage that hinders you from doing things normally. This is a disability. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2997 | 創立 | そうりつ | Establishment | Founding | Create it and stand it up. This is your establishment, your founding. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2998 | 第一印象 | だいいちいんしょう | First Impression |  | The first (第一) phenomenon is what's sealed into your head. This is your first impression of something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
2999 | 占い | うらない | Fortune Telling |  | Although this has a い on the end it's tricky and not an adjective. The kanji is fortune, and the vocab word is fortune telling. \n I'm going to do some fortune telling on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on Uranus (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.
3000 | 万年筆 | まんねんひつ | Fountain Pen |  | The only kind of writing brush you can use for ten thousand years is a fountain pen! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3001 | 河豚 | ふぐ | Fugu | Blowfish\n Pufferfish | The river pig is what's known as fugu or blowfish. You may know it from our mascot and best friend, the Tofugu!\nBut why does "river pig" = fugu? It's true that fugu usually live in the ocean, but sometimes they make their way into rivers near the ocean too. The "pig" part probably comes from their round, puffed-up appearance. \n The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is ふぐ as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!
3002 | 怪談 | かいだん | Ghost Story | Horror Story | If you have a suspicious talk, you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a ghost story. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3003 | 怪獣 | かいじゅう | Giant Monster | Kaiju | Look at that suspicious beast... it's Godzilla, walking around looking suspicious. What is Godzilla? He is a giant monster. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3004 | 氷河 | ひょうが | Glacier |  | An ice river is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a glacier. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though. \n The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says heyo (ひょう). Note that the か becomes が here.
3005 | お誕生日おめでとう | おたんじょうびおめでとう | Happy Birthday |  | 誕生日 is birthday. おめでとう is like "congratulations." So, congratulations for your birthday is like happy birthday! \n The reading is the same as 誕生日, so if you know that you know this!
3006 | 我 | われ | I | Me\n Myself | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n我 is an old-fashioned pronoun and isn't commonly used outside of set phrases like 我を忘れる (to forget oneself or be utterly absorbed) or 我に返る (to come back to reality or return to one's senses). \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nIt is I! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-ware (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.
3007 | 輸入 | ゆにゅう | Import |  | The transport of things that enter your country are imports. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3008 | 独立 | どくりつ | Independence | Being Autonomous\n Independent | Alone I stand. I have independence!\n独立 often implies both being autonomous and independent. While it can also refer to self-reliance, it's more commonly associated with political independence or independence from organizations. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3009 | 人差し指 | ひとさしゆび | Index Finger | Pointer Finger | Your person distinction finger is the finger you use to point at people to distinguish them from other people. This is your pointer finger... your index finger. \n The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word 人, the word 差す, and the word 指. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.
3010 | 間接 | かんせつ | Indirect |  | After an interval of time it will adjoin, but not right away. That is because it was being indirect. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3011 | 激しい | はげしい | Intense | Violent\n Fierce | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fierce and violent? Fierce and violent! That's intense. \n What is fierce and violent? That old hag (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!
3012 | 故意 | こい | Intentional | On Purpose\n Deliberate | The circumstance was caused by the idea I had. Because I had this idea before the circumstance, it shows I was intentional in doing it. I did it on purpose.\nNote that 故意 is mostly used in formal contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Now you're showing it, so we can begin the real interview.\n面接 generally refers to a job interview or an oral examination. 3014 | 河童 | かっぱ | Kappa |  | A river juvenile... not what you think. It's a kappa, a mythological Japanese creature. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.

You get a lot of junk mail so you throw it in the waste bin (びん). The waste bin is where junk mail goes.

While 人工 means "artificial" in general, 人造 specifically refers to something that is produced or constructed by humans. It's not as commonly used as 人工 and is often found in creative writing when talking about 人造人間 (androids). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 3038 | 河 | かわ | River | Large River | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n河 originally referred to the Yellow River in ancient China, so it's usually associated with very large rivers. 河 is a lot less common than 川, but you might still find it in literature, where it can emphasize the grand and powerful nature of a river or its cultural significance. \n The reading is the same like the word 川 which has the same meaning. Associate the two to remember!

3040 | 給与 | きゅうよ | Salary | Wages\n Pay\n Compensation | The salary I give you is your salary, or wages. It is the pay you earn.\nCurious about the difference between 給与 and 給料? 給与 is generally considered the formal version of 給料, but there is another minor difference in nuance. 給料 often refers to your base pay, while 給与 refers to the total amount of compensation you receive, including overtime, bonuses, etc. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

3047 | 障子 | しょうじ | Shoji Screen | Japanese Sliding Door\n Shoji | It can hinder a child, but that's about it. This is a shoji screen, which is a type of Japanese sliding door. They're lightweight and designed to let in some natural light. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 子 is changed from し to じ, though, so be careful.
