3060 | 象徴 | しょうちょう | Symbol |  | A phenomenon of some kind that's an indication of something else is a symbol. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3061 | 教授 | きょうじゅ | Teaching | Professor | If you teach and instruct then you are doing teaching. Who does teaching? A professor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3062 | 替わる | かわる | To Be Replaced | To Be Substituted\n To Be Switched | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace, and this word means to be replaced, to be substituted, and to be switched.\nWondering about the difference between 代わる and 替わる? 代わる is used when someone or something takes the place of another, like filling in for a sick coworker. Whereas 替わる is used when things or situations switch places or are replaced with something new, like when talking about generations changing or a new governmental cabinet taking over.\nThis verb is intransitive, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. You'll sometimes see it with the particle を, though, because the を is showing a "path" rather than a direct object in this case. For example, 席を替わる (to switch seats) indicates your location is moving from one seat to another. Likewise, 電話を替わる indicates that a call is being handed off to another person. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
3063 | 燃える | もえる | To Burn | To Be On Fire | Remember how 燃やす means "to burn something" or "to set on fire”? Well, 燃える is the version that means to burn or to be on fire. You might say that paper and wood 燃える easily, for example. And if your house is 燃えている, you're in trouble.\nYou can remember this slightly different meaning for 燃える because of the える part, which refers to the letter "L." And the "L" stands for "love" — as in your passionate, burning love for kanji. \n The reading is the same as the word 燃やす.
3064 | 燃え付く | もえつく | To Catch Fire | To Catch On Fire | When something attaches a burn to something that something is about to catch fire. \n This is the readings of 燃える and 付く put together.
3065 | 造る | つくる | To Construct | To Build\n To Make\n To Brew | The kanji means create, and this word is for the creation of big things. So it means to construct or to build or to make, and it's usually used with ships, bridges, buildings, and other large-scale work.\nIt can also mean to brew, as in brewing sake. I guess brewing is like constructing, since it involves carefully choosing and mixing ingredients to get those sip-worthy creations! \n The reading is like 作る, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use 作る to help you to remember the reading of this word.
3066 | 涼む | すずむ | To Cool Oneself | To Cool Off | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cool (temperature-wise) and the verb vocab version is to cool oneself or to cool off. Whoo, that feels much cooler now. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this one too.\nIf you need a refresher, remember that the Sue Zoo (すず) was made for the penguin Sue to cool off in, even when it's hot outside.
3067 | 届ける | とどける | To Deliver |  | 届く is "to be delivered." This word is when you're doing the actual delivering, making it to deliver. You can remember this because you care (ける) about the package so much that you deliver it yourself, thus doing the action of delivering it! \n The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.
3068 | 差別する | さべつする | To Discriminate |  | 差別 is discrimination. This is the verb version, to discriminate. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3069 | 励ます | はげます | To Encourage Someone | To Cheer Up Someone\n To Encourage | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encourage and the verb vocab version is to encourage someone (or to encourage). \n Think about encouraging a hag (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.
3070 | 任せる | まかせる | To Entrust Something | To Delegate Something\n To Leave Something To | If you pass a duty on to someone, that means you're going to entrust something to that person, or you're going to delegate something. In other words, you're going to leave something to them, so that they do it for you. \n This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn order to entrust something to someone, you need to make a (まか) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?
3071 | 検討する | けんとうする | To Examine | To Study\n To Consider | You examine it but you also chastise it, because you want to make sure this examining is correct. This is to examine or to study. All require chastising things to be sure for sure.\n検討する generally implies thoroughly examining something to consider its pros and cons, suitability, or viability. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3072 | 輸出する | ゆしゅつする | To Export |  | Remember how 輸出 is an export? This is the verb, so this is to export. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the word 輸出.
3073 | 栄える | さかえる | To Flourish | To Prosper | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means flourish or prosper, so the verb vocab versions of these would be to flourish or to prosper. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing soccer (さか) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.
3074 | 差し上げる | さしあげる | To Give | To Raise Up | This is a really humble and polite way to say "to give," probably because you're lowering yourself down and raising the item above your head so far that you have to point at it because if you were touching it you'd be defiling it anyways so, you know, point at it and raise it way up, you little worm on the ground. \n The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.
3075 | 渡す | わたす | To Hand Over | To Ferry Something Across\n To Lay Something Across | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit. It's also in the verb 渡る, which means "to cross." But with 渡す, it's more like you're sending something across instead, usually to another person. So 渡す means to hand over.\nIt can also mean to ferry something across a river, or to lay something across an expanse, like when you lay a plank over a pothole or build a bridge across a river.\nTo remember the す in 渡す, think of suing someone. When you sue (す) them, you have to hand over the papers to let them know you're suing. If you don't 渡す the papers, you can't sue! \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
3076 | 障る | さわる | To Irritate | To Annoy\n To Negatively Affect\n To Be Bad For | This is the verb version of hinder, but it's what happens when you hinder someone else enough. You'll start to irritate and to annoy them.\nNote that this word isn't used by itself, but in phrases like 気に障る (to hurt one's feelings) or 体に障る (to be bad for one's health). Check out the Common Word Combinations for more examples! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you want to irritate me, all you have to do is make what I'm eating sour (さわ). Did you know sour food is known to be bad for you, too? Don't make that sour face, stop eating sour things!
3077 | 狭める | せばめる | To Narrow Something | To Narrow Down Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means narrow, so the verb version is to narrow something or to narrow down something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to narrow the width of something. The only way you can do that is to sever (せば) off each end. Maybe you're trying to get a sofa up a tight stairway. The only way to do that is by severing off each arm to narrow it.
3078 | 従う | したがう | To Obey | To Follow | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obey so the verb vocab version is to obey. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nI am going to obey you. I think your order is a bit of shit が (したが), I'll do it and obey you.\n(Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)
3079 | 占める | しめる | To Occupy | To Account For | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means occupy so the verb version is to occupy. \n What is it you want to occupy most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of sheep (し). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!
3080 | 過ごす | すごす | To Pass Time | To Spend Time | 過ぎる means "to pass," and 過ごす is to pass time.\n過ごす refers to how you live through or experience your time. So it usually needs some extra context when you use it, like what you do while passing time, who you pass it with, or what was it like. Check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word! \n The reading is the same as  過ぎる. If you know it, it's OK to pass time relaxing for a bit! If you don’t know it, maybe it's good to spend time reviewing…
3081 | 載せる | のせる | To Place On Something | To Put On Something\n To Put On Record | Remember how 載る is "to be placed on"? This one is to place on something, like a mug on a table. 載せる is transitive, and you know this because you do it yourself (せる). Like 載る, 載せる also often refers to putting something in a written document or publication, so it can mean to put on record.\nNote that 載せる is never used to refer to putting clothing or accessories on. That's 着る or 着ける respectively, which you've learned already. \n The reading is shared with 載る, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.
3082 | 振る | ふる | To Shake Something | To Wave Something\n To Swing Something\n To Break Up With Someone | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means to shake something, to wave something, or to swing something. You'll often see it paired with 手, as in 手を振る, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave".\nThis word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way, as in to break up with someone. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSomeone is trying to shake something. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally full (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).
3083 | 担う | になう | To Take Responsibility | To Assume Responsibility\n To Take On A Burden | 担ぐ is more like when you're carrying something physical. 担う is when you carry a responsibility, which is why this word means to assume responsibility. You can remember this because YOU (う) are responsible for this. You assume this responsibility.\nNote that 担う is generally used with another word that specifies the responsibility, like 役割を担う (assume a role) or 未来を担う (bear the future). \n What is your responsibility? To raise this girl named Nina (にな).
3084 | 触れる | ふれる | To Touch | To Come Into Contact With\n To Touch On | 触る means "to touch," and 触れる also means to touch. The word also means to touch on, as in touching on some subject. Just think of a subject that is rare (れる) for you to want to touch on.\n触れる is often for when something happens to come into contact with something, possibly in a fleeting or momentary way. It's still used in phrases like "When I touched your hand," but has a lighter, more indirect and literary feel than 触る, which conveys a greater sense of purpose and intent behind the action.\n触れる is often used in constructions like 手がカバンに触れる (one's hand touches a bag), where が indicates what's doing the touching and に marks what's being touched. If you see を instead of が, 触れる becomes transitive, changing the meaning to "to have your hand touch a bag." \n The reading is totally different from 触る so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some fur (ふれ).
3085 | 独特 | どくとく | Unique | Peculiar | It is alone and special. Nothing is like it. It is very unique and peculiar. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3086 | 従来 | じゅうらい | Up To Now | Convention\n Conventionally | You've obeyed all that has come up to now. That's because it's the conventional way of doing things, and it's what's conventionally expected of you.\nThis word is a relatively formal way to talk about how things have been up to now. It's commonly used with の to modify a noun or phrase, or as an adverb. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3087 | 自販機 | じはんき | Vending Machine |  | Remember the super long vending machine that is 自動販売機? This is a shorter easier to remember and say version. Basically every other kanji is removed, making it 自販機. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know 自動販売機 already.
3088 | 獣医 | じゅうい | Veterinarian | Vet | One who does beast medicine is a veterinarian, taking care of all them animals. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3089 | 振動 | しんどう | Vibration | Oscillation | The movement that has to do with shakes is vibration and oscillation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3090 | 違反 | いはん | Violation | Transgression\n Breach | If you're anti- something in a way that's different from the norm then you'll be in violation of the law! The laws that the "not" different people made. Either way, those people will give you a hard time for your anti-stance against the thing they like, and say it's a transgression. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 違 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you find yourself in violation of the law just pull out your pet eagle (い). Eagles are so majestic, they'll forget all about your transgression and let you go. If you're going to go be anti-something make sure you bring that eagle. People seem to care more about animals than other people like that.
3091 | 気象庁 | きしょうちょう | Weather Agency | Meteorological Agency | The energy phenomenon agency sounds like something that could be really cool but it's really just the weather agency or meteorological agency. Nothing shady going on here. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3092 | 何故 | なぜ | Why | How | When you want to know what the circumstances are around you, you have to ask why. Why do things happen around you? Asking why is very important if you want to understand the world. \n The reading for this is an exception. The reading for 何 is just the first な from なに. You can remember the second part this way:\nNo one knows quite how or why that big zeppelin (ぜ) crashed in the 1930s. People are still asking today and no one has any answers. We have to keep asking until we get some.
3093 | 野獣 | やじゅう | Wild Beast | Wild Animal | A field beast/animal is one that lives outside and not under human care. It is a wild beast / wild animal. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3094 | 筆 | ふで | Writing Brush | Paintbrush\n Brush | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: For as long as you can remember, your family and another family has had a bloody feud (ふで) over this one writing brush. Just think of all the people killed over this brush. This feud has to end.
3095 | 健忘症 | けんぼうしょう | Amnesia | Memory Loss\n Forgetfulness | A healthy bit of forgetting symptoms means you might have amnesia.\n健忘症 often refers to short-term memory loss, either full or partial, but some people might also use it in a sort of joking way for everyday forgetfulness. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3096 | 南極 | なんきょく | Antarctica |  | The extreme south is the extreme of south. It's about as south as you can go. That place is known as Antarctica. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3097 | 取り決め | とりきめ | Arrangement | Agreement | You've taken a decision from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of arrangement with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The 取り comes from 取る and the 決め comes from 決める. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi とりきめ!
3098 | 訪問 | ほうもん | A Visit | Visit | A visit problem is when someone makes a visit, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why a visit is a visit problem. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3099 | 悩み | なやみ | A Worry | A Trouble | This is the noun version of worry, making it a worry, or a trouble. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have a worry about it.
3100 | 悪影響 | あくえいきょう | Bad Influence | Negative Impact\n Harmful Effect | 影響 is "influence," so an evil influence is a bad influence. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3101 | 野郎 | やろう | Bastard |  | Ugh, that field guy. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the bastard. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3102 | 腹 | はら | Belly | Abdomen\n Stomach | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n If anyone ever tries to touch your belly make sure you yell "Sekuhara (はら)! Sekuhara!” Sekuhara is short for sexual harassment in Japan. And if you don't want someone to touch your belly, but they're trying to, then that's sekuhara!
3103 | 退屈 | たいくつ | Boring | Boredom\n Tedious | I retreat! I yield! I can't take it anymore, it's so boring. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3104 | 両替 | りょうがえ | Change Money | Money Exchange\n Currency Exchange | Coins? Bills? Both can be replaced if you want to change money at this money exchange. Just don’t do your currency exchange at the airport — the rates aren’t so great.\nYou'll probably see this word the most in arcades where you can go to the 両替 machine and get coins to feed your crane game addiction. \n The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being か (it changes to が for the rendaku), it is がえ. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your guy (がえ).
3105 | 着替え | きがえ | Change Of Clothes | Spare Clothes | You know how 替える is "to replace"? Well, you're replacing what you wear. That's a change of clothes, or spare clothes. \n The reading is 着る and 替える put together. The か goes to が.
3106 | 手掛かり | てがかり | Clue | A Clue | It was a hand which hangs the things we're looking for: a clue! Clues really are usually put down by people quite often. Or, perhaps, think of a hand hanging on something as your clue. \n The reading is 手 plus 掛かる put together. Just watch out for that rendaku.
3107 | 腰抜け | こしぬけ | Coward |  | You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If your waist falls out, you can't remain standing. You have to curl up on the ground, like a coward. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!
3108 | 濃い | こい | Dense | Thick\n Deep\n Strong | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning it's probably an adjective. The kanji means dense, and this can also mean dense or thick in some contexts, like if you’re describing fog, or body hair! More generally, it can be used for anything that’s highly concentrated, so you can use it for things like deep colors, or strong coffee too! \n What’s the most dense thing you can think of? A 子 (こ). Children are so full of joy, you can practically see how dense, thick and concentrated the joy is.
3109 | 濃度 | のうど | Density | Concentration | When something is dense to a certain degree, you’re talking about the density or concentration of something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3110 | お構いなく | おかまいなく | Don't Mind Me | Without Regard For | Remember how 構う is "to care about"? You can convert it into お構いなく to politely tell someone not to care about you. So this means, don't mind me.\nIt can also mean without regard for, especially when someone keeps doing something without caring about other people, their surroundings, or unfavorable conditions. \n The reading comes from 構う, so if you know that you know this!
3111 | 頑張れ | がんばれ | Do Your Best | Hang In There\n Good Luck | Remember 頑張る means “to persevere” or “to do one’s best”? This time you're telling someone to 頑張る, so this word means something like do your best, hang in there, or good luck! Speaking of which, 頑張れ, you! \n The reading comes from 頑張る.
3112 | 端 | はし | Edge | End\n Corner | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.\n端 refers to the edge or end of something, like the edge of a table, the far end of a bridge, or even the corner of a page. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nIf you're on edge, just eat some hash (はし) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!
3113 | 効果的 | こうかてき | Effective |  | Remember how 効果 means "effect"? Add ~like to that and it's effective! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3114 | 限定販売 | げんていはんばい | Exclusive Sale | Limited Offer\n Sell Exclusively | When a 限定 (limit) is applied to 販売 (selling), it’s a sort of exclusive sale or limited offer.\n限定販売 is a sales strategy where companies limit the availability of their products to certain regions, stores, time frames, or club members. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3115 | 極端 | きょくたん | Extreme |  | At the extreme edge, which is just the extreme.\n極端 means something is taken to the extreme without moderation, so it generally has a negative connotation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3116 | 就職 | しゅうしょく | Finding Employment | Getting A Job | Getting a position of employment means finding employment, or getting a job. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3117 | 栄光 | えいこう | Glory |  | You helped your city prosper, and a light shines out of you, so that the entire city can bask in your glory.\nDon't confuse this with 光栄! With that one, light is shining on you, and you receive honor from it. With this, you made things prosper and the light came after, making you look glorious. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3118 | 段々 | だんだん | Gradually | Steps | Step by step. If you take things step by step, you're moving up gradually, taking steps.\n段々 is often used to describe gradual progress. But sometimes you'll see it used for terraced fields or buildings too, since they sorta resemble steps! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3119 | 中途半端 | ちゅうとはんぱ | Half Finished | Half Assed | Take the middle route, half to the edge. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really half finished and half assed of you. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぱ at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just think of your ol' Pa (ぱ), who is the biggest half-asser you know.
3120 | 頭痛 | ずつう | Headache |  | Head pain is when you have a headache. \n The reading for 痛 should be okay. The reading for 頭 isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the zoo (ず) you get a terrible headache. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.
3121 | 健康 | けんこう | Health | Healthy | You're so healthy it puts you at ease. That's your health! So healthful, go you! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3122 | 間抜け | まぬけ | Idiot | Dumb | You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If an interval of time falls out of you, you're totally spaced out. You won't learn anything and you'll become an idiot.\n間抜け can refer to both a person who does something foolish and to the foolish actions themselves. It's often used to criticize dumb behavior. \n The readings come from the ま reading of 間 and from 抜く.
3123 | 不眠症 | ふみんしょう | Insomnia |  | The not sleep symptom shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is insomnia. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3124 | 居酒屋 | いざかや | Izakaya | Japanese Style Bar | An alive alcohol shop is a place that does a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often izakaya, or, if you don't know Izakaya already from English, you can consider it to be a Japanese Style Bar. \n The readings here are all kun'yomi, but this is the first time you've seen the さか reading for 酒, which rendaku then turns into ざか in this word! If you know what an izakaya is already, it will help you to remember the reading, but if not here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAfter soccer (さか) practice, you always go to your favorite izakaya!
3125 | 昇進 | しょうしん | Job Promotion | Promotion | Ascend and advance! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new job promotion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3126 | 景観 | けいかん | Landscape | Cityscape\n Scenery | Quite the scene, this view is. So what you're looking at is a landscape. This often refers to a cityscape or the general scenery of an area.\nThis is a formal word that’s commonly used in the context of urban planning or environmental design. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3127 | 大規模 | だいきぼ | Large Scale |  | Remember how 規模 is scale? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a large scale. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3128 | 早退 | そうたい | Leave Early |  | An early retreat means that you leave early.\nNote that 早退 means leaving school or work earlier than usual. It's not used for leaving hangouts or parties early. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3129 | お任せ | おまかせ | Leaving Decisions To Someone Else | Chef's Choice\n Omakase | This word comes from 任せる, but without the る on the end it's a noun. You also have the honorific お on the beginning, which is a clue that you're addressing someone else. So you're entrusting something to the person you're talking to, and this means leaving decisions to someone else. This is used a lot in restaurants, where it means chef's choice or simply omakase. In other words, you're leaving the choice of food to the chef.\nIt can be used in other contexts, too, like if you leave your haircut up to your stylist or a flower arrangement up to the florist, or even if you follow the recommended program at the gym. \n You learned this reading with the word 任せる, so I'll leave this one to you.
3130 | 居間 | いま | Living Room | Sitting Room | A room that comes alive in intervals is your living room, or sitting room. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes.\nNote that 居間 is a little old-fashioned. These days, the more common word for a living room is リビングルーム. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
3131 | 理屈 | りくつ | Logic | Reasoning\n Argument | Reason yields to logic and more reasoning.\n理屈 can be neutral, but it often has negative connotations too, like when it refers to an argument that contains questionable logic, pretexts, or too much pedantry. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3132 | 迷子 | まいご | Lost Child | Lost Person\n Stray Animal | A child that's astray is a lost child. Help them home, don't invite them into your windowless van, please. \n The reading for 迷 is an exceptional reading. The ご comes from こ. Think of the まい as the child asking: "Where is my (まい) mommy???"
3133 | 迷路 | めいろ | Maze |  | A road where you're astray is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a maze. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3134 | 再来月 | さらいげつ | Month After Next | The Month After Next | The next month (来月) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it again. That month is the month after next. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3135 | 結構です | けっこうです | No Thank You | No Thanks | 結構 is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say no thank you to someone trying to offer you something. \n The reading comes from 結構.
3136 | 客観的 | きゃっかんてき | Objective |  | Remember 主観的 meaning "subjective"? This is the counterpart to that. And since guests' and customers' views are always objectively right, this means objective. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3137 | 途中 | とちゅう | On The Way | En Route\n In The Middle Of\n Half Done | If you're on a route, right in the middle, you're on the way or en route.\n途中 can also be used figuratively to say you're in the middle of doing something or something is half done. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3138 | 組織 | そしき | Organization |  | A group that's weaved together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an organization. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 組, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nYou start an organization for soap (そ). You're all about soap and making it more effective through your organization. So you call it the Soap Organization for Antiseptic Progress, or S.O.A.P. for short.
3139 | 痛い | いたい | Painful | Sore | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pain? It's painful.\n痛い is commonly used to say that some part of the body hurts or feels sore. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An eater (いた) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's painful to eat.
3140 | 昇給 | しょうきゅう | Pay Raise | Getting A Raise | When you ascend in salary you get a pay raise at work.\nNote that this is a relatively formal word to talk about getting a raise. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3141 | 迫害 | はくがい | Persecution | Oppression | Your urge is to damage things. You are always trying to commit persecution onto others. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3142 | 支度 | したく | Preparation | Getting Ready | To support yourself to some degree, you need preparation. Doing your hair and makeup in the morning supports your presentation to some extent, right?\nThis is another word for "preparation" besides 準備 and 用意. They’re all similar, but 支度 is usually used in personal contexts, such as 身支度 (getting dressed) or 旅支度 (getting ready for a trip). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 度 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember them together:\nIn preparation for getting sheared, a sheep will sit on a tack (したく). This sheep tacking makes it so that the shearing part is nothing! Imagine watching some sheep getting ready by sitting on tacks. Yikes. You want to tell them being sheared doesn't hurt and that sheep tacking is worse, but something makes you think they won't listen to you.
3143 | 圧迫 | あっぱく | Pressure | Constriction\n Oppression | The pressure is urged upon you. It's the pressure, so much pressure!\n圧迫 refers to a tight pressure caused by strong compression, or to the act of pressing down itself. Figuratively, it can also mean constriction, like tuition fees putting a strain on a household budget, or oppression, such as people being subjugated. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The あつ turns into a small っ, and はく goes to ぱく.
3144 | 値段 | ねだん | Price | Cost | The value is in various steps. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a price or cost.\n値段 refers to the price attached to something you can buy, like in stores or markets. For example, you could use 値段 to ask how much something costs at a shop or when talking about the price of a particular meal. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading for 値 plus the on'yomi reading for 段. Combine them together to get the reading here. You've learned both of these readings already, so just remember 値 is ね because you neigh (ね) when you see a good price.
3145 | 貸し切り | かしきり | Private Reservation |  | The lending gets cut right away when you make a private reservation.\n貸し切り means reserving a space exclusively, like renting out a restaurant for a birthday party or chartering a bus, cruise, or jet. \n It's the reading of 貸す and 切る put together. Know those two readings and you know this one as well. Sometimes you'll see this word as 貸切り or 貸切 as well.
3146 | 建前 | たてまえ | Public Behavior | Public Stance\n Social Niceties | We all build up something in front of ourselves. It's the front we present to the world, the public behavior, public stance and social niceties that maintain harmony.\n建前 is very important in Japan. For example, you might find yourself invited to an acquaintance's home out of courtesy, with the expectation that you’ll decline (also out of courtesy!). A host of a party may say "just bring yourself," but guests know this could be 建前, and considering their own 建前, they bring a small gift anyways.  People can also be reluctant to say "no" to things, like drinks with coworkers when they really want to go home, and may not to show it when they find situations inconvenient or unpleasant. So you might need some guesswork to peek behind the 建前 that people build up in front of themselves! \n The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like 建物 in that it's read as たて, which is like the word 建てる even though the て isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like 建てる but the て gets pushed into the kanji.
3147 | 長靴 | ながぐつ | Rain Boots | Rubber Boots\n Riding Boots | Long shoes aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long to keep you dry when it's raining. Yes, these are rain boots.\nIn modern Japanese, 長靴 is most commonly used to mean rain boots or rubber boots. It can occasionally mean riding boots as well. But if you're referring to fashion boots or boots in general, you can just call them ブーツ. \n The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of 長い and 靴 getting added together. 靴 is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.
3148 | 引退 | いんたい | Retiring | Retirement\n Withdrawing From Public Life | When you pull yourself back and retreat, you're retiring. At some point in everyone's lives you just can't do it anymore and it's time to take your retirement.\nThis word focuses on the moment of retiring. It's often used to mean withdrawing from public life, when someone ends their career in a particular field, like when celebrities or pro athletes retire. It can also be used for students who stop extracurricular activities like clubs and sports teams ahead of graduation, often to study for their exams. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nNow that you're retiring, you decide to go and spend your retirement at an inn (いん). Inns are great places to spend your retirement because everything is done for you, and you can just sit back and relax!
3149 | 巻きずし | まきずし | Rolled Sushi | Sushi Roll\n Makizushi | 巻く is "to roll." ずし is すし. This is rolled sushi. \n The reading comes from 巻く.
3150 | 誘惑 | ゆうわく | Seduction | Temptation | You're being invited, but you're also being misguided. This is seduction that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing!\nThis word also translates to temptation, but keep in mind that 誘惑’s focus is more on an external factor that entices someone into succumbing to temptation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3151 | 切腹 | せっぷく | Seppuku | Ritual Suicide | When you cut your abdomen you are committing seppuku aka ritual suicide. It will help if you already know the word "seppuku" from English, as it is the reading. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But it's got shortening and rendaku going on, so you have to remember those if you want to get it right. Or just know the word seppuku already since it's pretty popular. That works too.
3152 | 靴 | くつ | Shoes |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!
3153 | 靴屋 | くつや | Shoe Store | Shoe Shop\n Shoemaker's Shop | A shoes shop is one that sells shoes. It's a shoe store or shoe shop. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
3154 | 睡眠 | すいみん | Sleep |  | Feeling drowsy and like I want to sleep. I just want to sleep so bad. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3155 | 眠い | ねむい | Sleepy |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sleep? It's sleepy. \n You're so sleepy you can't even remember your own name (ねむ).
3156 | 小規模 | しょうきぼ | Small Scale |  | 規模 is "scale." This is a small one, making this small scale. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3157 | 靴下 | くつした | Socks |  | What's below your shoes? Your socks. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!
3158 | 暇 | ひま | Spare Time | Free Time\n Not Busy | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n暇 means the spare time or free time you have when you're not busy with work, school, or other obligations. It can also indicate a slow period for a business or a time when you have nothing to do, often suggesting a sense of boredom. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nIn your spare time you like to drink hima (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.
3159 | 春巻き | はるまき | Spring Rolls |  | 巻く is "to roll up." If you roll up spring, you get a roll that's spring flavored. These are known as spring rolls. \n The readings come from 春 and 巻く.
3160 | 段階 | だんかい | Stage | Phase | The current step of the floor is at the second stage. Now it's at the third stage. Now it's in the final phase! Nice! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3161 | 階段 | かいだん | Stairs | Stairway | The floor that makes up the steps are the stairs. Don't get this confused with the similar word 段階, which is the stairs making up the floors to a certain stage. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3162 | 胃 | い | Stomach |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nJust keep in mind 胃 is specifically for the internal organ "stomach," not for the general abdominal area "stomach." \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
3163 | 胃痛 | いつう | Stomachache |  | When your stomach hurts you have yourself a little stomachache.\nTry to remember this isn't for general abdominal pain. 胃痛 is specifically for pain or discomfort in the stomach (the internal organ) — a literal stomachache. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3164 | 迷信 | めいしん | Superstition |  | Led astray in what you believe by all these superstitions. These superstitions will lead you astray, don't believe them! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3165 | 供給 | きょうきゅう | Supply | Supplying | Your servant gets a nice salary because the supply of available servants is so small these days. Lucky him!\n供給 is a somewhat formal word you’d generally hear in the context of economics or supply and demand. You wouldn’t use it for art supplies or the food you buy every day. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3166 | 症状 | しょうじょう | Symptom |  | Your symptom condition is your symptoms that you have. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3167 | 〜症 | しょう | Syndrome | Disease | Multiple symptoms combine to make a syndrome. If you see this at the end of a word, you know it means "______ syndrome," or else indicates some kind of health condition.\n〜症 is used in medical terms for certain health conditions, symptoms, or syndromes, like 熱中症 (heatstroke) or 認知症 (dementia). \n Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.
3168 | 第一段 | だいいちだん | The First Step | First Step | 第一 means "the first," and 段 is a step. So, this is the first step. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3169 | 先端 | せんたん | Tip | The Latest\n Cutting Edge | The previous (or ahead) edge is the tip of something, like your finger or your chopsticks. It's also a word used to describe the latest (technology, etc), because it's on the cutting edge. The tip! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3170 | 逮捕する | たいほする | To Arrest | To Capture\n To Apprehend | Remember how 逮捕 is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is to arrest or to capture. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word 逮捕 already as well.
3171 | 従える | したがえる | To Be Accompanied By | To Have In Tow\n To Take Along | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means obey, but the verb meaning is a bit different. In most contexts, it often just means to be accompanied by someone or to have in tow. To help you remember this, imagine that everyone you're accompanied by obeys you! You're sort of their leader, so you go everywhere with them following in tow.\n従える is a relatively formal word that's often used in literature. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 従う. Remember it?
3172 | 退院する | たいいんする | To Be Discharged | To Leave The Hospital | Time to retreat from the institution. Basically, you are leaving an institution, particularly institutions like hospitals, asylums, etc. When you are leaving one of these places, it means you are to be discharged. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3173 | 隠れる | かくれる | To Be Hidden |  | 隠す is "to hide." 隠れる is to be hidden. You know that this is the version where something is hidden (and you're not doing the hiding) because it is rare (れる) that you ever find something that has been hidden (not by you). \n The reading is the same as 隠す. So as long as you know that you know this as well.
3174 | 掛かる | かかる | To Be Hung | To Be Hooked\n To Be Caught | Remember how 掛ける is "to hang something"? 掛かる is the intransitive version where something just hangs. At some point it decided to be hung, and now it's hanging there. You know this because there is a car (かる) hanging there on the wall. You certainly didn't hang it, that would be impossible. It's just hanging by itself.\nThis word can also mean to be hooked, both for the car that got hooked to the wall and for the fish that happened to be caught on a hook. \n The reading is the same as 掛ける, so as long as you know that you know this too.
3175 | 属する | ぞくする | To Belong To | To Fall Under | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means belong so the verb vocab version is to belong to.\n属する is a formal term for describing someone or something’s belonging to or being part of a group, category or classification. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going to belong to you.
3176 | 屈む | かがむ | To Bend Down | To Crouch\n To Duck\n To Squat | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yield, and 屈む means to bend down or to crouch. After all, bending down and crouching are sort of like yielding to gravity, don’t you think?\n屈む refers to the act of lowering your head or body, so it can also mean to duck or to squat depending on the context. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou always have to bend down to get into your car garage (かが) because you’re just too tall. You have to crouch just to get inside your car garage! Let’s hope you can find a bigger one someday.
3177 | 捕える | とらえる | To Catch | To Capture\n To Seize\n To Grab | Remember how you learned 捕まる is "to be caught." Well this is the transitive version, so it means to catch or to capture. You (or someone else) is doing the catching, which is better than being the one who gets caught, I suppose. \n The reading is also not the same as 捕まる. Sorry! It does have a similar reading to 取る though, which also has to do with grabbing things (like grabbing onto an idea, for example). You can use 取る as a jumping off point for remembering the reading of this word. You might also find it useful to think back to 捉える, which has to do with mentally "catching" or "grasping" things. You'll sometimes see this written as 捕らえる as well.
3178 | 抜ける | ぬける | To Come Out | To Fall Out | Remember how 抜く means "to pull something out"? 抜ける describes something coming out of where it was, so it means to come out or to fall out.\nThis can be used for air coming out of a balloon, hair falling out, or pages missing from a book. It also means passing through places or leaving a group you were a part of.\nTo distinguish this word from 抜く, imagine a bunch of kale (ける) coming out of the ground on its own! Nobody pulled it out, it just came out by itself. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also, it is the same as 抜く.
3179 | 比較する | ひかくする | To Compare |  | 比較 is comparison. So, verb version of that? It's to compare. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.
3180 | 締結する | ていけつする | To Conclude | To Enter Into | When you tighten things up and bind things together, it's hard to separate them again. That's why this word is used to conclude or to enter into important agreements, like treaties and contracts.\nNote that this word is quite formal, which makes sense, given the contexts it’s usually used in. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3181 | 怒る | おこる | To Get Angry | To Get Mad | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means angry, the verb vocab version is to get angry. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting to get angry about something. It's mostly this okra (おこ). It tastes terrible.
3182 | 迷う | まよう | To Get Lost | To Go Astray\n To Waver\n To Hesitate | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means astray and the verb vocab version is to go astray (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?). You can use it if you ever happen to get lost.\nBeyond physically getting lost, 迷う is also for times when you waver between different choices or hesitate to take a decisive step. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you are going to go astray, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy too much mayo (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.
3183 | 与える | あたえる | To Give | To Grant\n To Bestow | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give so the verb vocab version is to give or to grant.\nThis is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing. In conversations, people commonly use more relaxed words like あげる or くれる. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou go to give a bone to your dog. Atta (あた) boy, Sparky! Atta boy.
3184 | 手渡す | てわたす | To Hand Over |  | Remember how you learned that 渡す means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual hand to hand over something too! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
3185 | 招待する | しょうたいする | To Invite |  | You beckon someone to come to you, but then you wait. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means to invite .\n招待する is a formal word for inviting someone, particularly to formal events or places. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3186 | 貸す | かす | To Lend | To Rent | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lend so the verb vocab version is to lend. \n Allow me to lend you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.
3187 | 憧れる | あこがれる | To Long For | To Yearn After\n To Admire\n To Be Attracted By | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means long for, so the verb version is to long for and to yearn after. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
3188 | 抜き出す | ぬきだす | To Pull Something Out | To Extract | You know 抜く means "to pull something out" and 出す means "to remove," so this word also means to pull something out, or to extract.\nMore specifically, 抜き出す means to pull something out from a larger set of something. For example, this could mean taking a single bill out of your wallet, or selecting specific data from a large dataset. \n The readings are from 抜く and 出す, combined together. Know those two and you'll be able to read this word as well.
3189 | 取り替える | とりかえる | To Replace | To Swap Out\n To Exchange | Take and replace something. That is to replace something with something else.\n取り替える generally means to swap out something with a new or different item of the same kind, like replacing an old gas meter with a new one, or exchanging books with your friend after you've both read your own. \n The readings are 取る and 替える put together into one. If you know those words you'll be able to read and understand this one as well.
3190 | 隠居する | いんきょする | To Retire | To Be Retired\n To Go Into Retirement | 隠居 is "retirement". Make that a verb and you have to retire, to be retired, or to go into retirement.\nLike 隠居, this word emphasizes life after retiring, and usually implies having a quiet, maybe secluded, lifestyle. It's a bit of an old-fashioned word, but you'll still see it in modern writing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3191 | 見抜く | みぬく | To See Something's True Nature | To See Through\n To Find Out | You know 抜く means "to pull something out." Whenever you see something and pull something out of it, you're able to see something's true nature. You're able to see through things like situations, lies, and people. \n This is the reading for 見る and 抜く put together.
3192 | 費やす | ついやす | To Spend | To Expend\n To Waste\n To Consume | Turn expense into a verb and you get to spend or to expend. Or, in some cases, to waste.\nIn addition to spending money, 費やす can be used to refer to spending other resources like time, effort, energy, and emotions. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nJust as you're about to spend some money, a familiar sound comes from inside your wallet: "TWEET (つい)!" It's the little bird that lives inside your wallet and angrily tweets at you whenever you're about to waste money on something you don't need. Maybe you should listen to the bird tweeting from inside your wallet a little more.
3193 | 締める | しめる | To Tighten | To Tie | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten so the verb vocab version means to tighten. \n You go to tighten and to tie your captive up, and you realize you don't have anything to do it with. Then you see a sheep standing nearby. Okay. You take the sheep (し), pull its wool, and tie the sheep and your captive up together around a tree. Problem solved!
3194 | 迫る | せまる | To Urge | To Approach\n To Press | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.\nAt its core, 迫る means to approach, like a deadline or danger drawing near. This idea extends to urging someone because it's like you're coming really close to them, to press them into action. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nDo you prefer to urge people to do something, or to press them to do it? It depends on how you want to approach them. But it's all semantics (せま) because they're basically the same.
3195 | 訪ねる | たずねる | To Visit |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit so the verb vocab version is to visit. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to visit your friend Taz (たず) the Tasmanian Devil. He's your best bro, so imagine visiting him and having a good time and saying you're going to visit him again.
3196 | 織る | おる | To Weave | To Knit | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means weave so the verb vocab version is to weave. \n When you have to weave the only thing you can weave is an O (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.
3197 | 悩む | なやむ | To Worry | To Be Troubled | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worry so the verb vocab version is to worry. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need to worry about it.
3198 | 怒鳴る | どなる | To Yell | To Shout | An angry chirp is a type of shout. The verb version is to yell or to shout.\n怒鳴る suggests anger, as you can tell from the kanji, so it's used when someone yells or shouts to scold others or to express anger or frustration. \n This one is a bit tricky, as it uses the on'yomi reading you learned for 怒 and the kun'yomi reading for 鳴る, so try to keep that in mind!
3199 | 迷惑 | めいわく | Trouble | Troublesome\n Inconvenience\n Nuisance | You've been led astray and you've been misguided. What a trouble, and indeed a troublesome inconvenience all this is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3200 | 究極 | きゅうきょく | Ultimate |  | You are trying to research the extremes. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the ultimate weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3201 | 統一 | とういつ | Unity | Uniformity | To unite as one is to achieve total unity and uniformity. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, it uses a reading for 一 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou dream about unity so often that it eats (いつ) away at you. Thoughts of uniting your country occupy you day and night, but you can't let them consume you.
3202 | 残品 | ざんぴん | Unsold Merchandise | Remaining Stock | The remainder products are the things that haven't been sold. They're the unsold merchandise. They're the remaining stock.\nThis is a very specific word that is mainly used in the context of inventory management or retail sales. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ひん changes to ぴん.
3203 | 切迫 | せっぱく | Urgency | Drawing Near\n Impending | We're cut right down to the end, reaching that urge position where urgency is so strong.\n切迫 is used to describe the tension in a situation where a time limit is drawing near, or to describe something bad or dangerous as impending. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.
3204 | 休暇 | きゅうか | Vacation | Holiday\n Time Off | The restspare time is your vacation. It is your holiday.\n休暇 is a relatively formal word that commonly refers to time off from work, ranging from a day off to seasonal vacation to temporary leave. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3205 | 就業 | しゅうぎょう | Working | Being Employed\n Being At Work | When you get a position in some business, you’re considered working.\n就業 is a formal word that can refer to both being employed and being at work for the day. It’s commonly used in kanji compounds, such as 就業時間 (working hours) and 就業規則 (employment regulations). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3206 | 再来年 | さらいねん | Year After Next | The Year After Next | You have next year (来年), but then you do a year again. That's the year after next. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3207 | 浴衣 | ゆかた | Yukata |  | The bathe clothes are clothes you wear to and from the bath. They're your yukata.\n浴衣 originated as robes worn in a steam bath (that explains the kanji), but these days people mostly wear them at summer festivals or traditional Japanese inns. Be careful not to mix up 浴衣 with 着物, which are much more formal and elaborate! \n The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.
3208 | 進撃 | しんげき | Advance | Charge | You advance and attack! This is a charge on someone or something, though it can also be an advance on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here. \n The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!
3209 | 前売り券 | まえうりけん | Advance Ticket | Ticket Sold In Advance | A ticket you sell beforehand are advance tickets. This is a ticket sold in advance. Buy your tickets early, or how else will you get in on a Conan audience? \n The readings are 前, 売る and 券 combined into one awkward word.
3210 | 再び | ふたたび | Again | Once Again | This is the adverb version of 再, so it shares the meaning again and also has the meaning once again.\nNote that this word is somewhat formal and literary. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nOnce again, you have to say "Who? Ta-ta!" (ふたた). That's because people you don't know keep trying to talk to you, again and again. Whenever this happens you say "Who? Ta-ta!" again and run away.
3211 | 巨人 | きょじん | A Giant | Giant | A giant person is a giant. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3212 | 軍隊 | ぐんたい | Army | An Army | The army squad is an army. It's also just the army. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3213 | 矢印 | やじるし | Arrow | Arrow Symbol | This combines the kanji arrow and the vocab word 印 (mark), to give us the type of arrow you use for pointing at things (as opposed to firing at things). It could be an arrow on a sign, or on piece of paper, or a document or whatever. We can just call it an arrow, or an arrow symbol. \n The reading is 矢 and 印 put together into one. The 印 is like the actual vocab word 印, but watch out for rendaku changing it from しるし to じるし.
3214 | 金庫 | きんこ | A Safe | Safe | Gold storage is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in a safe. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3215 | 星占い | ほしうらない | Astrology | Horoscope | 占い is "fortune telling." Star fortune telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as astrology or horoscope. \n The reading is the words 星 and 占い put together into one. Did you foresee that one coming?
3216 | 攻撃 | こうげき | Attack |  | With aggression you attack the enemy. This is an attack. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3217 | 浜辺 | はまべ | Beach |  | A beach area is just a beach! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nBeach starts with be. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!
3218 | 浜 | はま | Beach |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is ビーチ, and many people actually say 海 even though this literally means "sea." \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
3219 | 何故なら | なぜなら | Because | The Reason Is | When someone asks you 何故, or "why," you did something, you respond with, "何故なら blah blah blah." That makes it mean because. Why did you do that? Because I was mad! Why did you dance? Because I was happy! \n This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word 何故, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!
3220 | 有益 | ゆうえき | Beneficial | Useful | To have benefit is to be beneficial. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3221 | 大間違い | おおまちがい | Big Mistake |  | A 間違い is a mistake. A big mistake is a big mistake. \n The reading is 大 and 間違い put together into one not so mistaken word.
3222 | 沼 | ぬま | Bog | Swamp | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that, unlike English, which differentiates between different types of wetlands like marshes, swamps, or bogs, Japanese 沼 refers to any pond-like areas with muddy, murky water. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, ぬま.
3223 | 回数券 | かいすうけん | Book Of Tickets | Train Tickets\n Train Coupons | Many times is how many times you can use this number of tickets. That means there are many tickets, making this a book of tickets. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3224 | お菓子屋 | おかしや | Candy Store |  | お菓子 is "candy," right? Add store onto that and you have a candy store. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. It will help to know the word お菓子 as well.
3225 | 幼年時代 | ようねんじだい | Childhood |  | You have 時代 as a "period" of time you're talking about. What period? The infancy years. Those years are not just when you're a baby, but when you were growing up, too. That was your childhood. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
