3226 | 幼稚 | ようち | Childish | Immature | He who is both in his infancy and immature is probably childish and immature. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3227 | 幼い | おさない | Very Young | Childish | The kanji means infancy. The adjective version describes someone who is very young, like little kids in their early childhood or babyhood!\nDepending on the context, it can also describe behaviors or ideas that are childish or immature, often with a negative connotation. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you were very young and childish you were sent off to do prayers to ask for forgiveness. One of the things you had to do was sing "hosanna (おさな) in the highest."
3228 | 児童 | じどう | Children | Child | The child who is a juvenile is just a child. A group of them is children. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3229 | 清潔 | せいけつ | Clean | Cleanliness | Something so pure it's pure twice must be really clean! Cleanliness is next to pure...liness, after all. I'm sure that's how the saying goes. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3230 | 冷たい | つめたい | Cold | Cool\n Cold To The Touch | Something that is cool is cold. This refers to something that is cold to the touch, not the weather or something like that (which is 寒い). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's mnemonic to help you: Something that is really cold to the touch is cold enough to make ice cream with.
3231 | 比較的 | ひかくてき | Comparatively | Relatively | 比較 is a comparison. Add 的 to it and you have  comparatively. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 比較.
3232 | 全景 | ぜんけい | Complete View | Full View\n Panoramic View\n Panorama | When you can see all the scene you have a complete view.\nThis is not a common word in everyday conversations, but it can be found in literature, art, film, photography, and travel writing to describe a panoramic or comprehensive view of a scene. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3233 | 憲法 | けんぽう | Constitution |  | The constitution laws are what makes up the constitution. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3234 | 憲政 | けんせい | Constitutional Government |  | A constitution government is a constitutional government. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3235 | 冷静 | れいせい | Cool Headed | Calm\n Composure | You're cool and quiet. That's you, daddio. Nice and cool-headed and calm. So much composure \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3236 | 反攻 | はんこう | Counterattack | Counter Offensive | Anti aggression is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your counterattack. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3237 | 従兄弟 | いとこ | Cousin | Male Cousin | Remember how 兄弟 means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to obey they're not your brother or sister, they're your cousin. \n The entire reading for this is an exception. Sorry about that. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat are the two defining traits your cousin has? They're good and a child. いいと子, or いとこ for short. Just remember your good, kid cousin. Your いとこ cousin.
3238 | 創造的 | そうぞうてき | Creative |  | If 創造 is creation, then you add 的 to it, which means you have a creational thing, which is quite creative wouldn't you say? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3239 | 創造力 | そうぞうりょく | Creative Power | Creativity | If 創造 is creation and you add power to it, you have creative power. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!
3240 | 規準 | きじゅん | Criterion | Standard | The standard of standards is the main criterion we work off of. That’s the standard we follow.\nCompared to 基準 that's often a quantitative "standard" for assessment, 規準 is more of a quality-focused "criterion" that can be a basis for goals. You'll often see this word used in academic or professional contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.\nAlthough they’re not official readings, people sometimes distinguish 基準 and 規準 by calling them もとじゅん and のりじゅん respectively when speaking.
3241 | 処理 | しょり | Deal With | Take Care Of\n Process | I can deal with it, no matter what the reason. I can take care of this problem, process it, and deal with it on my own. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3242 | 程度 | ていど | Degree | Extent\n Level | The extent degrees show to what degree or extent you're willing to take something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3243 | 微か | かすか | Delicate | Faint\n Indistinct\n Dim | The kanji is delicate, and the vocab has this meaning too. It's that kind of "subtle" delicate, not so much that something will break (like it is with the kanji). Something that is a bit faint and indistinct is going to be delicate in this sense, perhaps, too. \n If you're going to cuss (かす) up a storm, that's not really being delicate.
3244 | 直接的 | ちょくせつてき | Directly | Direct | 直接 is direct. Add 的 to the mix and you have directly. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 直接 already.
3245 | 処分 | しょぶん | Disposal |  | Please deal with part of this trash. It is too much to handle all at once when it comes to the disposal of it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3246 | 入隊 | にゅうたい | Enlist In The Army | Enlist | Enter into a squad... an army squad. When you do this, you enlist in the army. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3247 | 程 | ほど | Extent | An Extent | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that 程 is a word that works in conjunction with other words or phrases to express the extent, degree, amount, or time related to a particular action or event. \n You'll remember this kanji to the extent that you study it. If you study it like Hodor (ほど) would study it, you won't learn it at all. You would only be able to say "hodor, hodor," over and over again, which isn't helpful at all.
3248 | 不潔 | ふけつ | Filthy | Dirty | Not clean things are filthy and dirty. Ewughh. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3249 | 前景 | ぜんけい | Foreground |  | The front scene is the foreground.\nThis word primarily refers to the visual foreground in art, photography, or theater. Unlike "foreground" in English, it’s not commonly used in a figurative sense to describe the most prominent aspect of situations. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3250 | 冷凍庫 | れいとうこ | Freezer |  | A cool frozen storage is one which is really cold on the inside, so cold it can freeze things. This is called a freezer, not to be confused with 冷蔵庫, which is refrigerator, and doesn't have the kanji for "freeze" in it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3251 | 凍死 | とうし | Freeze To Death |  | A frozen death isn't a bad way to go, I hear. Still, you don't want to freeze to death if you can help it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3252 | 凍結 | とうけつ | Freezing | Get Frozen | Things that are frozen have been tied up in freezing ice. They get frozen that way.\n凍結 is a relatively formal word that is used for the physical freezing of infrastructure, such as roads and water pipes. It can also refer to the freezing of systems or accounts, like the suspension of social media or bank accounts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3253 | 振り仮名 | ふりがな | Furigana | Small Kana Next To Kanji | 振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to furigana, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go. \n The readings are 振る and 仮名 put together into one. If you know those words, you won't need no furigana to help you with this word.
3254 | 博打 | ばくち | Gambling |  | A gambling hit can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's gambling. \n The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. はく goes to ばく, maybe because you're playing some gambling backgammon. The ち can be cheating, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're backgammon cheating (ばくち), you big cheater.
3255 | 車庫 | しゃこ | Garage |  | Car storage is where you store your car. It's your garage. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3256 | 大衆 | たいしゅう | General Public |  | A big populous place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the general public. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3257 | 身振り | みぶり | Gesture |  | Somebody shakes something at you. It was a finger, it seems. What a weird little gesture. \n The reading is 身 and 振る put together, where the 振り gets rendaku'd to ぶり.
3258 | 潔い | いさぎよい | Honorable | Dignified\n Gracious | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji means pure, but this is an adjective that often describes behavior or character, so it means honorable, dignified, or gracious.\nHow does that work? I guess if you can stay pure despite a tough situation, you must be pretty honorable and dignified. You're the type who can make a gracious apology (潔い謝り), have a dignified manner (潔い態度), or even die honorably (潔く死ぬ).\n潔い is about being strong and doing the right thing without hesitation, especially when it's hard. For example, when someone admits their mistake honestly or handles a tough situation with courage, you can say they're 潔い. It's a way to praise someone for being straightforward and admirable in difficult times. \n Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like it's soggy (いさぎ)... then the second part is like the word 良い (good). So, you can think of a honorableperson eating soggy cereal. They're so gracious that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they accept it with dignity! They keep saying "it's soggy... 良い!" over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.
3259 | 家政婦 | かせいふ | Housekeeper | Maid | The person who governs your house like a wife is your housekeeper. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3260 | 衆議院 | しゅうぎいん | House Of Representatives |  | It's the institution that does deliberation on behalf of the populace. They represent the people. They are the house of representatives. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3261 | 主婦 | しゅふ | Housewife |  | The master wife is the one that takes care of all your stuff for you. She is the housewife, a very common profession for married ladies in Japan, though things have been changing little by little. Still, being a housewife means you control the money, which is pretty neat if you ask me. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3262 | 巨大 | きょだい | Huge | Gigantic\n Enormous | A giant big thing is something that is huge and gigantic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3263 | 夫婦 | ふうふ | Husband And Wife | Wife And Husband\n Married Couple | A husband and wife combo are a husband and wife. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Immigration nation! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3265 | 並行 | へいこう | In Parallel | Going Abreast | Line up and go together. If you did that, you'd be in parallel or going abreast with someone.\n並行 refers to two or more things placed or moving parallel to each other, like buses or trains running side by side. It's also used to describe two or more activities happening at the same time. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3266 | 婦人 | ふじん | Lady |  | A wife person is a lady, because I guess ladies are wife people? 3267 | 限度 | げんど | Limit | Bounds | A certain limit’s degree is how far it can go. It’s the limit; turn it up one more degree and it’s out of bounds. Keep it right where it is and it’s perfect.\nThis word refers to the maximum extent or range of something, beyond which it cannot be surpassed. While similar to 限界, 限度 often implies a predetermined acceptable or tolerable limit, while 限界 is more closely associated with an absolute or ultimate limit. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

3277 | 微妙 | びみょう | Not So Good | Not Really\n Delicate\n Doubtful | This word is pretty weird. It has two distinct sort of meanings. One is the "not so good" meaning, and the other is the "delicate" meaning. Lately the "not so good" meaning has taken priority, I think, so let's focus on that for now. Something is both delicate and strange. This delicate strange thing really is just not so good. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. It's just not so good. Why? Because if you touch it too hard, it will break. Also, it's not that normal either, so it's not helpful to you. Imagine a thing that could be like this, then think: Is this good? not really. It's not so good. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3278 | 未だ | いまだ | Not Yet | Still | This is the adverb version of 未, so it means the same thing: not yet, or still, depending on the context. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn it with this kanji, so here a mnemonic to help you:\nSomeone's telling you "not yet... not yet.... not yet...". You have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it 今 (いま).\nNote that this word can also be read まだ. However, いまだ is often written in kanji, while まだ is almost always written in kana. So when you see 未だ, it's a safe bet to read it as いまだ!
3279 | 妙 | みょう | Odd | Unusual\n Strange | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though "odd" is getting the number one definition for this word, and strange comes in later. \n The reading is actually the same as the kanji you learned. On'yomi all the way, despite being all alone. Strange!

Sad for all the ordinaries. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nYou're at the coast, looking out at the 波 (なみ), which are all very ordinary, average. Nothing exceptional about those waves.

3287 | 精度 | せいど | Precision | Accuracy | Your spirit's degree of focus is what helps you to hone your precision and accuracy, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great precision you have gained by honing your spirit!\n精度 is a relatively formal word, often used to talk about the precision or accuracy of something in technical or analytical contexts. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3288 | 綺麗 | きれい | Pretty | Beautiful\n Clean | Things that are beautiful and lovely are very beautiful, pretty, and often clean, too. You can call someone 綺麗. You can also mention how clean something is with 綺麗. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.\nWondering what the difference is between 綺麗 and 美しい? 美しい is more dramatic, so it implies you’re really blown away by something’s (or someone’s) beauty. 綺麗, on the other hand, is a more everyday word that covers anything that’s beautiful, pretty, or even just clean. In other words, the bar is a bit lower for 綺麗! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

It's a process that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

3303 | 〜隊 | たい | Squad | Party\n Team | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned, probably because this is stuck onto things, describing various squads.
3304 | 庫 | くら | Storehouse | Warehouse\n Kura | The kanji means storehouse, and the vocab is also storehouse! Specifically, this usually refers to a traditional Japanese storehouse, which is typically a two story building used to store personal property or merchandise. \n What do you put in your storehouse? Nothing that nice. Just your totally crashed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.
3305 | 独り言 | ひとりごと | Talking To Yourself |  | 独り is when you're alone. 言 is when you say something. So, when you say something and you're alone, you're just talking to yourself. \n The reading for 独り is just the reading for 独り. The reading for 言 is an exception, though. It's ごと, which comes from こと. Just think that as you're talking to yourself you're telling yourself over and over to go to hell. You're mean to yourself, and you're also insane, which is why you keep saying that out loud to nobody but you.
3306 | 解凍 | かいとう | Thawing | Defrosting\n Unzipping | If you untie something that's frozen, you're thawing it. The best way to go about defrosting anything is always to untie it first.\nIn the context of computer files, this word can also mean unzipping. We unzip files in English, but in Japanese we thaw them! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this one on your own.
3307 | 故に | ゆえに | Therefore | Consequently | With 故 meaning "reason" if you head towards that reason, you transition towards it. To say that in words, you might say therefore or consequently. You stated your case and ideas, then in order to go towards reason we use these words to transition towards it. \n By knowing the word 故 you'll know the reading for this word too! Here's a mnemonic in case you need a reminder, though:\nYou're using WaniKani, therefore you're studying kanji and vocab. Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.
3308 | 〜券 | けん | Ticket |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.
3309 | 攻める | せめる | To Attack | To Assault\n To Assail | You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word to attack. This refers to a planned attack, though. Think about what you're going to do. Plan it out. Then, 攻める! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo attack someone, use a celery (せ) stick. Celery is not a deadly weapon but most people hate it, so it's perfect to casually attack someone, especially those who hate celery.
3310 | 招く | まねく | To Beckon | To Invite\n To Cause | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means beckon so the verb vocab version is to beckon.\nSince 招く conjures up the image of someone beckoning, it also means to invite, and is a relatively formal word. Figuratively, it can also mean to cause, as in inviting some undesirable outcome or situation. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You move to beckon your friend over. You can't see him well, so that's why you invite him to come closer. He is hiding something, and it turns out to be his long, luxurious horse mane (まね). Why does he have a mane!? Horse steroids?
3311 | 揃う | そろう | To Be Complete | To Be Uniform | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb that uses the complete kanji. It means to be complete. It can also be used when you want things to be uniform. It feels satisfying to have everything complete and uniform, right? \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this!
3312 | 並ぶ | ならぶ | To Be Lined Up |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means line up so the verb vocab version is to be lined up. You know this is the version where things are just lined up (you're not doing the lining up) because you keep saying boo (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? I should have got here earlier so I don't have to wait (if you were doing the lining up yourself, you'd put yourself in the front, duh). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Only for you, when you visit Nara (なら), the deer there are to be lined up for you to inspect, as you are the deer inspector. If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.
3313 | 痛む | いたむ | To Be Painful | To Hurt | 痛い is "painful." The verb version of that is to hurt or to be painful.\nIt's an intransitive verb, so it happens without you trying to cause it. It describes the sensation of feeling pain 🤕 \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned already!
3314 | 絶つ | たつ | To Break Off Contact | To Sever\n To End | The kanji means extinction or die out, but the verb version here means to break off contact, to sever, or to end. Just think about how when you’re breaking off contact with somebody, you’re essentially making them go extinct or die out from your life completely. It’s such a complete severance, they basically stop existing to you. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn terms of things you need to sever, tacos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.
3315 | 幼児 | ようじ | Toddler | Preschooler | An infancy child is a toddler. The kanji are kind of deceptive since this isn't really used for infants. It's more for small children, from toddlers on up to preschoolers.\n幼児 is sort of formal, but it's commonly used to talk about small children from about one to six years old, or about that specific period of early childhood. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3316 | 降る | ふる | To Fall | To Come Down | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means descend, but this word means something closer to to fall or to come down. Usually used with things like rain or snow. \n The rain is to fall and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth full (ふる) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!
3317 | 凍る | こおる | To Freeze | To Be Frozen | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frozen, so the vocab version is to freeze. \n The reading actually comes from the word 氷, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to こおり, then change the り to a る and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this こおる, in all (or most) of 氷's glory.
3318 | 逆らう | さからう | To Go Against | To Oppose\n To Be Contrary To | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means opposite so the verb version is to oppose or to go against. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nJust like when you play soccer (さか). You never play right, causing you to go against all things you're supposed to do and shoot goals into your own goalie's net.
3319 | 輸入する | ゆにゅうする | To Import |  | 輸入 is import. Now let's make it a verb. To import. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 輸入 as well.
3320 | 面接する | めんせつする | To Interview With | To Interview | 面接 is an interview. Make that into a verb and you have to interview with. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 面接 as well.
3321 | 間違える | まちがえる | To Make A Mistake | To Mistake | Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means to make a mistake or to mistake.\nThis verb is transitive. That means that it takes a direct object. Bear in mind that this one is a bit tricky, though, because although it's transitive in Japanese, the English translation will sometimes be intransitive. \n It's read the same as 間違い! Nice and easy!
3322 | 極める | きわめる | To Reach The Peak Of Something | To Perfect\n To Reach The Extreme | The kanji itself means extreme. The verb vocab version isn't "to extreme" because that wouldn't make sense. Instead, you bring something to extremes, making this to reach the peak of something, to perfect, or to reach the extreme.\n極める commonly means reaching the highest level of proficiency or excellence in a particular skill, art, or field. It can also mean taking something to the extreme, like being crazy busy. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you go to reach the peak of something or to perfect something, you tend to go a little overboard, so there has to be a key word (きわ) that other people can say to remind you to calm down a little. “PINEAPPLE! PINEAPPLE!”
3323 | 回復する | かいふくする | To Recover |  | 回復 is recovery. Make it into a verb and you have to recover. \n The reading comes from 回復, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.
3324 | 退く | しりぞく | To Retreat | To Withdraw\n To Resign | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means retreat, and the verb vocab version means to retreat, to withdraw or to resign. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to retreat because she re-zoned (しりぞ) where you are standing. Now this is a no standing zone. Who is she? The re-zoner, duh.
3325 | 誘惑する | ゆうわくする | To Seduce | To Tempt | If 誘惑 is seduction or temptation, then the verb version would be to seduce or to tempt. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 誘惑 first, though.
3326 | 移す | うつす | To Shift | To Transfer | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift so the verb vocab version is to shift. \n All that dubstep (うつうつうつうつうつ) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware to shift off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. うつうつうつうつうつ♪
3327 | 撃つ | うつ | To Shoot | To Fire | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to attack, but 撃つ means to shoot.\nThis can mean to fire a weapon such as a gun or to shoot a projectile, like an arrow. It can also mean to shoot a person or animal. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat are you going to shoot at? Uni (う)! Why? Because this area is overrun with those black, spiky sea urchins. You need to cull them by shooting them down.
3328 | 無我夢中 | むがむちゅう | Total Absorption | Losing Oneself In\n Frantic | You already know that 無我 is "selflessness" and 夢中 is "crazy about." So this means something like total absorption. You're so into something that you’ve started losing your sense of self. Just like 夢中, this can also describe doing something frantically, like running away from somebody or something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3329 | 研修 | けんしゅう | Training | Give Training | You sharpen your mastering of a specific skill. One could say that you're training. Additionally, when you sharpen someone else's mastering, you give training. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3330 | 傘 | かさ | Umbrella |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
3331 | 傘立て | かさたて | Umbrella Stand | Umbrella Holder | This is when you take your umbrella and you stand it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an umbrella stand. \n The reading is the readings for 傘 (learned with the kanji) and 立つ (to stand).
3332 | 我々 | われわれ | We | Us | 我 is me, so two of me makes we! Or us! \n The reading is 我, twice.
3333 | 再来週 | さらいしゅう | Week After Next | The Week After Next | You know how 来週 is next week? Well, if you do next week again, you have the week after next. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3334 | 針金 | はりがね | Wire |  | A needle made of gold is a wire. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both. You've learned 針 already, but 金 is more like お金, rendaku'd.

They are known as wonder drugs. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3336 | 憧れ | あこがれ | Yearning | Longing\n Admiration | If you long for something you'll get feelings of yearning and longing. Don't worry, some day you'll get whatever it is.\n憧れ can also describe a strong feeling of admiration, particularly for people. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
3337 | 横浜 | よこはま | Yokohama |  | It's the side of the beach! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: Yokohama. \n The reading is 横 and 浜 put together into one nice word, よこはま.
3338 | 省略 | しょうりゃく | Abbreviation | Omission\n Abbreviate\n Leave Out | Conserve those letters with abbreviation and it's... an abbreviation! If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3339 | 略語 | りゃくご | Abbreviation |  | Abbreviation in language is abbreviation. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3340 | 板 | いた | A Board | Board\n A Plank\n Plank | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho can make good use of various boards? An avid eater (いた)! If you’re an avid eater, you’ll need lots of (cutting) boards to prepare all the delicious food you’re going to eat. This makes boards and eaters the perfect match.
3341 | 怒気 | どき | Anger | Fit Of Anger | An angry energy comes out of you when you have anger. It also can refer to a fit of anger. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3342 | 怒り | いかり | Anger | Wrath | This is the noun version of 怒る. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nI have a lot of anger because I carry (いかり) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!
3343 | 痛み | いたみ | A Pain | Pain | 痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is a pain or pain. \n The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.

3345 | 面積 | めんせき | Area |  | The surface that accumulates into one area is a particular area. This has to do with math. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3346 | 添付 | てんぷ | Attachment |  | Append and attach this document to your email. It's an attachment. \n The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading ふ, which you've learned with 付近. But for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an attachment where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of poop (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.

3363 | 締切 | しめきり | Deadline | Closing Date | You saw 締める, which means "to tighten." So when things tighten, and then they get cut off, it's when you've reached the deadline. You know that feeling? When you get close, you feel a tightening in your stomach. The deadline is near! But, then when your tightening gets cut off completely, it's because you've reached the end. The deadline. \n The reading is 締める and 切る put together. Notice how the hiragana bits get pushed into the kanji though, that's the interesting part, but also the part that's hard to remember. It's probably because this is a short version of 締め切り, but you'll see 締切 more often.

If you were looking for a word to describe all your indignation, then this is it. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3400 | 再建 | さいけん | Rebuilding | Reconstruction | Again you build it. This is rebuilding.\n再建 is a formal word that refers to the act of rebuilding something that has deteriorated or been lost, whether it's a physical structure like a building or an organization, or a part of the body in the context of medical procedures. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!
3401 | 宗教 | しゅうきょう | Religion |  | The religion teachings are what makes up a religion. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3402 | 貸し〜 | かし | Rental |  | To lend or to rent is 貸す. This is the noun version of that, used as a prefix. It is something that has been rented, a rental. \n The reading is the same as 貸す.
3403 | 略図 | りゃくず | Rough Sketch | Rough Map | An abbreviation version of a diagram isn't the completed diagram, nor is it one you spend a lot of time on. It's the abbreviated version, so it's more like a rough sketch or a rough map. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3404 | 怖い | こわい | Scary |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scary? It's also scary.\n怖い is commonly used in everyday language to describe something that's scary on a more immediate or personal level. \n You know what's really scary, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your coworkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.
3405 | 捜索 | そうさく | Search | Investigation | A search search is a more intense search, like the ones for a missing person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3406 | 宗派 | しゅうは | Sect | Denomination | A religion sect is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a sect or denomination. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3407 | 商店街 | しょうてんがい | Shopping District |  | A merchandise shop street is a street with all kinds of shops and merchandise on it. Sounds like a lot of shopping goes on here in this shopping district! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3408 | 招き猫 | まねきねこ | Shop Window Cat | Beckoning Cat\n Maneki Neko | 招く is "to beckon," so a cat that beckons is known as a maneki neko or a beckoning cat. These are the cat statues placed in front of shops that move their arms up and down and are like, "Hey, come on in!" \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!
3409 | 睡眠薬 | すいみんやく | Sleeping Pills | Sleeping Drugs\n Sleeping Medicine | Sleepy sleep medicine is sleeping pills. Don't take too many or you might get addicted. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3410 | 眠り薬 | ねむりぐすり | Sleeping Pills | Sleeping Drugs\n Sleeping Medicine | Some kind of sleep medicine? That's sleeping pills. \n The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz\nJust remember that くすり turns into ぐすり here because of rendaku.
3411 | 勧誘 | かんゆう | Solicitation | Invitation | I recommend this to you, so I'd like to invite you to try it. This is a solicitation or invitation.\nThis word describes inviting someone to join a group or activity, often with a pushy or persistent tone. It's commonly used in business, religious, or social settings. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3412 | 韓国 | かんこく | South Korea | Korea | The Korea Country is Korea, of course... well, South Korea that is. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3413 | 迷惑メール | めいわくめーる | Spam | Spam Mail\n Junk Mail\n Unsolicited Mail | When you have troublesome (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as spam, spam mail, or junk mail. On a more technical level it's unsolicited mail. \n The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)
3414 | 主催 | しゅさい | Sponsorship | Promotion | The master who sponsors you is the one who provides your sponsorship. Without this person, you wouldn't have sponsorship at all, which is why you call them "master" (plus, that was one of the rules with the sponsorship). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3415 | 看板 | かんばん | Store Sign |  | A watch over board is a board that goes over your store and watches over everything. What board on a store watches everything? It's the one that gets the most visibility, so it's probably the store sign. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3416 | 奇妙 | きみょう | Strange | Curious\n Odd | That's very odd and strange, making it odd and strange. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3417 | 緊張 | きんちょう | Stress | Tension\n Nervous | When your tenseness is stretched out as far as it is, it becomes not just tenseness, but stress as well. The tension is crazy when you stretch it out like this! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3418 | 強烈 | きょうれつ | Strong | Intense | Things that are strong and intense are strong and intense (the "strong" meaning is more along the lines of the "intense" meaning, so not so much like my muscles are super muscly and strong). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3419 | 大略 | たいりゃく | Summary | Outline | The big abbreviation is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the summary or outline of something bigger. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3420 | 監督 | かんとく | Supervision | Head Coach\n Director | The one who oversees and directs is the one who gives supervision.\n監督 refers to the act of supervising or to the person who supervises, such as the head coach of a sports team or a movie director. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3421 | 恐ろしい | おそろしい | Terrifying | Frightening\n Dreadful | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? When you really feel fear, you think something is terrifying or frightening or even dreadful.\n恐ろしい can describe something that inspires deep fear or awe, often beyond normal feelings of fear. Since it can be used to create a dramatic or intense atmosphere, you might find 恐ろしい more often in literature. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nHow terrifying is it? It's Oh so (おそ) terrifying!
3422 | 恐怖 | きょうふ | Terror | Fear | I fear it. It is scary. It is pure terror. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3423 | 織物 | おりもの | Textile | Fabric | The things that are weaved are, essentially, just textile or fabric. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of cloth that is monochrome.
3424 | 三杯 | さんばい | Three Cups | Three Cups Of Liquid | Three cups of liquid is three cups of liquid, or more simply, three cups. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for 杯, which becomes ばい thanks to our old friend rendaku.
3425 | 略す | りゃくす | To Abbreviate | To Omit | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abbreviation, so the verb vocab version is to abbreviate or to omit. \n The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. りゃくす.
3426 | 積もる | つもる | To Accumulate | To Get Piled Up | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accumulate and the verb version is to accumulate. \n If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least two (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.
3427 | 怒らせる | おこらせる | To Anger Someone | To Provoke\n To Offend Someone | Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means to anger someone. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!
3428 | 添える | そえる | To Append | To Accompany\n To Garnish | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means append, so the verb vocab version is to append. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To append something to something else, you can just sew (そ) it onto something else.
3429 | 寄る | よる | To Approach | To Visit\n To Drop In\n To Stop By | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means approach, and the verb version is to approach, to visit, to drop in and to stop by. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you're too shy to approach people just learn how to use a yo-yo (よ)! Then people will approach you to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!
3430 | 昇る | のぼる | To Ascend | To Rise | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ascend so the verb vocab version must be to ascend, or to rise. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? 登る is one example. 上る is another. They're all のぼる, and so is this. Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.
3431 | 壊す | こわす | To Break Something | To Break | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means break so the verb vocab version is to break something, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to sue (す) you for the things you broke of theirs. \n The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic koala (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.
3432 | 任す | まかす | To Entrust Something | To Delegate Something\n To Leave Something To | The meaning of this word is the same as 任せる. Both words are pretty common, but 任す is slightly less common than 任せる.\nHere's the mnemonic again, just in case you need a refresher:\nIf you pass a duty on to someone, that means you're going to entrust something to that person, or you're going to delegate something. In other words, you're going to leave something to them, so that they do it for you. \n This uses the same reading you learned with 任せる.
3433 | 診る | みる | To Examine A Patient | To Examine | In order to diagnose a patient, you must first go to examine a patient. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is to examine. \n The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading み as well.
3434 | 就く | つく | To Get A Position | To Get A Job | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means get a position. The verb vocab version is to get a position, or to get a job.\nNote that 就く is used with another word that indicates a position or a job, like 王位に就く(becoming a king) or 仕事に就く (finding employment). \n If you want to get a position, there are two (つ) interviews. Just pass the two interviews to get a job!
3435 | 乾く | かわく | To Get Dry | To Become Dry\n To Be Dried | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry. This verb vocab version is to get dry, to become dry, or to be dried. You're not doing the drying, it's just happening. That's coo', you say, things can get dry all by themselves. \n The 川 (かわ) has started to get dry. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.
3436 | 道に迷う | みちにまよう | To Get Lost | To Be Lost | Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a road, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means to be lost or to get lost. \n The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.
3437 | 腹立つ | はらだつ | To Get Mad | To Get Angry | What's that feeling when your belly stands up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means to get mad. \n The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ, though.
3438 | 見極める | みきわめる | To Get To The Bottom Of | To Identify Something | 極める is "to carry to extremes." If you take the action of seeing something to the extremes, you're going to get to the bottom of whatever it is. You'll be able to identify something, like the truth.\n見極める primarily involves the careful examination and discernment of the underlying aspects or truth of a matter. It emphasizes the thoroughness and effort required to make well-informed decisions or judgments, particularly when the situation is complex or difficult to understand. \n The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. Get to the bottom of this word and learn it.
3439 | 相次ぐ | あいつぐ | To Happen Successively | To Happen One After Another | Things that happen mutually right next to each other are said to happen successively. In other words, to happen one after another. \n Since this word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi readings. You've learned this reading for 相, but not for 次. Instead of giving you a mnemonic, we think it's easier to remember that 次ぐ being read つぐ comes from the 次 reading つぎ. Not too hard! All in all, that makes this あいつぐ.
3440 | 誘う | さそう | To Invite | To Tempt\n To Entice | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means invite. The verb vocab version is to invite.\n誘う refers to casually inviting someone to a place, an event, or an activity. If it's an invitation to something tempting, it can also mean to tempt, or to entice. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You saw so (さそ) much in this person that you decided to invite them to dinner.
3441 | 豚カツ | とんかつ | Tonkatsu | Breaded Pork Cutlet | 豚 comes from 豚肉 (pork), and カツ comes from the word "cutlet" and means just that. And a pork カツ is what any Japanese food fan will probably know as simply tonkatsu, a.k.a. breaded pork cutlet.\n豚カツ is a Japanese pork cutlet coated in crispy panko breadcrumbs and deep-fried, making it light and crunchy. It's usually served with a tasty sweet-savory sauce. It's so good, you'll pig out on it! \n This word uses the on'yomi of 豚. You haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou really like tonkatsu so you just ate a whole ton (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of breaded pork cutlet.
3442 | 勧める | すすめる | To Recommend | To Suggest\n To Advise\n To Offer | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend. \n To remember the reading think about how you are going to recommend this restaurant to your friends, Sue and Sue (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.
3443 | 構える | かまえる | To Set Up | To Assume A Stance\n To Hold In Preparation | The kanji itself means set up, so this means to set up, as in establishing something in an orderly manner.\nThis can also mean to assume a stance, like taking a fighting posture, or to hold in preparation, such as a weapon, while preparing to engage in a fight. \n The reading is like 構う, so as long as you know that you know this too.
3444 | 眠る | ねむる | To Sleep |  | 眠い is "sleepy." The verb version is to sleep. *yawn* \n The reading comes from 眠い.
3445 | 詰める | つめる | To Stuff In | To Cram In | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed, this word means to stuff in, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know that this is the case because when it comes to the mail (める), you stuff that mail into the garbage as hard as you can (it's all junk). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.
3446 | 請ける | うける | To Take | To Undertake\n To Accept\n To Receive | A person requests something, so you are the one to take it. You're really nice to accept their request. What a nice person you are! \n What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading!
3447 | 締まる | しまる | To Tighten | To Become Tight\n To Be Toned | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten, so the verb vocab version is to tighten. \n What can you do if you want something to tighten or to become tight? You need to hug your sheep (し) really close until...\nThe sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!
3448 | 促す | うながす | To Urge | To Pressure | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge. \n Someone with a weird accent is trying to urge you to eat "Unagah" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.
3449 | 訪れる | おとずれる | To Visit |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit and the verb vocab version is also to visit.\nWhat makes it different from 訪ねる, though? With 訪ねる, you're going somewhere or visiting someone with a clear purpose. With 訪れる, the emphasis is on the act of visiting a place (and not a person), regardless of purpose. So, if you're simply saying that you're going to go visit the Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto, you could say 訪れる. On the other hand, if you're visiting the Kiyomizu Temple to discover something, or you're going to pay a visit to a teacher in Kyoto for some advice, you could use 訪ねる.\nThose uses we just described for 訪れる are for when it is transitive. However, it can also be intransitive, if the action is done by something rather than someone. In that case, it means "to come", as in "winter comes" (冬が訪れる) or "peace comes" (平和が訪れる). 訪ねる, on the other hand, cannot be used in this way. \n The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず. Remember how this means just visiting a place? Unfortunately, you completely forgot what you were visiting. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "Oh Toes!" (おとず), you exclaim.
3450 | 二杯 | にはい | Two Cups | Two Cups Of Liquid | Two cups of liquid equals two cups of liquid, aka two cups. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3451 | 不健康 | ふけんこう | Unhealthy | Not Healthy | If 健康 is "health," then something that is not this is unhealthy. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.
3452 | 玄米 | げんまい | Unpolished Rice | Unmilled Rice\n Brown Rice | Mysterious rice is unpolished rice, or brown rice. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe biggest problem when you buy unpolished rice is the mice (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.
3453 | 催促 | さいそく | Urge | Press For\n Demand | I'm so for this I'm willing to sponsor you. I am going to urge you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great urge and press for you to do this! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3454 | 緊急 | きんきゅう | Urgent | Emergency | Things are tense and we have to hurry! This is quite the urgent emergency! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3455 | 体積 | たいせき | Volume |  | In the body, liquids accumulate. It can be the body of a cup, a body of a bucket, or the body of your body. Whatever it is, this body accumulation represents the volume of liquid in your body. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3456 | 禅宗 | ぜんしゅう | Zen Sect |  | The zen religion is a part of Buddhism. It is the Zen Sect of Buddhism. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3457 | 浮気 | うわき | Affair | Infidelity | You are floating above everything, at least that's how your spirit feels. You're having an affair, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not. \n This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.
3458 | 魅力 | みりょく | Allure | Charm\n Attraction\n Appeal | The alluring power is the power of allure. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3459 | 一覧 | いちらん | A Look | A Glance\n List\n Table | One look at... just one. A little one. Just a look. Just a glance. That's all I want.\nIt also has another meaning! When you're talking about computers and you want to see everything in one look, you will arrange it into a nice list or table. That way you only have to look at the data one time! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3460 | 遊園地 | ゆうえんち | Amusement Park | Theme Park | The play park ground is where you go play. It's fun. It's an amusement park! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3461 | 適当 | てきとう | Appropriate | Proper\n Suitable\n Irresponsible | Everything is suitable and right. Therefore it is appropriate, proper, and suitable. Strangely enough, this also means irresponsible. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible? \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3462 | 服飾 | ふくしょく | Attire | Fashion\n Clothing | The clothes with which I decorate myself with is my attire or my fashion. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3463 | 先程 | さきほど | A While Ago |  | The previous extent of time was a while ago. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a while ago, now, associate! \n The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.
3464 | 背景 | はいけい | Background |  | The back scene is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the background. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3465 | 背後 | はいご | Background | Behind The Scenes | Something that's behind your back is in the background. It's also probably plotting against you, behind the scenes. Sneaky, sneaky. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
3466 | 預金 | よきん | Bank Deposit | Deposit\n Bank Account | Deposit your gold here in the bank. When you do that, it is a bank deposit. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3467 | バイキング | バイキング | Buffet | Smorgasbord\n Viking | バイキング comes from the English word Viking, but in Japanese, it often refers to a buffet.\nバイキング came to mean "buffet" thanks to Japan’s first all-you-can-eat restaurant, "Viking", which was named after a feast scene from a movie called (you guessed it) "Viking".
3468 | 官僚的 | かんりょうてき | Bureaucratic |  | If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it bureaucratic. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.
3469 | 強盗 | ごうとう | Burglary | Robbery\n Burglar\n Robber | You are strong so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then steal from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a burglary or robbery, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. But 強  has two on'yomi readings, and you haven't really seen this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nThink about how when you commit a robbery, you go (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.
3470 | 版権 | はんけん | Copyright |  | You have edition rights over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have copyright. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3471 | 電飾 | でんしょく | Decorative Lighting |  | The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have decorate. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have decorative lighting.\nThis is quite a specific word that is generally used as a product category for decorative lighting. It’s a less common word than other expressions, such as デコレーションライト or イルミネーションライト. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3472 | 電気柵 | でんきさく | Electric Fence |  | If you combine 電気 (electricity) with 柵 (fence) you have an electric fence. Shocking, I know. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

3482 | 鉄柵 | てっさく | Iron Fence |  | Ready for this one? An iron fence  is an iron fence. Be careful though, 鉄 is normally read as てつ, but in this case it is shortened to てっ.
3483 | 鉄板 | てっぱん | Iron Plate | Iron Griddle\n Teppan Grill\n Sure Thing | Well, you've got iron and you've got a board. You'd probably just call it an iron plate, though. But this often isn't just any iron plate. If you could guess from the reading, it's often used in cooking as an iron griddle, or a teppan grill. Ever heard of Teppanyaki?\nFiguratively, it means a sure thing or a practically guaranteed success. For example, you can use 鉄板 for a racehorse almost certain to win, or a joke that consistently gets big laughs. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Watch out for the rendaku and you should be good!
3484 | 成程 | なるほど | I See | That's Right\n Indeed | If you become aware of something to an extent you'll end up saying I see or That's right! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, indeed." \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

3496 | 我が〜 | わが | Our | One's Own\n My | Here we have I followed by the particle が, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say our, one's own, or my.\nOne explanation for this is that in ancient Japanese, が was used as a possessive particle, much like の is in modern Japanese. \n You haven't learned this reading for 我 so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nLet us present you with our walrus (わ). Well it's my walrus really, but I'm happy to share.

3498 | 主 | ぬし | Owner |  | The master is the owner who has dominance or control over something.\n主 is usually used with other words to indicate a person who owns something or who is principally involved in an action. That might sound a little vague, so check out the collocations and context sentences to get a better grasp of this word! \n The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this:\nThe owner of those nude sheep (ぬし) doesn’t even need their wool, he just likes owning nude sheep. So he keeps them as pets and shaves them every day. He’s not interested in sheep with fur. Only nude sheep for this owner!
3499 | 撮影 | さつえい | Photoshoot | Movie Shoot\n Photographing\n Filming | Back in the day, you'd use shadows to photograph things. Now it's all fancy and digital. More simply, it can be photographing or filming as well. Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 3502 | 快い | こころよい | Pleasant |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasant? It is also pleasant. \n This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a pleasant feeling. A こころよい feeling.

3521 | 構え | かまえ | Stance | Posture\n Structure | You know 構える, which can mean to assume a stance? This is the noun version, making it stance.\n構え is often used to describe specific stances or postures, both in a literal and figurative sense. In this vein, it can also convey the notion of being mentally and physically prepared for action. Additionally, 構え is also used to refer to the structure of something, often focussing on visual appearance. \n The reading is like 構える, so as long as you know that you know this too.
