3526 | 翌月 | よくげつ | The Next Month | Next Month\n The Following Month | The next month is the next month. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3527 | 翌朝 | よくあさ | The Next Morning | Next Morning\n The Following Morning | The next morning is the next morning. \n The reading can be what you've learned with the kanji, よくあさ, or it can be the on'yomi reading across the board, よくちょう. Both are good to remember because よくちょう is more formal (you'll use that reading in writing more often) and よくあさ is more informal - you'll use that in speaking more often.
3528 | 翌年 | よくねん | The Next Year | Next Year\n The Following Year | The next year is the next year. \n The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.
3529 | 切符 | きっぷ | Ticket |  | A cut token is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a ticket. \n The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.
3530 | 揃える | そろえる | To Arrange Something | To Collect Something\n To Align Something | Remember 揃う, "to be complete"? This is the transitive version of that, and it means things like to arrange something, to gather something, and to align something.\nThis one is a little tricky to understand and translate well. At its core, this verb describes the act of arranging all of the necessary things for something. But it can also describe aligning certain things in a uniform, matching manner. If this still isn't clear, have a careful look at our context sentences and collocations! \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already know this, so you're all good here!
3531 | 攻撃する | こうげきする | To Attack |  | 攻撃 is an attack. Make that into a verb and you have to attack. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 攻撃 as well.
3532 | 渇く | かわく | To Become Thirsty | To Be Thirsty\n To Become Dry | When you have a thirst, you tend to become thirsty.\nNote that this does not mean “to be thirsty” by itself, but only in combination with 喉, as in 喉が渇く. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?
3533 | 怖がる | こわがる | To Be Scared | To Be Afraid Of\n To Fear | 怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it to be scared or to be afraid of. \n The reading comes from 怖い.
3534 | 移る | うつる | To Be Shifted | To Be Transferred | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift and the verb vocab version is to be shifted. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really rude (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely). \n The reading is the same as 移す, so use that to remember this!
3535 | 詰まる | つまる | To Be Stuffed | To Be Crammed Full\n To Be Stuck | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed. The vocab word is to be stuffed, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying). \n This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji!
3536 | 冷やす | ひやす | To Chill Something | To Chill | 冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is to chill something. \n To chill something, you need to apply cold, not heat (ひ).
3537 | 飾る | かざる | To Decorate |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decorate. The verb vocab version is to decorate. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To decorate something, you don't really need a cause (かざ). You should just do it, just because.
3538 | 預ける | あずける | To Deposit | To Entrust\n To Leave Something With Someone | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means deposit so the verb vocab version is to deposit or to entrust. You use this word when you are leaving something with someone else. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn terms of places where you want to deposit your money, the last place on your list should be a zoo (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.
3539 | 診断する | しんだんする | To Diagnose |  | 診断 is a diagnosis. Make this into a verb, and you have to diagnose. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3540 | 絶える | たえる | To Die Out | To End\n To Be Cut Off | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means die out so the verb vocab version is to die out. You know that this one is "to die out" because you're up in the air (える), looking down at the dinosaurs, who are all dying out. Thank goodness you're up in the air, because the ground is all on fire. \n The reading can come from 絶つ, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.
3541 | 照れる | てれる | To Feel Embarrassed | To Be Shy\n To Be Bashful | If you illuminate the things I've done, I start to feel embarrassed. Please don't embarrass me. :( \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your 手 (て). It's all blue and scary looking.
3542 | 浮く | うく | To Float |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means float so the verb vocab version is to float. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. う!
3543 | 埋もれる | うもれる | To Get Buried | To Be Buried\n To Be Covered | You know that 埋まる is "to be buried." This verb is also to be buried or to get buried.\nHowever, there's a slight difference between them. 埋まる focuses on the subject itself getting buried or filled, while 埋もれる highlights the sense of something being hidden or obscured by being covered. So you could use it to describe a yard covered in snow or your talent being overshadowed in a competitive environment.\nYou can remember this nuance because it's more rare (もれる) to see something completely buried and covered up. \n The reading comes from 埋める.
3544 | 越える | こえる | To Go Beyond | To Cross Over | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond, the verb vocab version is to go beyond. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in both the USA and Japan.
3545 | 押さえる | おさえる | To Hold Something Down | To Grasp Something | The kanji means push, and this verb means things like to hold something down and to grasp something. This verb is pretty versatile, and you can use it if you're holding down a piece of paper, holding a cloth to a wound, or grasping a concept. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so hopefully you can read this on your own.
3546 | 痛める | いためる | To Injure Something | To Hurt Something\n To Hurt Someone | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means pain, and this verb is transitive, so it means to inflict pain. In other words, it's to injure something or to hurt someone.\nThis verb focusses on the pain involved in an injury, so it can only be used for things that feel pain, like people and body parts. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the word 痛い.
3547 | 漏れる | もれる | To Leak | To Leak Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leak so the verb vocab version is to leak. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you to leak all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend Moe (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.
3548 | 並べる | ならべる | To Line Something Up | To Put Something In Order | 並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. In other words, 並べる is transitive. It means to line something up or to put something in order. You know this because when it comes to bears (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure. \n The reading of the kanji is same as for 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.
3549 | 騒ぐ | さわぐ | To Make Noise | To Be Boisterous\n To Make A Fuss | The kanji is boisterous. The verb version is to make noise or to be boisterous. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from. \n You're always going to make noise and be boisterous when you eat something sour (さわ). Imagine stuffing lemon slices, sour candy, and umeboshi into your mouth. All at once. See how much noise you make? They're so sour, and they make you so boisterous.
3550 | 寄せる | よせる | To Move Something Close To | To Pull Something Over\n To Contribute Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means approach, and the verb version is about making or letting something approach. That's why it means to move something close to, to pull something over, and also to contribute something. \n You want to move something close to you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty yo-yo (よ) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!
3551 | 豚骨ラーメン | とんこつらーめん | Tonkotsu Ramen | Pork Bone Ramen | Pig bone ramen is tonkotsu ramen or, very logically indeed, pork bone ramen.\n豚骨ラーメン is a type of Japanese ramen made with a rich, creamy broth from 豚骨 (pork bones). The bones are simmered for hours to extract the flavors, resulting in a flavorful and hearty soup. It's so delicious, you'll be back for more. Bone appetit! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know both of these readings, but in case you need a reminder, here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nYou really like tonkotsu ramen so you just ate a whole ton (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of pork bone ramen.

If someone doesn't want to play with you, they're the a**hole (あそ), not you.

3554 | 延ばす | のばす | To Prolong Something | To Lengthen Something\n To Extend Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prolong and this verb means to prolong something.\n延ばす conveys the idea of expanding upon something that already exists to make it longer, often in terms of time or physical distance. For example, it can refer to delaying a schedule or extending a railway. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. 3556 | 登録する | とうろくする | To Register |  | 登録 is registration. Make that into a verb and you have to register. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3557 | 退ける | しりぞける | To Repel Something | To Dismiss Something\n To Reject Something | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means retreat, and this verb version is when you make something retreat. In other words, it means to repel something, to dismiss something, or to reject something.\nThis is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You repel something, like bad luck. You reject something, like a proposal. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this with its intransitive pair verb 退く, but here's a mnemonic just in case:\nRemember the re-zoner? Well, to repel bad luck, she, re-zoned (しりぞ) the whole place. No bad luck allowed inside the zone.
3558 | 匂う | におう | To Smell | To Smell Bad | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smell so the verb version is to smell.\nAlthough 匂う is technically a neutral term, it often means to smell bad. To emphasize the stinkiness, you can also use the kanji 臭 instead of 匂. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
3559 | 盗む | ぬすむ | To Steal |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means steal, so the verb vocab version is to steal. \n What are you going to steal? How about a noose (ぬす)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...
3560 | 撮る | とる | To Take A Picture | To Take A Photo\n To Take A Video | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means photograph. When you make that into a verb, you are doing a photograph, aka making it become to take a picture. It can also be to film as well. Really anything to do with a camera. \n Think of the reading like you do the meaning to take a photograph. You "take" all these things, and how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's 取る, aka とる, which happens to be the same reading!

3563 | 処置 | しょち | Treatment | Measure\n Disposal\n Deal With | We're going to deal with it by putting this up your butt and giving you the treatment you need. 3565 | 浮世絵 | うきよえ | Ukiyo-e | Ukiyo-e Woodblock Print\n Ukiyo-e Painting | A floating world painting is what you call an ukiyo-e woodblock print in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment are. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e! \n The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

3604 | 壊れ物 | こわれもの | Fragile Thing | Breakables\n Fragile Item | A thing that could break easily, is a fragile thing. Be careful with things like this. \n The reading is 壊れる and 物 put together.
3605 | 貨物 | かもつ | Freight | Cargo | Freight things is freight or cargo. \n The reading is the 物 reading that's もつ. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (持つ it!).
3606 | 融合 | ゆうごう | Fusion |  | Dissolve and then join together again to create a reaction, a fusion reaction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3607 | 華美 | かび | Gaudy | Pomp\n Splendor\n Splendour | If something has showy beauty then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as gaudy. Too much is too much. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3608 | 幾何学 | きかがく | Geometry |  | How many? What? In this area of study, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is geometry, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?). \n The 学 is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The 幾 and 何 is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with か. So, it's like, "何か????" and that's why it becomes か. Then, for 幾 think about how the key (き) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the keyか?"
3609 | 孫 | まご | Grandchild |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou are the grandchild of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a maggot (まご). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.
3610 | 墓 | はか | Grave |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n When you finally have a grave and you're dead and buried, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.
3611 | 花粉症 | かふんしょう | Hay Fever | Pollinosis | The flower powder symptoms are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is hay fever. \n The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but 花. Instead, 花 is か, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the hay fever is to jump in your car and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.
3612 | 幾つ | いくつ | How Many | How Old | This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how many meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "つ." This can also be used to ask how old someone is, but generally only for children's ages.\nThis word is usually written in kana in modern writing. \n The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.
3613 | 幾度 | いくど | How Many Times | How Often | How many occurences is just another way of asking how many times.\nThis word is more literary and formal than 何回 or 何度. \n The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
3614 | 幾ら | いくら | How Much |  | This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how much meaning. To remember this, just think about how Ra, the Egyptian God, is always asking "How much will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
3615 | 尋問 | じんもん | Interrogation | Questioning | When you inquire about a problem, you tend to do interrogation-style questioning to get to the bottom of it. Why is it like this? What happened? Is it bigger than a breadbox? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

3617 | 巣立ち | すだち | Leave The Nest | Become Independent | When you stand up out of the nest, you're getting ready to leave it. Your mother may be sad about this, but this means it's time to leave the nest and become independent. \n The readings are from the words 巣 and 立つ put together.
3618 | 豪華 | ごうか | Luxurious | Splendid\n Luxury | Oh wow, that is exceptionally showy! Whatever that thing is, it is luxurious and splendid and I want one. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3619 | 雄 | おす | Male |  | The kanji means male and this also means male. It's used for animals, plants, and the like.\nNote that this is often written in katakana, as in オス. \n Male animals can be kind of pushy, always trying to push (押す) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.
3620 | 雄犬 | おすいぬ | Male Dog |  | A male dog is a male dog.\nIt's worth mentioning that you'll see this most often written in katakana, as both オス犬 and オスの犬. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for 犬, but for 雄 you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying to push (押す) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.

3643 | 華やか | はなやか | Showy | Gorgeous\n Glamorous | Something that is showy is showy. \n For the reading, think about something that's showy... in particular, 花s (はな). Flowers are super showy, always showing off their colors and stuff.

3645 | クモの巣 | くものす | Spiderweb |  | クモ is a spider. Add a nest to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spiders call their nests? They call it a spiderweb (that is, if they can talk). \n 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
3646 | 倉 | くら | Storehouse | Warehouse\n Kura | The kanji means storehouse, and the vocab is also storehouse!\nWondering what the difference between 倉 and 庫 is? Long ago, 倉 were places to store grain, while 庫 used to be associated with places to store vehicles, as the kanji composition suggests. These days, they're both used for general storage, but also refer to places to store goods and merchandise. Between the two, 倉 is much more commonly used. \n The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 庫. They're basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).
3647 | 鼻詰まり | はなづまり | Stuffy Nose | Blocked Nose | 詰まる is "to be stuffed." So, if your nose is stuffed, then you have a stuffy nose. \n The reading is 鼻 and 詰まる put together. the 詰まり is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.
3648 | 均整 | きんせい | Symmetry | Balance | Things are equal in how they're arranged. They have perfect symmetry and balance. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3649 | 壊れる | こわれる | To Be Broken | To Get Broken | 壊す is "to break something." 壊れる is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is to be broken. \n The reading comes from 壊す, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.
3650 | 延びる | のびる | To Be Extended | To Be Delayed\n To Be Prolonged | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means to be extended, to be delayed, or to be prolonged. If you know the word ビル, you can think about how building work is always prolonged or delayed, to help you remember that this is intransitive. We never know why it's delayed, it just happens all by itself! \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 延ばす.
3651 | 富む | とむ | To Be Rich In | To Be Abundant In\n To Be Wealthy | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rich so the verb vocab version would be to be rich in.\n富む is a formal word that's commonly used in writing. While it can refer to material wealth, it's more commonly used figuratively to describe an abundance of qualities, a place rich in nature or specific resources, or emotional richness or fulfillment. \n Think about the richest person you know. That person is Tom (とむ). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.
3652 | 散る | ちる | To Be Scattered | To Get Scattered\n To Scatter | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scatter so the verb vocab version is to be scattered. You know that this verb represents when something is scattering (you're not doing the scattering), because you would never be so rude as to scatter someone or something yourself. It only happens when it happens on its own. \n Think about something scattering. That something is cheese (ち), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?
3653 | 驚く | おどろく | To Be Surprised | To Be Shocked | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surprised, so the verb vocab version is to be surprised. \n What are you so surprised by? Your friend's odor (おどろ). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.
3654 | 思い詰める | おもいつめる | To Brood | To Dwell On\n To Take Something To Heart | 詰める is "to stuff in." If you're really stuffing in your thoughts (think), you're thinking very deeply and seriously. So this is to brood, to dwell on, or to take something to heart.\n思い詰める suggests you're pondering deeply over something serious or distressing, bordering on overthinking. \n The reading is 思い and 詰める put together into one reading.
3655 | 除く | のぞく | To Exclude | To Remove | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exclude so the verb vocab version is to exclude. \n You would like to exclude your nose (のぞ) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.
3656 | 恐れる | おそれる | To Fear | To Dread | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fear so the verb version is to fear. \n The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.
3657 | 照らす | てらす | To Illuminate |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to illuminate. Don't get it confused with 照れる which is "to feel embarrassed," though, that would be embarrassing. You know this is "to illuminate" because the らす is the rash (らす) you get every time you're illuminated. \n Speaking of things that illuminate, your hands (手) illuminate all the time for some reason.
3658 | 尋ねる | たずねる | To Inquire | To Ask | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inquire so the verb vocab version is to inquire. \n I'd like to inquire about a few things. Wait, what? You won't cooperate? How about I just taze (たず) you with this tazer then? BzzzbbzbhhhAHHHHHH!
3659 | 絶やす | たやす | To Kill Off | To Let Die Out | 絶える is "to die out." 絶やす is "to kill off." You know this because if something is to die off, you'd say "no." But if you're the one doing the killing off, you'd say yes (やす). \n The reading comes from 絶える.
3660 | 編む | あむ | To Knit |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means knit so the verb vocab version is to knit. \n When you start to knit, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "A" (あ). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.
3661 | 徳川 | とくがわ | Tokugawa | Tokugawa Shogun | This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the Tokugawa family name, also known as the Tokugawa Shogun. They ran Japan for a while, you know? \n The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one.
3662 | 徳島県 | とくしまけん | Tokushima Prefecture |  | The virtue island prefecture is Tokushima prefecture. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture." \n The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is Tokushima Prefecture.
3663 | 嘆く | なげく | To Lament | To Grieve | When you sigh, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you to lament and to grieve. \n For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. Throw (投げる) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!
3664 | 迷わす | まよわす | To Lead Astray | To Perplex | The word 迷う means "to go astray" but this word is to lead astray. You are doing the astraying to someone or something else. You know this because the other person was (わす) just fine until you came along to lead them astray. \n The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.
3665 | 探す | さがす | To Look For | To Search For | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look for and the verb version of the kanji is to look for.\nCurious about the difference between 捜す and 探す? While there is some overlap between the two, 捜す is typically used in official, thorough searches for something or someone that is thought to concretely exist and has disappeared or cannot be easily found. In contrast, 探す can also be used for personal searches for things that one desires or is looking for. \n You are looking for a sagger (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go to search for them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.
3666 | 積む | つむ | To Pile Things Up | To Accumulate | 積もる is "to accumulate." Now you're doing the accumulating, and in order to do that you must go to pile things up. More and more and more. How do you know that this verb is when you're doing the accumulating? It's because you are piling up cows (む). Wow, a cow piler. \n The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.
3667 | 救う | すくう | To Rescue |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rescue so the verb vocab version is to rescue. \n The すく in the reading is a lot like the scue (すくう) part of to rescue, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.
3668 | 似る | にる | To Resemble | To Look Like | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resemble so the verb vocab version is to resemble or to look like. \n You should have learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic to help you, just in case:\nWhat are you trying to resemble?? Is that... oh no. A knee (に) face resemble surgery, where you make your face look like your knee and vice versa? Do you know how dangerous that surgery is?
3669 | 離れる | はなれる | To Separate | To Leave\n To Detach Oneself | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means detach, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it to separate and to leave. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's rare (れる) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see れる usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it. \n For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the 花s (はな) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.
3670 | 主催する | しゅさいする | To Sponsor | To Promote | If 主催 is sponsorship, the verb version of that would be to sponsor. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 3671 | 見詰める | みつめる | To Stare At |  | When you really stuff in (詰める) what you are seeing, you're really looking at something, causing you to stare at whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into. \n The reading is 見 and 詰める.

That or subways/trains, but underground shopping centers are way more interesting. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3676 | 普段 | ふだん | Usual | Usually\n Always | The normal steps are the ones that are totally usual. They're the ones you usually do, unlike those weird not usual steps. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3677 | 野菜 | やさい | Vegetable |  | A field vegetable is still a vegetable, whether it comes from the field or not. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3678 | 菜食 | さいしょく | Vegetarian Diet |  | If you eat vegetable food you are on a vegetarian diet. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3679 | 倉庫 | そうこ | Warehouse | Storehouse | A storage warehouse is some kind of warehouse, or some kind of storehouse.\nCurious about the difference between 倉庫 and 庫? While 庫 refers to traditional Japanese storehouses, 倉庫 is used for modern warehouses and storehouses, both the commercial kind and the ones for personal use. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3680 | 富 | とみ | Wealth | Riches | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. Someone who is rich has wealth and riches, right? \n For the reading, think about the person you know with the most wealth. It is Tommy (とみ) Hilfiger.
3681 | 富裕 | ふゆう | Wealthy | Affluent\n Rich | If you're rich and abundant, you are super wealthy, affluent, and rich. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3682 | 地帯 | ちたい | Zone | District | This earth belt is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own zone or district. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3683 | 功績 | こうせき | Achievement | Accomplishment | Your achievements and exploits are your achievements. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3684 | 賛成 | さんせい | Agreement | Approval\n Support | It has become that we agree. We have agreement! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3685 | 志 | こころざし | Ambition | Intention | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n When you have the ambition to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say 心ざし (こころざし), which is how this word was written in classical Japanese. In modern Japanese it's always 志, but the reading is exactly the same. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!
3686 | 先祖 | せんぞ | Ancestors | One's Ancestors | Your previous ancestors are your ancestors. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！
3687 | 食欲 | しょくよく | Appetite |  | I have a food want. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your appetite. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3688 | 恩人 | おんじん | Benefactor |  | A kindness person is a very kind person. This person is a benefactor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3689 | 血液 | けつえき | Blood |  | Your blood fluid is your blood. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3690 | ゆで卵 | ゆでたまご | Boiled Egg |  | The ゆで comes from the verb ゆでる, which means "to boil." So this word means boiled egg. \n The reading comes from the kanji.
3691 | 火傷 | やけど | Burn | Scald | A fire wound is a burn or scald you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch! \n The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a burn (on your arm) being caused by a yakky dodo (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.
3692 | 背広 | せびろ | Business Suit |  | If your back is wide, you need a nice business suit to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.
3693 | 肉欲 | にくよく | Carnal Desires |  | Your meat wants are your deepest desires, your carnal desires. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3694 | 桜んぼ | さくらんぼ | Cherry |  | A cherry tree can create a cherry. This is what this word is. \n The reading comes from the kanji.
3695 | 大騒ぎ | おおさわぎ | Clamor | Uproar\n Big Noise | If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a big version of this is even louder. It's a clamor and an uproar. \n This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!
3696 | 押入れ | おしいれ | Closet | Cupboard | You push things to make them enter the closet or cupboard. \n The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.
3697 | 銭 | ぜに | Coin | Money\n Bucks | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also mean money more generally. \n The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is ぜに. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."
3698 | 共産党 | きょうさんとう | Communist Party |  | The idea of everyone together sharing property between them comes from which party? That's the Communist Party. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3699 | 複雑 | ふくざつ | Complicated | Complex | There are duplicates of everything, not to mention the duplicates are random. Nothing makes sense, and everything is super complicated. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3700 | 便秘 | べんぴ | Constipation |  | For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A toilet secret is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is constipation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."
3701 | 伝染病 | でんせんびょう | Contagious Disease |  | A sickness that can transmit and then dye into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a contagious disease. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3702 | 複写 | ふくしゃ | Copying | Photocopy\n Carbon Copy | When you make a duplicate copy you are copying things. Especially if you're making a photocopy or a carbon copy. It's like a copy of a copy!\n複写 is a pretty formal word for copying documents, text, or images. It's still often used to talk about carbon copies. But for photocopies, most people just say コピー(する) these days. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3703 | 飾り | かざり | Decoration | Ornament | This is the noun version of the kanji decorate, so it means decoration. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
3704 | 志望 | しぼう | Desire | Ambition\n Applying | Your intention for your hope is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your desire. This is your ambition. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3705 | 机 | つくえ | Desk |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
3706 | 汚水 | おすい | Dirty Water | Filthy Water\n Sewage | Dirty water is dirty water. Gross. Could also be sewage. Even grosser. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

3708 | 英訳 | えいやく | English Translation |  | English translate is an English translation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3709 | 眼 | め | Eye | Eyeball | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than 目. \n The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!
3710 | 眼球 | がんきゅう | Eyeball |  | An eyeball sphere is an eyeball. Eww. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3711 | 老眼 | ろうがん | Farsightedness |  | An elderly eyeball is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means farsightedness. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3712 | 永遠 | えいえん | Forever | Eternity\n Permanence | An eternity that is far away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's forever, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3713 | 永久 | えいきゅう | Forever | Eternity | Eternity is a long time... as in forever. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3714 | 成績 | せいせき | Grades | Ranking | You become exploits... as in, your exploits become a thing you can actually see, and you can see them in the form of grades. Ouch, some of your exploits weren't all that amazing... \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3715 | 祖父 | そふ | Grandfather | Grandpa | Your ancestor father isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your grandfather. \n The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a fool (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.
3716 | 祖母 | そぼ | Grandmother | Grandma | Your ancestor mother isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your grandmother. \n The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your grandmother had a boat (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.
3717 | 傷心 | しょうしん | Heartbreak |  | A wound of your heart. That could be many things, but in this case it's heartbreak. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3718 | 桜肉 | さくらにく | Horse Meat |  | Strangely, cherry tree meat isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's horse meat. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji. \n The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

3727 | 久しい | ひさしい | Long Ago | For a Long Time | This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of long time? Well, it's long ago, or can mean for a long time. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nLong ago, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "Heesa (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!
3728 | 結婚式 | けっこんしき | Marriage Ceremony | Wedding | If 結婚 is marriage, then a marriage ceremony is a marriage ceremony or wedding. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3729 | 雑費 | ざっぴ | Miscellaneous Expenses |  | Random expenses are miscellaneous expenses. Not actually random, but they feel that way. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.
3730 | 複数 | ふくすう | Multiple | Plural | The duplicate numbers are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing multiple. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3731 | 雑音 | ざつおん | Noise | Static | Random noise is still noise, though more specifically it is random noise, like static. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3732 | 撮影禁止 | さつえいきんし | No Photos | No Photos Allowed | 撮影 is photography. 禁止 is prohibition. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a no photos or no photos allowed rule in place. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.
3733 | 背中 | せなか | One's Back | Back | The middle of your back is one's back (or your back). \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.
3734 | 酸素 | さんそ | Oxygen |  | The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “Säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck.\nOr you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3735 | 党員 | とういん | Party Member |  | A party member is party member of a political party. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3736 | 人脈 | じんみゃく | Personal Connections | Network | Your person veins are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your personal connections, your network. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3737 | 桜色 | さくらいろ | Pink | Pale Pink | A cherry blossom color is what color? Kind of a pink, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be. \n The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.
3738 | 遊び | あそび | Play | Playing\n Games | This is the noun version of the kanji play, so it means play or playing! \n You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!

3741 | 貧乏人 | びんぼうにん | Poor Person |  | 貧乏 is poor, so a poor person is a poor person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

3744 | 銭湯 | せんとう | Public Bath |  | Give a coin and get hot water. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a public bath. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the public bath, you're in Tokyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.
3745 | 出版社 | しゅっぱんしゃ | Publishing Company | Publisher | If 出版 means publishing, then a company that does said publishing is a publishing company. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.
3746 | 押しボタン | おしぼたん | Push Button |  | If 押し is push, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a push button. \n The reading is the same as 押す.
3747 | 生卵 | なまたまご | Raw Egg |  | Remember how 生 can mean raw? Well, it does now. So, a raw egg? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means raw egg. \n The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one 生卵.
3748 | 訳 | わけ | Reason |  | This word takes the reason meaning of the kanji, making it reason. What's the reason for it having two meanings? I have no clue, but there must be a reason.\nWhile 理由 is the general term for reasons, 訳 tends to be more focused on the underlying reason or cause of something. It's also used when explaining a situation or when there's an implied need to justify or clarify something. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?
3749 | 恩賞 | おんしょう | Reward |  | A kindness prize is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a reward.\nNote: this is an older word, so you'll probably only see it in history books, but it's important to know anyway! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3750 | 桜 | さくら | Sakura | Cherry Tree\n Cherry Blossom | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
3751 | 衛星 | えいせい | Satellite |  | A defense star isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a satellite, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion canons and video and things like that. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both already, so you should be able to read this word!
3752 | 恐い | こわい | Scary | Frightening\n Eerie\n Dreadful\n I'm Afraid\n I'm Scared | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? Scary or frightening. It can also mean I'm afraid or I'm scared  too. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.
3753 | 密か | ひそか | Secret | Private | Something that has secrecy is secret and private. \n Think about that really secret and private dude. He so (ひそ) secret...
3754 | 秘密 | ひみつ | Secret | A Secret | Secret and secrecy. Combine the two and you have quite the secret. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3755 | 密告 | みっこく | Secret Information |  | In secrecy you must announce this information. It's not for anyone to hear, it's secret information. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.
3756 | 密会 | みっかい | Secret Meeting | Clandestine Meeting | A secrecy meet is a secret meeting. You know the password? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.
3757 | 自衛 | じえい | Self Defense |  | Self defense is when you protect yourself. It's self defense. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3758 | 順序 | じゅんじょ | Sequence | Order\n Steps | The order of things is the preface to the entire sequence and steps we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3759 | 飾り気 | かざりけ | Showing Off | Affectation | If you decorate your spirit with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just showing off. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations. \n Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary.\nThe second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAt the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.
3760 | 匂い | におい | Smell | Scent\n Odor | This the noun version of the kanji for smell. It also means smell, or scent!\nAlthough 匂う often implies something smells unpleasant, 匂い is more neutral and can refer to any kind of smell. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
3761 | 密輸 | みつゆ | Smuggling |  | A secrecy transport is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to smuggling. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3762 | 社会党 | しゃかいとう | Socialist Party |  | The society (社会) party is the socialist party. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3763 | 酸っぱい | すっぱい | Sour |  | The taste of something with acid is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a sour taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word. \n Something was so sour that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to sue (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.
3764 | 汚点 | おてん | Stain | Smudge | A dirty point is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a stain or smudge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3765 | 背丈 | せたけ | Stature | Height | Someone's back height is their height. It also refers to their stature. \n The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.
3766 | 厳しい | きびしい | Strict | Harsh\n Severe | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strict? It is also strict. \n The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!
3767 | 厳禁 | げんきん | Strictly Forbidden | Strictly Prohibited\n Strict Prohibition\n Ban | Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3768 | 背が高い | せがたかい | Tall |  | This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree. \n This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!
3769 | 照り焼き | てりやき | Teriyaki |  | You illuminate some food, then bake it. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from the teriyaki you get in the west. \n The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.
3770 | 冷える | ひえる | To Be Chilled | To Get Cold | If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing. \n The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.
3771 | 浮かれる | うかれる | To Be Happy | To Be In High Spirits\n To Be Elated | 浮く means "to float," and 浮かれる draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean to be happy, to be in high spirits, or to be elated. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine." \n The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going to be happy and you won't have a care (かれる) in the world!
3772 | 秘める | ひめる | To Conceal | To Keep Secret | If you secret something, you are trying to keep secret something. That, or you're trying to conceal it. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing to conceal about this reading, you gots it.
3773 | 染める | そめる | To Dye |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dye so the verb vocab version is to dye. \n You need to dye something that you just sewed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.
3774 | 火照る | ほてる | To Feel Hot | To Flush\n To Burn | If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing:\nWhen are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!
3775 | 採る | とる | To Gather | To Take\n To Pick | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gather so the verb vocab version is to gather. \n When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: とる.
3776 | 汚れる | よごれる | To Get Dirty | To Get Polluted\n To Become Dirty | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dirty so the verb vocab version is to get dirty. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's rare (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own. \n Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean.\nNote that the reading よごれる is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas けがれる is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.
3777 | 濡れる | ぬれる | To Get Wet | To Be Wet | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet, so the verb version is to get wet. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
3778 | 越す | こす | To Go Beyond |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond so the verb vocab version is also to go beyond.\nThis is very similar in meaning to 越える. Both can refer to overcoming some physical object or passing beyond a certain amount of time. However, 越す tends to sound a little less intense, while 越える really focuses on the physical or emotional challenge of overcoming a certain milestone. For example, while 山を越す simply refers to crossing a mountain, 山を越える gives the impression that crossing the mountain is a difficulty you've overcome. \n The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic:\nTo go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.
3779 | 飼う | かう | To Keep A Pet | To Raise A Pet\n To Own A Pet | The kanji is domesticate. When you domesticate an animal, you get to keep a pet of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of cat!
3780 | 漏らす | もらす | To Leak Something | To Leak | If 漏れる is "to leak," then this is when you do the leaking yourself. The reason this thing is leaking, though (and it shouldn't be), is because you rushed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself), which is why you know this is to leak something. \n The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.
3781 | 預かる | あずかる | To Look After | To Take Care Of\n To Hold On To | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means deposit, and you already learned a similar word that means the same thing as the kanji, 預ける. With this verb, someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you to look after, to take care of, or to hold on to it.\nTo differentiate it with 預ける, think of the か in 預かる. The only thing you're willing to look after is your car (か), and nothing else! Someone asks you to look after their kids? Sorry, nothing doing, you're busy taking care of your car. Can you hold on to someone's luggage for them? Nope, your car takes priority. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:\nYou need someone to look after your kids for the day. Hey, I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at a zoo (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your cars (か) for the day!
3782 | 結婚する | けっこんする | To Marry | To Get Married | 結婚 is marriage, so the verb version of that would be to marry or to get married. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.
3783 | 迎える | むかえる | To Pick Someone Up | To Meet Someone\n To Welcome\n To Invite | The kanji means welcome, but the verb version is to pick someone up or to meet someone. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going to meet someone too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways. \n To pick someone up you are going to drive your moo car. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.
3784 | 延長する | えんちょうする | To Prolong | To Extend | If 延長 is prolonging, then the verb version is to prolong. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3785 | 出版する | しゅっぱんする | To Publish |  | If 出版 is publishing, then the verb vocab version is to publish. \n The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.
3786 | 購読する | こうどくする | To Subscribe |  | If 購読 is a subscription, then the verb vocab version would be to subscribe. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3787 | 似合う | にあう | To Suit | To Match | It resembles you! It suits you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf to suit you, you know? \n The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.
3788 | 捨てる | すてる | To Throw Away | To Abandon | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw away so the verb version is to throw away. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to throw away that bit of knowledge just yet!
3789 | 訳す | やくす | To Translate |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means translate so the verb version would be to translate. \n The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.
3790 | 訳語 | やくご | Translated Term |  | A translated bit of language is a translated term. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3791 | 訳者 | やくしゃ | Translator |  | Someone who translates things is a translator. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3792 | 採用 | さいよう | Use | Adoption\n Acceptance\n Employment | I gather things and use them. The things I've gathered, are the things I use. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3793 | 採決 | さいけつ | Voting |  | When people gather and decide things, they decide together, usually by voting. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3794 | 欲しい | ほしい | Wanted | Desired\n Want | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of want? It's also wanted. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A hoe (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.
3795 | 欲求 | よっきゅう | Wants | Desires\n Craving | What you want and request are your wants, your desires, perhaps your craving. You want these things so you request them. I wants them! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.
3796 | 温暖 | おんだん | Warm | Mild\n Warmth | Warm warm is warm. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3797 | 暖かい | あたたかい | Warm | Mild | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm as well! Though this is for a warm weather or temperature, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right? \n The reading is the same as 温かい, which also means warm. But while that 温かい refers to a warm thing, this 暖かい refers to a warm temperature or place.\nJust like with 温かい, people often pronounce this as あったかい in conversation. But when it comes to kanji exams or typing out the kanji, remember to use あたたかい!
3798 | 白旗 | しろはた | White Flag |  | A white flag is a white flag. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji! \n The most common reading for this is the vocab kun'yomi readings put together to make しろはた. The other two readings are much less common, so I'd recommend focusing on しろはた!
3799 | 意志 | いし | Will | Volition | You have an idea and you have intent to carry it out. This is your will and volition. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3800 | 意欲 | いよく | Will | Desire\n Ambition | If you have an idea of what you want already, then that's good! You have will, desire, and ambition. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3801 | 傷 | きず | Wound | Damage\n Flaw | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a wound... she would kiss (きず) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?
3802 | 異常 | いじょう | Abnormal | Strange\n Disorder | When something differs from normal it's called abnormal or strange. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3803 | 異状 | いじょう | Abnormality | Something Wrong | It differs from the normal condition of things, making it weird. It is an abnormality. There is something wrong. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3804 | 忠告 | ちゅうこく | Advice | Admonishment | A loyalty announcement is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of advice or maybe admonishment, if you're upset with what they've done. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3805 | 裏通り | うらどおり | Alley | Back Street | A backside street (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an alley. \n The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.
3806 | 年次 | ねんじ | Annual | Yearly | The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual?\n年次 is a formal term typically used in business settings, such as in 年次報告書 (annual report) or 年次休暇 (annual leave). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3807 | 武装 | ぶそう | Arms | Armament\n Armed | The most important part of your military attire are your arms (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3808 | 灰 | はい | Ash | Ashes | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
3809 | 灰皿 | はいざら | Ashtray |  | An ash plate is a plate you use for ashes. That's an ashtray. \n The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together.
3810 | 不振 | ふしん | A Slump | Sluggish | If something does not shake, it’s probably in a slump. If nothing’s shaking, things must be sluggish.\n不振 is used for times when things are slower or worse than usual. For example, 業績不振 is when a business isn’t doing as well as it usually does, and 食欲不振 is when you don't feel like eating as much as you normally would. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
3811 | 装い | よそおい | Attire | Dress\n Garb | This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it attire. \n "Yo, so, oh, you gonna wear that attire today or what?"
3812 | 服装 | ふくそう | Attire | Dress | Your clothes which attire you is your attire. It's how you dress. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3813 | 著者 | ちょしゃ | Author |  | Someone who is an author is an author. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3814 | 裏口 | うらぐち | Back Door | Rear Entrance | The backside mouth (think: entrance) is the back door or rear entrance. \n The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.
3815 | 裏 | うら | Backside | Reverse\n Other Side | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.
3816 | 裏切り | うらぎり | Betrayal | Treachery | From the backside you cut someone. Wow. What a jerk. What betrayal and treachery. \n This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.
3817 | 体操 | たいそう | Calisthenics | Gymnastics | Take your body and manipulate it around for exercise. This is Calisthenics or gymnastics. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3818 | 操 | みさお | Chastity |  | This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, chastity. \n Who is doing the chastity thing? That missa, oh (みさお), yes she is.
3819 | 熟語 | じゅくご | Compound Word | Compound Kanji\n Jukugo | Ripened languages are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a compound word or compound kanji. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3820 | 股間 | こかん | Crotch | Groin | The groin interval is simply the groin or crotch. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3821 | 皇太子 | こうたいし | Crown Prince |  | The emperor's fat child is the crown prince, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3822 | 否定 | ひてい | Denial | Deny\n Negation | No! I will not determine that. In fact, I deny it. This is my denial. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3823 | 異性 | いせい | Different Gender | Opposite Sex | Someone who differs in gender from you is of a different gender. This is often used to mean the opposite sex in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3824 | 異義 | いぎ | Different Meaning |  | My idea of righteousness is different from yours. Really, it's just a different meaning. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3825 | 変装 | へんそう | Disguise |  | Change your attire to look like someone else. This is a disguise. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
3826 | 編集者 | へんしゅうしゃ | Editor |  | An edit is 編集. Someone who does those edits is an editor! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.
3827 | 天皇 | てんのう | Emperor Of Japan | Emperor | The Japanese emperor is supposed to have come from the heavens, so that just makes this heaven emperor the emperor of Japan. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. NOOOOOOOOOOOOO~ (のう).
3828 | 拡張 | かくちょう | Enlargement | Expansion\n Extension | Go ahead and extend it and stretch it. That's how we'll do this enlargement, expansion and extension. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.
3829 | 装置 | そうち | Equipment | Device\n Apparatus | This attire is put inside this equipment, where it's changed into something else. This attire device is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
