This includes not only painting or drawing but also digitally creating images on a computer screen. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4387 | 懸命 | けんめい | Eager | Eagerness | Go ahead and suspend fate, let's get this done before the time we are fated to do it. We are that eager to get started. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4388 | 高齢者 | こうれいしゃ | Elderly Person | Old Person | Someone of tall age is going to be an elderly person or an old person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4389 | 逃亡 | とうぼう | Escape | Flight | If you escape death you have, well, an escape. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4390 | 避難 | ひなん | Evacuation |  | Dodge a difficult situation by getting away from it. Do an evacuation to get out of there! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4391 | 夕刊 | ゆうかん | Evening Edition |  | The evening edition is the evening edition. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4392 | 奥 | おく | Far Back | In The Back | Something that is in the interior of something else is inside of it, deep, and far back / in the back. Just imagine something interior to something else, it's probably in the back. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4393 | 致命的 | ちめいてき | Fatal |  | Somebody doing you fate -al would... probably be pretty fatal! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4394 | 一人称 | いちにんしょう | First Person |  | The one person title is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the first person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4395 | 対外 | たいがい | Foreign | External\n Overseas | Something is versus the outside. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's foreign or external.\nThis is a formal word typically used at the beginning of compounds to indicate that the subject is related to foreign affairs, such as 対外政策 (foreign policy) or 対外貿易 (foreign trade). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
4396 | 全般的 | ぜんぱんてき | General | Overall\n Across The Board | All general-al! It's super general. It's general and overall and across the board. Nothing specific going on here. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4397 | 遺伝子 | いでんし | Genes |  | If 遺伝 is heredity and you pass your heredity to your child, how is it being passed? Via genes, of course. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4398 | 還元 | かんげん | Give Something Back | Reduction | Send back to the origin means you are going to give something back. This word is commonly used to mean "giving benefits back to the consumers.” For example, if a company makes more money than usual, they can thank consumers with a 利益還元 sale, lowering prices to "give back" some of the profits.\nIn the context of chemistry, 還元 also means reduction, like reducing an oxidized substance back to its original, unoxidized form. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4399 | 宜しい | よろしい | Good | Okay\n All Right\n Fine | You send your best regards to everyone. Is this good? Is it okay? Is it all right? Yes, of course, how nice of you. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

This is indoor heating, kind of like the same way how an air conditioner is a "cool cluster." \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4401 | 膝 | ひざ | Knee |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
4402 | 膝頭 | ひざがしら | Kneecap | Patella | Your knee's head is the kneecap. It's also called the patella, if you want to get fancy and talk about bone names. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're walking around in your mom's house, minding your own business, when you slam your kneecap right into that gargoyle she loves (がしら). It hurts so bad, you can't even think out that phrase and instead you shout out, "GA SHE RA" and fall to the floor, clutching your searing kneecap (which has probably broken in half).
4403 | 由緒 | ゆいしょ | Lineage | History | The reason that ties people together is their lineage or their history. Lineage and history ties people (especially families) together.\nThis word can be used for people with a prestigious family history as well as for historic buildings, especially temples and shrines. \n You didn't learn this reading for 由 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you had good lineage you'd never make a U-ey (ゆい) on the highway. That's dangerous, and people with good lineage and a long history would simply never do such a thing.
4404 | 緩やか | ゆるやか | Loose | Mild\n Gentle | This is the na-adjective version of loose, so that means this word means loose or mild or gentle. \n The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

You won't get any strikes with weak shins!\nNote that the ぼう reading is the rendaku'd reading for 抱.

4420 | 〜漬け | づけ | Pickled In | Marinated In | You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something," so if you add that to the end of a food word (and leave off the る) it means that food has been pickled in something, like  酢漬け  (pickled in vinegar). \n You've already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and you've pickled whatever comes before 〜漬け. Easy peasy.

4430 | 出所 | しゅっしょ | Release From Prison | Source\n Origin | You exit a facility. It's your release from prison!\n出所 commonly refers to leaving or being released from facilities ending in 所, particularly 刑務所 (prisons). It can also be a slightly formal word for source or origin, often used in discussions of copyright to specify the origin of cited information, images, or content. \n The reading follows on'yomi protocols, but you just have to be careful of the shortened しゅつ which becomes しゅっ.\nNote: There is also the reading でどころ for the meanings origin and source. This version is generally used in spoken language, often to emphasize the significance or curiosity about where something came from.

4437 | 同伴する | どうはんする | To Accompany |  | The same accompany means you are in the same place as someone, and you are accompanying them. This word means to accompany. 4438 | 伴う | ともなう | To Accompany |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accompany and the verb vocab version is to accompany. This can be used both literally and figuratively. \n You need to accompany your friend, so to call out to them you yell "友, NOW!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.
4439 | 避ける | さける | To Avoid | To Dodge | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means avoid or dodge and the verb vocab version is to avoid or to dodge! \n Each reading has a slightly different meaning. Here's some mnemonics to help you remember them:\nYou need to avoid people who drink sake (さけ) all the time. Why? Because when they get drunk you'll have to dodge the yo-yos (よ) they spin at you. Sake makes you want to toss the ol' yo-yo around. Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!
4440 | 傾く | かたむく | To Be Leaned | To Be Tilted | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean, and the verb vocab version means to be leaned or to be tilted. You aren't doing the leaning or the tilting, though, you're just watching, which is why you say "cool" (く) when you see it, because it's already done. \n You cut a moo (かたむ), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.
4441 | 妊娠する | にんしんする | To Be Pregnant | To Get Pregnant | To do pregnant pregnant is to be pregnant. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4442 | 噛む | かむ | To Bite | To Chew | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 4443 | 致す | いたす | To Do |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means do and the verb vocab version is to do. This is a polite way to say "to do." \n What are you going to do? You're going to become a professional eater (いた), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.
4444 | 描く | かく | To Draw | To Sketch | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means draw so the verb vocab version is to draw or to sketch. \n The reading is the same as 書く, which is similar to drawing something (you use a writing instrument on a piece of paper, which you can do with drawing). Another reading is えがく, which is like saying 絵を書く, but combined and rendaku'd.
4445 | 食う | くう | To Eat | To Consume | You know the kanji means eat, and you also already know 食べる. So what's the deal with this also meaning to eat?\n食う carries a more masculine and coarse tone than 食べる, so it can come off as rough or impolite in certain situations. It also has a wider set of usages, for example in saying that something is eating up time or resources, or saying that you were bitten by a bug. You'll come across more of these, but they're all pretty straightforward, so don't worry! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You do know that reading, but this uses a different one, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThere's nothing you love to eat more than cookies (く). You could eat them day and night, but watch out, as that might get a little… time-consuming.
4446 | 託す | たくす | To Entrust |  | If you consign something to someone, you are going to entrust them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you. \n The reading for this one is unusual, but I will entrust you with the knowledge of why to help you remember it! This uses the on'yomi reading and not the kun'yomi, as you might expect, because the す here is the old-fashioned version of the verb する.\nLuckily, you learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so it's unusual but hopefully not too hard!
4447 | 逃げる | にげる | To Escape | To Flee\n To Run Away | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means escape so the verb vocab version is to escape. Also, it can be to flee or to run away. Basically, if you're trying to get away from someone or something, you could be doing this. \n You are trying to escape from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your knee (に). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.
4448 | 超す | こす | To Exceed | To Go Over\n To Surpass | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ultra or super so the verb version is what happens when you do something ultra or super much. You start to exceed the amount you were meant to do it. If you ultra drive a car, you exceed the speed limit. If you ultra study, you exceed your brain capacity. Get it? \n Who likes to exceed everything? Your 子 (こ)! Or you, when you were a 子. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!
4449 | 及ぼす | およぼす | To Exert | To Cause | If you have reach, that means you're able to exert a great influence on people. Watch out, though, because it also means you're able to cause great harm. \n The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that, you'll be able to read this one too.
4450 | 一緒 | いっしょ | Together |  | You are one and together. If you're together as one, you are together. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 一 becomes いっ.

4453 | 緩む | ゆるむ | To Loosen |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means loose, so the verb version is to loosen. 4454 | 維持する | いじする | To Maintain |  | To "do maintenance (維持)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is to maintain. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.
4455 | 一致する | いっちする | To Match |  | You do one do and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing to match it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The いち is shortened to いっ.
4456 | 賄う | まかなう | To Pay | To Cover | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bribe, but when you pay a bribe, you are going to pay something or to cover something, like a meal, or something like that. \n You need to make a payment, make a payment now (まかなう) to cover the cost of this room.
4457 | 指摘する | してきする | To Point Out | To Identify | If 指摘 is "pointing out" then the verb version is to point out. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from 指摘.
4458 | 刊行する | かんこうする | To Publish |  | The edition will go out to the public if we were to publish it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4459 | 頼る | たよる | To Rely On | To Trust\n To Depend On | 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is to rely on or to trust or to depend on. You know it is this word because it is rude to rely on your friends, but you are anyways. \n The reading is a bit different from 頼む, however. It's たよ, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become tiyored (たよ). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.
4460 | 戻す | もどす | To Return | To Return Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to return something. You know you're doing the action of returning someone or something because when you do, they just sue (す) you because you broke the thing you were supposed to return before returning it. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
4461 | 炒る | いる | To Roast | To Toast | The kanji is fry. You already know the verb for "to fry" (炒める), so this verb is for a slightly different cooking technique — to roast.\nSo what's the difference between the two? Generally speaking, 炒める involves the use of hot fat or oil, while 炒る describes a way of cooking that involves less or no oil or fat, often to dry roast things. For example, you'd use 炒める for making fried noodles or fried rice, and 炒る for roasting sesame seeds or beans. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. The tricky part is where this doesn't use the same kun'yomi as 炒める, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:\nNow that you know the difference between frying and roasting, we're going to roast our first dish: Eagle (い)! I heard it's your favorite food, so I just had to prepare this for you. What do you mean, "eww"?!
4462 | 繰る | くる | To Spin | To Turn Over\n To Reel In\n To Shuffle | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spin so the verb vocab version is to spin. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.
4463 | 懸ける | かける | To Stake | To Risk | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suspend, but in this case, you're going to suspend your win or loss and try to stake it all on one, big bet. You're going to risk it all! \n You decide to risk it all and bet everything on your car (か). If you lose, you lose the car, but if you win, then you were right to stake it all on this.
4464 | 踏み込む | ふみこむ | To Step Into | To Step Hard On\n To Intrude\n To Delve Into | 踏む is "to step on" and the kanji 込 means into, so this means to step into.\n踏み込む means to step further and harder than usual, like stepping forward to lunge for a ball or stepping hard on the accelerator. Figuratively, it can also mean to intrude or to delve into, like stepping into someone's house without permission or exploring complex topics one step further. \n The readings come from the word 踏む and the kanji 込, put together.
4465 | 伸ばす | のばす | To Stretch Something |  | If 伸びる is "to be stretched" then 伸ばす is to stretch something, where you're doing the stretching. You know this because you took a bus and you stretched it out to be an even longer bus. \n The reading comes from 伸びる, so if you know that you should know this.
4466 | 乗り換える | のりかえる | To Transfer | To Change Trains | You have ride and exchange, so you take your ride (bus, train, whatever) and exchange to another bus, train, or whatever. That's why this word means to transfer, and most commonly to change trains. \n The reading comes from 乗る and 換える.
4467 | 貿易会社 | ぼうえきがいしゃ | Trading Firm |  | A trade (貿易) company (会社) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a trading firm. \n The reading for the 易 portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train stations (えき).
4468 | 盤 | ばん | Tray | Board\n Disc | The kanji and the word are the same! This word also means board and disc, which makes sense if you think about it. Boards you play games on are basically just trays for the pieces, and discs go inside boards (like records) for storage. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
4469 | 信託 | しんたく | Trust | Entrusting | If you believe you can consign your trust to someone, then you can trust them, or you are being entrusting. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4470 | 奥さん | おくさん | Wife |  | The interior person (the honorific さん shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your wife. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again. \n The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.
4471 | 仮称 | かしょう | Working Name | Tentative Name | A temporary title is what you give something when you don't have a final title for it. it's a working name or a tentative name. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4472 | 欠伸 | あくび | Yawn | Yawning | When you lack stretching, your body has to get that energy out somehow, so you end up yawning. \n The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou've never seen more yawning than when you performed acupuncture (あく) on a bee (び). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.
4473 | 年齢 | ねんれい | Years Old | Age | Your year age is the number of years old you are. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4474 | 活躍 | かつやく | Active Participation | Activity\n Success\n Do Great | A lively leap is what you do when you have active participation in an activity and often find success and do great.\nThis word is usually used to describe someone’s outstanding or remarkable activity in a certain sport, career, or other field or activity. Have a look at the common word combinations for some example usages. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4475 | 宛名 | あてな | Addressee | Name\n Address\n Name and Address | The address name is the name that's on the address, making it the addressee. This can also mean name and address.\nThis can be used for both physical mail and email. \n The reading for 宛 is the same one you learned for the kanji. The reading for 名 comes from the kun'yomi reading, which you learned in the vocabulary word 名 and 名前. So, the reading for this word is あてな.
4476 | 小遣い | こづかい | Allowance | Spending Money | If 遣う is something along the lines of "to consider" then a "small consider" is what I'll give you for your spending money. Can I have some money? $50? No, how about a smaller consideration on that, maybe something that's more along the lines of an allowance? \n The reading is the alternate reading of 小 and 遣う's reading. Watch out for the rendaku.
4477 | 南極圏 | なんきょくけん | Antarctic Circle | Antarctica | If 南極 is Antarctica, then the Antarctica Range is the area that makes up Antarctica. That's the Antarctic Circle. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4478 | 原子爆弾 | げんしばくだん | Atomic Bomb |  | 原子 is atom and 爆弾 is bomb. What is an atom bomb? An atomic bomb. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4479 | 控え | ひかえ | Backup | Reserve\n Spare\n Copy\n Stub | Something that can abstain until it's needed makes for good backup. Think about it — you don't want backup rushing in too early, right? It should abstain until the backup is actually needed.\nNote that 控え isn't used for spares and extras. It's more for necessary backups, like a backup player in sports, a document copy for record keeping, or a receipt stub. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Good for you!
4480 | 渋い | しぶい | Bitter Flavor | Bitter | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of bitter is bitter, or more specifically, a bitter flavor. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly bitter. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "She boooo" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.
4481 | 片言 | かたこと | Broken Language | A Few Words\n Broken Japanese\n Broken English | One sided saying things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in broken language, for example speaking a few words in broken Japanese or broken English. \n The reading is the reading you learned for 片 and the こと of 言葉.
4482 | 掲示板 | けいじばん | Bulletin Board |  | A 掲示 is a notice or sign. Put this on a board, and it becomes a bulletin board. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4483 | 免状 | めんじょう | Certificate | License\n Diploma | Your excuse for the current condition is surprising, especially considering your diploma and license on the issue. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4484 | 言葉遣い | ことばづかい | Choice Of Words |  | If you try to consider (遣う) your words (言葉) you are making a choice of words. \n The reading is 言葉 and 遣う combined together.
4485 | 連邦 | れんぽう | Commonwealth | Federation | Take along your home country to all the other spaces you want to add to your group. Put them together to form the commonwealth or federation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4486 | 死刑囚 | しけいしゅう | Condemned Criminal | Death Row Convict | Remember how you learned that 死刑 means "death penalty?" Well a criminal who has been sentenced to it is a condemned criminal or a death row convict. They're condemned to death. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4487 | 御飯 | ごはん | Cooked Rice | Meal | The honorable meal is cooked rice. It's the meal of Japan. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4488 | 群集 | ぐんしゅう | Crowd | Multitude | A flock that has gathered is a crowd and multitude. Because, well, lots of things gathering. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4489 | 水仙 | すいせん | Daffodil |  | A water hermit, for some reason, is a daffodil. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking daffodils, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4490 | 銃殺 | じゅうさつ | Death By Shooting |  | A gun kill is a death by shooting. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4491 | 紅 | くれない | Deep Red | Crimson\n Rouge | The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this also means deep red, or crimson. Additionally, it can also mean rouge, usually in reference to the cosmetic.\n紅 is also a bit of an old-fashioned and somewhat literary word, so keep that in mind! \n This is where things get a little complicated. You already learned べに as a reading with 口紅. 紅 can also be read べに just by itself, and in that case, it means rouge. However, there’s a different reading that’s used for deep red, which we’d like to focus on here, so here’s a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nThere's so much deep red blood everywhere, there's no way of helping this person bleeding out. One might say, cure ない (くれない).  Just remember: when there's deep red everywhere, cure ない.
4492 | 慎重 | しんちょう | Discreet | Careful | Humility is heavy, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be discreet instead. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember the alternative reading for 重. If you aren't discreet or careful, the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)will find you and kill you!
4493 | 呼び鈴 | よびりん | Doorbell |  | A buzzer that will call you to the door is a doorbell. \n The reading is 呼ぶ and 鈴's reading, put together.
4494 | 併殺 | へいさつ | Double Play |  | A join kill is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a double play. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4495 | 甲斐 | かい | Effect | Result\n Worth | A turtle shell that is patterned has much more effect and result and worth than a non-patterned turtle shell. \n You haven't learned this reading for 甲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you want to know how much you're worth, just take a look at your car (か). Cars are the result of money and hard work. So basically, they say how much you're worth!
4496 | 雇用 | こよう | Employment |  | The employ task is employment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4497 | 英語圏 | えいごけん | English Speaking World |  | The English range is the areas where people speak English, aka the English Speaking World. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4498 | 免除 | めんじょ | Exemption | Exempt | To excuse and to exclude, that's exemption.\n免除 means granting relief or exemption from a duty or obligation that would otherwise be required, like paying tuition fees, repaying debts, obtaining specific licenses for certain activities, and so on. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4499 | 眉毛 | まゆげ | Eyebrow |  | An eyebrow's hair is the individual eyebrow hair that makes them up. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!
4500 | 邦人 | ほうじん | Fellow Countryman | Japanese National\n Compatriot | A home country person is a fellow countryman or compatriot (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a Japanese national. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4501 | 群れ | むれ | Flock |  | This is the noun version of the kanji, making it flock. \n A flock? A flock of cows (む)! Imagine a flock of cows, probably flying like birds, because flocks usually have something to do with birds.
4502 | 足跡 | あしあと | Footprint |  | Foot traces are footprints. \n The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the kanji, put together.
4503 | 片〜 | かた | Fragment | One Of A Pair\n Incomplete | Something that is one-sided has only one side and not the whole. That's just one of a pair or a fragment of the whole. Stick this onto another word and you have one of a pair or an "incomplete_____." \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4504 | 香り | かおり | Fragrance | Aroma | This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, fragrance. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The fragrance you smell is somebody's 顔 (かお). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!
4505 | 枠組み | わくぐみ | Frame | Framework | The frame group is a frame or a framework. \n The reading is the reading of 枠 and the reading of the vocab word 組み. Watch out for the rendaku.
4506 | 枠 | わく | Frame | Limit | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
4507 | 充実 | じゅうじつ | Fullness | Beefing Up | Allocate the truth more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached fullness. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4508 | 岐阜 | ぎふ | Gifu |  | The branch off mound is the area of Japan known as Gifu. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4509 | 棋院 | きいん | Go Hall | Go Club\n Go Institution | A chess piece institution is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a Go hall or a Go club (it's a very interesting game you should look it up!). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4510 | 銃 | じゅう | Gun | Firearm | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
4511 | 群馬県 | ぐんまけん | Gunma Prefecture |  | The flock of horses prefecture is the part of Japan known as Gunma Prefecture. \n The readings for 群 and 県 are okay, but you haven't learned this reading for 馬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nGunma Prefecture is where your mama (ま) lives! Imagine going back to your mama's house, and finding it's now in Gunma Prefecture. It's a bit of a surprise, but very handy for practicing your Japanese. Thanks mama!
4512 | 跡継ぎ | あとつぎ | Heir | Heiress\n Successor | The traces are the people that inherit what you have. They are your heirs or heiresses. Your successor. \n The reading is the vocab words 跡 and 継ぐ put together.
4513 | 仙人 | せんにん | Hermit | Mountain Man | A hermit person is a hermit or mountain man. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4514 | 本塁打 | ほんるいだ | Home Run | Homer | A hit you get in baseball that takes you to the origin plate is a home run. HOOOMMEERUNNNN! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4515 | 謙譲語 | けんじょうご | Humble Japanese | Humble Language | Language when you defer to modesty is humble Japanese. Of course, this doesn't have to refer to Japanese, though it usually does, meaning this could mean humble language as well. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. 4516 | 要項 | ようこう | Important Points | Main Points | A needed paragraph contains the important points of what you want to say. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4517 | 項目 | こうもく | Item | Entry\n Clause\n Data Item | You need to go through a paragraph in chunks that you can easily see with your eye so you break it up by item. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you out with 目. If you can't see this item in the paragraph with your eye, someone will mock (もく) you for sure.
4518 | 跳躍 | ちょうやく | Jump | Leap\n Bound\n Skip | If you hop and leap into the air, you probably are doing a jump and leap into the air. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4519 | 縄跳び | なわとび | Jump Rope | Skipping Rope | A rope that you hop over is a jump rope. \n The reading is the vocab words 縄 and 跳ぶ, put together.
4520 | 片仮名 | かたかな | Katakana |  | One-sided kana is katakana. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one. \n 片 is かた, and 仮名 is かな. Put them together to get katakana.
4521 | 免許 | めんきょ | License | Certificate\n Permit | You have an excuse that permits you to do what you want. It is a license and certificate allowing you to do this. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4522 | 事項 | じこう | Matter | Item\n Subject | You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." So a matter paragraph shows the matters, items, or subjects that make up a larger issue or discussion at hand.\n事項 is a formal word usually seen at the end of another phrase that specifies what matters or items are being referred to, like 注意事項 (matters to be noted) or 協議事項 (items for discussion). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4523 | 謙虚 | けんきょ | Modesty | Humility | The modesty void is that big pit you go into when you are showing modesty or humility. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4524 | 募集中 | ぼしゅうちゅう | Now Hiring | Now Recruiting | Recruit and gather everyone to the middle. They're all here gathering for this recruitment because we're now hiring / now recruiting. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4525 | 由緒正しい | ゆいしょただしい | Of Honorable Lineage | Venerable | Someone or something whose 由緒 (lineage) is 正しい (correct) is of honorable lineage, and venerable indeed. \n You already know the readings for 由緒 and 正しい so you just need to put them together to read this word.
4526 | 片手 | かたて | One Handed |  | A one sided hand is one of your hands, that means you're doing something one handed. \n These readings are the ones you learned with both of these kanji.

4528 | 圏外 | けんがい | Out Of Range |  | The range is outside of the range, meaning you're out of range. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4529 | 短銃 | たんじゅう | Pistol | Revolver | A short gun is a pistol, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4530 | 祈念 | きねん | Prayer | A Prayer | You pray with your thoughts, making this a prayer.\nThis is similar to 祈願, but can also be used in formal settings to express wishing for somebody's success or good health, among other things. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
4531 | 囚人 | しゅうじん | Prisoner | Inmate | A criminal person will end up as a prisoner or an inmate if they get caught! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4532 | 隆盛 | りゅうせい | Prosperity |  | Prosperity in piles is a lot of prosperity! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4533 | 隆起 | りゅうき | Protuberance | Bulge | When prosperity wakes up it will push through whatever it's in and create a protuberance or bulge. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic for the reading of 起. To get out of this bulge, you use a key (き). The key lets you get out.
4534 | 梅雨 | つゆ | Rainy Season |  | In the ume season, it rains a lot in Japan (and some other East Asian countries). That's why ume rain means rainy season. It usually happens from the end of May to mid-July, when ume get ready to be harvested.\nKeep in mind this is a seasonal word unique to Japan and East Asia, so you usually don't use it to refer to rainy seasons that happen in other regions of the world. \n This word uses an exceptional reading, so don't try to read this with the kanji readings you already learned. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nRainy season is a special season to you (つゆ). All of your favorite things in the year happen during rainy season, like… staying inside all day because all it does is rain! But to you, there's nothing better than rainy season.
4535 | 充電 | じゅうでん | Recharge |  | Allocate electricity back to the battery with a recharge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4536 | 勧告 | かんこく | Recommendation | Official Advice | If you take what you recommend and announce it to the world, you are making a recommendation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4537 | 拒否 | きょひ | Refusal | Rejection | I refuse. I am saying "no." That is my refusal. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4538 | 補充 | ほじゅう | Resupply | Refill | To take a supplement and allocate it to where it needs to be is to resupply or refill  something. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4539 | 稲作 | いなさく | Rice Cultivation | Rice Crop | If you make a rice plant then you are doing rice cultivation, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all! \n The reading is the いな reading with the regular 作 on'yomi reading.
4540 | 稲田 | いなだ | Rice Field | Rice Paddy\n Paddy Field | A rice plant rice paddy is a rice field or rice paddy. \n The reading is the いな reading for 稲 and the regular 田 reading rendaku'd.
4541 | 稲 | いね | Rice Plant |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the いね reading of this kanji. You can think of it like you're saying "いいね!" at the rice plant you're looking at (just shorten the い).

4547 | 鈴 | すず | Small Bell | Bell | The meaning for this word comes from the kanji. It's a small bell! \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. 4548 | 御免 | ごめん | Sorry | I Beg Your Pardon | An honorable excuse is all I have, and that is no good. I'm sorry and I beg your pardon. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4549 | 鋼 | はがね | Steel |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou take a look at the steel. It's shaped like a person. Turns out you turned that hag into a steel statue. You say, "huh, that's the hag ね?" (はがね). Whoops, sorry hag lady.
4550 | 製鋼 | せいこう | Steel Manufacture |  | If you manufacture steel that is steel manufacture. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4551 | 鋼材 | こうざい | Steel Material |  | Steel material is steel material. Boom! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4552 | 依然 | いぜん | Still | As Yet\n As It Was | If you have a dependent nature, then even if you go off on your own, you're still going to ask for help. Dependent people still need help because that's just how they are.\nNote that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4553 | 免税 | めんぜい | Tax Exemption |  | An excuse from taxes? That's a tax exemption. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4554 | 狙う | ねらう | To Aim At | To Aim | Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have to aim at. \n The reading comes from 狙い, so if you know that you'll be able to aim at knowing this word's reading as well.
4555 | 応募する | おうぼする | To Apply For | To Enlist\n To Answer An Ad | If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is to apply for or to enlist. \n The reading is the same as 応募's reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.
4556 | 惑う | まどう | To Be At A Loss | To Be Bewildered | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means misguided, but the verb version is usually used to describe how you feel after being misguided — to be at a loss!\n惑う usually refers to being in a quandary or a state of confusion. Using 惑う is kind of old-fashioned, but other forms like 惑わせる and 逃げ惑う (to flee frantically) are still fairly common in modern Japanese. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going to be at a loss you're going to be mad (まど) about it, most likely. Nobody likes to feel at a loss, so imagine how mad you feel when you are.
4557 | 慎む | つつしむ | To Be Discreet | To Be Careful | If you have humility you will try to be discreet. \n Why are you going to be discreet? Because that tutu she (つつし) wears is really embarrassing.
4558 | 譲る | ゆずる | To Concede | To Hand Over\n To Turn Over | If you are going to defer to someone, you are going to concede something. I concede / defer this to you. \n What are you conceding? Some delicious yuzu (ゆず). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.
4559 | 崩れる | くずれる | To Crumble | To Collapse | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means crumble and the verb vocab version means to crumble, like, something is crumbling or collapsing. \n The reading comes from 崩す, so if you know that you know this reading as well!
4560 | 削除する | さくじょする | To Delete | To Eliminate | If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be to delete. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4561 | 雇う | やとう | To Employ | To Hire | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means employ so the verb vocab version is to employ. \n You are going to employ more people to your business so you can make more money and eventually buy a yacht (やと). That's the dream life, it is.
4562 | 免れる | まぬかれる | To Escape Something | To Avoid Something | You are going to excuse yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have to escape from the person / thing trying to hold you there in order to avoid them. \n In order to do that, you jump inside your man(u) car (まぬか) which is a car for a tough man(u) that needs to drive fast, just like you.
4563 | 解雇する | かいこする | To Fire Someone | To Fire | You are going to untie the person who is in your employ from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means to fire someone. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4564 | 跳ねる | はねる | To Jump | To Leap\n To Hop | Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however. \n The reading for this one is は because you're laughing (HAHAHA!!) at the person who put Nair (ねる) on their legs, then only finding it to be really painful, so they have to jump around to get the pain to go away.
4565 | 躍る | おどる | To Leap | To Jump\n To Bounce | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leap so the verb vocab version means to leap. It also means to jump or to bounce. \n You go to leap and leap again. You do it so much that you start sweating, which is causing a foul odor (おど) to come from your body.
4566 | 御覧になる | ごらんになる | To Look | To Please Look | It honorable(y) becomes (なる) that you look at something. This is a respectful way to say to look or to please look at something. The reading を御覧になって下さい！ \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4567 | 弾く | ひく | To Play A Stringed Instrument | To Play | You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means to play a stringed instrument. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune. \n The reading is the same as 引く, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...
4568 | 掲載する | けいさいする | To Publish | To Print | 掲載 is publication so the verb version of that is to publish or to print. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know 掲載 as well.
4569 | 拒む | こばむ | To Refuse | To Reject | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means refuse and the verb vocab version is to refuse. \n What are you refusing? You are refusing a child, because children are all bad. You say "子 bad, 子 bad" over and over again.
4570 | 払い戻す | はらいもどす | To Repay | To Refund\n To Reimburse | 払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going to repay, to refund, or to reimburse someone for their payment. \n The readings come from 払い and 戻す.
4571 | 奪う | うばう | To Rob | To Steal By Force | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rob so the verb vocab version is to rob. \n This reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4572 | 取り戻す | とりもどす | To Take Back |  | To take and return something to yourself is to take back something. Give it back! \n The readings come from 取る and 戻す. Combine them to get this.
4573 | 渋滞 | じゅうたい | Traffic Jam | Traffic Congestion | A bitter stagnate is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is traffic jam and traffic congestion. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4574 | 移譲 | いじょう | Transfer | Assignment | Shift something and defer it somewhere else. This is a transfer or assignment.\nThis is a formal term used to describe the legal transfer of rights, properties, or liabilities, so it's most commonly seen in official or legal documents. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4575 | 邦訳 | ほうやく | Translation Into Japanese | Japanese Version | A home country translation is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a translation into Japanese. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4576 | 甲 | こう | Turtle Shell | Instep\n Back Of The Hand | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n甲 has traditionally meant turtle shell, but these days it appears much more often in expressions like 足の甲 (instep) and 手の甲 (back of the hand). If you think about it, those body parts kind of resemble turtle shells, don’t you think? \n This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!
4577 | 虚栄心 | きょえいしん | Vanity |  | When how much you prosper goes into your heart and just enters a void, it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme vanity because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
4578 | 壁 | かべ | Wall |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji!
4579 | 壁紙 | かべがみ | Wallpaper |  | A wall's paper is wallpaper. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings. It's what you learned with 壁 and the vocab reading of 紙, rendaku'd.
4580 | 戻り道 | もどりみち | Way Back | The Way Back | If 戻る is "to return" then you return on the street you came from, you are taking the way back. \n The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think 戻る for the 戻り portion.

4606 | 排出 | はいしゅつ | Emission |  | Things that are emitted and then exit are, well, emissions. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4607 | 虚しい | むなしい | Empty | Vacant\n Futile\n Vain | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of void? It's empty or vacant. Just think of what has to happen to make a void in the first place. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf everything in life seems empty and futile, even cows will be affected. Listen to them say, "Moo, nah (むな), never mind. What's the point?" Nothing makes life seem empty like a cow saying "Moo, nah."
4608 | 妖しい | あやしい | Enchanting | Charming\n Mysterious | You can guess this is an adjective by looking at the い it ends with. One of the meanings of the kanji, enchanting, is already an adjective. That's the meaning of this word, too: enchanting. What is enchanting? It's basically charming in a mysterious way. \n So this enchanting and charming feeling is mysterious... some would say 怪しい (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as 怪しい. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference:\n怪しい usually has a negative feel to it whereas 妖しい generally has a positive feel. 妖しい also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.
4609 | 排除 | はいじょ | Exclusion | Removal\n Elimination | If you expel and exclude something or someone, you’re doing exclusion. Alternatively, you could also call this removal or elimination. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4610 | 排他 | はいた | Exclusion |  | When you expel others, you're doing exclusion. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

4613 | 殿様 | とのさま | Feudal Lord |  | Milord (you say very formally with a formal name ender). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a feudal lord. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nFeudal Lords were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My toe?! NO!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

4617 | 頻りに | しきりに | Frequently | Repeatedly\n Often | Something that goes towards being frequent is something that is frequently happening. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. People want to do this thing frequently, because it is so chic (しき).
4618 | 頻発 | ひんぱつ | Frequent Occurrence | Occur Frequently | Something that frequently departures has much frequency and is a frequent occurrence. Oh, that? Yeah, it departures with much frequency. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4619 | 逃亡者 | とうぼうしゃ | Fugitive | Runaway | Someone who has escaped death by running away is a fugitive or a runaway. I think there was a movie about that once! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4620 | 俊才 | しゅんさい | Genius | Person Of Exceptional Talent\n Exceptionally Talented Person | A person with genius and talent is a genius, or a person of exceptional talent. So smart!\n俊才 is an advanced word usually only seen in writing. It tends to refer more to the kind of genius or talent that can be developed through effort. In that sense it differs from 天才, which is for the kind of genius that comes from heaven — either you have it or you don't. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

It's also glad! \n Whenever you're really glad to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "Ooh, rays (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is happy you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.
