4625 | 内堀 | うちぼり | Inner Moat |  | The inside ditch is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the inner moat. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least! \n The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. 内 + 堀 added into one word.
4626 | 雅楽 | ががく | Japanese Court Music | Gagaku | It's so elegant and so comforting. This is Japanese court music, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it gagaku if you'd like. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4627 | 香川県 | かがわけん | Kagawa Prefecture |  | The fragrance river prefecture is Kagawa Prefecture. Might help to look at the reading first. \n This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nIf you want to get to Kagawa Prefecture you're going to need a car (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!
4628 | 膝小僧 | ひざこぞう | Kneecap |  | In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap.\nThis is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings for 膝 and 小, but the on'yomi reading for 僧, which gets rendaku'd from そう to ぞう, so watch out for that! You've learned all these reading before, so you should be able to read this as well.
4629 | 飛躍 | ひやく | Leaping | Rapid Progress | To fly and leap is leaping.\n飛躍 is mainly used in a figurative way to highlight remarkable progress in areas like personal growth or technological advancement. It can also describe a logic that jumps suddenly from one point to another without clear connections. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4630 | 繁茂 | はんも | Luxuriant Growth |  | Something that is overgrown and luxuriant must have quite the luxuriant growth. Lots and lots of growth. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4631 | 褒賞 | ほうしょう | Medal | Prize\n Reward | I praise you for what you did, so here's your prize to go along with my praise, a medal! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4632 | 薬剤 | やくざい | Medicine | Drugs | A medicine dose is medicine or drugs you're taking. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4633 | 〜剤 | ざい | Medicine | Dose | If you take a dose of something, you are taking a dose of medicine. Take your cough syrup, child! \n The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.
4634 | 回顧録 | かいころく | Memoirs | Reminiscences | You revolve to review the record of the past. These records are memoirs or reminiscences. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4635 | 麺つゆ | めんつゆ | Mentsuyu | Noodle Soup Base\n Noodle Broth | You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious mentsuyu , or noodle soup base. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum! \n You learned the reading for 麺 when you learned the kanji.
4636 | 妖怪 | ようかい | Monster | Yokai | What's supernatural and suspicious? A monster, or, if you know the Japanese term, a yokai. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4637 | 〜殿 | どの | Mr. | Ms.\n Lord | The kanji means Milord, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title Lord, but nowadays it's closer to Mr. or Ms.. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nDo you know a Lord? Imagine it being someone named Mr. or Ms. Don (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.
4638 | 隣人 | りんじん | Neighbor |  | A neighbor person is a neighbor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4639 | 隣 | となり | Neighbor | Next To\n Next Door Neighbor | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Remember the movie "Tonari (となり) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.
4640 | 近隣 | きんりん | Neighborhood |  | All the near neighbors are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the neighborhood. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4641 | 隣国 | りんごく | Neighboring Country |  | A neighbor country is a neighboring country. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell... \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
4642 | 隣家 | りんか | Neighboring House |  | A neighbor house is a neighboring house. That house is right next to ours! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4643 | 麺 | めん | Noodles |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some noodles to celebrate!
4644 | 沖縄県 | おきなわけん | Okinawa Prefecture |  | Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, Okinawa Prefecture. \n The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.
4645 | 外堀 | そとぼり | Outer Moat |  | The outside ditch is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the outer moat. \n This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that 堀 gets rendakued - don't forget!
4646 | 過敏 | かびん | Oversensitivity | Nervousness | You've surpassed what is normal alertness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is oversensitivity. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4647 | 殿堂 | でんどう | Palace | Sanctuary\n Hall Of Fame | Milord's hall is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A palace. By extension, this can also mean a sanctuary, and even a hall of fame. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4648 | 駐車場 | ちゅうしゃじょう | Parking Lot |  | A location where cars can be a resident is a parking lot. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
4649 | 巡回 | じゅんかい | Patrol | Going Around | You patrol and revolve around the block to make your patrol. You're going around patrolling. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4650 | 薬剤師 | やくざいし | Pharmacist |  | A medicine dose expert is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a pharmacist. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4651 | 巡礼 | じゅんれい | Pilgrimage |  | A patrol of thanks is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a pilgrimage. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4652 | 柱 | はしら | Pillar |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n You'll have to imagine a pillar standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a hash-ra (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.
4653 | 巡査 | じゅんさ | Police Officer | Patrol Officer | Those who patrol and inspect are police officers or patrol officers.\n巡査 specifically refers to the lowest-ranking officers in the police force in Japan, whose duty is patrolling or doing things around 交番 (police boxes), or responding to emergency calls. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4654 | 携帯 | けいたい | Portable | Cell Phone\n Mobile Phone | A portable belt is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is portable. Note, this is also a very common term for a cell phone or mobile phone. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4655 | 防腐剤 | ぼうふざい | Preservative | Antiseptic | A prevent rot dose is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an antiseptic or preservative. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4656 | 繁栄 | はんえい | Prospering | Prosperity | If you're overgrown with prosperity you are probably really prospering. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4657 | 機敏 | きびん | Quick | Quick-Witted\n Prompt | A machine alert is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. It's pretty quick. It's also quick-witted. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all.\n機敏 is often used to describe the way someone responds promptly to various situations, and implies being highly responsive and adaptive. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4658 | 生殖 | せいしょく | Reproduction |  | Life, when it multiplies (multiply), is doing reproduction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4659 | 屋敷 | やしき | Residence | Estate | Your roofs are spread out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your residence or estate. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4660 | 駐在 | ちゅうざい | Residence | Stay | You're a resident and you exist in the place you're residing in. That means you have residence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4661 | 褒美 | ほうび | Reward | Prize | I praise you for your beauty. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a reward... a prize, basically. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4662 | 麺棒 | めんぼう | Rolling Pin |  | Grab your noodle pole and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a rolling pin!\nYou use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.
4663 | 犠打 | ぎだ | Sacrifice Fly | Sacrifice Bunt | A sacrifice hit is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a sacrifice bunt or sacrifice fly. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!
4664 | 〜房 | ふさ | Section | Bunch | Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum! \n You learned this reading already when you learned 房!
4665 | 敷金 | しききん | Security Deposit |  | Spread the gold around. First part, I want you to put in a security deposit. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4666 | 敏感 | びんかん | Sensitivity | Sensitive To\n Sensibility | If you have an alert feeling, you are sensitive to things going on around you. That means you have a lot of sensitivity! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4667 | 鋭い | するどい | Sharp |  | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sharp? It's sharp. \n Something that is sharp will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They sue rude (するど) behaviors...
4668 | 鋭利 | えいり | Sharpness |  | Something that is sharp will benefit from its sharpness, since that's all it has, really. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4669 | 鋭敏 | えいびん | Sharpness | Quick Witted\n Keenness | Someone on sharp alert has a sharpness about them. They are quick witted and have a strong keenness to them.\nThis word is formal and literary. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4670 | 衝撃 | しょうげき | Shock | Crash\n Impact | If you collide and attack what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large shock but also crash and impact into them. Blamo! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4671 | 兼業 | けんぎょう | Side Business | Second Job\n Moonlighting | Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4672 | 歌唱 | かしょう | Singing | Song | You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4673 | 唱歌 | しょうか | Singing | Songs | You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4674 | 独唱 | どくしょう | Solo |  | An alone chant is one you do alone. It's a solo! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4675 | 獲物 | えもの | Spoils | Trophy\n Game | A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy! \n Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for 獲 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (え)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!
4676 | 嬉々 | きき | State Of Enjoyment | Joyful State | You're so glad, you get glad again. No matter what you're doing, it's undoubtedly in a state of enjoyment.\n嬉々 itself refers to a joyful state where someone happily does something. It's generally used as the adverb 嬉々として, which means “happily” or “gladly.” While less common, it can also serve as an adjective when combined with たる. \n This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.
4677 | 駐日 | ちゅうにち | Stationed In Japan |  | Something or someone resident in 日本 (Japan) is stationed in Japan.\n駐日 is generally used to describe both individuals and institutions stationed in Japan for official duties, such as the 駐日大使 (Ambassador to Japan) or 駐日大使館 (embassy stationed in Japan). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4678 | 駐留軍 | ちゅうりゅうぐん | Stationed Troops | Occupying Troops | A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4679 | 座敷 | ざしき | Tatami Room | Tatami Mat Room | A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4680 | 電柱 | でんちゅう | Telephone Pole |  | An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4681 | 薄い | うすい | Thin | Weak\n Dilute | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute. And something that's been diluted is now thin. \n This drink is way too diluted. You sue (うす) the makers for their thin drink.
4682 | 薄まる | うすまる | To Be Diluted | To Be Diminished\n To Become Weak | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means dilute, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means to be diluted, to be diminished, or to become weak. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nThe reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou don't want your drink to be diluted, so you sue (うす) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.
4683 | 茂る | しげる | To Be Luxuriant | To Grow Thickly | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxuriant or to grow thickly. \n She gave (しげ) me a razor because my beard was starting to grow thickly... too thickly. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.
4684 | 透ける | すける | To Be Transparent | To Be See-Through | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something). \n To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.
4685 | 吹く | ふく | To Blow |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4686 | 唱える | となえる | To Chant |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant. \n Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest  comes naturally.
4687 | 兼ねる | かねる | To Combine | To Double As | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from. \n For example, a car (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.
4688 | 遠慮する | えんりょする | To Decline | To Restrain\n To Refrain | If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.
4689 | 携わる | たずさわる | To Engage In | To Participate\n To Take Part In | Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place). \n A Taz saw (たずさ) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you to participate in all kinds of things, like  cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.
4690 | 避難する | ひなんする | To Evacuate |  | If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.
4691 | 駆ける | かける | To Gallop | To Drive | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop. \n You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
4692 | 巡る | めぐる | To Go Around | To Return | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around. \n You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.
4693 | 世に出る | よにでる | To Go Out Into The World | To Be Published\n To Be Released To The Public\n To Become Renowned | Here we have world with the particle に, following by the verb 出る (to go out). Put that together and this means to go out into the world, to be published or to be released to the public in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it to become renowned. \n This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!
4694 | 懸かる | かかる | To Hang | To Depend On\n To Be At Stake | If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on! \n We're depending on you to help us to get this car (か), okay?
4695 | 傾ける | かたむける | To Lean Something | To Tilt Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean something. \n You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!
4696 | 顧みる | かえりみる | To Look Back On Something | To Reflect On Something\n To Be Attentive To Someone | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on something or to reflect on something. This can also mean to be attentive to someone, for example your family.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family. \n For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.
4697 | 緩める | ゆるめる | To Loosen | To Relax | 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax. \n The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!
4698 | 取り扱う | とりあつかう | To Manage | To Handle | To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it. \n The readings come from 取る and 扱う.
4699 | 逃す | のがす | To Miss | To Lose\n To Let Go | You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means to miss or to lose a good chance, or to let go of a good opportunity. \n Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word:\nYou missed a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was no gas (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.
4700 | 殖える | ふえる | To Multiply | To Increase | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase. \n What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!
4701 | 称える | たたえる | To Praise | To Give Praise | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you. \n After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta-ta (たた)! I'm outa here."
4702 | 褒める | ほめる | To Praise | To Compliment | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means praise and the verb vocab version is to praise. \n If you are going to praise this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing hoe-using (ほ) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.
4703 | 繰り返す | くりかえす | To Repeat | To Repeat Over And Over | 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this to repeat or to repeat over and over. \n The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.
4704 | 選択する | せんたくする | To Select | To Choose | 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going to select or to choose. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.
4705 | 敷く | しく | To Spread Out | To Lay Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spread and the verb vocab version is to spread out or to lay out.\nThis word generally refers to laying something flat, like a carpet or a picnic blanket. This use also extends to laying railroad tracks or asphalt for street paving. Metaphorically, it describes laying down something foundational, like establishing rules or specific organizational systems. \n What is getting spread out? Sheep (し)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.
4706 | 戒める | いましめる | To Warn | To Caution\n To Admonish | I say my commandment in order to warn and to caution the people not to do bad things. \n The first commandment I say to warn them of not doing bad things is I mash (いまし) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?
4707 | 透明 | とうめい | Transparent | Transparency | Something that is transparent and bright so that you can see through it is transparent. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4708 | 警戒 | けいかい | Vigilance | Precaution | My warning commandment is there to make sure you take precaution and show vigilance when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4709 | 訓戒 | くんかい | Warning | Admonition | My instruction is my commandment. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my warning. This is my admonition. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4710 | 薄弱 | はくじゃく | Weakness | Feebleness | Something is diluted to the point of weakness. It has much weakness and feebleness. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4711 | 一生懸命 | いっしょうけんめい | With All One's Might | All Out | You have only one life so do everything with lots of eagerness (懸命). Do everything with all one's might. Go all out. \n Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going all out to learn these readings!
4712 | 奥様 | おくさま | Your Wife | Wife\n Ma'am | Your interior formal name ender (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is your wife. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
4713 | 放棄 | ほうき | Abandonment | Abandoning\n Relinquishing | You release and abandon something. This is abandonment.\n放棄 is a relatively formal word for abandoning something. It can refer to giving up responsibilities, like neglecting duties or parental obligations, or relinquishing entitlements and rights. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4714 | 航空母艦 | こうくうぼかん | Aircraft Carrier |  | An aviation (航空) mother warship is a warship that is like mother to all the aviation things (the airplanes). They come home to their mother warship, which is an aircraft carrier. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4715 | 徹夜 | てつや | All Night | Sleepless Night\n All Nighter | Penetrate the night and go on through to the morning. You were up all night and had a sleepless night aka all nighter. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4716 | 凄い | すごい | Amazing | Wonderful\n Terrible\n Awful | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of amazing? It's also amazing! Or terrible. This word can be both good and bad, it really depends on the context, because what is amazing is usually also a little awful. You know? \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe most amazing and terrible thing you've ever seen is Suit Godzilla (すご). Godzilla was wearing a nice suit (amazing!) but also destroying your home, your friends, and your family (terrible!).
4717 | 鉱山 | こうざん | A Mine | Mine | A mineral mountain is one that you should build a mine in, to get all those minerals. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
4718 | 原爆 | げんばく | Atomic Bomb |  | 原 is often tied to atomic things, as atoms are the origin of all things. If an atom explodes, you have yourself an atomic bomb. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4719 | 手の甲 | てのこう | Back Of One's Hand |  | Your hand's turtle shell is the back of it (see you can make it shaped like a turtle shell if you try hard!). That's why this is the back of one's hand. \n The readings are the respective vocab readings of 手 and 甲.
4720 | 根拠 | こんきょ | Basis | Grounds | The root that this is based on is the basis and grounds for my argument. Look, it goes all the way down to the root problem! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4721 | 軍艦 | ぐんかん | Battleship |  | An army warship is a battleship. Did you sink it? Oh oh! You sunk my 軍艦! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4722 | 蜂 | はち | Bee | Hornet\n Wasp | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4723 | 偽装 | ぎそう | Camouflage | Disguise | Some fake attire doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is camouflage. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4724 | 炭素 | たんそ | Carbon |  | Things of the charcoal element are made up of much carbon. Just look deep into the charcoal to see all the carbon in there. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4725 | 儀式 | ぎしき | Ceremony | Ritual | A ceremony ceremony is a ceremony. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4726 | 炭 | すみ | Charcoal |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n I'm gonna put charcoal in your mouth. Whatchoo gonna do? Sue me (すみ)?
4727 | 拳骨 | げんこつ | Clenched Fist | Knuckles | A fist that's like a bone (hard) is a fist that's clenched and ready to punch, making this a clenched fist or knuckles, if you want to get even bonier about it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 拳 doesn't use the one you learned, it uses げん instead. Just imagine someone clenching their fist at you. You gulp and say げん instead of けん out of fear.
4728 | 石炭 | せきたん | Coal |  | A stone charcoal is charcoal shaped like a little stone. Or, maybe it's often found in stone. That's coal. \n This uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
4729 | 炭鉱 | たんこう | Coal Mine | Coal Pit | Charcoal mineral has been found! Time to dig a coal mine or coal pit to retrieve it! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4730 | 祝儀 | しゅうぎ | Congratulatory Gift | Congratulatory Money | To celebrate a ceremony, you offer a congratulatory gift.\n祝儀 generally refers to monetary gifts for celebrations, such as congratulatory money for weddings. It can also include money given away when you make a hole-in-one in golf or win big on a gamble.\nWhile 祝儀 can also refer to the celebration itself, this use is not as common. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 祝 is read as しゅう for this one and you'll be fine.
4731 | 思い遣り | おもいやり | Consideration | Compassion\n Sympathy | If you dispatch what you think to the other person, you're thinking about them, and you're being nice. You're showing consideration, sympathy, and compassion for the other person. \n One reading comes from 思う, so that's all good. 遣り has a weird alternate reading, though (やり). To remember it, just think about how much consideration you're always showing. You're always like "Yah (や), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/
4732 | 廃棄 | はいき | Disposal | Disposing\n Scrapping | It's obsolete, so you’re going to abandon it. This is the act of disposal. Whatever it is, you’re disposing of or scrapping it because it’s no longer needed. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4733 | 潜水 | せんすい | Diving |  | To conceal yourself in water, you'd better start diving and get under the water where it can conceal you! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4734 | 雇用者 | こようしゃ | Employer | Employee | An employment (雇用) someone is someone who gives you employment, aka an employer. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4735 | 凄絶 | せいぜつ | Extremely Gruesome | Extremely Fierce\n Extremely Violent | Something really terrible causing mass extinction will be extremely gruesome. It will also probably be extremely violent, so don't look. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
4736 | 偽 | にせ | Fake | Imitation | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIt turns out she is a fake. Your niece (にせ) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an imitation niece. A 偽niece, if you will.
4737 | 畑 | はたけ | Field | Farmland | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nYou can also stick this after the name of a crop and get a ____ field. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.\nNote when you stick this onto a type of crop to mean a ____ field, this gets rendaku'd to ばたけ.
4738 | 田畑 | たはた | Fields | Rice And Crop Fields\n Farmland | We're talking about both a rice paddy and the other fields where farmers grow crops. So, this means fields, or more precisely rice and crop fields. It's all about farmland. \n The readings come from what you learned with the kanji. 畑 uses the shorter はた reading that you learned.
4739 | 喧嘩 | けんか | Fight | Quarrel\n Argument | When things get noisy and rowdy there's a good chance things will end in a fight. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4740 | 蛍 | ほたる | Firefly | Lightning Bug\n Glowworm | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
4741 | 拳 | こぶし | Fist |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You make a fist. Why? Because she stole your corn on the cob. "Cob! She (こぶし) stole my cob!"
4742 | 偽造 | ぎぞう | Forgery |  | Let's create a fake. This fake we've created? It's a forgery. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4743 | 破片 | はへん | Fragment |  | Tear off a one-sided piece. It's only one part, not all the parts. It's a fragment. \n The 破 reading is the one you learned, the 片 reading isn't one you've learned. Just think about how you're tearing off pieces of a hen (へん), one fragment at a time. Here little chicken, I want another feather from you please. *CAW*
4744 | 果樹 | かじゅ | Fruit Tree |  | A fruit wood is what a fruit grows on (the wood of a fruit is a tree, dummy). That makes this word a fruit tree. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4745 | 葬儀 | そうぎ | Funeral |  | A burial ceremony is known as a funeral. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4746 | 岐阜県 | ぎふけん | Gifu Prefecture |  | You've seen how 岐阜 is "Gifu." Now make it a prefecture to make Gifu prefecture. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4747 | 故郷 | こきょう | Hometown | Birthplace | By circumstance this is your hometown. Not much to say other than it's your hometown and birthplace. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.\nWhile こきょう is the more common reading for this word, it can also be read as ふるさと, which is a native Japanese word that originally didn't have kanji. ふるさと is also common in hiragana.
4748 | 郷里 | きょうり | Hometown | Birthplace | Your hometown home village is the one that's your hometown. It's also your birthplace, where you were born. \n The reading for 郷 is the one you learned, but the reading for 里 isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your birthplace is the place you were reared (り), and you really (り) miss the place.
4749 | 蜂蜜 | はちみつ | Honey |  | A bee's honey is its honey, honey. \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
4750 | 蜜 | みつ | Honey | Nectar | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That's honey, baby!
4751 | 香港 | ほんこん | Hong Kong |  | The fragrance harbor, perhaps this is where the perfumes came from back in the day. This place is Hong Kong. \n The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to ほんこん. Almost the same, right?
4752 | 仁 | じん | Humanity |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

4754 | 謙遜 | けんそん | Humble | Humility\n Modesty | If you have modesty and are humble, then you are probably humble and have humility (and have modesty too, I guess). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4755 | 必至 | ひっし | Inevitable | Necessary\n Foregone | If it's certain that you will attain it, then it is inevitable. It is a foregone conclusion. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4756 | 侵害 | しんがい | Infringement | Violation | You invaded and damaged me. You are doing infringement on my territory. This is a violation of me. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

4758 | 侵攻 | しんこう | Invasion |  | If you invade with aggression that's an invasion. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4759 | 鉄鉱 | てっこう | Iron Ore |  | The iron mineral is iron ore. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4760 | 躍り | おどり | Jumping | Leaping | If 躍る is "to leap" or "to jump," then this noun version will be jumping or leaping. \n The reading comes from 躍る.
4761 | 包丁 | ほうちょう | Kitchen Knife |  | Wrap up the street and take it away. I cut it apart with my kitchen knife (don't ask why this word comes from these kanji). Just imagine yourself using a kitchen knife to cut up the street so you can wrap it up and take it away. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4762 | 嘘吐き | うそつき | Liar |  | If lies puke (吐く) out of your mouth, you're a liar. \n This is a combination of the kun'yomi readings, one of which you haven't seen yet. You'll usually see this word without the 吐 kanji, as in 嘘つき, but for now let's learn its kanji reading!\nYou can't just tell one lie, it always turns into two (つ). Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.
4763 | 嘘 | うそ | Lie |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. A lie is a lie! \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned with reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
4764 | 忠誠 | ちゅうせい | Loyalty |  | I have sincerity about my loyalty. That shows loyalty, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4765 | 礼儀 | れいぎ | Manners | Courtesy\n Etiquette | The thanks ceremony is the dance you do in life when it comes to your manners and courtesy to others. Also means etiquette. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4766 | 措置 | そち | Measures | Steps | Set aside and put what you'll need to get the job done over there. These are the measures and steps we're taking to make sure things get done properly. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4767 | 鉱物 | こうぶつ | Mineral |  | A mineral thing is a mineral. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4768 | 鉱業 | こうぎょう | Mining Industry |  | The mineral business is the mining industry. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4769 | 艦隊 | かんたい | Naval Fleet | Armada | A warship squad is a naval fleet or an armada. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4770 | 喧しい | やかましい | Noisy | Picky | You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is noisy and picky, so the adjective version is also noisy and picky.\nThis type of noisy can be just about being noisy, like a group of turkeys. It can also be a ""picky"" sort of noisy, when someone is being particular in a vocal sort of way. \n My noisy mom has earned the nickname yak-a-Ma (やかま). "Yakka yakka yakka," is what my mom says about my life choices.
4771 | 鉱石 | こうせき | Ore | Mineral | A mineral stone is an ore / mineral. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of the kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.
4772 | 証拠 | しょうこ | Physical Evidence | Evidence\n Proof | The evidence is based on something. What is it based on? This physical evidence. Ha ha! Guilty! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember that 拠 is using the こ reading you learned, not the きょ one. Just remember that you can never trust the word of a 子 (こ), so you always require them to provide physical evidence.
4773 | 拠点 | きょてん | Position | Location | Something based on points has a ranking, meaning you'll know where your position or location is, compared to everyone else. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4774 | 瀬 | せ | Rapids | Shallows\n Current | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, actually!
4775 | 生き甲斐 | いきがい | Reason For Living | Something Worth Living For | You know that 甲斐 is "effect" or "worth." So, the "worth for being alive" is your reason for living. It gives life worth. It's your reason for living.\n生き甲斐 is a noun so usually gets used and translated that way, like 仕事が生き甲斐 (work is a reason for living) or 生き甲斐が欲しい (want something worth living for). \n The readings come from 甲斐 and 生き, so if you know those you may have a reason for living, or at least a reason for doing your kanji study.
4776 | 渋々 | しぶしぶ | Reluctantly | Unwillingly | If you bite into something bitter (twice!) you'll take your next bite reluctantly. Because who would want that much of something bitter? Not you. \n This is the kun'yomi reading twice. You learned this reading when you learned 渋い. If you remember that, you know this too!
4777 | 甲斐性 | かいしょう | Resourcefulness | Competence | The result (甲斐) of being your own gender shows your resourcefulness. Depending on your gender, certain things are harder than others, so your resourcefulness and competence will help you to overcome those hurdles. \n This word combines the word 甲斐 (that you already learned) with the on'yomi reading for 性. You know them both, just put them together!
4778 | 御手洗 | おてあらい | Restroom | Bathroom\n Toilet | You know 手洗い, right? This is like that, but way more polite sounding. The meaning is still the same though: restroom, bathroom, toilet. \n The reading for the 御 is お, the rest is てあらい, even though the い isn't showing on the end. It gets pushed into the 洗い.
4779 | 拳銃 | けんじゅう | Revolver | Pistol\n Handgun | A fist gun is a small fistish sized gun that has some punch (because, you know, fist!). The gun I'm describing is a revolver, or a handgun. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4780 | 廃墟 | はいきょ | Ruins | Abandoned Building | Obsolete ruins are places that are abandoned because nobody can run them anymore (due to being obsolete, or due to not having money, or due to whatever else). These things are ruins or abandoned buildings. People like to explore these, a lot. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4781 | 瀬戸 | せと | Seto |  | The rapids door is actually Seto, which is the name of a few different places in Japan. One of those places is where the famous earthenware Seto ware comes from 🍶 \n This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4782 | 高瀬 | たかせ | Shallows |  | The high rapids are the shallows. How does that make sense?! I guess this means geographically high. So higher up the river, near the source, the water tends to be pretty shallow.\nYou'll see 高瀬 mostly in names, such as 高瀬川 (Takase River) or 高瀬ダム (Takase Dam). \n The reading comes from 高い and the reading you learned for 瀬.
4783 | 渋谷 | しぶや | Shibuya |  | The bitter valley is a place known as Shibuya. This is a very famous area in Tokyo. Very busy too. \n The reading of 渋 comes from 渋い. The reading for 谷 is an exception. Just think about someone asking you if  Shibuya is cool. Your answer of course is "yah." (や)
4784 | 焼酎 | しょうちゅう | Shochu | Shouchuu\n Japanese Traditional Hard Liquor | Baked hard liquor is slightly higher in alcohol content. This is shochu, which I'm guessing is heated in some way during its production.\nShochu is a type of Japanese traditional hard liquor. It's a distilled spirit made from ingredients like sweet potato, barley, rice, buckwheat, and sugar cane. \n The reading for 焼 and 酎 are the on'yomi readings, but you didn't learn the reading for 焼 yet. That's okay, because if you know the (also English) word Shochu, you'll be able to remember the reading for this one as well too.
4785 | 包囲 | ほうい | Siege | Encirclement | Wrap and surround them. We are going to siege the enemy. This is encirclement around their base! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4786 | 誠実 | せいじつ | Sincere | Honest\n Faithful | You have sincerity and you have truth. You are so sincere and honest and faithful, good friend. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4787 | 誠意 | せいい | Sincerity | Good Faith | The idea of sincerity is sincerity. It's also to have good faith in others. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4788 | 誠 | まこと | Sincerity | Truth | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Sincerity and truth are so important to me that I always keep them inside my coat (まこと). That's where I keep everything that's dearest to me, and what could be more important that sincerity and truth? Where do you keep sincerity and truth? I bet your answer is "my coat" too.
4789 | 社会福祉 | しゃかいふくし | Social Welfare |  | 福祉 is welfare, 社会 is society. So, a society's welfare is social welfare. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4790 | 御免なさい | ごめんなさい | Sorry | I Beg Your Pardon | Remember 御免? This is a polite way to say it. It means sorry and I beg your pardon. \n The reading comes from 御免. The addition is all kana.
4791 | 潜在意識 | せんざいいしき | Subconscious |  | If 意識 is consciously, then what exists concealed in your mind is your subconscious. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4792 | 潜水艦 | せんすいかん | Submarine |  | A conceal in the water warship is a submarine. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4793 | 夏至 | げし | Summer Solstice |  | If you have attained summer, that must mean you finished out with the previous season and are going into summer. This is the summer solstice. \n You didn't learn this reading of 夏 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nJust think about how cute little geckos (げ) start to come out into the open during the summer solstice. It's too cold for them to be out in the open before that, so if you look outside at the right time, you'll see geckos popping out of the ground all over the place!

4798 | 控える | ひかえる | To Abstain | To Refrain\n To Hold Back\n To Stand By | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abstain and the verb vocab version is to abstain as well!\n控える is super versatile. It can mean to refrain from drinking, to hold back  comments, or to stand by (abstaining from taking action). In some contexts, it can even mean "to take a memo" because memo-taking is like putting information on standby! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, good for you!
4799 | 至る | いたる | To Arrive At |  | The kanji means attain but the meaning of this verb is to arrive at. 4800 | 拠る | よる | To Be Due To | To Be Caused By | The kanji means based on and the verb means to be due to. This is probably because when something is based off something, it does something else, which is due to what it was based on. It was caused by what it was based on. \n For example, yogurt is due to milk. If milk didn't exist, neither would yogurt.

The kanji itself means wrap so the verb vocab version is to wrap. \n You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a two two (つつ) wrapping technique.\nつつむ is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that 包む can be read as くるむ as well. くるむ is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. つつむ on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.

4872 | 国柄 | くにがら | National Character |  | The country pattern is the pattern of things a country does. This is the national character of a nation. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.
4873 | 網 | あみ | Net | Netting\n Web | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen it comes to nets, you gotta go talk to Amy (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.
4874 | 一泊 | いっぱく | One Night's Stay |  | One overnight is a one night's stay. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.
4875 | 不透明 | ふとうめい | Opacity | Opaque | You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is opaque, making this word opacity. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4876 | 双 | そう | Pair |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a pair, you know?
4877 | 括弧 | かっこ | Parentheses | Brackets | The fasten arcs are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (parentheses) and [brackets]. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.
4878 | 柄 | がら | Pattern | Design | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck. Follow that reading pattern to here, and you should be okay.
4879 | 人柄 | ひとがら | Personal Character | Personality\n Character | A person's pattern is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their personal character or personality. \n The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!
4880 | 哲学 | てつがく | Philosophy |  | The philosophy study is the study of philosophy. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4881 | 携帯電話 | けいたいでんわ | Portable Phone | Cell Phone\n Mobile Phone | You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a portable phone or cell phone or mobile phone. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.
4882 | 挑発 | ちょうはつ | Provocation |  | My challenge has made a departure and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a provocation to see if they'll take me up on my challenge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4883 | 拉麺 | らーめん | Ramen | Ramen Noodles | If you're going to abduct some noodles, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, ramen! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you pull the dough to stretch it when you make ramen noodles. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best!\nThis word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺 or ラー麺. \n Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long らー, just think how excited you are about these ramen! Raaaaaa! Raaaamen! So exciting!
4884 | 躍進 | やくしん | Rapid Progress | Great Advancement | When you leap and advance, you make rapid progress and great advancement.\nYou might recall that 飛躍 also means "rapid progress," but what sets them apart? 躍進 emphasizes the subject's perspective as it advances at a rapid pace, whereas 飛躍 conveys significant progress or leaps more neutrally, without highlighting pace or perspective. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4885 | 綱 | つな | Rope | Sumo Champion's Belt | The kanji is rope so this word also refers to a rope. This can also mean a sumo champion's belt, though you'll probably see that meaning a lot less, unless you're a huge sumo fan. \n The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.
4886 | 袋 | ふくろ | Sack | Bag | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a sack and move on to the next item.
4887 | 犠飛 | ぎひ | Sacrifice Fly |  | A sacrifice fly is a sacrifice fly. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base. \n The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 飛 just think about how he (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball heated up.

I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
4889 | 堅い | かたい | Solid | Serious\n Upright\n Hard | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of solid? It's solid, serious, upright, or hard. This word is often used in the figurative sense, as in a solid defence, a serious topic, or an upright person. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, somen, or somen noodles, which are fine white noodles. \n The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because somen are your soul (そう) food.

4895 | 干潟 | ひがた | Tidal Flat | Tideland | A dry lagoon is a tidal flat. \n The reading for 干 is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the heat (ひ) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.
4896 | 焦げる | こげる | To Be Burned | To Get Burned | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means char, but the verb version is to be burned or to get burned. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!). \n The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a kid (子). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.
4897 | 吹き出す | ふきだす | To Begin To Blow | To Spout Out\n To Burst Out Laughing | If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need to begin to blow to do that! \n The readings come from 吹く and 出す.

You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

When it becomes 漬かる, it means the food has reached a state where the pickling or marinating process is complete, and it's ready to eat. So this word means to be well pickled or to be well marinated. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.
4901 | 吹き飛ばす | ふきとばす | To Blow Away |  | You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going to blow away it. \n The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.
4902 | 吹き込む | ふきこむ | To Blow In | To Breathe Into\n To Imbue | You know that 吹く is "to blow" and the kanji 込 means into. So this word means to blow in or to breathe into, and it can be used both transitively and intransitively.\nIt can also be used figuratively to mean to breathe into orto imbue, like breathing new life into something, or imbuing someone’s mind with hatred. \n The reading comes from the word 吹く and the kanji 込む.

4904 | 揚げる | あげる | To Deep Fry | To Hoist\n To Raise | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hoist. I guess you can think of it as hoisting that delicious deep-fried food out of the oil.\nOf course, 揚げる can also mean to hoist (a sail) or to raise (a flag) depending on the context. \n Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

4954 | 暴露 | ばくろ | Disclosure | Exposure | Using violence I'm going to expose the truth! This is disclosure. This is exposure.\nThis word carries the connotation of something scandalous being revealed, often in a dramatic manner. \n The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step back (ばく) to deal with the new information.
4955 | 幻滅 | げんめつ | Disillusionment |  | The illusion is destroyed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is disillusionment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4956 | 距離 | きょり | Distance | Range | The distance that is detached from the distance is the distance and range. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4957 | 滅亡 | めつぼう | Downfall | Ruin\n Destruction | Destroy to death. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your downfall and ruin. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4958 | 軒 | のき | Eaves | Stand In A Row\n Stand Side By Side | In order to use a house counter in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find eaves. And all those eaves together stand in a row. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:\nThese houses that stand in a row are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have no key (のき). With no key, those eaves are just there for you to look at.
4959 | 封筒 | ふうとう | Envelope |  | Seal in the cylinder. This cylinder that is sealed in is an envelope. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an envelope. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4960 | 露出 | ろしゅつ | Exposure | Photographic Exposure | When what you expose is exited out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is exposure. It can also refer to photographic exposure too, in case you were wondering. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4961 | 撲滅 | ぼくめつ | Extermination | Eradication | Slap that bug and destroy it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is extermination. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4962 | 絶滅 | ぜつめつ | Extinction | Become Extinct | Extinction where everything is destroyed is extinction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4963 | 偽物 | にせもの | Fake | Counterfeit | A fake thing is fake or counterfeit. \n You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.
4964 | 濡れ衣 | ぬれぎぬ | False Accusations | False Charges\n Baseless Accusations | Ah yes, wet clothes must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for false accusations. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason. \n This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "give new (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"
4965 | 戸籍 | こせき | Family Register | Census | Enroll your door... and by door, I mean enroll your family, because each family has one door to their house. Enrolling your family means you are enrolling them into the family register. This is actually an interesting topic. Look up "koseki" in Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories. \n The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of children (こ).
4966 | 垣 | かき | Fence | Hedge\n Wall | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that for the word fence in Japanese, フェンス is typically used. 垣 isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
4967 | 封建主義 | ほうけんしゅぎ | Feudalism |  | You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that onto an ism that is building a seal(ed) in system, and you have feudalism. Why? Because with feudalism, power is sealed in with one group or one family. Nobody else can get in (until they are overthrown, anyways), making this feudalism. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4968 | 暖炉 | だんろ | Fireplace | Hearth\n Stove | A warm furnace is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a fireplace or hearth or even a stove. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4969 | 露骨 | ろこつ | Frank | Blunt | I'm going to expose my bones for a second here and be blunt with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4970 | 摩擦 | まさつ | Friction |  | Things that chafe and rub have lots of friction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4971 | 懇意 | こんい | Friendly | Closeness | Being courteous is the right idea if you want to be on friendly terms with others. The more courteous you are to someone (and vice versa), the more a sense of closeness grows between you.\n懇意 formally describes being on good, cordial terms with someone. You might talk about a colleague you've become friendly with (懇意になった同僚) or a professor who treats you warmly (懇意にしてくれる教授), for example. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4972 | 懇話 | こんわ | Friendly Talk | Friendly Discussion | A courteous talk is a friendly talk. We all know that "friendly talks" are never what they seem, though... right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4973 | 懇親 | こんしん | Friendship |  | A courteous parent is a parent who knows when a kid needs a friend. Then, they set their kid up with you so that you can have a friendship. What a nice parent the other person is! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4974 | 柔らかい | やわらかい | Gentle | Flexible\n Soft\n Tender | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle... but in this word's case, it's also flexible, soft, and tender. \n You find something that is so gentle and soft to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "Yah what (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "Yah, what can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.
4975 | 柔和 | にゅうわ | Gentle | Tender\n Gentleness | A gentle and peaceful person is gentle and tender.\n柔和 is commonly used in literature to describe someone whose nature or features express gentleness. \n You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to be gentle and tender if you want to touch something that's new (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs that gentleness.
4976 | 旨 | むね | Gist | Principle | The point of something is the gist and principle of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's gist as well. \n The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as むね.
4977 | 朗報 | ろうほう | Good News |  | A bright news report is going to be one full of good news. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4978 | 垣根 | かきね | Hedge | Fence | A hedge (or fence) root is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a hedge or a fence. \n The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.
4979 | 満潮 | まんちょう | High Tide | Full Tide | A full tide is a high tide or full tide. That's when the water comes up. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

4981 | 即〜 | そく | Immediate | Instant | If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is immediate or instant. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4982 | 即座 | そくざ | Immediate | Instantaneous | An instant sit is immediate. It's also instantaneous. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4983 | 即効 | そっこう | Immediate Effect | Instant Effect | It's instantly effective! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means immediate effect or instant effect. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.
4984 | 即興 | そっきょう | Improvisation |  | An instant interest in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some improvisation, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of そく.
4985 | 誠に | まことに | Indeed | Really\n Sincerely | The に on the end of this word turns sincerity into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's sincerely, or indeed. It really is. \n This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case:\nMy coat (まこと) really is a coat! Indeed, it is.

It's an informal but courteous talk, usually between acquaintances rather than close friends. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
4987 | 伺い | うかがい | Inquiry | Enquiry\n Question\n Visit | If 伺う is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say inquiry or enquiry. In other words, a question. It can also mean a visit. \n The reading comes from 伺う.
