Just think about how with this pasture you have to constantly sew (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.
4999 | 牧野 | ぼくや | Pasture Land | Ranch | A pasture field is pasture land. It's also a ranch. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.\nThe secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"
5000 | 慰問 | いもん | Paying A Sympathy Call | Consolation\n Sympathy Visit | The best consolation for someone's problem is paying a sympathy call. It is consolation through a sympathy visit.\n慰問 is a formal way of saying お見舞い (sympathy visit). It's often used when someone notable, like a celebrity or politician, makes a visit to offer support and comfort to people in difficult situations, like hospital patients, nursing home residents, or those affected by disasters. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5001 | 安泰 | あんたい | Peace | Security | Relax in peace. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly peace. You feel security too. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5002 | 筒 | つつ | Pipe | Cylinder\n Tube | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You'll see this used to mean pipe more often than cylinder, though. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to pipes, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a two two (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.
5003 | 論旨 | ろんし | Point Of An Argument |  | The point to my theory is the point of an argument. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5004 | 印刷 | いんさつ | Printing |  | With a seal we're printing everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this printing. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5005 | 珍しい | めずらしい | Rare | Unusual\n Curious | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of rare? It's rare. But, this can also mean unusual or curious (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something). \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou know what's unusual and rare? This maze is rare (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!
5006 | 即日 | そくじつ | Same Day |  | The instant day is the day that's going on this instant. It's the same day as now. \n The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the truth (じつ) is that it's the same day today.
5007 | 封 | ふう | Seal |  | The kanji is seal in, but the vocab noun version is seal. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with). \n The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a fool, make sure you seal your envelopes.
5008 | 封書 | ふうしょ | Sealed Letter |  | A seal in writing is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a sealed letter. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5013 | 石垣 | いしがき | Stone Wall |  | A stone hedge is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a stone wall. \n The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.
5014 | 露店 | ろてん | Street Stall | Stand\n Booth | An exposed shop is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a street stall. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5015 | 相撲 | すもう | Sumo Wrestling | Sumo | A mutual slap is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is sumo wrestling. \n The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's すもう.
5016 | 奇襲 | きしゅう | Surprise Attack |  | An odd attack is an attack you don't expect. This is a surprise attack. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5017 | 沼沢 | しょうたく | Swamp | Marsh | A bog swamp is a swamp or marsh. \n Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular swamp, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the Shogun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.
5018 | 潮 | しお | Tide | Current | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of salt (しお).
5019 | 潮流 | ちょうりゅう | Tide | Tidal Current | A tides stream is the stream going through the tide. It's the tide or the tidal current. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5020 | 風潮 | ふうちょう | Tide | Current\n Trend | The wind tide is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the tide and current. These days, we usually use this word for the current trends that come in like the tide. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5021 | 威張る | いばる | To Act Big | To Be Arrogant\n To Be Bossy | Take your dignity and stretch it. Your dignity is so stretched! That makes you feel big! That's why this word is to act big or to be arrogant. \n The reading is from 威 and 張る.
5022 | 襲う | おそう | To Attack |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attack and the verb vocab version is to attack. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going to attack me or something? Oh so scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."
5023 | 揚がる | あがる | To Be Fried Up | To Be Deep Fried\n To Be Up | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb. The kanji means hoist, but the verb most commonly means to be fried up, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, to be up. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.
5024 | 慰める | なぐさめる | To Console |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.
5025 | 滅ぼす | ほろぼす | To Destroy | To Annihilate | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate. \n You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.
5026 | 群がる | むらがる | To Flock | To Crowd | Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that! \n The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small 村 (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.
5027 | 潜る | もぐる | To Go Under | To Dive Underwater\n To Go Underground\n To Pass Through | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but as a verb, this word means to go under or to pass through. Most commonly, this word means to dive underwater or to go underground. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you! \n 潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhy are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get mo' goo (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?
5028 | 懲りる | こりる | To Learn By Experience |  | The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising). \n As a child (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).
5029 | 刷る | する | To Print |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print. \n When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.
5030 | 沈む | しずむ | To Sink |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.\nThis is an intransitive verb, so it refers to something sinking on its own. You didn't do anything to make it sink. You know this is when something is just sinking on its own (you didn't sink it), because of the む, which shows it's a cow sinking. The cow stepped into some quicksand and now it's sinking, not because of you. \n You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (しず) sinking.
5031 | 裂く | さく | To Tear | To Rip Up | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means split, but if you split something, you are going to tear it or to rip up it. \n In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!
5032 | 開封 | かいふう | Unsealing | Breaking A Seal\n Opening A Letter | When you open something sealed, you're unsealing it or breaking a seal.\n開封 generally refers to opening something sealed, like opening a letter or package. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5033 | 珍〜 | ちん | Unusual | Rare\n Peculiar | Something rare is often unusual. This word could also mean rare (of course) and peculiar depending on the context.\nThese days, media often uses this word to describe the way something is unusual, quirky, and funny. \n The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too rare, wouldn't you say?
5034 | 挑戦者 | ちょうせんしゃ | A Challenger | Challenger | A challenge (挑戦) someone is someone who is going to challenge you. They are a challenger. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5035 | 軒並み | のきなみ | Across The Board | Row Of Houses\n Altogether | Line up house counters and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same across the board. It also turns them into a row of houses. \n This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too. Just note that for 並, the み in なみ is sticking out! While you might sometimes see this written 軒並, 軒並み is way more common.
5036 | 一翼 | いちよく | A Part | A Role | One wing is just a part of the bird or plane it's attached to. But that one wing plays a role that's very important!\nThis word usually comes up in the phrase 〜の一翼を担う (to play a part in…). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5037 | 助力 | じょりょく | Assistance | Support | When you help with your power, you are providing assistance and support.\nNote that this is a formal word that’s mostly used in professional situations. It implies that someone has done something substantial for you. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nYou really need some assistance with this lock (りょく). You are certain that world peace and eternal happiness lie behind this one lock. But no one is willing to support you in opening it. What a cruel world.
5038 | 寝床 | ねどこ | Bed | Crib | A sleep bed is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a bed or a crib. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji. \n This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "where (どこ) is it?"
5039 | 刃 | は | Blade | Edge | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But it also has a secondary reading you haven't learned, so here’s a mnemonic for it:\nBlade in hand, you charge at your foes hollering "Yah! Eee! Baa!" (やいば). As the blade cuts through them, you cry "Yah! Eee! Baa!" even louder. This battle cry always fuels your fury and doubles the force of your swinging blade. "Yah! Eee! Baa!"\nWhile both readings relate to blades, they have slightly different uses. は is used for any cutting tool's blade or edge, whereas やいば is a little old-fashioned and specifically refers to the blades of swords or knives, often in literary contexts.
5040 | 金髪 | きんぱつ | Blonde |  | Gold hair is blonde hair. Makes sense! \n The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were blonde, you'd wear many hats (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.
5041 | 両翼 | りょうよく | Both Wings | Both Flanks | Both wings are both wings! There are two and you have them all! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5042 | 缶コーヒー | かんこーひー | Canned Coffee | Can Coffee | A can coffee (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's canned coffee or can coffee. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5043 | 大砲 | たいほう | Cannon |  | A big cannon is... wait for it... just a cannon. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5044 | 携帯ストラップ | けいたいすとらっぷ | Cell Phone Strap | Mobile Phone Strap | You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a strap (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a cell phone strap or mobile phone strap. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.
5045 | 選択肢 | せんたくし | Choices | Options\n Alternatives | You're free to choose and select any of these limbs, leaving you many choices. With all these options and alternatives, which one will you go for? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5046 | 紛らわしい | まぎらわしい | Confusing | Misleading | The kanji is distract and the adjective version is confusing or misleading. \n You know who is particularly confusing? That maggie (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses magic (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.
5047 | 笠 | かさ | Conical Hat | Bamboo Hat | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5048 | 管制塔 | かんせいとう | Control Tower |  | The pipe control tower is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the control tower. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5049 | 為替 | かわせ | Currency Exchange |  | For the sake of exchange! What sounds so glorious is really just currency exchange. \n You need to do a bunch of currency exchange for your newest investment: car wash celery (かわせ)! Why of course, it's celery that's stored, cleaned, and… smoked inside of a car wash. So go get all the currency you have, we have some exchanging to do.

5054 | 刃物 | はもの | Edged Tool | Cutlery\n Knife | A blade thing is an edged tool or cutlery. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 刃's reading with the kanji, and you probably remember 物 from so many other words.
5055 | 刃先 | はさき | Edge Of Blade | Blade Edge | The blade's ahead is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the edge of the blade or blade edge. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 刃 you learned that with the kanji. For 先 that's the vocab version of the kanji.
5056 | エッフェル塔 | えっふぇるとう | Eiffel Tower |  | The Eiffel (エッフェル) tower is the Eiffel Tower. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5057 | 一斗缶 | いっとかん | Eighteen-Liter Container | Five-Gallon Container | A one ladle can is a eighteen-liter container, which is also a five-gallon container. That must be one big ladle!\nIf you live in Japan you've probably seen these. They're rectangular shaped containers made of metal that are used mostly for industrial purposes, for storing liquids like paint, fuel and chemicals. The 斗 actually refers to an old Japanese measurement, which is roughly equivalent to eighteen liters. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Just watch out for the 一, which gets shortened to いっ.
5058 | 絶叫 | ぜっきょう | Exclamation | Scream\n Shout | Extinction caused by a shout. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you scream and shout over them. You are making an exclamation, gosh darn it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.

5061 | 手袋 | てぶくろ | Gloves |  | A hand sack is a sack for your hands... better put, these are gloves. \n The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of 手 and 袋 as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

5069 | 丘 | おか | Hill | Knoll | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as 岡 which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!
5070 | 斗 | と | Ladle | Big Dipper\n Measure Of Volume\n Eighteen Liters | How much can you hold in this ladle? Why, exactly eighteen liters of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5071 | 左翼 | さよく | Left Wing |  | The left wing is the left wing, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that. \n The reading for 左 is the on'yomi reading, さ. You can remember this because the left wing uses saws (さ) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

5077 | 縁起 | えんぎ | Omen | Luck | The edge of wake up is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. 5079 | 寸前 | すんぜん | On The Brink | On The Verge\n Just In Front Of\n Just Before | Before you take the last measurement, you know you're on the brink of something. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.
5080 | 独創 | どくそう | Original Creation | Creating Something Original | You are alone in what you are able to create. Nobody else can create like you. So what you create is your own original creation.\n独創 refers to the act of creating something original, or the resulting creation itself. This word is quite formal, and generally used as 独創的 (original) or 独創性 (originality). \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

5097 | 土砂 | どしゃ | Sediment | Earth And Sand | Earth and sand is earth and sand, or sediment. \n This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. 5098 | 手堅い | てがたい | Solid | Steady\n Firm | You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your hand is solid and tough, it's solid and steady. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something. \n The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

5102 | 寸 | すん | Sun | Three Point Zero Three Centimeters | This measurement also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. 5103 | 感涙 | かんるい | Tears Of Gratitude | Being Moved To Tears | The feeling of teardrops is a feeling that makes you cry. But it's not a bad feeling because these are tears of gratitude, or because you're being moved to tears.\n感涙 is an advanced word primarily used in writing. It refers to the kind of tears you might shed when you're profoundly touched with emotion, like when you're truly grateful for something or moved by a song or movie. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 涙 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour excessive tears of gratitude have ruined (るい) your life. Your friends didn't like being cried at for the smallest compliment or favor, so now they don't even return your calls. No one else you know is being moved to tears on a daily basis like this. It's ruining your life!
5104 | 北斗七星 | ほくとしちせい | The Big Dipper | The Plough | What can you see in the north that looks like a ladle and is made up of seven stars? That's the group of stars we call the Big Dipper or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps the Plough. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.
5105 | 雷 | かみなり | Thunder | Lightning\n Thunderbolt | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n To remember the reading think about thunder. 5106 | 落雷 | らくらい | Thunderbolt | Lightning\n Bolt Of Lightning\n Lightning Strike | Thunder that falls from the sky is a thunderbolt. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5107 | 雷雨 | らいう | Thunderstorm |  | A thunder rain is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think thunderstorm. \n The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you learned it with 雨天. So you should be able to put them together!
5108 | 缶 | かん | Tin Can | Can\n Tin | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like can.
5109 | 紛れる | まぎれる | To Be Diverted | To Be Distracted | You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word to be diverted or to be distracted. \n The reading comes from 紛らす.
5110 | 揺れる | ゆれる | To Be Shaken | To Be Jolted | Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it to be shaken or to be jolted. You know this because it's really rare (れる) for you to be shaken like this. \n The reading comes from 揺る.
5111 | 裂ける | さける | To Be Split | To Be Torn\n To Burst Apart | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means split, so this verb has to do with something splitting.\nThis is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be split, to be torn, or to burst apart. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 裂く.
5112 | 焦がす | こがす | To Burn | To Scorch | You know that 焦げる is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it to burn or to scorch. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of gas (がす) to burn whatever it is you burn. \n The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.
5113 | 克服する | こくふくする | To Conquer |  | 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is to conquer. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5114 | 忍ぶ | しのぶ | To Endure | To Conceal\n To Hide | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure so the verb vocab version is to endure. \n Those who are able to endure are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The shinobi (しの).
5115 | 取り逃がす | とりにがす | To Fail To Catch |  | The thing you want to take has escaped. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is to fail to catch. \n The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.
5116 | 釣る | つる | To Fish |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fishing so the verb vocab version is to fish. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5117 | 荒らす | あらす | To Lay Waste | To Devastate | 荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying to lay waste and to devastate everything around you. \n The reading comes from 荒れる.
5118 | 見逃す | みのがす | To Overlook |  | 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your seeing, then you are going to overlook it. \n The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.
5119 | 竜巻 | たつまき | Tornado |  | A dragon scroll is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a tornado. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a standing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a tornado. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.
5120 | 魚雷 | ぎょらい | Torpedo |  | Fish thunder is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a torpedo. Load the fish thunder! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5121 | 叱る | しかる | To Scold | To Chide\n To Reprimand | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scold and the verb vocab version also means to scold. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
5122 | 揺する | ゆする | To Shake | To Rock\n To Sway\n To Jolt | Shake plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's to shake or to rock slowly. \n The reading comes from 揺る.
5123 | 揺さぶる | ゆさぶる | To Shake | To Jolt | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake. \n The reading comes from 揺る.
5124 | 叫ぶ | さけぶ | To Shout | To Scream | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shout so the verb vocab version is to shout. Can also be to scream. \n To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start to shout and to scream when you drink way too much sake (さけ).
5125 | 沈める | しずめる | To Sink Something |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.\nThis is a transitive verb, so it's used when you're sinking something else. You can differentiate it from the intransitive 沈む by imaging that you're watching an enemy ship sink, and they shout out, "Who did this to me!" You respond, me (め). I did." \n When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.
5126 | 塔 | とう | Tower | Pagoda | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a pagoda. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5127 | バベルの塔 | ばべるのとう | Tower Of Babel |  | バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the Tower of Babel. \n The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.
5128 | 無縁 | むえん | Unrelated |  | If something has a nothing edge, it's probably unrelated to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5129 | 朱 | あけ | Vermilion | Scarlet Red\n Blood | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also say it's scarlet red or blood as well, though more in a poetic sense, I'd say. I don't think you'll hear surgeons calling blood 朱. \n The reading あけ is like the beginning of 開ける, which means "to open." Just imagine you're opening (あけ) a person up, and out gushes a vermilion colored blood. You shouldn't open people up like that.
5130 | 荒々しい | あらあらしい | Wild | Rough | 荒い is rough. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: wild or rough. \n The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!
5131 | 翼 | つばさ | Wing |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n In each political  wing there are two bosses (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.
5132 | 廃絶 | はいぜつ | Abolition | Elimination\n Extinction | Something that is obsolete will end in extinction. Join in the calls for its abolition, elimination and extinction, whatever it is. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5133 | いつ頃 | いつごろ | About When | How Soon | いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "about when?" or "how soon?" \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.
5134 | 警鐘 | けいしょう | Alarm Bell | Fire Bell | A warn bell is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an alarm bell or a fire bell. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5135 | 年頃 | としごろ | Approximate Age | Adolescence\n Marriageable Age | The year approximate is your approximate age. This is also an indirect way to refer to adolescence, and when people reach marriageable age! \n The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together. Note: You will also sometimes see this written partially in kana like 年ごろ.
5136 | 頃 | ころ | Approximate Time | Around\n About | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means approximate time and around (as in "around 3:00"). \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.
5137 | 凶悪 | きょうあく | Atrocious | Fiendish | A villain who is bad is the most atrocious and fiendish villain of them all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5138 | 細菌 | さいきん | Bacteria |  | A thin bacteria is... well... a bacteria. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
5139 | 悪趣味 | あくしゅみ | Bad Habit | Bad Taste | Your 趣味 is your hobby. It's the thing you do on habit. A bad hobby is a habit that you do all the time that's no good. This is a bad habit. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5140 | 鐘 | かね | Bell | Chime | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Seeing the bell, you decide you need to ring it. You take your cane (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.
5141 | 賭け | かけ | Betting | Gambling\n A Gamble\n A Bet | The noun version of gamble is gambling or betting or a gamble or a bet. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
5142 | 小舟 | こぶね | Boat | Small Craft | A small boat is a boat or small craft. If something is a "big boat" it's better to call it a "ship" I think, which is why this is just a boat. \n The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.
5143 | 舟 | ふね | Boat |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this word isn't usually used by itself (that would be 船). It's usually attached to things that are boat-related, but I wanted you to learn it individually so you can use it that way. \n The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.
5144 | 嫁 | よめ | Bride | Wife | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5145 | 電卓 | でんたく | Calculator |  | An electricity table is a calculator. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5146 | 暦 | こよみ | Calendar | Almanac | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n When looking at a calendar, the 子読み (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.
5147 | 霊園 | れいえん | Cemetery |  | A ghost garden is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a cemetery. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5148 | 西暦 | せいれき | Christian Era | Western Calendar | The West's calendar shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the Christian Era. It also used to be used as a way to refer to the Western Calendar, though we usually just say カレンダー nowadays. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5149 | 曇り | くもり | Cloudy Weather | Cloudiness\n Fog | The noun version of cloudy is cloudy weather or cloudiness. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of fog you'd find on a window or your glasses.\nDespite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5169 | 狩人 | かりゅうど | Hunter |  | A hunt person is a person who hunts. A hunter. \n You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named Rudolph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.
5170 | 狩り | かり | Hunting |  | You have the noun version of hunt. That is hunting. \n The reading uses the reading from the kanji.
5171 | 霊感 | れいかん | Inspiration | Sixth Sense\n ESP | A ghost feeling is inspiration. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the sixth sense. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5172 | 黒潮 | くろしお | Japan Current | Kuroshio Current | The black tide isn't what you think, most likely. This is the Japan current, aka the Kuroshio Current. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that. \n The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.
5173 | 近頃 | ちかごろ | Lately | Recently | The near approximate is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the lately period of time. It's recently. \n The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

5177 | 塊 | かたまり | Lump | Mass\n Bundle\n Embodiment | The kanji and the word are the same, so this can mean lump, mass, or bundle. 5180 | 献立 | こんだて | Menu | Meal Plan | I'm offering to stand up and announce what's on the menu for today. I'll tell everyone about today's meal plan.\nThis word doesn't mean the kind of physical menu you see in a restaurant, but rather a menu, or meal plan, in the sense of the foods you're planning to eat. \n You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nI'm actually announcing the menu for condors (こん). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

5188 | 小包 | こづつみ | Package | A Package\n Parcel\n A Parcel | A small bundle is merely a package. Something big would be a big package, I guess. \n The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. 5189 | 磨き | みがき | Polish | Shine | A polish is a polish or even a shine. \n The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
5190 | 義塾 | ぎじゅく | Private School |  | A righteousness cram school is, for some reason, a private school. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure.\nYou may have seen the abbreviation 私学 (for 私立学校) as another word for private school. 私学 is typically used for any schools, elementary through university, that are run by individuals or private groups.\n義塾 instead generally describes private schools founded during the Edo and Meiji periods. In contemporary Japanese, it's not really used on its own but can be seen in school names like 明徳義塾高等学校 (Meitoku Gijuku High School). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5191 | 眺望 | ちょうぼう | Prospect | View | You stare at hope. It looks good. That is your prospect and view, as you stare at hope. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5192 | 滝川 | たきがわ | Rapids |  | A waterfall river is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are rapids. \n The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.
5193 | 先頃 | さきごろ | Recently | The Other Day | The previous approximate was the previous approximate time, which is recently or the other day. \n The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.
5194 | この頃 | このごろ | Recently | Nowadays\n These Days | This (この) approximate is this approximate time. It is recently or nowadays or these days. \n The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.
5195 | 元凶 | げんきょう | Ringleader | Main Culprit | The origin villain is the villain who's running everything. They're the person responsible for the villainy going on. They are the ringleader or main culprit. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5196 | 脚本 | きゃくほん | Script | Screenplay | A leg book is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a script or screenplay. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5197 | 陰 | かげ | Shadow | Shade | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means shadow. \n Look at a shadow. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a cage (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.
5198 | 近距離 | きんきょり | Short Distance |  | A 距離 is a distance and 近 is near. A near distance is a short distance. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5199 | 短距離 | たんきょり | Short Distance |  | A 距離 (distance) that is short is a short distance. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5200 | 一斉に | いっせいに | Simultaneously | All At Once | 一斉 is simultaneous or all at once. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes simultaneously. For "all at once" it stays at all at once. \n The reading comes from 一斉.
5201 | 肌色 | はだいろ | Skin Color | Skin Tone | Skin color is skin color, or skin tone.\nThis word originally referred to a pale orange or peach color, and sometimes you'll still see it used that way. But labeling that as 肌色 wasn't inclusive of all skin tones. Now, it simply refers to skin color in general. \n The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.
5202 | 魂 | たましい | Soul |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Look inside your soul. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your soul rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari Tamashii (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!
5203 | 矛 | ほこ | Spear |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The person who's holding the spear is a little hoe 子. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a spear to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.
5204 | 〜魂 | こん | Spirit |  | When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's  the same meaning as the kanji, too. \n This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!
5205 | 殺菌 | さっきん | Sterilization |  | If you kill bacteria you are performing sterilization. You're killing those bacteria. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.
5206 | 無菌 | むきん | Sterilized | Aseptic | Someplace with nothing amounts of bacteria is sterilized and aseptic. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5207 | 硬い | かたい | Stiff | Hard\n Firm | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stiff? It's stiff, hard, or firm. \n The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!
5208 | 硬直 | こうちょく | Stiffness | Stiffening\n Rigidity | A stiff fix is when you fix something to be stiff, which leads to stiffness or stiffening.\n硬直 commonly describes a person's body becoming stiff in response to stimuli such as discomfort or shock, or after death. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5209 | 卓 | たく | Table | Desk | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
5210 | 卓球 | たっきゅう | Table Tennis | Ping Pong | Table sphere is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's table tennis or ping pong. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.
5211 | 肌触り | はだざわり | The Touch Of | Feel Of\n Texture | The skin touch is  the feeling of touching with your skin. That is the touch of, feel of, or texture of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something! \n The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.
5212 | 潮時 | しおどき | Tidal Hour | The Right Time\n High Time | The tide time is the tidal hour.\nThis word is often used figuratively, as in “the perfect time to act”, especially in reference to quitting something or backing away from a situation. \n The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.
5213 | 襲撃する | しゅうげきする | To Attack | To Assault | Remember how 襲撃 is an assault or attack? This is the verb form, so it's to attack or to assault. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5214 | 澄む | すむ | To Become Clear | To Become Transparent | Something with lucidity is clear. That's why this word is to become clear or to become transparent. \n You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
5215 | 湿る | しめる | To Be Damp | To Be Moist\n To Be Wet | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww. \n You know what's really damp and moist? Sheep men (しめ) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.
5216 | 滅びる | ほろびる | To Be Destroyed | To Be Annihilated | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr. \n "THE HORROR!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about to be destroyed.
5217 | 焦る | あせる | To Be In A Hurry | To Be Impatient\n To Be Anxious | This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is char, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going to be in a hurry and you're going to be impatient. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for rude. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying. \n You're being rude, but you're also being a big ass (あせ) with your impatience.
5218 | 呪う | のろう | To Curse | To Put A Curse On | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means curse, and the verb version is to curse or to put a curse on. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5219 | 稼ぐ | かせぐ | To Earn Income | To Make Money | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earnings and the verb vocab version is to earn income, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be to make money. \n To earn income, you decided to start a car sale. (かせ) "Every car sale, a step to richness!" was your quirky business mantra.
5220 | 翔る | かける | To Fly | To Soar | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means fly, so the verb version means to fly. \n You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!
5221 | 賭ける | かける | To Gamble | To Bet\n To Stake\n To Risk | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gamble and the verb vocab version is to gamble. \n The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.
5222 | 曇る | くもる | To Get Cloudy | To Become Cloudy | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cloudy and the verb vocab version means to get cloudy or to become cloudy. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).
5223 | 狂う | くるう | To Go Mad | To Go Crazy | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lunatic or crazy. The verb version of this is to go mad (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or to go crazy. \n To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!
5224 | 泊める | とめる | To Let Someone Stay Over | To Let Someone Stay The Night | 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this to let someone stay over or to let someone stay the night. \n The reading comes from 泊まる.
5225 | 嫁ぐ | とつぐ | To Marry | To Marry Into | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bride and the verb vocab version is to marry, because you can't really "to bride" someone.\n嫁ぐ is often used when describing how someone has or is going to marry into another family. \n Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like Tots (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).
5226 | 磨く | みがく | To Polish | To Shine\n To Brush Your Teeth | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means polish and the verb vocab version is to polish or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) to brush your teeth. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5227 | 擦る | する | To Rub | To Scrub | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rub and this verb means to rub or to scrub. \n If you're going to rub me like that, I'm going to sue (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The cost  (こす) of your rubbing actions will be high.\n\nSo this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use する for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while こする means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.
5228 | 仕える | つかえる | To Serve |  | Everything we're doing is to serve you, you know.\nThis verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others. \n To serve you well, we've gotten ourselves two cars (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.
5229 | 眺める | ながめる | To Stare At | To Look At\n To View\n To Gaze At | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stare and the verb vocab version is to stare at (or to look at in a very staringish way). \n To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like ながめる's kanji-part reading.
5230 | 引き裂く | ひきさく | To Tear Up | To Tear Off\n To Split | You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're pulling it at the same time, you are going to tear up that thing, or more accurately perhaps to tear off something, since you're pulling. \n The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.
5231 | 苛む | さいなむ | To Torment |  | As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means frustration, and unfortunately frustration tends to torment people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know! \n We all know it's not okay to to torment each other. So how about we all sign a (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

5234 | 包み紙 | つつみがみ | Wrapping Paper |  | A 包み is a bundle or package, and 紙 is paper. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be wrapping paper. \n The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.
5235 | 瞬き | まばたき | A Blink | Blink | A blink is a blink and a wink as well, depending on how many eyes you use. \n A wink is all it takes to get the "Ma butter" (まばた) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.

5238 | 一瞬 | いっしゅん | An Instant | A Moment | One blink is one instant. That is an instant or a moment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5239 | 瞬間 | しゅんかん | An Instant | Instant\n Moment | A blink interval of time is a very short period of time. It's an instant or a moment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5240 | 歳入 | さいにゅう | Annual Revenue |  | Every time a government is years older, it calculates the money that has entered its coffers. 5242 | 万歳 | ばんざい | Banzai | Raising Your Hands\n Hooray | Ten thousand years old! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, banzai! \n The reading isn't the same as 万's normal reading. It's ばん instead of まん. But, since the word "banzai" is so well known, you probably can remember this reading.

5246 | 寮生 | りょうせい | Boarding Student | Boarder | A dormitory student (comes from 学生) is a boarding student or a boarder. This is a student who lives in a dormitory. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5251 | 椅子 | いす | Chair |  | A chair child is for some reason just a chair. Not sure why it's a child, but it is. \n The reading for 子 is weird. It's す, so think about how you sat on this chair and it broke, so you sued (す) the person who made the chair (who happened to be a child).
5252 | 租界 | そかい | Concession | Settlement | The tariff of the world is a concession or settlement. That's just how the world works. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5253 | 幽閉 | ゆうへい | Confinement | Imprisonment | Secluded and closed off, putting you in confinement and imprisonment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5254 | 架設 | かせつ | Construction | Building | The shelf, once established, makes up the construction and building of the building. Just think of a building that's being built. It looks like a little shelf, doesn't it? That's important because this type of construction usually goes over something between two things, like a bridge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5255 | 涼風 | りょうふう | Cool Breeze | Refreshing Breeze | A cool wind is a cool breeze. \n The reading is all on'yomi, and you know how to read 風. You didn't learn 涼's on'yomi (りょう) with the kanji though, so here's a mnemonic to help:\nImagine that a cool breeze is pushing your little row (りょう) boat along, so that you don't need to do any rowing. Ahh, what a nice cool breeze…
5256 | 木綿 | もめん | Cotton |  | Cotton that comes off a tree is still cotton! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own as long as you watch out for 木. It drops the く from もく making this reading just もめん.
5257 | 綿布 | めんぷ | Cotton Cloth | Cotton Material | A cotton cloth is a cotton cloth of cotton material. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5258 | 綿 | わた | Cotton Plant | Cotton Material | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading can be either the kun'yomi or on'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Let's learn the わた reading, though. Just think what (わた) is cotton? What is it? What does it mean? Ask a lot of "what" questions about cotton to yourself.
5259 | 揚げ出し | あげだし | Deep Fried | Agedashi | Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry"? 揚げ出し is a Japanese cooking technique where you deep fry something (usually tofu) and serve it in broth. This word might be easy to remember if you know that "dashi" soup stock is often used to make the agedashi broth. \n The reading is 揚げる and 出す's reading.

5262 | 寮 | りょう | Dormitory | Hostel | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also refer to a hostel. \n This is a word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5263 | 鈍い | にぶい | Dull | Thickheaded | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dull? It's dull. \n To remember the reading, think about how when you're inebriated (にぶ) you need to use a dull knife. The にぶい reading talks about a thing that is dull. For のろい, which refers to a dull mind (someone who's thickheaded). Think about a Norse (のろ) God, the God of dullbrains.

5267 | 歳暮 | せいぼ | End Of The Year | Year End Gift\n End Of Year Gift | Years old of livelihood. 5270 | 眼孔 | がんこう | Eye Socket |  | Your eyeball cavity (hole) is where your eye is held. This is your eye socket. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5271 | 口癖 | くちぐせ | Favorite Phrase | Catchphrase\n Habit Of Saying | A mouth habit is something you say with your mouth a lot. It's a habit. It's your favorite phrase or catchphrase. 5272 | 水泡 | すいほう | Foam | Bubble | Water bubbles are bubbles that come from the water. This is usually in the form of foam, but could also be a bubble.\n水泡 is a literary word, mainly seen in the idiom 水泡に帰す (to come to nothing). This phrase paints a picture of your efforts going down the drain, turning into foam or bubbles in the water, and ultimately disappearing into nothingness. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This thing is a ghost or specter. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5283 | 黙殺 | もくさつ | Ignoring |  | Shut up and kill your talking or I'll kill it for you. I'm not listening to this. I'm ignoring it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5284 | 焦り | あせり | Impatience |  | Remember 焦る, which means "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient"? This is the noun version, which is impatience. \n The reading comes from 焦る.
5285 | 帝政 | ていせい | Imperial Government | Imperialism | Sovereign government and Politics are those who are part of the imperial government. This type of government is imperialism. Of course, back in the day there weren't as many sovereign governments out there, so imperialism is the one that fits the bill in this word's case. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5287 | 墨絵 | すみえ | Ink Painting |  | An ink painting is an ink painting.\n墨絵 refers to artwork created in monochrome, using black sumi ink with a brush on handmade paper. \n The reading is the readings you learned with the kanji.
5288 | 鈍感 | どんかん | Insensitive | Thickheaded\n Obtuse | If you’re too dull to have feeling, you’re insensitive, or thickheaded.\n鈍感 often means someone's not very tuned in to emotions or what's happening around them. It's like they can miss subtle romantic hints or not sense the silent tension in a room. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5289 | 帝 | みかど | Japanese Emperor | Emperor Of Japan | The one true sovereign is the Japanese emperor, a.k.a. the emperor of Japan. On its own, 帝 only refers to him, not to other emperors around the world.\n帝 is a classical term for the emperor in Japan. It's found in works of classical literature, historical novels, or period dramas that are set in feudal Japan. In modern Japanese, the Japanese emperor is called 天皇. \n To remember the reading, think about how the Japanese Emperor, can always pull out his "me card" (みかど) when he's in trouble. It's kind of like how a "trump card" is the one that's above all the others, but with the emperor he's always up there, so it's a "me card" to him. And who's gonna argue with the emperor? Not me.

You can think of it this way: You were barefoot too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you had ashi (はだし) at one point in the past.
