5367 | 掌握 | しょうあく | Grasping | Seizing\n Holding | Manipulate your grip over and over. You have to manipulate it because you're slipping. You're just grasping right now. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5368 | 砂利 | じゃり | Gravel |  | If sand makes a lot of profit, it swells up and becomes gravel. They're like the fat cats of the beach. \n You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou're walking through that big fat gravel, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... jaguar (じゃ)! Run!
5369 | 煎茶 | せんちゃ | Green Tea | Green Leaf Tea\n Sencha | When you roast tea, you get green tea, also known as green leaf teaor sencha.\nIn reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5370 | 帽子 | ぼうし | Hat | Cap | A hat child is a hat or cap. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5371 | 心願 | しんがん | Heartfelt Desire | Heartfelt Wish | The thing your heart requests is what your heart wants. This is your heartfelt desire.\n心願 is often found in the phrase 心願成就 (fulfillment of a heartfelt wish), commonly used in the context of prayer rituals at Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5372 | 〜狩り | がり | Hunting |  | You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (hunting). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing. \n The reading is the same as 狩り, but since it follows another word, it gets rendaku-ed. Here is a mnemonic to help with remembering the rendaku.\nHunting can be girly (がり), if you dress up like a girly hunter.
5373 | 挿入 | そうにゅう | Insertion |  | If you insert and enter something, you are doing insertion to it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5374 | 点滴 | てんてき | Intravenous Drip | IV Drip | Point drips are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an intravenous drip.\nBack in the day this was a way of talking about raindrops, or really any falling drops of water. But nowadays we only use it for IV drips. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5375 | 伊勢 | いせ | Ise |  | The place with Italy force is a place known as Ise. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.
5376 | 塊魂 | かたまりだましい | Katamari Damacy |  | A lump spirit is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game Katamari Damacy. \n The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.
5377 | 欠如 | けつじょ | Lack | Deficiency | You lack likeness to anything out there. You totally lack something that gives you likeness. It's a deficiency, or something. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5378 | 中佐 | ちゅうさ | Lieutenant Colonel | Navy Commander | The middle help in the army or navy is the lieutenant colonel or the navy commander. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5379 | 唇 | くちびる | Lips |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5380 | 愛憎 | あいぞう | Love And Hate |  | If you have love and hate then you have love and hate. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5381 | 下唇 | したくちびる | Lower Lip | Bottom Lip | The bottom lip is your lower lip or bottom lip. \n したくちびる is the vocab reading for 下 and the reading you learned with the kanji for 唇. This is how you'd usually read this word.\nかしん is very technical and it's rarely used outside of scientific writing. If you don't plan to read science papers in Japanese, you can ignore this reading!
5382 | 少佐 | しょうさ | Major | Lieutenant Commander | The few who help are the majors or lieutenant commanders. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5383 | 化粧 | けしょう | Makeup | Cosmetics | Change your face with cosmetics! This is via makeup or, of course, cosmetics. \n The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on makeup. They finish putting it on, and then you say "K, show (けしょう) me!"
5384 | 詐称 | さしょう | Misrepresentation | False Statement | If you lie about your title, the title which represents who you are, then that is a misrepresentation. A false statement. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5385 | 貨幣 | かへい | Money | Currency\n Coinage | The freight of cash comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just money, currency, or coinage. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5386 | 朝霧 | あさぎり | Morning Fog |  | Morning fog is morning fog, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think. \n The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.
5387 | 土塀 | どべい | Mud Wall | Earthen Wall | A soil fence is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a mud wall or an earthen wall. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5388 | 老婆 | ろうば | Old Woman | Elderly Woman | An elderly old woman is just an old woman. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5389 | 親父 | おやじ | One's Father | Middle-Aged Man\n Father | One's parent father is simply just one's father.\nNote that 親父 has a masculine and somewhat vulgar tone to it. It can refer to your own dad, someone else's, or a middle-aged man you're friendly with. When not talking about your own father, you'll want to add a さん at the end, making it 親父さん. \n The reading for this is unfortunately a bit of an exception. 親 uses the kun'yomi おや, and 父 uses the じ reading which you learned with 叔父. You've learned all these readings before, so as long as you remember them, you're good to go. If you don't, check out the mnemonics for these readings on their vocabularies' pages!
5390 | 掌 | てのひら | Palm Of One's Hand | Palm | When you manipulate something, imagine you're doing it with your palm. You use your palm to manipulate the movement, and then you fine tune it further, all with your palm!\nSomething to note here is that you'll typically see palm in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing. \n Where is the palm of one's hand? It's on your 手のhere (てのひら). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was."\nAnother noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.
5391 | 紙幣 | しへい | Paper Money | Notes\n Bills | Paper cash is paper money. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know paper money is made of sheep (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.
5392 | 岳 | たけ | Peak | Mountain | The peak of the mountain is a peak or mountain. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you climb to the top of the peak, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is 竹 (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...
5393 | 可哀想 | かわいそう | Pitiful | Poor\n Pitiable\n Pathetic | A possible pathetic scenario you might imagine is probably not just possibly pathetic. It's downright pitiful and pathetic, for sure. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some pathetic person who lost their home. They may be pitiful but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "Why (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.
5394 | 哀れ | あわれ | Pity | Sorrow\n Grief | If something is pathetic then you should have pity on it. You should also feel a little sorrow and grief for it, because seriously, so pathetic! \n You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel pity for and just think... aww (あわ), that's really pathetic.
5395 | 矛先 | ほこさき | Point Of Spear | Spearpoint\n Brunt | The spear ahead is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the point of spear or spearpoint. \n The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.
5396 | 粉砕 | ふんさい | Pulverization | Smashing | To powder I will smash it! If I do that, it's pulverization and smashing. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5397 | 虹 | にじ | Rainbow |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5398 | 虹色 | にじいろ | Rainbow Colored |  | Rainbow colored things are rainbow colored. \n The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.
5399 | 花柳 | かりゅう | Red Light District |  | The flower willow for some reason is a red light district. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5400 | 爽やか | さわやか | Refreshing | Fresh\n Invigorating\n Eloquent | This is the noun version of the kanji, making it refreshing as well. \n The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!
5401 | 痛恨 | つうこん | Regret | Regretful\n Contrition\n Remorse | A pain grudge is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my regret. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5402 | 休憩 | きゅうけい | Rest | Break\n Recess\n Intermission | A rest rest is a rest. A break. A recess. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5403 | 炊飯器 | すいはんき | Rice Cooker |  | A cook food container is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a rice cooker. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5404 | 砕石 | さいせき | Rubble | Broken Stone | Smashed stone is smashed stone. It's rubble and broken stone. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5405 | 煎餅 | せんべい | Senbei | Rice Cracker | What do you get when you roast mochi? Senbei, a crispy Japanese rice cracker! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help:\nYou sit eating senbei next to a bay (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.
5406 | 尺 | しゃく | Shaku | Japanese Foot | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5407 | 撃墜 | げきつい | Shooting Down | Shooting Down An Aircraft | An attack that causes a crash is when you're shooting down something, usually an aircraft. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5408 | 悲哀 | ひあい | Sorrow | Grief\n Sadness | I am sad and pathetic in how I feel. Such a deep sorrow! Such grief from my sad pathetic feelings. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5409 | 割り箸 | わりばし | Splittable Chopsticks | Splittable Wood Chopsticks | Divideable chopsticks are chopsticks you can split apart. They are splittable chopsticks, almost always made from wood of some kind. \n The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.
5410 | 粘々 | ねばねば | Stickiness | Sticky | Sticky sticky things are really sticky and covered with stickiness. \n The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you never never want to touch something sticky.
5411 | 突如 | とつじょ | Suddenly | All Of A Sudden | When something bears a sudden likeness, we say it happens suddenly, or all of a sudden.\nNote that this word is relatively formal and somewhat literary. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5412 | 詐取 | さしゅ | Swindle | Cheat\n Defraud\n Rip-Off | You use your lie to take what you want. That's when you swindle or cheat someone to get their stuff. How dare you! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5413 | 巻尺 | まきじゃく | Tape Measure | Measuring Tape | A scroll of shaku. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A tape measure! \n The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.
5414 | 畳 | たたみ | Tatami Mat | Tatami | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is tatami mat. The たたみ part, specifically.
5415 | お陰で | おかげで | Thanks To | Because Of | 陰 is a shadow, and adding お to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means thanks to, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out!\nIf that's hard to remember, think about shade helping you out. Perhaps thanks to the shade you were able to survive the heat of the desert. \n The reading comes from the word 陰. Thanks to that other vocab word, you can read this one!
5416 | 黒い霧 | くろいきり | Thick Fog | Black Veil\n Covered Up | A black fog is going to be a really thick fog or black veil that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking. \n The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.
5417 | 擦れる | すれる | To Be Rubbed | To Be Grazed\n To Be Scraped | This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means to be rubbed. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean to be grazed or to be scraped, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall. \n You really don’t want your knee to be grazed. If it happens, you are gonna sue (す). But the cost (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place!\nDepending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.
5418 | 粘る | ねばる | To Be Sticky | To Persevere | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sticky and the verb vocab version is to be sticky. It can also mean to persevere, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around. \n Will I give up? I'll never (ねば) give up! I'll also never unstick from you.
5419 | 歯を磨く | はをみがく | To Brush One's Teeth |  | 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your teeth you are brushing them. That's why this is to brush one's teeth. \n The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.
5420 | 彫る | ほる | To Carve Something | To Engrave Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve and the verb version is to carve something, or to engrave something.\nThis is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects. \n Imagine trying to carve something using a hoe (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.
5421 | 欺く | あざむく | To Deceive | To Swindle\n To Delude | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deceit, so when you're doing deceit, you are going to deceive someone. \n As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, as a moo (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.
5422 | 滴る | したたる | To Drip |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drip and the verb vocab version is to drip. \n To drip drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "sh*t, ta-ta (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.
5423 | 扇ぐ | あおぐ | To Fan |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means folding fan and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means to fan instead. \n Imagine yourself trying to fan yourself with an 青 (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?
5424 | 憎む | にくむ | To Hate | To Detest | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hate and the verb vocab version is to hate or to detest. \n What do you hate and detest more than anything? 肉 (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.
5425 | 恨む | うらむ | To Hold A Grudge |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grudge and the verb vocab version is to hold a grudge. \n Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be you, Ra (うら). You and your dumb sun.
5426 | 澄ます | すます | To Make Something Clear | To Clear Something\n To Strain | 澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you must (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or to make something clear or to clear something.\nThis can also mean to strain when used together with 耳, as in 耳を澄ます, "to strain one's ears". \n The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.
5427 | 湿らせる | しめらせる | To Moisten | To Dampen | Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it to moisten or to dampen. \n The reading is the same as 湿る.
5428 | 憩う | いこう | To Rest | To Relax | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest and the verb vocab version is to rest or to relax. \n I'm going to rest and play some Ico (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.
5429 | 胴 | どう | Torso | Abdomen\n Waist | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5430 | 零す | こぼす | To Spill Something | To Drop Something\n To Shed Tears | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means zero, but the verb vocab version means to spill something or to drop something. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach zero. \n Imagine you're co-boiling (こぼ) water with someone. With the two of you co-boiling, the water is boiling pretty hard. Watch out, though — you're about to spill the hot water everywhere!
5431 | 車掌 | しゃしょう | Train Conductor |  | A car manipulator is someone who manipulates the car. This 車 riffs off of 電車, which is a train, making the train manipulator a train conductor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5432 | 上唇 | うわくちびる | Upper Lip | Top Lip | The above lip is the upper lip. \n The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.
5433 | 眺め | ながめ | View | Scene\n Prospect | 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is view or scene. It's what you're staring at. \n The reading is the same as 眺める.
5434 | 塀 | へい | Wall | Fence | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5435 | 柳 | やなぎ | Willow | Weeping Willow | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The willow you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's yah naggy weeping willow.
5436 | 女権 | じょけん | Women's Rights | Woman's Rights | A woman's rights consist of women's rights.\nThis is a formal word that is often used at the beginning of compounds, such as 女権拡張運動 (movement for the expansion of women's rights). In everyday conversations, you can just say 女性の権利 to talk about women’s rights. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5437 | お嬢さん | おじょうさん | Young Lady | Miss\n Daughter | Adding an お in front and a さん behind miss makes for a very respectful way of addressing ayoung lady. It can also be used to refer to somebody’s daughter in a polite manner.\nNote that older generations tend to use this word to directly address a young woman. But be careful when doing this yourself, as it might come across as overly formal! \n The reading of 嬢 is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!
5438 | 遂行 | すいこう | Accomplishment | Execution | Accomplish and go forth! These are your accomplishments. This is your execution of actions. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5439 | 癖に | くせに | And Yet | Though\n In Spite Of | Even though you have this habit you're still able to win. That's why this is And yet, though, and in spite of. Because, in spite of your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating. \n The reading comes from the word 癖.
5440 | 麻酔 | ますい | Anesthesia | Anaesthesia | A hemp drunkness is when you take some "hemp" and put it into your body so you don't really feel anything anymore. This is anesthesia. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5441 | 畜産 | ちくさん | Animal Husbandry |  | Livestock will give birth to more livestock. You're in the biz of raising livestock, that's why. This is animal husbandry. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5442 | 塗布 | とふ | Application | Coating | Let's paint a cloth's worth of paint on the wall. This is one application or coating of paint. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5443 | 脇 | わき | Armpit | Under One's Arm | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now isn't that a bit wacky (わき)?
5444 | 未遂 | みすい | Attempt |  | I have not yet accomplished anything yet. This is only an attempt, so we'll see how it goes. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5445 | 後ろ盾 | うしろだて | Backing | Support\n Backer\n Supporter | The rear shield is the shield that protects your back. This is your backing or support. So, not a literal shield, but the kind of protection that you want to have anyways. \n The reading comes from 後ろ and 盾 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.
5446 | 盆踊り | ぼんおどり | Bon Festival Dance | Bon Odori\n Lantern Festival Dance | The lantern festival dance is the bon festival dance (or bon odori or lantern festival dance). It's a fun time, be sure to go to one sometime! \n The reading is 盆 plus 躍り put together into one word.
5447 | 鉢 | はち | Bowl | Pot\n Basin | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5448 | 火鉢 | ひばち | Brazier | Hibachi | A fire bowl is something you use to put fire in. It's a brazier. \n The reading is the vocab reading for 火 and the reading you learned for 鉢, rendaku'd.
5449 | 光輝 | こうき | Brightness | Splendor | The sunlight's radiance is that of brightness and splendor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5450 | 迷彩 | めいさい | Camouflage | Camo | Astray coloring is coloring that's all over the place. It's astray all over your clothes. This astray coloring is camouflage. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5451 | 麻 | あさ | Cannabis | Hemp | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means cannabis as well. \n You always smoke your cannabis in the 朝. No other time. Just the 朝.
5452 | 賢い | かしこい | Clever | Intelligent | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of clever? It's clever or intelligent. \n If you're clever enough, you can start up an awesome company that makes tons of cash. A cash co (かしこ).
5453 | 塗装 | とそう | Coating | Painting | With paint I want to attire the wall. Let's put a coating of painting up on the wall. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5454 | 色彩 | しきさい | Color |  | The color coloring is the color of something. \n 色 uses the しき reading (remember 景色?). Use that here with the 彩 kanji reading.
5455 | 返り咲き | かえりざき | Comeback | Second Bloom | The return blossom is when the blossoms return. A second bloom. This is another word for a comeback. \n The readings are the readings from 返る and the kanji 咲. Watch out for the rendaku.
5456 | 矛盾 | むじゅん | Contradiction |  | A spear and a shield. Totally different things. Not at all like each other. A complete contradiction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5457 | 隙 | すき | Crevice | Gap\n Space\n Chance\n Fault\n Room | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5458 | 隙間 | すきま | Crevice | Crack\n Gap\n Opening | A crevice interval is an area with a crevice or crack. \n The reading for 隙 is the one you learned with the kanji and the 間 is the 間に合う reading.
5459 | 培養 | ばいよう | Cultivation | Nurture | Cultivate and foster something. That's cultivation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5460 | 畜生 | ちくしょう | Damn It | Beast\n Son Of A Bitch | The livestock life. The life of a beast! Arghhh, damnit, I hate the life of a beast. Damnit. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5461 | 踊り | おどり | Dance |  | A dance is a dance. \n The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
5462 | 暗闇 | くらやみ | Darkness | The Dark | A dark darkness is a darkness. It's the dark. \n The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both kanji. The reading from 暗い and the reading of the kanji 闇.
5463 | 闇 | やみ | Darkness | The Dark | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5464 | 餓死 | がし | Death From Starvation | Starving To Death | Starve to death is death from starvation... Starving to death. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5465 | 斜め | ななめ | Diagonal | Slanting\n Tilted | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n A diagonal is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a 七 (なな) percent angle is a diagonal, slanting, tilted angle.
5466 | 屈辱 | くつじょく | Disgrace | Humiliation | Yield a humiliation onto your life. What a disgrace. What a humiliation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5467 | 恥辱 | ちじょく | Disgrace | Shame | If you shame and humiliate me, I will have a sense of disgrace, shame. \n The reading from 恥 is the ち reading, a reading you haven't learned yet. To remember this, just think about how the cheese jock is the biggest disgrace to this sports team. He is cheese, after all. He falls apart and smells funny.
5468 | 家畜 | かちく | Domestic Animals | Livestock\n Cattle | House broken livestock are domestic animals / livestock. They're made to live with us in or near our homes. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5469 | 耐久性 | たいきゅうせい | Durability |  | I have the nature of being resistant for a long time. Things that are resistant for a long time have good durability. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5470 | 土俵際 | どひょうぎわ | Edge Of A Sumo Ring | Last Moment\n Critical Moment | A soil sack on the edge. Pretend the sacks are lined up around in a circle. It's the edge of a sumo ring. It can also refer to a last moment or critical moment in time, like the moment before getting pushed out of the ring. \n The first two kanji (土俵) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji 際 uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.

5472 | 電灯 | でんとう | Electric Light | Lamp\n Electric Lamp | An electricity lamp is an electric lamp. Nowadays they're all electricity, though, which means it's a lamp. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

I'm building up a stockpile of reserves, just in case. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5475 | 耐火 | たいか | Fireproof |  | If something is resistant to fire then it is fireproof. Turtles are not this. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5476 | 紛れ | まぐれ | Fluke | Chance | When you're distracted, everything you do is a fluke. You're not focusing, so it all comes down to chance.\nNote that this word is mostly written in kana only! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This uses a different reading than the one you've already learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSomebody was trying to mug (まぐ) you, but you managed to escape by pure chance! Your escape might have just been a fluke, but at least you didn't get mugged!

5487 | 灯り | あかり | Lamp | Light\n Torch | The meaning of this noun is the same as the kanji, lamp. Can also mean light and torch as well, depending on where you herald from. \n The reading is like that of 明るい, which means "bright." At least the あか part is the same. What is a lamp if not 明るい (あか)? Another way to think of it is "what is a bright color?" The color 赤 (あか) is a bright color and would make a sexy lamp.
5488 | 踊り場 | おどりば | Landing | Plateau\n Dance Floor\n Dance Hall | While a dance location can be a location in which you dance, this word actually means landing (as in, a landing between two flights of stairs on a staircase) or plateau (as in, for example, a plateauing economy) most of the time.\nWhile the meaning has changed over time to mostly refer to landings on staircases, it can still be used to mean dance hall or dance floor, although loanwords like ダンスホール are more commonly used these days. \n You know all the readings for this vocab already, just make sure to use the kun'yomi ones!
5489 | 遅咲き | おそざき | Late Flower | Late Blooming | A slow bloom is a bloom that happens late. It's a late flower or late blooming. Important to know if you're going to go do 花見. \n The reading is 遅い and 咲く put together (the same reading you learned from the 咲 kanji). Watch out for the rendaku.

When you think of lava, think about Gandhi, coming out of the lava. He's immune, because he's a robot.

5515 | 脇役 | わきやく | Supporting Actor | Supporting Role\n Minor Role | If you're on armpit duty you're definitely not the lead. You're standing next to the lead's armpit, because you're the supporting actor. You're in a supporting role. \n The reading is 脇's reading and 役's reading, put together.

5517 | 無闇に | むやみに | Thoughtlessly | Unreasonably\n Recklessly\n Absurdly | "Darkness is nothing to worry about," I said thoughtlessly and unreasonably. Of course darkness is worth worrying about. It's darkness! Who knows what is in there! \n The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
5518 | 脅迫 | きょうはく | Threat | Menace | The thing that will threaten and then urge you to do something else is the threat and menace.\nNote that 脅迫 often involves overt and serious threats that may cross legal boundaries. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5519 | 蓄える | たくわえる | To Amass | To Store Up\n To Lay In Stock\n To Grow A Mustache | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means amass and the verb vocab version is to amass.\n蓄える means to gradually accumulate something to store up. So you can use 蓄える for storing up resources or knowledge, or even for growing a mustache or beard! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou need to amass things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly store up lots of things.
5520 | 尽きる | つきる | To Be Used Up | To Be Exhausted\n To Run Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means use up or exhaust, and this verb is to be used up, to be exhausted, or to run out. \n If something is exhausted it's because you used up too (つ) much of it, and now it's all gone.
5521 | 咲く | さく | To Bloom | To Blossom | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blossom or bloom and the verb version is to bloom. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5522 | 彩る | いろどる | To Color Something | To Color | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means coloring so the verb vocab version is to color something, because you're doing coloring. \n You go to color something, painting the coloring all over the wall. Problem is, the coloring is made of ACID. This causes the wall to erode (いろど).
5523 | 炊く | たく | To Cook | To Boil\n To Cook Grains | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cook and the verb vocab version is to cook or to boil. Often it has to do with cooking grains (to cook grains). \n When you cook something, it's like you're attacking (たく) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!
5524 | 培う | つちかう | To Cultivate | To Foster | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cultivate and the verb vocab version means to cultivate. \n You have two cheese cars (つちか) that are growing mold. But that's a good thing, because it's the good kind of cheese mold. So, you cultivate the mold on these two cheese cars, comparing the difference between the two.
5525 | 踊る | おどる | To Dance |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5526 | 耐える | たえる | To Endure | To Withstand | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resistant. If you're resisting things, then you're enduring and withstanding them. That's why this is to endure and to withstand. \n What is it that you have to endure? A barrage of tacos (た), coming at you.
5527 | 零れる | こぼれる | To Get Spilled | To Spill\n To Fall Out\n To Overflow | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to get spilled, to fall out, or to overflow. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.
5528 | 辱める | はずかしめる | To Humiliate | To Embarrass | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means humiliate so the verb vocab version is to humiliate. \n Remember the word 恥ずかしい? It has the same reading as this one, and a similar meaning as well.
5529 | 溶かす | とかす | To Melt Something | To Melt | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means melt and this word means to melt something or to melt. You're doing the melting, and you know it because you are the cause (かす) of the melting. \n The thing that you melted in this situation is your toe (と). Feel your toe getting melted away. Augghh it hurts.
5530 | 塗る | ぬる | To Paint | To Plaster\n To Lacquer\n To Spread | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paint and the verb vocab version is to paint and to plaster and to lacquer. \n Let's put a new (ぬ) layer of paint on the wall. Then we'll plaster it.
5531 | 貼る | はる | To Paste | To Stick | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paste so the verb vocab is to paste (or to stick). \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5532 | 殴る | なぐる | To Punch | To Strike\n To Hit | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means assault. What are some ways to assault a person? How about to punch, to strike, or to hit, to name a few? \n Someone is nagging (なぐ) you and nagging you about something. You can't take it any more, so you turn around to punch them in the face.
5533 | 輝く | かがやく | To Shine | To Glitter\n To Sparkle | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means radiance. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it to shine or to glitter or to sparkle. \n The cog yak is so shiny. It's so shiny that it starts to shine and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.
5534 | 砕く | くだく | To Smash | To Break | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smash and the verb vocab version of the kanji is to smash or to break. \n You want to smash my stuff? That's coo' だ (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.
5535 | 飢える | うえる | To Starve | To Be Starved For\n To Have A Thirst For | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means starve and the verb vocab version is to starve.\nThis is a formal word and it's often used in phrases like 愛情に飢える (to be starved for love) or 知識に飢える (to have a thirst for knowledge). \n When you're about to starve, what do you yearn for? Uni (う), of course! As your hunger intensifies, all you can think of is uni!
5536 | 理不尽 | りふじん | Unreasonable | Irrational | Reason is not exhausted... but what you're asking is unreasonable. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5624 | 勘案 | かんあん | Taking Into Consideration | Giving Consideration | Using our intuition we will come up with a plan. 5625 | 炊ける | たける | To Be Cooked | To Be Boiled\n To Be Done Cooking | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means to be cooked, to be boiled, or to be done cooking. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.
5626 | 劣る | おとる | To Be Inferior To |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inferiority and the verb vocab version is to be inferior to. \n When thinking about cars, an automatic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.
5627 | 潤う | うるおう | To Be Moist | To Be Damp\n To Be Watered | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means watered. When something is watered, it is moist and damp. That's why this verb is to be moist or to be damp or to be watered. \n If you get moist and damp, then you're all (うるお) wet. It's just how it is.
5628 | 覆る | くつがえる | To Be Overturned | To Be Reversed\n To Be Retracted\n To Topple Over | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means capsize but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going to be overturned. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink! \n Of all the ideas that need to be overturned, it's the ones from the 靴 guy (くつがえ). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over our entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like to be retracted, 靴 guy.
5629 | 砕ける | くだける | To Be Smashed | To Be Shattered\n To Break | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThis is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be smashed, to be shattered, or to break (for things like waves and tension!). \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.\nLucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 砕く.
5630 | 浸る | ひたる | To Be Soaked In | To Be Submerged\n To Be Flooded | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like to be soaked in or to be submerged or to be flooded. \n What is soaked and submerged in water (that shouldn't be)? It is your heater (ひた). It's all soaked and doesn't work anymore :(
5631 | 煮る | にる | To Boil Something | To Simmer Something | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nThe kanji itself means boil and the verb vocab version is to boil something. This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you put something into a pot and boil it up. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5632 | 謀る | はかる | To Conspire | To Plot | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conspire and the verb vocab version is to conspire or to plot. \n A group of hackers (はか) are getting together and trying to conspire and plot to take down the mainframe! Those hackers!
5633 | 衰える | おとろえる | To Decline | To Decay\n To Become Weak\n To Wither | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decline and the verb vocab version is to decline. \n You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy auto rope (おとろ), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.
5634 | 挿入する | そうにゅうする | To Insert |  | 挿入 is "insertion" so the verb version is to insert. \n The reading comes from 挿入, so if you know that you can insert this reading into your memory no problem.
5635 | 隔てる | へだてる | To Isolate | To Partition\n To Separate | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means isolate and the verb vocab version is to isolate or to partition or to separate. You get the idea, anyways. \n Why did you have to isolate him from the rest of the soccer players? Because all he could do was headers (へだ) and that was getting pretty dangerous. He would head everything in his reach. He was going crazy with headers. He had to be isolated!
5636 | 一蹴する | いっしゅうする | To Kick | To Reject\n To Flatly Reject\n To Brush Aside\n To Easily Beat | Giving one kick is certainly an effective (if brutal) way to flatly reject or to brush aside something or someone. That one kick can also be used to easily beat anyone. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.  First up, notice that いち changes to いっ. And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji 蹴 (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you're planning to flatly reject someone, one kick is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your shoe (しゅう) on first.
5637 | 蹴る | ける | To Kick | To Reject | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kick so the verb version is to kick. \n This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.
5638 | 刈り取る | かりとる | To Mow | To Reap\n To Harvest | If you prune and take from what you pruned, you're going to mow or to reap or to harvest whatever it is you're pruning. \n The reading is the reading you learned with 刈 and the reading from the vocab 取る.
5639 | 慌てる | あわてる | To Panic | To Hurry\n To Rush\n To Be Upset | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means confused or bewildered but this is usually just used when someone starts to panic. They're so confused and bewildered that they try to hurry through things. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.
5640 | 哀れむ | あわれむ | To Pity | To Have Mercy On | If something is pathetic then you should try to pity that thing. \n Awww (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.
5641 | 刈る | かる | To Prune | To Mow\n To Cut | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prune and the verb vocab version is to prune (or to mow or to cut). \n The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
5642 | 悟る | さとる | To Realize |  | If you have comprehension, then you are probably going to realize something about something else. Comprehension leads to realization, after all. \n You realized something so amazing that you couldn't believe it. That comprehension, wow! The realization was so big that you sat (さと) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.
5643 | 紫外線 | しがいせん | Ultraviolet Rays |  | The purple outside line is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are ultraviolet rays (the lines are the rays). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5644 | 一概に | いちがいに | Unconditionally | As A Rule | We're moving towards one approximation. It used to be more approximations, but now it's just one, and because it's just one it's not really an approximation anymore. It's unconditionally set. It's set as a rule. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5645 | 価 | あたい | Value | Price | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n価 refers to the monetary value or the price of goods in a transaction. Although it's somewhat old-fashioned and less common these days, you may still see it used in advanced phrases like 価をつける (to set a price) or 一文の価もない (not even worth a penny).\nNote that あたい can also refer to a numerical value in mathematics, such as the value a variable or function takes, but it's more commonly written with the kanji 値 in this use. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great value and price. Wait, what is? A tie (あたい). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.
5646 | 剛健 | ごうけん | Vigor | Vigour\n Virility | When you are sturdy and healthy you are full of vigor and virility. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5647 | 誓い | ちかい | Vow | Oath | This looks like an adjective, but it's actually a noun. This word is the same as the kanji meaning: vow (or oath). \n This has the same reading as 近い (ちかい). Just think about how when you're making a vow or oath, you become closer to the thing or person you're vowing to. You belong to them, in a way, which is why you become close (近い).
5648 | 誓約 | せいやく | Vow | Pledge\n Oath\n Covenant | A vow promise is the promise that you made with your vow. It's the oath you swear to keep! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5649 | 陛下 | へいか | Your Majesty | His Majesty\n Her Majesty | Your highness I am so below you because your majesty is so great and amazing! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5650 | 唐突 | とうとつ | Abrupt | Unexpected\n Sudden | A sudden stab is abrupt and unexpected. Quick, dodge!!\n唐突 describes sudden actions or events that catch people off guard. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5651 | 帳簿 | ちょうぼ | Account Book | Register\n Ledger | A notebook that is also a record book is an account book or register, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5652 | 巧い | うまい | Adept | Skillful\n Clever | You're so adept! That makes you adept at that thing. Skillful and clever are other ways to do it too. \n Remember 旨い, which means "delicious"? Remember how it also means "skillful" and "clever"? It's the same with this word, and the reading is the same as well.
5653 | 鰐 | わに | Alligator | Crocodile | The great alligator! This can mean both alligator or crocodile, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure. \n The reading is a reading you've known your whole life. It's like you were born with the reading, whispering in your ear, ready to emerge at just the right moment... and that moment is now.
5654 | 古墳 | こふん | Ancient Tomb | Kofun | An old tomb is an ancient tomb. They're mostly from the Kofun period, and indeed that's where the period gets its name. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5655 | 伯母 | おば | Aunt |  | Who is the chief mother? That's your aunt. And this aunt is the older sister of your mom or dad because she is the chief mother. An aunt who is a younger sister of your parent is 叔母, which is another word for "aunt" you already know! \n The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all.
5656 | 銘柄 | めいがら | Brand | Make | The inscription's pattern shows what brand or make this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc. \n This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second. Luckily, you've learned them both already so you should be able to slap them together and know the reading of this word!
5657 | 偶然 | ぐうぜん | By Chance | Unexpectedly\n Coincidence | Accidentally but naturally (as in nothing was set up artificially before). So the accident was a true, natural accident. This kind of accident is something that happens by chance, or unexpectedly. In other words, a coincidence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5658 | 搬出 | はんしゅつ | Carry Out |  | Transport and exit these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to carry out. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5659 | 騎兵 | きへい | Cavalry |  | A horse riding soldier is a member of the cavalry. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5660 | 洞穴 | どうけつ | Cave | Den | A cave hole is a cave or den. \n The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?
5661 | 洞 | ほら | Cave | Den | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Hoe Ra (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.
5662 | 翻意 | ほんい | Change One's Mind | Change Your Mind | When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5663 | 伯 | はく | Chief | Count\n Earl | The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another. \n The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.
5664 | 風邪 | かぜ | Cold | Common Cold | A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold. \n Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.
5665 | 彩り | いろどり | Coloring | Color Scheme\n Makeup | This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring. \n The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色 dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.
5666 | 漫才 | まんざい | Comic Dialogue | Comedy Double Act | A comic talent! And not just one, but two comic talents, because this means a comic dialogue or a comedy double act.\nMore specifically, 漫才 refers to a double act that features a "funny man" (ボケ) and "straight man" (ツッコミ) in a comic dialogue routine. 漫才 is one of the most popular forms of comedy in Japan. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5667 | 訂正 | ていせい | Correction | Revision | When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5668 | 〜把 | わ | Counter For Bundles | Counter for Bunches | The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my! \n Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for walrus (わ)!
5669 | 法廷 | ほうてい | Court | Courtroom | The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5678 | 堤 | つつみ | Embankment | Bank\n Dike | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These 包み (つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!
5679 | 興奮 | こうふん | Excitement | Stimulation | My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact! \n The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to こういち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.
5680 | 殴り合い | なぐりあい | Fistfight | Fist Fight | Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got punches that have come together with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a fistfight. \n The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.
5681 | 無駄 | むだ | Futility | Uselessness\n Pointlessness | Nothing but burdensome. That's all you get out of doing this task. The futility of it is ridiculous. The uselessness is huge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5682 | 下駄 | げた | Geta | Japanese Wooden Clogs | Look below you. These things carry your burdensome weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically geta, or Japanese wooden clogs. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well. \n The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.
5683 | 鬱陶しい | うっとうしい | Gloomy | Depressing\n Annoying | Gloom pottery is... well, it's gloomy and depressing!\nThis word can also mean annoying. If something or someone always makes you feel gloomy, you'll probably think it's annoying, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.
5684 | 鬱気 | うっき | Gloomy Mood | Feeling Downcast\n Gloom | A gloomy energy has filled the room. This puts you in a gloomy mood. You are now feeling downcast.\nThis word is formal, so you'll mostly just see it in literature. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.
5685 | 把握 | はあく | Grasp | Understand | Using the grasp meaning of 把 and combining it with grip, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. 5686 | 墳墓 | ふんぼ | Grave | Tomb | A tomb grave is a grave... or it could be a tomb. Or maybe both. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5687 | 麻布 | あさぬの | Hemp Cloth | Linen | A hemp cloth is a hemp cloth. \n The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

5689 | 空洞 | くうどう | Hollow | Cavity\n Cave | A sky cave is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a hollow, but can also refer to a cavity. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5696 | 皇后 | こうごう | Japanese Empress |  | The emperor empress is the emperor's wife. 5697 | 壮大 | そうだい | Magnificent | Grand\n Epic | It's so robust and big! Things like this are magnificent, grand, and epic! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
