5699 | 連峰 | れんぽう | Mountain Range |  | Take along this summit and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a mountain range! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5700 | 桑原 | くわばら | Mulberry Field | Kuwabara | A mulberry field is a mulberry field.\nBased on an old belief that lightening does not strike mulberry fields, 桑原 (often recited twice, as in "桑原桑原") can also be used as a charm to ward off undesirable events, though it's pretty old-fashioned.\nApart from that use, 桑原 now mainly refers to the family name Kuwabara, like one of the main protagonists of the anime and manga series 幽遊白書. \n These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead:\nYou know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!
5701 | 駄目 | だめ | Not Good | Hopeless\n Cannot\n Not Allowed | If something is burdensome to the eye (when you look at it), you know that that thing is not good or hopeless. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean not allowed. Parents say this to their kids all the time. \n The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.
5702 | 偶に | たまに | Occasionally | Once In A While | Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while.\nAlso note that this word is usually written in hiragana. You'll only occasionally see it in kanji. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nOccasionally Tamara (たま), the local ball girl, will take a break from her duties. But it's really only once in a while, because Tamara is such a hard worker.
5703 | 生涯 | しょうがい | One's Lifetime | One's Career | A life horizon is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is one's lifetime, though it could also refer to one's career. Basically, at the end of it something dies. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5704 | 軌道 | きどう | Orbit | Trajectory | A rut in the road is for some reason an orbit or trajectory. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a trajectory that will send you into orbit. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5705 | 仰々しい | ぎょうぎょうしい | Pompous | Exaggerated | You look up to someone... twice. That's too many times that you're looking up to someone. They must be pretty amazing for that to happen. Really, though, you're being fooled. This person is pompous and exaggerated. So you think they're cool, but really they're pretending to be more than they are. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.
5706 | 壮年 | そうねん | Prime Of Life |  | Your robust years are the best years of your life! This is the prime of life. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5707 | 表彰 | ひょうしょう | Public Acknowledgement | Public Recognition\n Commendation | You want people to express how they feel about you in a clear manner, so you demand they give you public acknowledgement. You want clear, concise public recognition for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5708 | 公告 | こうこく | Public Notice | Public Announcement | A public announcement is a public notice.\n公告 looks and sounds a lot like 広告, but the meanings are different. You might remember 広告 is for advertisements, but 公告 here is for the kind of official statements that companies or governments put out for the public, especially shareholders, creditors, or other stakeholders.\nYou can remember 公告 is a public notice because the kanji for "public" is 公, and it's not covered by a canopy like the other one. It's uncovered, all out in the open for everyone to see — public! \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5709 | 検疫 | けんえき | Quarantine |  | We have to examine you during this epidemic... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a quarantine, sorry about that. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5710 | 諮問 | しもん | Question | Enquiry | I need to consult you on this problem, if I could. I have a question / enquiry I'd like to ask you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5711 | 輝き | かがやき | Radiance |  | If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be radiance. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering. \n The reading comes from 輝く.
5712 | 殴り込み | なぐりこみ | Raid |  | An assault into a place is a raid.\n殴り込み usually means a raid by gang members or delinquents, where they barge into someone's home or enemy territory to start a fight. \n The reading comes from the word 殴る and the kanji 込.
5713 | 名簿 | めいぼ | Register Of Names | List Of Names\n Roll | A name record book is a book that contains names. That is a register of names or a list of names. Is your name on the list? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5714 | 信仰 | しんこう | Religious Faith |  | I believe and look up to a higher power, for I have religious faith. \n The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is こういち.
5715 | 〜亭 | てい | Restaurant | Traditional Japanese Restaurant\n Inn\n Pavilion\n Tea House | If you see the kanji restaurant attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a restaurant, especially a traditional Japanese restaurant. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like inns, those traditional pavilions you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and tea houses. \n The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
5716 | 改訂版 | かいていばん | Revised Edition |  | The renewed and revised edition of something is the revised edition. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5717 | 律動 | りつどう | Rhythm |  | The law of movement is governed by rhythm. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm.\nNote that リズム is a much more common word to use for "rhythm," but you may see the kanji version sometimes in formal writing. One thing you will see more often is 律動的 which means "rhythmic." \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5718 | 騎馬 | きば | Riding A Horse | Mounted\n Equestrian | A horse riding horse is what you need for riding a horse.\nThis is a formal word and it’s typically used at the beginning of compounds where you'll see it translated as things like mounted, as in "mounted police," or equestrian, as in “equestrian peoples.” It's working like an adjective there, but it's still a noun in Japanese. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5719 | 壮行 | そうこう | Send-Off | Farewell | You want to make someone feel robust when they go away somewhere, so you give them a send-off. It's just a nice way to say farewell!\n壮行 is usually for celebratory send-offs and appears in words like 壮行会 (farewell party) or 壮行式 (pep rally). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5720 | 配偶者 | はいぐうしゃ | Spouse | Partner | Distribute yourself accidentally to someone. That person ended up becoming your spouse. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5721 | 奮起 | ふんき | Stirring | Rousing Oneself | I'm stirred up causing me to wake up. I'm stirring and rousing oneself. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5722 | 峰 | みね | Summit | Peak\n Ridge | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be peak or ridge. \n Look up at the summit. It's such a mean (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.
5723 | 仰天 | ぎょうてん | Taken Aback | Amazed\n Horrified\n Flabbergasted | I look up to heaven, and I am taken aback and amazed by it. It's just so amazing. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5724 | 遂げる | とげる | To Accomplish | To Achieve\n To Carry Out | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accomplish and the verb vocab version is to accomplish. \n Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky toe (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.
5725 | 煮える | にえる | To Be Boiled | To Be Cooked | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.\nYou already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means to be boiled or to be cooked. \n Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!
5726 | 翻る | ひるがえる | To Billow | To Flutter\n To Suddenly Change | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means flip, the verb vocab version is to billow or to flutter, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean to suddenly change your mind, or your attitude, etc. \n For something to billow and to flutter, you'll need to ask the here guy (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.
5727 | 灯る | ともる | To Burn | To Be Lighted\n To Be Lit\n To Be Burning | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lamp, so the verb version is to burn or to be lit. Just like what you'd do with a lamp. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho wanted the candle to be lit? Tom (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.
5728 | 諮る | はかる | To Consult With | To Discuss\n To Confer | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consult and the verb vocab version is to consult with or to discuss. \n You need to consult with a hacker (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.
5729 | 漂う | ただよう | To Drift | To Waft | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drift and the verb vocab version is to drift or to waft. \n You're going to drift away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "ta-da yo-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.
5730 | 尽くす | つくす | To Exhaust Something | To Run Out\n To Do To Exhaustion\n To Devote Oneself | 尽きる is "to be exhausted". 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it to exhaust something or to run out. It can also mean to devote oneself to a certain cause. \n The reading comes from 尽きる.
5731 | 仰ぐ | あおぐ | To Look Up At | To Look Up To | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look up to and the verb vocab version is to look up at or to look up to. \n Personally, I look up to the color 青 (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.
5732 | 溶ける | とける | To Melt | To Dissolve\n To Thaw | 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける to melt (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting). \n The reading comes from 溶かす.
5733 | 悔やむ | くやむ | To Regret | To Mourn\n To Lament | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means regret and the verb vocab version is to regret or to mourn. \n The reading comes from 悔しい.
5734 | 貯える | たくわえる | To Save | To Save Up\n To Set Aside | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to save up.\n貯える means to set something aside for future needs or emergencies, like saving money or storing water. \n This shares a reading with 蓄える, which makes sense, as the meanings of them are very close to each other! If you’re not sure you remember the reading, here’s the mnemonic once more to help you remember it:\nYou need to save up things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly save up lots of things.
5735 | 脅す | おどす | To Threaten |  | Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means threaten and the verb vocab version is to threaten. \n I'm going to threaten you with your life if you have a bad odor (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.
5736 | 軌跡 | きせき | Track | Trajectory\n Trace\n Path One Has Taken | Rut traces left in the road are tracks that mark the trajectory of a vehicle’s wheels.\nThis can also be used figuratively to refer to leaving or following some sort of trace, or to describe someone’s or something’s trajectory, among other things. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5737 | 翻訳 | ほんやく | Translation |  | Flip the translation of a word from one language to another. That is the translation of that word (or phrase, etc). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5738 | 運搬 | うんぱん | Transport | Carriage | To carry you and transport you. That's a form of transport. Could also be a carriage, which is also a form of transport. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
5739 | 搬送 | はんそう | Transportation |  | Things that transport and send you places are forms of transportation.\n搬送 is most often used in medical contexts to refer to the transportation of patients. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5740 | 伯父 | おじ | Uncle |  | Who is the chief father? That's your uncle. And this uncle is the older brother of your mom or dad because he is the chief father. An uncle who is a younger brother of your parent is 叔父, which is another word for "uncle" you already know! \n The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all.
5741 | 邪 | よこしま | Wicked | Evil | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being wicked. Evil, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the 横島 (よこしま).
5742 | 淀川 | よどがわ | Yodogawa |  | The eddy river isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about Yodogawa. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info. \n The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.
5743 | 慈愛 | じあい | Affection | Kindness\n Love | When you have mercy upon those you love it's called affection. You end up doing things out of the kindness of your heart because they mean a lot to you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5744 | 又 | また | Again | And Also\n Or | The meaning of this word and the meaning of the kanji are the same: Again!\nThis is a very common word, but it's almost always written in kana in casual situations. However, it's often written in kanji in formal contexts, such as official paperwork and legal documents. You'll also see it in some literature, particularly stuff that was written around the time of Miyazawa Kenji and Natsume Soseki. \n The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You hopefully won't have to learn it... again.
5745 | 耕地 | こうち | Arable Land |  | Plowed land is called arable land. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5746 | 喚起 | かんき | Awaken | Rouse\n Evoke\n Excite | If you scream wake up! at someone you can bet they're going to awaken. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably rouse them. They'll probably be mad at you though. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5747 | 浦 | うら | Bay | Inlet | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nThat said, it's mostly used as a standalone word meaning "bay" in classical literature. Nowadays, it comes up most in place names, like the port Tagonoura (田子の浦) and the city of Urayasu (浦安市). \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5748 | 血族 | けつぞく | Blood Relative |  | Those sharing blood within a tribe are blood relatives.\nThis is a formal term often used in legal matters related to inheritance or insurance claims. In fiction it’s sometimes applied to vampire bloodlines and other supernatural families. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5749 | 沸点 | ふってん | Boiling Point |  | The point at which something starts to boil is the boiling point. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5750 | 瓶 | びん | Bottle | Jar | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5751 | 瓶詰 | びんづめ | Bottling | Bottled | What's stuffed in the bottle? Jam you bottled for later! How could you forget? \n This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 瓶 and the kun'yomi reading for 詰 that you learned when you learned 詰める. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too! Just remember that 詰 is taking the め from 詰める with it in this word too. You can't see it, but it's there.
5752 | 勘定 | かんじょう | Calculation | Counting\n Allowance\n Payment\n Bill\n Check | When you use your intuition to determine the amount of something, you'll end up doing the calculations in your head. You do the same thing when it's time to pay your bill at dinner too: just determine the amount in your head, go with your intuition, and all should be good. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, 定 uses a reading you didn’t learn, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you're having trouble with the calculation of your bill, just call Joe (じょう)! He’s surprisingly good with numbers, so whenever you’re lost at the restaurant table, just give him a quick call.

These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5760 | 耕作 | こうさく | Cultivation | Farming | Plow the earth to make it ready for cultivation and farming. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5761 | 乾燥 | かんそう | Dehydration | Dryness | Even something dry will dry up more if it's got dehydration. There's a lot of dryness going on here. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5762 | 洗濯粉 | せんたくこ | Detergent |  | Wash wash powder is the detergent you put in the wash you make sure your clothes are washed well. Detergent used to only be available in powder form back in the old days, and it still can be, so this is for that good powdery stuff.\nNote that this word sounds a bit old-fashioned. To talk about laundry detergent in general, 洗濯洗剤 is more common nowadays. \n This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 粉. You already learned this reading for 粉 when you learned the word 小麦粉. If you can remember that, you should know the readings for this one too!
5763 | 郡 | ぐん | District | County | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5764 | 洗濯屋 | せんたくや | Dry Cleaners | Laundromat | The wash wash shop is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the dry cleaners! They wash your clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice. \n This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!
5765 | 枯渇 | こかつ | Drying Up | Depletion\n Exhaustion | Something that will wither and dry up ends up doing exactly that, drying up. And as it dries up, there's less and less of it until there's nothing left. This is called depletion!\nThis word is often used to describe situations where natural resources are getting used up and running out. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 渇 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf all of your plants are drying up you should just give them to your cats (かつ). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.
5766 | 愛媛県 | えひめけん | Ehime Prefecture |  | The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture. \n This reading is a little messy. This reading for 愛 is an exception, 媛 uses the kun'yomi reading ひめ, and 県 uses the on'yomi reading けん. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for 愛:\nIf you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (え). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"
5767 | 空き瓶 | あきびん | Empty Bottle |  | A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle. \n The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for 空 when you learned 空き缶. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!
5768 | 従業 | じゅうぎょう | Engaging In Work | Working\n Employment | You must obey your business. When you're in this situation, you’re engaging in work.\nThis is most commonly used in the compounds 従業員 (employee) and 従業者 (worker). You might also come across other forms, such as 従業する, but these are generally found in formal writing. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5769 | 解釈 | かいしゃく | Explanation | Interpretation | Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5770 | 釈明 | しゃくめい | Explanation | Vindication | An explanation that's bright is just a really clear and well developed explanation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5771 | 農耕 | のうこう | Farming | Agriculture | Farming with a plow is still farming. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5772 | 脂肪 | しぼう | Fat | Grease\n Blubber | Something that's both fat and obese has even more fat on it than you first thought. Like the blubber on a really big whale. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5773 | 蛇口 | じゃぐち | Faucet | Tap | This isn't a literal snake's mouth, but rather a faucet. They do kind of have a resemblance though, just think about how the shape of a faucet kind of resembles that of a snake, with water coming out of its mouth. \n This one's a little unique, as it uses on'yomi for 蛇, and kun'yomi (which gets rendaku'd) for 口. You didn't learn this reading for 蛇, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEvery time you try to drink from the faucet, you get viciously attacked by a jaguar (じゃ). Trying to drink from the faucet has become a fight for life and death. You just know the jaguar is hiding right there behind the faucet, guarding it.
5774 | 柔軟 | じゅうなん | Flexible | Pliable | A gentle and soft thing will be really flexible and pliable. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5775 | 四隅 | よすみ | Four Corners |  | Four corners are four corners! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.
5776 | 偉い | えらい | Great | Excellent\n Admirable\n Remarkable | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of greatness? Great! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (えら). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

You should be able to read this on your own.
5780 | 軟禁 | なんきん | House Arrest |  | Soft prohibition isn't going to be as bad as jail or prison. They went soft on you, so you're only under house arrest. That's not so bad, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5781 | 慌ただしい | あわただしい | Hurried | Hasty\n Busy\n Hectic\n Frantic | This is a single kanji with an い all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. Confused is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already hurried, busy, and things were hectic. So this adjective is what causes your confusion. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!
5782 | 焦燥 | しょうそう | Impatience | Uneasy\n Irritation | If you want to char fish for dinner it will dry up because of your own impatience. Charring fish takes time and if you're too uneasy and shove it too far in the fire it will dry out, burn, and get gross. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5783 | 内因 | ないいん | Internal Cause | Internal Factor\n Endogenous Factor | The inside cause is an internal cause. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me.\nThis word is mostly used in the fields of medicine and psychology. You’ll often see it as 内因性, which is a technical term used to talk about factors that originate within a person or an organism. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
5784 | 法規 | ほうき | Laws | Regulations | Laws are standard in society. You must have laws and regulations in society.\n法規 is a formal term commonly used in legal and bureaucratic contexts. In everyday conversation, people are more likely to use simpler terms, such as 法律 for laws or 規則 for rules and regulations. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

5801 | 律動的 | りつどうてき | Rhythmical | Rhythmic | Rhythm is 律動, but by adding a 的 in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it rhythmical or rhythmic.\nNote that リズミカル and テンポのいい are much more common words to use for "rhythmical" and “rhythmic” respectively, but you may sometimes see 律動的 in formal writing. \n The reading is the same as 律動. The 的 part you should also be able to read by now.

You should be able to read this on your own. Yay for easy names!

5813 | 世界恐慌 | せかいきょうこう | The Great Depression |  | 世界 means "world" and 恐慌 means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to The Great Depression. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. 5814 | 脅し | おどし | Threat | A Threat | The kanji is threat and the noun version (here) is threat or a threat.\nCurious about the difference between 脅し and 脅迫? Both involve threats or intimidation, but the key distinction is the level of severity. 脅し is generally associated with milder forms of intimidation and coercion, while 脅迫 entails more direct and serious threats that may even break the law. \n Think about a threat being sent to you. It's in the form of bad odor (おど). Yuck, what a nasty way to send a threat.
5815 | 沸く | わく | To Boil | To Grow Hot\n To Get Excited | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (わ). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat its yummy walrus flesh is to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.
5816 | 召す | めす | To Call | To Take\n To Wear | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to call, as in calling someone over.\n召す is an honorific verb, so it's used to talk about the actions of social higher-ups. 召す suggests the image of a superior who summons someone or something to themselves, hence the main meaning to call. But it can also be a polite way to say to take, like when they take a meal or a drink, and to wear when talking about their clothes. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf a noble decides to call you over, don’t look them in the 目 (め). That's super rude! To show respect when you're called, turn away your 目.
5817 | 覆う | おおう | To Cover | To Hide\n To Conceal | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "おお!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you おお at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. They're always roasting coffee beans and the like. That's how they stay so alert.

They're infesting your home now and you don't know what to do! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5837 | 綾乃 | あやの | Ayano |  | This is a design from Ayano. Do you know an Ayano who's good at designing things? A couple creative Ayanos include traditional Okinawan folk singer and sanshin player Uema Ayano (上間 綾乃), and author Takeda Ayano (武田 綾乃) who won the Yoshikawa Eiji Literary Newcomer Award in 2021. \n This name uses the readings that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
5838 | 擁立 | ようりつ | Backing | Support | Stand behind someone and embrace them. That's how you show them you're backing and supporting them. Do this to your local politicians. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5839 | お風呂 | おふろ | Bath |  | Let the wind in from the window above your bath so the water is cool enough for you to take a bath! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. This isn't the same on'yomi reading you learned for 風, though. It's a little different: ふ. If you're taking a bath you'd be a fool (ふ) to bring food in there. Drop the う or you'll end up as soup!
5840 | 封鎖 | ふうさ | Blockade | Freezing | A sealed chain won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a blockade. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them freezing your account! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5841 | 綾取り | あやとり | Cat's Cradle |  | One design that you can take anywhere with you is cat's cradle, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns. \n This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji.
5842 | 陥没 | かんぼつ | Cave In | Collapse\n Sinking\n Depression | A cave in where everyone dies is still a cave in, just a really sad one. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5843 | 鎖 | くさり | Chain | Chains | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe best way to break out of the chains life puts on you is to put on a cool sari (くさり). A cool sari will remind you where you come from. Who your family is. And how beautiful you look. Cast off those chains and put on a cool sari!
5844 | 連鎖 | れんさ | Chain | Chaining\n Connection | If you take along a chain with you it's still a chain, it's just moving somewhere new. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5845 | 慢性 | まんせい | Chronic |  | If it's in your nature to ridicule people, it will become a chronic problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5846 | 陳腐 | ちんぷ | Cliched | Stale\n Hackneyed | If you keep exhibiting the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to rot and sound cliched to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get stale, do you?! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for ふ becoming ぷ.
5847 | 閉鎖 | へいさ | Closing | Closure\n Shutdown\n Lockout\n Unsociable | A closed chain lets everyone know that a building or store is closing for good. It's got to lockout everyone so they won't try to get in anymore. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5848 | 冷遇 | れいぐう | Cold Reception | Inhospitality | When you are given cool treatment it's called a cold reception or inhospitality. This sucks. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5849 | 制覇 | せいは | Conquest | Domination\n Mastery | Those with leadership who want control will set out on missions of conquest and strive for world domination! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5850 | 恒常 | こうじょう | Constancy | Constant\n Unchanging | Keeping things constant and normal ensures constancy.\n恒常 is a formal word used to describe something that remains constant and unchanging. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5851 | 大輔 | だいすけ | Daisuke | Taifu\n Osuke | Who's a big help? That'll be Daisuke!\nFamous Daisukes include film director and screenwriter Itō Daisuke (伊藤 大輔), figure skater Takahashi Daisuke (髙橋 大輔), and actor and singer Namikawa Daisuke (浪川 大輔). \n This name uses the on'yomi for 大 and the nanori for 輔. You learned both of these with the kanji, so that should be a big help.\nNote: Historically, this name can be read たいふ or おおすけ, as is the case for Heian period poet 伊勢大輔, whose name can be read either いせのたいふ or いせのおおすけ. In modern contexts, you'll only need to know だいすけ though, not to worry!
5852 | 欠陥 | けっかん | Defect | Fault\n Deficiency\n Deformity | If there is a cave in because it was lacking something that means there was a defect or a fault in there somewhere. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5853 | 遭難 | そうなん | Disaster | Shipwreck\n Accident\n Being Stranded | If you encounter something difficult it's going to result in disaster. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a shipwreck! Ick! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5854 | 没 | ぼつ | Discard | Reject\n Death | When a plant or an animal dies you have to discard it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house after death, that's weird. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5855 | 抱擁 | ほうよう | Embrace | Hug | An embrace and a hug are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to embrace and hug people! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 抱 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho gives the best hugs in the world? Harry Houdini (ほう)! He knows what it's like to be hugged too tightly because he's always in straight jackets. So his hugs are nice and gentle. Just the way you like them!
5856 | 遭遇 | そうぐう | Encounter |  | It doesn't matter what kind of treatment you get on your encounter with new people because it's the encounter itself that's scary! Don't worry, people are just people. They shouldn't make you nervous. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5857 | 我慢 | がまん | Endurance | Perseverance\n Tolerance\n Patience\n Self Control | I get ridiculed a lot, but it makes me have really strong endurance. You should be able to read this on your own.

You should be able to read this on your own.

His dog is also named Ken, because that's how Ken and Ken do things.
5873 | 没頭 | ぼっとう | Immersing Oneself | Immersing Yourself\n Immerse Oneself\n Immerse Yourself | All the extra things in your head die when you immerse yourself in one thing. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.
5874 | 埋没 | まいぼつ | Implantation | Burial\n Embedding | You bury things into people who look like they've died. It's called implantation. They're not really dead though. This is surgery and they'll wake up and go about their lives with whatever that thing was that you put in them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 埋 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWait that's not a person you're embedding things into. It's a bunch of mice (まい). I guess that's okay. Just don't go putting the mice into people. That's... don't cross that line.

You should be able to read this on your own.

5882 | 偏狭 | へんきょう | Narrow Minded | Intolerance | Narrow biased people are considered to be narrow minded and they're usually disliked for their intolerance of other cultures and anything unfamiliar to them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. It's where all the tour guides say to go, and they're too narrow minded to listen to anyone else. So they see Kyoto and head back home right away without seeing anywhere else.
5883 | 鎖国 | さこく | National Isolation | Exclusion Of Foreigners | A country in chains is under a national isolation policy. They're bound and they can't visit anywhere else. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5884 | 怠慢 | たいまん | Negligence | Procrastination\n Carelessness | You ignore everything around you because you are lazy with laziness. That's too much lazy for one person so you're prone to negligence and procrastination. You definitely can't manage to take care of things when you're this lazy. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5885 | 一貫 | いっかん | One Piece Of Sushi | Consistency\n Integration | One sushi counter is counting one piece of sushi. This can also mean consistency, which makes sense if you think about piece of sushi—each one should be as consistent as the last! Linked to this, it can also mean integration, because integration is easier if there's consistency, after all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

5900 | 颯と | さっと | Quickly | Suddenly | This is the adverb version of the kanji quick, so it means quickly. \n This actually uses the kun'yomi reading, but it's almost the same as the one you learned when you learned the kanji. It's just さっ instead of さつ. If you can remember that さつ gets shortened here, you'll know how to read this!
5901 | 賠償 | ばいしょう | Reparations | Compensation | Compensation reparations are still compensation and reparations! That's convenient. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5902 | 蘇生 | そせい | Resuscitation | Revival | When you revive life, what you're doing is resuscitation. Or, to be less medical, revival. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5903 | 没落 | ぼつらく | Ruin | Fall\n Collapse | A building or civilization that dies and then falls is in a state of ruin and collapse. Like the Mayans or the Western Roman Empire. They fell pretty hard. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5904 | 突貫 | とっかん | Rush | Charge | If you stab to pierce something, you’d better do it in a rush. If you aren't quick enough, you could get into trouble, so rush forth with a mighty charge.\n突貫 means doing something in a rush. It’s usually used in the compound 突貫工事, which means fast but often sloppy construction work. It can also describe charging at an enemy, but that meaning is less common today. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5905 | 不祥事 | ふしょうじ | Scandal |  | A not-auspicious occurrence is a scandal. A scandal is pretty much the opposite of an auspicious occurrence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5906 | 紫蘇 | しそ | Shiso | Japanese Perilla | What could a purple revive be? This actually means shiso, or Japanese Perilla, and it's a type of herb commonly used in Japanese cuisine. You can remember this refers to a plant by the flowers radical in 蘇. You might also want to google "shiso," as you'll notice how some of them have purple leaves!\nNote that, as with other plant and tree species, you'll often encounter this being written in katakana as well. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5907 | 沈没 | ちんぼつ | Sinking | Going Down\n Submersion | If you sink and die it's because you were sinking in the ocean or a pool or something. It's important to notice you're going down so you don't die like that. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5908 | 緩慢 | かんまん | Slow | Sluggish\n Dull | When your laziness is loose you can't pull yourself together and you end up moving really slow. Your arms and legs get loose and your movements become sluggish. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 緩 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou've become so slow that you can only eat things out of the can (かん). You don't have the energy to cook and your arms are all loose so it doesn't even matter if you weren't moving so slowly. So just lay there, eating slowly from a can.
5909 | 孤島 | ことう | Solitary Island |  | An orphan island is one that's all alone, without any other island friends or family. That's what makes it a solitary island. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 島 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThere are a few solitary islands off the coast of Japan that are actually considered to be a part of Tokyo (とう). Usually people think Tokyo is just the big city on the mainland, but it includes these little, lonely islands too!
5910 | 特殊 | とくしゅ | Special | Unique | An especially special thing is even more special and probably a lot more unique than ordinary special things. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5911 | 噴出 | ふんしゅつ | Spewing | Gushing\n Spouting\n Eruption | When something erupts out an exit it usually had to fight pretty hard to get to that exit. That's why it ends up spewing and gushing all over the place. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5912 | 恒星 | こうせい | Star |  | A constant star is the kind that stays in one place. It's just a regular star, like the north star or our sun, not a comet or an asteroid. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5913 | 陳述 | ちんじゅつ | Statement | Declaration\n Allegation | Exhibit what you want to mention in a loud, clear statement. You have to say it if you want people to listen. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5914 | 示唆 | しさ | Suggestion | Hint\n Implication | Someone prone to indicate and instigate will have lots of suggestions for other people. By dropping hints, they can indicate problems and instigate fights among people. Their implications do a lot of harm. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 示 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSomeone keeps coming up to you making suggestions and dropping hints that you should buy a sheep (し). It happens so much that you finally decide to grab the hint-droppers arm and... oh my gosh, that's a hoof. They're a sheep!
5915 | 日没 | にちぼつ | Sunset |  | At night the sun dies at sunset. Don't worry, it will be reborn tomorrow morning at sunrise and everything will be okay. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5916 | 覇者 | はしゃ | Supreme Ruler | Champion | Someone with the most leadership is known as the supreme ruler. No one has more leadership than them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5917 | 〜貫 | かん | Sushi Counter | Counter For Pieces Of Sushi | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5918 | 芳しい | かんばしい | Sweet | Fragrant\n Aromatic\n Good | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of perfume? Sweet or fragrant. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you want to smell a sweet fragrance, just open some potpourri. But be careful if it's a can. Fragrant cans will baa (かんば) like a sheep at you when you open them. That can baa is just a sweet smell side effect.
5919 | 茨 | いばら | Thorn | Briar\n Wild Rose | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5920 | 偏る | かたよる | To Be Biased | To Be One Sided\n To Be Partial\n To Be Prejudiced | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means biased, so the verb version is to be biased or to be prejudiced. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou meet someone who claims to be biased about everything. You ask them why and they say, "I'm a cutter, yo (かたよ)! I cut everything in half and only like one of 'em. But I guess if you wanna call that biased go ahead, man." Huh okay.
5921 | 怠る | おこたる | To Be Negligent | To Neglect\n To Shirk\n To Be Off One's Guard | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect, so the verb version is to be negligent or to neglect something. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you always seem to be negligent to your kids you'll end up with this situation. It's winter and your kid comes home from school covered in snow and sneezing. "Oh, coat... (おこた)" you say. You didn't give them a coat when they went out today. Maybe if you weren't so negligent that wouldn't have happened.
5922 | 陥る | おちいる | To Cave In | To Collapse\n To Fall\n To Trap | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cave in, so the verb version is to cave in or to collapse. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe cave you're hanging around in is about to cave in! Right as you're about to get crushed you scream, "Oh CHEESE (おちい)!!" You can't swear for real or you'll go to hell when this cave in crushes you to death. And OH CHEESE felt right as your last words.
5923 | 貫く | つらぬく | To Go Through | To Pierce\n To Penetrate\n To Persist\n To Stick To | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pierce, so the verb version is to go through or to pierce. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe best way to go through someone's mind or a college campus is to run nude (つらぬ). So if you really want to pierce someone's mind and soul remember this!
5924 | 擁する | ようする | To Have | To Possess | To do an embrace is to have that person or animal in your arms. You hug it and then run away with it. It's yours now. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
5925 | 遭う | あう | To Meet | To Encounter | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encounter, so the verb version is to encounter or to meet. \n Remember how 会う also means to meet? Well they're both read あう too! So if you know that one, you know this one too!
5926 | 膨れる | ふくれる | To Swell | To Expand\n To Be Inflated\n To Distend\n To Bulge | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSomeone comes up to you and asks, "Hey, do you want your stomach to swell like that?" How dare they ask you about your stomach. You respond with, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" It's none of their business how much you want your stomach to expand.

5980 | 頂戴 | ちょうだい | Humbly Receiving | Humbly Eating\n Humbly Having | Humbly receive something and you'll be humbly receiving it. The theme here is humility!\nThis is usually formal when written in kanji and used together with a verb like する. It can also be used alone to make very casual requests. In casual requests, it's still written in kanji in novels and other creative writing, but is generally written in hiragana anywhere else. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.
