You should be able to read this on your own.
5993 | 清浄 | せいじょう | Pure | Clean\n Purity | Pure cleansed things are pure and clean. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5994 | 浄土 | じょうど | Pure Land |  | Land where all the people have been cleansed and purified is the Pure Land of Buddhism. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5995 | 浄化 | じょうか | Purification | Cleanup | Purify water to change it from being dirty. This is called purification. It's important to purify water before you drink it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5996 | 平壌 | へいじょう | Pyongyang |  | What's the city of flat soil? Pyongyang in North Korea. Which is pretty misleading, it's got more than a bunch of flat dirt, but back in the old days before the illustrious Kim Jong line built it up, that's all that was there. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It can also be pronounced the way we say it in English sometimes too. That's ピョンヤン, if you're wondering, and these kanji are used for it too.
5997 | 批准 | ひじゅん | Ratification | Ratify | If there is only semi criticism on a law ratification is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
5998 | 緋鯉 | ひごい | Red Carp | Golden Carp\n Red Koi\n Golden Koi | A scarlet colored carp is called a red carp and sometimes a golden carp because sometimes people don't understand colors. \n The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
5999 | 余剰 | よじょう | Redundant | Surplus\n Residue\n Balance | If you have a surplus surplus it's a little redundant and you end up having a surplus of surpluses! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6000 | 啓示 | けいじ | Revelation |  | What indicates that you've been enlightened enough to reach enlightenment? A revelation! That's the only way you can know you've been enlightened enough. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6001 | 莉子 | りこ | Riko |  | Jasmine child is one way to write the girl's name Riko. Imagine fashioning a child out of jasmine, and calling her Riko. Examples of people named Riko include pop star and singer Fukumoto Riko (福本 莉子) and idol and actress Nakayama Riko (中山 莉子). \n You learned this reading for 莉 with the kanji, and I bet you're very familiar with this reading for 子 by now. A lot of Japanese girls' names that end in 子, too.
6002 | 諒一郎 | りょういちろう | Ryoichiro |  | If you only comprehend one guy, make that guy Ryoichiro.\nThe name 諒一郎 isn't very common, but it's worth learning because the kanji 諒 is used in lots of names, and both 諒 and 一郎 are names in their own right. So by learning this name, you should be able to read a whole lot of other names, too. \n You learned all the readings in this name with the kanji. What could be easier to comprehend?
6003 | 襟巻き | えりまき | Scarf | Muffler\n Comforter | Remember how you learned that 巻く means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your collar is a scarf! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
6004 | 苗木 | なえぎ | Seedling | Sapling\n Young Tree | A seedling tree is still a seedling. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
6005 | 自浄 | じじょう | Self Purification | Self Cleansing | If you purify your self you are performing self purification. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6006 | 舗 | ほ | Shop | Store | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that you won’t actually see this used as a standalone word very often, except in the phrase 舗を構える (to open a shop), but even that is fairly rare! \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6007 | 店舗 | てんぽ | Shop | Store\n Shop Counter\n Store Counter | A shop shop is still a shop. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6008 | 胡座 | あぐら | Sitting Cross Legged | Sit Cross Legged | When barbarians sit they only sit cross legged. Sitting on your feet hurts and they don't care how they look, so they're going to be comfortable and cross their legs. \n The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nIf you're sitting cross legged lots of people will think you're a grouch (あぐら). Back in the day sitting like this was thought to be really manly, and if you were a woman who did it they'd call you a grouch too.
6009 | 皮膚病 | ひふびょう | Skin Disease |  | Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is sick, you have a skin disease. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6010 | 土壌 | どじょう | Soil |  | Soil soil is still soil. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6011 | 南緯 | なんい | Southern Latitude | South Latitude | South latitude is south latitude or southern latitude. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6012 | 胞子 | ほうし | Spore |  | The child of a cell is a spore. They're just as tiny and they're floating all around you right now. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6013 | 投稿 | とうこう | Submission | Post\n Contribution\n Submit | Throw your draft at people to post it on their Facebook wall! Wait, that's not how it works? Hush, yes it does, just throw it harder. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6014 | 高騰 | こうとう | Sudden Price Jump | Steep Price Rise | Tall inflation of prices means that there was a sudden price jump and it's waaaay more expensive than it used to be. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6015 | 暴騰 | ぼうとう | Sudden Rise | Sharp Rise\n Boom\n Skyrocketing | Violent inflation causes a sudden rise in prices. It sucks. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6016 | 急騰 | きゅうとう | Sudden Rise | Sharp Rise\n Jump | Sudden inflation results in a sudden rise of prices, aka a sharp rise or a jump in prices. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6017 | 頂 | いただき | Summit | Peak\n Top\n Crown | The kanji means summit and this word means summit, peak, top and crown, most often in reference to mountains. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You should already know this reading from when you learned 頂く. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!
6018 | 統帥 | とうすい | Supreme Command | High Command | The commander that unites and rules the world is one with supreme command. He's better than all the other commanders who couldn't bring everyone together and now he rules over everyone. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6019 | 剰余金 | じょうよきん | Surplus |  | Surplus of surplus money is still a surplus. There's just too much money everywhere! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6020 | 合繊 | ごうせん | Synthetic Fiber |  | Fibers you join together to make more, stronger fibers, they turn into synthetic fibers.\nNote that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 合成繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6021 | 化繊 | かせん | Synthetic Fibers |  | Fibers that have been changed from other materials are synthetic fibers. They aren't natural because they were something else once. Like plastic, or kittens.\nNote that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 化学繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6022 | 教諭 | きょうゆ | Teacher |  | Who admonishes and teaches you? A Teacher. Probably not the nicest one though...\nThis word is more formal and specific than 先生 or 教師. It refers to licensed teachers who have permanent positions in schools, not temporary ones like supply teachers. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6023 | 諭す | さとす | To Admonish | To Persuade\n To Warn | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means admonish, so the verb version is to admonish or to warn. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour mom started to admonish you so you instantly sat (さと) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.
6024 | 沸かす | わかす | To Boil | To Heat\n To Excite | You already learned the word 沸く which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It still means to boil or to heat. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 沸く, so you should be able to read this word as well.
6025 | 召し上がる | めしあがる | To Eat | To Drink | You've learned that 召す can mean "to take" when a social higher-up takes a meal or a drink. Now you're adding 上がる (to go up), so you've got the added image of the food or drink rising up to their mouth. In other words, this is a respectful way of saying to eat or to drink. \n This is a combination of the words 召す and 上がる that you've learned already.召す becomes 召し and then you add 上がる to it. Pretty straightforward, right?
6026 | 挟まる | はさまる | To Get Between | To Be Caught In | You already learned the word 挟む which means "to put between." Well this is when something is between two things and you're not putting it there. It's just kinda doing it by itself. It means to get between or to be caught in. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 挟む, so you should be able to read this word as well.
6027 | 据える | すえる | To Install | To Place\n To Fix\n To Set\n To Lay\n To Seat | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means install, so the verb version is to install or to fix. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
6028 | 寛大 | かんだい | Tolerance | Liberality\n Leniency | It doesn't matter how big your tolerance is because it's still tolerance. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6029 | 寛容 | かんよう | Tolerance | Open Minded\n Forbearance\n Generous | All forms of tolerance are still tolerance. Usually people like this are really open minded and generous too. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6030 | 枯らす | からす | To Let Dry | To Kill\n To Season | You already learned the word 枯れる which means "to wither," but this is when you are the one making a plant wither. It means to let dry or to kill your plants. They didn't just die on their own, you did it. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 枯れる, so you should be able to read this word as well.
6031 | 肯く | うなずく | To Nod | To Bow One's Head | If you want to show your agreement with someone you need to nod at them so they know. \n The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nYou seem to nod your head a lot when you're at the unagi zoo (うなず). Unagi zoos are really rare and hard to get into. So while you're there, keep nodding to everyone because you're so honored to be there!\n肯く also has two readings. うなずく is the standard, but うなづく is more and more acceptable these days too. Luckily they sound pretty similar (if not the same), so they should be easy to remember!
6032 | 虐げる | しいたげる | To Oppress | To Persecute\n To Tyrannize | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means oppress, so the verb version is to oppress or to persecute. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe best way to oppress someone is to make it so they can't use the sh*tter (しいた). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter."\nTo help you to remember that there's an い in there, think about an eagle, as we often do for い. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.
6033 | 寛ぐ | くつろぐ | To Relax | To Feel At Home | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tolerance, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able to relax and to feel at home because nothing really gets to you. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to relax so you go down to old coots road (くつろ). It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.
6034 | 暴虐 | ぼうぎゃく | Tyranny | Outrage\n Atrocity\n Cruel | Violence and oppression are all signs of tyranny and that someone is being really cruel. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6035 | 不浄 | ふじょう | Uncleanliness | Dirtiness\n Impurity\n Filthiness\n Defilement | If you have not cleansed yourself you're going to be covered in uncleanliness and dirtiness. Eww. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6036 | 随分 | ずいぶん | Very | Extremely\n Surprisingly\n Considerably | If you manage to make all parts of something work together you worked very, extremely, considerably hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6037 | 洗浄 | せんじょう | Washing | Cleaning\n Laundering | You wash something to cleanse it by doing the washing and cleaning. You have to do the washing if you really want to get all the dirt out and make your things clean. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6038 | 西瓜 | すいか | Watermelon |  | Melons that grow in the west are round and striped and green and wait a second. That's a watermelon. I guess they come from the western part of Japan. \n The reading for 西 here is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nWatermelons taste best after you swing (すい) them around. Whether you tie a rope to them or swing them on an actual swing, it mixes up the yummy watermelon insides and they end up tasting the best this way. So always remember to swing your watermelon before you crack it open.
6039 | 渦巻き | うずまき | Whirlpool | Eddy\n Coil | This is a combination of the word 渦 meaning "whirlpool" and 巻く meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a whirlpool, just a really violent one. \n This is a combination of the words 渦 and 巻く. 巻く becomes 巻き and you just add 渦 to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.
6040 | 丹誠 | たんせい | Working Earnestly | Sincerity\n Diligence\n Effort | A miner works with such sincerity that her arms and legs start turning rust colored from working earnestly. All the clay and rocks she's putting her effort into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious diligence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6041 | 顕在 | けんざい | Actual | Obvious\n Explicit\n Overt\n Apparent\n Evident | If it appears to exist, then it's probably an actual thing... you know, existing and stuff. That should be pretty obvious. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6042 | 逸話 | いつわ | Anecdote |  | How do you deviate from a normal talk? With lots of anecdotes. If you add enough of them into your conversations no one will ever be able to keep track of what you were talking about to begin with. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6043 | 杏 | あんず | Apricot |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!
6044 | 兵糧 | ひょうろう | Army Provisions | Provisions | Provisions that are only for soldiers are army provisions. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the reading for the second kanji but not the first one yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe army said it would provide you with some army provisions. That's great! You go to the drop site where the provisions are, and you see the provisions. "Heyo! It's roe!" (ひょうろう) you say out loud. You're pretty happy that your provisions consist of tons and tons of roe!
6045 | 自叙伝 | じじょでん | Autobiography |  | Tell everyone how you describe yourself in your autobiography. It's the only way they'll be able to understand the real you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6046 | 哺乳瓶 | ほにゅうびん | Baby Bottle |  | A milk bottle that babies use to nurse is called a baby bottle. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6047 | 風呂場 | ふろば | Bathroom |  | Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the place you take a bath in is the bathroom! \n This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 場. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!
6048 | 偏り | かたより | Bias | Deviation\n Prejudice | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 偏る, so you should be able to read this one too!
6049 | 空欄 | くうらん | Blank Space |  | A space as empty as the sky is a blank space. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6050 | 盆栽 | ぼんさい | Bonsai |  | Tray planting is bonsai. It makes sense because that is exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6051 | 栞 | しおり | Bookmark |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6052 | 和尚 | おしょう | Buddhist High Priest | High Priest\n Buddhist Priest | Who works for peace and is held in high esteem? A Buddhist high priest. They work harder than anyone else to reach world peace so they're held in very high esteem. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe only thing you ever hear the Buddhist High Priest say is "Oooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.
6053 | 欄 | らん | Column | Column Of Text\n Field | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6054 | 叙勲 | じょくん | Conferring Of Decorations | Decorate | Describe someone's merit at a ceremony for the conferring of decorations. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6055 | 紋章 | もんしょう | Crest | Coat Of Arms | Look at a chapter on family crests in that book and you'll see every crest in your area. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6056 | 冠 | かんむり | Crown | Diadem\n Coronet\n Traditional Cap | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, and that is its most common reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn your mind, the only person who can wear a crown is Bill Murray. He asks you, "Can I wear the crown?" and you say "Yes you can, Murray (かんむり)". Murray goes ahead and puts on the crown. He's movie royalty, after all.
6057 | 王冠 | おうかん | Crown | Diadem\n Bottle Cap | A king's cap is his crown. It's a hat only he can wear. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6058 | 冷酷 | れいこく | Cruel | Coldhearted\n Relentless\n Ruthless | A cruel cool person is more cruel and coldhearted than just a normal cruel person. It's probably because they're cold all the time and it makes them mad. You should stay away from people like that. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6059 | 酷い | ひどい | Cruel | Awful\n Severe | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cruel? Cruel or awful. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThink of a man who is cruel. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? He do (ひど) cruel things.
6060 | 残酷 | ざんこく | Cruelty | Harshness | The remainder of cruelness is cruelty. There always seems to be plenty to go around, and it kind of sucks. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6061 | 栽培 | さいばい | Cultivation | Growing | Planting seeds in land to cultivate crops is called cultivation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6062 | 勲章 | くんしょう | Decoration | Order\n Medal | To show that you had merit for a chapter of your life you will be given a decoration or a medal. Especially if you're a soldier or an athlete. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6063 | 痴呆 | ちほう | Dementia |  | If you seem stupid and shocked all the time you might have dementia. It makes it so everything is unfamiliar and confusing, so you can't help looking silly and confused all the time. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6064 | 過疎 | かそ | Depopulation |  | If the neglect of an area surpasses what was expected, then the result will be depopulation. No one wants to live in a neglected town, especially one that's worse than what they were told. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6065 | 逸脱 | いつだつ | Deviation | Departure | If you deviate from the plan and escape from it, that's a serious deviation and could ruin everything! Stick to the plan! Stop deviating! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6066 | 露顕 | ろけん | Discovery | Detection\n Exposure | You expose something new and it appears in front of the whole world as your discovery. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6067 | 疾患 | しっかん | Disease | Ailment\n Disorder | Something that you are afflicted with rapidly is a disease. You should go to the doctor's right away to treat this fast-acting ailment. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6068 | 無秩序 | むちつじょ | Disorder | Chaos\n Confusion | Remember how you learned that 秩序 means "order?" Well if you have nothing like that then it falls into disorder and chaos! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6069 | 叙事詩 | じょじし | Epic Poem | Descriptive Poetry | If you describe a bunch of occurrences in a poem, it's probably an epic poem. This is for those super long, really descriptive poems you might be forced to read in school, like The Epic of Gilgamesh (ギルガメシュ叙事詩). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6070 | 殊に | ことに | Especially | Particularly\n Additionally\n Unusually | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This is the kanji followed by the particle に, so it uses the kun'yomi reading like a kanji does if it's alone. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat do you wear when it's especially cold out? Your favorite coat (こと). You only wear it when it's unusually cold though, never any other time.
6071 | 必須条件 | ひっすじょうけん | Essential Condition | Requisite\n Must | You already learned that 必須 can mean "essential" and that 条件 means "condition," so put them together and you get essential condition! That basically means that it's a must. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6072 | 疎外 | そがい | Estrangement | Neglect\n Alienation | Neglect someone so much that you remove yourself from their inner circle and live outside of their life and it's called estrangement. You might never see them again. But that's okay with you, your relationship is too weird to fix now. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6073 | 疎遠 | そえん | Estrangement | Neglect | If your neglect of family members goes too far you'll end up with estrangement in your relationships with them. And they'll probably neglect you as much as you neglect them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6074 | 悠久 | ゆうきゅう | Eternity | Perpetuity\n Permanence | Leisure that last for a long time ends up going on for all eternity. It never ends, and why should it? You're soooo relaaaaaxed, you can't possibly ever stop. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6075 | 倫理的 | りんりてき | Ethical |  | Things that are ethic al are ethical. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6076 | 倫理学 | りんりがく | Ethics | Moral Philosophy | You already learned that 倫理 means "ethics" so when you add study it means the ethics you study in school. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6077 | 疎開 | そかい | Evacuation |  | You’re looking for a neglected place that you can open up and use for evacuation.\nWhile 避難 is a more general term for evacuating or seeking shelter during emergencies, 疎開 describes evacuating specifically from cities or crowded areas to safer places during disasters like earthquakes, tsunamis, etc. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6078 | 秀逸 | しゅういつ | Excellence |  | Do you excel when you deviate from the norm? Well, then you're made for excellence, my friend! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6079 | 応酬 | おうしゅう | Exchange | Reciprocation | Repay what someone lent you in response to them already lending YOU money, and the two of you will have exchanged money. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6080 | 酷使 | こくし | Exploitation | Overuse\n Abuse | If you use something in a cruel way it's called exploitation. You're probably going to overuse it, at that rate too. Cut it out, dude. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6081 | 露呈 | ろてい | Exposure | Disclosure | Present and expose wrongdoing to get proper exposure. The world needs disclosure and so do you! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6082 | 紋 | もん | Family Crest | Crest\n Coat Of Arms | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6083 | 指紋 | しもん | Fingerprint |  | The family crest on your finger? That's just your fingerprint. It can be used to identify you, so it's pretty much the same as your own personal family crest. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6084 | 民謡 | みんよう | Folk Song | Popular Song | The peoples Noh chanting is folk songs. They're the songs for the common people. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6085 | 阿呆 | あほ | Fool | Simpleton\n Idiot | Shock someone by flattering them and they'll end up looking like a fool. Taking compliments always turns people into silly idiots. It's okay, they're just embarrassed. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own, but keep in mind that the reading is often shortened to あほ these days.
6086 | 愚 | ぐ | Foolish | Silly\n Folly\n Foolishness | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Since this word is both a noun and a na-adjective, it can also mean things like folly and foolishness. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6087 | 尚 | なお | Furthermore | Still\n More\n Greater | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen do people tend to use the word furthermore? Right now (なお)!
6088 | 疾風 | しっぷう | Gale | Strong Wind\n Fresh Breeze | A rapid wind is a gale or a strong wind. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6089 | 逸品 | いっぴん | Gem | Treasure\n Article Of Rare Beauty\n Fine Article | Deviate from normal, everyday products and buy lots of gems and treasures! Especially if you're buying presents. Normal stuff just isn't going to cut it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6090 | 庶務 | しょむ | General Affairs |  | Common tasks are a part of the general affairs of the people. That's why they're general, they're the ones everyone is involved in. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6091 | 銀杏 | いちょう | Ginkgo | Ginkgo Nut\n Ginkgo Tree | Silver apricots are called ginkgo nuts. Okay, they aren't really apricots, but they are silver and they sure look the same. \n This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:\nBefore you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now.\nWhen you think of a ginkgo tree think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles but evil Mrs. Chou likes to eat eagles AND whole ginkgo trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND ARE STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And ginkgo trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo.\nThe other meaning is the ginkgo nuts themselves. They taste like 銀 (ぎん) naan (なん). Mm mm soft and metallic, but still not the jukugo word though. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.
6092 | 叙述 | じょじゅつ | Giving An Account | Narrating\n Describing | When you describe an event by mentioning everything that happened, you must be giving an account of it.\n叙述 refers to narrating or describing events in an orderly sequence. It usually suggests a specific writing technique associated with storytelling and narrative. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6093 | 厳粛 | げんしゅく | Gravity | Solemnity\n Severity\n Seriousness | If everyone is acting solemn and strict then you should probably pay special attention to the gravity of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6097 | 高尚 | こうしょう | High | Noble\n Refined | You only hold someone in high esteem if they are really high, noble people. They have to be refined to be held so highly by you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6098 | 別荘 | べっそう | Holiday House | Villa | A villa separate from your normal house is a holiday house. You go there when you're sick of your normal house to relax. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6099 | 顕彰 | けんしょう | Honoring |  | Sometimes someone will appear before you and it's clear they're worth honoring. If Koichi appeared before you, for example, it should be pretty clear what you should do. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6100 | 茨城県 | いばらきけん | Ibaraki Prefecture |  | The prefecture famous for its ancient thorn castle is Ibaraki prefecture. I may or may not be making this up. Don't fact check me, just look at that cool thorny castle in Ibaraki that I put in your head. Ooooh, how cool! \n This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 茨, and exception for 城 and the on'yomi for 県. Phew! You haven't learned this weird reading for 城 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIbaraki prefecture is famous for making keys (き)! It's their biggest export. The key to knowing this reading is in the keys they make! Or, just knowing that it's the same in English and Japanese.
6101 | 愚痴 | ぐち | Idle Complaint | Grumble | A foolish and stupid person will make lots of idle complaints. You really don't like being around them because they grumble about how nothing is good enough all the time. But they really just don't get it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6102 | 疾病 | しっぺい | Illness | Disease | A rapid sickness is an illness or a disease. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 病 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you don't treat an illness right away you'll end up paying (ぺい) with your life. And if you don't die, you'll still have to pay a lot for doctor and hospital fees. Yuck.
6103 | 酷暑 | こくしょ | Intense Heat |  | Cruel hot weather is the kind that's too much for anyone to handle. It's intense heat. Stranded in the desert in summer, heat. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 暑 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIntense heat will show (しょ) on your face. You'll turn red and get all sweaty. You really can't hide it.
6104 | 誘拐 | ゆうかい | Kidnapping | Abduction | Invite someone to kidnap you and you'll have a kidnapping on your hands. That wasn't very smart. You should try to be more careful. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6105 | 悠長 | ゆうちょう | Leisurely | Slow\n Deliberate\n Easygoing | Long leisure makes everything you do leisurely and slow. You're able to perform tasks at a deliberate rate because nothing's rushing you. And you've been like this for so long, why would anything try? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6106 | 叙情 | じょじょう | Lyricism | Description Of Feelings\n Expression Of Feelings | The best way to describe your feelings is with lyricism. Making a clear description of feelings is difficult, but it will make you feel better. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6107 | 茜色 | あかねいろ | Madder Red | Dark Red\n Crimson | Red dye color is madder red, or dark red. This word is used most often to describe the color of the sky at sunset in literature. \n The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.
6108 | 欄外 | らんがい | Margin |  | If you write outside the columns in your notebook paper you're actually writing in the margins. It's a good space to put doodles. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6109 | 庶民 | しょみん | Masses | Common People | Common peoples make up the masses. They are the common people and no society is complete without them.\nDepending on the context, 庶民 can take on a slightly negative connotation, especially if the 庶民 in question are contrasted with more elite or sophisticated groups. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6110 | 殊勲 | しゅくん | Meritorious Deeds |  | You do things especially worthy of merit and they're called meritorious deeds. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6111 | 新陳代謝 | しんちんたいしゃ | Metabolism |  | Your body thinks you want to substitute new exhibits inside yourself but it apologizes and replaces them more than you'd like. What it's actually doing is controlling your metabolism. Picture your body using food you eat by setting it up in an exhibit in your stomach. But it gets bored of it and wants to substitute it with a newer one, so it makes you hungry again, digesting the food fast. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know all of these, but 代 uses the less common たい reading, so here’s a mnemonic in case you’d like some help remembering that:\nAs everyone knows, the best way to boost your metabolism is to wear a tie (たい). They make your body more efficient overall, which includes your metabolism, so make sure you’re always wearing a tie for that metabolism boost!
6112 | 最優遇 | さいゆうぐう | Most Favorable Treatment | Warmest Reception | The most superior treatment is another way of saying it's the most favorable treatment you've ever received. It's when you get the warmest reception out of everyone around you. Like they think you're the president or something. Either way, it's pretty great! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6114 | 疎通 | そつう | Mutual Understanding | Removal Of Blockage\n Drainage | If you never neglect to pass through your thoughts to another person the two of you will be able to have a special mutual understanding. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6115 | 童謡 | どうよう | Nursery Rhyme | Children's Song | Noh chanting for juveniles are nursery rhymes. Kids won't understand the heavy stuff, so you have to dumb it down for them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6116 | 哺育 | ほいく | Nursing | Suckling | Nurse and raise your baby by nursing. Milk helps babies grow up big and strong. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6117 | 孤児院 | こじいん | Orphanage |  | You already learned that the word 孤児 means "orphan," so when you put a bunch of orphans in an institution it's called an orphanage. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6118 | 極楽 | ごくらく | Paradise |  | This place has extreme comfort. It is paradise.\n極楽 is a short for 極楽浄土 (the Pure Land in Mahayana Buddhism). While it might sound a bit old-fashioned, you can still use it to describe something heavenly. For example, if you're soaking in a cozy, relaxing hot spring, you could say, "Ahhh…極楽!" \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 極 has two on'yomi readings, though. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:\nIn paradise, you meet Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z. He grins and tells you he's taking a break from extreme battles and enjoying the extreme comfort of this heavenly paradise.
6119 | 実践 | じっせん | Practice | Put Into Practice | To tell you the truth, practice is practice. You can't just substitute something else for it. You'll only make progress with real practice! You can do it! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6120 | 時期尚早 | じきしょうそう | Premature |  | You already learned that the word 時期 means "time period," so when you add furthermore and early to that, it means that something happened ahead of time. It means premature. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!
6125 | 悠々 | ゆうゆう | Quiet | Calm\n Leisurely\n Easy | Leisure with more leisure added on? That's a really quiet and leisurely life you've got going on!\nNote that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective! \n The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

6128 | 酷似 | こくじ | Resemblance | Resemble | If you resemble someone who's cruel, you, well, you resemble them. Maybe you're really mean too. I guess only you can know that. But you do look like that other guy... \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 似 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhich cruel guy do you resemble? Jesus (じ), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.
6129 | 報酬 | ほうしゅう | Reward | Compensation | Repay people for the news they tell you by rewarding them! Everyone deserves compensation for the time they take to pass information to you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You should be able to read this on your own.

6136 | 静粛 | せいしゅく | Silent |  | A solemn quiet person will always be silent. They never ever speak. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6137 | 荘厳 | そうごん | Solemnity | Gravity | A villa that's kept under really strict rules will press solemnity on everyone who tries to stay there. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 厳 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo help you understand the solemnity of a moment of silence, usually a gong (ごん) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.
6138 | 歌謡 | かよう | Song | Ballad | Noh chanting out a song makes it an even longer, more confusing song. But it's still a song nonetheless! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6139 | 疎ら | まばら | Sparse | Thin\n Scattered\n Straggling\n Sporadic | The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen things are sparse, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your mama would baa (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

6141 | 茎 | くき | Stem | Stalk | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6142 | 噴き出す | ふきだす | To Burst Out | To Spout Out | "To Remove" an eruption it needs to burst out of the earth or volcano it's in. \n Remember how you learned the word 吹き出す? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!
6143 | 膨らむ | ふくらむ | To Expand | To Swell\n To Get Big\n To Become Inflated | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!
6144 | 貫き通す | つらぬきとおす | To Follow | To Stick With\n To Stick To\n To Go Through | This is a combination of the words 貫く meaning "To Go Through" and 通す meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start to follow them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide to stick with them. \n This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!
6145 | 呆ける | ぼける | To Grow Senile | To Be Mentally Slow | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.
6146 | 音痴 | おんち | Tone Deafness | Tone Deaf\n Off Key | If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6147 | 怠ける | なまける | To Neglect | To Be Idle\n To Slack | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect and lazy, so the verb version is to neglect or to be idle. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (なま). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.
6148 | 卸す | おろす | To Sell Wholesale | To Grate | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
6149 | 逸らす | そらす | To Turn Away | To Avert | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deviate, so the verb version is to turn away or to avert. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.
6150 | 空疎 | くうそ | Vain | Groundless\n Futile | The sky has an air of neglect about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in vain. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6151 | 犠牲者 | ぎせいしゃ | Victim |  | You already learned that 犠牲 means "victim," so when you add someone to that, it still means victim. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6152 | 鯨 | くじら | Whale |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nA whale is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin kujira (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!
6153 | 鯨肉 | げいにく | Whale Meat |  | Whale meat is whale meat. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6179 | 瑛斗 | えいと | Eito | Akito | A crystal ladle is the Japanese given name Eito. If you know the singer-songwriter Eito, imagine him holding a crystal ladle. If not, any Eito will do! Get yourself a crystal ladle to celebrate!\nNote: This name can also sometimes be read あきと, as is the case for pro baseball player Takabe Akito (髙部 瑛斗).

6183 | 悪因悪果 | あくいんあっか | Evil Breeds Evil | Evil Begets Evil | The evil cause yields the evil fruit, or more simply, evil breeds evil.\nThis is a Buddhist term, often used together with 善因善果 (virtue breeds virtue) to illustrate the concept of karma. While not a widely known phrase, it a nice saying to remind us of the importance of our actions. \n This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last 悪果 gets the 悪 shortened a little bit.
6184 | 佳作 | かさく | Fine Work | Good Piece Of Work | Make something excellent and everyone will call it a fine work. Or make something that sucks and let everyone down. It's your call. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6186 | 唐揚げ | からあげ | Fried Chicken | Karaage | You've got a combination of China and 揚げ, meaning "fried." That makes this Chinese-style Fried Chicken, or as you'll probably also know it, karaage.\nWhile 唐揚げ most often refers to fried chicken, it can technically also refer to other deep fried meats, fish, or vegetables. As it's the most common meaning, remembering this as "fried chicken" will be just fine, though. \n You know how to read the 揚げ part, but this uses the kun'yomi reading for 唐, which is new. You'll likely be able to remember this reading by associating fried chicken with Japanese karaage, but in case you're not familiar with it, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nTo make this kind of fried chicken, you have to first give it one strong からて chop. If you fry it up without that からて chop, it just comes out terrible no matter what you do. So just remember that next time you make it for me, kay?

6203 | 勿論 | もちろん | Of Course | Needless To Say | You must not consider this a theory, because of course it's a fact. Needless to say, you should be able to read this on your own!
6204 | 老舗 | しにせ | Old Shop | Old Store | An elderly shop is an old shop. \n This reading is an exception, so here's a mnemonic:\nYou go to an old shop and come across a sheep knee sale (しにせ). When you ask what a sheep knee sale is, the clerk tells you quite matter-of-factly that it's a sale on all the sheep knees. You've never seen this in newer shops, so it must be a pretty old practice to buy and sell sheep knees.

6212 | 繁昌 | はんじょう | Prosperity | Flourishing\n Thriving | Overgrown prosperity is still prosperity. Why, it's even thriving. Nice! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6213 | 南瓜 | かぼちゃ | Pumpkin | Squash\n Kabocha | Melons from the south are lumpy and orange, sometimes orange and green because they try to look like the hot sun. Wait, those aren't melons, they're pumpkins and squash. Or... kind of a mix of the two, if you already know what kabocha tastes like. \n The reading for this is an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nJapanese pumpkins don't taste like American pumpkins. They taste more like canned boiled chocolate (かぼちゃ). Oh, you don't know that either? Well then just taste the pumpkin and you'll know what that tastes like too.\nThis word is also sometimes read なんきん, especially in the east of Japan.
6214 | 遺憾 | いかん | Regrettable | Unsatisfactory | If you leave behind something and it makes you feel remorse it's a really regrettable situation. You should probably go back for whatever it was so you won't lead an unsatisfactory life. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6215 | 鎮魂 | ちんこん | Repose Of Souls |  | To tranquilize souls you have to a have a mass repose of souls. Then their souls will move on to the next life and stop hanging around here, haunting umbrellas. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6216 | 粗野 | そや | Rustic | Rough\n Rude\n Vulgar | Your home is out in the middle of a coarse looking field. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's rustic. That's pretty rude of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6217 | 遼太 | りょうた | Ryota |  | Distant fat makes up the Japanese given name Ryota. Imagine soccer player Noguchi Ryota (野口 遼太) kicking a fat soccer ball into the distance while voice actor Asari Ryota (浅利 遼太) commentates. \n This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You haven't learned this particular on'yomi for 太 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nRyota's diet consists only of tacos (た). Tacos, tacos, tacos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Yum!
6218 | 奉公 | ほうこう | Service | Apprenticeship\n Public Duty | Dedicate yourself to the public by doing community service! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6219 | 素朴 | そぼく | Simple | Naive | People made from simple elements are also pretty simple. And they can be naive too. But that's just how they're built. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6220 | 凝固 | ぎょうこ | Solidify | Coagulate\n Freeze | Your pudding congealed and is all hard. How on earth did it solidify like this? It shouldn't freeze unless you put it in the freezer. Unless, did you? Oh... \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6221 | 脊髄 | せきずい | Spinal Cord |  | Marrow that gives you stature is inside of your spinal cord. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6222 | 凝視 | ぎょうし | Stare | Gaze\n Fixation | Freeze and look at me. Your stare is giving me the creeps! You can move now. Hey. You can move now. Stop I said! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6223 | 国賓 | こくひん | State Guest |  | A VIP from another country is a state guest. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6224 | 継父 | けいふ | Stepfather |  | A father you've inherited isn't your original father, he's your stepfather. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.\nThis word can also be read as ままちち, because 継 can take the special reading まま when it's used as the prefix "step," as in "stepfather."
6225 | 累進 | るいしん | Successive Promotion | Gradual Promotion\n Graduated | Accumulate enough of a good reputation at your company in advance and you'll be able to have successive promotions. You'll be boss in no time! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6226 | 鎮圧 | ちんあつ | Suppression | Subjugation | Tranquilize pressure with medication that helps with its suppression. Then you won't have to feel it anymore. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6227 | 降伏 | こうふく | Surrender | Submission | Bow as you descend into enemy territory. This is how you have to surrender if you want to live. Keep your head nice and low and descend into their ranks. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6228 | 之 | これ | This | This One | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\nNote that this is almost always written in kana in modern Japanese. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6229 | 鎮める | しずめる | To Appease | To Suppress\n To Calm | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tranquilize, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's to appease or to suppress. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to appease her because she's (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how to calm her down!
6230 | 憂える | うれえる | To Be Anxious | To Worry About\n To Lament\n To Grieve\n To Be Distressed | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grieve, so the verb version is to grieve or to be anxious. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.
6231 | 惜しむ | おしむ | To Be Frugal | To Be Sparing | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frugal, so the verb version is to be frugal or to be sparing. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou should try to be frugal when you go to the ocean (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?
6232 | 凝る | こる | To Be Passionate About | To Be Into\n To Grow Stiff | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means congeal or freeze, so the verb version is to grow stiff. Remember 肩こり (shoulder stiffness)? This is where that こり part comes from.\n凝る also means  to be passionate about something. Think of it this way: your passions are freezing onto one thing, so you're going to be into that thing. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat have all your friends started to be passionate about? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.
6233 | 栃木県 | とちぎけん | Tochigi Prefecture |  | The prefecture with lots of horse chestnut trees is Tochigi prefecture. \n This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!
6234 | 伏せる | ふせる | To Cover | To Hide\n To Lay Upside Down\n To Turn Over | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bow or lay, so the verb version is what when you try to cover or to hide something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.
6235 | 据え付ける | すえつける | To Install | To Equip\n To Mount | This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going to install something or to equip something. There's just more hands on work happening. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6236 | 起伏 | きふく | Undulation | Ups And Downs\n Highs And Lows | Wake up, now lay yourself down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called undulation. If your emotions do it it's called ups and downs. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6238 | 躍如 | やくじょ | Vividly Depicted | Clearly Expressed | A leap of likeness is when something that's not real takes a big leap towards the likeness to reality. This happens when something is vividly depicted or clearly expressed.\nThis word is generally used in the phrase 面目躍如たる, which functions as an adjective to exemplify someone’s honor. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6239 | 山葵 | わさび | Wasabi | Japanese Horseradish | If you dig up hollyhocks in the mountains, and grind up their roots, you'll have wasabi! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off. \n This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!
6240 | 披露宴 | ひろうえん | Wedding Reception | Reception | You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a banquet to that and you're at a wedding reception! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal reception. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6241 | 弥生 | やよい | Yayoi Period | Yayoi | Life in Japan was increasing at its fastest rate during the Yayoi Period. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it. \n The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's Yayoi (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

Or, on the opposite side of things, still less. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

Well this is a bit of an exception. Saying りんりん is kinda hard so just drop the んs and you'll have the reading りり!

6282 | 所轄 | しょかつ | Jurisdiction |  | The place you have control over is your jurisdiction.\n所轄 commonly refers to the jurisdiction of a police station or other law enforcement agency, like 所轄の警察署 (the district police station) or 所轄の税務署 (the district tax office). It can also be used for government departments that have authority over certain tasks or regions, like 所轄官庁 (the authorities concerned), as well as within organizations to describe which department is responsible for specific tasks, like 所轄部門 (the responsible department). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You should ask for help next time you don't know what you're doing and you won't make these errors. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6291 | 交錯 | こうさく | Mixture | Blending\n Complication | You mix a bunch of ingredients into a confused mixture. That's going to be one weird cake, or whatever the mixture's for. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6292 | 記念碑 | きねんひ | Monument |  | Some tombstones are used to write down the thoughts of dead people. They're monuments. They can be really big or really small, but they have to be dedicated to somebody (usually a dead somebody). \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6293 | 那智の滝 | なちのたき | Nachi Falls | Nachinotaki | What wisdom waterfall is Nachi Falls, one of the most famous (and wisest) waterfalls in Japan. \n You learned all three of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6294 | 疎か | おろそか | Neglect | Negligence\n Carelessness | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nYou notice a lot of neglect when it comes to old road soap cars (おろそか). If you drive down the old road you'll see neglected cars made of soap all over the place. It's sad, really.
6295 | 窒素 | ちっそ | Nitrogen |  | An element that can cause a person to suffocate is nitrogen. Too much or too little will cause it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6296 | 方向音痴 | ほうこうおんち | No Sense Of Direction | Bad Sense Of Direction | This is a combination of the words 方向 and 音痴. When your sense of direction is tone-deaf, it means you have no sense of direction. You get lost no matter how hard you try. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6297 | 庶民的 | しょみんてき | Ordinary | Unpretentious\n Approachable | Remember how 庶民 means "common people"? Well, anything that's "common-people-like" is ordinary, unpretentious, and approachable.\nUnlike 庶民, which can sometimes have negative connotations, 庶民的 is usually positive. It's used for things that appeal to ordinary people, like an unpretentious restaurant or a person with a familiar, approachable vibe. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6298 | 凡人 | ぼんじん | Ordinary Person | Average Person\n Mediocre | A mediocre person is an ordinary person. There isn't anything weird or interesting about them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6299 | 弊社 | へいしゃ | Our Company | Our Humble Company | An evil company is actually our company or our humble company. We're not going to say our company is virtuous, are we? That wouldn't be humble at all. So instead we call it evil, to show our humility. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6300 | 倒錯 | とうさく | Perversion |  | When your confused urges overthrow normal thoughts and feelings it's a perversion. Some are harmless, but some are not. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6301 | 歌謡曲 | かようきょく | Popular Song | Retro J-Pop\n Showa-Era Pop Music\n Kayokyoku | You already learned that 歌謡 means "song," so when you add music to that it becomes a super popular song. It's not just a song anymore. It's in everything you hear!\nMore broadly, this can refer to a whole genre of Japanese pop music from the Showa era. In other words, it refers to retro J-POP or Showa-era pop music. The word kayokyoku is sometimes used for it in English too. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6302 | 窮乏 | きゅうぼう | Poverty | Destitution | Towns destitute and scarce of food will end up in poverty and destitution. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6303 | 困窮 | こんきゅう | Poverty | Distress | You'll be distressed and destitute if you're living in poverty. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6304 | 宰相 | さいしょう | Prime Minister |  | The person everyone comes to a mutual agreement about to be the manager of the country is the Prime Minister.\nCompared to 首相 or 総理大臣 that you've learned as "prime minister" previously, 宰相 were prime ministers appointed by monarchs. So this is a bit of a dated term used for the prime ministers of an imperial or royal court. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know both readings, but make sure to read 相 as しょう. This should be easy to remember since Shoguns (しょう) were like prime ministers back in the day!
6305 | 非凡 | ひぼん | Prodigy | Rare\n Unique\n Extraordinary | It's an injustice that so many people in this world are mediocre and we can't all be a prodigy at something. Everyone deserves to be unique, but it just isn't true. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6307 | 恭しい | うやうやしい | Respectful | Reverent | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of respect? It's respectful. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji so you should be able to read this too.
6308 | 束縛 | そくばく | Restraint | Shackles\n Restriction\n Confinement\n Binding | Bind a bundle of sticks to a person as a type of restraint. 6310 | 飽食 | ほうしょく | Satiation | Eating One’s Fill\n Having Everything One Needs | You're bored but you keep eating. Maybe you're eating because you're bored. If you're bored all the time, eventually your main goal in life becomes satiation.\nIn modern Japanese, this word crops up most in 飽食の時代, which could be roughly translated as "the age of plenty". 飽食の時代 refers to the modern era in countries like Japan, which are characterized by an abundance of food, in contrast to the past, when food was scarce. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6311 | 飽和 | ほうわ | Saturation |  | If you're so bored of peace because all there IS is peace, it's called saturation of the peace market. You've pretty much been soaked through with peace and now you want a little chaotic excitement! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6317 | 静寂 | せいじゃく | Silence | Still\n Quiet | If you're lonely and quiet you'll be surrounded in silence.\n静寂 is pretty advanced, so you'll mostly only see it used in literature to suggest a sense of profound silence. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. 6324 | 呆れる | あきれる | To Be Amazed | To Be Shocked\n To Be Astonished | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock, so the verb version is to be shocked or to be amazed. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you were going to be shocked, you'd shout, "ACK (あき)!"
6325 | 飽きる | あきる | To Get Tired Of | To Lose Interest In | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bored, so the verb version is to get tired of or to lose interest in. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (あ)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.
6326 | 縫う | ぬう | To Sew | To Stitch | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sew, so the verb version is to sew or to stitch. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (ぬ). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!
6327 | 搾る | しぼる | To Squeeze | To Press\n To Milk | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means squeeze, so the verb version is to squeeze. The way that this word differs from 絞る is that 絞る means "to wring out" and 搾る means to squeeze or to juice fruits/vegetables or to milk a cow. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAfter the farmer milks the cow, she bows (しぼ) to the cow to say thank you for letting her squeeze out some fresh milk.
6328 | 逸れる | それる | To Stray | To Turn Away\n To Digress\n To Deviate | You already learned that 逸らす means "to turn away," so this means that but also to stray. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You've already learned this mnemonic but here's a quick review:\nIf you're the type of person who starts to stray easily, you'll end up saying sorry (それ) a lot. Even if you don't do it often, if you stray, say sorry!
6329 | 縛る | しばる | To Tie | To Bind | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You have to tie her up outside when you leave the house. It's sad, but at least it keeps her safe!
