6365 | 太鼓 | たいこ | Drum | Taiko | A fat drum is still a drum. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the taiko. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play!\nIf talking about taiko drums specifically, you can also say 和太鼓 to be clear that you're not talking about any old drums. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6367 | 胎児 | たいじ | Embryo | Fetus\n Foetus | A child that's still in a womb is a fetus. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6368 | 羅列 | られつ | Enumeration |  | Spread out a complete row of numbers in the right order and you have enumeration! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6369 | 酵素 | こうそ | Enzyme |  | The one element you need to ferment something is an enzyme. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6370 | 均衡 | きんこう | Equilibrium | Balance | Equal out your equilibrium and you'll have solid equilibrium. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6371 | 遍歴 | へんれき | Experiences | History\n Journey\n Travels | It’s a universal truth that we are the continuation of our experiences and history.\nThe original meaning of this word is journey, or travels, in the literal sense of the word, but nowadays you’d usually use it more abstractly, to talk about things like your past experiences, or perhaps your spiritual journey. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6372 | 発酵 | はっこう | Fermentation |  | When you ferment something it makes a departure from what it originally was and transforms during fermentation into something new. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6373 | 敢闘 | かんとう | Fight Bravely |  | If you're involved in a daring struggle you need to be strong and fight bravely. Even if you might get hurt, you should do your best! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6374 | 水槽 | すいそう | Fish Tank | Water Tank | A tank of water can be used as a fish tank or a water tank for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6375 | 萌芽 | ほうが | Germination | Sprout | A sprout that sprouts can thank germination for being able to sprout nice and big and strong. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo ga ga (が).
6376 | 憂い | うれい | Grief | Distress\n Sorrow | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means grief, so this word means grief or distress. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!
6377 | 腸 | ちょう | Guts | Bowels\n Intestines | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou like to use your hand drum when two dudes meet (つづみ). You drum and tap it and it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable which makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

Probably a lot of times. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes べん here.

6394 | 烏龍茶 | うーろんちゃ | Oolong Tea | Oolong | Imperial tea the color of a crow's feathers can only be the famous, delicious Oolong tea. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color. \n This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea.\nAnd make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

6407 | 乙 | おつ | Second | B\n Thanks\n Chic | If something is the latter, it can't be first, it has to be at least second. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be B.\nThis word is also used as slang for おつかれさま, which is where the thanks meaning comes from. It can also be used as a prefix to mean chic. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6408 | 烏賊 | いか | Squid | Cuttlefish | Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a crow moving under the water and it's a thief! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a squid. Or a cuttlefish? One or the other. \n The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nYou call the fish police to arrest that thieving squid, but it jumps into it's eagle car (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.

6410 | 拓哉 | たくや | Takuya |  | The cultivation of a question mark is something that only people called Takuya can do. I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (木下 拓哉 a.k.a. キノタク) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (寺田 拓哉). \n You learned both of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this name on your own.

6412 | 醸す | かもす | To Brew | To Cause\n To Give Rise To\n To Distill | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?
6413 | 癒す | いやす | To Heal Something | To Cure Something\n To Quench A Thirst | The kanji means healing and the verb version means to heal something, to cure something, and even to quench a thirst, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it.\nLike many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive, meaning it's being done to something. So you can use it when you cure an illness, heal a broken heart, or quench your thirst for adventure! \n To heal something it's sometimes necessary to do something いや (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.
6414 | 遮る | さえぎる | To Interrupt | To Intercept\n To Obstruct | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means intercept, so the verb version is to intercept or to interrupt. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.
6415 | 弔う | とむらう | To Mourn For | To Hold A Memorial Service For\n To Condole | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.
6416 | 鎮まる | しずまる | To Quiet Down | To Calm Down\n To Subside\n To Die Down | You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. 6431 | 拍子 | ひょうし | Beat | Rhythm\n Tempo\n The Moment | Break down a beat into all of its children and you’ve got more than just a single beat. You’ve got an assortment of beats, making a rhythm, and setting a tempo.\nAdditionally, this can also refer to the moment something happens. You’ll usually encounter this in the form of ~した拍子に. Have a look at our context sentences to see this usage in action! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of its kanji. However, 拍 uses its secondary reading, which you haven’t learned yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you:\nYou get the beat and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!

6439 | 暁 | あかつき | Dawn | Daybreak | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6440 | 老朽 | ろうきゅう | Decrepit | Overage\n Obsolete\n Too Old | Elderly people start to decay and they get all decrepit and gross. Like a corpse. Bleh. Good thing I'll never be too old. Ho ho ho! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6441 | 戯曲 | ぎきょく | Drama | Play | A play that uses lots of intense, emotional music is a drama. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6442 | 呆気 | あっけ | Dumbfounded | Taken Aback\n Astonished | The energy of being shocked fills your body and leaves you dumbfounded. You're so taken aback by this surge of shock that all you can do is stand still and let the energy go through you. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. Just remember that they're the two readings you didn't learn when you learned the kanji and you should be okay.
6443 | 地殻 | ちかく | Earth's Crust |  | The earth's shell is called the earth's crust. You should have learned that in earth science. And if you didn't, at least you know now! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6444 | 享受 | きょうじゅ | Enjoyment | Enjoy | The best thing to receive and accept into your life is enjoyment! Don't block it out, let it in! Be happy! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6445 | 晩酌 | ばんしゃく | Evening Drink | Drink With Dinner | At night you are served an evening drink. It's okay to have a strong drink with dinner every now and then. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6446 | 藩主 | はんしゅ | Feudal Lord | Daimyo | The master of a fiefdom is the feudal lord. We also call them Daimyo. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6447 | 藩 | はん | Fiefdom | Domain | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6448 | 瑞々しい | みずみずしい | Fresh | Young\n Juicy\n Lively\n Vibrant | You give your congratulations to someone a few times because they seem so fresh and vibrant. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away. \n The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.
6449 | 遊戯 | ゆうぎ | Game | Play\n Sport | You play and play all day! What do you play? A game! Or a sport! Which are technically games! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6450 | 棋譜 | きふ | Game Records |  | Write down the scores people get from taking all of their opponent's chess pieces and you'll be writing down game records. This is usually only used for old-fashioned Japanese games like go and shogi. Let's see who has the highest score at the end! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6451 | 系譜 | けいふ | Genealogy | Pedigree\n Family History | Your lineage and genealogy make up your genealogy, also known as your family history. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6452 | 紳士協定 | しんしきょうてい | Gentlemen's Agreement |  | Remember how you learned that 紳士 means "gentleman?" Well when two men determine that the best thing to do is cooperate they form a gentlemen's agreement. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6453 | 淑やか | しとやか | Graceful | Modest\n Gentle\n Polite | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you're trying to be graceful and polite you have to keep your secret sheep toe (しと) under wraps. You're kind of fond of your sheep toe (it's unique after all) but you're careful to hide it when you want to be all modest and gentle and all that.
6454 | 手錠 | てじょう | Handcuffs | Manacles | You want to lock this criminal's hands up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some handcuffs to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good. \n This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!
6455 | 縛り首 | しばりくび | Hanging | Death By Hanging | Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's neck then it's called hanging. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be death by hanging. \n This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!
6456 | 豪傑 | ごうけつ | Hero | Bold Person\n Daring Person\n Extraordinary Person | If you look back in history and see someone of exceptional greatness, they're probably a hero. Not just a normal person, but an extraordinary person like Hercules or Mae Jemison. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6457 | 呆け | ぼけ | Idiot | Fool | Someone who's shocked at everything all the time will seem like an idiot. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a fool lets himself be shocked by everything he sees. \n Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.
6458 | 不朽 | ふきゅう | Immortal | Everlasting\n Eternal | If it does not rot then it's immortal. It will live forever! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6459 | 媒介 | ばいかい | Intermediary |  | A mediator jammed in the middle of a group of angry people ends up becoming the intermediary between them. The mediator can't just ignore what's happening around them, and they have the tools to fix this. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6460 | 浄瑠璃 | じょうるり | Joruri | Ballad | If you cleanse a lapis lazuli rock until it goes glassy, you can use it in a joruri performance. In case you haven't heard of joruri, it's traditional Japanese chanted storytelling, sort of like a ballad, that's accompanied by shamisen music, and often puppets. \n You learned all these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6461 | 陪審 | ばいしん | Jury | Juror | Who is going to accompany the judge in deciding the results of the trial? The jury! They're the only other people besides the judge who can decide someone's fate in court. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6462 | 淑女 | しゅくじょ | Lady |  | A graceful woman is a proper, fancy lady. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6463 | 錠 | じょう | Lock | Padlock\n Tablet\n Pill | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6464 | 酌量 | しゃくりょう | Making Allowances | Taking Into Consideration | If you serve someone a certain quantity of understanding, you're making allowances. You're taking into consideration all extenuating circumstances. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6465 | 傑作 | けっさく | Masterpiece | Best Work | Something you make that oozes with greatness is your masterpiece. The very best work you'll ever make in your entire life. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6466 | 媒体 | ばいたい | Media | Medium | A mediator who works with someone who doesn't have a body has to use some kind of mortal media to record what they're saying. Print media? Sure. Electronic media? Alright? Ghost media? No! Humans can't read that stuff! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6467 | 濁流 | だくりゅう | Muddy Stream |  | A muddy stream is a muddy stream! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6468 | 楽譜 | がくふ | Musical Score | Sheet Music | A comforting score is a musical score. Music is really relaxing, and so is reading sheet music. You should try it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6469 | 辛勝 | しんしょう | Narrow Victory |  | A spicy win is a narrow victory. Kind of makes sense, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6470 | 管弦楽 | かんげんがく | Orchestral Music |  | You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some pipes to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have orchestral music. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6471 | 容赦 | ようしゃ | Pardon | Forgiveness\n Mercy\n Leniency | Form a pardon with your mouth and actually pardon someone. Show your forgiveness with the words "I'm sorry." \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6472 | 赦免 | しゃめん | Pardon | Amnesty | An excuse and a pardon is a pardon or amnesty. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6473 | 嘱託 | しょくたく | Part Time Employee | Temporary Employee | A company requests consignment work and you take it to become a part time employee. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6474 | 錠剤 | じょうざい | Pill | Lozenge\n Tablet | You take a dose of medicine but it gets locked in your throat because it's the kind of pill you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6475 | 汚濁 | おだく | Pollution | Contamination\n Corruption | If the air is muddy and dirty it's because there is too much pollution in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of contamination. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6476 | 肖像 | しょうぞう | Portrait |  | Art that's so good it resembles a statue of a person is actually a portrait. Really, it resembles the original person, but it looks like it's a portrait of a statue of a person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6477 | 酌 | しゃく | Pouring Alcohol | Pouring Sake\n Filling Someone's Glass | If you serve someone, you're pouring alcohol or pouring sake for them. You're filling someone's glass. \n You learned this reading with the kanji. Cheers!
6478 | 憤り | いきどおり | Resentment | Outrage\n Anger | This is the noun version of the kanji resent, so it means resentment. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou feel some pretty strong resentment toward your roommate because you had to touch their icky door (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an outrage!!!
6479 | 更迭 | こうてつ | Reshuffle | Dismissal | You renew and alternate certain positions or people, making this a reshuffle, or dismissal.\n更迭 generally highlights the dismissal of someone from a position for replacement. You’ll often see this used in political contexts, like the reshuffling of certain ministers or other offices in a cabinet or diet; or just in general for important positions in other fields as well. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6480 | 諦観 | ていかん | Resignation |  | When you give up and just try to enjoy the view, that's resignation. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 諦, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIn resignation, you throw all of your tater (てい) tots onto the ground. Look at the tater tots at your feet. Now they're lying scattered there, a symbol of your feelings of resignation.
6481 | 奔走 | ほんそう | Running About | Efforts\n Be Busy | If you bustle and run around all day from being busy you end up running about to get them all done. You'll be busy getting it all done, but your efforts won't be in vain! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6482 | 帆 | ほ | Sail |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you sail in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden hoe (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!
6483 | 帆走 | はんそう | Sailing |  | A sail runs boats along the sea by sailing! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6484 | 縫目 | ぬいめ | Seam | Stitch\n Suture | Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your eye is if you see a seam. If your eyes can't spot the stitches, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together. \n This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!
6485 | 譜面 | ふめん | Sheet Music | Musical Score | The score on a surface is your sheet music or musical score.\n譜面 often refers more specifically to a music score’s pages. For a more general term for musical score, go with 楽譜. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6486 | 殻 | から | Shell | Husk | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nShells are a good defense against からて chops. You can't get hurt if you have a nice strong shell to protect you from that からて-chopping weirdo who just showed up out of nowhere.
6487 | 絹糸 | けんし | Silk Thread |  | A silk thread is silk thread! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 絹 and 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWho only uses clothes made with silk thread? Ken's sheep (し)! Ken's sheep is very particular, and only wears clothes made from silk thread while it's waiting for its wool to grow back.
6488 | 金縛り | かなしばり | Sleep Paralysis | Temporary Paralysis | Remember how you learned that 縛る means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by gold means you're experiencing sleep paralysis, or temporary paralysis. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving. \n This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!
6489 | 脊椎 | せきつい | Spine | Spinal Column\n Backbone | Your stature's spine is really just your spine, when you think about it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6490 | 弦楽器 | げんがっき | Stringed Instrument |  | You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument" so adding a couple of bowstrings to it will make it a stringed instrument. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6491 | 感慨 | かんがい | Strong Feelings | Deep Emotion | Feelings that make you sigh out loud are really strong feelings. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6492 | 菅原 | すがはら | Sugahara | Sugawara | Sedge field is both Sugahara and Sugawara, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one!\nThis is a very old surname, said to have originated with Nara period scholar Hanishi-no-sukune (土師宿禰) who changed his name to Sugawara-no-furuhito (菅原古人). Historically, the name has been associated with scholars and writers, including prominent Heian period statesman, scholar, and poet Sugawara-no-michizane (菅原道真) and noblewoman, writer, and poet Sugawara-no-takasue-no-musume (菅原孝標女), also known more simply as Lady Sarashina in the English speaking world. \n The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular わら reading for 原, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSugawara-san went to war a (わら) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his sedge fields.
6493 | 硫酸 | りゅうさん | Sulfuric Acid | Sulphuric Acid | Mix sulfur and acid and you'll get sulfuric acid! That's how science works! How simple! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6494 | 扶養 | ふよう | Support | Maintenance\n Provide For | Aid and foster someone to show your support for them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6495 | 執行猶予 | しっこうゆうよ | Suspended Sentence |  | Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well the jury has a tenacious grip on the idea of trying to let you go and they request an extension, so they give you a suspended sentence until they can figure out how to do it properly. You might be set free! E... eventually. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6496 | 起訴猶予 | きそゆうよ | Suspension Of Indictment |  | Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you wake up ready to sue people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a suspension of indictment on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6497 | 窃盗 | せっとう | Theft | Stealing | You decided to steal... and then you steal again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for theft. Stealing is wrong, you should have known better! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6498 | 呆れ返る | あきれかえる | To Be Utterly Amazed | To Be Stunned\n To Be Amazed | This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means to be utterly amazed! \n This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.
6499 | 朽ちる | くちる | To Decay | To Die Out | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decay, so the verb version is to decay or to die out. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.
6500 | 凌ぐ | しのぐ | To Endure | To Keep Out\n To Stave Off\n To Surpass\n To Outrank\n To Eclipse | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to keep out. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
6501 | 濁す | にごす | To Make Muddy | To Make Cloudy\n To Speak Ambiguously\n To Speak Vaguely | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means muddy, so the verb version is to make muddy or to make cloudy. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.
6502 | 酌む | くむ | To Serve | To Scoop\n To Take Into Consideration | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means serve, and the verb version is to scoop or to serve.\nIt can also mean to take into consideration someone else's feelings or opinions. Kind of like you're scooping up the person's feelings and considering them! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat do you decide to scoop out for your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't serve anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.
6503 | 飽くまでも | あくまでも | To The Last | To The End | I'm so bored. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so bored, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored to the last or to the end. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!
6504 | 戯れる | たわむれる | To Toy With | To Play With\n To Flirt\n To Kid | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play, so the verb version is to play with or to toy with someone. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nEveryone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel and your towel moves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!
6505 | 勿体ない | もったいない | Wasteful | A Waste\n Too Good | You must not use your body for anything wasteful, because that would be a waste. You're too good for that!\nThis word is used in all kinds of situations where there's a feeling that something is going to waste, including food, money, time, talent, and opportunities. You can also use it to say that someone is too good for a job, or even for another person. While it's usually written in kana, you'll see it in kanji too. \n This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji, except that もち becomes もっ.
6506 | 飽き | あき | Weariness | Tiresomeness | If you're bored all the time it makes you tired and the weariness you feel will show on your face. \n Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!
6507 | 奔放 | ほんぽう | Wild | Uninhibited\n Extravagant\n Rampant | Some day you'll run around, released from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running wild. All your actions will be completely uninhibited when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.
6508 | 環礁 | かんしょう | Atoll | Circular Coral Reef | A reef in the shape of a loop is an atoll. If you don't know what that is, it's a circular coral reef. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6509 | 一遍に | いっぺんに | At Once | At One Time | Remember how you learned that 一遍 means "once?" Well if you add に and make it an adverb, it becomes at once. \n This has the same reading you learned with 一遍 so you should be able to remember this too!
6510 | 慶事 | けいじ | Auspicious Event | Happy Event | If you can congratulate someone for an occurrence in their life, it must be an auspicious event. You'll remember this happy event for a long, long time. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6511 | 梓川 | あずさがわ | Azusa River | Azusagawa | Japanese birch river is Azusa River or simply Azusagawa. Azusagawa is both the Japanese name for the Azusa River, and a Japanese family name. \n You learned both of these readings with the kanji. You just need to remember that rendaku turns かわ into がわ.
6512 | 弁慶 | べんけい | Benkei | Strong Person | You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of dialects because they have to be a really strong person, just like Mr. Benkei was. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person — a Benkei — to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are!\n弁慶 is the name of a Japanese historical figure who was really strong, so Benkei is the Japanese equivalent of Hercules or Achilles in Western languages. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6513 | 憂き目 | うきめ | Bitterness | Misery\n Hardship\n Distress | Grief shows in your eyes by making them look like you've gone through a lot of bitterness and hardship. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too.\nYou’ll see this word most often in 憂き目を見る and 憂き目に合う, which both mean “to experience misery.” \n This word uses one of the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You haven’t learned this kun’yomi reading for 憂, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nWhy the bitterness in your eyes? You visited a famed uni (う) restaurant, only to find it closed and locked. Where is the key (き)? Your 目s scream of the uni missed. In a sea of misery, a missed uni is the hardest to swallow.
6514 | 大胆 | だいたん | Bold | Daring\n Audacious | If you have really big guts you're a super bold and daring person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6515 | 岬 | みさき | Cape |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6516 | 鋳造 | ちゅうぞう | Casting | Founding\n Minting | If you want to create a cast you need to learn casting first. Then you can make lots of neat art, crafts, and counterfeit money. Wait, no, don't do that last one. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned both of them, so you should already know this word!
6517 | 変遷 | へんせん | Change | Transition | Change and transition mean change and transition! Nifty.\n変遷 refers to historical or long-term changes. It’s often used when discussing the evolution or progression of entities over long periods. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6518 | 慶祝 | けいしゅく | Congratulation | Celebration | You congratulate someone and celebrate by saying congratulations and having a celebration! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6519 | 慶弔 | けいちょう | Congratulations And Condolences |  | If you are saying congratulations and also giving your condolences then they are congratulations and condolences. Pretty easy, right? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6520 | 危篤 | きとく | Critical Condition | Critical Illness\n On The Verge Of Death | If someone is so dangerous that they deliberately hurt you, you're going to end up in critical condition. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're on the verge of death. Hold on, kiddo. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6521 | 遮断機 | しゃだんき | Crossing Gate | Railway Crossing Gate\n Circuit Breaker | Remember how 遮断 means "isolation?" Well the machine that isolates you from a train is a crossing gate. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

6523 | 回忌 | かいき | Death Anniversary | Anniversary Of Death | The times when you are in mourning each year are for a loved one's death anniversary. They come around again every year. It's important you remember your loved ones at this time.\nYou'll often see this used with a number before 回忌, indicating a certain anniversary. However, you actually start counting your 回忌 starting with the first period of mourning around the time of the person's death, which would be the 一回忌. Hence, 二回忌 would usually be translated as "first death anniversary", 三回忌 as "second death anniversary", and so on. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6524 | 詠嘆 | えいたん | Deep Feeling | Exclamation\n Marvel | If you compose something with a sigh, it's because you're experiencing a deep feeling. You might express this deep feeling with an exclamation, as you marvel at the wonders of the world.\nThis word can be used for a range of deep feelings, good or bad, and can also be used for the expression of those feelings, so you'll notice that the English translation varies quite a bit depending on the context. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read it on your own.

6549 | 峠 | とうげ | Mountain Pass | The Worst | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.\n峠 refers to a mountain pass, and often specifically the highest point of a mountain pass, where it passes between two mountains. When used figuratively, it means the worst, as in the toughest moment of a specific event, like the height of a health crisis or the hottest day of a heatwave. \n You climb along the mountain pass and see adorable little Tokyo geckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!

6558 | 早乙女 | さおとめ | Rice Planting Girl | Saotome | A young woman who is planting rice from early morning into the latter evenings is a rice planting girl. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice.\nThis is also a common family name, and on rare occasion, a given name as well. Some well-known people with this name include historical fiction writer Saotome Mitsugu (早乙女 貢), former pro-wrestler, model, and idol Saotome Miku (早乙女 未来), and stage and screen actor Saotome Taichi (早乙女 太一). \n This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them.\nTake the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.
6559 | 浪人 | ろうにん | Ronin | Masterless Samurai | A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong.\nIn modern times, ronin refers to those who failed their university entrance exams, waiting until for another chance to take the test again. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

I bet they'd find some skillful ways to do it. \n This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji.

And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.
6564 | 吟味 | ぎんみ | Scrutiny | Testing\n Careful Investigation | If you tasted the air at a recital the flavor would taste like scrutiny. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. 6567 | 萌え | もえ | Sprouting | Budding\n Crush\n Infatuation\n Moe | What is a sprout doing? It's sprouting and budding.
