6570 | 禁忌 | きんき | Taboo |  | Prohibition of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in mourning after is a taboo. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6571 | 詠む | よむ | To Compose | To Recite | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo:\nOne string to rule them all,\nOne string to find them,\nOne string to- hey wait a minute...
6572 | 侮る | あなどる | To Despise | To Disdain\n To Make Light Of | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThink of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"
6573 | 堪える | こらえる | To Endure | To Bear | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to bear. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji!
6574 | 凹む | へこむ | To Get Dented | To Feel Down | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concave, but "to concave" doesn't really make sense. So the verb version is to get dented. Or, more figuratively, to feel down.\n凹む is used in a physical sense when the surface of something is dented, collapsed inward, or features some kind of hollow depression. That can be anything from a dented car to even a fit, slimmed-down belly (sort of like the flab is "dented" in).\nIn a figurative sense, 凹む is used when you're feeling down. Almost like your heart is dented, you know? We all have those days. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou feel like you've started to get dented when you have a head cold (へこ). Like all that sniffling makes dents on the sides of your nose. It's easy to feel down when you have a head cold too, but try not to let it get to you.
6575 | 蔑む | さげすむ | To Scorn | To Despise | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scorn, so the verb version is to scorn and to despise. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (さげす) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!
6576 | 紡ぐ | つむぐ | To Spin | To Make Yarn | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nBefore you start to spin you have to let out two moos (つむ) as tribute to the cows that gave you their fur to make yarn out of. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!
6577 | 凸凹 | でこぼこ | Uneven | Rough\n Rugged | Remember how you learned that 凹凸 means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word! \n However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven it ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.
6578 | 普遍的 | ふへんてき | Universal | Omnipresent\n Ubiquitous | Remember how 普遍 means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6579 | 忌まわしい | いまわしい | Unpleasant | Disgusting\n Inauspicious | This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYour mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.
6580 | 稚拙 | ちせつ | Unskillful | Childish | Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6581 | 流浪 | るろう | Vagrancy | Wandering\n Nomadism | Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to vagrancy. You'll love wandering so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you haven't learned this particular reading for 流, here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhen you think about it, vagrancy is kind of a loophole (る). No one ever knows where you could be, making it hard to track you down.
6582 | 浮浪者 | ふろうしゃ | Vagrant | Bum | Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.) \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAll the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!
6583 | 甚だ | はなはだ | Very | Very Much\n Greatly | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nIf you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like,  "Hannah ha ha ha (はなは)."
6584 | 放浪 | ほうろう | Wandering | Roaming | Release your worldly ties and wander the world. You'll get used to wandering and you'll spend the rest of your days roaming the world until you die. It's quite the life! But you can only do it if you let go of everything else. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6585 | 戦禍 | せんか | War Damages | Ravages Of War | One of the most evil things about war are the war damages that happen during it. Whole countrysides, cities, and lots of people can die. So I'd say the ravages of war are the most evil thing about war. Period. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6586 | 浪費 | ろうひ | Waste | Extravagance | If you wander around doing nothing at your own expense it will be a huge waste of money. It's not like you were doing or buying anything important, you were just wandering around, after all. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6587 | 惜しまない | おしまない | Without Sparing | Spare No | Remember how you learned that 惜しむ means "to be sparing?" Well if you make that negative with ない, then you're doing it without sparing anything instead. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this already too!
6588 | 崇拝 | すうはい | Worship | Adoration\n Admiration\n Cult | Worship in the morning, worship in the night, worship all day! Worship that WaniKani poster. Do it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6589 | 某国 | ぼうこく | A Certain Country |  | A certain country is a certain country! \n This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6590 | 某氏 | ぼうし | A Certain Person |  | A certain family name belongs to a certain person. \n This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6591 | 某所 | ぼうしょ | A Certain Place |  | No surprises here. A certain place is a certain place. \n This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6592 | 約款 | やっかん | Agreement | Stipulation\n Article\n Clause | An article you write a promise on is an agreement. Make sure you read them thoroughly before you sign them! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6593 | 解剖学 | かいぼうがく | Anatomy |  | Remember how you learned that 解剖 means "autopsy?" Well you have to learn about anatomy before you're going to be allowed to perform an autopsy or dissect anything. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6594 | 匿名 | とくめい | Anonymity | Pseudonym | Hide your name for anonymity. There's lots of that here on the internet. In fact, you're probably using a pseudonym right now, aren't you? Yeah, you are. You can't hide THAT from me at least... uh... Ssssteve? \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6595 | 定款 | ていかん | Articles Of Incorporation | Company Statute\n Articles Of The Company Laws | Articles that determine the rules and regulations of your job or a company are called articles of incorporation. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6596 | 蛮行 | ばんこう | Barbarism | Brutality | Barbarians go around and commit acts of barbarism! What else would they do? They're barbarians! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6597 | 花婿 | はなむこ | Bridegroom | Groom | A groom gets a flower on his lapel and he's finally a real bridegroom! Before that he was just waiting to be one. The flower makes it for real. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6598 | 煩忙 | はんぼう | Busy |  | If you annoy someone who's busy they're still going to be busy. You annoying them can't change them. Though now they're probably busy AND annoyed. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6599 | 某〜 | ぼう | Certain | One | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6600 | 吸い殻 | すいがら | Cigarette Butt | Tobacco Ashes | This is a combination of the words 吸う meaning "to smoke" and 殻 meaning "shell" or "husk." The husk left over after you're done smoking is the cigarette butt. Or tobacco ashes if you just have a pile of them. \n This is a combination of the words 吸う and 殻. Change the う to い and don't forget the rendaku, and you should be able to remember this reading too!
6601 | 煩雑 | はんざつ | Complex | Intricate\n Complicated | If you think someone is trying to annoy you at random, just pay attention and you'll see that they have a complex annoying pattern they're using on you. Once you figure that out, it won't annoy you as much and you'll win! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6602 | 矯正 | きょうせい | Correction | Remedy | Correct something you thought was already correct by making a correction. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6603 | 逝去 | せいきょ | Death |  | Die in the past and it was death that you suffered from! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6604 | 感慨無量 | かんがいむりょう | Deep Emotion | Deeply Moved\n Filled With Emotion | Remember how you learned that 感慨 means "strong feelings?" Well feelings so strong that you can not even think of a quantity to measure or explain how much you feel. These are really deep emotions. They fill you all the way up and you can't help but tell everyone about them. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6605 | 感慨深い | かんがいぶかい | Deeply Moving | Deeply Emotive | This is a combination of the words 感慨 meaning "strong feelings" and 深い meaning "deep." Something that makes you feel strong emotions deep down inside is deeply moving. \n This is a combination of a jukugo word and an i-adjective. You've learned both of them so just mash them together, with the rendaku making ふ to ぶ, and you've got the reading down pat!
6606 | 妄想 | もうそう | Delusion | Fantasy | Reckless things you imagine are just delusions. You shouldn't dwell on them, they probably aren't going to happen. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6607 | 下痢 | げり | Diarrhea | Diarrhoea | Diarrhea that goes below you is still diarrhea, unfortunately. I hope it's going down into a toilet... \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6608 | 殉職 | じゅんしょく | Die At One's Post | Die On Duty\n Die At Your Post | If you want to become a martyr during your employment you need to die at your post. I don't know why you'd WANT to do that though. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6609 | 罷免 | ひめん | Dismissal | Discharge | You quit your job but with a pretty good excuse to back it up, so you get a dismissal instead of just quitting outright. If you're in the army and you do this it's called a discharge. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6610 | 赤痢 | せきり | Dysentery |  | Red diarrhea means there's blood in there and you're probably dying of dysentery! Have you been playing too much Oregon Trail? Either way, get to a doctor! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 赤 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou know what dysentery isn't? Sexy (せき). That's right. If anyone tries to seduce you by saying they have dysentery and they'd like to share it with you, tell them how NOT sexy that is and get the heck away from them!
6611 | 申し申し | もうしもうし | Excuse Me | Hello | It's kind of like you're saying say say, and it’s used in classical Japanese to get someone’s attention, so this is excuse me or hello.\nYou would generally encounter 申し申し in dialogues set in older times, unlike its modern, shortened version もしもし, which is used for telephone greetings (and almost always written in kana). \n This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.
6612 | 漸く | ようやく | Finally | At Last\n Narrowly\n Hardly | If you do something gradually for a long time, when you finish it gives you that FINALLY feeling. It took so long and you worked so hard and you're finally done! \n The reading for this word is an exception, but you learned it with the kanji. Congratulations!
6613 | 升 | ます | Grid | Box\n Measuring Container\n Measure | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6614 | 謹賀新年 | きんがしんねん | Happy New Year | Happy New Year! | Remember how you learned that 新年 means "New Year?" Well when you say humble congratulations on the new year, you're really saying Happy New Year! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6615 | 首班 | しゅはん | Head | Leader\n Prime Minister | The neck of the squad is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the head or leader of a group.\nThis is a very formal word to refer to someone in a top role, especially a Prime Minister (aka the head of the cabinet). \n This is a jukugo word so it uses the on'yomi readings. You learned the on'yomi for 首 in the words 部首 and 首位, and you learned the on'yomi for 班 with the kanji. Go you!
6616 | 隠匿 | いんとく | Hide | Concealment\n Conceal | Hide and hide make hide! Lots of hiding going on around here. I think... I can't find anyone so I can only assume. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6617 | 婿 | むこ | Husband | Groom\n Son In Law | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6618 | 弾劾 | だんがい | Impeachment | Accusation\n Censure\n Denunciation | The final bullet of censure is impeachment. You've already been publicly humiliated and now you're being impeached because of it. Yikes. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6619 | 藍 | あい | Indigo |  | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should know this too!
6620 | 湖畔 | こはん | Lake Shore |  | The lake shore is the lake shore! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6621 | 領袖 | りょうしゅう | Leader | Boss\n Chief | Someone who has territory under their sleeve is the leader. They're the boss of all this territory because they say so, and because they shoved it all into their big sleeves.\nThis is a very formal word often used in political contexts, particularly when referring to the leader of a faction or political party. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 袖, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:\nIt's always hard to fill a leaders' shoes (しゅう). Leaders have big responsibilities and power. Just big shoes to fill! Picture these big ol' leader's shoes, like in a literal sense. Not only do they have big responsibilities, leaders have big shoes as well.
6622 | 長唄 | ながうた | Long Shamisen Song | Epic Shamisen Song\n Nagauta | A long shamisen song is a long shamisen song! They're also called nagauta, and they're usually pretty epic too. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6623 | 廉価 | れんか | Low Price | Cheap | Buy something at bargain value and you'll be getting it at a really low price. Good for you! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6624 | 帆柱 | ほばしら | Mast |  | The pillar the sail is attached to is called a mast. Without it the sail wouldn't do it's job and your sailboat wouldn't move at all. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned these readings with other vocabulary, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6625 | 渓流 | けいりゅう | Mountain Stream |  | A stream that runs through a valley is a mountain stream. Valleys happen in between mountains, so just picture the river running through the middle of them in your head. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6626 | 煩い | うるさい | Noisy | Loud\n Annoying | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of annoy? It's annoying! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nWhat's noisy? That uni's rude sighing (うるさい). It just keeps sighing loudly over and over. It's sooo annoying!
6627 | 管弦楽団 | かんげんがくだん | Orchestra |  | Remember how you learned that 管弦楽 means "orchestral music?" Well the group that plays that music is an orchestra. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6628 | 桟橋 | さんばし | Pier | Wharf | Add a bridge to a jetty and you'll have a pretty cool pier. Put a ferris wheel on there and make some money! \n This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 桟 and the kun'yomi reading for 橋. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!
6629 | 戯れ | たわむれ | Play Flirt | Joke\n Flirt | Remember how 戯れる can mean "to play" or "to flirt?" Well this is when you play flirt! Or just make a joke. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
6630 | 冥王星 | めいおうせい | Pluto |  | The underworld king star is the dwarf planet Pluto. Since Pluto was the ruler of the underworld in classical mythology, this makes a lot of sense! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6631 | 冥土 | めいど | Realm Of The Dead | Underworld\n Hades | The underworld dirt is another word for the realm of the dead, underworld, or Hades. Like the word 冥界 (also in this level), it's rather poetic, and mostly used in written contexts involving spirituality, Buddhism, and ancient mythologies.\nThere are a few set expressions that only use 冥土, though. One example is 冥土の土産, "a souvenir to take to the realm of the dead". It refers to something abstract that is so valuable, it's worth taking to the underworld, such as the solution to a great mystery, or a happy memory.\nAnother expression is 冥土の旅支度, which means "preparations for the journey to the realm of the dead", and can refer to the preparation of the deceased before a funeral, as wells as certain preparations made by Buddhists while they're still alive.\nYou'll also see this word written as 冥途 sometimes. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6632 | 容赦なく | ようしゃなく | Relentlessly | Mercilessly | Remember how 容赦 can mean "forgiveness" and "mercy?" Well add なく (basically making it NOT that), and it becomes relentlessly and mercilessly. The exact opposite of what it was before! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji (with なく attached to it). You should be able to read this on your own.
6633 | 帆船 | はんせん | Sailboat | Sailing Boat\n Sailing Ship | A sail boat is a sailboat! \n This word uses the on'yomi readings. You know them!
6634 | 野蛮 | やばん | Savage | Uncivilized\n Uncivilised | Barbarians who live in fields, not even in huts or houses or anything, are called savage by people who DO live in huts and houses. They think if you live out in a field you're really uncivilized. But that's all a matter of opinion, I guess. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6635 | 醜聞 | しゅうぶん | Scandal |  | What do you hear that is really ugly? A scandal. Scandals are the ugliest topics for gossip. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6636 | 海藻 | かいそう | Seaweed |  | Sea seaweed is still seaweed! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6637 | 藻 | も | Seaweed | Duckweed\n Algae | The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. \n Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nSwim into a floating group of seaweed and shivers will go up your spine. It feels so gross and slimy that you can't help but moan (も) out in distress.
6638 | 分泌 | ぶんぴつ | Secretion | Discharge | Part of you is starting to secrete some kind of secretion. It's kinda gross, so maybe you should go to the doctor to check if it's normal. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6639 | 醜態 | しゅうたい | Shameful Sight | Disgraceful Behavior | Something with an ugly appearance is a shameful sight, or disgraceful behavior. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6640 | 寡黙 | かもく | Silent | Shy | Tell a widow to shut up and she'll be silent for the rest of the day. That wasn't very nice. You're a mean person. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6641 | 某 | なにがし | Someone Or Other | You-Know-Who\n Something | The kanji means certain, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like someone or other, you-know-who, or something. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason. \n This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou bump into someone or other, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her nanny gashes (なにがし) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor you-know-who, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.
6642 | 唄 | うた | Song | Shamisen Song | A shamisen song is a shamisen song, yes. But did you know it's also... a song?! Oh, you did? Well okay then. \n This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
6643 | 娘婿 | むすめむこ | Son In Law |  | Your daughter's groom will become your son in law. He's a great guy! Congratulations! \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6644 | 南蛮 | なんばん | Southern Barbarians | Nanban\n South Sea Countries | Southern barbarians are called Southern barbarians! While it originally referred to the people of Southeast Asia, the term Nanban was used to refer to Western traders who began arriving in Japan in the 1500s. There's yummy food named after them too! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6645 | 升目 | ますめ | Square | Box\n Measure | Measure that shape on the paper with your eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph. \n The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6646 | 硫黄 | いおう | Sulfur | Sulphur | Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow. \n The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nThis sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (いおう)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.
6647 | 悪戯 | いたずら | Tease | Prank\n Lewd Behavior | A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it! Depending on the context this can sometimes have a far more negative connotation and mean lewd behavior. \n The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:\nIf you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (いたずら), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.
6648 | 倹約 | けんやく | Thrift | Economy\n Frugality | I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6649 | 慕う | したう | To Adore | To Miss\n To Yearn For | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use to adore too. \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nYou realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (した)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!
6650 | 濁る | にごる | To Become Muddy | To Become Impure\n To Become Cloudy | You already know that 濁す means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy. \n This has the same reading as 濁す. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.
6651 | 詠う | うたう | To Compose | To Recite\n To Sing | The verb form of compose is to compose. This particular verb is usually used in relation to poetry, and can also mean to recite or to sing, though more in the sense of singing someone's praises than singing a song. \n This word shares the same origin as 歌う and 唄う, and they share the same readings as well.
6652 | 酌み交わす | くみかわす | To Drink Together | To Pour Each Other A Drink | 酌む means "to serve" and the kanji 交 means mix. What happens if you serve and mix together? You're going to pour each other a drink because you plan  to drink together. \n You haven't learned this reading for 交 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nAll the bars are closed so you and your friends are going to drink together in your car (か). You set up a little bar in the back of your car and settle down for some drinks. It's cramped but cosy.
6653 | 拷問 | ごうもん | Torture | The Rack\n Third Degree | Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6654 | 唄う | うたう | To Sing | To Recite\n To Chant | This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing. \n Remember how 歌う means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!
6655 | 坑道 | こうどう | Tunnel | Mine\n Shaft | A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6656 | 醜悪 | しゅうあく | Ugly | Mean\n Offensive | Ugly, bad things are ugly, mean, and offensive. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6657 | 醜い | みにくい | Ugly | Unattractive\n Unsightly\n Unseemly | This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still! \n Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:\nThe most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (みにく). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.
6658 | 冥界 | めいかい | Underworld | Hades\n Realm Of The Dead | The underworld world is the underworld, Hades, or the realm of the dead.\nThis word is a bit poetic, and mostly used in writing, particularly in contexts like Buddhism, spirituality, and ancient mythologies. It's usually interchangeable with 冥土 (which is also in this level), but 冥土 is used more in certain set expressions, which we'll mention in the page for that word! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned those with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
6659 | 泌尿器 | ひにょうき | Urinary Organs |  | The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6660 | 渓谷 | けいこく | Valley | Ravine\n Canyon | A valley in a valley is still a valley! \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6661 | 寡婦 | かふ | Widow |  | A widowed wife is a widow. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
6662 | 思慕 | しぼ | Yearning | Deep Affection | If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone. \n This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
